text: The next item is the debate on the recommendation for second reading by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down measures concerning access to an open Internet and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users' rights in the field of electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 2002/22/EC on universal service and users' rights in the field of electronic communications networks and services. Regulation (EC) No 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile communications networks within the Union (10788/2/2015 - C8-0294/2015 - 2013/0309(COD)) (Rapporteur: Pilar del Castillo Vera) (A8-0300/2015).

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Vice-President Ansip, ladies and gentlemen, the procedure on the Regulation of the Single Market in Telecommunications is coming to an end. After an intense period of negotiation with the Council, in which it must be said that Parliament has shown great determination, we have achieved the objectives we had set ourselves from the outset. First, the abolition of the oversteer that consumers face when accessing the internet or trying to communicate over the phone when they are outside their country. Secondly, we have managed to establish the necessary guarantees so that everything , I insist: everything – internet traffic is treated equally and that access to an open internet is done on an equal footing, thus ensuring neutral network behaviour. These two objectives are fully reflected in the agreement with the Council on 30 June and endorsed by most of the political groups that participated in the negotiations. As regards roaming costs, they will be abolished from June 2017 and, in addition, from April 2016 there will be a very significant reduction in costs, both in data and voice. It must be said that the disappearance of roaming costs is a long-awaited measure. Expected by all: by individuals, by small and medium-sized enterprises, start-ups and organisations of all kinds, which today can see in a tangible way that the European Union, the European project, has a clear added value. We have undoubtedly taken another step in removing internal barriers, in the free movement, in addition to people, towards a single digital market. As regards equality in internet access, I have to say that, with this agreement, Europe will be the only region in the world to ensure, by law, an open internet and net neutrality. The principle of net neutrality will be applied directly in all 28 Member States and will ensure that all traffic is treated equally, without discrimination, without restrictions or interference. The agreement reached further ensures that there will be no dual-track internet, prohibiting priority by payment one way or another. This is also, in my view, extraordinarily important. For this reason, where it is necessary to intervene in traffic management, such intervention may only occur where it is linked to the solution of temporary or exceptional congestion problems, to protect users from cyberattacks or in cases where there is an obligation, a resolution that so requires; and, moreover, when such management occurs—where necessary—it will have to be transparent, non-discriminatory and proportionate. I would like to mention the various measures that have also been taken in relation to consumer protection in respect of all these provisions to which I mentioned. Finally, I would like to express my appreciation to the presidency of Latvia, during which the agreement was negotiated and closed, and to the current presidency of Luxembourg, which is now managing it; commission, which, for its part, has long made great efforts to achieve the objectives now achieved. Let me make a special mention to Commissioner Reding, Commissioner Kroes, Commissioner Oettinger and Vice-President Ansip, who in different times have helped make this moment a reality. I conclude by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs, and I do not forget the rapporteurs who are not here today, but who had those responsibilities in the last legislature. Everyone's effort has made it possible for us today to ensure an open, non-discriminatory internet and to take a step towards a connected Europe and a single market without digital customs.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone, and particularly rapporteur Pilar del Castillo Vera, for their hard work on this file. We have come a long way since the Commission proposed this legislation just over two years ago. It has been a bumpy road. I would like to thank this House, as it has only been possible to hold today’s landmark vote because of the European Parliament. In April 2014, Parliament showed that it can act decisively and quickly when the interests of the people, the open internet and the single market are at stake. Today, I invite Parliament to adopt this text on two key pillars in plenary so that consumers and businesses can benefit as soon as possible from common net neutrality rules and the abolition of roaming surcharges. They have been waiting a long time for this. Adopting the Telecommunications Single Market (TSM) Regulation will be a major achievement for the Digital Single Market. It will show Europeans that the Union can deliver tangible results. Failure, of course, would have an opposite and demoralising effect. Roaming surcharges will be significantly reduced from April next year and finally banned from 15 June 2017, subject to a fair use policy. This is a historic achievement, and we could not have done it without the leading role of Parliament. Many governments were initially reluctant until they heard the voice of their people and of the people’s representatives here. The package is faithful to Parliament’s first reading position: there is a clear end—date for roaming surcharges and clear steps to be taken beforehand. There is still a lot to do for the abolition of surcharges to be sustainable throughout the European Union. The wholesale roaming market has to be reviewed. The fair—use policies and sustainability mechanisms need to be defined. The Commission has started to work on this. We are committed to making the abolition of roaming surcharges a reality. There is no justification for any further delay. Adopting the TSM Regulation will enshrine binding net neutrality rules into EU law for the first time ever. The regulation will create the individual and enforceable right for end users to access and distribute internet content and services of their choice. The net neutrality provisions also lay down rules on non-discriminatory traffic management and on end—users’ free choice of content, applications and services. These provisions cannot be circumvented through commercial agreements and practices. Common rules on net neutrality mean that internet access providers cannot pick winners or losers on the internet or decide which content and services are available. They mean that the freedom of Europeans to access or distribute internet content will not depend on the country where they are resident. This will increase consumer choice and competition, and will strengthen the Digital Single Market. National authorities will be required to monitor market developments. They will have the powers and the obligation to assess traffic management and commercial practices and agreements, including pricing practices like zero rating. Since this is a regulation, the rules are directly enforceable before national courts. The rules also give the necessary certainty for internet access providers and providers of content and applications to offer specialised services with quality requirements. Adopting the TSM Regulation will help to sustain continued network and service innovation. That will benefit both European businesses and consumers. Let me turn now to radio spectrum. I welcomed Parliament’s efforts to include the spectrum provisions in our original TSM proposal. These could not be retained because of the lack of Council support at that stage. But the need to solve these issues remains, and I rely on Parliament’s continuous support in the future. We have already started working on our telecoms review and look forward to close cooperation with this House. We plan to present an ambitious proposal by the middle of next year. I therefore welcome the call for priority to be given to a coordinated framework for spectrum assignment to boost long-term infrastructure investments. Parliament now has the deal in its hands. It is a good deal, for Europe and Europeans. I urge Members to vote for it.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the – Dear President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. What is the European Union? Well, we all understand that it is meant that people, goods, services and money can move freely across the borders of the European Union. What is the reality so far? These principles did not always work, but especially when we travel abroad using our phones, we know that we pay dearly for so-called roaming. This house, the European Parliament, has argued for years that we need to abolish roaming charges. The industry has often stood in front of it. What we have achieved now is a lovely thing: it has finally been agreed between Parliament and the Member States of the Council of Europe that we will actually eliminate these roaming charges with June 2017. Consumers will benefit. But, importantly, there is no way that consumers get it and entrepreneurs lose. Entrepreneurs also benefit. Firstly, here is that we clearly and clearly anticipate the principles of net neutrality so as to be a safe investment environment for service providers. Secondly, by 2017, we will adjust wholesale prices. (Just a question, chairman, shall I repeat everything that I said?) In the European Union, we want free borders, but these borders have not always been free, especially when we travel abroad by telephone, we pay dearly for so-called roaming. Parliament has insisted for years that these roaming charges should be abolished. There has not always been a consensus with the Council to achieve this, but finally, in a number of years, we have achieved this, and roaming charges will be abolished in June 2017. Consumers will benefit from travelling abroad. There will be no need to pay anymore. But importantly, not only will consumers benefit, but businesses will also benefit. Companies will benefit, first of all, in such a way that we clearly anticipate what is the principle of net neutrality. This means a safe environment for service providers to invest in the future. Secondly, and it is very important that by June 2017 wholesale prices will also be regulated so that companies do not suffer losses in any country when providing this service to roaming customers, and local tariffs should not be raised to cover the arrivals of tourists. So this is really the case where the consumer wins, the companies win, the Council wins and Parliament wins. Thanks everyone for the attention!

name: Patrizia Toia
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say that, as a representative of the Group of the Party of European Socialists and Democrats, I have fought very hard, I have negotiated very hard, with the support of my group, to achieve ambitious results. That was our objective, as ambitious was the first reading, and I remember our shadow rapporteur, Catherine Trautmann, doing an excellent job.  I believe that the result we have achieved is very good. I think that we have built a step forward in integrating the telecommunications markets towards a single market with two points of reference: the interests of the citizen and the ability to innovate industries, businesses, their innovation and the competitiveness of the European system in this strategic sector.  As far as the citizen is concerned, I would just like to say one result, which our group has been pursuing for years and years: that of reducing roaming costs. Commissioner, Vice-President, I am addressing you: we will achieve the objective of having the fall in roaming come into force in 2017 if, however, the Commission immediately gets down to work on a review of the wholesale market. We will not accept excuses from this point of view. Do not say on the threshold of 2017 that the market review has not ended, because this is not possible. We know from now on that it is a pre-season, we work to overcome it. Secondly, net neutrality. Well, here we have reconciled the interests of the citizens and the need to grow the system. I want to make it clear – and it has already been said – that there is no legislative system in Europe that affirms these principles. Many people tell us about the United States, where there is a more advanced address. I would like to remind colleagues who always quote us from the United States that there is a decision there by a federal commission, not a legislative body, and therefore a decision that can always change. In Europe, on the other hand, we only have two states, the Netherlands and Slovenia, which have advanced legislation, the other 26 do not.  There are important legislative principles that affirm net neutrality. It is not a definition, but all the elements are there: no to discrimination, etc. But here too our laws are good and must be implemented. I would ask you to ensure that the national authorities take action to monitor, to monitor this system, to ensure that states have sanctions, otherwise our good principles will not be implemented.  There is one point for us that will have to be taken up again, which is that of zero rating, on which we will already be focusing the Commission. For the rest – spectre and other elements that you mentioned – we will be at your side, because these are objectives that we have been pursuing for a long time.  That is why I too believe, as you said, that this is an opportunity not to be missed. This regulation must be voted on without amendments and a whole new system must enter into force immediately.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, in recent years people have travelled across Europe for their holidays, only to come home to a nasty shock when their phone bill arrives. Ending mobile roaming fees will be welcomed by millions of people.  Safeguards have been put in place to prevent excessive usage and to make sure that telecom operators are not forced to offer services at a loss. This is to make sure domestic customers will not subsidise customers who travel. To put it another way, when you travel across Europe, you can use your phone as though you were at home, but those who stay at home will not pick up an extra bill.  The deal also covers the common issue of internet packages not living up to the user’s expectation. Fixed-line customers will be entitled to clear information on the quality of services offered. They will be entitled to take action against their internet provider if the service does not match that which was advertised, for example if speeds are much slower than they expected. Telecoms regulators from across Europe’s 28 countries will agree a new set of guidelines on how broadband performance can be measured, compared and described.  The new rules do guarantee net neutrality. Users will be free to access content of their choice. It will not be blocked or slowed down. Access to start-up services will not be throttled or held back by a bigger company. There will be no two-speed Europe. Importantly, parental controls, where permitted in a Member State, will be able to continue. This is to make our internet safe, accessible and affordable across Europe.

name: Jens Rohde
text: for the ALDE Group. Mr President! When the ALDE Group presented a resolution in April 2013 saying that we should abolish roaming charges in Europe, we were met with great scepticism in this House and we were met with great excitement in the industry and some of the governments of some Member States. We were accused of wanting to break down the current telecommunications package, of making too much intervention in the market and of being illiberal in general – and how could a liberal group make such a proposal? At the same time, we were also told that now the internal market was not just about roaming charges.  Firstly, of course, there is to be the saying that if you want an internal market, you have to do some regulation so that we have a common game board. And what is absurd is that we have an internal market in a large number of areas in Europe, but the greatest growth potential we do not have a real internal market for today. That is why the aim of this is to create a single market for digital services, because the overall aim is to create growth and jobs in Europe. We are only doing this by reducing the cost of freedom of movement and by ensuring that we have a common game board in Europe.  I am proud and pleased that we have now agreed that we have a common game board when it comes to roaming, that we are getting rid of roaming charges. I'm also glad we're getting the first few years for an open internet. It should be remembered that if this agreement falls, then there is nothing in Europe. We would have liked us to be able to move forward and want something more, but this is the first step towards creating a single market that guarantees consumer rights and also ensures a high level of consumer protection. This is a huge step forward for Europe, both for citizens and for businesses, and not least for the basis for increasing growth and employment in one of the biggest potential growth areas we have in the coming years, namely the Digital Single Market.

name: Marisa Matias.
text: – Mr President, I do not in any way want to make any of the efforts made by the rapporteur in this negotiation, but no, it is not true, we have not achieved the objectives we have wanted since we started this process. This version is not the same as that which has been voted on before, it is not the same version that was announced to European citizens at the european elections, in which the end of roaming was announced on the one hand and, on the other hand, the neutrality of the Internet. Announced—if the end of roaming and now we have a promise for 2017. I hope that this promise will not be as flawed as the one that was feit in 2014, on the campaign trail. The neutrality of the Internet has been announced, but what we have achieved is an ambiguous agreement and there are no rights guaranteed with ambiguities.  We have received emails from many european citizens concerned about ensuring internet neutrality. The Internet, despite being recent in historical terms is already a world heritage site. Even before UNESCO has declared it, it will do so without a doubt, sooner or later. Therefore, we can say that attacks on the free, universal and neutral Internet are attacks on the common heritage of humanity. They are, more or less, like the attacks on Palmyra, but in a modern version, and that is why all fundamentalisms become so similar. It is that the fanatics of the market and the privatisation of common goods are also the destroyers of the economy and developed societies.  In this sense, we table amendments to this Plenary to clarify the regulation and to ensure that internet neutrality is indeed a guarantee for the whole of the European Union. Trafficking has to be treated equally, without discrimination, without restriction, with interference. We should return to the 2011 proposal. It is the most basic of basic principles and commitments to citizens. There should be no compromise in this House other than commitment to the citizens.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Democracy is communication.  Democracy thrives on being able to talk to each other.  That is why we have freedom of the press, that is why we have created freedom of expression.  The Internet – a neutral Internet – is the most important infrastructure of democracy for the future. If we undermine net neutrality, we will also damage our democracy. Net neutrality is not an issue that can be considered gradually. The net is neutral and the same for everyone or it is not. What we are deciding today – with the majority of conservatives, many social democrats, and liberal right-wing conservatives – is an end to net neutrality, and thus a loss to democracy. Nor is it an advantage for the economy, as is always argued here. Because in a neutral network, small companies can challenge the big corporations. When neutrality is abolished, we concrete the great, the powerful, for all time. That is what is happening here. In Europe, only a few large corporations benefit from this, which are telecoms industries. That is the only thing you are creating here today for the population: you are helping a few large corporations. It is commendable that Vice-President Ansip is standing here, but Commissioner Oettinger should actually be at the forefront, because Commissioner Oettinger is the person responsible and the culprit for this bad decision at Commission level. He should stand here and deal with us. But he's eagerly tweeting along, or his team, I've seen. Democracy is communication, that is how it should be, but it should not only send, it should also read, it should look into its mobile phone, what the people here say and write about this decision. I do not see any agreement, I see no support for these decisions. I only see resistance, I only read protest against this decision. Ladies and gentlemen, we should listen to it, we should vote against it and not accept it.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today could have been a great day, the day when we could have completely and truly abolished the costs of roaming, making Europe a truly connected continent, truly projected towards the twenty-first century. Instead, we have succumbed in the negotiations not only to the abolition of delayed and conditional roaming, but also to the fact that telecoms will be able to pass on the lost profits to the majority of Europeans, even those who do not even know what roaming is, those who cannot use it because they are unable to travel abroad, who are increasingly numerous on a continent suffering from the crisis. Yes, colleagues, it could have been a great day! Instead, we have traded a far-reaching abolition of roaming with the lack of a certain and incontrovertible definition of net neutrality, with insidious repercussions on those who may not use roaming, but use the Internet in their own country and often use it every day. These are an increasing proportion of us European citizens.  Yet, ladies and gentlemen, in spite of everything, not everything is lost. There is still time to remember this vote as an historic vote, there is still time to sanction net neutrality in Europe and make this a day of celebration. Let's listen to the appeal of Tim Berners-Lee, the inventor of the World Wide Web! Today we can still safeguard this extraordinary global public space, an intangible common good, an extraordinary engine of innovation, knowledge, equality and opportunity for a growing part of humanity. The world of the network is watching us and judging us and Europe cannot fall behind in the world. Let us not allow it to water down, let us not miss this unique opportunity to say no to new iniquities, new inequalities, privileged lanes even in the virtual world. Ladies and gentlemen, no one should ever fall behind again! Let's press that button with our conscience! Let's vote for net neutrality!

name: n/a
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, Commissioner Ansip, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work For almost two years now, this House has been dealing with the telecoms package, and it is really important that this is concluded today, because there must be legal certainty, and because it is important that this package, which is such an important and essential point in the context of the digital agenda, is implemented. It has now been reduced and we have all received so many Internet inscriptions. It has been reduced not only to the protection of users' rights, but to the abolition of roaming charges, as has been said several times today. There will be a cap from next year and the abolition in 2017. But essentially it was about net neutrality. Net neutrality must be maintained, there must be no two-speed Internet. Network operators should send all data packets through their lines on an equal footing, regardless of their content and where they come from. However, if we look at the traffic, we have to say that in a few years' time, the traffic will be completely restructured. There will be 3.2 billion internet-enabled machines over the next four years, which account for 50% of traffic in Europe and will account for a third of the world's data traffic. In addition, many households are not yet connected to the Internet. Broadband expansion is absolutely necessary: EUR 34 billion for fast broadband, eur 90 billion for the last mile. The last mile will be necessary for the transmission capacity per household to be fixed. This, ladies and gentlemen, is net neutrality and free access to the Internet. Every citizen should have it. Every citizen should have the right to go online. Let us give him the chance to take advantage of it!

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the free movement of people, goods and services is an important European fundamental value, but we know that, as far as digital services are concerned, it is not yet being thin. Too often, the digital service stops at borders.  This agreement, which has now been negotiated, is an important step towards ending roaming charges, abandoning roaming charges. It will affect tens of millions of EU citizens and benefit their daily lives and also our digital single market. In 2017, roaming charges will be abolished completely in the European Union.  Parliament would have liked to have seen a faster timetable, but it is quite right that a time-out was introduced in order to combine that wholesale pricer with this solution. It is important if we are to be able to move to this new situation in a sustainable way. It is important that wholesale prices are regulated in the same context as roaming charges are abolished. Once again, I would like to thank Parliament's negotiator, Pilar del Castillo Vera, for his excellent work and all those involved in the negotiations, because we know that this work was very demanding and required numerous negotiations.  Another important element in this package is that net neutrality, which will now be realised in such a way that operators cannot restrict or slow down traffic on commercial grounds anymore, but that restriction will only be accepted on technical grounds, and that is an important principle. Now the first in the world in Europe is the principle of net neutrality, and that is an historic step.

name: Petra Kammerevert (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For me, there is no way around a future-proof and comprehensive legal safeguard for net neutrality. Unfortunately, the text of the regulation does not offer exactly that. There is no definition of net neutrality or legal. There is only a basic obligation to treat data traffic equally. The possible exceptions are so far-sighted that net neutrality is dangerously watered down. Service classes are already allowed in the open network. Traffic management, including blocking and prioritization, is possible even in the event of impending network congestion, and special services are not sufficiently limited.  In my view, we are paying too high a price for the abolition of roaming: the complete softening of net neutrality. Due to its open and non-discriminatory nature, the Internet has proved to be an innovation engine for social and economic development. The stated aim of the European Parliament was the safe and legal safeguarding of net neutrality as an essential guarantor of communicative equality of opportunity and freedom of information as well as protection of diversity. If I have this perspective, I can only reject this regulation.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Mr Vice-President, we should not be happy about any price regulation in principle. In this case, however, I am glad that we are nearing the end of roaming. This can benefit citizens and entrepreneurs travelling abroad, who will make more use of data services. But even operators will finally be clear about the rules on charging roaming services. Briefly on net neutrality: I believe that the new rules are balanced, and I fully support the compromise negotiated with the Council. We are closing one chapter today, but consultations by the Commission are still ongoing. We expect big investment from the telecoms sector, but they need regulatory stability. I therefore hope that we will carefully weigh any new regulation and that it will be future-oriented regulation and for the benefit of the cause.

name: Kaja Kallas (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, we definitely seem to have problems with communication in this House as well. I often say that there are disparities between the communication that knows no borders and the barriers to communication that countries actually create. Roaming surcharges are a good example of this. I am happy that they are coming to an end in 2017, although Parliament wanted a much earlier end date.  But net neutrality goes beyond that date. How net neutrality is defined and how it is enforced will shape the future of the internet. We must remember that the internet was created to be an open platform for innovation and communication. It did not seem to matter until recently when we saw all the innovation coming from the internet. So we just cannot allow fast lanes to be created for those who pay. I am not only thinking about the start-ups that are not able to innovate on the internet, but we should also think about citizens who cannot receive their e—mails because somebody else is paying for the fast lane. So I would in particular call for Commission Vice-President Ansip to clarify the remaining issues in order to ensure that the principles are applied in the same way across Europe, and in this respect also to think seriously about the role of BEREC in order to look at the big picture.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we value Parliament's positions in defence of net neutrality and the end of roaming. However, we do not miss the concessions made to the Council which show that some parties have negotiated very differently from Parliament and from the Government. We hope that these ambiguities will be resolved in the vote and with the application of the Rules of Procedure.  When it comes to roaming, it is clear that we cannot tolerate large telecommunications groups demanding double charging for the same service. Today we can correct this situation. Let's not miss the opportunity to do so. As for net neutrality, this is a basic and fundamental requirement, not only for respect for freedoms, but also for productive innovation and equal access in a increasingly digitized world, both in leisure and at work. Beyond today's debate, the Union's digital strategy must consider the future not only of consumer rights but also of the place and rights of producer and worker in this digital world. I hope that in this debate we will be able to maintain the same consensus that we intend to reach today.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, net neutrality means that traffic is treated equally without discrimination, restriction or interference, independent of the sender—receiver type, content, device, service or application. The Council is trying to make us believe that this is what we are getting with this regulation, but I wonder why the Council refused to include this definition, or even the word net neutrality, in the agreement.  I wonder why the founder of the World Wide Web, Tim Berners-Lee, is urging us not to undermine net neutrality and to adopt amendments. Tim Berners-Lee is joined in his call for amendments by leading EU start-ups and investors, by the German Stanford Professor, Barbara van Schewick, who is the world’s leading expert on net neutrality issues, and by US presidential candidate Lawrence Lessig.  The fact is that this regulation allows business practices that rely on keeping the internet slow and expensive, such as zero-rating; it allows the slow-down of encrypted traffic; it gives incentives to companies not to protect our privacy and not to invest in broadband roll—out. That is exactly the opposite of a net neutrality regulation. So please adopt amendments to make sure that Parliament delivers on its promise to keep the internet open.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Mrs Reda, I congratulate you first of all for concluding by supporting this report. And I support him. The question I want to ask you: do you think we need to have a guarantee from the Commissioner here at the moment that the 2017 deadline is not being exceeded? Because Patrizia and others asked this. I want to know if you think it is important to have a commitment from the Commission to stop a deadline that is so expected in the internal market of the European Union.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – My statement criticising the net neutrality regulation in this package was precisely on the net neutrality part – I believe your question relates to the roaming part of the package. I do not believe that the regulation as such really sets an end date for roaming. I think it is our job as legislators to do that: to put an end to roaming and to clearly define net neutrality in the regulation. I think what we are doing here as a Parliament is that we are giving responsibility to the Council, to BEREC and to the Commission to actually do the job that we, as legislators, should be doing, and that is to pass clear rules on roaming and on net neutrality.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, my party supports net neutrality but we do not agree that heavy-handed top-down European regulation is the best way to deliver it, and I note that more than one Member State agrees with us. Then we come to the question of roaming, which has been presented as a wonderful benefit for consumers. Of course, it is no such thing; it is profoundly regressive. It will benefit well-heeled jet-setters and business executives and it will result in higher costs for domestic users. We have had Members of this House, including Vicky Ford, who have told us that there will be no rebound effect on domestic costs. I have to say that if you take that view, you simply do not understand how markets work: the operators will have lost a major revenue stream, they will seek to recover it, and the only place to recover it is from domestic prices. We MEPs will get lower prices, but Mrs Lumsden in Coronation Street will pay more. Yet again we see European regulation delivering unintended consequences and perverse incentives.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Vicky Ford (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Helmer, many millions of people from across your region and my region use their phones. I do not want to push up their domestic prices, but I do want to them to be able to use their phones affordably when they travel across Europe. This is why, in the two years of negotiations, we have put in place a safeguard through the review of wholesale caps so that domestic prices will not be put up. Here is my question to you: why in two years have you never bothered to turn up to a negotiation? Have you even read the text?

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – I have been fully briefed on the text, so thank you very much for that, Vicky. I appreciate that. But you tell me that you do not want to push up domestic prices, so I have to ask you: why are you supporting a measure which will clearly have that effect? If you are relying on a couple of clauses buried in the small print to protect consumers at home, I suggest that you should think again, because those assurances are not worth the paper they are written on.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's approach is always the same. First, the virtues of a single market and competition are being touted: 110 billion savings for the single telecoms market and a 5% increase in GDP until 2020. Secondly, in the name of the virtue of the single market and competition, national state leaders and their suppliers are being broken, or at least they and their OEMs are severely weakened. France was - you understand me well - world number one with Alcatel, since nothing more. Third, in the name of global competitiveness, new and old players are being destroyed in order to obtain a new concentration through unfair competition. Fourthly, the external powers are being let in, because the Commission is not working for Europe - think of the Schneider case - to absorb the leaders who have survived and, if they do not succeed, the transatlantic treaty is put in place. Yes, the excessive cost of homelessness must be stopped, but there is no miracle that if there are fewer benefits, there is less investment in research and innovation.  Net neutrality is an illusion if it is in the hands of the United States and the United States remains in control of the network. It is the states that must remain guarantors of legislation and service; there needs to be a European intranet based on national intranets for independence and resilience. Tomorrow we will have to take back this democratic sovereignty, get out of this Europe, ladies and gentlemen, for the citizens you claim to defend by enslaving them a little more.

name: Paul Rübig (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to express my sincere thanks to the rapporteur, Pilar del Castillo Vera, because she has continued what the citizens of Europe have called for. Once a student approached me and complained about the exorbitant costs of going to another country in Europe. I sat down with Commissioner Reding at the time and she confirmed that. The European Commission has made a proposal for Roaming I that was groundbreaking. I would like to thank the European Commission today for not leaving this path, but for consistently continuing along the way.  I believe that it is still important today to see that we can actually eliminate roaming charges by 14 June 2017. By April 30, 2016, costs will be reduced to 5 cents per minute, SMS to 2 cents and data totalto 5 cents. I believe that it is a huge step forward to actually implement the Digital Single Market by 2018. I believe that, in the case of net neutrality too, it must also be said that the threat of network congestion must be prevented by equal treatment. This clarifies the current definition and prevents large, powerful corporations from using our infrastructure in Europe free of charge. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Like many of your peers, you are, I'm afraid, celebrating something you don't have. So what happens in 2016 or 2017, 2018 - that's what you can praise. But then I ask you, why didn't we try to make this happen now?

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Thank you very much for this comment. I can only say that this text states quite clearly that 'operators of Internet access services do not have the opportunity to circumvent the general prohibition on blocking, slowing down, modifying, restricting, disrupting, harming or discriminating against certain content, applications or services or certain categories thereof'. I think that is groundbreaking. You didn't even get that far in America. I believe that the European regulation is a model for global development and thus gives the Internet a new security.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Sur President, gťalkemm hemm σafna eittadini li huma xettièi fuq il-proťett "Ewropa", huwa important nuru s-suèesssi ta' dan il-prożett. Ir-riżultat tal-pakkett tat-Telecom Single Market jista' jitqies bťala wieťed mill-kisbiet tal-Unjoni Ewropea li żgur ser iťalli impatt tajjeb fuq il-ťajja taż-żittadini tagťna. Dan huwa t-tmiem tal-battalja twila tal-Parlament Ewropew, battalja li bdiet bosta snin ilu. Dan huwa t-tmiem tar-roaming charges u l-bidu ta' regoli fuq net neutrality li ser isaťťu d-drittijiet tal-konsumatur. Bťala parti min-negozjati gťall-Grupp S&D tal-kumitat IMCO, insistejt sabiex ikollna fixed date gťat-tmiem tar-roaming charges u ninsab satisfy li finalment gťandna d-data ta' Żunju 2017. Mill-perspettiva tal-konsumaturi, il-ftehim huwa wkoll pass important 'il quddiem. Il-Kumitat IMCO rnexxielu jinkludi numru ta' proviżjonijiet important dwar it-tisťiť tal-informazzjoni kuntrattwali u t-transparence, monitorażż tal-konsum u miżuri gťall-immaniżjar tat-traffiku. Dan jipprovdi gťodda ta' tqabbil bejn is-servizzi, aktar informazzjoni gťar-rimedji u proèedura biex jiżu indirizzati l-ilmenti tal-konsumaturi. Minix sodisfatta fuq il-ftehim tan-net neutrality, but almenu gťall-ewwel darba se jkun hemm regoli Ewropej li japplikaw gťall-Member States kollha gťall-benefièju taè-σittadini.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I will be voting in favour of this report later today because I believe it strikes the right balance between protecting consumer rights, encouraging competition and fostering innovation. The prospect of ending roaming charges in the EU is a significant bonus for consumers, and I am pleased that my constituents will be able to use their phones across Europe without the fear of incurring huge bills. With regard to the open internet, this report takes a sensible approach. It will ensure that all internet traffic is treated equally, with some reasonable exceptions to overcome congestion. It will also allow for new and innovative technologies that have specific speed requirements, such as in the area of e-health.  The report also allows countries like the United Kingdom to maintain our system of parental filtering. This is an important issue for my constituents and I am pleased to see that this is been safeguarded. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. "I was reassured to hear from the Member that he supported the proposal that has just been tabled. At the same time, we know that, while the European Commission has set a much earlier date for the introduction of roaming charges, we in the European Parliament – as well as the Member of the previous term – wanted to abolish roaming charges much earlier. What could be the reason why, once again, the European Heads of Government, in the Council, have tried to push this, postpone it? Nation-state arrogan, just to put in the Commission and Parliament to propose otherwise, or perhaps the lobby of some multi-company, in which governments could be persuaded and us, and not the European Parliament.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not know the reasons for different members of the Council voting as they might have done, but what I would say to the honourable Member is this: we are engaging in some degree of price fixing.  Now, I would say that I am instinctively against that, but I would say that in this area the free market has failed to deliver lower prices on roaming charges. So I think that where the Commission is intervening in the market, it is reasonable and fair to give phone companies a period – and we are giving them just over 18 months – to get used to those price caps. I think the benefit for consumers will be significant and an 18-month delay really is not a problem.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Pilar del Castillo Vera, as well as the shadow rapporteurs, for achieving this deal with the Council.  This new regulation is an example of how the European Union can bring concrete benefits to its citizens. Parliament had called for the abolition of roaming surcharges and we will have this. As of June 2017, European Union citizens will be able to travel across the EU without paying extra communication surcharges. This will also bring significant benefits to European companies. I regret that the Council refused to accept the definition of net neutrality called for by Parliament. Nevertheless, we managed to include in the regulation minimum provisions to ensure non—discrimination and equal treatment on the internet. I deplore, however, that the Council rejected negotiation on spectrum and end-user rights as this would have been a concrete step towards full realisation of the Digital Single Market.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we have seen rather inflamed professions of faith in the liberalisation of various sectors of economic activity. The truth, however, is that the single market for electronic communications, as life and practice have proven in other sectors of activity, is tailored to the major powers and their monopolies. They lose workers, they lose consumers, they never see myrific promises come true. Advances monopolistic concentration, advances the private appropriation of public goods, such as a spectrum or the Internet, whose neutrality is put at risk to satisfy the business perspective of some colossi of the sector. Even if it is agitated as the great benefit of this regulation, the end of roaming charges in the realm of the multinational domain is not exempt from potential harmful effects. Just a few weeks ago, the president of the body that brings together the 28 national regulators in the telecommunications sector said that, in the face of the dominant tourist flows in Europe, the countries of the south will be harmed. It will be the people who do not travel from these countries who will have to bear the costs associated with eliminating roaming charges by increasing their own tariffs. We still have no convincing answer to these alerts.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the agreement we have reached as the European Parliament with the Council on the single market in telecommunications, in my view we have been content with the 'little is better than nothing'. That is a completely wrong approach.  We are playing with words: on the one hand we guarantee security and certainty, on the other hand in that regulation we have practically offered mechanisms to contradict these commitments. If we are talking about roaming, which has already been postponed to too late, then we are actually allowing operators to spread these extra expenses on unkedable users. With regard to net neutrality, we have even given in to its definition and therefore leave it to the operators once again to control the flow of information.  Let us ensure today, with the vote, that we do not miss yet another opportunity to have a free, accessible and neutral Internet.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF).
text: Mr President, today 27 October 2015, the European Parliament will enshrine a new freedom, net neutrality. The stakes are high. The aim is to allow every internet user, whether poor or rich, to have indiscriminate access to the site of their choice, from the smallest personal blog to the largest sites of multinational companies.  This equal access to the internet is necessary. It is unfortunate that the text before us is vague. If it were voted on as it stands, it could lead to a scandalous filtering of content on the Internet that would compromise the ability of citizens to inform themselves. That is why I will support the amendments that seek to stave off this risk. On February 26, 2015, the U.S. Federal Telecommunications Commission guaranteed net neutrality in the United States. The European Parliament must prove today that it is capable of doing the same for Europe.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – This is indeed the largest and most anticipated regulation for Eu citizens that we are dealing with today – the most anticipated for a long time, because we are finally setting a date for the final abolition of roaming charges. This is a step that we have all been waiting for impatiently. From 15 June 2017, operators will not be able to impose additional charges on consumers for the use of their phones or for data transmission in the European Union. In the end, we have managed to break the Council's resistance on this issue, and I very much congratulate my colleague del Castillo on his determination on this issue. I also very much appreciate Commissioner Ansip's commitment. I am convinced that with it the European Commission will quickly propose appropriate rules on wholesale prices, so that the costs of providing roaming services to operators will indeed and apprecially fall. I wanted this to happen sooner, but from 30 April next year we will feel their decline, because operators will only be able to add as much to our bills as they actually pay to operators abroad. But what we have also achieved is a compromise on net neutrality, and I am very pleased about that. Let me quote briefly: 'internet access service providers treat all data transmissions equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference'. But let us be ready to improve this law if necessary. Some of you complain about diluting. However, let us remember that the digital environment is changing and developing very quickly and dynamically and our regulations must be geared towards it.

name: Dan Nica (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would first of all like to congratulate all those who negotiated, on behalf of Parliament, this agreement with the Member States and managed, on the one hand, to have an elimination of roaming surcharges and, on the other hand, to introduce safeguards for the neutrality of networks in European Union law. The overcharging of calls, SMS, and data roaming within the European Union will be eliminated by 15 June 2017 after a transitional period, and the price decrease may be up to 4 times less than some consumers are paying today. On net neutrality, I would like to point out that so far there have been no binding pan-European rules on net neutrality. For the first time, the principle of neutrality will be enshrined in 28 national legal systems. Internet service providers across Europe will have to treat all internet traffic equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference, and regardless of who is the sender or receiver, of the content, applications or services used. Congratulations once again to the european Parliament's negotiators!

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Ladies and gentlemen, we must be careful that the concept of 'net neutrality' does not become an ideological concept of combat here in this House. The best thing that the EU and, in the past, the European Economic Community has offered us is clearly the European internal market. It is the basis for prosperity, for jobs and, ultimately, for the moral positions that the European Parliament is trying to spread throughout the world.  All of this is at risk by two things: firstly, in the digital economy, we are falling further behind the rest of the world. Secondly, it is essential that we ensure that the European internal market is also connected to foreign countries. Ladies and gentlemen, both must happen at the same time, and that is why I also support the Commission's proposal.  Incidentally – and here comes my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single currency in Europe only leads to discord and discord and must therefore be abolished.

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The telecoms package is a very complex legislative package with an improbably great relevance for all citizens here in Europe, and in several respects. On the one hand, we are talking about the abolition of roaming, which, as I have had to learn here, is unfortunately not welcomed by all sides, but is very much welcomed by most of us here in Parliament. Secondly, however, we are also talking about net neutrality. This seems to be a term that the Council, like the devil, shies away from holy water. That was the first objective: this term had to be removed from the directive. I deeply regret that the Council does not sit here today to explain to us why net neutrality has been so strongly opposed. Almost a year and a half ago, Parliament adopted a good draft on net neutrality, which unfortunately was significantly softened in the negotiations with the Council. However, the question that needs to be asked, precisely because we have a complex package, is: how do the individual aspects and the individual points that have been achieved in the package work together? Here, it has to be said, we are achieving more than we have so far. So far, there is no definition of net neutrality, but so far there is no safeguarding of equal treatment, non-discrimination and free permeability, regardless of sender and receiver. In other words, at the moment, telecommunications companies have a relatively free hand, as we have had in the past, and competition law can only be used to intervene. In other words, if we come to a regulation here, we will be able to take significant further steps than we have done so far. I am not satisfied with the outcome on net neutrality, but I am satisfied because the overall package is a step in the right direction.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With this telecommunications package, we are taking a very important first step towards advancing the rights of citizens, consumers, and that is very important. And our hard fight, which we have fought time and again to ensure that roaming charges are finally abolished, is very slow to produce results, but the results are coming to an end, and this is therefore a very important question. Another important issue, of course, is this issue of net neutrality, on which we have also worked. And, of course, I would have preferred Parliament's text to have prevailed in the negotiations that we have had. The question is, how do we deal with this now? I think that with this text we have taken a first correct step, an important step, because there are no rules in 26 countries. We have to see that again.  But that means, Commissioner, and here I would ask you to really listen to me, that we cannot sit down now and turn the screw, but we must work very hard to ensure that such things as the zero-rating are clearly given the definition of 'reject'. And we must also continue to work in the area of net neutrality, so that it is also really clear that all citizens have free access to it.

name: Bendt Bendtsen (PPE).
text: Mr President! I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Pilar del Castillo Vera, and also thanking the shadow rapporteurs for a very good negotiating result. Europe needs more growth and jobs, which is why we also need a single internal market for telecommunications services. We haven't had that, we're about to get that. No one would have thought that we could push the club, which has used roaming charges as a milking machine for consumers in Europe. There is also reason to say thank you on behalf of small and medium-sized enterprises. We live in a global digital age and it benefits the single market for small and medium-sized enterprises. I can then hear that not everyone is equally satisfied with what has happened about net neutrality. I think we should listen a little after what the Commissioner has said today. After all, this is the first time we have got a safeguard into our legislation.

name: n/a
text: Mr President, we are just getting ready to adopt a fundamental two-way regulation: first, the end of homelessness. In June 2017, after years of progressive capping, it will be the end of tariff surcharges for those of our fellow citizens who cross borders, and I am thinking not only of those who have the chance to travel, but also of those who travel across borders for professional reasons. I am thinking particularly of border workers, this is a remarkable achievement. The second fundamental element is the inclusion of the principles of net neutrality in our European legal body. This is a significant step forward for me, and I would like to respond here to the concerns and criticisms that have been expressed about the outcome of the negotiation between Parliament and the Council. Does this text clearly enshrine a principle of neutral and non-discriminatory treatment of internet traffic? Yes, it is. Does this text open obvious loopholes that would contravene the principle of net neutrality? I don't think so, although we can still estimate writing ex abstracto a clearer text. But does this potential gain in clarity merit taking the risk of undermining all of our achievements?  It is on this issue, and only on this issue, that our differences will be expressed later. For my part, I will not take this risk - because a negotiation is not reopened - while warning the Commission and the Member States that we will remain vigilant both on the implementation of this regulation and on the next texts already on the agenda.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to convey my thanks to the rapporteur and say to Mr Helmer and all the others behind their borders: ‘welcome to the 20th Century’. When you have arrived there, you will get the information that the rest of us are in the 21st Century, where there are no borders for mobile telephones or the internet. That is why it is important and a step forward with this package, because now we are clarifying that we need a European telecom market. We are taking away some of the hindrances, but we need to do more. One of the things we need to do more is more spectrum, and I think it is important to go ahead and open up the 700 megahertz band, because that will be a precondition for Europe to have the best capacities and higher speeds. To those who are advocating some sort of doctrinaire net neutrality, I would say that in reality you are hindering and blocking the emergence of new services, because you say that different services are not to be allowed to have different preconditions. We shall not discriminate and block, but we shall open up. What you are saying is not net neutrality, it is anti-net; it is not internet, because a growing and potential internet is open for suppliers and for users: that is the future. We need to go further ahead, but this is an important step forward.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, as always, when we adopt a legislative text once and for all, we wonder whether it is a step forward for Europe. As always, the compromise reached in the eternal dispute with the Council may not be satisfied. In this case there is no doubt. The text that I very much hope we will approve strengthens the rights of European consumers, creates the conditions for making our continent a freer and more inclusive area. This is all the more important because it is a strategic sector, the telecommunications sector, which can now represent for Europe what coal and steel were at the beginning of the integration process.  The affirmation of the principle of net neutrality and the definitive abolition of roaming charges are two important results. For a Europe that needs to relaunch the single market as a driver of development and growth and define a new model of development based on knowledge and innovation, the creation of a European communications and digital area appears to be a necessary condition for winning its future.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Parliament is voting today to bring an end to data text and mobile phone roaming surcharges throughout Europe by June 2017. I urge all of my colleagues in Parliament to vote for this so that we can see an end to outrageous phone bills for people when they return from their holiday or if they travel within the EU to work. This vote will mean that people no longer need to be afraid of facing huge bills just for keeping in touch with their family and their friends.  Roaming charges have been an unjustified burden on holiday-makers and business travellers for far too long, and the end of roaming charges will be of direct benefit to consumers all across Europe and in the UK, not forgetting that this is yet another reason why the EU benefits us in Britain and why the UK is stronger in the European Union.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, I congratulate the rapporteur and support with all my might this important step by the European Union with regard to the abolition of roaming charges. It is a very important achievement for both the European Union and European citizens, but much more so for society, because there has really been a great distortion here and in this way we are actually restoring an injustice that has existed for so many years.  But another important chapter that should concern the European Union – and I take this opportunity to mention it – is the issue of the Internet. There are countries in the European Union that are isolated and island-based, such as Cyprus, Malta and possibly other regions of the European Union that pay high Internet costs. It is essentially exploited by telecommunications companies, and I believe that my intervention will also take it seriously and regulate it so that there can be tolerable costs for the use of the Internet. My proposal is that in small countries such as Cyprus, Malta and other island regions there should be a "free wifi zone", free use of the Internet. And it is a great challenge for small countries to start the European Union, with its support, to implement the free free use of the Internet. The Internet is a human right, and the European Union must provide it to all Member States and to all European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, we are going to vote on an important text later that has two components. The first, the abolition of roaming charges: we wanted it even earlier, for December 15, 2015, it will be June 15, 2017. But we can only welcome this, in the interest of all European consumers and in the perspective of a single market, which is truly unique from this point of view.  The other aspect is net neutrality, of course, with the management of the data flow, which could also pose some problems in relation to the concept of emergency threat, which naturally risks reopening the possibility of a two-speed internet. Zero-rate practices should be banned. And to that end, I propose to you, to be clear and to avoid a lack of precision that could weaken net neutrality, to support a series of amendments: Amendments 2, 4-9 and 11-23, which could in any case clarify the shadows and guarantee European citizens the best protection, which is still the aim of this text in globo. I suppose we can do that and vote on the text later.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, we live in the age of information and communications, at a time when human needs are largely served electronically. At the same time, the digital age gives new opportunities to the world's economies, but also to businesses, to grow and become more competitive. Productivity growth now depends, to the greatest extent, on investment in new technologies. In this context, the single European electronic communications market plays a key role in Europe's transition to the new digital age. However, this requires, firstly, net neutrality, ensuring equal free access for consumers and businesses, and, secondly, the abolition of roaming charges, roaming, which will contribute to the free movement of persons and services and to the strengthening of the competitiveness of small and medium-sized enterprises. For these reasons, roaming should be abolished immediately, in 2015, as was the original target, and not in 2017, because that is how electronic customs are maintained. So here and now immediate abolition of roaming without terms and conditions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, our task will be fully fulfilled as the European Parliament at a time when the internet will become europe's fifth freedom. This is how citizens and all those who are interested, who need the internet, can be completely satisfied. However, this is still a step in the right direction. Because in 2016 we will have similar communication costs on the digital market and because in 2017 we will virtually abolish roaming. Perhaps we could have achieved more, but in these relations we have with the Council and with the Member States it was clearly not possible.  That is why, in the end, I strongly welcome what we will all vote together today and I believe that in the end we will show that this Europe has the strength to be more unique, to be stronger together, because everything we experience on the other hand goes towards watering down our communion, and I think the common digital market also shows our common strength.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
text: – The principles of neutrality in the open internet mean that traffic must be treated in the same way, without discrimination, restriction or interference, independently of the sender, recipient, type, content, device, service or application. We are all in the eu-neutrality system today, but obviously there are differences in understanding whether this regulation really guarantees whether we are really going to achieve these objectives through this regulation. When comparing the first reading text, it can be found that virtually all the provisions relating to the concept, definition and guarantee of the independence and neutrality of the Internet are missing. And it is precisely this looseness of the language, experts in Slovenia also warn, that can be a major problem in Europe. And I have to say that a good example of the practice of legislation, how this should be regulated, is the case of Slovenia.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE).
text: – Sur President, illum hija urnata importanti gsall-konsumaturi madwar l-Ewropa. Illum ser niesdu deiżjoni biex fl-assar innessu darba gsal dejjem it-tariffi tal-mobile roaming madwar l-Unjoni Ewropea, u and b'ses a mill-2017. Ser niesdu l-assar pass f'proess leiżlattiv, li frankament dià kien twil wisq u li ma kellux jitwal daqshekk. It-tnesija tat-tariffi tar-roaming huma eżempju iesor concrete tal-benefiji ta' unjoni ekonomika b'rabtiet aktar b'sasithom. Bid-deiżjoni tagsna llum, ser ine au pratti antikwati tan-negozju, u-ittadini tagsna ser jaraw il-benefijiji reali ta' suq Ewropew diitali u and bi prezzijiet or aos. Is-servizzi diitali ma jistgsux jieqfu mal-fruntieri. Il-kunett tal-Ewropa huwa dwar it-tnesija tal-barrieri u jiena kburija 서afna li llum ser titne aa barriera osra. And mhuwiex biss dwar ir-roaming imma dwar il-bżonn li jiu ggarantiti aessibilità s an tal-internet u s-servizz diitali. Nirringrazzja lill-kollega Pilar de Castillo u l-MEPs l-osra involuti kif ukoll il-Kummissarju u lill-Kunsill li tant aadmu fuq and id-dossier.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, unlike Mrs Kammerevert, who spoke earlier in a personal capacity, I would like to announce that I am also voting in favour of this regulation together with other S&D colleagues from the Committee on Culture, Youth, Education, the Common Security and Energy because it is the result of difficult negotiations lasting three months and because, although we would have liked to have had more certainty, we must say for the first time that binding rules on net neutrality will be established in Europe. , which will be enshrined in the 28 national legal systems and will oblige Internet service providers in the European Union to treat internet traffic fairly, without discrimination, interference or limits. National regulatory authorities will also have to fully implement the proposal with additional powers and will also monitor discriminatory practices, such as zero rating. Sanctions will also be imposed, and this seems to us to be a very significant step forward, together, of course, with the end of the additional roaming charges in June 2017. So I think it's to be welcomed as an important step forward.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has The exit for roaming charges in the EU was long overdue and comes about two years later than requested by Parliament and the Commission. However, I welcome the fact that, in the interests of consumers, a definitive date has finally been set for the abolition of roaming charges. We have free movement of people, goods and services in Europe. In the case of telecommunications, however, artificial limits still exist, and that simply cannot be the case.  However, in addition to the late abolition of roaming charges, I am critical of the fact that telecommunications providers still have the option of providing for special rules after 2017, when users make mobile calls more frequently in other EU countries than on occasional trips. In future, we must pay close attention to this, which is a call to the Commission to ensure that there are no disadvantages for the population in a border region, and that cross-border work is not put further into burdening them.  In border regions, it is not only at travel times that you cross borders, but europe is naturally lived there every day. The border population should not have to pay for this.

name: Andrus Ansip
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Members for this very fruitful debate this morning. Parliament has negotiated well and played a leading role for us to get this far. Today we are taking bold steps on both roaming and net neutrality. I must stress that the political understanding should not be reopened with last-minute amendments. Any change now would create a real risk of delays that might not be only months but years. We are not asking any Member State to change existing national rules if these can be interpreted by regulators and courts consistently with the regulation. Our regulators and the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC) have a long track record in safeguarding open, competitive markets, and I am sure they are up to the task. Our people have been waiting a long time for common principles of net neutrality and the end of roaming surcharges. If you do not approve of the deal today, there is no date at all. This would be worse. I am sorry to say that we already have in the European Union a generation of people who know how dangerous it is to use your mobile devices in some other countries. If service providers have to tell their customers not to use their services if travelling in some other countries, then we have to say that this is not a sustainable business model. If customers do not care about this advice and they continue use their mobile devices, they could easily start to hate those service providers because of those high bills they have to pay. Now it is up to Members to change this system. I am also really happy that we were able to find consensus in the common principles of net neutrality: no blocking, no throttling, no pre-paid prioritisation. All traffic has to be treated equally on the internet. This is really important for all of us, not only for Europe, but for the whole world. Parliament now has the deal, with its very tangible effects for people, in its hands. It is a good deal for Europe and for Europeans. I urge Members again to vote for it.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, momentous decisions will be taken today on two aspects which I think is of the utmost relevance to the digital future of the European Union, to the future of the digital economy, to the future of digital society; a road that is underway, which is like a high-speed train with no stops, and on which Europe has to be on the locomotive. Firstly, roaming costs, roaming costs, which affect millions and millions of citizens across the European Union, are going to disappear. Roaming costs, in terms of the free movement of persons – a fundamental pillar of the European Union – are a charge to this free movement. Well, that digital customs office, that rate that we have been knowing, living, to the free movement of people, and also of companies that generate services and exchange goods, is going to disappear, and this seems to me to have enormous value. And, secondly, the internet. The Internet is a beautiful good. The Internet is an extraordinary territory that has given us technology, which we must take care of — and I believe that even pampering - and with this Regulation we establish conditions for internet access with guarantees, so that traffic is treated equally, but so that, at the same time, innovative services can flourish within the framework of the European Union , so that not all talent, all creativity, is drowned out. It's a huge step forward. It is the first time that there has been a regulatory framework of this nature in the world, and it is balanced. It's a land of opportunity for everyone and no one should drown it. That is what this regulatory framework on the internet that we have ahead of us today entails.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Tuesday 27 October, at 1.00 p.m. I am sorry for some of the technical and organisational problems that have occurred. I leave the presidency to Martin Schulz. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Since our economy is more and more interlinked with a digital dimension, I believe that a genuine single market for electronic communications is an essential part in order to pave the path for sustainable growth in Europe by improving conditions for the existing international businesses and digital industries. In addition, the telecoms single market would vastly benefit consumers who would enjoy fair and competitive prices for the digital devices and services.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I support the proposal put forward, as I believe that roaming in the current EU has no place and must be abolished. On the other hand, I can imagine that the final proposal could be even better. In my opinion, the dragging-out negotiations to abolish roaming charges are a good example of bad practice, i.e. the lobbying skills of telecommunications companies. Roaming could and should have been cancelled earlier, we could have called cheaper from this year's holiday. Despite these delays, I am glad that we have been able to agree on gradual steps, namely capping roaming prices and then abolishing them from June 2017. This is certainly an important step towards the EU's digital single market. On the other hand, I regret that the Council has clearly not taken the stand for the need to respect net neutrality. The Internet is a kind of public infrastructure and it is not desirable for some operators to be able to pay for better access and movement in this infrastructure at the expense of others. I am against tolerating any practices that would prevent all internet users from having the same rights and possibilities. I would consider such a situation to be unequal competition. However, I believe that the proposal put forward is better than no proposal. Although I agree in principle with the content of the amendments tabled, I have decided to abstain.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – 15 June 2017 will be an emblematic day for Europe. I believe – and I do not think I am exaggerating – that, once the borders are interoperable, this is once again an EU achievement that will affect all citizens: it will finally be possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings: in recent years, the cost of telephone use abroad has gradually decreased. I stress that Parliament has made every effort to abolish roaming charges, which can be considered extraprofits, as soon as possible.  The issue of net neutrality is also regulated in the document. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality Internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. I congratulate my fellow Member Del Castillo Vera on his steadfast work in the negotiations, and thank you for your excellent performance.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. It is unacceptable to me that the Council, which brings together the governments of the Member States, is delaying the introduction of roaming charges in Europe by two years and endangering the freedom of the Internet, its democratic and community character. The Democratic Coalition is convinced that, in a Europe without borders, roaming charges that make it more expensive to use the internet abroad are no longer recratic. Roaming charges should be phased out immediately rather than gradually in the summer of 2017. There is no alternative to this decision, mobile operators should not charge more for foreign telephony than domestic calls!  At the same time, I cannot support a proposal that threatens the neutrality of the European Internet, limiting the free use of the Internet by European and Hungarian people at any level. National governments want legislation that results in a two-speed Internet: a faster band for the richer, slower, worse quality for the poorer. The current proposal also allows for arbitrary restrictions on certain internet services and for certain content specified by the service provider not to be included in the consumer's monthly limit. The proposal risks the freedom of the Internet and is harmful to innovation, it can also stif over start-ups in Hungary. We have recently seen an attempt by the Hungarian Government to tax and limit internet use. The DK rejected this even then, and we will not support efforts against internet neutrality at European level.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Finally, the desire to see the roaming charges for calling, texting or browsing the net from another EU country!
