But negotiating with Erdogan, who, under the pretext of fighting terrorism, is actually bombing the Turks, which is the case for the Islamic State, negotiating with Erdogan, who clearly does nothing against the smugglers' industry that flourish in the Bodrum region is a risky gamble. In any case, there is a rule to be respected, Mr President: for cyclical aid on the part of Turkey, the European Union's counterpart can only be cyclical and not structural.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the Slovenian police use tear gas against refugees; Slovenia, with liberal government. Hungary, ruled by the People's Party, uses dogs, water cannons and gases at borders and in the fields. October 16 – Bulgarian police shoot and kill a person from Afghanistan at the border; Bulgaria: Rules the People's Party. But, without a doubt, what best defines the European Union's treatment of refugees is the Government of the Czech Republic, marking them with numbers on its arms, and the German Government, using the Dachau concentration camp as a reception centre. European Parliament's condemnations to this human rights violation: zero. Expulsions from the European Social Democratic Party, the European People's Party or the Liberal Party of colleagues from Hungary, Bulgaria, Slovenia or the Czech Republic: zero. European Union sanctions on these countries: zero. So, Mr Juncker, Mr Pittella, Mr Weber, it is your parties, from governments, that not only do not practice solidarity, but systematically violate human rights. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: question raised by raising the blue card. – I must react to this tendencyy rumour from my colleague regarding Slovenia. I ask her how she would react when the conflict between the refugees themselves developed, which had to be sorted out so that the matter does not spread into a bigger fire. The Slovenian police acted responsibly.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – I believe that acting in a responsible way is respecting human rights and, of course, using gases against people fleeing war and barbarism cannot be a way of respecting human rights.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, actually and unusually I am not all that disappointed at what came out on Sunday, unlike Mr Schulz or some other voices here, because finally the Heads of State present have at least realised that we have a humanitarian crisis at hand. It should be obvious that refugees need shelter, food, water – the things you have mentioned, Mr Juncker. But for once, finally, we have it in the conclusions, so let us hope that all of those things are finally going to be delivered. I am also happy that the Geneva Convention and complying with EU law was highlighted; I am just not sure how you are going to bring that together with sending people back to Afghanistan, because Afghani refugees are recognised as refugees inside the European Union; they almost fulfil the threshold of 75% to be eligible for relocation. Afghanistan certainly is not a safe place and, again, unfortunately the mini-summit on Sunday failed to address the crucial questions of a new and fair distribution system – fair for Member States and for refugees, and the question of legal access. Those are the issues we actually need to address, not some weird Fortress Europe issues.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Three observations after the Summit. Firstly, it is finally recognised that Europe has so far stubbornly failed to protect its external borders and it has at least been agreed that certain steps will be taken. This is actually good. Secondly, the Council will allocate around EUR 10 billion to Asian and African countries, apparently hoping to buy peace so that migrants do not flock to Europe. I think it is naïve. Thirdly, colleagues, we need a new immigration policy, which makes it clear that Europe is only open to refugees coming directly from hostilities in the region, the principles of which are based on decisions held by national governments and new decisions on temporary accommodation or integration policies for war refugees, if community countries agree. And more. National interests are far from being nationalistic, and there is no need to pretend to understand it and to scare themselves and those around them with things that have not happened.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF).
text: Mr President, as the summits continue in Europe, migration flows are increasing. In France, the UMP mayor of Calais, after declaring that illegal immigrants were an exceptional cultural wealth, is now reduced to asking some residents to move, when they are plagued by aggressive and violent migrants.  This is the reality of migration anarchy, for which the European Union and the servile governments are fully responsible for re-claiming control of their borders. That is why the Valletta summit will not change anything, because it insists, I quote, on the promotion of legal immigration routes and the strengthening of migrant protections.  In contrast to these irresponsible proposals, I call for the immediate suspension of the Schengen agreements and the strengthening of national border controls, in order to place migrants in detention centres and deport them immediately to their country of origin. This is a clear message for migrants: don't let them come to us!

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Mr President, the decisions taken by the Council of Europe on 15 October are the result of the panic that has taken over the leaders of the countries of Europe from the sudden and sudden invasion of thousands of illegal immigrants and the inability they have to deal with the crisis that has arisen from this problem. Thus, all they managed to do was to upgrade the role of Turkey, a country that is largely responsible for both the creation and the exacerbation of the migration problem. Instead of the European Union demanding that Turkey, which does not meet the criteria of the Copenhagen Treaty, is a country to join, to comply with its obligations and not to promote thousands of illegal immigrants to Greece, it tolerates it blackmailing Cyprus with division if it does not succumb to its pressures and demands, and at the same time, through Mrs Merkel's mouth. , it offers three billion euros to the European Investment Bank (EIB) and the European Mr Erdogan,despite the fact that he refuses to receive them and wants more and possibly twice as much. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I fully agree with the diagnosis made by President Tusk that emigration is a challenge that changes not only Europe, not only the European Union and the intra-Union agreement, but also the challenge that affects political systems in individual countries. The number of 710 000 migrants who (if this figure is obviously fully true) have arrived in Europe at this time brings with it a number of humanitarian, existential problems. This is a challenge for many of the countries where these migrants have found themselves. However, It seems to me that it is good that the Union has agreed to this and that we should first of all help where there are sources of migration: in Africa and in the Middle East. And these decisions were taken as part of the summit on 23 September. It is good that we have all acknowledged together that border protection should be a priority. It is not possible to help those who are already in the European Union if the border is leaking like a colander. This, in a sense, provokes further emigration, regardless of the fact that places are being created where the humanitarian crisis, such as in Syria, will continue to affect emigration. It was decided to provide eur 1 billion in aid to refugees in the Middle East. The question, of course, is whether that is enough. After all, no money is enough when there is a humanitarian crisis. But It seems to me that the decision to help Turkey is also important. Without this assistance, Turkey, a country with more than 2.5 million refugees, could not help stem this migratory pressure. This is where the Member States have to come.  There is also some hope of improving the situation in Libya. Here we must help, and It seems to me that all forms of assistance and international cooperation, including the UN, are effective in countering this great humanitarian crisis.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Although you have avoided the numbers, I would like to ask you one thing, whether you have a specific number or a ratio, what proportion of the refugees arriving here are legitimate refugees and what proportion of them are not legitimate refugees, so should they be reversed?

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I did not talk about what are the groups among those who have come to Europe, how many real political refugees there are, and how many are those who are economic migrants. This needs to be evaluated. If there was a normal registration system in the place where these refugees appear, we could say that. We don't know that at the moment. We know that this is about seven hundred thousand, more than seven hundred thousand until September this year. But in fact, this diagnosis is yet to come. Moreover, here in this House, both the President of the European Council and the President of the Commission have said that this, unfortunately, also requires the help of professional specialists who are able to help to identify the real motivation for migrants arriving in Europe.

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I do not want to go back to the Leaders Meeting.  It's bad enough, which we have to record as a success by now – that's how we stand. However, I would like to express my support for you from the Commission and Commissioner Timmermans to vigorously conduct negotiations with Turkey. Firstly, they deserve it because they have been with the Syrian refugees for a long time, and secondly, it gives us the air we need to create and consolidate structures to better serve the people – the refugees, and those who welcome the refugees. Of course, we must not indiscriminately throw our convictions and our values overboard, and no one believes that this will happen in these negotiations. But we must also be aware that morality alone will not solve the problem. Secondly, I would ask you to continue to make every effort to work together with the United States, Russia, Iran and Saudi Arabia to end the war in Syria. We can only do this together. Here, too, we will not end the suffering of the people there without pragmatism.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, in five days last week and despite the sea disturbance, the Aegean islands were flooded by 48,000 new refugees, which came to add to the 450,000 refugees who had already flooded Into Greece since the beginning of the year.  Under the refugee allocation clause at European Union level, depending on the size, population and GDP of each country, as recently decided by the European Council, Greece must accommodate a total of 11,000 refugees.  Yet with a tool the memorandum at the previous mini-session in Brussels was essentially imposed on Greece to accommodate five times the number of refugees, reaching 50,000. Greece cannot turn into a huge refugee favela. The poor Greek people cannot accommodate other refugees, and you must understand that. As well as you must understand that guarding the Greek border belongs to the sovereign rights of Greece. It is time to stop supporting Turkey and force it to put an end to the slave trade circuits operating on its territory. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – Dear Mr Juncker! Thank you for calling a meeting on Sunday, which was undoubtedly useful. I liked less about your tone of criticism aimed at liders from countries along the Balkan route. It would be good if we were critical of everyone, because the liders of these countries have a 100 per cent problem and a problem that goes beyond their capacities, which is why they were nervous, but I think the meeting has fixed a lot of things here. My country, Slovenia, is all because it is small, on the notorious Balkan route, we can also say on the cross path of tens of thousands of refugees and migrants. Today, We Europeans must recognise that we are all in the Balkan direction. We have a problem that is not self-caused by nature or evil fate. It is the result of the disastrous decisions of politicians of this generation, interventions, wars and illusions that we can govern the world according to our desires, ambitions and image. The mass of unhappy people from countries that our short-sighted politics helped to take down are here. They came to us, as many people, of different faiths, races and beliefs, came and went in the history of our continent. But the difference is - today Europe is stronger and richer, built on shared values. They must also be met by concrete and effective action by the European Union as a whole, of governments and activists of humanitarian organisations and civil society.  A joint, coordinated action, solidarity, vision, tolerance and efficiency, a political solution to the problems of the Middle East with the participation of all those affected and involved.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission and especially of the Council, it is time for words to move on to the projects and so far we have been delayed and postponed, even in the implementation of decisions you have taken. A sustainable European solution, humanitarian, to the problem of refugee flows is needed. If this is not given, European unification itself is at risk of a dissolving crisis and Europe is threatened by the revival and strengthening of xenophobic, racist, fascist views.  My country, Greece, cannot bear the burden on its own, and it lifts the greatest burden; it cannot become a warehouse of souls and winter comes and the Aegean every day becomes a cemetery. When will Dublin II finally change? When will you get peace, European initiatives on the war in Syria? When will you finally apply the stability pact flexibly to the countries that are lifting the burden of refugees?

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which It is very positive – and i am also grateful to you, President Juncker – that this meeting took place on Sunday, because the future of Europe really lies in those who have to decide to sit down at the table and not build barbed wire fences against each other, but negotiate solutions together at one table. You are right, Mr Junker, when you say that this should actually be the normal case. Unfortunately, it is not yet. It is necessary for there to be support, including for those countries that are not yet in the European Union, such as those in the Balkans. It is about human lives, especially now that winter is coming. They are refugees who are coming, who are fleeing from bombs. What is missing, however – and this has also become clear – is that what the Member States have promised will actually be implemented. money, but also a fair distribution of refugees among all Member States. It is up to you, Mr Tusk, to finally put pressure on the members of the Council and say: you must do this. A common asylum system would be necessary, and now, so that ... (The President interrupted the speaker) ....  fight against each other and against each other here things .....  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as Rome debates, Sagunto burns. To this I thought, approaching the border war in the Western Balkans, the risk of the collapse of Macedonia and Serbia and Schengen, the long discussions and insufficient solutions of recent months. There is a river of human despair that only clothes remain and the hope of surviving the 100 000 new redistributions in the face of 260 000 new transits in a month in Croatia.  And what do these conclusions say? They talk about integrated border management with a new Frontex, a single border guard, the dismantling of criminal networks... Small useful steps, with a large sword of Damocles: the when. And again: when is a common European asylum with legal access routes? When is the promised redistribution far from complete? When is the Dublin review? When is a real change of direction in our policies in Africa and especially in Syria?  There is only one line, a wretched line, on concrete efforts to tackle the root causes and support African socio-economic development. What these efforts are, no one knows. While many others were written to greet Erdoğan and his regime as his best friend, to remember that the promised donations were not paid out.  Verhofstadt is right: the real problem is not the competition of the political groups that Weber mentioned. I will tell you what it is: it is the existence of a single European party, the party of war, exploitation and inconsistency, the police station of democracies. The worst party of all, the one taken. And while Europe is debating, the Mediterranean and Africa are burning, indeed drowning, on the threshold of our homes. Congratulations to the Nobel Prize for hypocrisy.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: – How far can cynicism take place? Jean-Claude Juncker congratulates Angela Merkel for not taking a back on her in polls showing how averse the population is to her migration policy. "Wir schaffen es nicht" seems to be the motto, but we don't care. There is no more intrusive, no more profound and no more efficient way of making the citizens of Europe realise that this Union does not take account of their view that this Union has nothing more to do with democracy than the way in which you have abused the free movement of goods and persons to organise one of the greatest migratory flows in our history. Socio-economic, too, it had already become clear in recent years that the European Union has taken the place of the citizens of Europe. Just look at the European Union coup in Portugal. But there is really no sharper picture of the implosion of democracy in Europe than your mismanagement, your blackmail and your manipulation of migration.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Mr President, the decisions of the summit are very dangerous for both refugees and peoples as a whole. It goes a long way for the Greek government to pretend that it has prevented them, because Greece with them is turning into a forced assembly station in camps of more than 50,000 stranded refugees, in a new version of Dublin. The sorting centres will accept qualified refugees, on demand of monopolies, and the rest, most of them, will be redirected. Quite simply, they will be deported back to the hell of the wars for which the European Union, the United States and NATO are responsible.  The joint patrols of Greece and Turkey are managed in the Aegean Sea, while the assignment to FRONTEX of a role of repression on refugees at the Greek-Macedonian and Greek-Albanian borders, and with the concentration of rapid intervention forces, means "keeping the sheep", that is, the European Union's borders abolishing all notions of a sovereign right.  Peoples can claim immediate measures to support refugees and fight imperialist interventions, EU repression mechanisms, marking the very capitalist system that breeds wars, poverty and refugees. (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, that is enough, our powerlessness, our contradictions, our hypocrisies, that is enough! Let us understand the lessons to be learned from the migration exodus that continues to rush to our doorstep. First lesson: the Union is unfit to deal with crisis situations, it is a problem of governance. Preparing to stop global warming in 2040, we know how to do. On the other hand, saving, sheltering, accompanying hundreds of thousands of refugees to our country, we do not know. We are dealing in a chaotic way with a chaotic crisis. Second lesson: financial problems. Again, promising $100 billion to cool the climate in twenty years, we are the best, but strengthening our border guards by a few hundred people, immediately the European Union does not have the means. In a few days we will adopt a 2016 Community budget with grossly inadequate resources. Europe! Everyone agrees to receive, but no one wants to give, neither rich countries, nor poor countries, nor large countries, nor small countries. Finally, the third lesson: political hypocrisy in all our countries, at all levels and almost in all our groups. Between our groups, it is an outbid on values: some evoke Judeo-Christian roots, others the philosophy of the Enlightenment and secularism, others the union of proletarians in all countries, and all of us, the universal declaration of human rights. But in election speeches and in the silence of polling stations, the defenders of these universal values leave women and children in indifference to suffer from the cold and hunger in our country, simply because they are other than us or they come from elsewhere.  It is time to put the spirits back in place and Europe on its feet. Thank you, President Juncker, for reminding us by your words and actions.

name: Preşedintele. –
text: We have two colleagues who asked for blue cards. I would very much ask you to understand the situation and move forward with the debate as we are very late. Do you accept this situation, Mr Breton and Mr. Leaf? Thank you very much. I know it's not exactly the right thing, but we have to compromise.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The European Union is a voluntary community, but its members are committed to shared sovereignty and shared responsibility. But old and new member states are always inclined to forget this and fall into national egoisms. But improved border controls must allow refugees legal access throughout the European Union. Those who want repatriations must first secure their individual right to asylum.  The reception capacities now planned for the registration of refugees can only work if, in a short period of time, the distribution is carried out to all European states, integration is organised and, at the same time, we improve the situation for refugees in other states. Incidentally, tax justice would also be a fundamentally important issue that we must address.  National selfishness is not the solution. The Member States must now act as a community of solidarity, as the European Union.

name: n/a
text: The only result of the mini-summit is that there will be 100 000 additional reception places along the Balkan route. Is that all? The exodus to Western Europe, including economic migrants, continues and is now merely better organised. The Commission wanted to set practical arrangements for short-term results. I would have liked to have suggested such a solution, namely pushbacks. Drives back are absolutely possible in accordance with European and international legal rules and case law. However, the conditions under which this may be possible have never been seriously investigated. Half a million people entered the EU via Greece in 2015 alone. Turkey is now using these asylum seekers as a currency for visa liberalisation or even EU accession. This in return for better monitoring of the EU coastline. And why? Because the EU can no longer or will not guard its external borders. The EU has a moral duty to stop attracting fortune-seekers through the de facto open borders policy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, at the last meetings of the Council of the European Union and the European Council, the mask of solidarity has finally fallen. The conclusions of this meeting, all of them, are in practice a guide on how to expel more and more effectively migrants from the European Union. It is said in all words that the strength of the example of repression must work against the undesirables, but the icing on the cake is when it is said that all measures must be taken to ensure the effective return of irregular migrants, including detention as a legitimate measure of last resort — that is, they treat migrants in the same way they treat criminals. This is exactly what the UN has criticised in the Czech Republic, and it is not clear what the Council differs from these measures. We also do not know what is happening with the EUNAVFOR MED military mission, but there are reports of migrants whose boats have been attacked by military forces, and migrants have been targeted. Urgent clarification on the role of these military missions is needed to know exactly what is happening on the ground.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President of the Commission, Mr President of the European Council, on 11 and 12 November you will be travelling to Valletta for a summit on migration. But make no mistake, the planned discussions on economic development or the organisation of legal immigration channels will be marginal at best, at worst the object of outrageous haggling. Unable to envisage a common approach to reception, the European Union and, in particular, some of its Member States persist in militarising their borders and dubious agreements with authoritarian leaders.  This summit should not be a strengthening of the Khartoum process. The exploitation and trafficking of migrants will not stop by subcontracting our borders to others or by launching perilous military operations against smugglers. The opening of legal and safe routes for migration, both for migrants and refugees, is an emergency. To avoid tragedy, we must change our policies and build on solidarity.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, when I hear the Council's conclusions and the statements of many Members here, It occurs to me that fake humanism is Europe's big problem. You who supported the regime's turmoil in Syria, in Libya, were really interested in the welfare of those people, or were you just trying to unseat evil dictators and show the world how humane you are? Those of you who have opened your arms to migrants and given them generous support really want these people to be better off, or do you just want to show the world and yourself how humane you are? The Council is now talking in its conclusions about wanting to strengthen the protection of the external border, but it was your Government Members who voted here a month ago to criticise the monitoring of the external border. So it seems to me very cheap from the comfort of the European Parliament to criticise border control. I'm afraid the big problem here is fake humanism.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The current migration of peoples from the African continent to Europe is one of the few examples where a strong international community really needs to be built, which, firstly, ensures that peace can take place in the region. Secondly, the first reception centres guarantee protection and assistance for people in need of protection and assistance in the region and, thirdly, create safe zones in the region – that would be the task of a strong international community.  The European Union is doing exactly the opposite: one gets the impression that the decision-makers of the European Union are swaying around almost like a heap of chickens and are unable to make a clear decision here.  The two who caused all the chaos, Chancellor Merkel, who said, towards Arabia and Africa, you can all come, and then the Austrian Chancellor Faymann, who is all smuggling through Austria, are the main culprits. I say that those who recognise that everyone has a priority obligation to look after their own compatriots in their own country, not a migration of peoples, are making really good policies (the President is taking the floor from the speaker.)

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the slow pace with which we are facing a crisis in which human lives are at stake is desperate. It is desperating to be faced with another Council meeting talking again about the same thing, without anything having changed. The refugee crisis is becoming a real institutional crisis. Member States do not implement the measures proposed by the Commission. We do not have, nor are we working on a common immigration and asylum policy. We're not dealing with the problem of war. Instead of securing external borders, we build new interior walls. We hope that third countries will solve our problems urgently and at any cost, and we spend the meetings blaming each other for what we do or what we stop doing. The question that many citizens are asking the very few people when they look at the European institutions is: "Don't you know, are you not able to? Our slowness in dealing with the problem is causing anti-Europeans to be right, to grow nationalism, to grow separation, to grow hatred of foreigners. The refugee crisis began as a humanitarian problem and is now becoming a real political problem. The European institutions seem to want to take no more refugees and, at the same time, not get involved in the war that drives them. Or, in other words, that others have refugees and others deal with the war that causes refugees to have to flee. Until we understand that the war that drives refugees is also a war against the European Union, that the war against Syrians is also a war against Europeans, we will not begin to solve the refugee problem or solve europe's problem. Refugees and Europeans have the same war against us. It's time we realized.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am very pleased with this initiative by the Commission, which needs all our support. I have travelled several times in these weeks on the Balkan route, in Gevgelija, Presevo and passau. When you see people, you see exhausted people, desperate people, you see a lot of hustle and bustle, you see an eerie pace. In Passau alone, 7 000 people cross the border every day. This looks like an exodus. I believe that we urgently need to calm the pace, we need to calm these developments. My main concern here is that we provide immediate and generous aid in the countries of origin, that we organise the hotspots at the external borders efficiently and in accordance with human rights, and that we urgently create winter-proof quarters along the Balkan route.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – I consider the protection of external borders to be one of the priorities of the refugee crisis. An example of effective cooperation in this area is the joint sending of police forces to Hungary carried out by the V4 countries. Turkey's role in the influx of refugees into Europe is crucial. However, let us be right, financial and humanitarian aid to Turkey should have come clearly sooner. The European Union must not retreat from its fundamental values or formulate a political agreement with Turkey. Turkey is calling for the accession process to be accelerated, but it is unacceptable that we should trade the rules that each of the Member States had to comply with. Why, in the recent past, German Chancellor Angela Merkel has proposed a so-called privileged partnership to Turkey instead of Turkey's real accession to the EU, and today, under pressure and panic, we are changing that attitude. Let us offer Turkey what it needs to stop migratory flows to Europe, but let us not modify our sensible approach. The state of human rights or freedom of the media is sufficient evidence of whether or not a country wants to meet the accession criteria.

name: n/a
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I wonder how many more years the Commission and the Council will be discussing how to deal with this unprecedented humanitarian crisis. In the face of this harsh reality, the tragic reality, we watched yesterday's farce of the mini-summit. The conclusions we are debating today do not stand up to any criticism and are an insult to the millions of refugees, to the thousands of dead, but of course also to European culture, and the humanitarian crisis has revealed the nakedness of European policy.  Germany openly wants to turn the South, and especially Greece, into a vast concentration camp, thereby reinforcing closed-border policies within the European Union. At the same time, it plays dangerous destabilisation games with Turkey, at the expense of both European enlargement policy and Greek sovereign rights. Only those who blindly do not realise that the European edifice reveals its flimsy foundation. I have said before, then, that the humanitarian crisis goes far beyond the dilemma of which Europe we want. If we continue with this policy, there simply will be no Europe.

name: Janice Atkinson (ENF).
text: – Mr President, the Left and Mr Pittella today reached a new low in this House by calling us a virus. Then we have Mr Schulz, who seems to think it is wrong to protect national interests. I was actually sent here to protect our national interest, and actually the people of Britain will vote to leave this place, because they recognise that our national interests are not being served in this place. Mr Juncker: when in doubt, have a summit. Of course, we must have a summit, and the man from Luxembourg comes along, too. Now it is great that the man from Luxembourg comes along to talk about migration – but nobody, not one single migrant, is banging on the door to get into Luxembourg. I go to Calais quite a lot, and now the number of migrants in Calais trying to get into the UK has doubled to 6 000. I said it before: the majority of these people are not refugees. They are economic migrants. Interjection regarding an apparent lack of French interpretation. Well it does not matter. I will carry on, because my audience is Britain. As I said before, these people are not refugees; they are economic migrants. The main concern of the migrants is not safety, but economic gain. In Calais, the majority of people storming the tunnel are aggressive young men. I was on Eurostar yesterday, and when I entered France there were a number of migrants sitting on the tracks on this side. The police did not detain them, they did not deport them, and that is wrong. That is why this place is going to crumble.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, As an Italian, I would like to point out that Italy has been little appointed today and a little too forgotten, and I would like to say that ours are really small skirmishes in the face of the huge problem we are facing.  I am deeply convinced of what Mr Juncker said, that our resources are not unlimited. That is why our solidarity cannot be unlimited. Although that is right, we urgently need to address this urgency and we must put in place everything that has been promised. However, whether those who say sealed borders win, or if solidarity is won without limit, we will not seriously tackle the problem and Europe will end up crumbling, because this is only one step in what we must do: the immediate emergency. But there is the geopolitical problem: if we look at the routes, if we look at where they start, we understand that we need to stabilize and we have to work to ensure that migrants are put in a position to live in their places of origin. We must ensure assistance and stability. We must prevent the systematic emptying of entire regions that are at risk of desertification, not only because of climate change, but are at risk of cultural desertification. Culture is the great absentee.  So I want to bring you back to this House in the words of a great Italian, Pier Paolo Pasolini, who in the 1960s was a prophet and spoke of "Blue-eyed Ali": "Blue-eyed ali will descend from Algiers on sailing and rowing ships, millions of men will be with him, they will disembark in Crotone or Palmi in their millions, dressed in rags". It was the vision of a great Italian man in the 1960s, but it seems the description of what is happening today. We must give serious, true, profound and lasting answers.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D).
text: – The 17 points on the Western Balkans route I think is an important achievement. It demonstrates that a common European policy based on cooperation and solidarity can be effective despite all difficulties, while a policy based on fences, selfish lock-in and rejection is doomed to failure. At the same time, we all know that we only took the first steps on Sunday – and I am not thinking, in particular, of further border protection actions and measures. The biggest challenge for the next period will be the rapid and effective integration of immigrants and refugees. We need inclusion, social inclusion, not forced cultural assimilation. We need language learning, education, training, social care. And money, a lot of money! It is not the protection of Christian Europe that should be emphasised, it is not the need to create fear, but the need for effective and well-coordinated joint integration programmes. Until we achieve this, until the European Union has a common integration strategy, we will not be able to move forward.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Dear Colleagues, The migration issue, this crisis situation, has been on the agenda of our plenary sessions for months. Meanwhile, migratory pressures have intensified and confusion has increased. The way I see it, in the current worsening situation, we need innovative solutions and responsible action. In order to truly express our solidarity, in order to truly help those in genuine need, we need to put an end to the policy of open borders and unrestricted admission. It's time for straight talk without hypocrisy. The rapid two consecutive Council meetings have shown that if we do not finally identify the most pressing short- and medium-term tasks and the immediate action taken to them, the situation will become unmanageable. Today, the Balkan route is proof of this, and tomorrow more and more Member States are facing a similar crisis at their borders. It was finally time to say the facts and things that have been hanging in the air since August. For example, a few weeks ago, the Hungarian Prime Minister was threatened with ostracism when he dared to say that the protection of the external borders should take precedence, that a distinction should be made between a refugee who is entitled to refugee status and an economic immigrant – and that the latter should be returned. You have to register your passes, you can't get them from one border to another. Nor can the migrant choose where he or she will be prosecuted. We cannot solve the problem within Europe until we secure our borders and tell who and how many people can come in. This is also a condition for safeguarding the Schengen system, one of the union's greatest achievements. At the same time, refugee camps must be helped locally. That is where access to education and work must be ensured. After all, real refugees are in these camps, waiting to return to their homes. Our citizens expect responsible, decisive action, and I am pleased that the Madrid Congress of the People's Party has all this in its resolution.

name: Președintele. –
text: Thank you, Mrs. Gál. I remember, speaking of the route, that someone told me that this route was also used by the armies that besieged Vienna in the late 1600s.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President; fast, urgent, immediate: I don't know what the point of these words makes for some in this House. We are already, some, tired of the hypocrisy of hearing some MEPs talk about solidarity here, while their governments are acting nefariously in managing this crisis. Because it was a month ago that it was decided to share the quotas for refugees, and yesterday, Mr Rajoy's government, to give an example, announced that it was sending officials to participate in a pilot project and to take in the first fifty refugees. If we weren't talking about such a serious thing, I'd think it was a joke. But everything has its explanation. Mr Orbán's image at the Congress of the European People's Party in Madrid, cheered, applauded, when he made such reactionary statements against refugees and immigration, makes a very clear sense. Stop fooling around, because we're killing the lives of hundreds of thousands of refugees.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, I, as a Croat, am concerned about the situation of how to reconcile the national egoisms and European cohesion that Mr. Tusk spoke about this morning. It is good that a meeting was called on Sunday where all the leaders of the Balkan countries were and it should not be surprising to Mr Juncker, I am sorry that he is not here, that the leaders could not find themselves alone.  You must know that this situation in the Countries of the Western Balkans exceeds the capacity of these countries and it is good that they were invited under the auspices of the European Commission. I agree that instead of internal borders, we should guard the external borders. I also agree with Mr. Gonzáles, who said that the war against Syria is a war against the European Union, and until we solve the problems at the starting point, we will not solve the problem of migration. I'm totally in agreement with that. Also, I support the action plan.  Turkey needs to be helped, because unless we help Turkey, we will also not be able to resolve the situation further. There may be chaos, winter is coming, if we do not start implementing the decisions taken by the European Council and the European Commission. I agree that Member States must implement the decisions that have been taken unless we want chaos to occur. And we as politicians have a task and citizens expect us to do that, solve problems. And so I ask you to finally get serious and understand the seriousness of the destabilisation of the European project.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we should indeed understand the gravity of the situation. It is important that, whatever our political views, we do not give up on the European Union for a well-organised and compassionate response. It is the reason why Commissioner Avramopoulos and the Committee on Budgets will meet with us in a few minutes after the votes: we have to do something. We have to take action.  It is right that the Commission convened the West Balkan summit. It did so with a lot of criticism, but the chaos has to be resolved. People are suffering as winter comes. We will see more deaths and this Parliament will call for action. So action has to be taken, and that means that this Parliament must do its work. After all the talk is finished, we will have to do the work, we will have to get the financial instruments and we will have to ensure that the hotspots work. Commissioner, my interest is to ensure that those hotspots and reception centres work. They would have worked if the asylum conditions had been created over the past years and Member States had done it then. So we have to do it now. We have to get on with it and we have to make it work in the next few weeks.

name: Μανώλης Κεφαλογιάννης (
text: PPE). Mr President, there was an important meeting in the Council. There has been an increase in the reception capacity of refugees to 100,000, along the entire balkan corridor, from the Greek border to Austria's border with Germany. Greece alone was given the opportunity, i.e. Greece agreed to have 50,000 more refugees and to create hot spots for the refugee registration and identification centre. So welcome 30,000 refugees and provide for another 20,000 refugees, with a rent subsidy and the support of the UNHCR. What was missing from the meeting is Turkey, the joint action, the joint action programme with Turkey, far from eastern bazaars, even in the run-up to elections in Turkey. The meeting with the African states was missing.  It's important that Mr. Tusk and Mr. Juncker announced the meeting in Valletta. I think he has a great deal to offer in our joint effort. But mostly the rich Arab states are missing, with the exception of Lebanon and Jordan. In Saudi Arabia alone, ladies and gentlemen, there are facilities with tents ready for 3 million refugees. We are all judged, the European Union is judged. We are judged if we have done our duty ... (The President interrupts the speaker).

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, Europe - in what everyone calls a crisis - gives the impression of suffering and not of controlling an evolution that is at its doorstep.  Who is interested in the situation in Syria? Who says that the need for such a massive influx of refugees today is because in Syria the Islamic State is making progress? Who says that it is not with Mr al-Assad that we can find a solution? Who says that we are not able to agree on the European Union's relationship with Russia? So, Commissioner, tell the President of the Commission that he must act because, otherwise, there are only interdependencies between us, there is no solidarity. In exactly the same way that we have made economic and monetary union without an economic pillar, we have made Schengen without an asylum policy, without a European refugee and asylum protection office, without a migration policy, without external border protection.  I ask the President of the Commission to open up the work and to carry out a strong initiative, not to point the finger at the Council's responsibilities, but to enable us to give Europe its voice back in this matter.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Above all, this debate is a mirror to us. If we are all no longer able to see people in the crowd, then we have lost the European values that we constantly rely on. We can't let that happen. But to show mercy with those people who need us and need protection, and to be able to show solidarity with the countries that take in the most refugees, you also have to dare to be very clear. And clarity is also in all honesty to someone saying, "You don't need our protection" and then arrange a decent return. Clarity is also saying: 'Yes, people, this is going to cost effort and money' and not as the Member States do: make commitments but then do not get over the bridge and pretend that it is all for free and, above all, for nothing. The solidarity and humanity that we hear here in most of this house will come under pressure if we are unable to guard our borders. That is why I am pleased that the President of the Commission is saying that he will quickly come forward with a proposal for a European coastguard. That is why I welcome all the cooperation that has been established with neighbouring countries, including financially, although I doubt that, for example, you should link Turkey's accession process to the discussion on refugees. I don't think so. But let's get to work now, the elements are there and do it in all honesty and in all clarity.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D).
text: – Chair, Sur Kummissarju, fis-summit tal-pajjiżi Balkan dehret bl-aktar mod d-tensjoni li teżisti fl-Unjoni Ewropea, meta suppost dan għandu jkun il-mument fejn l-Unjoni Ewropea t magkunħquda u titkellem b'vuħi waħda. Il-"Valletta Summit" li se jsir fi ftit jiem oħra huwa opportunità tad-deheb għall-Unjoni Ewropea biex tiftaħ diskussjoni kostruttiva mal-Unjoni Afrikana li tista' twassal għal riżultati conckreti. L-influssi ta' migrazzjoni huma riżultat tal-gwerer, l-instabilità, il-faqar, il-qgħad u l-ksur tad-drittijiet umani li għadhom rampanti f'ħjji pajjiżi Afrikani u Għarab. L-Unjoni Ewropea trid ta大大erta ruħha li l-għajnuna li tagħti, twassal biex jinbidlu l-affarijiet. Irridu nkunu sodi meta nitolbu flower-mexxejja ta' dawn il-pajjiżi biex jaraw li l-ewwel u qabel kollox jagħtu prijorità lin-nies tagħhom. Hemm bżonn li f'dan il-mument, l-Unjoni Ewropea titkellem b'vuħda u b'saħħitha jekk verament irridu nindirizzaw is-sitwazzjoni bis-serjetà u b'mod li nagħmlu differenza.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Mr President, with regard to the Council conclusions and, in particular, also at this summit which was now at the weekend with the countries essentially linked to the Balkans and the reception of refugees, I would like two principles to be made clear. The first is that this is a European responsibility, and this is how all the countries of the European Union should see this issue, which means that we all have an obligation to receive refugees and that we all have an obligation to participate in the financial effort to help the countries from which refugees come from, as well as to the countries that are the border that receives the impact of the first refugees. But it is also certain, and this is the second principle, that this solidarity must be done with discretion: we must not confuse migrants with refugees, and therefore we must make this separation and screening, precisely in the reception camps and hotspots, and we must work to do this with the countries that are on the front line, whether they are members of the European Union or not. So this is a responsibility that we have and we must also leave to all the countries of the European Union. I would also like to say that, from our point of view, it is absolutely essential that we also do some prevention work, particularly with regard to sub-Saharan Africa. In addition to the points that are now the hottest points and deserve an urgent response, we will have, in the long term, very strong movements of sub-Saharan Africa.

name: Ms. Marlene Mizzi
text: – Sur President, il-migrazzjoni hija s-sintomu u mhux il-kawża, u sakemm mhux se nindirizzaw il-kawża mill-għerq din il-problema se tibqa' u se tiżdied. L-instabilità economics, soèjali in politics, gwerer, ksur tad-drittijiet tal-bniedem in attakki terroristièi huma ftit mir-raġunijiet li jikkawżaw is-sintomi. L-Istati Membri, l-Unjoni Afrikana, in-Nazzjonijiet Uniti at oħrajn ser ikollhom opportunità unika waqt il-Valletta Summit sabiex jikkolaboraw biex tinstab soluzzjoni internazzjonali at ġenwina għall-kriżi tal-migrazzjoni, you tista' sseħħ biss jekk tinżamm l-attenzjoni fuq il-kawża fundamentali tal-migrazzjoni. Inħeġġeġ għalhekk lill-Istati Membri biex l-EU African Summit fil-Belt Valletta, ġo pajjiżi, ġo Malta, jintuża bħala pjattaforma sabiex tiġi żviluppata strateġija li tirreaġixxi għall-isfidi umani, soèjali in politièi li sfortunatament qed jisforzaw in-nies li jaħarbu minn djarhom in qed jikkawżaw exodus mill-Afrika għall-Ewropa. M'hemmx soluzzjoni one size fits all. Iżda nħeġġeġ lill-parteèipanti biex jiffokaw kif lil dawn in-nies jagħtuhom futur ġo pajjiżhom biex b'hekk ma jkollhomx jitilqu upper jiikolaw ħajjithom ifittxu futur dinjituż ġo pajjiżhom. Sphinx kbira in strateġija fit-tul, vera, iżda jekk ma nibdewx illum qabel għada, din il-problema se tibqa' magħna għal the day in se tikber.

name: Glenis Willmott (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on behalf of British Labour MEPs, I welcome any cooperation with Turkey and other countries that can help better manage the current crisis. You have heard the cynical voices from some in this House, but they will never seek solutions. Instead, they will only seek to use this tragic situation for political gain. National leaders who have reached this deal must take on their responsibilities to deliver their own agreement. This crisis is a continuing nightmare for all those families forced to walk mile upon mile to reach shelter and food for their children. These are people just like us: they are human beings. It is not a political game. Talking of which, I note that at the Council meeting there was a short discussion on the terms of the UK’s negotiations and referendum, so I will use this opportunity to warn Prime Minister Cameron: there can be no more delay. This is too important. He now needs to join us in securing a future that Britain deserves: a future inside the European Union.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, let me use this opportunity to thank the European Commission for its commitment to find practical solutions to this huge challenge we are all facing. I welcome the action plan that was developed jointly with Turkey, as Turkey and the EU need each other to share the burden of providing safe havens for so many people fleeing war. So we urgently need to discuss further about financial support, resettlement, the effective return of economic migrants and fighting smugglers. I nevertheless do reject the linkage of cooperation on refugees to the EU accession process, as these issues are unrelated. Postponing the progress report on Turkey without any explanation gives the impression that the EU is avoiding being critical on the human rights situation ahead of important elections. That gives a totally wrong signal. The EU should not stop expressing its concerns on the freedom of the press or the situation of the Kurdish minority.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I shall start from the words of Mr Juncker, who said to us: 'The problems of some are the problems of others'. It's the basic principle of every unit, every community, and I think that applies in life as well as in institutions.  Europe will only stand if it leans on this foundation of solidarity. There is no other way, because today it is the problems of refugees that divide us, tomorrow it will be others, if the approach is not unified.  I come from a country that has been left alone for too long, to make the same mistake today towards Slovenia, towards Greece, towards other countries. And I know that the tide of people today in the mud of balkan land routes is the same as it has been for hours, for days, under the scorching Sun of the Mediterranean. We therefore call on the Council, Mr Tusk, to ask you, in your leading role, and we call on the Commission to do everything necessary, step by step, action after action, to make concrete action, to give concrete answers.  But we also have to get to the root of the problem. As my group leader Pittella said, we need to change the paradigm with Africa: the African Union, african countries, gulf countries must be called to a common responsibility. If global is destabilization, global must also be the answer.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, I come from Croatia, where over 250,000 people have entered in the last month. Everyone was provided with healthcare, food and organised transport. All without the use of force, the burning of camps and the militarization of borders. Statements about deliberately driving refugees into rivers have been completely deplased. It is a desperate move by people who could not but cross the border over the bridge to Slovenia.  Sunday's deal is in theory good, but how it will work if 10,000 people head for Europe again and one country on the route limits admission to 2,500. This crisis did not arise in the Western Balkans, nor can it be resolved there until the bloc's external border with Turkey is under control. In doing so, registration should be an obligation, not an option.  Instead of calling out, let's turn to cooperation. The European Union needs to find a sustainable common response to the problem. Otherwise, we cannot expect countries exposed to the crisis to assume their own security with a common European policy that it does not actually have.

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Mr President, the day before yesterday we were presented with the 19-point agreement, which is very important if it succeeds in finally being implemented, because it is the timid and late answers that have raised the problem in the host societies and which are making xenophobia flare up. But we must again warn you: without a permanent relocation mechanism, refugees will not sit in reception centres for three days, if they can become prisons, and without asylum applications in European offices in Turkey and permanent roads, safe access roads, will not stop drownings in the Aegean.  There is an answer: Tilos, a small island, lost in the Eastern Aegean, forgotten by God and government, without a doctor and a teacher. But Tilos asked for a hundred Syrian refugee families to settle permanently on the island. There is leadership there, there is a community leader who shows the path of solidarity and the inhabitants are organized and followed.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (
text: PPE). Mr President, at the small summit on 25 October it was decided, inter alia, to host 30 000 refugees in Greece by the end of the year and another 20 000 with a rent subsidy from the European Union.  In a country in its sixth year in an economic crisis with nightmarish unemployment, no food, no clothing, no care can be provided to these people, but only problems with unforeseen consequences. This decision, moreover, invalidates in practice the measure of relocation of 64,400 refugees from Greece, which has been in force since last October. A serious approach to refugees means responsible cooperation with Turkey, which is a transit country, to respect the readmission agreements signed, but above all to effectively control the networks of smugglers exploiting the waves of migrants to Europe, otherwise the refugee issue risks proving to be a ticking time bomb on the foundations of the European Union. (applause)

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all, let us stop the nonsense about the ‘coup d’état’ in Portugal. I noted that Mr Weber said that he was concerned about the prospect of a fully democratically-based left coalition in my country as a result of the elections. Apparently he does not worry about the prospect of a xenophobic, anti-European extreme right wing government in Poland. At least in Portugal we are ready to receive refugees. That has been stated by all the authorities and entities involved in the reception. But the fact is that the relocation process is not working at European level. They are not coming. I hope that at least the Valletta Summit will be an opportunity for our leaders to realise what they have been told here in this Parliament, namely that, without opening safe and legal avenues for refugees and migrants, they will continue to feed business into the criminal gangs. Without working strategically to end the conflicts in Syria and Libya and to defeat the terrorists of ISIS in Iraq and Turkey, the EU will not be addressing the root causes of why refugees have to flee, and they will keep coming. This is not a refugee crisis. It is a truly European crisis because we are failing in our duties to protect those in need. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jozo Radoš (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I welcome the agreement reached on Sunday because it will allow refugees to suffer less and help countries that are on their route, including my country Croatia, which has recently received and has seen more than 200,000 refugees.  But these measures will not prevent refugees from coming to the European Union, as this is not possible without the active use of force that I hope Europe will not decide to do. A more permanent solution is a deal with Turkey that will certainly be difficult both financially and politically. And the really permanent solution is to influence sources of crisis resolution in the Middle East and North Africa. Unfortunately, the European Union does not even have plans for this solution.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, I have followed the whole debate for about three hours. In all honesty, I tell you that, if I were a refugee, an immigrant, and I listened to this debate, I would literally try to find my way to the Aegean, to go and kill myself: from the inexpensive rhetoric of defending the rights of refugees, to mr. Juncker, who did not mention any substantive proposal for an immediate solution to the problem.  I will say two words about Turkey: I fully understand the willingness to cooperate, but from the willingness to cooperate to going on to say that Turkey is a safe country, after the bombing – not to mention the hundreds of other dead of turkey's other bombings or attacks against the Kurds – the hundredth of a hundred dead in Ankara, to calling this country safe in order to drive the problem out of our own backyard, goes too far.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the interventions by Presidents Tusk and Juncker explain the truth: that of the absence of the European Union in political terms. We are shocked by the border fights between some and the other Balkan countries and hear accusations between political groups in this House. But the real scandal occurs not in the Balkans, but in Western Europe, in the great and powerful members of the European Union. The one who is failing is not the Europe of the twenty-eight, it is the Europe of fifteen. If the only coincidence is border protection and refugee registration, we are 5% of the problem. Haven't we heard and understood the message refugees are sending us yet? They call us loud and strong: "It's Europe, stupid" —It's Europe. So let us act as Europeans. Let's start with a global relocation plan. Just as we will provide European border guards, let us already enable European basic fields and services in France, Germany, Spain, United Kingdom, Netherlands, Luxembourg, Sweden. Let us provide existence and political responsibility to the European Union.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Reception centres, hotspots, common border guards, louder, so far empty keywords! The fact is that the Union has failed and fallen asleep. No protection of the external borders! Schengen has failed. A loss of confidence among our citizens, which is catastrophic. State sovereignty is destroyed when more than 1 million refugees illegally flock to Central Europe, largely uncontrolled and unregistered. Ladies and gentlemen, this is an invasion, this is a land grab! For 70%-80% are young men, as harbingers for their families, in search of the promised land, mainly in Germany, Austria, Sweden and cetera. And that is no wonder, with a minimum security that is more than the average academic salary in Syria or Afghanistan. Ladies and gentlemen, this is an avalanche, good words, kind words will not help. Clear action must be taken.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, since the beginning of the migration crisis I have been appealing to EU leaders to include the Western Balkan countries in its solution. These countries are directly affected by a flow of refugees and migrants passing through the Balkan route. In order to solve this crisis we need to find a mode of tighter cooperation with them. We also need to be careful to prevent the creation of other crises in this region. Financial support has so far been limited and our response came quite late. I am glad that the summit on Sunday tackled these issues. I welcome the basic plan and concrete actions instead of building walls. In order to manage the migration flow we must cooperate closely on border management, fight human trafficking, share information and help in providing the necessary humanitarian assistance. I think managing this crisis together is also a chance to better prepare these countries for future EU membership.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: – I would like to pay tribute to the Commission's position in this situation and overall in terms of tackling the refugee crisis. What I think is more to consider and criticise is the attitude of some Member States than they were not prepared to deal with this crisis. Last but not least, Commissioner, I would like to mention one topic that is directly affecting the resolution of the refugee crisis, namely the rise of extremism, radicalism and fascism in the Member States of the European Union. We are beginning to witness not only mass demonstrations by extremists and radicals, but also repeated attacks on facilities where refugees are located and where we are trying to help them. I would therefore like to appeal to the Member States, not to us, to Parliament, not to the Commission, but to the Member States, to be much more proactive in combating the rise of radicalism and fascism in their countries.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! Perhaps the few remaining colleagues who continue their private discussions here in plenary could also take their seats. That would be very polite. With the best of intentions, I cannot imagine that the last ten speakers here have caught anyone's attention. A parliamentary debate is for colleagues to be able to make their speeches and for other Members to listen to them. That was certainly not the case with the last ten speakers in this House, which I find unfair.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members of Parliament, today President Juncker gave a strong message on the Commission’s actions and support in order to address the refugee crisis. We are committed. I noticed here today strong support from almost all of you for our initiatives. We really need this support from the European Parliament, and what we have achieved so far is thanks to this support. We need it also from different States inside and outside the European Union, and we have to help them as well. Sunday’s mini-summit, as it was called, is positive, as States along the Balkans route came to the same table, and the dialogue now is open – but several used their own national narrative. I have to admit there is still not a full European spirit of cooperation. More cooperation, more solidarity, more responsibility are needed, and now we need actions – not only commitments. It is now; implementation is key. This is also the message I got from you here. Implement and do even more on border management, on protection of asylum seekers in an organised way, and on cooperation within countries outside Europe. The role of the Commission has changed with this crisis. Constant monitoring, dialogue and support, and initiatives in a more strategic way and scope, are needed. This is also why the Commission work programme will have to give some answers in relation to borders, Dublin, resettlement, legal migration and relocation already on the table. They are all key, because we cannot afford to fail. Let us not forget that the refugee crisis is used in multiple ways in internal national debates and public opinion. The only solution is to explain to our citizens: to explain to people the need for a common approach at different levels and to demonstrate the supportive role of the Commission to the Member States and neighbouring countries affected. I am fully committed and ready to cooperate with Members in the different countries, directly or indirectly involved: European, African and Asian countries, including on our policy on returns. I had planned to go to Pakistan tomorrow, but because of the terrible earthquake I have postponed it until next week. But I will go there and discuss with the Pakistani authorities the readmission policy and their commitments in that. Members of Parliament, the refugee crisis is a catalyst for more Europe. It is a crash test for Europe. It is a test of credibility of our principles and the capability of our institutions, and this is what the Commission is doing by having put migration at the top of its priorities from the very first day, taking the necessary initiatives like the Balkan Route Summit last Sunday, standing by the Member States in need, in order to give value and substantial content to the principles of solidarity and responsibility, and enhancing the unity of the Union.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, of course I share the concerns of this Chamber: the realisation of decisions undertaken during this crisis is not going as quickly as is necessary. This is the time when regular procedures in all the Member States should be replaced by emergency procedures. Awareness of this fact is not dominant, unfortunately, in all the Member States. I am convinced that this will happen and I would like to assure you that the Luxembourg Presidency is ready to support the efforts of the Commission in acquiring human and financial resources indispensable to tackling this crisis.  But let us also be fair. Contributions to the World Food Programme, UNHCR and other agencies exceed what has been pledged so far and this is not the easiest time for governments to spend fresh money today as you can imagine; it is maybe the most difficult one.  Let us remember when it comes to relocation that there are today eight times more places prepared for refugees to be relocated than refugees who want to make use of them. But most importantly, we are still working on the common view when it comes to the methods and the purpose of protecting external borders.  From the beginning of this crisis I have underlined that our clear aim should be a significant containment of the migration tide. But the opinion that it is impossible and that Europe should accept nearly all who want to come here is still being voiced. There have also been comments about refugee treatment in some Member States by the police. We heard accusations that human rights have been violated. I want to state very firmly that human rights are threatened mainly when the law is not enforced. Those people are fleeing countries where there is no police and no administration at all. The condition for respecting human rights is the protection of the legal order and enforcement of rules. In fact, this general remark refers to all these issues we are discussing here in the context of the migratory crisis.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. – Fast, urgent, immediate: I don't know what the point of these words makes for some in this House. We are already, some, tired of the hypocrisy of hearing some Members speak of solidarity here, while their governments are acting nefariously in managing this crisis. It has been a month since the refugee quota-sharing was decided, and yesterday, Mr Rajoy's government, to give an example, announced the sending of officials to participate in a pilot project and take in the first fifty refugees. If we weren't talking about such a serious thing, I'd think it was a joke. But everything has its explanation. Mr Orbán's image at the Congress of the European People's Party in Madrid, cheered, applauded, when he made such reactionary statements against refugees and immigration, makes a very clear sense. Stop fooling around, because we're killing the lives of hundreds of thousands of refugees.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. We call on the European Commission and the Member States to join forces and to achieve a genuine common asylum policy. European asylum policy must be based on solidarity and the right to asylum for those who need our protection, and on the other hand, a responsible return policy for those who are not fleeing war or persecution. It is normal that we now really focus on those who need our help most. The proposals put forward by Jean-Claude Juncker for this purpose are concrete and effective. It is now up to the Member States, thanks to European resources and seconded European staff, to quickly implement the European Agenda on Migration, to speed up asylum procedures, to support the construction of reception camps and to develop a coordinated return policy. We also need to work quickly on a common European coastal and border guard to guard the external borders.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. On the current migration situation, the European Council calls for addressing the migrant and refugee crisis in a 'spirit of solidarity'. He wants to commit the UNION to more cooperation with Turkey and increased financial support even as Erdogan's regime indirectly supports the Islamic State and has no control over its migration flows. Worse, the Council encourages them to take in refugees, find them a job and give them access to education until "return to their country of origin is possible", which is a pipe dream since we know that there will be few returns and that immigrants settled in Europe will remain there.  The only immigration policy is to adopt a firm attitude, like Australia, and remove all the suction pumps and reception facilities that are open doors to the Union and its Member States.  Finally, on Syria, I denounce the attitude of the Council, which, in trying to fight against Bashar al-Assad and the Islamic State, remains in total inaction when it would be more urgent to cooperate with the regime in place to stop Daesh.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. – Fast, urgent, immediate: I don't know what the point of these words makes for some in this House. We are already, some, tired of the hypocrisy of hearing some MEPs talk about solidarity here, while their governments are acting nefariously in managing this crisis. It has been a month since the refugee quota-sharing was decided, and yesterday, Mr Rajoy's government, to give an example, announced the sending of officials to participate in a pilot project and take in the first fifty refugees. If we weren't talking about such a serious thing, I'd think it was a joke. But everything has its explanation. Mr Orbán's image at the Congress of the European People's Party in Madrid, cheered, applauded, when he made such reactionary statements against refugees and immigration, makes a very clear sense. Stop fooling around, because we're killing the lives of hundreds of thousands of refugees.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. I would like to confirm my support for the Commission's initiative, particularly in view of the concrete and operational measures that it is endeavouring to put in place despite the well-known difficulties of dialogue between the Member States. It is important to implement in practice, right from the start, the 17 points of the plan drawn up on Sunday at the meeting of the leaders of the Member States affected by the Balkan route, to provide for the creation of further points of crisis and reception, especially in view of the approaching winter and therefore the increasingly imminent risk of a humanitarian catastrophe, and to facilitate the constant connection and transfer of information between states. We must, of course, continue with relocation and with a fair sharing of responsibilities, including financial responsibilities, throughout the Union.  We welcome the fact that at last recognition is given to the efforts made, especially by certain countries, including Italy, to deal with the migration emergency, also with a view to greater flexibility with regard to the constraints imposed by the Stability Pact. We are paying particular attention to the forthcoming Summit in Valletta. Dialogue with African Heads of State or Government may send important signals of a finally forward-looking approach to this issue.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – Fast, urgent, immediate: I don't know what the point of these words makes for some in this House. We are already, some, tired of the hypocrisy of hearing some MEPs talk about solidarity here, while their governments are acting nefariously in managing this crisis. It has been a month since the refugee quota-sharing was decided, and yesterday, Mr Rajoy's government, to give an example, announced the sending of officials to participate in a pilot project and take in the first fifty refugees. If we weren't talking about such a serious thing, I'd think it was a joke. But everything has its explanation. Mr Orbán's image at the Congress of the European People's Party in Madrid, cheered, applauded, when he made such reactionary statements against refugees and immigration, makes a very clear sense. Stop fooling around, because we're killing the lives of hundreds of thousands of refugees.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the emergency meeting convened by Juncker on 25 October has finally taken decisions beneficial to the Member States, namely a plan with 17 operational measures. One of the most important is that it "reaffirms the principle of denying entry to third-country nationals who do not agree to apply for international protection". It is well known that migrants do not register in eu peripheral countries because they wish to reach the highly developed northern Member States of the Union. I hope that this measure will discourage migrants and traffickers and reduce the flow of illegal migrants. The other very important measure, which unfortunately does not bind Turkey because it was not invited to the meeting, is "to discourage the movement of refugees and migrants to the borders of other countries or regions without informing those countries". We all know very well that it is Turkey that massively organises the trafficking and flow of migrants to the European Union. The European Union must urge the Turkish authorities to limit the activities of traffickers to the maximum, to cooperate in the fight against them, and to properly implement the readmission treaty signed with the Union. This is the only way Turkey can prove that it deserves to be a partner of the European Union.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – In the face of the humanitarian drama of the refugee crisis, in the face of the hundreds of thousands of people fleeing chaos and war in their countries – chaos and war, it is not too much to remind you, in which the EU has direct responsibilities, for the destabilisation and aggression actions it has supported and in which it has participated. The EU had already decided that the solution was to erect the walls of Fortress Europe higher. Now the European Council decides to add barbed wire to these walls. The Conclusions of the European Council all the rawness show the indemillity of EU policies: expelling more migrants and doing so more effectively. This is the synthesis of the guidelines decreed by those who assimilate migrants to criminals. At the same time, the refugee crisis is used as a pretext to force further steps in deepening federalism, seeking to cement the role, extend the powers and functions of EU agencies, in the judicial, police and "border management" fields. New reasons for concern about safeguarding rights, freedoms and guarantees. These conclusions also open the door to the introduction of a kind of conditionality in development cooperation policy, a desabrida blackmail, which seeks to subject its recipients to the acceptance of the guidelines of the inhumane EU migration policy.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. – The events of recent weeks make it increasingly clear: the refugee crisis demands a pan-European solution. Shifting the problem from one state to the next, as happened with Hungary, Croatia, Serbia, and Slovenia, only worsens the situation – both for the refugees and for the relationship between the states. And even Bavaria or Austria will not be able to solve the refugee problem on their own.
