That is why, as was the case with the Greek crisis, I am calling for more negotiations between the individual Member States, with the aim of a fair distribution of those seeking help. My demand last April that the European Union must do everything possible to end the war in Syria is now being implemented more and more. It is not only welcome, but essential that all parties to the dispute – those on the front lines and also those on the front lines, and also those who pull the strings behind the scenes – are involved in the negotiations. In addition to Turkey and Russia, Iran must also take part in the discussions that will take place in Vienna next Friday. I strongly support the active role played by EU External Relations Representative Federica Mogherini on behalf of the European Union in resolving the war in the region.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – In order to cope with this dramatic ins arriving in refugees into the EU, the European Parliament has mobilisation all its resources to carry out effective management as soon as possible of the situation. However, we are beginning to be tired and, why not say so, also frustrated, to see a whole series of Council meetings pass in recent months as an 'urgency', and that the implementation of the decisions taken is constantly delayed. Among them the most important, the financial contribution by Member States to assist in the management of this crisis. The European Parliament is fulfilling its responsibility, now it is up to countries to do their part and to provide the EUR 2.3 billion for refugees and humanitarian aid they promised. We cannot afford to continue in this impasse because of the unwillingness of certain countries; the lives of thousands of men, women and children are at stake.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. – Fast, urgent, immediate: I don't know what the point of these words makes for some in this House. We are already, some, tired of the hypocrisy of hearing some MEPs talk about solidarity here, while their governments are acting nefariously in managing this crisis. It has been a month since the refugee quota-sharing was decided, and yesterday, Mr Rajoy's government, to give an example, announced the sending of officials to participate in a pilot project and take in the first fifty refugees. If we weren't talking about such a serious thing, I'd think it was a joke. But everything has its explanation. Mr Orbán's image at the Congress of the European People's Party in Madrid, cheered, applauded, when he made such reactionary statements against refugees and immigration, makes a very clear sense. Stop fooling around, because we're killing the lives of hundreds of thousands of refugees.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. – The conclusions reached by the European Council at the 15-16 October session concerning the so-called Balkan route of migrants entering the European Union is another firefighting solution, not a complete and long-term solution to the problem. The way individual member states perform and express dangerous nationalist egotism does not solve the problem.  The ultimate responsibility and solidarity of all participants is needed to resolve the migrant crisis in the long term. Once again, the Balkans have demonstrated how important the area for the stability and security of the whole of Europe is, and in this context everything needs to be done to speed up the way for entry into the European Union by countries from the Western Balkans.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – Turkey, as a NATO ally, as a G20 economy and as the most successful Muslim democracy in the world is a partner Europe needs. Today more than ever, the EU cannot deal with the refugee crisis without Turkish help. It is ironic that once again Europe is allowing important foreign policy decisions to be driven by events than long term strategy. To those of my colleagues who say we promised too much in the EU – Turkey Joint Action Plan - I say the question is not whether we work with our ally Turkey but how we can strengthen our existing cooperation. The EU will need Turkey beyond the current refugee crisis. As a democratic Muslim country, Turkey is a role model for the whole Muslim world. As a NATO member, essential for our security. And as the fastest growing economy in Europe, crucial for our economic well—being.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. – A purely humanitarian problem such as the refugee problem results in a policy lesson that tarnishes the EU. Turkey began accession negotiations ten years ago under political pressure. Without the minimum guarantees, she was granted candidate status with an expectation of improvement in the future. We're ten years later. Politics failed with deteriorating situation: Erdogan seeks to re-establishment of Ottoman empire as a neo-Sultan, oppresses the peoples within Turkey (Turks, Kurds, Alevites, etc.), cooperates and supports the modern bloodthirsty scourge of humanity, the so-called Islamic State, persecutes and imprisons political opponents and journalists who simply express their opinion, chooses bloodshed with the Kurds while years ago promising human rights until it was established in power , continues the illegal occupation and colonizes the European territory of the Republic of Cyprus by refusing to withdraw its occupying troops, disregards the decisions of the European Courts, does not apply its obligations to the EU concerning Cyprus...  The list of anti-European behaviour is inexhaustible. However, the EU plans to reward Erdogan with a few billion euros in aid. In exchange for Erdogan treating refugees humanely, Turkish nationals were released on visas, and new chapters were opened in exchange for Erdogan treating refugees humanely. This transaction tarnishes the EU itself.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – (20) The European Union is experiencing a social crisis, a crisis of values, which implies a strengthening of solidarity between Member States with a view to resolving the serious humanitarian crisis we are experiencing. Member States should act more swiftly and expeditiously to provide the European institutions with concrete funding and support mechanisms in order to help refugees arriving in Europe as soon as possible.  This type of support can be both at the level of support infrastructure and at the level of registration sites or the rerouting of migrants to other countries. The countries of the Western Balkans as well as several countries in Southern Europe or Central Europe have tried to solve the migration problem unilaterally, understanding that it is time for everyone to cooperate with each other and develop mechanisms for mutual help and support.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – I find it difficult to be optimistic about the prospects of negotiations on Euro—African cooperation regarding migrant movements and related socio—economic give—and—take. Since the heyday of neo—colonialism in Africa, things have not improved much. Through the IMF and other bodies, the West has imposed its neo—liberal model of development on most African countries. Privatisation, the removal of protectionism, and tailor—made forms of project tied aid from supposedly liberalised economies but failed to trigger sufficient growth. They confirmed the pattern of extractive industries and agricultural commodity production where value added was produced by among others, European and Chinese MNCs outside Africa. Urbanisation accelerated, farm communities dwindled and became poorer, jobs failed to materialise in townships. In this neoliberal context, unsurprisingly corruption and public mismanagement did not abate; they flourished. For hundreds of thousands of Africans, immigration became the only hope. Strictly speaking, in a neo—liberal, globalised context, free movement of labour cannot be excised from a doctrine which preaches the virtues of free movement of goods and services worldwide. Conceptually and politically, Europe is in a weak position to demand a transparent give—and—take from African countries over the mass emigration of their citizens.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing – on a daily basis, the media reports on refugee-related problems, on which Member State closes its borders, which, on the contrary, transports refugees by bus to another country's borders. The Member States make up-to-date decisions according to the situation, we cannot blame them, because there are no quick and up-to-date decisions within the EU. I see both Mr Tusk and Juncker's speeches positively, but their speeches are at least one year late. If we had talked a year ago about strict border protection, about extending Frontex's mandate, about the rights but also of refugees, about the help of experts and experts in the refugee crisis, thousands of fleeing people today did not have to suffer from hunger, winter and, in the unrealistic notion of a trip to a dream country in Germany, many people might not have died. I appreciate that negotiations have begun with Turkey on joint assistance to refugees in detention camps in this country, where we would help to build and ensure social, material, hygiene and health conditions for refugees.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: Writing. – Increasingly, it seems that migration to Europe will not be a temporary phenomenon, but that we must permanently settle on the fact that huge crowds want to settle in our countries. This challenge will test our society, our supply systems, our border control systems and can be a cause of political instability. In the meantime, I see that our citizens are baffled by this phenomenon because we have not discussed it with them. We have not told them that world politics can arrive in their cities and villages and we cannot or do not want to prevent this. Therefore, many now feel that they are left alone with their problems and that their political leaders are ignoring their point of view. These people will seek out the parties and politicians who offer simple answers to these problems, promise them a solution and, in return, ask for their votes. The consequences will go much further on the aspects of the migration crisis, so I think that this is the time to pursue a sensible policy and take concrete measures to address the situation. To do so, I wish the leaders of the Member States wisdom and courage.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – Cooperation with the Mediterranean and Middle Eastern countries is crucial for tackling the migration crisis, but we cannot offer the states concerned short-term financing, but especially real development projects that will bring long-term stability and economic growth.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The Council's ambitions must be followed by budgetary decisions. The Commission has proposed an amending letter for the 2016 budget indicating substantial increases in funding for migrants. However, these increases are insufficient because, as the President of the Commission said, "in an exceptional situation, the Union must provide an exceptional response".  The next budgetary reconciliation will be an opportunity to test the sincerity of the Council. Only extraordinary funding will be made to deal with the crisis. Turkey is hosting two million refugees, and the Council of 15 October has proposed a 3 billion increase in financial aid for that country. However, the Commission is still awaiting Member States' contributions to the Madad fund set up for refugees from Syria. The latest version of the amending budget foresees a reduction of 2.3 billion member states' contributions to the EU budget.  In the face of our historical responsibility, we must force the Council to review its copy, in order to respond not only to the migrant crisis but also to the Union's other priorities, investment in recovery and employment , and youth employment in particular.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, is it in order to congratulate Mr Donald Tusk in his skilful decision to resign as Prime Minister of Poland last year in order to take up the job of President of the Council, at 5 times the salary [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: President. –
text: This is not a point of order.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to say that today's vote puts an end to the legislative process of the single market in telecommunications. And because Parliament has shown leadership throughout the process of communication and negotiation with the extraordinary Council, we have achieved the main objectives we had set ourselves. First, the end of roaming costs. We can also say that this is the elimination of a kind of fee on the free movement of people in the European Union, and that barriers are removed so that small businesses, start-ups and all kinds of organisations and institutions can make their way into the European single market. It is a palpable test of what the added value of the European Union entails. And second—a little respect, please, a little respect, be so kind—and second, the internet. Internet, there is no doubt that it is a gem. It is a precious value that technology has given us; it is full of opportunities, which is full of opportunities for all; that we have to take care of delicately and that we even have to pamper. This regulation establishes the necessary safeguards for the Internet to provide equal access for all, without discrimination, without interference, without restrictions, in a clear and unambiguous manner. And besides, ... (The Member's intervention is interrupted by boos in plenary) No, no; I will continue and I will end, because I am within my right to speak in this House. And if there are people who lack respect for the intervention of any parliamentarian, who wait and who hear who is in the word. And I have to say... With the noise, ladies and gentlemen, little things are done, nothing more than trying to create confusion. And I have to say that, in addition to creating a level playing field in internet access and establishing the guarantees of the principles of net neutrality, this legislation allows creativity, that talent, that innovation for innovative services on the Internet can also flourish. Ladies and gentlemen, we are... Thank you, thank you very much, for the efforts of the shadow rapporteurs and all those who have contributed to make this moment today a reality.

name: Marietje Schaake
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, do not worry, I am not going to give a big speech, but just to ask for the final vote to be postponed, and the file referred back to committee so that we can start the trilogue and finish in a first reading agreement.

name: President. –
text: The matter is referred back to committee in order to start negotiations with the Council.

name: Charles Goerens
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I am introducing an oral amendment for a paragraph 2 bis (new) of the following content: 'consider that there is no need to let our guard down in relation to the few new cases of Ebola, the mode of transmission of which is still questioned'.

name: Charles Goerens
text: rapporteur. – Madame la Présidente, comme la situation en matière de lutte contre le virus Ebola a changé depuis l'adoption de mon rapport en commission du développement, j'ai introduit un amendement oral relatant les chiffres les plus récents disponibles avant le vote en plénière. Il est de la teneur suivante...  ‘whereas three new confirmed cases of Ebola virus disease were registered in the week to 18 October, all of which in Guinea; whereas the country had reported zero cases for the previous two weeks; whereas Sierre Leone reported zero cases for a fifth consecutive week; whereas the WHO declared Liberia free of Ebola virus transmission in the human population on 3 September; whereas there have been 28 512 confirmed cases, including 11 313 confirmed deaths.’

name: President. –
text: That concludes the vote.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: Dear Colleagues, We'll move on to voting. I would like to inform you that many oral requests for votes have been sent to us and that the meeting must be interrupted no later than 2.45pm so that the services can prepare for the meeting, which will resume at 3pm.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: The opt-outs will therefore take place tomorrow, after the vote. Non-voting ballots may be submitted in writing. I hope, dear colleagues, that everyone has heard and understood my announcement in this confusion in Babel.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although UKIP does not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because this proposal aims to repeal certain acts adopted in recent decades that are no longer applicability, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, or because of their temporary nature. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not within the Commission's powers to declare obsolete acts which were adopted by the Council. The acts contained in the proposal should therefore be repealed by the Council and the European Parliament following the ordinary legislative procedure. The objective and content of the proposal for a Regulation consist of a pure repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. In particular, the two acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been incorporated into regulation 1881/2006, subsequent, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 established only a temporary regime, which is no longer applicable.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which did not have any stakes. However, it was interesting through this vote to reaffirm our position on European policy in the agricultural sector with in particular the transitional sugar beet regime, one of the two texts concerned with the repeal. This includes the end of beet quotas or the opening of sugar markets under free trade agreements. These measures will have disastrous repercussions such as the ruin of small producers, the collapse of prices or the oligopolistic concentration of the market around large structures.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this purely technical report which repeals two acts that have ceased to serve any legislative function.  The Directives in question are related to the fixing of maximum levels of erucic acid in fats and oils and another establishing a temporary scheme for restructuring the sugar industry. The former is now included in a Regulation in the same format, and the latter is no longer applicable as it only concerned temporary measures.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question here concerns outdated legislation. The repeal of obsolete acts will have no concrete impact. However, I took advantage of this vote to oppose the EU's policy on sugar beet (end of beet quotas, opening of sugar markets under free trade agreements). One of the two texts concerned with the repeal deals with the transitional sugar beet regime. I also keep in mind that sugar quotas will be abolished in October 2017 (like milk quotas a few months ago). This will lead to the collapse of prices, the ruin of small producers and an oligopolistic concentration of the market around large structures (like Lactis in the dairy sector). At a time when farmers are under pressure, such a policy is extremely harmful. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this motion because there appears to be more to the matter than the simple repealing of an obsolete act.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is in line with a simplification of the CAP.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, as this legislation is no longer relevant.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote was about obsolete acts, i.e. outdated legislation: it was therefore a vote of pure form, with no concrete impact. Nevertheless, one of the two texts concerned with the repeal concerned the transitional sugar beet regime, with a view to abolishing sugar quotas in October 2017, modelled on what was just achieved in March 2015 with the end of milk quotas.  This further abolition of quotas will have serious consequences, especially for France, Europe's leading better-aircraft country: the collapse of prices, the ruin of small producers and the oligopolistic concentration of the market around large structures that will play even further downwards on prices. It is therefore because this report endorses the abolition of sugar quotas that I have opposed it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report which proposes the abolition of certain agricultural and fisheries legislation which is no longer relevant either because their content has been taken up by subsequent texts or because of their temporary nature.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote on this report is another example of the scarecrow gesticulations represented by the European institutions. Mr Siekierski's report dealt with the repeal of obsolete legislation within the framework of the Common Agricultural Policy.  A vote without real stakes, therefore, if not to reaffirm our opposition to the current eu's conduct of agricultural policy, which continues to be part of a logic of the great king market at the expense of producers and consumers; for example, the report included the repeal of Regulation (EC) No. 320/2006 of the Council establishing a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry: a real death sentence for this sector, which is likely to suffer the same fate as milk producers who are victims of the end of milk quotas. The EU therefore seems to choose once again to favour the monopoly of large multinationals over local and domestic production. Therefore, I have taken the opportunity given to me by this unsealed text to renew my support for our agriculture and to once again mark my strong opposition to the suicidal policy of Brussels.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Siekierski report is acceptable and balanced. The aim of the text is to adapt the legislation currently in force to the legal basis given by the Treaty of Lisbon; That is why I wanted to support you with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the determination of the maximum percentage of eruic acid in oils and fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector since both acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been taken up by the subsequent Council Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006, while Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 merely established a temporary regime which is no longer applicable.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it supports the repeal of the 1976 Council Directive on the fixing of maximum levels for erucic acid in oils and fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry. Certain legislation adopted in recent decades is no longer relevant, given that its content is regulated by newer acts or by their temporary nature. In line with the Interinstitutional Agreement on better law-making, EU legislation should be updated and reduced by repealing obsteonceable legislation, thus ensuring greater transparency and certainty. The Commission's proposal states that the Commission does not have the power to publish acts adopted by the Council in no longer relevant terms. The Council and the European Parliament must therefore do so in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ i supported the proposed report because, in order to comply with the acquis, it is necessary to repeal two legal acts in the field of the common agricultural policy, a regulation and a directive. The fact is that some of the legal acts adopted in the last few ten years are no longer relevant, and the reason for this may be in their temporary nature or because their content has been summarised by subsequent acts. In the present case, the limitation period is the directive setting the ceiling for the value of erucic acid in oils and fats, reproduced in Regulation 1881/2006, and the regulation establishing a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry which, by its temporary nature, is no longer in use.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this purely technical report which repeals two acts that have ceased to serve any legislative function. The Directives in question are related to the fixing of maximum levels of erucic acid in fats and oils and another establishing a temporary scheme for restructuring the sugar industry. The former is now included in a Regulation in the same format and the latter is no longer applicable as it only concerned temporary measures.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that, within the framework of the interinstitutional agreement on better lawmaking, it is important to repeal all those acts which, because they are taken up by subsequent acts or because they are temporary, have become obsolete. Both Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 on the common agricultural policy fall into this category and, therefore, I believe that they should be repealed.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to repeal already outdated legislation on the beet and sugar sector. It is therefore a question of deciding on a report that will have no concrete impact on the actors of the agricultural world. Nevertheless, we take this opportunity to reaffirm our positions in this area. From 1 October 2017, isoglucose quotas and the minimum beetroot price will be abolished. In 2018, producers will also lose a third of their CAP subsidies. This policy directly threatens the viability of this sector of activity, a source of job creation and revitalization in rural areas, which is already facing fierce competition because of the preferential trade arrangements that the European Commission has put in place, particularly in the context of the transatlantic treaty negotiations, to encourage lower prices.  These measures will ruin small farms for large structures that benefit from larger economies of scale to cope with wild competition from emerging countries. We are absolutely opposed to this ultra-liberal policy, which jeopardizes our agricultural model, based on quality and respect for the environment. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Common Agricultural Policy is a set of rules and mechanisms at European Union level, governing the production and marketing of agricultural products in the European area, paying attention to rural development. The European Union has the right to ensure that the common agricultural policy operates in the best possible conditions so that Member States can develop and produce high-quality food, help combat climate change and maintain agricultural diversity.  I voted in favour of this report on Community legislation which needs to be updated by repealing acts that are no longer in place, because it is very important that Union legislation on the common agricultural policy is transparent, clear and ensures certainty for all European states.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. It is simply a question of aligning the legal basis.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 on the common agricultural policy, which have exhausted their effects but are still only technically in force. Following the principle of 'better lawmaking', we must update EU law and reduce its volume by repealing acts that are no longer applied because their content has been incorporated into subsequent acts or because they were temporary.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this purely technical report which repeals two acts that have ceased to serve any legislative function.  The Directives in question are related to the fixing of maximum levels of erucic acid in fats and oils and another establishing a temporary scheme for restructuring the sugar industry. The former is now included in a Regulation in the same format, and the latter is no longer applicable as it only concerned temporary measures.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it rightly points out the need to improve the existing legislation in line with constantly changing trends in the agricultural sector and new emerging technologies. The Directive needs be updated to allow for greater accuracy.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by my colleague Czesław Adam Siekierski seeks to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 on the common agricultural policy because their sometimes provisional content has been taken up in subsequent acts. Since EU law needs to be updated and its volume reduced by repealing acts that are no longer applied in order to improve transparency and certainty in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement on better law-making, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report refers to the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC laying down a ceiling on the content of erucic acid in oils and fats and Regulation (EC) No 320/2002 Council Regulation (EC) No 06 establishing a temporary restructuring regime for the sugar sector Having regard to the Commission's proposal to the European Parliament and council and the report of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development, the Commission is asked to resubmit the proposal if it intends to make significant amendments to it or to replace the text.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the fixing of the maximum level of eucic acid in oils and fats intended as such for human consumption and in foods with the addition of oils or fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 on a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 President Juncker, since taking office, has made "better regulation" his workhorse. This is an objective that we can support, especially for a Europe that is increasingly perceived as a sum of laces and laces rather than as an institution that joins citizens and businesses in helping them to improve their conditions. Within this framework, we cannot but agree with the proposal to eliminate certain obsolete acts, provided that we do not fall back into a situation of regulatory vacuum or cancellation of protections and rights. On the basis of these considerations, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am in favour of repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 on the common agricultural policy, because some of the legal acts adopted have lost their relevance in recent decades. This took place because their content was taken up in subsequent acts or because they were of a temporary nature.  In this regard, in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Lawmaking, I firmly believe that it is necessary to update Union law and reduce its volume by repealing acts that are no longer applied in order to improve their transparency and certainty.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Acts which were adopted over the last decades have exhausted all their effects, but remain technically in force. In the interest of legal certainty, the Commission suggested that the above mentioned acts be repealed by the Council and this Parliament. I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 on the common agricultural policy, based on Article 43(2) TFEA. Certain legal acts adopted have lost their relevance either because they are temporary or because their content has been incorporated into subsequent acts. The Commission cannot repeal the acts listed in the proposal. This power rests with the Council and the European Parliament in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure. In the light of the position adopted by the European Parliament on the repeal of two obsolete acts and the introduction of Directive 76/621/EEC on the fixing of the maximum level of eerucic acid in oils and fats, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because this proposal aims to repeal certain acts adopted in recent decades that are no longer applicability, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, or because of their temporary nature. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not within the Commission's powers to declare obsolete acts which were adopted by the Council. The acts contained in the proposal should therefore be repealed by the Council and the European Parliament following the ordinary legislative procedure. The objective and content of the proposal for a Regulation consist of a pure repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. In particular, the two acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been incorporated into regulation 1881/2006, subsequent, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 established only a temporary regime, which is no longer applicable.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal aims to repeal Council Directive 76/621/ECG on the common agricultural policy and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. Certain acts adopted over the last decade are no longer relevant because their content has been taken over by subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The Commission does not have the power to declare acts adopted by the Council obsolete, therefore, the repeal of the acts listed in the proposal should be ensured by the Council and the European Parliament, with the conduct of the ordinary legislative procedure, and I therefore voted in favour of Parliament's report in a simplified procedure, which seeks to achieve consistency with directive 76/621/EEC on the fixing of the highest levels of oils (cooking oils) and fats (edible fats), the highest level of erukaic acid (agricultural and internal market policy).

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this regulation, which is repealing two obsolete acts that had exhausted all their effects, because their content has been taken up by successive acts in the first case and because of their temporary character in the second case.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since increasing the transparency of Union legislation is an essential element of the better regulation strategy implemented by the Union institutions, I consider it appropriate to repeal those pieces of legislation that have ceased to have real effects.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report aims to repeal outdated CAP acts adopted by the Council in 2006. This is Council Directive 76/621/EEC, the content of which was taken up by Regulation (EC) No. 1881/2006 of the Commission and Regulation (EC) No. 320/2006 of the Council, whose temporary regime was applicable only until the 2009/2010 marketing campaign. Considering that for reasons of legal certainty, it is necessary to repeal these acts, I supported the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. It is with great common sense that the European Commission has chosen to abolish outdated legislation. As the directive on setting the maximum rate of erucic acid in oils and fats and the regulation establishing a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry have both become obsolete, Parliament then chose to repeal them. I support any measure that contributes to greater clarity of European legislation.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Siekierski report on the proposed regulation repealing the directive on setting the maximum rate of erucic acid in oils and fats and the regulation establishing a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry. It is a technical text whose purpose is to add a reference to Article 114 of the TFUE for the sake of consistency with the dual legal basis (agricultural policy and internal market policy).

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European Parliament's proposed regulation aimed to remove the maximum limit of erucic acid levels in oils and fats. However, by once again favouring the sugar industry at the expense of public health, the European Union continues in its 'all sugar beet' policy. At the expense of a diversified and therefore balanced production. By distorting competition through favours on the sugar beet industry, the European Union will impose even more lax rules on the whole of Europe through its Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). While the European Union should promote diversity of production, and remain attentive to public health, the opposite is true. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal to repeal the two acts in question. In order to achieve better law-making and greater transparency in European legislation, it is important that we continuously review European law. As both acts have been taken into account in new Commission and Council regulations, and due to the fact that the envisaged temporary scheme ended in 2010, their practical application is useless. For this reason, I agree that the only logical next step is to repeal them.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As these Council directives and regulations have become obsolete and therefore obsolete they should also be repealed.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed in their interinstitutional agreement on better law-building that Community law should be updated and that its scope should be reduced by repealing acts that are no longer applied. Acts that are no longer relevant should be removed from the ACQUIS in order to improve the transparency and security of EU law. In the present case, it is simply an amendment of a technical nature. Commission Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006 laying down maximum levels for certain contaminants in foodstuffs has fully adopted the provisions of Directive 76/621/EEC and Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 and it is therefore necessary to delete the latter legislation. For these reasons, I supported the adoption of the report in line with the European People's Party stance.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Certain legislative acts adopted in recent decades are no longer relevant today, either because their content was taken up by subsequent acts or by their temporary nature. Union legislation should therefore be updated and reduced by resuming the acts that are no longer applied in order to improve transparency and legal certainty. This report seeks to amend the addition of a reference to Article 114 TFEU which 'aims to ensure consistency with the dual legal basis (agricultural policy and internal market policy) used for the adoption of Directive 76/621/EEC on the setting of the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats'. I voted in favour.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it goes in the direction of the repeal of the sugar quotas to which I am opposed.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal serves to object to Council Directive 76/621/EEC, on the setting of the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, which establishes a temporary scheme for restructuring the sugar industry, as some of the legal acts adopted in recent decades are no longer relevant either because their content was adopted by other subsequent legal acts or due to some temporary nature of these. After the interinstitutional agreement for the simplification and improvement of EU legislation, this same legislation should be updated and condensed, removing legal acts that are no longer applicable in order to improve transparency and trust. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not in its power to declare obsolete legal acts that have been adopted by the Council. The acts listed in the Commission proposal should therefore be repealed by decision of the European Parliament.  These delegated acts have become obsolete as the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been repealed by Regulation 1881/2006 and Regulation 320/2006 only establishes a temporary scheme which is no longer applicable. The proposal is not problematic and we voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it was necessary. Both acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been taken up by the subsequent Regulation 1881/2006, whereas Council Regulation 320/2006 only established a temporary scheme, which is no longer applicable.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which is not complicated and is only a question of legal alignment.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report of the Common Agricultural Policy, since these Council regulations and directives have become obsolete and therefore obsolete, so they should also be repealed.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal aims at repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 related to the common agricultural policy, which are based on Articles 42 and 43(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. Certain legal acts adopted in the last decades no longer have continued relevance, either because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts or due to their temporary character. In accordance with the inter-institutional agreement on better law—making, European Union law should be updated and condensed by removing acts which are no longer applied, in order to improve transparency and certainty.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Common agricultural policy: repeal of outdated legislation' because I believe it is important to protect our farmers and family farms in particular from unnecessary bureaucracy. A good approach that should also be used in other areas.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is essential for the European Union to act effectively that existing legislation is continuously reviewed. This is the only way to guarantee a legal situation that meets the requirements. Today, Parliament approved the repeal of outdated legislation. This not only increases the transparency of European legislation, but also improves the protection of the final consumer.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to repeal two obsolete acts that had exhausted all their effects.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote, as it was highly technical, and as always with the EU, repealing does not necessarily mean less regulation!

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. Directive 76/621/EEC on the determination of the maximum percentage of eruc acid in oils and fats and Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector had become obsolete and unensused, although they remained in force. For reasons of legal certainty and clarity, such outdated legal instruments should be repealed.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of repealing Directive 76/621/EEC, regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector since the contents of these rules had been outdated by the new CAP regulation and therefore made no sense for them to remain in force.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Alongside my colleagues in the S&D group, I voted in favour of this report. The agreement on better law—making between the Council and this Parliament states that EU law should be updated and de-cluttered by repealing acts which are no longer applied. This regulation repeals two obsolete acts that are no longer in effect, but technically remain in force. It is a pure formality and aims at ensuring transparency and legal certainty, making sure that EU law is easier understood.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because certain legal acts adopted in the last decades have lost their relevance because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts, or due to their temporary nature. I believe that in accordance with the inter-institutional agreement on better law—making, European Union law should be updated and condensed by removing acts which are no longer applied, in order to improve transparency and certainty.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported this report because certain legal acts adopted in the last decades no longer have continued relevance, either because their content has been taken up by subsequent acts, or due to their temporary character. In accordance with the interinstitutional agreement on better law making, Union law should be updated and condensed by removing acts which are no longer applied in order to improve transparency and certainty.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the European Commission's move to simplify European regulations and make them more readable and understandable to those who apply them on a daily basis, the European Parliament has approved the repeal of two obsolete acts of the Common Agricultural Policy. These are technical considerations on fixing the maximum level of erucic acid in oils and fats.  While these changes appear obscure to the uninitiated, they have the merit of providing clarity to the experts on the issue. This is exactly what is expected of Europe and that is why I have supported these repeals without hesitation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 76/621/EEC. 320/2006 on the basis that I support the fact that acts that no longer apply to improve the transparency and security of Union legislation need to be removed. The repeal of the obsolete acts concerned is in line with the interinstitutional agreement on better law-making with a view to updating and simplifying legislation in order to remove those acts that have ceased to produce any practical effects.  I believe that certainty, accessibility and simplicity of rights are key factors for the correct and efficient functioning of EU legislation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote is about outdated legislation. This vote will have no concrete impact. However, one of the two texts concerned with the repeal deals with the transitional sugar beet regime. Indeed, in October 2017 the abolition of sugar quotas is planned, following the model of what has just been achieved in March 2015 with the end of milk quotas. The harmful consequences are foreseeable: collapsing prices, ruining small producers and oligopolistic concentration of the market around large structures (such as Lactalis in the case of milk), which will play even further downwards on prices. Our ENL Group therefore proposes to take advantage of this opportunity (although there is no real stake) to reaffirm our opposition to the EU's policy in this sector, which involves: the end of beet quotas, the opening of sugar markets within the framework of free trade agreements. So I voted AGAINST.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Although I do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, my colleagues and I therefore abstained.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report in order to simplify European legislation. For reasons of clarity, it was necessary to repeal these two texts, which have now become obsolete and are part of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this report as it concerns the repeal of now obsolete rules. The report is purely technical.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal, as I agree that European Union law should be updated and condensed by removing acts which are no longer applied, in order to improve transparency and certainty.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The aim of the following proposal is to repeal certain legal acts which have now become obsolete, either temporary or have content which has been incorporated into subsequent acts. Specifically, it aims to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC, which was taken up in Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006, which defines the maximum levels of certain contaminants in foodstuffs. It also aims to repeal Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, which established a temporary scheme, which remained in force only until the 2009/2010 marketing year. I have chosen to vote in favour because the removal from legislation of acts that no longer have real effects is an essential part of the 'better regulation' strategy, which makes it possible to simplify the regulatory framework for those in the sector and citizens.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Siekierski report envisages repealing acts that have become obsolete under the Common Agricultural Policy, including The Council's Directive 76/621/EEC on setting the maximum rate of erucic acid in oils and fats and the Council's temporary sugar industry restructuring regime (EC) No. 320/2006.  If this is a vote to clarify the law, and even if the stakes of this vote are relatively low, I have decided to vote against this text in order to reiterate my opposition to the EU's sugar beet policy.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. It was only a vote of form, with no concrete impact, since concerning the repeal of texts already obsolete. Nevertheless, they set out in particular the EU's policy on sugar beet, which I strongly oppose.  So I voted AGAINST, to denounce the end - scheduled for 2017 - of the betteravier quotas. As with milk quotas, this new EU-imposed regime will ruin our small producers, and the valuation of large groups that can play blithely lower on sugar market prices...

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because this proposal aims to repeal certain acts adopted in recent decades that are no longer applicability, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, or because of their temporary nature. According to the Commission's proposal, it does not fall within the Commission's powers to declare obsolete acts which were adopted by the Council. The acts contained in the proposal should therefore be repealed by the Council and the European Parliament following the ordinary legislative procedure. The objective and content of the proposal for a Regulation consist of a pure repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. In particular, the two acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been occupied by the subsequent Regulation 1881/2006, which Council Regulation 320/2006 has only established a temporary regime, which is no longer applicable.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The approved text was intended to repeal two earlier ones, one from the Commission on the maximum percentage of eruc acid in oils and fats, and another from the Council, which established a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector.  Although both legal acts had become obsolete, they formally remained in force. Following one of the principles of the European Union which seeks to improve the transparency of EU law and whose purpose is to legislate better, it is essential to repeal those legal acts which no longer have real effects.  That is why I am in favour of this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒In order to protect the security of EUROPEAN Union law, and to improve transparency, policies need to be updated and summarised by removing acts that no longer apply. The purpose of the report is to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 76/621/EEC. 320/2006 in relation to the Common Agricultural Policy. The content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC is included in Commission Regulation (EC) No 76/621/EEC. 1881/2006 establishing the maximum levels of certain contaminants in food. I supported Czesław MEP Adam Siekierski's report, as it is important for legal certainty to repeal rules that do not apply to simplify citizens' understanding of regulations and strengthen trust in the security and fairness of the legal order as a driver of the modern state.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 During the existence of the European Union and its institutional predecessors, a huge number of different regulations were adopted, which were or still have the task of determining the principles of functioning in all political areas. This gradually led to a situation in which a number of regulations were simply no longer in force because their period had expired or other newer regulations occupied their place in terms of liability. Consequently, I consider it logical to take steps so that such regulations are no longer up to date. I fully support cooperation between the European Parliament, the Commission and the Council in the further standardisation and unification of Union legislation. Before the accession of the Republic of Latvia to the European Union, two sugar factories were active in my country, which used sugar beet as the main resource. In economic and social terms, this has had a positive impact on agriculture, the light and food industries, the existence of jobs and related taxes. Consequently, although I support the principles of the free market, I cannot without regret not note the fact that there used to be a whole industry in my country, the production capacity of which allowed the export of products abroad, while sugar is now being imported.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the abolition of obsolete and practically ineffective rules will contribute to simplifying and clarifying legislation in the area of the common agricultural policy. Similar revisions must be made on all Union policies, and EU law will also become more comprehensible and unambiguous in terms of its interpretation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC laying down a ceiling on the content of eerucic acid in oils and fats and Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly.  Furthermore, I would like to inform the House that the troika is continuing its anti-social attack on the Greek people. The Agricultural Memorandum dissolves the primary sector, increases production costs, savagely taxes land and agricultural production and imposes increased insurance contributions on farmers. That is why the rural world in my home country of Greece has warmed up the tractors and is preparing for major mobilizations. Because with the imposition of the memorandums the income of farmers in Greece has fallen dramatically and the taxation of the rural world has skyrocketed. I support the struggle of Greek farmers and will stand by them in claiming their fair demands for productive reconstruction, for strengthening the primary sector, for supporting livestock farming and to throw the troika out of our homeland and get Greece back.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text. This text, which concerns sugar beet in particular, echoes another text on the end of milk quotas. The consequences will be the same: collapsing prices, ruins of small producers, ends of quotas, opening up markets under free trade agreements. We strongly oppose this EU-led policy.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this tidying-up proposal. The Commission proposal aims at repealing Council Directive No 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, which have exhausted all their practical effects and remain only technically in force.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the fixing of the maximum level of eerucic acid in oils and fats intended as such for human consumption and in foodstuffs with the addition of oils or fats and Council Regulation No 320/2006 on a temporary arrangement for the restructuring of the sugar industry. Improving the transparency of EU law is an essential part of the strategy for better lawmaking. In this context, acts which no longer have real effects should be removed from the legislation in force.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation to repeal Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, as I believe that regulatory progress in this area is desirable.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It makes sense for Article 114 TFEU to be added to the legal basis for the repeal of acts. This report was therefore to be supported.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to repeal both Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, as both acts have become outdated since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC was taken up by the subsequent Regulation 1881/2006, while Council Regulation 320/2006 only established a temporary scheme which is no longer valid.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In their inter-institutional agreement entitled 'Better Regulation', the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission agreed that EU legislation should be updated and that its volume should be reduced by the repeal of acts that are no longer applied.  This would, in particular, give citizens a better understanding of European regulations. The Commission proposes here to repeal two acts under the common agricultural policy, which have become obsolete although they are still formally in force.  What a feat! This is the Council's Directive 76/621/EEC on Oils and Fats, the content of which is included in Regulation (EC) No. 1881/2006 of the Commission and Regulation (EC) No. 320/2006 of the Council, which instituted a temporary regime in the sugar industry for 2009 and 2010, which is obsolete. I am voting for this text, which aims to simplify the understanding of European regulations.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote is about outdated legislation: it is therefore a vote of pure form, which will have no concrete impact. Nevertheless, one of the two texts concerned with the repeal deals with the transitional sugar beet regime. It should be noted, in fact, that in October 2017 the abolition of sugar quotas is planned, following the model of what has just been achieved in March 2015 with the end of milk quotas. The harmful consequences are known in advance: collapsing prices, ruining small producers and oligopolistic concentration of the market around large structures (such as Lactalis in the case of milk), which will play even further downwards on prices. We therefore propose to take advantage of this opportunity (although there is no real stake) to reaffirm our opposition to the EU's policy in this sector, which involves: end of beet quotas, opening of sugar markets within the framework of free trade agreements... Therefore, the member voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have presented my vote in agreement with the report on the proposal for a regulation for the repeal of obsolete acts under the Common Agricultural Policy. The Commission's proposal aims to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, which no longer take effect and remain only technically in force. The need for certainty and legal certainty requires that obsolete acts be repealed. Furthermore, it is a question of adding Article 114 TFEU to the legal basis for the approximation of legislative provisions relating to the establishment and functioning of the internal market.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as legal acts adopted in the last decades may no longer be relevant, as they were replaced by subsequent acts, or due to their temporary character. It is essential that obsolete acts are repealed to condense and update European Union law in order to improve transparency and certainty.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal to repeal obsolete acts, which are only formal in nature and are no longer relevant in the current amended context. After the Commission has examined the proposal, Parliament and the Council are entitled to repeal the acts by the ordinary legislative procedure. This is the abolition of obsolete directives on the basis of previous contracts or directives of a temporary nature. The repeal of obsolete legal acts aims at greater legal transparency and clarity within the framework of Union policy. That report proposes the repeal of the Directive concerning the fixing of maximum eruic acid content in oils and fats and a regulation establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar industry. Both acts have become obsolete with a view to transposing them into a subsequent regulation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this regulation which repeals two obsolete acts that had exhausted all their effects, but remain technically in force. They have become obsolete because their content has been taken up by successive acts for the first one or because of their temporary character for the second.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A vote for bringing clarity to the legal maze of the EU through the abandonment of obsolete and useless legal acts still in force for no good or valid reason.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council with a view to repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC fixing the maximum levels of erukaic acid in oils (cooking oils) and fats (edible fats) and Council Directive 320/2006/EC laying down a temporary scheme for restructuring the sugar industry. In its amendment, the EP Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development proposed only one technical clarification, in particular recommending the Commission's proposal to Parliament for adoption, which is why I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Under the Common Agricultural Policy, Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the setting of the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establish a temporary restructuring scheme for the sugar industry, having exhausted its legal effects and does not currently correspond to the initial purposes for which they were established. The elimination of obsolete acts is an element of the Better Regulation strategy, implemented by the European institutions, and it is not justified that these acts remain in the existing legislative order. The content of Directive 76/621/EEC is reproduced in Commission Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006, setting the maximum levels of certain contaminants present in foodstuffs, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 would apply only on a temporary basis for restructuring the sugar industry, ending in the 2009/2010 marketing year. I am in favour of this proposal, as legal certainty and transparency should be safeguarded by repealing obsolete acts which are only formally in force.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Siekierski report envisages repealing obsolete acts under the Common Agricultural Policy, including The Council's Directive 76/621/EEC on setting the maximum rate of erucic acid in oils and fats and regulation (EC) No. 320/2006 of the Council establishing a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry.  If this is a vote to clarify the law, and even if the stakes of this vote are relatively low, I have decided to vote against this text in order to reiterate my opposition to the EU's sugar beet policy.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which authorises the repeal of two obsolete acts of the common agricultural policy. This is the Council's Directive 76/621/EEC, on setting the maximum level of erucic acid in oils and fats, whose content was taken up by Regulation (EC) No. 1881/2006 of the Commission and Regulation (EC) No. 320/2006 of the Council, which instituted a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry and whose temporary regime was applicable only until the marketing campaign of 2009 and 2010. The only amendment to the Commission's text is the reference to Article 114 of the TFUE, in order to be consistent with the dual legal basis (agricultural policy and internal market policy) used for the adoption of Directive 76/621/EEC.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 taking into consideration that both acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC was taken up by the subsequent Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006, while Council Regulation 320/2006 only established a temporary scheme which is no longer applicable.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this purely technical report which repeals two acts that have ceased to serve any legislative function. The Directives in question are related to the fixing of maximum levels of erucic acid in fats and oils and another establishing a temporary scheme for restructuring the sugar industry. The former is now included in a regulation in the same format, and the latter is no longer applicable as it only concerned temporary measures.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because red tape has increased significantly in recent years and the burden on competent authorities and farmers has increased. Due to the complexity, some errors have also crept in, which need to be eliminated. In the present case, therefore, it is at first sight a purely technical process – but for me it is also a step towards de-bureaucratisation.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to establish a regulation repealing Directive 76/621/EEC and Regulation (EC) 320/2006 of the Council due to legislative obsolescence. The first set a maximum level of erucic acid in oils and fats, which was then regulated by the Commission's Directive 1881/2006, which takes up its contents, thus rendering the previous one unnecessary. As for Regulation (EC) 320/2006, it set a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry, which expires in the 2009/2010 marketing year. With this campaign past, the regulations are no longer in effect. I support this report, which therefore aims to remove these obsolete acts from EU legislation, as clarification and security are necessary.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported because it is a repeal of obsolete legislation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report.   It should be noted that in recent decades some legislation adopted has become obsolete and no longer has any effect.   It is therefore essential to abolish outdated agricultural legislation that is not fit for purpose and to ensure that the norms are clear and predictable. Reducing the number of European Union legislation by eliminating the repeal of the existing ones would increase transparency. In addition, greater clarity would be given to all citizens and to all Member States, since the impact of the legislation on those to whom it applies must be clear and predictable.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring the transparency and certainty of European legislation is, in my view, one of the Union's objectives, in order to bring it ever closer to its citizens. That is why, in the light of the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Internal Market and in full agreement with it on the inclusion of Article 114 TFEI as the legal basis for this regulation, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report on the proposal for a Regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the establishment of the maximum level of eruk acid in oils and fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 76/621/EEC. 320/2006 establishing a temporary system for restructuring the sugar industry, as both acts are outdated. Regulation 76/621/EEC was replaced by the new Regulation 1881/2006 establishing the maximum levels of certain contaminants in food, and Regulation 320/2006 applied until the end of the 2009/2010 trade year.  I would also like to warn against the abolition of the sugar quota system that follows us next year and call for a timely response from the Commission so that the sugar sector does not find out the same situation that has happened in the milk sector. Having negative experience with the abolition of quotas in the dairy sector and unfair trading practices and the Russian embargo, as well as other problems that milk producers are in today, I take the opportunity again and call on the Commission to take the necessary steps on time rather than putting out the fire again when it is too late.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Siekierski report envisages repealing obsolete acts under the Common Agricultural Policy, including Council Directive 76/621/EEC on setting the maximum rate of erucic acid in oils and fats and regulation (EC) No. 320/2006 of the Council establishing a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry. If this is a vote to clarify the law, and even if the stakes of this vote are relatively low, I have decided to vote against this text in order to reiterate my opposition to the EU's sugar beet policy.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒I support all efforts to improve the security and transparency of Union law, which forms the basis for better and more consistent drafting of legislation, including this regulation on the repeal of current regulations establishing the maximum level of acid eruk in oils and fats and establishing a temporary system for restructuring the sugar industry. The competent authorities provided evidence of the existence and adequacy of the legal basis for these regulations, namely Article 43(2) and Article 114 of the TFEU.  In its entirety, these are legal bases and agreements aimed at improving legislation by compressing and updating, i.e. removing those acts that are obsolete, no longer applicable, the content of which is covered by subsequent acts, or because of their temporary character. In this case, the regulation on the permissible quantities of certain contaminants in food is a basic requirement to remove from active legislation those acts that no longer have a real effect.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I agree with colleague Czeslaw Adam Siekierski's report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the establishment of the maximum level of eruk acid in oils and fats and the Council Regulation establishing a temporary system for the restructuring of the sugar industry. The reason for the repeal is that some legal acts adopted in recent decades are no longer relevant because their content is covered by subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. In line with the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law-Making and with a view to improving transparency and security, Union law should be updated and summarised in a timely manner by removing acts that no longer apply. The acts mentioned in the proposal should be repealed by the Council and the European Parliament in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, since the Commission is not competent to declare outdated acts adopted by the Council. The content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC is included in Commission Regulation No 76/621/EEC. 1881/2006 establishing the maximum levels of certain contaminants in food, and the provisional system established by Council Regulation No 1881/2006. 320/2006 applied only until the 2009/2010 market year and, accordingly, those legal acts concerning the Common Agricultural Policy are outdated and should be repealed for reasons of legal certainty and clarity.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 'better lawmaking' strategy implemented by the European institutions aims to repeal legislative acts which have exhausted their effects but which are still technically in force. These acts are to be considered obsolete either because their content has been taken up in subsequent acts, or because they were of a temporary nature. Having said that, given that the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC was taken up in Council Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006, whereas Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 was only temporarily established, I am in favour of their repeal, in order to reduce the number of European regulations.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the repeal of the directive establishing the highest amount of eructonic acid in oils and fats, as well as the Council Regulation establishing a temporary restructuring regime for the sugar industry. I believe that both legislation in the field of the common agricultural policy is no longer relevant – either because of their temporary validity or because they have been replaced by the following legislation. By repealing directives and regulations that are no longer valid and necessary, we will increase transparency. Moreover, updates and briefs will certainly lead to a clearer overview of the legislation.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to ensure high health standards and to better harmonize practices and standards between Member States, the EU is amending and improving its legislation.  In this context, the European Parliament has decided to repeal two obsolete acts of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP): Directive 76/621/EEC setting a maximum level of erucic acid in oils and fats, and Regulation (EC) 320/2006 on the temporary sugar industry restructuring regime in force until 2009/2010. I have spoken in favour of this text, which allows for updating legislation in the agricultural field.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of understanding that the diplomas that have ceased to have effect should be repealed.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Although we do not approve of this Parliament legislating for 500 million people, as this repeals defunct legislation, we abstained.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the determination of the maximum percentage of eruic acid in oils and fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector since both acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been taken up by the subsequent Council Regulation (EC) No 1881/2006, while Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 merely established a temporary regime which is no longer applicable.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Position of the European Parliament, adopted at first reading on 27 October 2015 with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC on the setting of the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary restructuring scheme for the sugar industry.  This is an eminently technical proposal, which aims to provide greater legislative transparency and clarity by repealing diplomas which have ceased to have effect - as is the case in the field of the Common Agricultural Policy.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing.
