I voted in favour of this report calling for the repeal of the Council's Directive 76/621/EEC on setting the maximum rate of erucic acid in oils and fats and regulation (EC) 320/2006 of the Council establishing a temporary regime for restructuring the sugar industry.  Indeed, some of the acts that were adopted a few years ago are still in force despite the fact that they have become obsolete.  It is therefore for reasons of legal certainty that the Commission proposes their repeal to the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the repeal of Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, as I agree that these acts are obsolete and of no practical use and I am in favour of updating European agricultural policy legislation in order to promote greater efficiency in the sector.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of repealing Directive 76/621/EEC, regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector since the contents of these rules had been outdated by the new CAP regulation and therefore made no sense for them to remain in force.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because this proposal aims to repeal certain acts adopted in recent decades that are no longer applicability, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, or because of their temporary nature. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not within the Commission's powers to declare obsolete acts which were adopted by the Council. The acts contained in the proposal should therefore be repealed by the Council and the European Parliament following the ordinary legislative procedure. The objective and content of the proposal for a Regulation consist of a pure repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. In particular, the two acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been incorporated into regulation 1881/2006, subsequent, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 established only a temporary regime, which is no longer applicable.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 With today's vote, Parliament repeals Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. Both of these acts have become obsolete because they no longer have any practical application. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. This procedure is important as a matter of legal clarity and without going beyond what is necessary and strictly agreed in terms of the current Common Agricultural Policy 2014—2020.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, as although I do wish to see obsolete acts repealed I do not think this report will achieve what it hopes to do.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Repealing this act shows the EU’s ability to become more efficient and do away with unnecessary legislation. While they have effectively exhausted all of their effects, they do remain technically in force and because of subsequent acts, they have been rendered obsolete.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ in order to guarantee the transparency and accuracy of European law, it is necessary to regularly update and condense legislative acts that have become obsolete. I therefore agree with the Commission's proposal to repeal those regulations relating to the common agricultural policy that have become redundant, as they are no longer applied in practice. We will repeal both the outdated directive regulating the maximum eruic acid content of oils and fats and the regulation establishing a temporary framework for restructuring the sugar industry.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to ensure better lawmaking, it is essential that European Union law is continuously updated and compacted. We can also do this by repealing acts that no longer apply. In this way, we will ensure better transparency and certainty.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The proposed regulation is nothing more than a formality and has the aim of ensuring transparency and legal certainty, which are prerequisites of responsible law—making.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Some legal acts adopted in recent decades are no longer relevant because their content is covered by subsequent acts or because of their temporary nature. The aim of this proposal is to repeal Council Directive 76/621/EEC on determining the maximum level of eruk acid in oils and fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 100/2013/ 2013. 320/2006 on the establishment of a provisional system for the restructuring of the sugar industry, based on Article 42 and Article 43(2) of the Regulation. treaty on the functioning of the EU. These common policy legal acts are formally still in force, although outdated and should be repealed for reasons of legal certainty and clarity. I fully support the proposal to remove these acts from active legislation, as they no longer have a real impact and only technically remain in force.  In order to improve transparency and security, Union law should be updated and summarised by removing acts that no longer apply. The removal of these acts is a key element of the institutions' better law-making strategy.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ given that the legal acts in question no longer have practical use, I voted in favour of repealing them. However, the common agricultural policy contains substantially more parts that have long since been overcome or even made no sense in their initial implementation. Abolishing them would help EU taxpayers, as well as productive farmers, who could compete in fair competition on the market, rather than an environment warped by unequal levels of subsidies.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the common agricultural policy: repealing obsolete acts. I have confirmed the technical corrections that we use to repeal outdated acts. The European Commission does not have the power to repeal acts adopted by the Council and acts the content of which has been summarised by other acts or no longer current must be approved by the Council and the European Parliament in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since these Council Directives and Regulations have become obsolete and therefore obsolete they should also be repealed.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the implementation of competition rules for the production and trade of certain agricultural products and also aims at the establishment of a common organisation of agricultural markets. The aim of the proposal is to repeal provisions relating to the common agricultural policy which are no longer relevant. Some of these content has been taken over by subsequent acts or have been removed as a result of their temporary nature, thus simplifying and compressing EU legislation.  Article 114 TSI on the approximation of legislation on the creation and functioning of the internal market is a new proposal. The aim is to bring the dual legal basis for agricultural and internal market policy into line with the fixing of the highest levels of oils (cooking oils) and fats (edible fats), eeric acid content. Accordingly, the European Parliament and the Council adopt measures on the creation and functioning of the internal market under the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 European legislation needs renewal at certain times. The Treaty of Lisbon has created new mechanisms by which the European Parliament can act to bring European documents up to date. In some areas, scientific research is discovering new methods and products that create the prerequisites for change in favour of European consumers. One of these areas is the Common Agricultural Policy. Developed since the dawn of European construction, it is clear that European agricultural policy must be regulated in accordance with the imperatives of the present. It should be borne in mind that a number of compounds and chemicals found in agricultural products can adversely affect the evolution of individuals who consume them without being aware of the dangers to which they are exposed. It is the mission of specialists in the field to inform us of the existence of such dangers. Our mission is to pass legislation to protect the citizens who have given us their trust. For these reasons, I believe that it is necessary to support the document here.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. These are just corrections to the existing text, a kind of update which I share the evolutions of.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal of the Commission to repeal two legal acts concerning the common agricultural policy which have become obsolete, even though they are formally still in force. The repeal affects Council Directive 76/621/EEC relating to the fixing of the maximum level of erucic acid in oils and fats and to Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry. This move is in line with better law—making of the EU institutions, which agreed that Community law should be updated and condensed by repealing acts which are no longer applied.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 76/621/EEC establishing a maximum level of erucic acid in oils and fats and Council Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 of 17 May 1999 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2913/92 establishing the Community Customs Code [3]. I supported the introduction of a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry, as I believe that some of the legal acts adopted in recent decades are inadequate, their validity is only formal and should be repealed for reasons of legal certainty and clarity.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of repealing Directive 76/621/EEC, regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector since the contents of these rules had been outdated by the new CAP regulation and therefore made no sense for them to remain in force.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal of the Committee on Agriculture, which aims to bring it into line with the double legal basis (agricultural and internal market policy) applied when directive 76/621/EEC on the fixing of the highest levels of eerric acid in oils (cooking oils) and fats (dietary fats). This is important in order to establish a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour of repealing Directive 76/621/EEC, regulation (EC) No 320/2006 establishing a temporary regime for the restructuring of the sugar sector since the contents of these rules had been outdated by the new CAP regulation and therefore made no sense for them to remain in force.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this technical report to give greater legal certainty to the framework of the Common Agricultural Policy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution relating to the fixing of the maximum level of erucic acid in oils and establishing a temporary scheme for the restructuring of the sugar industry. I agree that improving the transparency of EU law is an essential element of the better law–making strategy that EU institutions are implementing, therefore it was necessary, in order to insure legal certainty and clarity, to repeal those legal acts which no longer have real effect.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a proposal from the European Commission to Parliament and the Council to repeal two obsolete acts: Council Directive 76/621/EEC, the content of which has been incorporated into Council Regulation (EC) No 1881/20061 and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/20061 on the time scheme established by this Regulation, which was only applicable during the period 2009/2010. In view of the technicality of this report, Parliament's Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development decided to adopt it by simplified procedure. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in your favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because this proposal aims to repeal certain acts adopted in recent decades that are no longer applicability, either because their content has been incorporated into successive acts, or because of their temporary nature. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not within the Commission's powers to declare obsolete acts which were adopted by the Council. The acts contained in the proposal should therefore be repealed by the Council and the European Parliament following the ordinary legislative procedure. The objective and content of the proposal for a Regulation consist of a pure repeal of Council Directive 76/621/EEC and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006. In particular, the two acts have become obsolete since the content of Council Directive 76/621/EEC has been incorporated into regulation 1881/2006, subsequent, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006 established only a temporary regime, which is no longer applicable.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the interinstitutional agreement for the simplification and improvement of EU laws, legislation should be updated and condensed, removing legal acts that are no longer applicable in order to improve transparency and trust. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not in the Commission's powers to declare obsolete legal acts that have been adopted by the Council. The acts listed in the Commission proposal should therefore be repealed by decision of the European Parliament, in this case the delegated acts establishing the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats and those establishing a temporary restructuring regime for the sugar industry.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It makes sense for Article 114 TFEU to be added to the legal basis for the repeal of acts. This report was therefore to be supported.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of the report on 'Common agricultural policy: repeal of outdated legislation'. Within the framework of the interinstitutional agreement on better regulation, the Commission proposes to repeal two pieces of legislation that are now obsolete. These two acts are in force, although they no longer have any practical application. The ECR supports the measure of repealing legislation that is no longer applicable – and that is my opinion. What is not needed should be gone, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report proposing the repeal of two legislation in the area of the common agricultural policy, Directive 76/621/EEC and Regulation (EC) No 320/2006(4). The Directive and the Regulation no longer fulfil their purpose in view of the changed circumstances. I am glad that with this vote we have contributed to simplifying and updating legislation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal serves to object to Council Directive 76/621/EEC, on the setting of the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats, and Council Regulation (EC) No 320/2006, which establishes a temporary restructuring regime for the sugar industry, as some of the legal acts adopted in recent decades are no longer relevant, either because their content has been adopted by other subsequent legal acts or because of their temporary nature. According to the Commission's proposal, it is not in the Commission's powers to declare obsolete legal acts that have been adopted by the Council. The acts listed in the Commission proposal should therefore be repealed by decision of the European Parliament, in this case the delegated acts establishing the maximum erucic acid content in oils and fats and those establishing a temporary restructuring regime for the sugar industry.  These have become obsolete as the content of Council Directive No 76/621/EEC has been repealed by Regulation 1881/2006 and Regulation 320/2006 only establishes a temporary scheme which is no longer applicable. We voted for it.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent On the way out, at least from purely geographical, historical, economic, cultural and other reasons, Switzerland has always been one of the most important partner countries of the European Union and its institutional predecessors, so I am quite pleased that soon after the adoption of this draft legislative resolution and the implementation of the protocol to the agreement as amended, as appropriate, cooperation with the Alpine Republic becomes even closer. I do not want to share sensitive information that could harm a country with such a reputation for much of the confidentiality of banks. And the security of personal information is a very important aspect of any person's life, including outside credit institutions. However, they often led to a situation where many people with accounts in Swiss banks simply did not pay taxes in their home countries, including the European Union, and information on such violations of the law was not available. Both purely human and as a socialist, I am in the opinion of social justice, which, among other things, is already a fair tax payment for the law. So I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, our policy toward Switzerland is driven by an unspoken or – indeed, in this Chamber – sometimes a voiced resentment about their stubborn independence. Not just the fact of being outside the European Union, but the fact that they dare to prosper – to be, according to the United Nations, the happiest and wealthiest country in Europe, with a remarkably low tax take. How they do it? How do they supply their peoples with the highest standard of living in the world while taking less than 30% of GDP in combined cantonal and federal spending, when we spend so much and get so little? Do you know what I would say: that is not they who have the problem. Perhaps, instead of trying to push the people of that sturdy mountain republic into joining the European Union, we should instead petition to become cantons of the Helvetic Confederation. We would have to be a lot more democratic, we would have to be a lot more open to referendums, we would have to cut our taxes and be a bit more competitive, and you know what: I can think of worse fates than that.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Madam President, there are many people who are trying to hide their income for which they have not paid taxes or do not want to pay taxes in the future. That's tax evasion. It is estimated that EUR 1 trillion is lost at European level in this way. Under the agreement signed this year, from 2018, the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents. The information exchanged includes income, interest, dividends, balance of accounts and income from the sale of financial assets. This report proposes concrete measures to combat tax evasion, in particular by natural and legal persons domiciled in the European Union, with the participation of financial institutions established in third countries. The report suggests mandatory disclosure of the full name and registration code. This leads to absolute transparency and reduces the risk of tax fraud or evasion.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, although I am aware that there is some tension between the issue of protecting banking secrecy, i.e. protecting certain sensitive information, which is the content of the right to privacy. Furthermore, there is the right of the State to pay taxes properly. It is undoubtedly clear that, in the past period, Switzerland has also served tax residents from European Union countries who have hidden their income from proper taxation here, and I think that is, of course, not right. Above all, it creates a kind of unfair competition between the two blocs, the EU bloc and Switzerland. I am therefore glad that the Swiss Federation has also agreed to the text of this agreement, which will indeed make it more difficult for tax residents to circumvent tax laws since 2018, which is why I supported it.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar is dóigh liom go bhfuilimid ag dul ar an tslí cheart. Dar ndóigh, is léir go n-úsáideann a lán daoine cuntas i mbanc san Eilvéis agus i dtíortha eile chun íocaíochtaí cánach a sheachaint agus níl sé sin féaráilte. Dar ndóigh, freisin, tá gaol an-mhór againn leis an Eilvéis agus tá buntáistí ann do mhuintir na hEilvéise de bharr an ghaoil sin.  Ag an am céanna, tá sé in am dúinn deireadh a chur leis an socrú seo ar mhaithe le saoránaigh nach mian leo a gcuid cheart de chánacha a íoc. Is tosach maith é seo, mar tar éis 2018 beidh malartú eolais airgeadais idir an tAontas agus an Eilvéis. Dar ndóigh, má íocann gach duine a chuid cheart, beidh níos lú le híoc ag na saoránaigh a íocann é gach uile lá. Dá bhrí sin, is dul chun cinn maith é seo.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary demand for financial information, it implies a position in favour of the use of tax havens for Europeans. The report implies an improvement in financial information exchange systems between the competent authorities of Switzerland and the European Union. However, this is not a sufficient commitment to ensure that European companies and citizens pay their funds in Europe, since in many States, despite the information being available, no action is taken. We need the abolition of the use of tax havens for Europeans, which must contribute to the financing of Member States like any citizen. That is why I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to amend the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This decision will also allow Switzerland to be subject to the same obligations as EU members, but also limit the possibility for taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to the tax authorities. The report also proposes the exchange of information on income, account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. Tax transparency and an end to bank secrecy both within the EU and on its doorstep is a priority in order to preserve the tax revenues of states.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While the intentions of this report were positive, it is another unfortunate case of style over substance. This is reflective of the democratic deficit which permeates the EU and means that much of the actions taken are often elaborate PR stunts. In this situation, the Council had decided on this report beforehand and only consulted Parliament after the ratification of the agreement. By way of background information, this agreement was signed on 27 May 2015 and it relates to the automatic exchange of financial account information and is aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The rapporteur did present a number of very good suggestions and tabled some important critiques but the Council refused to take them on board. It was for these reasons that I abstained on the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information to the eu's countries, which took place in March 2014, had to overcome the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg. One of the conditions for the abandonment of bank secrecy by these countries was Switzerland's acceptance of similar measures.  Following negotiations, a Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and Switzerland has been concluded and provides for the exchange of banking information within the framework of THE OECD's internationally proposed standards.  Being against capital flight, I voted in favour of the report on this protocol.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This sought Parliament’s approval of an EU-Switzerland agreement on the exchange of tax information. Such matters should be the subject of a bilateral agreement between nations, not dealt with at a European Union level.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation, which aims to make it more difficult for EU citizens to hide tax money in Swiss bank accounts.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for an EU-Switzerland agreement that will limit the ability of EU citizens to hide their finances in Swiss banks, thereby avoiding paying taxes. From 2018, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange their citizens' bank accounts data. This tax transparency agreement contributes to the fight against tax evasion and fraud. It will exchange not only information on interest or dividends, but also on balances of accounts or the sale of financial assets.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to achieve an end to bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information at the level of the Member States of the European Union, which took place in March 2014, the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg had to be overcome. One of the conditions for the abandonment of bank secrecy by these two Member States was Switzerland's acceptance of similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition. The Memorandum of Understanding, which is the subject of the Kofod report, provides that the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 1 January 2018. Because I am in favour of tax transparency and therefore at the end of bank secrecy, especially in order to preserve France's tax revenues, I logically voted for this text: for all the good that I can think of the Swiss Confederation, which defends its identity and sovereignty, it is unthinkable to let a country practice banking secrecy at the gates of the EU. , except to see a capital flight continue.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for an agreement between the EU and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. This exchange of information is expected to be implemented in 2018. In the current context and following the Swissleaks cases, it was essential to cele an agreement in order to increase tax cooperation in order to combat tax evasion.  The agreement includes certain provisions to limit the ability of taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to tax authorities by transferring their assets or investing in financial products outside the scope of the agreement. The information that must be exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which dealt with the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the protocol amending the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. Under this convoluted term lies a common-sense measure that will guarantee Member States to reduce their tax losses: it is an agreement between Switzerland and the EU to ensure the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. The principle of tax transparency and the end of bank secrecy are therefore anchored here, which should preserve the Cahuzac business of all kinds in the future. For example, the Kofod report provides for key measures such as limiting the ability of taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to tax authorities or requiring the States concerned to disclose not only income but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. It was therefore a question of voting in favour of this gradual end to tax impunity.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Kofod report is well developed and acceptable. The strengthening of the automatic exchange of tax information to ensure that Swiss legislation is in line with EU legislation, in compliance with OECD global standards, must form the basis of the EU-Switzerland relations; That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the conclusion of the EU-Switzerland Agreement on automatic exchange of reportable accounts with a view to improving international cooperation and tax compliance. This agreement is an important step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and renews the 2004 agreement, which ensured that Switzerland applied measures equivalent to those of the EU Savings Tax Directive. Under this agreement, from 2018, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on each other's financial accounts. The aim is to respond to cases where a taxpayer tries to conceal capital constituting income or assets for which no taxes have been paid. The agreement also aims to ensure that Switzerland applies more stringent measures that are equivalent to an EU directive, which was updated in March 2014. and that comply with the automatic provisions for the exchange of information on accounts to be reported, which are Global standards of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As I said on the previous point, mandatory tax exchange between countries, whether they are EU Member States or third countries, is a key step towards reducing tax evasion.  Switzerland has one of the highest levels of banking confidentiality and since World War II has enjoyed a reputation as a country where banks hide huge amounts of financial resources from all over the world, including suspicious origins. It is therefore necessary to improve dialogue with the Swiss Federation and to improve international cooperation in the tax area in the fight against tax evasion in the EU, which has gained considerable ly in the last year. The agreement, which I have, of course, supported, represents an important step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and provides, inter alia, for the automatic exchange of information on resident financial accounts between the EU and Switzerland from 2018 onwards. This seeks to disclose the taxpayer's full assets, regardless of where his assets or capital are located. The possibilities for avoiding the registration of assets to tax authorities by transferring assets to third parties or by investing in products not covered by the agreement are also limited. The information exchanged will relate not only to income in the form of interest and dividends, but also to the balance of the accounts and the proceeds of the sale of financial assets.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While the intentions of this report were positive, it is another unfortunate case of style over substance. This is reflective of the democratic deficit which permeates the EU and means that much of the actions taken are often elaborate PR stunts. In this situation, the Council had decided on this report beforehand and only consulted Parliament after the ratification of the agreement. By way of background information, this agreement was signed on 27 May 2015 and it relates to automatic exchange of financial account information and is aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The rapporteur did present a number of very good suggestions and tabled some important critiques but the Council refused to take them on board. It was for these reasons that I abstained on the report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes represents a marked improvement on the 2004 agreement and an important step in the fight against tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to convince the Austrian and Luxembourg authorities to ratify the agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which was announced in March 2014, the European Union has worked to negotiate with the Swiss government the end of bank secrecy which created unfair tax competition in Europe.   The agreement with Switzerland, which will take effect from 1 January 2018, provides that EU Member States and the Swiss government will automatically exchange data on income, account balances and capital gains from the sale of financial assets. These measures will greatly limit the ability of Europeans to evade taxation from their country of origin and allow Member States to recover the tax revenue due to them.  We are in favour of this cooperation which will limit tax evasion in Europe. That is why I voted for this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Switzerland Agreement on the Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information was signed on 27 May 2015. This agreement has a very important role to play at European level, because it improves cooperation in the tax field and carries out the rules at international level. This agreement will be implemented from 2018 and an attempt is being made for Switzerland to apply consolidated measures equivalent to the EU Directive and to respect the automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts promoted by the overall standards of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in 2014. By agreement, the financial administrations of the Member States and Switzerland will be able to correctly identify the taxpayers concerned and manage and implement national tax laws. I voted in favour of this report because this mechanism can combat tax evasion and evasion affecting the european Union economy and beyond.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The agreement is intended to ensure that Switzerland applies enhanced measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive, as updated in March 2014, and that it respects the exchange of financial account information promoted by oecd standards of 2014.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the agreement on the automatic exchange of tax information between the EU and Switzerland, which will finally make it possible to combat tax fraud and evasion.  Thanks to this agreement, the EU and Switzerland will be able to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents from 2018 to deal with any capital concealment and tax evasion activities. The exchange of information will cover not only income transactions, such as interest and dividends, but also accounting balances and proceeds from sales of financial assets, in compliance with the global standards promoted by the OECD in 2014 for the automatic exchange of financial communications for tax purposes. Although we will need other similar agreements in order to better define the timing and modalities of the automatic exchange of information and to guarantee the confidentiality and protection of personal data, the text provides for very effective instruments, and that is why I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ While the intentions of this report were positive, it is another unfortunate case of style over substance. This is reflective of the democratic deficit which permeates the EU and means that much of the actions taken are often elaborate PR stunts. In this situation, the Council had decided on this report beforehand and only consulted Parliament after the ratification of the agreement. By way of background information, this agreement was signed on 27 May 2015 and it relates to automatic exchange of financial account information and is aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The rapporteur did present a number of very good suggestions and tabled some important critiques but the Council refused to take them on board. It was for these reasons that I abstained on the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because changes to the already existing agreement are justified, as improvements are needed in order to be able to deal with the constant changes concerning the exchange of information at international level. The improvements will allow for a more efficient action against tax avoidance and tax evasion by ensuring full tax transparency and greater cross-border cooperation between different national tax administrations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement should be an important step forward in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. The aim is to address situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. Although the proposals in Mr Kofod's report add value, I felt that more needed to be done on such an important issue. In addition, our vote today is only advisory. In the light of the above, I have chosen to abstain.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on 27 May 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Switzerland implemented measures equivalent to those provided for in an EU directive on taxation of savings income.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information, signed on 27 May 2015. This agreement aims to ensure that Switzerland complies with its practices with those of the EU Directive on Administrative Cooperation, updated in March 2014, and that it respects the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standards. Under the agreement, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, starting in 2018. The aim is to address situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. The exchange of information concerns not only income such as interest and dividends, but also balancing items and income from sales of financial assets. There are also provisions to limit the possibility of taxpayers avoiding being reported to the tax authorities by transferring assets or investing in financial products outside the scope of the agreement.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it represents an important step forward in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. In addition, the agreement is intended to ensure that Switzerland applies enhanced measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive, as updated in March 2014 (amending the Administrative Cooperation Directive, "DAC2"), and that it respects the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD Global Standards. Finally, I agree with the rapporteur on the provisions aimed at limiting the possibility of taxpayers avoiding being reported to the tax authorities by transferring assets or investing in financial products outside the scope of the agreement. The exchange of information concerns not only income such as interest and dividends, but also balancing items and income from sales of financial assets.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement on the automatic exchange of tax information signed by Switzerland and the European Union is an important milestone in terms of international tax cooperation.  Indeed, I think it is right that Switzerland should apply enhanced measures equivalent to those of the EU directive and that it should respect the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the OECD's 2014 global standards, in order to prevent taxpayers from trying to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. I am therefore in favour of this proposal, an important agreement which represents a further step forward in efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal asks for Parliament’s approval of a new act that updates regulations regarding the exchange of financial information between Swiss and EU officials. The report stresses the importance of taking effective action against fraud and tax avoidance and in particular tax evasion and tax avoidance by natural and legal persons based in the European Union with the involvement of financial institutions based in third countries, thus I voted in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is parliament's consultation on the agreement signed between the EU and Switzerland on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The agreement should be an important step forward in efforts to combat fraud and tax evasion. The aim is to address situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. The rapporteur, in the ECON Committee, put forward some proposals that we can support on the automatic exchange of information, confidentiality and protection of personal data, arbitration in cases of litigation, alignment with current legislation and entry into force. Although the proposals add value, I believe that more needs to be done. I also believe that on such an important issue Parliament should not only be consulted. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary demand for financial information, it implies a position in favour of the use of tax havens for Europeans. The report implies an improvement in financial information exchange systems between the competent authorities of Switzerland and the European Union. However, this is not a sufficient commitment to ensure that European companies and citizens pay their funds in Europe, since in many States, despite the information being available, no action is taken. We need the abolition of the use of tax havens for Europeans, which must contribute to the financing of Member States like any citizen. That is why I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Automatic exchange of financial information is a key tool to combat both tax avoidance and evasion. I voted in favour of the resolution approving the amendment of the AGREEMENT between the EU and Switzerland to bring it into line with recent regulatory developments in tax matters. A clear and effective regulatory framework at European level, ensuring both full tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations, is of primary importance in order to ensure greater regulatory clarity and to reduce costs and administrative burdens for both tax administrations and economic operators.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. Under the agreement, an automatic exchange of information between the EU and Switzerland on the financial accounts of each other's residents will be established from 2018 onwards. The information to be exchanged relates not only to income such as interest and dividends, but also to account balances and income from the sale of financial instruments.  This is an important step in combating tax fraud and evasion, so I supported the report. The agreement aims to ensure that Switzerland applies reinforced measures equivalent to the EU Directive modernised in March 2014 and to comply with the automatic exchange of financial account information as advocated by global OECD standards.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this agreement, which aims at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The EU and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. This agreement represents an important step in addressing situations where taxpayers seek to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to make the exchange of information in the tax field between Switzerland and the European Union automatic and compulsory, with the aim of making it more difficult to practice fraud and tax evasion. The agreement, which will come into force in 2018, mainly concerns information from the bank accounts of Swiss and European residents. Considering that fraud and tax evasion penalise European citizens by initiating the state's means of action, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. Strengthening our international cooperation is essential in the fight against cross-border tax evasion and evasion. It is the importance of this agreement being aligned with the latest international developments developed by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against tax havens and forms of excessive tax competition is one of the main battles to which the European Parliament has given voice in these months of the legislature. Thanks to parliament's continued work, it was possible to push the Commission towards the conclusion of an agreement with Switzerland last May. This agreement focuses mainly on practices concerning the automatic exchange of tax information, thus improving cooperation and compliance with international standards. In particular, the exchange of information concerns not only labour and capital income, but also sales of financial assets. In this way, the principles present in the 2014 OECD standards are followed. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text. stressing the role of the European Parliament as the protagonist of European battles against aggressive tax planning for a more supportive and equitable Union, especially in the field of taxation.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report was to enable the exchange of information on the financial income of non-residents between Switzerland and the European Union. By approving the automatic and mandatory nature of the transmission of information, this report is a real step forward. Too many still problems of financial opacity related to Switzerland. It is really necessary to allow Member States to have accurate and automated monitoring of the financial income information of their nationals, without them being able to use the Swiss system to evade it. Defending the financial transparency and sovereignty of states over their nationals, I voted for this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the Kofod report on the EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information and welcome the fact that the existing savings agreement is made compatible with current EU and OECD global standards. I am in support of standards which will include, for example, a more detailed set of provisions on data protection, provisions on exchange or information upon request according to the OECD model, and a mechanism to adopt amendments to the global standard swiftly on the condition of consent by the other contracting party.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 Making the existing Services Agreement with Switzerland compatible with existing EU legislation and OECD global standards is an important step that is welcome.  We need to be very careful when it comes to the protection of personal data, the exchange of information and democratic control, especially when we consider the current issues of digital infrastructures and increasingly digitised economies. It must be ensured that the exchange of information is done in the safest and most effective way possible, ensuring transparency and legal clarity, especially for citizens who rely on the protection and retention of their personal data.  Also, given the fact that Switzerland has long been known for its strict confidentiality rules involving a very complex set of rules, it is necessary to adjust the existing rules in order to make them compatible with each other and to avoid inadvertently creating legal loopholes.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 States must conclud transnational agreements in order to be able quickly, reliably and always in accordance with the laws to investigate and deliver justice in cases of financial crimes. The European Union must be a helper in this effort by the States in such a way that their sovereign rights are not infringed. We do not agree with Articles 5 and 6 of the report, as they violate the principle of the protection of personal data and do not allow States to cooperate with Switzerland in order to provide the details of their nationals and to examine their bank accounts.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. On 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information to improve tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. Important progress in the context of the efforts being made to combat tax fraud and evasion. From 2018, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other party. The aim is to prevent situations where a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no tax has been paid. It also contains provisions to limit the possibilities for taxpayers to avoid communicating their information to tax authorities by transferring assets or investing in products outside the scope of the agreement. I voted in favour.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third states. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2004, the Council decided to conclude the agreement between the EU and the Swiss Confederation in order to ensure the adoption by the Swiss Confederation of measures equivalent to those to be applied in the EU to ensure effective taxation of savings income in the form of interest (Directive No 2003/48/EC). The agreement, signed on 27 May 2015, on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation represents an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement. However, there are several limitations of this proposal: the non-requirement of complete and detailed information on account owners, in line with the effort to achieve absolute transparency and full disclosure of information as a mandatory requirement; the fact that the original deadline for the automatic exchange of information is unsuitable, and it is necessary to tighten the reporting cycle from an annual basis to a quarterly basis; the existence of an exemption from disclosure of information, provision too broad and ambiguous. The agreement – the content of which the European Parliament cannot change – is clearly below what is necessary. Hence our abstention.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained because there is an obvious absence of any real effort at true reform in the agreement.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: on 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland concluded an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, the main objective of which is to improve international tax cooperation. This agreement represents a very important step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion. As a result of this agreement, the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on their people's financial accounts from 2018 on.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report to ensure that the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD global standards between the EU and Switzerland is respected.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the EU-Switzerland Agreement on the removal of the banking secrecy of EU citizens. Where there is evidence of money accounts which have been obtained illegally and are therefore the product of an economic crime, the authorities should be informed to do the appropriate thing.  This will make it more difficult for the tax authorities to hide funds. The fixed position of our movement is transparency in all transactions. Ending banking secrecy is a very important step in the fight against tax evasion so that "thieves go to jail and the stolen goods are returned to the people".

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the agreement signed on 27 May 2015 between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which will improve international tax cooperation and compliance. Switzerland is a key player and the agreement is a significant step in our efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion.  I believe that the automatic exchange on the financial accounts between the EU and Switzerland, starting from 2018, will address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. Also, I think it is very important that the agreement gives the ability to tax administrations in the Member States and in Switzerland to identify correctly the taxpayers concerned, as well as to administer and enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations. At the same time, I hope this will help authorities to better assess the likelihood of tax evasion being committed and, in some cases, stop unnecessary investigations.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of information in the financial sector, because from 2018 it will allow the automatic exchange of information concerning the bank accounts of residents of EU countries and Switzerland and will mark Switzerland's adaptation to OECD standards. The agreement is very important because it definitively puts an end to banking secrecy and will reduce tax evasion fuelled over time by those companies or individuals who conceal their wealth in open current accounts on Swiss territory with the aim of avoiding paying taxes. It will make it possible to crack down on fraud and tax evasion, since the exchange includes not only profits, and specifically dividends and interest, but also current account balances and financial assets. However, some financial products remain outside the agreement. This will allow taxpayers, even after 2018, to avoid declaring to the tax authorities certain transfers of assets or investments in certain products excluded from the scope of the agreement. The European Parliament has been taking action for years in favour of greater transparency in the tax field. I therefore hope that your action to stimulate the Council will be even more incisive in the future.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'EU-Switzerland Agreement on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts' because it is an important step in the fight against tax evasion, which ultimately benefits our public budgets and thus all honest taxpayers.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Existing tax loopholes must be closed. For this we need a complete documentation of all tax levies. The exchange of information between the EU and Switzerland, which will enter into force in 2018, is a groundbreaking example of this. The annual losses from lost tax revenue can thus be reduced.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This act seeks the approval of the EU Parliament for an agreement to exchange tax details between the EU and Switzerland. Any arrangement that needs to be made regarding taxation should be made bilaterally, and not via the EU. Once again, more sovereignty salami sliced away.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of approving the agreement between the EU and Switzerland because it is vital, in the global fight against aggressive tax planning and tax evasion, that we work with non-EU countries like Switzerland in order to make sure that no one can dodge taxes simply by hiding their money overseas.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The fight against tax evasion and evasion is one of C's priorities in Europe, as undeclared and unrecumbered incomes result in a significant reduction in national tax revenues and are a sign of insolidarity and irresponsibility. That is why I support the conclusion of the Protocol to amend the agreement with Switzerland agreeing to the automatic exchange of financial account information.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the EU-Switzerland agreement on the exchange of financial information for tax purposes. This agreement represents a great step forward in the fight against fraud and tax evasion. Our aim must be to fight against those who seek to conceal capital. Our priority must be to strengthen measures that respect the automatic exchange of information not only on income but also on the proceeds of sales of financial assets. The agreement needs to be further strengthened. I hope that this path will also be taken with other third countries through similar future agreements.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this text, which seeks to implement measures similar to those in other European countries in relation to Switzerland to promote transparency and combat tax evasion and avoidance. However, the agreement is clearly insufficient and provides for too many exceptions that will serve to maintain the status of tax haven of the Helvetic Confederation. In addition, it has been submitted to Parliament once it has been closed with Switzerland.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, voted in favour of approving the Agreement between the EU and Switzerland because it is vital, in the global fight against tax evasion, that we work with non-EU countries and key-players like Switzerland in order to make sure that no one can dodge taxes simply by hiding their money overseas. This agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this agreement because it represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion and upgrades the 2004 agreement that ensured that Switzerland applied measures equivalent to those in an EU directive on the taxation of savings. I support the fact that, under this agreement, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents, starting in 2018. The aim is to address situations where a taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it is aimed towards improving international tax compliance and stresses the importance of taking effective action against fraud and tax avoidance. In particular it stresses taking effective action against tax evasion and tax avoidance by natural and legal persons based in the European Union with the involvement of financial institutions based in third countries.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation on measures equivalent to those set out in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings interest income, as this strengthens cooperation between the Union and Switzerland in the area of financial transactions. This contributes strongly to the reduction of tax evasion and the situation of hiding capital that represents income or property and for which tax has not been paid.  In my view, the agreement obliges Switzerland to apply measures equivalent to European legislation in the sector concerned. I believe that the exchange of information is necessary to ensure a fair and coherent tax policy and therefore I support this report which accepts the draft Council decision and approves the conclusion of the agreement.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information to the eu's countries, which took place in March 2014, had to overcome the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg. One of the conditions for the abandonment of bank secrecy by these countries was Switzerland's acceptance of similar measures. Following negotiations, a Memorandum of Understanding between the EU and Switzerland has been concluded and provides for the exchange of banking information within the framework of THE OECD's internationally proposed standards. Being against capital flight, I voted in favour of the report on this protocol.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason I voted against the proposals.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses a Memorandum in the EU-Switzerland Agreement to facilitate and make the exchange of financial information automatic.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a great success for which the EP has worked systematically and effectively. The exchange of relevant information is extremely critical for any attempt to control black money and to tackle illegal economic actions and the shadow economy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report. It is based on the agreement, which provides for the EU and Switzerland to automatically exchange information on their respective customers' bank accounts from 2018. This measure is intended to help better record tax avoidance, tax avoidance and fraud through black money accounts. The aim is to help national tax authorities to obtain information more clearly, comprehensively and transparently and to no longer be dependent on legal grey areas (such as .B tax CDs).

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal as it is vital, in the global fight against aggressive tax planning and tax evasion, that we work with non-EU countries like Switzerland in order to make sure that no one can dodge taxes simply by hiding their money overseas.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The aim of the report is to narrow the possibilities of tax avoidance and fraud, so I supported it, of course. Unfortunately, there are many other countries and offshore areas other than Switzerland that offer the possibility of tax evasion, so the agreement signed between the European Union and Switzerland on 27 May 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information does not fully solve this problem, but it is clearly an important step.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour of this proposal for a Council decision. On 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of tax information. This represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. In fact, under the agreement, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, starting in 2018. I also believe that in the negotiation of future tax agreements with Switzerland or with third countries, the Commission must follow the proposals and guidelines laid down by Parliament and the Council and contained in this proposal for a decision.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Kofod report relates to the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the EU, of the protocol amending the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This agreement therefore aims to ensure the exchange of information on the financial income of non-residents.  Even if the text has shortcomings in the level of information transmitted or the automatic and obligatory nature of information exchanges or tax evasion, I voted in favour of this text which goes in the right direction.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this agreement with Switzerland because it guarantees the exchange of information relating to the financial accounts of residents of Switzerland and the European Union. It thus promotes tax transparency and helps to curb the flight of capital in Switzerland.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The agreement, negotiated by the Council on behalf of the European Union, provides for the automatic exchange of information between Switzerland and the European Union (from 2018) concerning the financial accounts of their respective residents. This measure will apply, for example, to French residents with an account in Switzerland. All the provisions of this text are part of a logic of fiscal transparency that I defend. The end of bank secrecy will also help to stop the flight of our capital to Europe's doorstep, to a country that does not practice this transparency. I voted for this report.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because this is Estados.De major step forward in combating tax evasion and avoidance, particularly that which takes place in third parties in accordance with this convention, from 2018 on the basis of 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary demand for financial information, it implies a position in favour of the use of tax havens for Europeans. The report implies an improvement in financial information exchange systems between the competent authorities of Switzerland and the European Union. However, this is not a sufficient commitment to ensure that European companies and citizens pay their funds in Europe, since in many States, despite the information being available, no action is taken. We need the abolition of the use of tax havens for Europeans, which must contribute to the financing of Member States like any citizen. That is why I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in May 2015 to enhance and harmonise international tax cooperation. The agreement is due to enter into force on 1 January 2017 and is an important step towards combating tax fraud and tax evasion where Switzerland will also apply measures equivalent to those of eu directives.  It adds an obligation to publish a full name and identification number to achieve absolute transparency, instead of one report per year, a reduction of the timeframe to three months is required, then unconditional exchange of information is required and that the scope for dividends, interest and royalty be aligned with current European legislation due to coherence and consistency. I supported Representative Jeppe Kofod's report, as it is necessary to detect suspicious behaviour of taxpayers in time and prevent tax evasion. All this is causing great damage to the EU budget, and quality international cooperation can be the key to success.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I warmly welcome another step that will bring both the European Union and our Swiss partners closer. I call on the responsible EU officials to work on similar agreements with other partner countries whose banking systems do not fully receive taxes due to them because of the specific nature of our banking systems.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Agreement of May 2015 concluded between the EU and Switzerland will enter into force and thus of practical relevance from 2018. The exchange of information on financial accounts will strengthen control and increase tax discipline, while helping to detect crime in tax fraud.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015 and because multinational companies have emerged as champions, which, through the system of intra-group transactions, avoid tax. Their allies are the various tax havens and some euro area Member States engaged in tax dumping and unfair practices, thus giving multinationals vital space not to pay multi-billion euro in taxes. In countries such as Greece, the total amount of the aid was EUR 1 million. Luxembourg with the so-called 'Lux Leaks' and the Netherlands give cover to German and other multinationals in order to avoid tax. And all this at a time when Mr. Dijsselbloem shakes his finger in Greece and demands a new tax-free resalto in the pockets of greeks. Moreover, the troika in Greece disguises all Greek governments that refuse to take advantage of the Lagarde list and tax Greek oligarchs who have illegal deposits in Switzerland.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this proposal but regret that no improvements could be made, particularly regarding information provided and the automatic, binding and unrestricted nature of exchanges of information.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes can be seen as a key step in the fight against tax evasion. The agreement provides for the European Union and Switzerland to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents from January 2018 and requires Switzerland to apply appropriate measures that are equivalent to those of the European Union to combat tax evasion. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of information in the tax field on 27 May. The ultimate aim of this agreement, which requires the EU and Switzerland to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, is to take further steps in the fight against fraud and tax evasion. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the report signed by Mr Kofod.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The purpose of the report or proposal is to cover situations in which a taxable person attempts to hide capital from the treasury in the form of income or assets for which no tax has been paid. The report makes changes that make this even more consistent. The report was therefore in agreement.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. On 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at increasing tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations.
