The objective is to deal with situations in which a taxpayer seeks to conceal capital that corresponds to income or assets over which the tax has not been paid. But the proposal does not provide for a requirement to disclose complete and detailed information about account holders, namely their name, first name and tax identification number. In other words, bank secrecy is maintained! The rapporteur validates the agreement, which does not need Parliament's opinion to be implemented anyway, while timidly criticising this point. All this is a charade, I abstain.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the AGREEMENT between the EU and Switzerland to improve tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations with a view to automatically exchanging information on financial accounts. It is very important that effective measures are taken against tax fraud and avoidance and, in this case, with regard to the practice by natural or legal persons established in the Union with the participation of financial institutions in third countries. The fight against tax fraud, avoidance and tax evasion involves not only a Community approach, involving national efforts at EU level but also at global level, in which the European Parliament plays a key role.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution on the agreement between the EU and Switzerland as it is another step forward in combating tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement means that as of 2018 the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of each other’s residents to clamp down on tax evasion.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. This is a long-awaited agreement that will allow automatic exchange of information between the EU and Switzerland on the bank accounts of its citizens from 2018. The agreement is adopted with the aim of improving international cooperation and compliance in the field of taxation, it will serve to reduce tax fraud and evasion. Switzerland will apply measures that comply with the EU Directive. I agree that the Commission will continue to act as a binding mediator for the role of control and consultation. I believe that there is scope for further modifications to the agreement, so I propose and call on the Commission to review the application of this agreement 18 months after its entry into force.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of the EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which aims at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in ongoing efforts to clamp down on tax fraud and tax evasion. Switzerland is a key player and more transparency is needed.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A vote adding to the legal architecture of Europe allowing the disciplining of financial transactions and limiting the scope for tax evasion and fraud.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed to the Council the repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings (see next point). The Directive was also applicable between EU Member States and Switzerland through a separate bilateral agreement concluded in 2004. On the other hand, on 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information, which amended that 2004 bilateral agreement in line with the 2014 global OECD standards for the automatic exchange of financial account information. The Council intends to take a decision on the ratification of this Agreement and, under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, it must consult the European Parliament before taking that decision. Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, in its report, recommended to Parliament the approval of the council's draft decision and thus the conclusion of the agreement. I supported the Council's draft decision accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This agreement confirms the end of banking secrecy in Switzerland from 1 January 2018, already in effect in March 2014 at EU level.  To do so, the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg had to be overcome. One of the conditions that these countries posed was Switzerland's acceptance of similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition.   Switzerland will apply measures equivalent to those set out in the European texts (Directive 2003/48/EC review). It will thus respect the automatic exchange of financial account information, as set out in OECD global standards in 2014. The information that will have to be exchanged will also concern not only income (interest, dividends), but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets, which greatly limits the remaining opportunities to evade taxation. This agreement is therefore to be welcomed.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Kofod report concerns the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the protocol amending the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's 2003/48/EC Directive on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This agreement therefore aims to ensure the exchange of information on the financial income of non-residents.  Even if the text has shortcomings in the level of information transmitted, the automatic and compulsory nature of information exchanges or tax evasion, I voted in favour of this text which goes in the right direction.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text which authorizes the Council to amend the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation and to take measures to improve the exchange of information on the taxation of savings income collected in the form of interest payments. According to European Commission estimates, tax evasion by EU-based individuals and corporations using third-country financial institutions represents a loss of income in the order of EUR 1 trillion. The concerted action of Member States in this area is essential to effectively combat this scourge, which has resulted in significant loss of public revenue.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the conclusion of the AGREEMENT between the EU and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of information, aimed at improving cooperation and compliance with tax obligations at international level. It is, in fact, an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion by improving the 2004 agreement guaranteeing the application of measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income.  An automatic exchange of information on the financial accounts of their residents will therefore be carried out from 2018. We believe it is essential for Switzerland to apply enhanced measures and to respect the automatic exchange of financial account data, promoted by oecd global standards. It will cover not only income such as interest and dividends, but also balancing items and income from sales of financial assets.  However, we share the rapporteur's view that there is still room for improvement: unfortunately, the procedure adopted does not allow amendments to the proposed international agreement, so we hope that future agreements with other third countries will be concluded quickly bilaterally.  Finally, we call for the date set for its entry into force, 1 January 2017, to be respected, as decided by the parties, without further unjustified delays.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on 27 May 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. I voted for this report that will ensure that Switzerland applies strengthened measures that are equivalent to the EU directive as upgraded in March 2014 and that it complies with the automatic exchange of financial account information promoted by the 2014 OECD global standards.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In order to effectively fight against fraud, tax avoidance and tax evasion, and to correctly limit those who would avoid paying the legal and proper taxes on their income, this report suggests a number of measures that I agree are necessary. It would extend to Switzerland the strengthened measures to prevent fraudulent activities that are already applied in the EU, and would allow an automatic exchange of financial account information to prevent persons based in the EU from hiding their capital in the financial institutions of Switzerland, exploiting its status as a non-member state. The OECD global standards that apply to this kind of information exchange would be respected in these cases, protecting the privacy of individuals who are adequately complying with Union tax laws. Additionally, this report provides a framework for preventing the use of non-Member State financial institutions by EU-based persons and companies to avoid paying the appropriate taxes, which will need to be addressed in many countries, not only Switzerland. Again, I reiterate that steps need to be taken to continue to fight tax evasion and tax avoidance, and this report offers viable solutions.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – While the intentions of this report were positive, it is another unfortunate case of style over substance. This is reflective of the democratic deficit which permeates the EU and means that much of the actions taken are often elaborate PR stunts. In this situation, the Council had decided on this report beforehand and only consulted Parliament after the ratification of the agreement. By way of background information, this agreement was signed on 27 May 2015 and it relates to automatic exchange of financial account information and is aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The rapporteur did present a number of very good suggestions and tabled some important critiques but the Council refused to take them on board. It was for these reasons that I abstained on the report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report mentions that From 2018, Switzerland will have to automatically exchange all information about bank accounts. This measure is intended to help better record tax avoidance, evasion and fraud through black money accounts. The aim is to help the treasury to obtain this information more precisely, comprehensively and transparently. That is because of this, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which is another step in the fight against tax evasion and evasion. It provides for the harmonisation of the measures of the agreement signed on 27 May 2005 between the European Union and Switzerland with those of the Council's 2003/48/EC directive on income savings taxation. This harmonization will allow for more detailed information to be identified in the context of the automatic exchange of financial account information. This harmonization protocol improves the capacity of tax administrations to act, which will have more means of correctly and unequivocally identifying fraudulent taxpayers and will be able to extend national tax laws to cross-border situations.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to detect tax fraud and tax evasion, it is important that the EU and Switzerland exchange data with each other and that Switzerland also applies measures equivalent to EU requirements. The purpose of the agreement is to improve international taxation cooperation.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report and welcome the conclusion of this agreement.  This agreement is necessary to prevent tax fraud and tax evasion.  Tax cooperation between the EU and Switzerland needs to be strengthened. Switzerland must become more open. The exchange of information on the financial accounts of each other is therefore necessary. In particular, it will ensure full tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations and prevent tax illegal activities.  It is essential that Switzerland applies the more stringent measures provided for in EU legislation. By providing mutual administrative and judicial assistance, the Contracting Parties will improve mutual international cooperation and tax compliance.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The EU-Switzerland agreement on the exchange of financial account information is far from the need to transmit all the information necessary to uncover tax evasion, tax avoidance and capital movements of large business groups and plutocracy. Except that it is not even explicitly binding, it does not provide for an exchange of all detailed information allowing at least identification. The exchange of information takes place on an annual basis, giving a long period of time for data change and avoidance of consequences. Most importantly: it introduces a number of terms and conditions, such as the non-delivery of information from complaints or when they (even arbitrarily) are deemed to be contrary to 'public policy' or where they are classified as 'confidential'. All these restrictions essentially remove any binding nature of the exchange of information and leave the margin for selective disclosure of information. The agreement is thus done 'for the eyes of the world', to appease popular indignation by the provocative tax immunity of plutocracy and monopolistic groups, at the same time as the EU and civil governments are smashing the people with all sorts of taxes. The bottom line is that, as long as monopolies and the profit-based market economy dominate, large capital will find both legitimate and illegal ways to treasure.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering it of particular strategic interest for the European Union to conclude this agreement with Switzerland with a view to combating tax fraud and evasion, which unfortunately further aggravate the already critical conditions of the economy of some Member States, and in line with what the rapporteur has requested to ensure its entry into force by 2017, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported this legislative resolution regarding the historic agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on tax transparency, which commits to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of my residents. The proposed and supported amendment from the European Parliament should make it easier for Member States to identify tax evaders and should also reduce the hiding of revenues and assets abroad in order to avoid paying taxes. I support the clear expression of this short resolution which underlines the importance of taking effective measures against tax fraud and tax evasion, in particular against tax fraud and tax evasion committed by natural and legal persons located in the Union with the participation of financial institutions located in third countries. I hope that in 18 months we will have a report from the European Commission that will show all the justification for the steps taken today.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to the Council's draft decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the protocol amending the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those provided for in the Council's 2003/48/EC Directive on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. This agreement therefore aims to ensure the exchange of information on the financial income of non-residents. Even if the text has shortcomings in the level of information transmitted, the automatic and compulsory nature of information exchanges or tax evasion, I voted in favour of this text which goes in the right direction.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the decision to cooperate and share information on financial accounts between the EU and Switzerland aimed at preventing and exposing attempts at tax fraud and tax avoidance, with a view to improving international tax cooperation. These are situations where they seek to hide income or funds on which no tax has been paid, and automated exchange of information will include interest and dividends and funds obtained from the sale of financial assets.  This decision will allow for the exchange of information with a view to identifying specific taxpayers, applying tax laws in cross-border situations, assessing the likelihood of tax avoidance and avoiding further unnecessary investigations. Furthermore, I agree with the rapporteur that there is scope for improvement and further measures, such as achieving an even greater level of transparency and more extensive exchange of information, reporting more frequently to the competent authorities on the actions and supervisory measures implemented, and lifting a number of exceptions and restrictions on this type of exchange.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on 27 May 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information, aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement is an important step in efforts to combat tax fraud and tax cover-ups, and to upgrade an agreement since 2004 that ensures Switzerland implements measures equivalent to those in the EU Savings Income Taxation Directive.  Under the agreement, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on residents' financial accounts, starting in 2018. The aim is to address situations where the taxpayer seeks to hide capital representing income or assets for which taxes have not been paid. The agreement aims to ensure that Switzerland applies measures equivalent to the EU directive, and to promote global standards in line with the automatic exchange of financial account information. There are further provisions intended to limit opportunities for taxpayers in order to avoid reporting to tax authorities by transferring assets or investing in products outside the scope of the agreement.  Tax administrations in the Member States and Switzerland will be able to identify correct and unambiguous taxpayers when it comes to managing and enforcing tax laws in cross-border situations and assessing the likelihood of tax evasions committed. For all of the above, I support rapporteur Jeppe Kofoda.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the adoption of Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings income, the EU signed an agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information on 27 May 2015. Thanks to this agreement, from 2018, the EU and Switzerland will be able to automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents. The exchange of information will include not only income from interest and dividends, but also balances and income from the sale of financial assets. The common objective is to be able to cope with situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. I believe that this agreement represents an important step forward in the fight against fraud.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report approving the conclusion of the protocol amending the agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation in relation to the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts. This agreement facilitates the exchange of financial information between the two spaces and strengthens trade control to combat fraud and money laundering.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because I consider it crucial to ensure compliance with the rules on the automatic exchange of information to improve compliance with international tax obligations.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency but not of the Commission being involved in negotiating tax treaties – something which could just as easily be done on a bilateral basis by Member States in their own capacity. For this reason UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this text which sets out the position of this House on the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of information relating to financial accounts, which will start in 2018. What will this agreement, signed on 27 May, bring in practice once it is in force? The latter will represent a significant step towards ending the banking secrecy of EU citizens in Switzerland. It will be more difficult for a taxpayer to hide money on which a tax must be paid.  Among the new means of action offered to the tax administrations of the Member States are the possibility of correctly and unequivocally identifying the taxpayers concerned, the possibility of administering and enforcing tax laws in cross-border situations or the possibility of assessing the likelihood of tax evasion perpetrated.  The European Union and Switzerland must now conclude the agreement on time to allow it to enter into force on 1 January 2017. We will be consulted again in this process.  Tax evasion is an attack on the values of solidarity on which our social models are based. This agreement is a new step, which will have to be extended, to put an end to it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this international agreement with Switzerland on the automatic exchange of tax information because it is a major step forward in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, particularly in third States. In accordance with this agreement, from 2018 an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts opened by the respective residents will be established between the EU and Switzerland.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the text of this resolution, which regrets that the Council's draft decision has not made any improvements, particularly with regard to the level of information transmitted or the automatic, mandatory and unrestricted nature of the exchange of information with Switzerland. In adopting this resolution, the European Parliament intends to reiterate and stress once again the importance of taking effective measures to combat tax fraud and evasion and calls on the Commission, 18 months after the agreement came into force, to carry out an assessment of its application and results.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. On 27 May 2012, the European Union and the Swiss Confederation signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. This agreement is intended to improve tax cooperation, comply with international tax obligations and, at the same time, combat tax fraud and tax evasion.  In accordance with the provisions of this agreement, the European Union and the Swiss Confederation shall automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of the other party's residents from 2018 on, as well as income, interest and dividends, account balances and income from the sale of financial assets by taxpayers. Bearing in mind that this agreement, on which the European Parliament was consulted, is intended to prevent situations in which a taxpayer tries to hide capital corresponding to income or assets for which no taxes have been paid, I voted in favour, as such measures will contribute to strengthening tax cooperation and transparency as soon as greater social justice.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the conditions for the automatic exchange of information with Switzerland on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The aim is to endorse the Council's position that complies with the INTERNATIONAL standard for the automatic exchange of financial information on taxation provided by the OECD.  Europe must take concrete and effective measures against tax evasion and evasion. An agreement with Switzerland was needed and this project is moving in the right direction.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the automatic exchange of financial information in order to combat the phenomenon of tax evasion. In fact, the agreement provides that, from 2018, the European Union and Switzerland will cooperate by exchanging information on the financial accounts of their residents.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as the text aims at greater cooperation in tax and administrative matters between the European Union and Switzerland.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this text, which seeks to implement measures similar to those in other European countries in relation to Switzerland to promote transparency and combat tax evasion and avoidance. However, the agreement is clearly insufficient and provides for too many exceptions that will serve to maintain the status of tax haven of the Helvetic Confederation. In addition, it has been submitted to Parliament once it has been closed with Switzerland.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary demand for financial information, it implies a position in favour of the use of tax havens for Europeans. The report implies an improvement in financial information exchange systems between the competent authorities of Switzerland and the European Union. However, this is not a sufficient commitment to ensure that European companies and citizens pay their funds in Europe, since in many States, despite the information being available, no action is taken. We need the abolition of the use of tax havens for Europeans, which must contribute to the financing of Member States like any citizen. That is why I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU and Switzerland signed an agreement on 27 May 2015 on the automatic exchange of tax information to improve cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations. I have decided to support the conclusion of the agreement as it represents an important step forward in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion. From 2018, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their residents, with the aim of addressing situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax fraud.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because such arrangements that need to be made in respect of taxation should be made bilaterally and not via the EU.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against aggressive tax planning and tax evasion is a global fight and my vote in favour of approving this agreement is because I believe that such an arrangement is vital in this battle. We must work with non-EU countries, like Switzerland, in order to make sure that no-one can dodge taxes simply by hiding their money overseas.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider transparency in the area of financial and banking operations to be an unprecedented condition for their operation. I therefore voted in favour of adopting the resolution on the proposal to conclude an amendment to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation, which provides for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments on behalf of the European Union. This amendment will allow the exchange of information on the bank accounts of EU and Swiss citizens in the context of many people's long-standing efforts to avoid tax liability in the EU through bank accounts in Switzerland.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: I voted in writing ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because I consider the agreement to be an important step in the efforts currently being made to reduce tax fraud and tax evasion and complement the 2004 agreement. I believe that the proposed measures will improve not only the automatic exchange of income information, but also balances on accounts and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. I also believe that this agreement is a step towards fairer and more transparent taxation in Europe and the end of Swiss banking secrecy for the people of EU countries. I also consider the AGREEMENT between the EU and Switzerland to be important because this agreement strengthens the EU's policy on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts and can also have a positive impact on the conclusion of agreements with other states.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of Parliament's position on the agreement between the European Union and Switzerland on the suppression of tax fraud and tax evasion. The agreement provides for the automatic exchange, from 2018, between the tax administrations of the Member States and the Swiss administrations of financial information relating to their residents, in order to limit the possibilities for taxpayers to avoid reporting to tax authorities by moving goods or investing in products in Switzerland.  By effectively ending the banking secrecy of EU citizens in Switzerland, the agreement marks an important stage in the EU's fight against tax fraud and evasion. As Switzerland remains a crucial player in the financial field, we must seek to ensure maximum transparency in our relations through enhanced fiscal cooperation at international level.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support increased transparency in EU-Switzerland communication. The automatic exchange of information on financial accounts can improve the protection of our citizens, by being an effective measure against fraud and tax avoidance and, in particular, tax evasion.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The importance of automatic information sharing as a means of combating cross-border tax fraud and cross-border tax evasion by ensuring full tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations around the world has recently been recognised internationally. The G20 entrusted the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) with the task of developing a single global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information. The report underlines the importance of taking effective measures against tax fraud and tax avoidance with a focus on tax evasion and tax avoidance by natural and legal persons in the Union with the participation of financial institutions in third countries. I fully support the report on the proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation on measures equivalent to those set out in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of savings interest income, as this amendment ensures a coherent, coherent and comprehensive approach to the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts at internal market level.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ since this proposal is primarily of a formal nature and responds in particular to other legislative changes, I supported it.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information. The events relating to the Luxleaks affair required us to act swiftly and effectively. Just as there must be an automatic exchange of information between Member States in the field of taxation, there must also be an automatic exchange of financial account information between the EU and third countries. The aim is, above all, to stop tax evasion and to make it easier to identify all those who avoid paying taxes.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 States must conclud transnational agreements in order to be able quickly, reliably and always in accordance with the laws to investigate and deliver justice in cases of financial crimes. The European Union must be a helper in this effort by the States in such a way that their sovereign rights are not infringed.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which is an important part of effective action against fraud and tax avoidance. Tax fraud knows no borders and it is therefore particularly important to make tax fraud by EU-based natural and legal persons involving financial institutions established in a third country impossible by appropriate agreements. In particular, I agree with the point in the report that, 18 months after the entry into force of the Agreement, the Commission should assess its effectiveness. Only in this way can we be sure that taxpayers have succeeded in preventing taxable persons from hiding income from swiss financial institutions for which the tax has not yet been paid.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Council's proposed decision amending the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation is another step to increase the effectiveness of measures taken against tax avoidance. This issue is particularly important when these activities are taken by natural and legal persons established in the Union with the assistance of financial institutions established in third countries.  In its report, the European Parliament approves the draft Council decision, while regretting the impossibility of making some improvements, in particular as regards the scope of the exchange of information and the automatic, mandatory and obstacle-free nature of the exchange. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of the report, hoping that, in line with the EP's position, 18 months after the entry into force of the agreement, it will be analysed and considered.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. This agreement marks an important step in the current efforts to combat tax evasion and evasion, and reinforces the 2004 agreement which ensured that Switzerland applied measures equivalent to those set out in the EU directive on the taxation of savings income. The agreement provides that the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 2018. The objective is to deal with situations in which a taxpayer seeks to conceal capital that corresponds to income or assets over which the tax has not been paid.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report relates to the Council decision to conclude, on behalf of the European Union, the Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation providing for measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. I voted in favour of it, as it underlines the importance of taking effective action against fraud and tax avoidance. This is crucial especially in the case of tax evasion and tax avoidance by natural and legal persons that are based in the EU with the involvement of financial institutions based in third countries.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement with the Swiss Confederation marks the beginning of a new era of fiscal transparency and cooperation between states. It is essential to continue in this direction in order to limit and eliminate tax evasion and to move towards fairer and more uniform taxation in Europe. The amendment of the agreement is a good thing for European citizens and an important step in the battle against tax fraud and in favour of justice. Any tax fraud involves the misappropriation of resources in areas such as education, health, research and transport. Parliament's support is a first step. It is now important to conclude similar agreements with other tax havens.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report on the draft Council Decision on the on behalf of the European Union, The Amending Protocol to the Agreement between the European Community and the Swiss Confederation on measures equivalent to those laid down in Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, because the agreement is a major step in the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion and builds on the agreement by which Switzerland implements measures equivalent to those of the EU Directive on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments.  The tax authorities in the Member States and Switzerland will be able to correctly and unambiguously identify taxpayers, manage and enforce national tax legislation in cross-border situations, assess the likelihood of tax evasion and ensure that no unnecessary further investigations are carried out.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this text, which seeks to implement measures similar to those in other European countries in relation to Switzerland to promote transparency and combat tax evasion and avoidance. However, the agreement is clearly insufficient and provides for too many exceptions that will serve to maintain the status of tax haven of the Helvetic Confederation. In addition, it has been submitted to Parliament once it has been closed with Switzerland.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The end of bank secrecy through the automatic exchange of information at EU level, enacted in March 2014, had to overcome the reluctance of Austria and Luxembourg. One of the conditions for the abandonment of bank secrecy by these countries was Switzerland's acceptance of similar measures, so as not to create unfair competition. The Memorandum of Understanding of the Kofod report stipulates that the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of their respective residents from 1 January 2018. Switzerland will apply measures equivalent to those provided in the European texts. It will thus respect the automatic exchange of financial account information, as set out in OECD global standards in 2014. In addition, the agreement provides for certain provisions to limit the ability of taxpayers to evade their reporting obligations to tax authorities by transferring their assets or investing in financial products outside the scope of the agreement.   I voted FOR the adoption of this text.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automatic exchange of information on financial accounts is an extremely important measure in the fight against tax evasion, as well as a factor in increasing tax transparency. In this respect, since March 2015, there has been an ambitious proposal to establish an automatic exchange of information on financial accounts between all Member States of the European Union, and in May 2015 an agreement was signed with Switzerland, with the aim of improving tax cooperation and compliance with tax rules. Therefore, under this 2018 agreement, the EU and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on their residents' financial accounts in order to avoid situations where taxpayers try to hide capital for which they have not paid taxes. The Kofod Report therefore aims to make some improvements to this agreement in order to ensure maximum efficiency of this agreement. In this perspective, the report proposes: an unconditional exchange of information, the elimination of the condition for the exchange of information based on the prior approval of the competent authorities, a quarterly frequency of exchanges.  I therefore voted in favour of the Kofod Report on the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts between the EU and Switzerland.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 27 May 2015, the European Union and Switzerland signed an agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving international tax cooperation and compliance. The agreement represents an important step in their efforts to combat tax fraud and evasion and updates the 2004 agreement to ensure that Switzerland applies measures equivalent to the EU Directive on the taxation of savings interest income, which is why I supported it in the vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We abstained in the vote on this text, which seeks to implement measures similar to those in other European countries in relation to Switzerland to promote transparency and combat tax evasion and avoidance. However, the agreement is clearly insufficient and provides for too many exceptions that will serve to maintain the status of tax haven of the Helvetic Confederation. In addition, it has been submitted to Parliament once it has been closed with Switzerland.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because this agreement between the European Union and Switzerland is a step towards more cooperation on exchange of information between the EU and Switzerland on the financial accounts of residents, which is a positive step towards addressing the issues of tax evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour on the matter concerning the EU-Switzerland agreement on the automatic exchange of financial account information in order to insure greater transparency and prevention of fraud and tax avoidance. These measures will make it harder for EU citizens to hide cash from tax authorities in Swiss bank accounts and therefore to avoid paying taxes. The regulation of taxation also contributes to insuring that taxes are collected and provided for social rights, for example education and healthcare. This is why I believe that ending bank secrecy is a very important step for tax justice. The information that will be exchanged includes not only income, such as interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The report highlights the importance of taking action against fraud and tax evasion. It also urges the Commission to keep Parliament informed in the event of any last-minute change in the conclusions of this agreement and reminds the Council of the obligation to consult Parliament once again if the draft agreement is a change. That is why, taking into account the above, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The European Parliament was consulted on the agreement signed between the EU and Switzerland on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The agreement should be an important step forward in efforts to combat fraud and tax evasion. The aim is to address situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. The rapporteur, Jeppe KOFOD, has put forward a number of proposals which we support. In particular, it called for the automatic exchange of information, greater transparency and greater frequency in the exchange of information to be introduced and for the entry into force scheduled for 1 January 2017 to be respected.  Although the proposals add value, we believe that more needs to be done. In our opinion, it is essential that the exchange of information should be automatic, compulsory and, above all, public. The agreement signed between the Commission and Switzerland is still weak in this respect. It is essential that agreements such as these are based on transparency. The progress made so far is not enough, in our view. We also regret that parliament has only been consulted on such an important issue. For these reasons, we abstained during the vote in this House.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report because, despite being a necessary demand for financial information, it implies a position in favour of the use of tax havens for Europeans. The report implies an improvement in financial information exchange systems between the competent authorities of Switzerland and the European Union. However, this is not a sufficient commitment to ensure that European companies and citizens pay their funds in Europe, since in many States, despite the information being available, no action is taken. We need the abolition of the use of tax havens for Europeans, which must contribute to the financing of Member States like any citizen. That is why I abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The regulation for the exchange of information with Switzerland contains several subterfuge to its compliance. Unfortunately, it is not possible to amend the Regulation. So let us adopt a report which is already out dated in the face of the commitments made and in view of the finding that the automatic exchange of information, created more than thirty years ago, does not work precisely because of regulations like this.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The purpose of the report or proposal is to cover situations in which a taxable person attempts to hide capital from the treasury in the form of income or assets for which no tax has been paid. The report makes changes that make this even more consistent. The report was therefore in agreement.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this agreement, the European Union and Switzerland undertake, from 2018, to exchange constant and automatic information on the financial accounts of their residents. The aim is to combat, through close cooperation, the concealment of capital consisting of income or assets resulting from tax evasion. The tax authorities of Switzerland and the Member States will therefore be able to clearly and precisely ascertain the identity of taxpayers and determine whether acts of tax evasion or avoidance have been carried out by natural and legal persons with the support of financial institutions established in third countries. The agreement between the EU and Switzerland on the exchange of financial information undoubtedly plays a major role in the strategy to combat fraud and tax evasion. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 In the vote, the European Parliament took a position on the adoption by the Council of a decision adopting a protocol amending the Agreement between the European Union and the Swiss Confederation on measures equivalent to those of Directive 2003/48/EC. The agreement is to be updated in view of the change in legal status on which it was based. In view of the proposal to repeal Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income and the amendments made to Directive 2014/107/EU on administrative cooperation, which extended its scope, it became necessary to modify the content of the existing agreement. The Amending Protocol implements the OECD Standard on automatic exchange of financial data in tax matters. This makes it possible to combat tax avoidance effectively, for which citizens of the European Union have used financial institutions located in third countries. I therefore voted in favour of the Council's adoption of a decision on the adoption of the amending Protocol.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The topic of roaming has been dragging on for several years. In 2012, a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council was adopted which set the political objective of gradually unifying mobile charges at home and abroad, namely abolishing the roaming surcharge. According to this Regulation, roaming should end on 15 June 2017. We have now adopted a new regulation in Parliament introducing a transitional period between the status quo and the total ban on roaming surcharges. During this period, the maximum roaming surcharges across the EU will be further reduced as early as April 2016. This means that customers will not pay more than 5 cents per minute for a mobile phone call from abroad, with the price of an SMS not exceeding 2 cents and 1 megabyte of transmitted data also costing a maximum of 5 cents.  However, mobile operators will be able to apply the so-called 'fair user policy', i.e. the fair use of services policy. This should prevent roaming from being used, for example, by customers who have permanently moved to another Member State during this transitional period. In such cases, operators will be able to charge the customer a small extra fee, but this may not be higher than the maximum wholesale margins between operators. The limit for fair user policy will be defined by the Commission by 15 December 2015.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against tax avoidance and the need for equitable taxation are a major concern both at European and global level. While great progress has been made at the international level, it remains important to exercise caution in repealing an existing Directive which has been in place for several years.  An automatic exchange of information between Switzerland and the European Union must be ensured, avoiding a situation of double communication of information and an unnecessary burden on Member States, or the slowing entry into force of the information communication systems of the Administrative Cooperation Directive; however, we must be cautious about repeal.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted to consult Parliament on the agreement signed between the EU and Switzerland on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. The agreement should be an important step forward in efforts to combat fraud and tax evasion. The aim is to address situations in which a taxpayer tries to conceal capital consisting of income or assets subject to tax evasion. The rapporteur, in the ECON Committee, put forward some proposals that we can support on the automatic exchange of information, confidentiality and protection of personal data, arbitration in cases of litigation, alignment with current legislation and its entry into force. However, although the proposals add value, I believe that more needs to be done. I also regret that parliament is only consulted on such an important issue. For these reasons, I abstained.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The EU-Switzerland agreement on the exchange of financial account information is far from the need to transmit all the information necessary to uncover tax evasion, tax avoidance and capital movements of large business groups and plutocracy. Except that it is not even explicitly binding, it does not provide for an exchange of all detailed information allowing at least identification. The exchange of information takes place on an annual basis, giving a long period of time for data change and avoidance of consequences. Most importantly: it introduces a number of terms and conditions, such as the non-delivery of information from complaints or when they (even arbitrarily) are deemed to be contrary to 'public policy' or when they are classified as 'confidential'. All these restrictions essentially remove any binding nature of the exchange of information and leave the margin for selective disclosure of information. The agreement is thus done 'for the eyes of the world', to appease popular indignation by the provocative tax immunity of plutocracy and monopolistic groups, at the same time as the EU and civil governments are smashing the people with all sorts of taxes. The bottom line is that, as long as monopolies and the profit-based market economy dominate, large capital will find both legitimate and illegal ways to treasure.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support this report because, in my opinion, the agreement represents an important step in the ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion and improves the 2004 agreement. Effective action must be taken against this negative behaviour by both legal and natural persons in the EU with holdings in third country financial institutions.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2004, the Council decided to conclude the agreement between the EU and the Swiss Confederation in order to ensure the adoption by the Swiss Confederation of measures equivalent to Directive 2003/48/EC), which should be applied in the EU to ensure effective taxation of savings income in the form of interest. The agreement, signed on 27 May 2015, on the automatic exchange of information from financial accounts, which aims to improve international tax cooperation, represents an important step in ongoing efforts to combat tax fraud and tax evasion. We are at odds with the impossibility of the European Parliament proposing improvements to this agreement, which is because the European Parliament was only heard after its ratification. We abstained.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent The Savings Tax Directive entered into force as early as 2003. It consists of a number of separate reciprocal agreements between the Member States of the European Union, their overseas territories, as well as Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco, San Marino and Switzerland in Europe. At present, the European Commission is, as we know, working to make it possible to move to automatic exchange of information between the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in these global standards, in particular on taxes with the five countries mentioned. At a later stage, the same will be the case with the Member States of the European Union and, if the European Commission is given the appropriate powers, also with the overseas territories. Consequently, the Savings Tax Directive will soon largely lose its rationality, as there will actually be double standards and their intersection will thus greatly increase the bureaucratic burden. I voted in favour.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, there is a difference between a tax haven and a territorial state that simply happens to have low taxes. You can cut your taxes without doing anything improper or illicit. I think for example of the Bailiwick of Guernsey, which as recently as the 1980s had an economy based on tomatoes and tourism but which is now a territory with far higher income per head than anywhere in the EU, because it has managed its affairs properly.  Now when I look at their lack of VAT, their maximum cap on income tax, their lack of inheritance tax and I see that they are providing the same level of public services as anyone else, I do not think it is they who have the problem. Perhaps their advantage is that they were not in the European Union and that they were therefore able to tailor their policies to suit their own conditions and needs.  The rest of us could learn from countries which have proximity to the citizen, small scale of government and efficiency in fiscal matters instead of trying to bully them. Instead of seeing them as a threat, we should see what they can offer us.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, with regard to the report under discussion, i.e. savings income and taxation according to the bilateral agreement concluded by the European Union under the 2003 directive when it entered into force, I, of course, supported it. This is a good way to prevent illegal taxation again in some Member States of the European Union by strengthening the EU's common position. Of course, this is to be welcomed, on the other hand, I must sigh that what are these valid agreements against when the representative of one of the EU Member States agrees that there will be two tariffs. One for everyone and the other for the different companies and businesses that the government will agree to. Then such agreements are almost useless.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we have the 2003 directive and the 2014 directive, but they are not entirely compatible in all areas. This results in dual reporting standards in the Union in certain cases. I welcome the recommendation in this report that we must avoid a situation of double reporting so as to avoid unnecessary burdens for Member States. Nevertheless, while the repeal may be necessary to avoid double reporting, I am in agreement with the rapporteur that the Commission must continue to closely monitor the repeal of the directive so as to avoid the creation of tax loopholes, and it should report back to Parliament on its findings of any such loopholes that may arise. I commend the call in this report that the Commission should act, if necessary by means of legislative proposals, in order to ensure that such loopholes are closed. This measure would ensure that the risk of loss of tax revenue from my own Member State and other Member States across the Union is reduced.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when is a repeal not a repeal? When it is a facade. It sounds like a little bit of a joke, does it not? I mean you might expect that I, as somebody who is opposed to British membership of the European Union, would be very much in favour of repeal and, of course, in general I am. But what we have got here is a repeal of a directive which has already been duplicated.  So it is not as if we are going to actually lose anything impractical from the statute book whatsoever, but at the same time when you read through the Scott Cato report, it is quite clear that the amendments which have been inserted into this report under Rule 50 of the committee procedure include things like calling on the Commission to negotiate tax arrangements, and so on. So what we have got, on the one hand, is something which headlines as a repeal but on the other it masquerades as a way of getting more Europe in there, so therefore I voted against.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. The 2003 Savings Yield Tax Directive was designed to gather information on the savings of non-resident individuals. Meanwhile, an Administrative Cooperation Directive covering the automatic exchange of tax information, in general, was adopted in 2011 and revised in 2014 to adapt it to OECD global standards. This Directive enters into force on the first of January 2016. The result is that there is a large overlap between the two directives, so in order to avoid confusion and to have to comply with two different information systems, I have not opposed repeal. However, the scope of both directives does not coincide in their entirety, so by repealing the 2003 Directive they fall outside the obligation to report certain types of low-risk savings deposits, as well as any 'paying agent' (stockbroker, insurance broker, etc.), since the 2011 Directive imposes obligations on financial institutions. More ambitious in general, this Directive imposes lower reporting obligations on foundations and trusts. The Commission must take steps to correct these requirements, thus achieving adequate coverage of all financial accounts.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC aimed at plugging the possible gaps that this legislation has in the field of taxation of income generated by savings. The current Directive leaves it to national bilateral agreements to impose savings located in five non-EU European countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra), as well as island and overseas territories under special tax regimes. This has led to numerous situations of fiscal competition in the field of savings, which is what this repeal seeks to correct. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report was concerned with the EU Savings Tax Directive which was adopted as a measure to ensure that tax is paid on the interest of savings, and the provisions became applicable in 2005. The Directive applied among EU countries and in separate agreements between EU countries and 12 overseas territories. In parallel, the Commission, on behalf of the European Union, negotiated similar bilateral agreements with five non-EU European countries.  As part of its March 2015 Tax Transparency Package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions in both directives, avoiding the inconvenience of double systems of collecting and reporting of data. It was decided that this should be fast-tracked under what is referred to as the fast-track procedure according to Rule 50 of the Rules of Procedure i.e. no vote in committee unless more than 10 percent of members object.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. It repeals the 2003/48 Directive on the Taxation of Savings, which duplicates the 2014/107 Directive on the Automatic Exchange of Information.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as proposed by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which is intended to be repealed in 2003. Savings Tax Directive. This is done in order to prevent Member States from applying both the Savings Tax Directive and the Directive on administrative cooperation, thus avoiding the disadvantages of double data collection and reporting systems.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of repealing The 2003/48 Directive as it is now duplicated by the 2014/107 directive. It is therefore a matter of clarifying the situation.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. As part of its March 2015 "Tax Transparency" package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive while keeping the 2008 directive so that Member States do not have to implement the provisions of both directives, thereby avoiding the inconvenience caused by the duplicity of data collection and communication systems. This report, for which I voted in favour, calls for this abolition while highlighting the shortcomings of the Savings Directive: - Bilateral agreements between the European Union and third countries will continue to exist regardless of the repeal of the directive. - The Commission has not been given a mandate to negotiate agreements on an automatic exchange of information with the twelve overseas territories of the European Union. - Some products, most of them low-risk deposit accounts for savings purposes, will no longer be subject to communication under the Administrative Cooperation Directive. If the risks of tax evasion are low, it is considered important that the Commission continue to monitor that the abolition of the directive does not create a gap.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I wanted to vote in favour of this report, which is a logical legal compliance: it was indeed a question of voting for the repeal of the old directive 2003/48 which duplicated the new directive 2014/107, which concerns the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments. Having positioned myself for the automatic exchange of information on savings income between EU countries, it seemed common sense to repeal the previous legal act, which had become obsolete in that it merely introduced the imposition of cross-border interest payments by European payers. A necessary clarification, therefore, which places itself in the objective of transparency, although it would be desirable for this new legal arsenal to be accompanied by separate bilateral agreements with non-member states such as Liechtenstein, Monaco, or Andorra, in particular to avoid any legal vacuum.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I am opposed to the current mechanisms governing taxation on savings, I believe that the European Commission's proposal to repeal the 2003 directive on the taxation of savings income in order to maintain only the directive on administrative cooperation, which regulates a wider range of cases, will avoid bureaucratic and management problems, and that is why I wanted to support it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The 2003 Savings Yield Tax Directive was designed to gather information on the savings of non-resident individuals. Meanwhile, an Administrative Cooperation Directive covering the automatic exchange of tax information, in general, was adopted in 2011 and revised in 2014 to adapt it to OECD global standards. This Directive enters into force on the first of January 2016. The result is that there is a large overlap between the two directives, so in order to avoid confusion and to have to comply with two different information systems, I have not opposed repeal. However, the scope of both directives does not coincide in their entirety, so by repealing the 2003 Directive they fall outside the obligation to report certain types of low-risk savings deposits, as well as any 'paying agent' (stockbroker, insurance broker, etc.), since the 2011 Directive imposes obligations on financial institutions. More ambitious in general, this Directive imposes lower reporting obligations on foundations and trusts. The Commission must take steps to correct these requirements, thus achieving adequate coverage of all financial accounts.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported the Commission's proposal to repeal the EU Savings Tax Directive 2003/48/EC. Its scope is largely overlapping with the 2014 Directive, which also provides that Directive 2014/107/EU takes precedence if the scope overlaps. The result is therefore that the standards for the provision of information in the Union are currently duplicated. Together with the March 2015 tax transparency package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 The Savings Tax Directive, so that Member States are not obliged to apply the provisions of both directives, avoiding the inconvenience caused by double data collection and reporting systems, and Parliament has today agreed to this.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report was concerned with the EU Savings Tax Directive which was adopted as a measure to ensure that tax is paid on the interest of savings, and the provisions became applicable in 2005. The Directive applied among EU countries and in separate agreements between EU countries and 12 overseas territories. In parallel, the Commission, on behalf of the European Union, negotiated similar bilateral agreements with five non-EU European countries.  As part of its March 2015 Tax Transparency Package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions in both directives, avoiding the inconvenience of double systems of collecting and reporting of data. It was decided that this should be fast—tracked under what is referred to as the fast—track procedure according to Rule 50 of the Rules of Procedure i.e. no vote in committee unless more than 10 percent of members object.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, in the light of the adoption and entry into force of the new directive on the subject, this directive is ultimately superfluous. It is important, as far as legal certainty is concerned, that there should be no duplication in the legal system, and that applies even more to tax matters.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to repeal, from 1 January 2016, the 2003/48 directive which is superimposed on the 2014/107 directive, in order to prevent two separate standards from coexisting. The first was to tax the payment of cross-border interest through European paying agents, while the second was characterized by the automatic exchange between EU Member States of data on the income of assets held abroad.  While this is an advisory opinion to the Council, we believe that this proposal is a good move. Nevertheless, we are dubious about the slow progress of the talks on the automatic exchange of this data with the twelve overseas territories of the Union. Finally, it seems to me essential that bilateral agreements with non-EU countries be concluded quickly so as not to create a legal vacuum. I therefore voted in favour of repealing the 2003/48/EC directive.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the repeal of the Savings Income Tax Directive because I believe that we need to have a tax economy that is as transparent and clear as possible.  Fair taxation is sped at both European and international levels. To achieve a healthy economy, we need sustainable economic growth, less inflation and poverty, both at national and international level, but this can only be achieved through a simple, transparent and efficient mechanism. The 2003 Directive covers the taxation of savings, requires the reporting of income in the form of interest on claims and applies to a large number of separate bilateral agreements between EU Member States and overseas territories. This Directive entered into force in 2005. Meanwhile, the 2011 Administrative Cooperation Directive was adopted in 2014 and is to apply from 1 January 2016, when the 2003 Directive may also apply. Following the discussions, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Directive so that Member States avoid the inconvenience of dual data collection and reporting systems.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Member States will not be required to apply the provisions of two different directives, avoiding the inconvenience and cost of dual data collection and communication systems. I am, however, opposed to the existing mechanisms on taxation on savings, and I believe that it would be useful to maintain only one reference regulation.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. The 2003 Savings Yield Tax Directive was designed to gather information on the savings of non-resident individuals.
