The Commission must take steps to correct these requirements, thus achieving adequate coverage of all financial accounts.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal to repeal the Directive as the information needs to be updated in line with the new Administrative Cooperation Directive. This is necessary to avoid dual reporting and loopholes between national tax systems and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Molly Scott Cato's report deals with the repeal of the 2003 Savings Income Taxation Directive to facilitate the entry into force of the Directive on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, adopted as part of the March 2015 tax transparency package, which is expected to apply from 1 January 2016. It is therefore a simple procedural vote that does not present any particular critical issues. However, I have chosen to abstain because it is important to proceed with caution in the event of the repeal of a directive that has been in force for several years.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 Concerns the proposal for a Council Directive repealing Directive 2003/48/EC. Having regard to the Commission's proposal to the Council, the European Parliament invites the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly, in accordance with Article 293(2) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of repealing the Directive on the taxation of savings income. In 2003, the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income was adopted as a measure to ensure the payment of tax on savings income, and the relevant provisions entered into force in 2005. The revision of the Directive was finally adopted in 2014 and is expected to apply from 1 January 2016.  Meanwhile, the 2011 Directive on Administrative Cooperation was revised to bring it into line with the OECD's global standard for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, and was adopted in 2014. It should also apply from 1 January 2016. The 2003 Savings Directive provides for the communication of data on interest accrued on claims and similar products, while the Directive on administrative cooperation covers a much wider range of products. As part of the March 2015 tax transparency package, the Commission proposed repealing the 2003 directive in order to avoid the application of both directives, thus avoiding the discomfort caused by the dual data collection and reporting systems.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive by the rapporteur Molly Scott Cato on the repeal of the directive on the taxation of savings income. Concerns about this directive are linked to the fight against tax evasion and therefore to the need for fair taxation at both European and global level. All this with a view to progress at international level. I support the rapporteur's proposal, although I am well aware that it is important for the Commission to continue to monitor the repeal process so that there are no gaps, as the repeal of a directive that has been in force for several years is risky. I congratulate the rapporteur on his work, on examining the possible shortcomings resulting from the repeal and on asking for expert advice through detailed analysis. For these reasons, I am voting in favour of the proposal.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against tax evasion is a major concern, both at European and global level. In order to ensure fair taxation in the European and global market, the EU must be able to sign agreements ensuring compliance with tax regulations and to formulate an effective control system to combat evasion. In this regard, I agree with the repeal of the 2003 directive on the taxation of savings income. The 2011 directive on administrative cooperation, which will eventually replace the 2013 directive, has in fact been revised ad hoc to comply with the OECD's global standard for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes.  This change in the rules will therefore allow greater alignment with the OECD's overall standard and avoid the discomfort of dual data collection and communication systems. However, I agree with the rapporteur that this repeal can lead to potential shortcomings and that, if they occur, it is up to the Commission to intervene, if necessary with legislative proposals, to ensure that these gaps are filled.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC aimed at plugging the possible gaps that this legislation has in the field of taxation of income generated by savings. The current Directive leaves it to national bilateral agreements to impose savings located in five non-EU European countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra), as well as island and overseas territories under special tax regimes. This has led to numerous situations of fiscal competition in the field of savings, which is what this repeal seeks to correct. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament resolution approves the Commission's proposal to repeal the rules on the taxation of savings income received in the form of interest payments. I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to prevent several measures from having the same scope, respecting the principles of better regulation and legal certainty and reducing bureaucratic and administrative burdens. Furthermore, with this resolution, the European Parliament is calling on the Commission to present a report on the effects of repeal, in particular with regard to possible legislative gaps.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I consented to repeal the Savings Directive, which was designed to collect data on the savings of non-residential individuals. However, it is extremely important that the Commission reports on the results of the repeal, with reference to any potential loopholes that may arise. It is imperative that the Commission acts to ensure that such loopholes are closed off completely.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the need for the European Executive to take the necessary measures to respect the time needed to review bilateral agreements between the EU and the five non-EU European countries (Swiss Confederation, The Principality of Liechtenstein, the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Monaco and the Principality of Andorra), as well as each of the Member States and the 12 dependent or associated territories in order to avoid the emergence of loopholes for cross-border tax fraud and evasion or other inaccuracies in the transition to the standard on the automatic exchange of information. I consider it essential that Parliament's role in reducing any possible loss of tax revenue by Member States across the Union.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the repeal of the Savings Income Tax Directive, which will be replaced by the 2014 Directive on Administrative Cooperation, whose scope extends beyond income taxation. Focusing on the transition period to the new legal framework, the report makes several recommendations to ensure legal certainty for citizens. In particular, it recalls the importance of the European Commission's supervisory role during the transition. Considering that this report is balanced, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of repealing the Savings Tax Directive. This procedure is indeed necessary in order to enable the proper implementation of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, which is more comprehensive than that on the taxation of savings received in the form of interest payments. By voting, we are ensuring that European legislation is consistent.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, on the European Parliament's legislative motion for a resolution, was intended to repeal a 2003 directive on the taxation of savings. Indeed, it was therefore unnecessary, in duplication with a 2014 directive on the automatic exchange of information. Opposed to legislative inflation, which is particularly dynamic in the European Union, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am favour of the Scott Cato report’s proposal to repeal the Savings Directive to ensure that only one applicable standard prevails on automatic exchange of financial account information within the EU. My party has also secured wording that the Commission will have no negotiating mandate with associated territories without the explicit consent of the relevant Member State. In short, I support this tax simplification in line with global standards.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 After successful negotiations, the report shows a balanced approach, which I believe is vital for mutual cooperation on issues such as taxation. An applicable standard for the automatic exchange of information in the financial sphere within the EU will ensure greater efficiency and transparency.  In the case of territories outside the EU, I welcome the compromise reached on the scope of the Commission's negotiating mandate. In my opinion, the mandate must be subject to explicit consent from the Member States. As well as fiscal policy, it is a matter of national governance. An EC mandate in this area would undermine the sovereignty of the Member States on this key issue.  I therefore strongly welcome the final report as I believe it reflects a balanced approach.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report, as the proposed text has legal loopholes.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2003, the Savings Tax Directive was adopted as a measure to ensure the payment of savings taxes in the form of interest. Following the 2008 evaluation, the Commission proposed a review with the aim of closing certain shortcomings, which was definitively adopted in 2014 and should be implemented from 1 January 2016. It should also be applied from 1 January 2016.  The Commission proposed, as part of its March 2015 Package of Measures on Tax Transparency, the repeal of the 2003 Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of both Directives and can thus avoid the difficulties caused by dual systems for collecting and reporting. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2003/48/EC concerns the taxation of savings income in the form of interest generated by credits and was implemented with the aim of ensuring the payment of savings taxes in the form of interest. That directive will be repealed so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of the 2003 and 2011 Directives (on savings taxation and administrative cooperation respectively) and can avoid the difficulties caused by dual reporting systems. This report proposes that the European Commission draw up a report on the results of the repeal. It also proposes that the European Commission put forward legislative proposals to ensure that any remaining gaps are addressed. Furthermore, it regrets that no specific cost-benefit analysis has been carried out of a dual communication system or a transition period between the two standards. Nothing to oot.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because overall it reduces any potential loss of tax revenue for ordinary citizens.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ in 2003, the Directive on taxation of savings in the European Union was adopted and entered into force in 2005. In March 2015, the European Commission presented a tax transparency package and proposed the repeal of the Savings Tax Directive 2003 as part of this package. With this measure, the European Commission wants to relieve Member States not to have to apply the provisions of both directives and to avoid a double system when collecting information and data. The repeal of the Directive on taxation of savings income is possible if the European Commission acts, if necessary, through legislative proposals, in order to ensure that the risk of loss of tax revenue for Member States in the European Union is reduced.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report because we are opposed to the existing mechanisms on taxation on savings and we share the concerns of the rapporteur who rightly believes that it is useful to maintain only one reference legislation.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the repeal of the Savings Directive. The Commission is right to align the EU’s standards with the OECD’s so as not to disadvantage Member States. This type of scrutiny of reports and acts is most welcome and can ensure that the EU is competitive in the wider world.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the proposal to repeal the EU Savings Tax Directive 2003/48/EC as we need to make sure that there is only one applicable standard for automatic exchange of information within the EU and to avoid any overlap between the Savings Directive and the Amending Directive on Administrative Cooperation that may result from their different approaches.  Whilst I support the repeal, I remain concerned about the potential for creation of loopholes if the separate bilateral agreements between the European Union and five European countries that are not Member States of the Union (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra) are not rapidly concluded. Therefore, I consider it important that the Commission report on the results of the repeal and on any potential loopholes that may arise, ensuring with all means that such loopholes are closed.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of this report, which is as technical as it is important, 'Taxation of savings income: repeal of the Savings Tax Directive', as I support the approach.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Taxation of savings income is important and must continue to exist in the future. However, it is important that this is made as efficient as possible and at the same time transparent to outsiders. The repeal of the 2003 directive, adopted today, is intended to prevent States from being particularly burdened by the provisions of two different directives on taxation.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ When is a repeal not a repeal? When the EU is involved. I voted against, as it was supposedly to repeal a directive which has since been duplicated by another one specifically designed to implement OECD common reporting standards. The rapporteur managed to put in a few calls for the Commission to negotiate tax agreements and make reports to the Parliament. More sovereignty down the EU drain.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of repealing the Savings Tax Directive because it has now been superseded by the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, and it makes no sense to burden businesses with having to report the same information twice. The new Directive on Administrative Cooperation should have a major impact in the fight against aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion, and Labour MEPs will make sure that it is being implemented properly when it comes into force next year.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The fight against tax evasion and evasion is one of C's priorities in Europe, as undeclared and unrecumbered incomes result in a significant reduction in national tax revenues and are a sign of insolidarity and irresponsibility. In order to ensure that there is only one rule applicable to the automatic exchange of information on savings income in the form of interest payments in the EU and to avoid errors, this Directive should be supported.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, in favour of repealing the 2003 Directive on the taxation of savings yields, since there is a more recent Directive on the same issue. The rapporteur expressed concern that this repeal would open up some legal vacuum, and therefore included a number of amendments in that regard which we supported.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in favour of repealing the Savings Tax Directive because it has now been superseded by the Directive on Administrative Cooperation and it makes no sense to burden businesses with having to report the same information twice. The new Directive on Administrative Cooperation should have a major impact in the fight against aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion. Labour MEPs will make sure that it is being implemented properly when it comes into force next year and if any loopholes occur we will call on the Commission to take any and all action necessary to make sure they are closed.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because the scope of financial products covered by the EU Savings Tax Directive and the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, while generally similar, is not exactly identical. Some products, mostly low-risk depository accounts promoted for savings purposes will not be reported anymore under the Directive on Administrative Cooperation. While there are low risks for tax evasion, I believe it is important for the Commission to continue monitoring that the repeal does not create loopholes.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – The 2003 Savings Yield Tax Directive was designed to collect information on the savings of non-resident individuals. The Commission must take steps to correct these requirements, thus achieving adequate coverage of all financial accounts.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report due to the concern regarding the potential to create loopholes and balancing this against the risk of burdensome double reporting. This report helps support the principle of fair taxation and helps tackle tax avoidance.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive repealing Council Directive 2003/48/EU, as this will avoid a double system of data collection and reporting. I believe it is necessary to simplify EUROPEAN Union law, bring it closer to citizens and avoid excessive administrative burdens in the form of ensuring clear and transparent legislation.  In this context, the fight against tax evasion and fair taxation are essential for European and global levels, and accordingly legislation in this area must be as clear and effective as possible. It is also important to stress that existing bilateral agreements between the EU and third countries continue regardless of the repeal of this Directive. I believe that an appropriate balance has been found between potential "gaps" in legislation and possible duplication overload, and therefore I support this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report and its proposals. UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it removes the Savings Tax Directive, which was replaced in 2014 by a more comprehensive directive. In the interests of simplification and clarity, it was therefore necessary to avoid two standards applying in parallel to the same situations.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The development is significant, but significant work is still needed in order to achieve internal harmonisation in the level of taxation of income resulting from interest on deposits.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report, as the rapporteur argues correctly about the agreements with Switzerland and other tax havens. Their demands are also in line with REFIT, the programme to ensure the efficiency and efficiency of legislation in the EU. This will lead to a clear, stable and predictable legal framework that promotes growth and employment.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the repeal. However, we call on the Commission to report on the results of the repeal, with reference to any potential loopholes that may arise.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the proposal for a Council directive repealing Council Directive 2003/48/EC. The repeal of the latter rule avoids the risk for Member States of a double and costly communication in cross-border tax and tax matters. In 2003, the EU Directive on the taxation of savings income was adopted as a measure to ensure the payment of the relevant tax. Meanwhile, the 2011 Directive on administrative cooperation has been revised in order to bring it into line with the OECD's global standard for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes. Both impose information obligations on similar matters. It is therefore considered appropriate to repeal the 2003 directive, in accordance with the Commission's decision, as amended and repealed by this Parliament.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Catto report concerns the Council's proposal for a directive repealing the 2003/48/EC Directive on The Taxation of Savings. This is therefore a vote of clarification since the directive to be repealed is duplicated with the 2014/107/EC directive on the automatic exchange of information. Although this repeal may lead to certain shortcomings if bilateral agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Andorra and San Marino are not quickly concluded, I voted for this text which would allow for better tax transparency and therefore an increased fight against tax evasion, while remaining vigilant about its application.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it repeals a 2003 directive on the taxation of savings, which duplicated a 2014 directive on the automatic exchange of information.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – The 2003 Savings Yield Tax Directive was designed to collect information on the savings of non-resident individuals. Meanwhile, an Administrative Cooperation Directive covering the automatic exchange of tax information, in general, was adopted in 2011 and revised in 2014 to adapt it to OECD global standards. This Directive enters into force on the first of January 2016. The result is that there is a large overlap between the two directives, so in order to avoid confusion and to have to comply with two different information systems, I have not opposed repeal. However, the scope of both directives does not coincide in their entirety, so by repealing the 2003 Directive they fall outside the obligation to report certain types of low-risk savings deposits, as well as any 'paying agent' (stockbroker, insurance broker, etc.), since the 2011 Directive imposes obligations on financial institutions. More ambitious in general, this Directive imposes lower reporting obligations on foundations and trusts. The Commission must take steps to correct these requirements, thus achieving adequate coverage of all financial accounts.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC aimed at plugging the possible gaps that this legislation has in the field of taxation of income generated by savings. The current Directive leaves it to national bilateral agreements to impose savings located in five non-EU European countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra), as well as island and overseas territories under special tax regimes. This has led to numerous situations of fiscal competition in the field of savings, which is what this repeal seeks to correct. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Tax systems must be simple, stable, secure, predictable and must be part of an incentive environment for entrepreneurs. Contributing to a simpler system is the repeal of the Council Directive on taxation of savings interest income.  The Council Directive on the taxation of savings interest income was the basis for establishing an exchange of information on savings interest paid by payers based in one Member State to natural persons resident in another Member State.  The new directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation has created a legislative framework for the application of OECD global standards in the field of automatic data exchange in terms of taxation, has a greater scope than the Savings Interest Income Taxation Directive and introduces different reporting standards.  Due to the simplicity of the system and the avoidance of double reporting standards, I supported the repeal of the Savings Interest Income Tax directive.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ when submitting proposals for repealing the rules, the Council and the Commission must carefully consider the specific impacts in practice, especially if there is a risk of tax revenue losses for the Member States of the Union. I therefore support the rapporteur's proposal for the Commission to report on the consequences of repealing the Savings Taxation Directive in relation to the bridging period until 2017, when the international exchange of information enters into force, and to ensure that, through legislative proposals, the Commission avoids any losses.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council directive on the repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015 and because tax evasion and avoidance are the modern scourge of euro area economies. Multinational companies have emerged as champions, which through the system of intra-group transactions avoid paying taxes of many billion euros. Euro. Their allies are the various tax havens and some euro area Member States, which engage in tax dumping and unfair practices, thus giving multinationals vital space not to pay multi-billion euro in taxes. In countries such as Greece, the total amount of the aid was EUR 1 million. Luxembourg with the so-called 'Lux Leaks' and the Netherlands give cover to German and other multinationals in order to avoid tax. And all this at a time when Mr. Dijsselbloem is waving his finger at Greece and demanding a new tax-free resalto in the pockets of the impoverished Greek people. Moreover, the troika in Greece whistles indifferently and disguises all Greek governments that refuse to take advantage of the Lagarde list and tax Greek oligarchs who have illegal deposits in Switzerland.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted to repeal this directive. This directive on the taxation of savings (2003/48/EC) has become redundant since the introduction of another directive, 2014/107. This directive sets up the automatic exchange of information on savings income between EU countries. In order to avoid a doubling of powers, we recognise the need to repeal the old directive.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on savings income in the form of interest payments: repeal of the directive on the taxation of savings income. The aim of the Regulation is to respond to the need to increase the transparency of securities financing operations concluded by all market participants, ensuring equal conditions of competition. In order to ensure the effective implementation of the reporting of securities financing transactions, the Regulation lays down stricter disclosure rules for counterparties, considering that tax evasion and the need for fair taxation are issues of considerable importance at both national and European level.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report but wish to emphasise that the fight against tax avoidance, and the need for fair taxation, must remain high on the political agenda.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the repeal of the 2003 EU Directive on the taxation of savings income. The 2003 Savings Income Tax Directive provides for the communication of data on accrued claims and interest, while the Administrative Cooperation Directive applies to a wider range of products. The repeal proposal was born out of the need to avoid discomfort for Member States in the application of the provisions of two directives and the consequent difficulty posed by the dual data collection and communication systems.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Under the new Information Exchange Directive - which will be extended to tax rulings by the Ferber report voted on this same session - information on savings income, and more generally all tax -reportable" financial accounts, will now be automatically exchanged. So there is redundancy with the 2003 Savings Directive, which provided for exactly the same thing. Its repeal will avoid a double communication of this information between member states.  The rapporteur ensured that there would be no blind spot, i.e. all the information that was exchanged under the Savings Directive would always be exchanged under the new framework. I voted in favour of this report, which follows the most basic logic and which has garnered broad consensus.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur has highlighted points to be taken into account when repealing the directive. In particular, the Commission's required reporting obligation to Parliament if the repeal loopholes arise is to be welcomed. That is why I supported this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In 2003, the Savings Tax Directive was adopted to ensure that taxes on interest on savings are paid. Its revised version in 2008 and adopted in 2014 will apply from 1 January 2016. Meanwhile, the 2011 Administrative Cooperation Directive has been revised to align with the OECD's global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information and was adopted in 2014. It will also apply from 1 January 2016. The committee proposes to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of both directives, thus avoiding duplicate data disclosure. The report validates this proposal while ensuring that bilateral data exchange agreements with third countries (Swiss Confederation, The Principality of Liechtenstein, the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Monaco and the Principality of Andorra) are renewed under the 2003 directive. I'm voting for. Let's hope that there will be no blow in this strange concern for simplification.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive repealing Council Directive 2003/48/EC. Based on principles of legal certainty and certainty, it is essential that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of both directives, avoiding the difficulties caused by the application of dual systems.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution seeks to repeal the Council Directive on taxing savings income, as the Amending Directive on Administrative Cooperation is due to come into effect in 2016. Therefore I chose to support the repeal of the Savings Directive to avoid any loopholes and double reporting that may arise if both directives are in effect.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my consent to the repeal of the 2003 EU Savings Tax Directive (EUSTD1), but on the condition that the Commission will report on the results of the repeal, with reference to any potential loopholes that may arise. The Commission needs to act, if necessary by means of legislative proposals, in order to ensure that such loopholes are closed.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Council Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation was amended by the Council by Council Directive 2014/107/EU in order to adapt to the Global OECD Standard on automatic tax exchange of account information, extending the automatic exchange of information to the full range of income. However, following the evaluation in 2008 of Council Directive 2003/48/EC on savings taxation, the Commission proposed a revision of this Directive, which was finally adopted by the Council in 2014. If Member States already apply the provisions of both Directives, they should operate a dual data collection and service system for the same data. To avoid this, the Commission proposed to the Council the repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC. Under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Council must consult the European Parliament before deciding. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommended the proposal to Parliament for approval, with amendments. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to repeal The 2003/48/EC Directive as it is now duplicated with the 2014/107/EU Directive. The first established the imposition of cross-border interest payments by European payers, the second marks the adoption of the automatic exchange of information on savings income between EU countries, according to the OECD standard.  In order to prevent two separate standards from co-existing, the first one must be removed.  If this rather technical repeal is to be supported, it is necessary that separate bilateral agreements with non-EU countries (Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra) be concluded quickly so as not to create unfair competition. The same is true of the 12 overseas territories of the European Union (the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man and the dependent or associated territories of the Caribbean).

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The agreement signed between the European Union and Switzerland on 27 May 2015 on the automatic exchange of financial account information aimed at improving tax cooperation and compliance with international tax obligations represents significant progress in combating tax fraud and tax evasion.  This agreement provides that the European Union and Switzerland will automatically exchange information on the financial accounts of residents of the other party from 2018.  I endorse the rapporteur's position on the amendments, in particular in the mandatory disclosure of the full name and identification number; the frequency of automatic exchange of information should be changed; to end the obligation to request permission to use the information exchanged with a third jurisdiction; the payment of dividends, interest and royalties between companies and the changes and termination of the agreement.  I consider it important to comply with the deadlines set for the entry into force of the agreement on 1 January 2017. By advocating greater transparency and sharing of tax information, with the aim of reducing its fraud and evasion, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Catto report concerns the Council's proposal for a directive repealing the 2003/48/EC Directive on the Taxation of Savings. This is therefore a vote of clarification, since the directive to be repealed is duplicated with the 2014/107/EC directive on the automatic exchange of information. Although this repeal may lead to certain shortcomings if bilateral agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Andorra and San Marino are not quickly concluded, I voted for this text which would allow for better tax transparency and therefore an increased fight against tax evasion, while remaining vigilant about its application.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which endorses the Commission's proposal to repeal the 2003 Directive on the Taxation of Savings. This directive applied since 2005 to Member States which have entered into separate agreements with twelve overseas territories (Anguilla, Bermuda, British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Falkland Islands, Gibraltar, Montserrat, Pitcairn Islands, St Helena, Turks and Caicos Islands) and aimed to pay taxes on interest on savings in these territories. In 2008, this directive was revised to fill some gaps. The new directive, which covers a wider range of products, was adopted in 2014 and will apply from 1 January 2016. As part of its March 2015 "Tax Transparency" package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of the two directives. The aim is to avoid a situation of double data communication which entails an unnecessary burden on the Member States.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The fight against tax evasion and the need for fair taxation are a matter of great concern, both at European and global level. Although important progress is being made at international level, it is nevertheless important to proceed with great caution in the event of the repeal of an existing directive which has been respected for several years.  It is true that it is all the more appropriate to avoid regulatory duplication, unnecessary burdens on Member States or to slow down the entry into force of the systems provided for under the Directive on administrative cooperation. However, we cannot fail to have a number of serious concerns about the repeal of the 2003 directive on the taxation of savings income, as the financial products covered by it are not identical to those covered by the Directive on administrative cooperation.  We therefore welcome this report, but call on the Commission to continue monitoring the repeal process so that no further gaps are possible, and to report back to Parliament once all Member States have drawn up the list of low-risk national accounts. We therefore call on the Commission to take action, if necessary, with appropriate legislative proposals to ensure that these gaps are immediately filled.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In 2003 the EU Savings Tax Directive was adopted as a measure to ensure that tax is paid on the interest of savings, and the provisions became applicable in 2005. In the meantime the 2011 Directive on Administrative Cooperation was revised to align it with the OECD’s global standard on automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters and was adopted in 2014. I voted for this report that will repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions in both directives, avoiding the inconvenience of double systems of collecting and reporting of data.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Directive on Administrative Cooperation that has been proposed by the Commission seeks to update and simplify the taxation procedures that were applied according to the 2003 Savings Directive, a necessary process that has my support. Part of this simplification involves fully repealing the prior legislation, as the contents have been renegotiated. If it is not repealed, there will be a period of double legislation. The Commission should always seek to avoid such unnecessary and repetitive legislation, but in doing so there is a possibility of taxation loopholes opening up for this short period. This report proposes amendments that would ensure that the Commission is closely monitoring the situation and reporting, under deadline, to the Parliament and Council on their findings. Ultimately, I am in favour of legislation that seeks to limit burdensome bureaucracy, and this report does that while also respecting the important democratic role that the Parliament plays in legislative decisions.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. This report was concerned with the EU Savings Tax Directive which was adopted as a measure to ensure that tax is paid on the interest of savings, and the provisions became applicable in 2005. The Directive applied among EU countries and in separate agreements between EU countries and 12 overseas territories. In parallel, the Commission, on behalf of the European Union, negotiated similar bilateral agreements with five non-EU European countries.  As part of its March 2015 Tax Transparency Package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive, so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions in both directives, avoiding the inconvenience of double systems of collecting and reporting of data. It was decided that this should be fast—tracked under what is referred to as the fast—track procedure according to Rule 50 of the Rules of Procedure i.e. no vote in committee unless more than 10 percent of members object.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report. I see the repeal of the Savings Tax Directive in line with the fight against tax evasion and tax havens.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The fight against tax avoidance and the need for fair taxation are important and must be carried out according to clear rules and not to create excessive burdens. The repeal of the Directive seeks to avoid a situation where Member States are obliged to report twice. However, it is important that there are no loopholes during the transitional period.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.   It is essential that all existing legal loopholes are closed and tax avoidance or evasion prevented.  In addition, only one standard for automatic exchange of information must apply to the EU. Two standards cannot be applied in parallel. An efficient common framework will help to avoid duplication of information systems. In view of this, I believe that it is appropriate to repeal the Savings Tax Directive. This would properly implement the principles of better regulation, as well as clarity and legal certainty. In addition, the new legal regulation will reduce potential additional risks and provide effective safeguards and reduce administrative burdens.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I reiterate my conviction that I believe that the Eu ropean Union must become increasingly involved in the fight against tax evasion and fraud, and I would like to join my concerns with those of the rapporteur on the possible legislative loopholes that such a repeal could entail. I also support the three proposed changes in order to remedy these regulatory gaps.  For these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Directive 2003/48/EU on taxation of savings interest income was aimed at combating cross-border tax evasion by creating an information-sharing system designed for tax authorities to help them identify the actual beneficiaries of interest on savings they receive in a country other than the country where they are resident.  The report on the proposal for a Council directive on the repeal of this Directive, which I supported, allows for the transition from the application of the old to the full application of the new Directive 2014/107/EU, which complements Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. During the transition period, it is necessary to take care not to create legal gaps in the application of these acts, especially if bilateral treaties with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra are not signed in time.  That is why I also supported the recommendation that the Commission submit a report by July 2016 on the implementation of the transition to the application of these acts and to submit a further report by October 2017 with a proposal for appropriate legal acts, if necessary.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report relates to the Council's proposal for a directive repealing the 2003/48/EC Directive on The Taxation of Savings. This is a vote of clarification since the directive to be repealed is duplicated with the 2014/107/EC Directive on the Automatic Exchange of Information. Although this repeal may lead to certain shortcomings if bilateral agreements with Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Andorra and San Marino are not quickly concluded, I voted for this text which would allow for greater tax transparency and therefore an increased fight against tax evasion. Nevertheless, I will remain vigilant about its application.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒Since five Non-Member States are currently being negotiated to adopt OECD global standards for automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, there has been a need to revoke the 2003 Tax Savings Directive, which thus becomes redundant. While the repeal of the Directive in question would potentially avoid the burden of double reporting, this decision should be taken with reservations as a result of the possibility of opening additional loopholes or reporting gaps that could lead to cross-border tax fraud and tax evasion.  As part of its expertise, the Commission should also take over the conduct of negotiations with 12 associated territories with a view to facilitating and promoting the revision of Member States' agreements. Fair taxation and the fight against tax avoidance remains a major global problem, and therefore it is necessary to proceed cautiously in revoking a directive that has been in force for several years. Member States should establish their lists of national low-risk accounts, which the Commission should inform Parliament of.  There are also fears about the possibility of opening a one-year transition period until the entry into force of automatic exchange of information, during which the exchange of information between Member States and third countries would not go normally. While we provide consent for the repeal of the old Directive, we should urge the Commission to study the risks in reporting in more detail.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. The Tax Directive was adopted in 2003 to ensure that tax was paid on savings interest and its provisions became applicable in 2005. The Directive applies between EU countries and twelve overseas territories (Anguilla, Aruba, British Virgin Islands, Cayman Islands, Curacao, Guernsey, Isle of Man, Jersey, Monserrat, St Martin, Turks and Caicos Islands).  In parallel, the European Commission, on behalf of the European Union, negotiates similar bilateral agreements with five non-EU European countries - Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco and San Marino. The greatest progress has been made with Switzerland and the Commission hopes to reach an agreement with the other four countries in the months ahead. The fight against tax avoidance and the need for safe taxation is of great importance both at European and global levels. Based on concerns about the possible formation of holes and balancing of the risk of double reporting, potential damages need to be assessed.  The report calls on the Commission to act if necessary through legal proposals to ensure potential loopholes are closeed. It is the amendments that will ensure that Parliament plays its part in reducing the potential loss of tax revenues in Member States across the Union. For all of the above, I support rapporteur Molly Scott Cato.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2003, the Council adopted a directive on the taxation of savings income received in the form of interest payments. Following the first review of the Savings Directive in November 2008, the Commission proposed a number of amendments aimed at filling existing gaps and more effectively preventing tax evasion. In the meantime, the 2011 Directive on administrative cooperation has been revised in order to bring it into line with the global standard set by the OECD (Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development) on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, and was adopted in 2014. As part of the March 2015 tax transparency package, the Commission therefore proposed repealing the 2003 directive. I am voting in favour of this report because it ensures that a single standard applies to the automatic exchange of information within the EU, thus avoiding possible errors due to the application of dual data collection and communication systems.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the commitment of the EU and Member States to the action plan on the erosion of the tax base and profit transfer within the OECD and the G20, the EU has decided to update the European legal texts. In this context, Parliament approved the repeal of the Savings Tax Directive. On the other hand, this measure can only be effective if Member States are more vigilant in the application of texts and measures.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the proposed amendments will give Parliament a role in reducing possible tax revenue losses for Member States across the Union.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of repealing EU legislation but the rapporteur on this report has arbitrarily included amendments that not only call on the Commission to produce reports and further legislation, but also encourage it to negotiate tax treaties on behalf of Member States. Repeal of the Directive, as proposed, would reduce disclosure requirements and would thereby undermine tax transparency. For these reasons UKIP is against the proposals.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The 2003 Savings Yield Tax Directive was designed to gather information on the savings of non-resident individuals. Meanwhile, an Administrative Cooperation Directive covering the automatic exchange of tax information, in general, was adopted in 2011 and revised in 2014 to adapt it to OECD global standards. This Directive enters into force on the first of January 2016. The result is that there is a large overlap between the two directives, so in order to avoid confusion and to have to comply with two different information systems, I have not opposed repeal. However, the scope of both directives does not coincide in their entirety, so by repealing the 2003 Directive they fall outside the obligation to report certain types of low-risk savings deposits, as well as any 'paying agent' (stockbroker, insurance broker, etc.), since the 2011 Directive imposes obligations on financial institutions. More ambitious in general, this Directive imposes lower reporting obligations on foundations and trusts. The Commission must take steps to correct these requirements, thus achieving adequate coverage of all financial accounts.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the repeal of the Savings Tax Directive. This directive had to be repealed, since the provisions on the exchange of information were extended as part of the revision of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, adopted a few months ago after the agreement in the Council on the taxation of savings.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to avoid distortions in capital movements and to allow effective taxation of interest payments made by paying agents established in the territory of a Member State (MS) to natural persons residing in another MS, the Council adopted in 2003 a Directive on the taxation of savings in the form of interest. It should be stressed that this legislation applies to a number of separate bilateral agreements between EU MS and overseas territories, as well as between the EU and five third countries.  With this scheme, it was facilitated the taxation of this type of interest payment, through the request for automatic exchange of information. With the entry into force of Council Directive No 2014/107/EU, which amends the Directive on administrative cooperation as a means of providing Member States with a European-wide legal basis for automatic exchange of information covering all types of financial products, provisions prevailing over those of the Savings Taxation Directive have been introduced. To that end, since Parliament has been called upon to deliver its opinion and in support of the Commission's proposal which notes that we are facing a case of overlap of two directives, I voted in favour of this proposal which supports the repeal of Directive No 2003/48/EC.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the Council's proposal for a directive repealing the 2003/48/EC Council Directive on The Taxation of Savings.  Nevertheless, while I support this repeal, separate bilateral agreements with certain countries must be concluded quickly.  It is therefore important that the Commission ensures that the repeal of the directive does not create a gap and that, in this sense, follow-up reports are published.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Commission's proposal to repeal the directive on the taxation of savings income in order to avoid uncertainty as to the application of existing tax provisions by Member States. Indeed, from 1 January 2016, the 2011 Directive on administrative cooperation will enter into force, adapted to the requirements of the OECD's overall criteria for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I agree with the objectives of the text with a view to simplifying legislation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, in favour of repealing the 2003 Directive on the taxation of savings yields, since there is a more recent Directive on the same issue. The rapporteur expressed concern that this repeal would open up some legal vacuum, and therefore included a number of amendments in that regard which we supported.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC aimed at plugging the possible gaps that this legislation has in the field of taxation of income generated by savings. The current Directive leaves it to national bilateral agreements to impose savings located in five non-EU European countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra), as well as island and overseas territories under special tax regimes. This has led to numerous situations of fiscal competition in the field of savings, which is what this repeal seeks to correct. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, as although I do wish to see obsolete acts repealed, I do not think this report will achieve what it hopes to do. It had various amendments in the report added by the rapporteur under committee rule 50 that calls on the Commission to do various things and I do not support the Commission bringing in new legislation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Today, I voted in favour of repealing the Savings Tax Directive because the Directive on Administrative Cooperation renders it redundant, and it doesn’t make sense to have businesses report on the same information twice. The new Directive on Administrative Cooperation should have a great impact in the fight against tax avoidance/evasion, and I want to makes sure that it is being implemented properly when it comes into force next year, and this vote will assist in that.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the fight against tax evasion and the need for fair taxation is an important issue at Both European and global level. Back in 2003, the Savings Taxation Directive was adopted in the EU as a measure to ensure that savings interest tax is paid. The directive has been applied in EU countries and in separate agreements between EU states and 12 overseas territories. Bilateral agreements with five European countries outside the EU have also been reached in parallel. In the meantime, the 2011 Administrative Cooperation Directive has been revised to align it with the OECD Global Standard for the Automatic Exchange of Financial Account Information in Tax Matters, which will apply from 1 January 2016. As part of the March 2015 tax transparency package, the Commission proposes to repeal the Savings Tax Directive so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of both directives in order to avoid the complexity of dual data collection and transmission systems. As the Directive on administrative cooperation has a much wider range of activities, I support the repeal of the Directive on taxation of savings income.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the proposals aimed at ensuring fair taxation, as this is an important issue at both European and global level. I also draw attention to the need to continue the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of repealing the Savings Tax Directive because it has now been superseded by the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, and it serves no purpose to burden businesses with having to report the same information twice. The new Directive on Administrative Cooperation should have a major impact in the fight against aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion, and Labour MEPs will make sure that it is being implemented properly when it comes into force next year.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. In 2003, the Council adopted the Savings Interest Income Tax Directive (Savings Directive). This Directive had two main purposes: avoiding distortions in capital movements and enabling the successful taxation of interest income paid by payers established in one Member State to natural persons resident in another Member State.  The Savings Directive facilitates the taxation of this type of interest income in accordance with the laws of the Member State where the natural person receiving the interest income resides, as it requires the automatic exchange of information on the interest income paid to those natural persons. I support the proposal to repeal Council Directive 2003/48/EC on the taxation of interest income on savings, as I believe that this ensures that there is only one applicable standard for automatic exchange of information in the EU, and can avoid situations where two standards apply at the same time.  Also, in order to avoid reporting gaps, the repeal of the Savings Directive must be timed to comply with the application of the Directive amending the Administrative Cooperation Directive.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments: the repeal of the Savings Directive. By repealing the 2003 Savings Tax Directive, we will make it easier for Member States to collect and report on information. The new directive will broaden the scope. We all agree and are working to strengthen the fight against tax fraud and fair taxation, and I therefore agree with the rapporteur's view that it is necessary to be very careful in this.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed text has legal loopholes.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, which helps Member States avoid additional administrative burdens caused by dual data collection and service systems.  My decision was also based on the oral opinion of parliamentary groups, tax experts DG TAXUD and independent experts on the Commission's proposal to repeal the 2003 Savings Taxation Directive. However, as the reporter rightly pointed out, the scope of the EU Savings Taxation Directive and the Directive on Administrative Cooperation is generally similar, but not quite the same. I therefore consider it of the utmost importance that the Commission continue to check that there are no loopholes in the wake of the repeal in order to reduce possible tax revenue losses for Member States.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The 2003 EU Savings Tax Directive was designed to ensure that tax is paid on the interest of savings. The Directive was applied among EU countries and in separate agreements between EU countries and 12 overseas, and five non-EU European countries (Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco and San Marino.) In 2014 the agreement was revised in order to tighten loopholes and align the Directive with the OECD’s Global Standard. As part of its March 2015 Tax Transparency Package, the Commission proposed to repeal the 2003 Savings Tax Directive, to enable Member States to avoid the inconvenience of double systems of collecting and reporting of data. Nevertheless, the repealing of an existing directive must take into consideration the need to uphold fair taxation across the EU. The current text gives consent to the proposed repeal, while asking the Commission to monitor possible loopholes, use legislative proposals if needed to address them, and report back to the EP. I believe this report, which I voted in favour of, will address and reduce the risk of potential loss of tax revenue to Member States across the EU.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The fight against tax evasion and the need for fair taxation are a major cause of concern both at European and global levels. While great progress is being made at the international level, it is nevertheless important to exercise caution when repealing an existing directive that has been in compliance for several years.  The scope of financial products covered by the Savings Tax Directive and the Administrative Cooperation Directive, although similar, are not exactly the same. Some products, most of them low-risk deposit accounts for savings purposes, will no longer be subject to communication under the Administrative Cooperation Directive. If the risks of tax evasion are low, the rapporteur believes that it is important for the Commission to continue to monitor that the abolition of the directive does not create a gap. It proposes that the Commission report to the European Parliament once all Member States have established their national lists of low-risk accounts.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns the Commission proposal for a Council directive that repeals Council Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments and I voted in favour of it. However, it should be noted that while Parliament supported the repeal of the Savings Directive, it warned that this may contribute to creating legal loopholes if separate bilateral agreements between the EU and five European countries that are not its Member States (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra) are not rapidly concluded. Parliament asked the Commission to continue monitoring the situation.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a Council directive repealing Council Savings Directive 2003/48/EC, because in the 2003 Savings Directive we require the reporting of interest income on debt claims and similar products, while the Administrative Cooperation Directive includes many more products, so I believe that we need to avoid double reporting and an unnecessary burden on Member States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, in favour of repealing the 2003 Directive on the taxation of savings yields, since there is a more recent Directive on the same issue. The rapporteur expressed concern that this repeal would open up some legal vacuum, and therefore included a number of amendments in that regard which we supported.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim here is to repeal The 2003/48 Directive as it is now duplicated by the 2014/107 Directive. The first established the imposition of cross-border interest payments by European payers, the second marks the adoption of the automatic exchange of information on savings income between EU countries, according to the OECD standard. In order to prevent two separate standards from co-existing, it is proposed to remove the first. I voted FOR.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of the above concerns about the possibility of loopholes and considering the risk of burdensome double reporting, the rapporteur had to assess how specific the potential loopholes might be and whether the burden of double reporting would weigh more for a year than ensuring that such loopholes did not develop. The rapporteur has fully examined possible loopholes related to repeal, with the involvement of experts and through a thorough analysis. It agreed with the repeal, but only with three amendments that voiced its concerns, and asked the Commission to report on the results of the repeal, referring to any legal gap that could emerge. It urged the Commission to take action, if necessary in the form of legislative proposals, to ensure that these loopholes are removed. It considered that these amendments would ensure that Parliament fulfils its role of reducing potential tax revenue losses for Member States across the Union. That's why I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, in favour of repealing the 2003 Directive on the taxation of savings yields, since there is a more recent Directive on the same issue. The rapporteur expressed concern that this repeal would open up some legal vacuum, and therefore included a number of amendments in that regard which we supported.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this rather technical file, taking into account our rapporteur managed to include in the report a certain number of possible concerns regarding the implementation of the international standard of automatic exchange of tax information.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution and therefore approved the Commission proposal as amended. The text addresses the bilateral agreements between the European Union and five European countries that are not Member States of the European Union (the Swiss Confederation, the Principality of Liechtenstein, the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Monaco and the Principality of Andorra), as well as between each of the Member States and 12 dependent or associated territories (the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man and the dependent or associated territories in the Caribbean) and it is important that such bilateral agreements are adapted to the new OECD global standard and to Directive 2014/107/EU. It is also crucial that no loopholes or other inadequacies are created in the process of moving from the existing to the new standard. At the same time this allows the Commission to take an active role in facilitating and promoting the revision of the Member State agreements with the 12 dependent or associated territories.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal aims to repeal the Savings Tax Directive. In this case, it is necessary that the repeal of this Directive should be coordinated well with the amendment of the Administrative Cooperation Directive. The main reason for proposing such a derogation is that the Administrative Cooperation Directive is much more encompassing in nature than the Savings Tax Directive. In the view of this fact, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that proposal.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a repeal of Council Directive 2003/48/EC aimed at plugging the possible gaps that this legislation has in the field of taxation of income generated by savings. The current Directive leaves it to national bilateral agreements to impose savings located in five non-EU European countries (Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Monaco and Andorra), as well as island and overseas territories under special tax regimes. This has led to numerous situations of fiscal competition in the field of savings, which is what this repeal seeks to correct. That's why I've decided to vote for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2003/48/EC concerns the taxation of savings income in the form of interest generated by credits and was implemented with the aim of ensuring the payment of savings taxes in the form of interest. That directive will be repealed so that MSs do not have to apply the provisions of the 2003 and 2011 Directives (on savings taxation and administrative cooperation respectively) and can avoid the difficulties caused by dual reporting systems.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur has highlighted points to be taken into account when repealing the directive. In particular, the Commission's required reporting obligation to Parliament if the repeal loopholes arise is to be welcomed. That is why I supported this report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A directive regulating the taxation of savings income was adopted in 2003 and laying down the obligation to communicate information concerning interest accrued on claims or the like. This directive applies to many bilateral agreements between EU Member States and third countries. However, the Commission is renegotiating a number of bilateral agreements on the same subject with many third countries, including Switzerland, Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco and San Marino, with the aim of tightening up compliance with the global standards set by the OECD for the automatic exchange of information. The Commission has therefore proposed repealing the 2003 directive on the taxation of savings income in order to avoid the formation of a dual system of data collection and communication. That is why I voted in favour, bearing in mind that the Commission will have to intervene, including through legislative proposals, if there is a risk that the system will be circumvented.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of repealing the Savings Tax Directive because it has now been superseded by the Directive on Administrative Cooperation, and it makes no sense to burden businesses with having to report the same information twice. The new Directive on Administrative Cooperation should have a major impact in the fight against aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion, and Labour MEPs will make sure that it is being implemented properly when it comes into force next year. Fighting and legislating for tax justice is part of our work of building a more social Europe in a fairer global economy. This type of legislation can only be effectively adopted and implemented at a European level.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the vote, the European Parliament expressed a non-binding opinion for the Council on the repeal of Directive 2003/48/EC on taxation of savings income. Its aim is to introduce a uniform standard for the exchange of financial information in tax matters. In view of the revision of Directive 2014/107/EU on administrative cooperation, which will introduce a global OECD standard on the flow of this information in the European Union from 1 January 2016, it was necessary to adapt the existing regulations to the new legal situation. In order to avoid the parallel application of the two standards, I consider it necessary to repeal Directive 2003/48/EC. At the same time, in view of the risk of possible loopholes in relations with the 12 associated territories, I support efforts to agree as soon as possible on appropriate agreements with non-EU regulated entities. In view of the need to combat tax avoidance behaviour, and at the same time to avoid imposing unnecessary obligations on traders, I voted in favour of the proposed resolution.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. In 2003, the Council adopted a Directive on the taxation of savings income in the form of interest payments, entitled 'Savings tax directive'. This Directive sought to avoid distortions in the movement of capital and to enable the effective taxation of interest paid by paying agents established in one Member State on natural persons resident in another Member State.  In order to ensure that there is only one rule applicable to the automatic exchange of information in the EU, to avoid situations of parallel application of two different rules and with the aim of preventing any interruption of the communication of information, the Savings Tax Directive should be repealed.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The repeal of the 2003 Savings Income Taxation Directive was voted on today to facilitate the entry into force of the Directive on the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, adopted as part of the March 2015 tax transparency package, which should apply from 1 January 2016.  This repeal has been proposed by the Commission so that Member States are not obliged to apply the provisions of both directives, thus avoiding excessive administrative burdens and the discomfort caused by dual data collection and communication systems. It is therefore a procedural vote which does not present any particular critical issues. However, I abstained, as I believe it is important to proceed with extreme caution with regard to the repeal of a directive that has been in force for many years.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2003/48/EC concerns the taxation of savings income in the form of interest generated by credits and was implemented with the aim of ensuring the payment of savings taxes in the form of interest. That directive will be repealed so that Member States do not have to apply the provisions of the 2003 and 2011 Directives (on savings taxation and administrative cooperation respectively) and can avoid the difficulties caused by dual reporting systems. The European Parliament's report proposes that the European Commission draw up a report on the results of the repeal and submit legislative proposals to ensure that any remaining gaps are addressed. The EP also regrets that no specific cost-benefit analysis has been carried out of a dual communication system or a transition period between the two standards. We voted for it.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Sweden has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, since we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to allow the automated exchange of personal data in Sweden. In the context of terrorism and in the context of combating cross-border crime, deepening cooperation between states must be a priority.
