The decisions drawn up in this report are in this direction, thus allowing Sweden to transmit the data, as the Council has approved the implementation of the general data protection provisions.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposed enforcement decision by the Commission is to facilitate the transmission and receipt of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. It strengthens cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and big banditry.  In the case of a decision affecting individual freedoms, strict control over the use of this data is essential. It is precisely for this reason that the exchange of personal data can only be implemented after complying with general data protection provisions. On 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Sweden had implemented all of these provisions. As cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism and big banditry, I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The exchange of such information should be a matter for the Member States concerned, not the whole of the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation aimed at deepening cross-border cooperation with Sweden, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to support Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on the exchange of personal data in Sweden with a view to improving cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This is one of three proposals for an enforcement decision by the Council to allow Sweden, Belgium and Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision. In the context of this decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of personal data provided for by the decision can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general data protection provisions set out in this decision. On the basis of the general assessment report presented to it, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Sweden, Belgium and Poland had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. I voted in favour of this report, saying that Sweden is fulfilling the necessary conditions. Yes, Member States must cooperate to combat cross-border crime and terrorism!

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Through the 2007 Pmo Treaty, several EU states committed themselves in an intergovernmental framework to intensify data exchange in order to intensify cross-border cooperation and combat terrorism and international crime more effectively. These data exchanges involve fingerprints, vehicle registration numbers and DNA. Before participating in the exchange system, each country must pass data protection tests. As Sweden has passed these tests, the Council therefore wishes that it can receive and transmit fingerprint data under the Treaty. I supported this point, as data exchange is an essential means of increasing security within the European Union

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime, I supported Mrs Benova's report, which aims to authorise Sweden to receive and transmit personal data. This included facilitating this exchange in the sense that the transmission of data under the Council's 2008/615/JAI enforcement decision can only take place after the data protection provisions have been implemented in national law. With Sweden meeting these conditions, there was no reason why this automated exchange of information should be endorsed.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Flašíková Beňová's report is balanced and unreliable. If we want to combat international crime and terrorism effectively, the first step is to allow a rapid and efficient exchange of information between the police forces of the Member States. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be initiated only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. On 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Sweden fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, Sweden should be enabled to receive and transmit personal data under Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. That is why I voted favourably on this report necessary to give approval to the exchange of fingerprint data with Sweden.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's decision on the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden. This Decision is part of the improvement of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Pursuant to Decision 2008/615/JHA, personal data may not be provided as provided for in that Decision until the general provisions on the protection of personal data laid down by that Decision have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States providing such data. Sweden has implemented these provisions and Sweden will soon have the right to receive and provide personal data for the purpose of automated dactyloscopic data.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The purpose of the proposed decision, which I supported, is to allow Sweden to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the applicable rules on improving cross-border cooperation.  This is particularly important in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and this is all the more necessary in the light of the current migrant crisis.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's three proposals for an enforcement decision to allow Sweden to receive and transmit personal data. This decision enables, in particular, the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime by deepening cross-border cooperation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because Sweden has complied with all the conditions required by Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime and on the automated exchange of dactic data and, therefore, must be admitted to the programme.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision by the Commission is intended to facilitate the receipt and transmission of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. This measure should strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and the big banditry whose organizations are free of borders. This transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of the general data protection provisions set out in the text. However, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Sweden had implemented all of these provisions. Considering that this type of cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the authorised exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden because cross-border cooperation is very beneficial for the Member States and is also beneficial for the protection of national legislation and helps to eradicate terrorism as well as to strengthen the rule of law.  The Commission's decision implementing Decision 2008/615/ JHA provides that the automatic exchange of data must be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a pilot test, a questionnaire prepared by the working group and an evaluation visit, this being done by the audit. Sweden has taken all the necessary steps, thus applying the data protection questionnaire and the fingerprint data exchange questionnaire.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The aim is to improve cross-border police cooperation between Member States. The authorities must be able to exchange police information quickly and efficiently in order to combat organised crime and terrorism effectively.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the draft Council decision to launch in Sweden the automated exchange of dactic data, i.e. fingerprint images, handhelds, and models of such images that are stored and processed in an automated database. The provisions concern, in particular, the exchange of information in the context of important events and in the fight against terrorism, as well as other forms of cross-border police cooperation. Sweden has successfully completed questionnaires on automated data exchanges and has also completed the pilot experiment with Austria. In this way, the general data protection provisions laid down in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA have been fully implemented.  Therefore, in order to allow Sweden to receive and transmit these types of data, I voted in favour of the project.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which deals with the stepping up of cross-border cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. According to a previous decision, personal data may not be supplied until general provisions on data protection have been implemented in national law. The Council now states that Sweden has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and can begin to receive and supply personal data under Decision 2008/615/JHA. This report is related to the implementation of the Prüm Decision, which I have consistently opposed, but these particular reports deal with the implementation of the data protection safeguards for fingerprint data exchange to occur. As I have always advocated for the implementation of adequate data protection safeguards for personal data exchange, I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sweden has managed to implement the relevant data protection provisions and should be included in the exchange of fingerprint data in order to combat international crime and terrorism more effectively. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The dossier concerns Sweden's authorisation to receive and transmit personal data under Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. The Council concluded that the country had fully implemented the necessary general data protection provisions and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report refers to the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden. Having regard to the Council's draft and the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we approve the Council's draft and call on the Council, if it intends to derogate from the text adopted by Parliament, to update it. It also calls on Parliament to be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the text adopted by Parliament.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the measure. The worrying proliferation of organised criminal groups capable of operating on a cross-border basis together with the use of terrorism obliges the European institutions to step up cooperation in the fight against these criminal phenomena. The exchange of sensitive information and data between the authorities and security forces of the Member States is a key element in implementing an effective crime-fighting strategy. As Sweden has put the general data protection provisions into practice, according to Decision 2008/615/JHA, it is considered necessary to authorise Sweden to receive and transmit fingerprint data.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Monika Flašíková Beňová's draft resolution on the exchange of dactic information and data with Sweden, as I consider it very important to step up cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. I believe that cooperation between the various EU states is essential to prevent and combat certain dangers or problems to which The Member States may be subject.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Decision No 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation substantially incorporates the Treaty of Prüm into the Community legal order, maintaining the objective of stimulating greater cooperation between member states' security forces, in particular through greater exchange of information.  As I have said several times, this exchange of information is essential in the field of security, and it is a requirement for a result of greater mutual trust. Certain requirements must therefore be respected, in particular the principles of necessity and proportionality and respect for fundamental rights.  Therefore, in order to establish the automated exchange of type-scopic data, each Member State must ensure that data protection standards are implemented. This Council decision correctly authorises the initiation of the automated exchange, since Sweden has implemented it correctly.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the automated exchange of dactic data for Sweden, as it aims to strengthen cross-border cooperation on the application of European law. In particular, Sweden has endorsed Prüm's decision on police cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crimes.  Sweden has fully implemented the general provisions on the protection of personal data in its legal system, which is why the Council is proposing Sweden's authorisation to provide and receive personal data for investigative and judicial purposes in the fight against transnational crime.  The approval of automated data exchange is part of the European Information Exchange Model (EIXM), a useful legislative tool that aims to promote security cooperation in the protection of European citizens.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ One aim of the European Union is to provide its citizens with high levels of freedom as well as security and justice for crimes. To do so, Member States must be interconnected, achieved through the creation of a national database for cross—border checks of people from DNA and dactyloscopic data (fingerprinting). This report states that the Member State of Sweden has meet the Directive’s criteria established for implementation of an automatic data exchange. I voted for this report that will allow the Member State of Sweden to receive and supply such above discussed data to combat terrorism and other such crimes.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to implement this Council Decision aims to authorise Sweden to receive and transmit personal data under Council Decision 2008/615/JHA from the date of entry into force of the Decision. According to the Commission, the provision of personal data provided under that decision cannot take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States concerned by the transmission. On the basis of a general evaluation report, the Council concluded that the three countries mentioned above have fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Council Decision 2008/615/JHA. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Sweden has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, since we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the Council's implementing decision, the European Parliament is merely in a consultation procedure. Parliament's LIBE committee approved the draft decision without propositioning an amendment, which was then submitted to Parliament's plenary. I voted in favour of the text. The aim of the report is to introduce automated data exchange in Sweden. The exchange of data may be introduced only if the country fulfils the conditions. Sweden has complied, inter alia, by completing the questionnaire on data protection and fingerprint exchange. Sweden may therefore send and receive personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/IB. The draft plays an important role in strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of the Council draft. This is a technical consultation procedure on the implementation of the Prüm Decision on exchanging fingerprint data by Sweden. Sweden fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of this decision.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to support the Council's draft decision on the launch of automated fingerprint data exchange in Sweden. The transmission of personal data under EU law can only take place after the general data protection provisions have been implemented in national law. Considering that Sweden has met the conditions for the exchange of such data, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden. The exchange of fingerprint data between Member States, while respecting data protection, is an essential step in strengthening the fight against terrorism and organised crime within the European Union.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 As regards the fight against terrorism and organised crime, cross-border cooperation and the necessary database are an essential element in dealing with them. I welcome the Council's report recognising that Sweden has complied with all the requirements as regards the protection of personal data, in particular fingerprint data.  I approve of Sweden's accession to the cooperation system and believe that this is an important step for the security of the Union, especially in a situation like the current one where the EU faces one of its biggest security challenges since its inception.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met), of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Sweden succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, is one of the most important issues to prevent terrorist acts against EU citizens. The exchange of information between countries is a crucial factor in minimizing these attacks. However, data sharing should be done in line with the agreement of the different countries. In this report, these aspects are properly safeguarded and therefore i am approved.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it is in line with efficiency in the fight against crime and terrorism, while giving states the protection of personal data.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision No 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime, the provision of personal data cannot take place until the general data protection provisions have been transposed into national law within the territory of the Member States concerned. The Council proposals aim to allow Poland, Belgium and Sweden to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the above-mentioned decision. These three reports relate to the Prüm Convention which was signed in May 2005 in Prüm (Germany) between seven Member States: Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands. It has been criticised for being negotiated and adopted in a very untransparent manner and without being subject to effective democratic scrutiny. The objective of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities, contributing to the possibility of comparing, for example, a particular DNA profile with profiles recorded in existing automated databases in the Member States. Our vote is inseparable from the more general consideration we make of the so-called fight against terrorism and the role it has been taking on the EU.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The reports are related to the implementation of the Prüm Decision, which I oppose but these particular reports deal with the implementation of the data protection safeguards for fingerprint data exchange to occur, and I advocate for the implementation of adequate data protection safeguards for personal data exchange. Therefore, as a compromise between those two angles, I abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this is a purely technical consultation procedure for the implementation of the so-called Prüm Decision in the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden. On the basis of the overall evaluation report presented to the Council, the Council decided that Sweden fulfilled all the conditions on 13 July 2015 and implemented the general data protection provisions as set out in Chapter 6 of the Decision.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report for a better exchange of data and information.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met) of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Sweden succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful. For these reasons I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the need to step up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and to strengthen cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approved the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden. The supply of personal data may not take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States involved. The verification that this condition has been met with respect to automated data exchange is done on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot run. Sweden has completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on dactyloscopic data exchange. A successful pilot run has been carried out by Sweden with Austria.  On 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Sweden had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore, for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic data, Sweden should be entitled to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Automated exchange of dactyloscopic data with Sweden', as I support the approach. In order to guarantee security in a borderless Europe, we also need efficient, cross-border cooperation between security authorities and the effective exchange of data.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is desirable and important to step up EU cooperation to protect citizens. In an emergency, data necessary for the efficient investigation of criminal offences can be provided more quickly.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves exchanging fingerprint data.  I voted against for obvious reasons.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report to increase cross-border cooperation in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The exchange of dactyloscopic or fingerprint data is important for the purposes of criminal identification, registration, and investigation. Following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this report, which aims to promote the cross-border exchange of fingerprint information from Sweden and thus improve cooperation between Member States' police services so that they can better combat terrorism and organised crime, in accordance with European data protection standards.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, in view of the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside other S&D MEPs, voted in favour of this report. This report is purely technical and is a simple approval of an evaluation report in which it is concluded that Sweden has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of the Prüm Decision.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden because it will help the stepping up of cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it helps the facilitation of exchange of such data for the fight against terrorism and cross—border crimes.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament approved by a large majority the decision on the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden.  In short, the aim is to allow the Swedish authorities to receive and transfer personal data, in this case fingerprints, to other Member States in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. In the current context of strong terrorist threats to European states, the exchange of information between the relevant authorities is a necessary measure of threat prevention and is an essential condition for the identification of radicalised and extremist individuals.  Today, we cannot do without these instruments to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, which are the new scourges of the 21st century. That is why I have been a strong backer of this decision.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision to launch an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden, as it strengthens cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.  Automated data exchange enables more efficient prevention and consistent investigation of crimes and empowers security within the European Union itself. Member States' synergies in this area contribute to the international fight against terrorism, the strengthening of cross-border police cooperation and stability, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision of the Commission facilitates the transmission and receipt of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. This decision aims to strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and big banditry.  This exchange of personal data can only be implemented after complying with the general data protection provisions stipulated in the text. However, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Sweden had implemented all of these provisions. As cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and my fellow UKIP MEPs reject the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report which will enable Sweden to receive and transmit personal information as part of cross-border cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report. Automated data exchange of dactyloscopic data is absolutely in favour of crime prevention and counter-terrorism. Such data exchange enables national security authorities to intervene in good time, thereby increasing citizens' general sense of security.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it aims to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. Also, following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The dattiloscopic investigation is an activity that aims at personal identification and, although it is very complex, is among the most effective in the field of criminality. The aim of this report is to strengthen cross-border police and judicial cooperation between the countries of the European Union. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of Mrs Beňová's work on the automated exchange of dactic data in Sweden.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Benova report concerns the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden. It is intended to allow this country to transmit and receive personal data. Indeed, in the context of deepening cross-border cooperation against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of this data can only take place after the implementation in national law of data protection provisions. Sweden fulfils these conditions, as the Council's conclusions prove. So I voted for it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it extends cooperation in the transmission of personal data to Sweden in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Sweden has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, since we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The purpose of MP Monica Flašíkova Beňova's report is to approve the Council Decision of July 2015, which empowers Sweden to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA, due to more advanced and improved cross-border cooperation. Since dactyloscopy is the most modern and safe method of identifying a person, and automated exchange of dactyloscopic data is a step forward for a safer society, supported the report with the aim of launching an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The exchange of data promoting public security is in all the need for the daily lives of the Member States of the European Union, especially in view of the increased frequency of cross-border crime in recent decades and terrorist activities on a global scale. In order for the people of our community to feel safer, the exchange of dactyloscopic data is an important step in further promoting this security. At the same time, it is important to note that, although the use of retina, fingerprints and other similar data on the same biometric and other documents is increasingly frequent, this information must under no circumstances be allowed to be taken into the hands of criminals, thereby jeopardising the security which should be encouraged by the use and exchange of these data.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden will strengthen international police cooperation in the fight against terrorism, international crime and illegal immigration. The adoption of the implementing regulation is urgent precisely at a time of difficult security situation, when the Countries of the Union are subject to an onslaught of enormous numbers of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this proposal. Fingerprint data is personal data, and is intended to be exchanged between Member States to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. For security reasons, only Member States with data protection provisions in their national law can be part of this agreement. An evaluation report shows that Sweden has put these general data protection provisions in place, so the exchange can be put in place.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch in Sweden of the automated exchange of dactic data.  Following a general assessment by the Council, Sweden appears to have implemented the general provisions on data protection, on the basis of Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation. This ensures that Sweden can receive and transmit fingerprint data.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes the fight against terrorism and crime prevention. Automated exchange will simplify the prosecution of criminals. I therefore supported the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim is to allow Sweden to receive and transmit personal data (DNA profile, fingerprints and vehicle registration) from its police files with those of other Member States. While the legislation contains an issue on data protection and the limits of its use, the flaws in these laws are known. The CNIL was also concerned about this legislation. Above all, this dossier is part of a general trend of registering offenders as well as European citizens or migrants. These files are then cross-referenced, against the very provisions of European law, to determine profiles of each citizen. A so-called Big Brother to fight terrorism, an argument that Snowden has largely demonstrated as ineffective. It is mainly a way of increasing the amount of data on citizens to make it available to the United States or even more recently to German intelligence services.  I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly with regard to the fight against terrorism and organised crime, I have presented my vote in agreement with the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of type-only data in Sweden. Cross-border data comparison reflects a new dimension in the fight against crime. The information obtained through comparison plays a crucial role in supporting the judicial and law enforcement authorities of the Member States.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which allows Sweden to both provide and receive dactyloscopic data for use in criminal investigations as Sweden has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with Parliament's adoption of the Proposal for a Council Implementing Decision on the launch of automated dactyloscopic data exchange in Sweden, which aims to facilitate cooperation and address common security challenges. In view of its 2015 resolution on the European agenda on security, Parliament has only a consultative role on the issue.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden, which is a purely technical consultation procedure on the implementation of the so—called Prüm Decision on exchanging fingerprint data by Sweden.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A vote adding Sweden to the legal architecture of Europe allowing the fighting of terrorism and organised crime while fully respecting human rights and the rule of law.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Council Decision 2008/615/IB on strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the provision of personal data provided for in this Decision shall not take place until the Member States concerned have introduced general data protection provisions through the national legislation in force in their territory.  On 13 July 2015, on the basis of the report submitted to it, the Council concluded that the existing Swedish legislation complies in all respects with the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/IB. The Council therefore intends to empower Sweden by decision to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/IB. The Council should consult the European Parliament before adopting the Decision in accordance with Article 39(1) of the Treaty on European Union, as amended by the Treaty of Amsterdam and Article 9 of Protocol 36 on transitional arrangements. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended the Council's draft to Parliament for approval. I supported the Council's draft decision accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime depends on efficient and close cooperation between Member States. The transmission of personal data under Decision No 2008/615/JAI may be carried out only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that Decision have been incorporated into the national legislation of the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission.  The verification of compliance with this condition relating to the automated exchange of data shall be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report which, in turn, is based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. Given that Sweden has met the requirements of Decision No 2008/615/JAI and successfully carried out a pilot test with Austria, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Benova report concerns the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden. It is intended to allow this country to transmit and receive personal data. Indeed, in the context of deepening cross-border cooperation against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of this data can only take place after the implementation in national law of data protection provisions. Sweden fulfils these conditions, as the Council's conclusions prove. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which relates to an old Council decision to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The exchange of dactyloscopic data refers to the study of fingerprints for the purposes of criminal identification, registration and investigation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Council's plan to allow Sweden to receive and transmit fingerprint data. The aim is to improve the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime in the European Union by promoting cooperation between Member States. This authorization comes after the Commission verifies that all data protection conditions are met.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will implement the Council’s decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it can bring significant progress in the area of crime prevention and counter-terrorism. Essentially, it is about the exchange of fingerprints. If we look at the current influx of refugees, which is already affecting the whole of Europe, progress can also be expected in the area of combating the abuse of asylum.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report proposes to approve Sweden's participation in the Prum scheme. The Treaty of Prem was signed in 2005 with the aim of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, allowing signatory states to exchange personal, genetic or numerical data on an individual suspected of intending homicide. The Council's 2008/615/JAI and 2008/616/JAI directives provide that a country's participation in this scheme should be conditional on the transposition of measures dealing with the protection of personal data into national legislation.  While I am aware of the stakes and the need for concrete action to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, I am not convinced that such a mechanism can effectively combat this without endangering the right to privacy. So I abstain.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to step up the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote positively because I am sensitive to the particularly topical debate on data protection and exchange on European territory. With special attention to the specific case of Sweden and its needs, I appreciate the efforts of the institutions in this area and I am confident in the development of their policies.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The exchange of dactyloscopic data is crucial in strengthening security throughout the European Union. In my view, the dactyloscopic data available in national fingerprint databases should be available to all Member States of the European Union for inspection and search and a constant exchange of dactylopscopic data should be carried out between countries, as this act would avoid lengthy investigations and searches for the culprits of certain crimes.  Such an exchange would successfully help detect and prevent organised crime that is more and more present in Europe and terrorism, which has unfortunately become a global threat. Sweden, as a country that is the ultimate destination for many immigrants, should have this security exchange set at a high level due to the constant influx of new people from other parts of Europe, including the world.  All the more so because statistics show that 25% of crimes in Sweden are made up of third-country nationals, while an additional 20% of crimes in Sweden are made up of immigrant family members, and given the new waves of migration that will further change the population structure, preventive steps should be taken to strengthen security and prevent organised crime such as this one.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerns the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden. It is intended to allow this country to transmit and receive personal data. Indeed, in the context of deepening cross-border cooperation against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of this data can only take place after the implementation in national law of data protection provisions. Sweden fulfils these conditions, as the Council's conclusions prove. So I voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The fight against terrorism and cross-border crime are important elements of interstate cooperation within the EU, and I believe that in this light the exchange and availability of personal data, in this case dactyloscopic, i.e. fingerprints, should be seen. However, it is also important to demand that such cross-border cooperation take place only on condition that the national laws of the countries involved have fully implemented rules on the protection of personal data. Given that these conditions in Sweden are met, I support this draft.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support Monica Flašík's Beňova report to initiate automatic data exchange with respect to dactyloscopic data (fingerprints) in Sweden. In line with the decision to intensify cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime and the supply of personal data.  Protection is carried out in the national law of the territories of the Member States participating in such offers. Sweden completed a data protection questionnaire and a dactyloscopic data exchange questionnaire, and a successful pilot ride was conducted by Sweden with Austria. On the basis of the presented overall evaluation report, on 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Sweden had fully implemented the general data protection provisions.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In an area of free movement of persons, the Member States of the European Union need to strengthen their cooperation in order to combat international terrorism, cross-border crime and irregular immigration more effectively. Sweden completed the data protection questionnaire and the dactic data exchange questionnaire and successfully carried out a pilot experiment with Austria, as provided for in Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation. Therefore, having fully implemented the general provisions on data protection, the Council authorises Sweden to receive and transmit fingerprint data. My vote can only be in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the provision of personal data provided for in this Decision cannot comm;as long as data protection rules are not implemented in the national law of the Member States. Poland, Belgium and Sweden completed a data protection questionnaire, as well as a questionnaire on the exchange of dactyloscopic data, and carried out pilot projects. On the basis of its overall assessment, the Council concluded that these countries had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a former Minister of Justice, I consider cooperation in this area to be very beneficial. I therefore did not hesitate to support the resolution, both in this case cooperation with Sweden and on other resolutions concerning Poland and Belgium.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted the text on the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden. I voted in favour of this report because it allows Sweden to receive and transfer personal data, such as fingerprints, to other Member States in order to strengthen security within the Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of understanding that cooperation and the exchange of information are decisive factors in strengthening the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be initiated only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. On 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Sweden fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, Sweden should be enabled to receive and transmit personal data under Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. That is why I voted favourably on this report necessary to give approval to the exchange of fingerprint data with Sweden.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Council's plan to launch the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Sweden. Such systematization of trade and strengthening cross-border cooperation will be useful in law enforcement and counter-terrorism.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative motion for a resolution aims to launch the automated exchange of fingerprint stylised data with Sweden. In the context of existing agreements aimed at deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the provision of personal data cannot take place until the general provisions on data protection are transposed into national law on the territory of the Member States participating in such transmissions. Given that Sweden has met the criteria necessary to operate the exchange of dactyloscopic data and that the pilot experience carried out with Austria in this context has been successful, the Council's overall assessment concluded that the Council fully complied with the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision No 2008/615/JAI, and i therefore considered that there were no reasons for the adoption of this report, eminently technical, by colleague Monika Flašíková Beňová, who voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the Council's draft implementation decision on the launch of the automated data exchange for fingerprint data in Sweden. The Council's proposed implementation decision is aimed at authorising Sweden to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden, as I believe that in order to combat terrorist activities and cross-border organised crime, it is of paramount importance that the authorities of the Member States responsible for international security cooperate with each other through an increasingly timely and comprehensive exchange of information.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because greater cooperation between the Member States of the European Union makes it possible to combat international crime and terrorism more effectively. Therefore, the competent authorities must be able to exchange information quickly and efficiently.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, in view of the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Sweden has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, since we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I do not wish to see UK citizens’ fingerprint data shared with foreign nations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a purely technical consultation procedure and concerns the implementation of the so-called ‘Prüm Decision on exchanging fingerprint data’ by Sweden. It’s well formed and I voted in favour of it, alongside my S&D colleagues.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Cooperation on the exchange of information on dactyloscopic data with Sweden is also an important step in this fight.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ in connection with the intensification of cross-border cooperation, in particular with regard to the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, I am glad that a system has been tested and launched in Sweden that will allow the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data. I voted in favour of this Proposal from the Council because I believe that it is essential for European internal security that the national authorities cooperate in the first place. By adopting this legislative resolution, Sweden will be obliged to communicate personal data if requested by the security forces of another country. This is also the case in Belgium and Poland.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding cross-border exchange of dactyloscopic data (the study of fingerprints for the purposes of criminal identification, registration and investigation) in an attempt to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. Following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of this draft Implementation Decision of the Council is to initiate an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden. International exchange of dactyloscopic data is the key to fighting cross-border crime. Decisions referred to in Article 25(2) of the Code of Art Decisions 2008/615/PUP are taken on the basis of a questionnaire-based assessment report. The questionnaire drawn up by the relevant Council working group concerns any automated data exchange and must be completed by the Member State, thus considering that it meets the requirements for data sharing in the relevant data category. I fully support this draft Council with a view to launching an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden, as I believe this will contribute to deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in countering terrorism and cross-border crime. The ultimate objective is to support Sweden in the fight against cross-border crime and to step up cooperation in law enforcement in the EU.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I supported the proposal in writing ‒ as it aims to deepen cooperation between Member States in the field of criminalisation and the fight against terrorism.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the United Kingdom did not participate in the original Council Decision with regard to automated exchange of dactyloscopic data, and is therefore not taking part in the adoption of this Decision, I abstained on this report.  While I support the objectives of the Decision, which are to have more Member States cooperating in the fight against serious crime and terrorism, the provisions on the exchange of DNA and fingerprint material relate closely to many of the elements of Prüm Treaty which the UK has not yet implemented.  Under the Prüm Treaty, a Member State can ask another state to check key personal data (and car registrations) against their database as part of a criminal investigation. I have significant concerns regarding certain civil liberties and data protection elements, and the cost implications related to its implementation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met), of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Sweden succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Ensuring the security of European citizens is one of the essential debts of the European institutions. In order to achieve this aim, it is necessary to take all necessary measures to avoid the risks of the alleged free movement of persons within the single European area, enshrined in the Schengen Convention. At the same time, however, those measures must not limit the rights and freedoms of individuals, but must be implemented in full respect of European values. The fingerprinting of people entering the European area is one of these preventive measures necessary to ensure European security. Although its application involves procedures characteristic rather of preventing national and cross-border crime, its concrete results are likely to strengthen the database needed to prevent dangerous persons, for example terrorists, from entering the European area. Of course, this does not exclude the penetration of individuals who are not in the existing database, but it is a first step in prevention work. Sweden is one of the countries affected by the phenomenon of extra-European migration that has intensified in recent months. In this context, closer cooperation with the other Member States is necessary in order to avoid the penetration of elements hostile to European values and of terrorist nature.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted on the Council's proposed implementation decision on the launch of the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data, following the informed advice of the political group.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which aims to launch automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden. The proposed Council implementing decision seeks to authorise Sweden to receive and supply personal data. This act follows Council Decision 2008/615/JHA, which incorporates the substance of the so-called ʽPrüm Treatyʼ. The initiative between Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Spain, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Austria, Slovenia, Slovakia, Italy, Finland, Portugal, Romania and Sweden focuses on the stepping up of cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal migration. In order to strengthen freedom, security and justice, it recommends making full use of new technologies and enabling reciprocal access to national databases.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Sweden, because the Council implementing decision will allow Sweden to receive and send data on the deepening of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, which will ensure greater security for EU citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, in view of the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed Council enforcement decision is intended to allow Sweden to receive and transmit personal data. In the context of this decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the planned transmission of personal data can only take place after the general data protection provisions set out in this decision are implemented in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission. On the basis of the general assessment report presented to it, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Sweden had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. I voted for this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime and strengthen cross-border cooperation.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament refers to the draft decision implementing the Council on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to fingerprint data in Sweden.  Automated access to fingerprint data (palm prints, latent fingerprints, etc.) is regulated in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on enhancing cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The aim of this decision is to accelerate cross-border police and judicial cooperation between European Union countries in criminal matters by improving the exchange of information between authorities responsible for preventing and investigating criminal offences. The launch of automated data exchange with regard to fingerprint data may be carried out only after the general provisions on the protection of personal data have been implemented in the national legislation of the Member States. Verification of compliance with this condition shall be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. These criteria were successfully met by Sweden, so the Council gave a favourable opinion to Sweden to receive and provide personal data for the purpose of automated search for fingerprint data.  Through the legislative resolution, Parliament approved this Council decision.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, in view of the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the three reports on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden, Poland and Belgium. This time, Parliament has at last been properly consulted on the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data. The Green Group had insisted already in 2008 on the inclusion of data-protection standards in the decision and proper consultation with Parliament. Now we can formally agree to automated data exchange.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden because I believe it is important to strengthen cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and to work on strengthening cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU. It has also been established that Sweden has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA, therefore I supported this resolution.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA on the intensification of cross-border cooperation, in particular with regard to the fight against terrorism and organized crime, the provision of personal data (including fingerprints) should not be carried out until the general data protection provisions have not been implemented in the legislation of the Member States concerned.  On the basis of a general assessment report submitted to the Council, the Council concluded that the Member State had implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore authorises it to receive and provide fingerprints in accordance with this Decision. For all the above, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Sweden responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Sweden has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2008, the European Commission presented a proposal for the establishment of the 'Eurodac' system for the purpose of the effective implementation of the Dublin Convention. This proposal is currently part of the Asylum package.  Eurodac is a common processing of personal data, used since 15 January 2003, and includes an automatic fingerprint recognition system. The purpose of this processing is to determine the Member State which, under the Dublin Convention, is responsible for the examination of an application for asylum lodged in one of the EU States. This draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of type-scopic data is part of this logic.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes the fight against terrorism and crime prevention. Automated exchange will simplify the prosecution of criminals. I therefore supported the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision on the launch in Sweden of the automated exchange of dactic data for two reasons. Firstly, I believe that cross-border cooperation is essential for strengthening the European Union. Secondly, I am convinced that terrorism and organised crime can only be defeated by joint action. Of course, the European Parliament and its Committee on Civil Liberties, Human Rights, Research and Rights, Research and Rights will ensure that this exchange takes place with full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms. In fact, you cannot violate the right to the protection of your personal data in the name of security.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of this report. The ECR supports the accession of Sweden, Poland and Belgium to the automated exchange system of dactyloscopic data. Poland, Belgium and Sweden have completed the data protection and dactyloscopic (i.e. fingerprint) data exchange questionnaire and carried out successful pilot projects. On the basis of a comprehensive evaluation report, the Council decided on 13 July 2015 that these Member States had fully implemented the general data protection rules. I support my group's position on this issue and have accordingly voted in favour of this report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported all three reports on automated dactyloscopic data exchange in Sweden, Belgium and Poland. This is part of a system that facilitates cross-border cooperation between countries, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, which is becoming increasingly important. And I believe that it is the exchange of personal data that is an important part of the fight against this expanding phenomenon. At the same time, I also support the principle on which national joining is based on this system. In order for countries to have personal data that is sensitive and potentially misused, countries need to meet well-defined conditions and thus demonstrate their ability to participate fully in the automated exchange system.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision No 2008/615/JAI on the deepening of cross-border cooperation, the fight against terrorism and crime, the provision of personal data provided for in the context of that decision cannot take place until the general data protection provisions have been transposed into national law. The Council proposal aims to authorise Sweden to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision 2008/615/JAI from the date of its entry into force. These three reports relate to the Prüm Convention which was signed on 27 May 2005 in Prüm (Germany) between seven Member States - Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain, and the Netherlands. The objective of the Prüm Decision is thus to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities, contributing to this, for example, the possibility of comparing, for example, a particular DNA profile with profiles recorded in existing automated databases in the Member States. We know that, on the pretext of combating terrorism and crime, the EU has been putting together a surveillance system that safeguards the freedoms and guarantees of individuals. This measure goes in similar logic from what we voted against.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Belgium has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to allow the automated exchange of personal data in Belgium. In the context of terrorism and in the context of combating cross-border crime, deepening cooperation between states must be a priority. The decisions drawn up in this report go in this direction, thus allowing Belgium to transmit the data, as the Council has approved the implementation of the general data protection provisions.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposed enforcement decision by the Commission is to facilitate the transmission and receipt of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. It strengthens cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and big banditry. In the case of a decision affecting individual freedoms, strict control over the use of this data is essential. It is precisely for this reason that the exchange of personal data can only be implemented after the Member State gives a guarantee that it will comply with the general data protection provisions contained in the European texts. On 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Belgium had implemented all of these provisions. As cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism and big banditry, I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The exchange of such information should be a matter for the Member States concerned, not the whole of the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation aimed at deepening cross-border cooperation with Belgium, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to support Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on the exchange of personal data in Poland with a view to improving cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This is one of three proposals for an enforcement decision by the Council to allow Sweden, Belgium and Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision.
