In the context of this decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of personal data provided for by the decision can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general data protection provisions set out in this decision. On the basis of the general assessment report presented to it, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Sweden, Belgium and Poland had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. I voted in favour of this report, believing that Belgium meets the necessary conditions. Yes, Member States must cooperate to combat cross-border crime and terrorism!

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Through the 2007 Pmo Treaty, several EU states committed themselves in an intergovernmental framework to intensify data exchange in order to intensify cross-border cooperation and combat terrorism and international crime more effectively. These data exchanges involve fingerprints, vehicle registration numbers and DNA. Before participating in the exchange system, each country must pass data protection tests. Since Belgium has passed these tests, the Council therefore wishes that it can receive and transmit fingerprint data under the Treaty. I supported this point, as data exchange is an essential means of increasing security within the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision of the Council aims to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision. This transmission of personal data can only take place after the general data protection provisions set out in this decision have been implemented in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission. The Council concluded that Belgium had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. So I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mrs Flašíková Beňová's report is balanced and acceptable. If the EU is to vigorously combat international crime and terrorism, the first step is to facilitate the exchange of information between the police forces of the Member States. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be initiated only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. On 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Belgium fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, Belgium must be enabled to receive and transmit personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. That is why I voted in favour of this report necessary to give approval to the exchange of fingerprint data with Belgium.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported Parliament's decision on the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium. This Decision is part of the improvement of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Pursuant to Decision 2008/615/JHA, personal data may not be provided as provided for in that Decision until the general provisions on the protection of personal data laid down by that Decision have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States providing such data. Belgium has implemented these provisions and Belgium will soon have the right to receive and provide personal data for the purposes of automated dactyloscopic data.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposed Decision allows Belgium to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the rules on improving cross-border cooperation.  This is particularly important in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and this is all the more necessary in the light of the current migrant crisis. I was pleased to support the decision.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's three proposals for an enforcement decision to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit personal data. This decision enables, in particular, the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime by deepening cross-border cooperation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because Belgium has complied with all the conditions required by Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime and on the automated exchange of dactic data and, therefore, must be admitted to the programme.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision by the Commission is intended to facilitate the receipt and transmission of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. This measure should strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and the big banditry whose organizations are free of borders.  This transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of the general data protection provisions set out in the text. However, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Belgium had implemented all of these provisions. Considering that this type of cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the authorised exchange of data on fingerprint data in Belgium because cross-border cooperation is very beneficial for the protection of national legislation and helps both eradicate terrorism and strengthen the rule of law.  The Commission's decision implementing Decision 2008/615/JHA provides that the automatic exchange of data must be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a pilot test, a questionnaire prepared by the working group and an evaluation visit, this being done by the audit. Belgium has taken all the necessary steps; thus applied the data protection questionnaire and the fingerprint data exchange questionnaire and carried out a pilot test with France and Luxembourg which was conclusive.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The aim is to improve cross-border police cooperation between Member States. The authorities must be able to exchange police information quickly and efficiently in order to combat organised crime and terrorism effectively.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision to launch the automated exchange of dattiloscopic data in Belgium. We are talking about fingerprint images, handheld images, and models of such images that are stored and processed in an automated database. With today's vote, we are committed to strengthening cross-border cooperation between the police and judicial authorities of the countries of the European Union, with the aim of combating terrorism and cross-border crime more effectively. Belgium has successfully completed the questionnaires on automated data exchanges, also carrying out a pilot experience with France and Luxembourg and fully implementing the general data protection provisions set out in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA.  Therefore, in order to include Belgium in the system for receiving and transmitting this information and data, I voted in favour of the project.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which deals with the stepping up of cross-border cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. According to a previous decision personal data may not be supplied until general provisions on data protection have been implemented in national law. The Council now states that Belgium has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and can begin to receive and supply personal data under Decision 2008/615/JHA. This report is related to the implementation of the Prüm Decision, which I have consistently opposed, but these particular reports deal with the implementation of the data protection safeguards for fingerprint data exchange to occur. As I have always advocated for the implementation of adequate data protection safeguards for personal data exchange, I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the changes in the data protection provisions that have been introduced recently in Belgium, the national authorities should be allowed the exchange of dactyloscopic data with the relevant international authorities. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Belgium presents legislation on the protection of personal data which is considered to ensure that the provisions of Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation can be applied to the country. These are particularly important in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, and I therefore voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report refers to the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium. Having regard to the Council's draft and the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we approve the Council's draft and call on the Council, if it intends to derogate from the text adopted by Parliament, to update it. It also calls on Parliament to be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the text adopted by Parliament.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the measure. The worrying proliferation of organised criminal groups capable of operating on a cross-border basis together with the use of terrorism obliges the European institutions to step up cooperation in the fight against these criminal phenomena. The exchange of sensitive information and data between the authorities and security forces of the Member States is a key element in implementing an effective crime-fighting strategy. Since Belgium has put the general data protection provisions into practice, according to Decision 2008/615/JHA, it is considered necessary to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit fingerprint data.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Monika Flasikova Benova's report on the project to automate the exchange of dactic data in Belgium. I believe it is important to stick to what the European model for the exchange of information in the Group of Member States (EIXM) wants to be, and I think it is essential to implement the Prüm decision on strengthening cross-border cooperation.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Decision No 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation substantially incorporates the Treaty of Prüm into the Community legal order, maintaining the objective of stimulating greater cooperation between member states' security forces, in particular through greater exchange of information.  As I have said several times, this exchange of information is essential in the field of security, and it is a requirement for a result of greater mutual trust. Certain requirements must therefore be respected, in particular the principles of necessity and proportionality and respect for fundamental rights.  Therefore, in order to establish the automated exchange of type-scopic data, each Member State must ensure that data protection standards are implemented. This Council decision correctly authorises the initiation of the automated exchange, since Belgium has implemented it correctly.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The exchange of personal data in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crimes is one of the Objectives of the European Union. Belgium has implemented the general provisions on the protection of personal data in national law and is one of the signatory countries to the Prüm decision on police cooperation and the exchange of fingerprint information. This legislative act must be fully implemented as soon as possible, so as to facilitate and speed up the procedures for sending and receiving data between Member States.  The report is part of the European Information Exchange Model (EIXM) which provides for cross-border police and investigation cooperation, while protecting the fundamental rights of European citizens. I agree with the adoption of this report, in order to effectively strengthen cross-border cooperation.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ One aim of the European Union is to provide its citizens with high levels of freedom as well as security and justice for crimes. To do so Member States must be interconnected, achieved through the creation of a national database for cross-border checks on people from DNA and dactyloscopic data (fingerprinting). This report states that the Member State of Belgium has meet the Directive’s criteria established for implementation of automatic data exchange. I voted for this report that will allow the Member State of Belgium to receive and supply such above discussed data to fight terrorism and other such crimes.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to implement this Council Decision aims to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit personal data under Council Decision 2008/615/JHA from the date of entry into force of the Decision. According to the Commission, the provision of personal data under that decision cannot take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States concerned by the transmission. On the basis of a general evaluation report, the Council concluded that the three countries mentioned above have fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Council Decision 2008/615/JHA. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Belgium has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the Council's implementing decision, the European Parliament is merely in a consultation procedure. Parliament's LIBE committee approved the draft decision without propositioning an amendment, which was then submitted to Parliament's plenary. I voted in favour of the text. The aim of the report is to introduce automated data exchange in Belgium. The exchange of data may be introduced only if the country fulfils the conditions. Belgium has complied, inter alia, with the questionnaire on data protection and fingerprint exchange. This means that Belgium may send and receive personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/IB. The draft plays an important role in strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Council draft. This is a technical consultation procedure on the implementation of the Prüm Decision on exchanging fingerprints data by Belgium. Belgium had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of this decision.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to support the Council's draft decision on the launch of automated fingerprint data exchange in Belgium. The transmission of personal data under EU law can only take place after the general data protection provisions have been implemented in national law. Considering that Belgium has met the conditions for the exchange of such data, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this text on the automated exchange of data relating to fingerprint data in Belgium. Facilitating this exchange of data on fingerprint data, i.e. fingerprints, in full compliance with data protection rules, enhances the security of European citizens.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 As regards the fight against terrorism and organised crime, cross-border cooperation and the necessary database are an essential element in dealing with them. I welcome the Council's report recognising that Belgium has complied with all requirements as regards the protection of personal data, in particular fingerprint data.  I approve of Belgium's accession to the cooperation system and believe that this is an important step for the security of the Union, especially in a situation like the current one where the EU faces one of its biggest security challenges since its inception.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met), of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Belgium succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, is one of the most important issues to prevent terrorist acts against EU citizens. The exchange of information between countries is a crucial factor in minimizing these attacks. However, data sharing should be done in line with the agreement of the different countries. In this report, these aspects are properly safeguarded and therefore i am approved.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it is in line with efficiency in the fight against crime and terrorism, while giving states the protection of personal data.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision No 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime, the provision of personal data cannot take place until the general data protection provisions have been transposed into national law within the territory of the Member States concerned. The Council proposals aim to allow Poland, Belgium and Sweden to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the above-mentioned decision. These three reports relate to the Prüm Convention which was signed in May 2005 in Prüm (Germany) between seven Member States: Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands. It has been criticised for being negotiated and adopted in a very untransparent manner and without being subject to effective democratic scrutiny. The objective of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities, contributing to the possibility of comparing, for example, a particular DNA profile with profiles recorded in existing automated databases in the Member States. Our vote is inseparable from the more general consideration we make of the so-called fight against terrorism and the role it has been taking on the EU.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As a compromise between the two angles, I again abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this is a purely technical consultation procedure for the implementation of the so-called Prüm Decision in the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium. On the basis of the overall evaluation report presented to the Council, the Council decided that Belgium fulfilled all the conditions on 13 July 2015 and implemented the general data protection provisions as set out in Chapter 6 of the Decision.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report for a better exchange of data and information.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met) of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Belgium succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful. For these reasons I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the need to step up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and to strengthen cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approved the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium. The supply of personal data may not take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States involved. The verification that this condition has been met with respect to automated data exchange is done on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot run. Belgium has completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on dactyloscopic data exchange. A successful pilot run has been carried out by Belgium with Austria.  On 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Belgium had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore, for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic data, Belgium should be entitled to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Automated exchange of dactyloscopic data with Belgium', as I support the approach. In order to guarantee security in a borderless Europe, we also need efficient, cross-border cooperation between security authorities and the effective exchange of data.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is desirable and important to step up EU cooperation to protect citizens. In an emergency, data necessary for the efficient investigation of criminal offences can be provided more quickly.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves exchanging fingerprint data.  I voted against for obvious reasons.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report to increase cross-border cooperation in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The exchange of dactyloscopic or fingerprint data is important for the purposes of criminal identification, registration, and investigation. Following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this report, which aims to promote the cross-border exchange of fingerprint information from Belgium and thus improve cooperation between the police services of the Member States in order to better combat terrorism and organised crime, in accordance with European data protection standards.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside other S&D MEPs, voted in favour of this report. This report is purely technical and is a simple approval of an evaluation report in which it is concluded that Belgium has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of the Prüm Decision.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted for the Automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium because I believe it will help step up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it helps the facilitation of exchange of such data for the fight against terrorism and cross—border crimes.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament approved by a large majority the decision on the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium.  In short, the aim is to allow the Belgian authorities to receive and transfer personal data, in this case fingerprints, to other Member States in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. In the current context of strong terrorist threats to European states, the exchange of information between the relevant authorities is a necessary measure of threat prevention and is an essential condition for the identification of radicalised and extremist individuals.  Today, we cannot do without these instruments to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, which are the new scourges of the 21st century. That is why I strongly supported this decision.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a Council decision on the introduction of automated data exchange in Sweden, Belgium and Poland, as this will achieve better synergy with regard to the exchange of information.  I am convinced of this because I believe that the exchange of information and cooperation are just as important as data collection and possible measures to improve data exchange must be supported in full respect of existing provisions and case law with regard to the protection of personal data.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision to launch an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium, because this type of exchange encourages more effective prevention and consistent investigation of crimes, thereby insegorates internal and international security.  It is of utmost importance that this improves cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. As regards more serious and major problems at EU level, unity and synergies between Member States are essential to ensure security and stability, and for this reason I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision of the Commission facilitates the transmission and receipt of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. This decision aims to strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and big banditry.  This exchange of personal data can only be implemented after complying with the general data protection provisions stipulated in the text. However, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Belgium had implemented all of these provisions. As cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and my fellow UKIP MEPs reject the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will enable Belgium to receive and transmit personal information in the context of cross-border cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report. Automated data exchange of dactyloscopic data is absolutely in favour of crime prevention and counter-terrorism. Such data exchange enables national security authorities to intervene in good time, thereby increasing citizens' general sense of security.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it aims to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. Also, following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Beňová's work on the automated exchange of dactic data in Belgium. Datyloscopic investigation is an activity whose purpose concerns personal identification and it can be counted among the most effective tools in the field of criminality. This report therefore aims to strengthen cross-border cooperation between the police and the judicial sector in the Member States.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. As in the case of Sweden, the aim is to allow Belgium to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision. As Belgium meets the necessary conditions according to the Council, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it extends to Belgium cooperation in the transmission of personal data to combat terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Belgium has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of the report is to initiate an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium. Due to more advanced and improved cross-border cooperation, in particular to expose terrorism and cross-border crime, in July 2015 the Council authorised Belgium to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA.  I supported mp Monica Flašíkova Beňova's report, as dactyloscopy is the most modern and safe method of establishing a person's identity and automated exchange of dactyloscopic data is a condition for a safer society. Dactyloscopy was introduced in Croatia in 1904 in Zagreb for the purpose of identification of persons.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report during the review of this report and the relevant vote in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. I did the same today because I believe that the exchange of dactyloscopic data is an important measure to promote the security of Europeans. Stepping up cross-border cooperation between the law enforcement authorities of the European Union and its Member States is absolutely necessary, especially at a time when there is a possibility that radicalism and terrorist methods may also enter the territory of the European Union with genuine refugees from the Middle East. As Belgium is one of the most popular destinations for irregular migrants, such a danger cannot be ignored. Although we must surely help the sufferers, first of all we need to think directly about the security of our common house, because otherwise it will no longer be safe for the people of our countries or for the same asylum seekers.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium will strengthen international police cooperation in the fight against terrorism, international crime and illegal immigration. The adoption of the implementing regulation is urgent precisely at a time of difficult security, when the countries of the Union are subject to an onslaught of enormous numbers of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this proposal. As in the previous case, that of Sweden, an evaluation report proves that Belgium has indeed put in place the general data protection provisions. We therefore accept that the exchange is in place.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Decision 2008/615/JHA aims to strengthen cross-border cooperation between the police and judicial authorities of EU countries to combat terrorism and cross-border crime more effectively, with particular reference to the automated exchange of information, in the context of important events and in the fight against terrorism, as well as other forms of cross-border police cooperation. Belgium has fully implemented the data protection provisions to which this decision refers. For these reasons, I am in favour of my colleague's report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes the fight against terrorism and crime prevention. Automated exchange will simplify the prosecution of criminals. I therefore supported the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim is to allow Belgium to receive and transmit personal data (DNA profile, fingerprints and vehicle registration) from its police files with those of other Member States. While the legislation contains an issue on data protection and the limits of its use, the flaws in these laws are known. The CNIL was also concerned about this legislation. Above all, this dossier is part of a general trend of registering offenders as well as European citizens or migrants. These files are then cross-referenced, against the very provisions of European law, to determine profiles of each citizen. A so-called big brother to fight terrorism, an argument that Snowden has largely demonstrated as ineffective. It is mainly a way of increasing the amount of data on citizens to make it available to the United States or even more recently to German intelligence services.  I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly with regard to the fight against terrorism and organised crime, I have presented my vote in agreement with the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of type-only data in Belgium. Cross-border data comparison reflects a new dimension in the fight against crime. Information obtained through data comparison plays a crucial role in supporting the judicial and law enforcement authorities of the Member States.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which allows Belgium to both provide and receive dactyloscopic data for use in criminal investigations, as Belgium has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Parliament duly consulted the Council on the report on the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium and approved the proposal in the light of its 2013 resolution on strengthening cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU. For these reasons, I support the adoption of the proposal and join the Council's call for parliament to be notified if it intends to depart from the approved text.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium, which is a purely technical consultation procedure on the implementation of the so-called Prüm Decision on exchanging fingerprint data by Belgium.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A vote adding Belgium to the legal architecture of Europe allowing the fighting of terrorism and organised crime while fully respecting human rights and the rule of law.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Council Decision 2008/615/IB on strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the provision of personal data provided for in this Decision shall not take place until the Member States concerned have introduced general data protection provisions through the national legislation in force in their territory.  On 13 July 2015, on the basis of the report submitted to it, the Council concluded that the belgian legislation in force complied in all respects with the general data protection provisions of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/IB. The Council therefore intends to empower Belgium by decision to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/IB. The Council should consult the European Parliament before adopting the Decision in accordance with Article 39(1) of the Treaty on European Union, as amended by the Treaty of Amsterdam and Article 9 of Protocol 36 on transitional arrangements. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended the Council's draft to Parliament for approval. I supported the Council's draft decision accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime depends on efficient and close cooperation between Member States. The transmission of personal data under Decision No 2008/615/JAI may be carried out only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that Decision have been incorporated into the national legislation of the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission.  The verification of compliance with this condition relating to the automated exchange of data shall be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report which, in turn, is based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. In view of the time that Belgium has fulfilled the requirements of Decision No 2008/615/JAI and has successfully carried out a pilot test with France and Luxembourg, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. As in the case of Sweden, the aim is to allow Belgium to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision. As Belgium meets the necessary conditions according to the Council, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which relates to an old Council decision to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The exchange of dactyloscopic data refers to the study of fingerprints for the purposes of criminal identification, registration and investigation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Council's plan to allow Belgium to receive and transmit fingerprint data. The aim is to improve the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime in the European Union by promoting cooperation between Member States. This authorization comes after the Commission verifies that all data protection conditions are met.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will implement the Council’s decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it can bring significant progress in the area of crime prevention and counter-terrorism. Essentially, it is about the exchange of fingerprints. If we look at the current influx of refugees, which is already affecting the whole of Europe, progress can also be expected in the area of combating the abuse of asylum.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report proposes to approve Belgium's participation in the Prum scheme. The Treaty of Prem was signed in 2005 with the aim of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, allowing signatory states to exchange personal data, genetic or digital, on an individual suspected of intending homicides. The Council's 2008/615/JAI and 2008/616/JAI directives provide that a country's participation in this scheme should be conditioned by a transposition of measures dealing with the protection of personal data into national legislation. While I am aware of the stakes and the need for concrete action to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, I am not convinced that such a mechanism can effectively combat this without endangering the right to privacy, so I abstain.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to step up the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In Belgium the terrorist threat manifested its physical presence on the territory when, last winter, the action of a jihadist cell was blocked by law enforcement. Regularisation of the exchange of typoscopic data is clearly a priority, which is why I have no hesitation in voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. I hold the exchange of dactyloscopic data crucial in strengthening security throughout the European Union. I believe that the dactyloscopic data available in national fingerprint databases should be available to all Member States of the European Union for inspection and search, and that continuous exchange of dactyloscopic data should be carried out between countries. This could avoid lengthy investigations and searches for the perpetrators of certain crimes.  Such an exchange can certainly contribute to the successful detection and prevention of organised crime that is more and more present in Europe and terrorism, which has unfortunately become a global threat today. As a member of the European Union, the Kingdom of Belgium sees this security exchange of data as useful and considers that it should be organised at the necessary high level in order to effectively strengthen security and prevent organised crime. For all of the above, I support this Decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. As in the case of Sweden, the aim is to allow Belgium to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision. As Belgium meets the necessary conditions according to the Council, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The fight against terrorism and cross-border crime are important elements of interstate cooperation within the EU, and I believe that in this light the exchange and availability of personal data, in this case dactyloscopic, i.e. fingerprints, should be seen. However, it is also important to demand that such cross-border cooperation take place only on condition that the national laws of the countries involved have fully implemented rules on the protection of personal data. As these conditions in Belgium have been met, I support this draft.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the report to initiate automatic data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data (fingerprints) in Belgium, in line with the decision to intensify cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime and the supply of personal data provided for in this decision. Effective international cooperation in the field of counter-terrorism and cross-border crime aims at effective international cooperation, which is fundamental in order to replace precise information quickly and efficiently.  Furthermore, it is aimed at introducing procedures to promote a fast, efficient and inexpensive way of exchanging data. For data sharing, these procedures should be subject to liability and adequate assurance as to the accuracy and security of data during transmission and storage, as well as procedures for recording and exchanging data restrictions on the use of information.  Belgium completed a data protection questionnaire and a dactyloscopic data exchange questionnaire. Successful pilot ride was carried out by Belgium with France and Luxembourg. On the basis of the overall evaluation report, on 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that the general data protection provisions had been fully implemented in Belgium.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automated exchange of dactic data is intended to intensify the exchange of information between Eu ropean Union Member States on fingerprints and genetic data (DNA). The aim is to enable an individual's DNA profile to be compared with profiles in member states' automated databases by making links between this personal data through national contact points used in the fight against domestic and international terrorism. I am voting in favour of the Council's decision to authorise Belgium to carry out the automated exchange of dactic data, aimed at preventing terrorist, crime and illegal immigration offences.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to improve the fight against terrorism and organised crime within the Union, I voted in favour of the report on the exchange of data on fingerprint data in Belgium. This text is important because it facilitates the transfer of sometimes key data to ensure greater protection for European citizens.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of understanding that cooperation and the exchange of information are decisive factors in strengthening the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be initiated only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. On 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Belgium fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, Belgium must be enabled to receive and transmit personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. That is why I voted in favour of this report necessary to give approval to the exchange of fingerprint data with Belgium.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Council's plan to launch the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Belgium. Such systematization of trade and strengthening cross-border cooperation will be useful in law enforcement and counter-terrorism.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bearing in mind the existing agreements on cross-border cooperation, counter-terrorism, cross-border crime and law enforcement in the EU – of which the implementation of the 'Prüm Decision' and the European Model for Information Exchange are good examples – this legislative motion for a legislative resolution is anator to promote the automated exchange of fingerprint data (fingerprints) with Belgium. As with the report on Sweden and Poland on the same subject, it was found that Belgium responded positively to the questionnaires on data protection and the exchange of datyloscopic data, and also successfully completed the pilot experience with France and Luxembourg on this exchange, so there are no reasons for the adoption of this report. , of an eminently technical nature, so I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the Council's draft implementation decision on the launch of the automated data exchange on fingerprint data in Belgium. The Council's proposed implementation decision aims to allow Belgium to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Council's decision to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit fingerprint data in order to counter the emergence of cells and terrorist activities on national territory. One of the fundamental tasks of the European Union is to ensure the safety of European citizens.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Belgium has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I do not wish to see UK citizens’ fingerprint data shared with foreign nations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Belgium has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of the Prüm decision, and so I voted in favour of this principally technical consultation procedure on the exchange of fingerprint data by Belgium.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Cooperation in the exchange of information on dactyloscopic data is also an important step in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Belgium has fully implemented the general conditions on data protection and can therefore be integrated into the exchange of dactyloscopic data.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, regarding cross-border exchange of dactyloscopic data (the study of fingerprints for the purposes of criminal identification, registration and investigation) in an attempt to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. Following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ International exchange of dactyloscopic data is the key to fighting cross-border crime. The aim of this draft Implementation Decision of the Council is to initiate an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium. The ultimate objective is to support Belgium in the fight against cross-border crime and to step up cooperation in law enforcement in the EU. Decisions referred to in Article 25(2) of the Code of Art Decisions 2008/615/PUP are taken on the basis of a questionnaire-based assessment report. The questionnaire drawn up by the relevant Council working group concerns any automated data exchange and must be completed by the Member State, thus considering that it meets the requirements for data sharing in the relevant data category.  Also taking into account the application of the Prüm Decision and the European Information Exchange Model, I support this draft Council with a view to launching an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium. In my view, the launch of automated dactyloscopic data exchange in Belgium can significantly contribute to deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in countering terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the United Kingdom did not participate in the original Council Decision with regard to automated exchange of dactyloscopic data, and is therefore not taking part in the adoption of this Decision, I abstained on this report.  While I support the objectives of the Decision, which are to have more Member States cooperating in the fight against serious crime and terrorism, the provisions on the exchange of DNA and fingerprint material relate closely to many of the elements of the Prüm Treaty which the UK has not yet implemented.  Under the Prüm Treaty, a Member State can ask another state to check key personal data (and car registrations) against their database as part of a criminal investigation. I have significant concerns regarding certain civil liberties and data protection elements, and the cost implications related to its implementation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. – The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met), of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Belgium has succeeded in evaluating and submitting the data protection assessment questionnaire.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of the Schengen Convention was one of the main achievements of the European integration process. Ensuring free movement at European Union level, including with regard to the citizens of the Member States, is a definite win. However, the application of the provisions of the Convention on the movement of persons, including citizens of third countries, may pose a number of problems to ensure European security. This is why it is necessary to take preventive measures, including the fingerprinting and exchange of such data between Member States. The application of that measure must respect the rights and freedoms of citizens underlying the European construction. The acceptance of Belgium among the Member States which have adopted these measures is likely to contribute to strengthening European security. This, all the more so since Belgium is hosting the main European institutions, contributing crucially to the smooth running of our work as Members of the European Parliament. For these reasons, I believe that the adoption of the current document is imperative and constitutes a step forward in order to strengthen European security.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted on the Council's proposed implementation decision on the launch of the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data, following the informed advice of the political group.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the case of Sweden, I also supported this report on the launching of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium, authorising it to receive and supply personal data. This act follows Council Decision 2008/615/JHA, which incorporates the substance of the so called ʽPrüm Treatyʼ. The initiative between Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Spain, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Austria, Slovenia, Slovakia, Italy, Finland, Portugal, Romania and Sweden focuses on stepping up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal migration. In order to strengthen freedom, security and justice, it recommends making full use of new technologies and enabling reciprocal access to national databases.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Belgium because this will allow Belgium to receive and send information on the deepening of cross-border cooperation, particularly in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, which will ensure greater security for EU citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision of the Council aims to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit personal data. In the context of this decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of personal data provided for by the decision can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general data protection provisions set out in this decision. On the basis of the general assessment report presented to it, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Belgium had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. I voted for this text

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime and strengthen cross-border cooperation.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament refers to the draft decision implementing the Council on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to fingerprint data in Belgium.  Automated access to fingerprint data (palm prints, latent fingerprints, etc.) is regulated in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on enhancing cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The aim of this decision is to accelerate cross-border police and judicial cooperation between European Union countries in criminal matters by improving the exchange of information between authorities responsible for preventing and investigating criminal offences. The launch of automated data exchange with regard to fingerprint data may be carried out only after the general provisions on the protection of personal data have been implemented in the national legislation of the Member States. Verification of compliance with this condition shall be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. These criteria were successfully met by Belgium, therefore the Council gave a favourable opinion to Belgium to receive and provide personal data for the purpose of automated search for fingerprint data.  Through the legislative resolution, Parliament approved this Council decision.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the three reports on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden, Poland and Belgium. This time, Parliament is at last being properly consulted on the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data. The Green Group had insisted already in 2008 on the inclusion of data protection standards in the decision and proper consultation with Parliament. Now we can formally agree to automated data exchange.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Belgium because I believe it is important to strengthen cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and to work on strengthening cross-border law enforcement cooperation in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA on the intensification of cross-border cooperation, in particular with regard to the fight against terrorism and organized crime, the provision of personal data (including fingerprints) should not be carried out until the general data protection provisions have not been implemented in the legislation of the Member States concerned.  On the basis of a general assessment report submitted to the Council, the Council concluded that the Member State had implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore authorises it to receive and provide fingerprints in accordance with this Decision. For all the above, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Belgium responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Belgium has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2008, the European Commission presented a proposal for the establishment of the 'Eurodac' system for the purpose of the effective implementation of the Dublin Convention. This proposal is currently part of the Asylum package.  Eurodac is a common processing of personal data, used since 15 January 2003, and includes an automatic fingerprint recognition system. The purpose of this processing is to determine the Member State which, under the Dublin Convention, is responsible for the examination of an application for asylum lodged in one of the EU States. This draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of type-scopic data is part of this logic.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes the fight against terrorism and crime prevention. Automated exchange will simplify the prosecution of criminals. I therefore supported the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I repeat that I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision on the launch, this time in Belgium, of the automated exchange of dacticoscopic data, because I am convinced of the need for joint action in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, which operate at European level. I would also like to stress that, however, the exchange of data must take place with full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of this report. The ECR supports the accession of Sweden, Poland and Belgium to the automated exchange system of dactyloscopic data. Poland, Belgium and Sweden have completed the data protection and dactyloscopic (i.e. fingerprint) data exchange questionnaire and carried out successful pilot projects. On the basis of a comprehensive evaluation report, the Council decided on 13 July 2015 that these Member States had fully implemented the general data protection rules. I support my group's position on this issue and have accordingly voted in favour of this report.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision No 2008/615 / JAI on the deepening of cross-border cooperation, the fight against terrorism and crime, the provision of personal data provided for in the context of that decision cannot take place until the general data protection provisions have been transposed into national law. The Council proposal aims to authorise Belgium to receive and transmit personal data pursuant to Council Decision No 2008/615 /JAI from the date of its entry into force. These three reports relate to the Prüm Convention, which was signed on 27 May 2005 in Prüm (Germany) between seven Member States - Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands. The objective of the Prüm Decision is thus to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities, contributing to this, for example, the possibility of comparing, for example, a particular DNA profile with profiles recorded in existing automated databases in the Member States. We know that, on the pretext of combating terrorism and crime, the EU has been putting together a surveillance system that safeguards the freedoms and guarantees of individuals. This measure goes in similar logic from what we voted against.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Poland responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Poland has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to allow the automated exchange of personal data in Poland. In the context of terrorism and in the context of combating cross-border crime, deepening cooperation between states must be a priority. The decisions drawn up in this report are in this direction, thus allowing Sweden to transmit the data, as the Council has approved the implementation of the general data protection provisions.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this proposed enforcement decision by the Commission is to facilitate the transmission and receipt of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. It strengthens cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and big banditry.  In the case of a decision affecting individual freedoms, strict control over the use of this data is essential. It is precisely for this reason that the exchange of personal data can only be implemented after the Member State gives a guarantee that it will comply with the general data protection provisions contained in the European texts. On 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Poland had implemented all of these provisions. As cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism and big banditry, I voted for this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The exchange of such information should be a matter for the Member States concerned, not the whole of the European Union.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation aimed at deepening cross-border cooperation with Poland, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal to support Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on the exchange of personal data in Poland with a view to improving cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This is one of three proposals for an enforcement decision by the Council to allow Sweden, Belgium and Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision. In the context of this decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of personal data provided for by the decision can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general data protection provisions set out in this decision. On the basis of the general assessment report presented to it, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Sweden, Belgium and Poland had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. I voted in favour of this report, saying that Poland was in place to meet the necessary conditions. Yes, Member States must cooperate to combat cross-border crime and terrorism!

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Through the 2007 Pmo Treaty, several EU states committed themselves in an intergovernmental framework to intensify data exchange in order to intensify cross-border cooperation and combat terrorism and international crime more effectively. These data exchanges involve fingerprints, vehicle registration numbers and DNA. Before participating in the exchange system, each country must pass data protection tests. As Poland has passed these tests, the Council therefore wishes that it can receive and transmit fingerprint data within the framework of the treaty. I supported this point, as data exchange is an essential means of increasing security within the Union,

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Like Sweden, Poland met all the conditions to be able to transmit and receive personal data in order to cooperate closely with other Member States in the fight against terrorism and crime.  As Poland therefore fell within the legal framework of the 2008/615/JAI enforcement decision, it seemed to me quite legitimate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report by Mr Beazley on be it is a good one. Flašíková Beňová is balanced and shareable. If the EU is to vigorously combat international crime and terrorism, the first step is to facilitate the exchange of information between the police forces of the Member States. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be initiated only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. On 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Poland fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, Poland should be enabled to receive and transmit personal data under Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. That is why I voted favourably on this report necessary to give approval to the exchange of fingerprint data with Poland.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported parliament's decision on the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland. This Decision is part of the improvement of cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime. Pursuant to Decision 2008/615/JHA, personal data may not be provided as provided for in that Decision until the general provisions on the protection of personal data laid down by that Decision have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States providing such data. Poland has implemented these provisions and Poland will soon have the right to receive and provide personal data for the purposes of automated dactyloscopic data.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The purpose of the proposed decision is to allow Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the rules on improving cross-border cooperation.  This is particularly important in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and this is all the more necessary in the light of the current migrant crisis.  As I believe that the safety of citizens must be guaranteed as much as possible, I supported the proposed decision.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's three proposals for an enforcement decision to allow Poland to receive and transmit personal data. This decision enables, in particular, the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime by deepening cross-border cooperation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because Poland has complied with all the conditions required by Decision 2008/615/JHA on strengthening cross-border cooperation, especially in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime and on the automated exchange of dacticoscopic data and, therefore, must be admitted to the programme.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision by the Commission is intended to facilitate the receipt and transmission of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. This measure should strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and the big banditry whose organizations are free of borders.  This transmission of personal data can only take place after the implementation of the general data protection provisions set out in the text. However, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Poland had implemented all of these provisions. Considering that this type of cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the authorised exchange of data with regard to fingerprint data in Poland, because I believe that cross-border issues are stipulated such as cooperation to protect the Member States of the European Union, to protect the rule of law, but also to eradicate terrorism and transnational crime in the Member States.
