The Commission's decision implementing Decision 2008/615/JHA provides that the automatic exchange of data must be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a pilot test, a questionnaire prepared by the working group and an evaluation visit, this being done by the audit. Poland has taken all necessary steps; thus applied the data protection questionnaire and the fingerprint data exchange questionnaire and carried out a pilot test with Austria which was conclusive.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The aim is to improve cross-border police cooperation between Member States. The authorities must be able to exchange police information quickly and efficiently in order to combat organised crime and terrorism effectively.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the draft Council implementing decision to initiate the automated exchange of dactic data in Poland, such as fingerprint images, handhelds, and models of such images that are stored and processed in an automated database. The automated exchange of information between the inspection and judicial bodies of European states appears to be essential in order to strengthen cross-border cooperation between the police and judicial authorities of the countries of the European Union and thus to combat terrorism and cross-border crime more effectively. Poland has successfully completed the questionnaires on automated data exchanges, also carrying out a pilot experience with Austria, fully implementing the general data protection provisions set out in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA.  Therefore, in order to include Poland in the system for receiving and transmitting this information and data, I voted in favour of the project.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which deals with the stepping up of cross-border cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. According to a previous decision, personal data may not be supplied until general provisions on data protection have been implemented in national law. The Council now states that Poland has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and can begin to receive and supply personal data under Decision 2008/615/JHA. This report is related to the implementation of the Prüm Decision, which I have consistently opposed, but these particular reports deal with the implementation of the data protection safeguards for fingerprint data exchange to occur. As I have always advocated for the implementation of adequate data protection safeguards for personal data exchange, I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ As Poland has successfully incorporated the general provisions on data protection into its national law, its authorities should be permitted to exchange dactyloscopic data internationally in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime more successfully. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Poland's legislation, such as that of Sweden and Belgium, was also deemed suitable for the application of the provisions of Council Decision 2008/615/JHA strengthening cross-border cooperation on the automated exchange of dacticoscopic data. This is an important cooperation measure, particularly in the fight against cross-border crime and terrorism. I therefore certainly voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report refers to the draft Council Implementing Decision on the launch of the automated exchange of typoscopic data in Poland. Having regard to the Council's draft and the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, we approve the Council's draft and call on the Council, if it intends to derogate from the text adopted by Parliament, to update it. It also calls on Parliament to be consulted again if the Council intends to make significant amendments to the text adopted by Parliament.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of the measure. The worrying proliferation of organised criminal groups capable of operating on a cross-border basis together with the use of terrorism obliges the European institutions to step up cooperation in the fight against these criminal phenomena. The exchange of sensitive information and data between the authorities and security forces of the Member States is a key element in implementing an effective crime-fighting strategy. Since Poland has put the general data protection provisions into practice, according to Decision 2008/615/JHA, poland is deemed to be obliged to be authorised to receive and transmit fingerprint data.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Monika Flašíková Beňová's report on authorisation for the exchange of dactic data in Poland because I believe very much in cooperation within the EU and between Member States. Only by constantly updating the details of each state can healthy and clean growth for the whole Of the European Union be promoted. For this reason, and also in the fight against terrorist actions and other fraud, I think it is important to exchange data.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU states have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that INTERPOL and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Decision No 2008/615/JAI on deepening cross-border cooperation substantially incorporates the Treaty of Prüm into the Community legal order, maintaining the objective of stimulating greater cooperation between member states' security forces, in particular through greater exchange of information.  As I have said several times, this exchange of information is essential in the field of security, and it is a requirement for a result of greater mutual trust. Certain requirements must therefore be respected, in particular the principles of necessity and proportionality and respect for fundamental rights.  Therefore, in order to establish the automated exchange of type-scopic data, each Member State must ensure that data protection standards are implemented. This Council decision correctly authorises the initiation of the automated exchange, since Poland has implemented it correctly.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU states have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that INTERPOL and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the report on the start of automated data exchange in Poland. The sending and receiving of data between Member States in order to combat terrorist crimes and cross-border crimes must be strengthened, so as to facilitate a rapid and effective exchange of information.  Poland has implemented the provisions on the protection of personal data in national law and therefore the Council proposes to authorise Poland to send and receive data, promoting cooperation between the police and investigative forces of the countries of the Union. This action is part of the European Information Exchange Model (EIXM), the aim of which is to promote cooperation in the field of security and protection of EU citizens.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ One aim of the European Union is to provide its citizens with high levels of freedom as well as security and justice for crimes. To do this, Member States must be interconnected, [and this may be] achieved through the creation of a national database for cross-border checks of people from DNA and dactyloscopic data (fingerprinting). This report states that the Member State of Poland has met the directive’s criteria established for implementation of an automatic data exchange. I have voted for this report that will allow the Member State of Poland to receive and supply such above discussed data to fight against terrorism and other such crimes.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal to implement this Council Decision aims to authorise Poland to receive and transmit personal data under Council Decision 2008/615/JHA, from the date of entry into force of the Decision. According to the Commission, the provision of personal data under that decision cannot take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States concerned by the transmission. On the basis of a general evaluation report, the Council concluded that the three countries mentioned above have fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Council Decision 2008/615/JHA. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Poland responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Poland has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the Council's implementing decision, the European Parliament is merely in a consultation procedure. Parliament's LIBE committee approved the draft decision without propositioning an amendment, which was then submitted to Parliament's plenary. I voted in favour of the text. The aim of the report is to introduce automated data exchange in Poland. The exchange of data may be introduced only if the country fulfils the conditions. Poland has complied, inter alia, by completing the questionnaire on data protection and fingerprint exchange. This means that Poland may send and receive personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/IB. The draft plays an important role in strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Council draft. This is a technical consultation procedure on the implementation of the Prum Decision on exchanging fingerprints data by Poland. Poland had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of this decision.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to support the Council's draft decision on the launch of automated fingerprint data exchange in Poland. The transmission of personal data under EU law can only take place after the general data protection provisions have been implemented in national law. Considering that Poland has met the conditions for the exchange of such data, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The adoption of this text allows the launch of the automated exchange of data relating to fingerprint data, i.e. fingerprints, in Poland. The secure exchange of this data in Europe is one of the necessary tools for the fight against terrorism in Europe. That is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 As regards the fight against terrorism and organised crime, cross-border cooperation and the necessary database are an essential element in dealing with them. I welcome the Council's report recognising that Poland has complied with all requirements as regards the protection of personal data, in particular fingerprint data.  I approve of Poland's accession to the cooperation system and believe that this is an important step for the security of the Union, especially in a situation like the current one where the EU faces one of its biggest security challenges since its inception.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met), of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Poland succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, is one of the most important issues to prevent terrorist acts against EU citizens. The exchange of information between countries is a crucial factor in minimizing these attacks. However, data sharing should be done in line with the agreement of the different countries. In this report, these aspects are properly safeguarded and therefore i am approved.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it is in line with efficiency in the fight against crime and terrorism, while giving states the protection of personal data.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision No 2008/615/JAI on the deepening of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and crime, the provision of personal data cannot take place until the general data protection provisions have been transposed into national law within the territory of the Member States concerned. The Council proposals aim to allow Poland, Belgium and Sweden to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the above-mentioned decision. These three reports relate to the Prüm Convention which was signed in May 2005 in Prüm (Germany) between seven Member States: Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands. It has been criticised for being negotiated and adopted in a very untransparent manner and without being subject to effective democratic scrutiny. The objective of the Prüm Decision is to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities, contributing to the possibility of comparing, for example, a particular DNA profile with profiles recorded in existing automated databases in the Member States. Our vote is inseparable from the more general consideration we make of the so-called fight against terrorism and the role it has been taking on the EU.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As a compromise between the two angles, I again abstained.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing \ u2012 it is a purely technical consultation procedure in the implementation of the so-called Prüm Decision in the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland. On the basis of the overall evaluation report presented to the Council, the Council decided that Poland fulfilled all the conditions on 13 July 2015 and implemented the general data protection provisions as set out in Chapter 6 of the Decision.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report for a better exchange of data and information.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met) of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Poland succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful. For these reasons I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the need to step up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and to strengthen cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ With today’s vote we approved the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland. The supply of personal data may not take place until the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national law of the territories of the Member States involved. The verification that this condition has been met with respect to automated data exchange is done on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot run. Poland has completed the questionnaire on data protection and the questionnaire on dactyloscopic data exchange. A successful pilot run has been carried out by Poland with Austria.  On 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Poland had fully implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore, for the purposes of automated searching of dactyloscopic data, Poland should be entitled to receive and supply personal data pursuant to Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Automated exchange of dactyloscopic data with Poland', as I support the approach. In order to guarantee security in a borderless Europe, we also need efficient, cross-border cooperation between security authorities and the effective exchange of data.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is desirable and important to step up EU cooperation to protect citizens. In an emergency, data necessary for the efficient investigation of criminal offences can be provided more quickly.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This involves exchanging fingerprint data.  I voted against for obvious reasons.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report to increase cross-border cooperation in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The exchange of dactyloscopic or fingerprint data is important for the purposes of criminal identification, registration, and investigation. Following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted today in favour of this report, which aims to promote the cross-border exchange of fingerprint information from Poland and thus improve cooperation between Member States' police services so that they can better combat terrorism and organised crime, in accordance with European data protection standards.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside other S&D MEPs, voted in favour of this report. This report is purely technical and is a simple approval of an evaluation report in which it is concluded that Poland has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection set out in Chapter 6 of the Prüm Decision.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland because I believe it will help step up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it helps the facilitation of exchange of such data for the fight against terrorism and cross—border crimes.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament approved by a large majority the decision on the automated exchange of fingerprint data in Poland.  In short, the aim is to allow the Polish authorities to receive and transfer personal data, in this case fingerprints, to other Member States in the context of cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. In the current context of strong terrorist threats to European states, the exchange of information between the relevant authorities is a necessary measure of threat prevention and is an essential condition for the identification of radicalised and extremist individuals.  Today, we cannot do without these instruments to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, which are the new scourges of the 21st century. That is why I have been a strong backer of this decision.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's draft implementing decision to launch an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland, because member states' synergies in this area contribute to the international fight against terrorism, the strengthening of cross-border police cooperation and stability.  In addition, cooperation in the fight against cross-border crime is encouraged and internal and international security is strengthened. Unity and synergies between Member States are necessary to achieve such a thing for the benefit of all Union citizens, and I therefore believe that this type of automated exchange is particularly important for national and EU authorities operating in the area concerned.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed enforcement decision of the Commission facilitates the transmission and receipt of personal data in accordance with decision 2008/615/JAI. This decision aims to strengthen cross-border cooperation in order to combat terrorism and big banditry.  This exchange of personal data can only be implemented after complying with the general data protection provisions stipulated in the text. However, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Poland had implemented all of these provisions. As cross-border cooperation is a necessity in the fight against terrorism, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and my fellow UKIP MEPs reject the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which will enable Poland to receive and transmit personal information in the context of cross-border cooperation to combat terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report. Automated data exchange of dactyloscopic data is absolutely in favour of crime prevention and counter-terrorism. Such data exchange enables national security authorities to intervene in good time, thereby increasing citizens' general sense of security.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it aims to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. Also, following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Beňová's work on the automated exchange of dactic data in Poland. This report is in addition to those adopted today in relation to Belgium and Sweden and will certainly make it possible to achieve better performance in the field of the personal identification of criminals, in order to strengthen cross-border police and judicial cooperation between the countries of the European Union.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. As with Sweden and Belgium, this Benova report aims to allow Poland to receive and transmit personal data. As it happens, Poland fulfils the conditions to allow this authorisation. So I voted for it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text because it extends to Poland cooperation in the transmission of personal data to combat terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Poland responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Poland has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report by MP Monica Flašíkova Beňova aimed at launching an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland. Dactyloscopy is the most modern and safe method of establishing a person's identity, and automated exchange of dactyloscopic data is another step towards a safer society. Due to more advanced and improved cross-border cooperation, in particular to expose terrorism and cross-border crime, in July 2015 the Council authorised Poland to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In July 2015, the Council decided that Poland fully complies with the data protection requirements, compliance with which is necessary for the implementation of the automatic exchange of dactyloscopic data affected by this report. I warmly welcome this judgment, both because it concerns a country that joined the European Union in parallel with the Republic of Latvia, thus demonstrating that the 'new' Member States can and also meet the high demands of the Union for the promotion of security, and because Poland is geographically located at the external border of the European Union. Poland's inclusion in the system of automatic exchange of fingerprint data is an important factor in promoting the security of all Europeans. The same applies to the development of productive relationships in different areas with our neighbours, both close and distant. If our partners see that we are doing everything we can to enhance the security of our own citizens, there may be a "spill-over effect" with great potential, so the higher the sense of security with us, the higher it may be for the people of our partner countries. In this respect, it would be worth noting the EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement (TTIP), which can exchange personal data. While the US is undoubtedly one of the most important partners of the European Union, any of the items contained in this Treaty must not be allowed to pose any threat to the security of Europeans. Any exchange of data must be fully legitimate and justified and reciprocal in cases of such exchanges.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland will strengthen international police cooperation in the fight against terrorism, international crime and illegal immigration. The adoption of the implementing regulation is urgent precisely at a time of difficult security, when the countries of the Union are subject to an onslaught of enormous numbers of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from voting on the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of fingerprint data in Poland because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this proposal. As in previous cases, from Sweden and Belgium, an evaluation report shows that Poland has properly implemented the general data protection provisions. We therefore accept that the exchange is in place.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the exchange of dactic data in Poland. As assessed by the Council, that State has fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Decision 2008/615/JHA. The aim of this decision is to strengthen cross-border police and judicial cooperation between the countries of the European Union in criminal matters, by establishing that the provision of personal data cannot take place unless the general provisions on data protection have been implemented in the national legislation of the territories of the Member States concerned by the transmission.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes the fight against terrorism and crime prevention. Automated exchange will simplify the prosecution of criminals. I therefore supported the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim is to allow Poland to receive and transmit personal data (DNA profile, fingerprints and vehicle registration) from its police files with those of other Member States. While the legislation contains an issue on data protection and the limits of its use, the flaws in these laws are known. The CNIL was also concerned about this legislation. Above all, this dossier is part of a general trend of registering offenders as well as European citizens or migrants. These files are then cross-referenced, against the very provisions of European law, to determine profiles of each citizen. A so-called Big Brother to fight terrorism, an argument that Snowden has largely demonstrated as ineffective. It is mainly a way of increasing the amount of data on citizens to make it available to the United States or even more recently to German intelligence services.  I'm voting against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly with regard to the fight against terrorism and organised crime, I have presented my vote in agreement with the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of type-only data in Poland. Cross-border data comparison reflects a new dimension in the fight against crime. Information obtained through data comparison plays a crucial role in supporting the judicial and law enforcement authorities of the Member States.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which allows Poland to both provide and receive dactyloscopic data for use in criminal investigations, as Poland has fully implemented the general provisions on data protection.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since the European Parliament has been duly consulted on the issue of automated dactyloscopic data exchange in Poland and all the legal elements of the legal act are fulfilled, I am voting in favour of the text tabled, which aims to intensify cross-border cooperation and the necessary exchange of information.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland, which is a purely technical consultation procedure on the implementation of the so-called Prüm Decision on exchanging fingerprint data by Poland.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A vote for adding Poland to the legal architecture of Europe allowing the fighting of terrorism and organised crime while fully respecting human rights and the rule of law.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under Council Decision 2008/615/IB on strengthening cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the provision of personal data provided for in this Decision shall not take place until the Member States concerned have introduced general data protection provisions through the national legislation in force in their territory.  On 13 July 2015, on the basis of the report submitted to it, the Council concluded that the polish legislation in force complied in all respects with the general data protection provisions of Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/IB. The Council therefore intends to empower Poland by decision to receive and provide personal data in accordance with Decision 2008/615/IB. The Council should consult the European Parliament before adopting the Decision in accordance with Article 39(1) of the Treaty on European Union, as amended by the Treaty of Amsterdam and Article 9 of Protocol 36 on transitional arrangements. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommended the Council's draft to Parliament for approval. I supported the Council's draft decision accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the effectiveness of the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime depends on efficient and close cooperation between Member States. The transmission of personal data under Decision No 2008/615/JAI may be carried out only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that Decision have been incorporated into the national legislation of the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission.  The verification of compliance with this condition relating to the automated exchange of data shall be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report which, in turn, is based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. Given that Poland has met the requirements of Decision No 2008/615/JAI and successfully carried out a pilot test with Austria, this report deserves my vote in favour.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. As with Sweden and Belgium, this Benova report aims to authorise Poland to receive and transmit personal data. As it happens, Poland meets the conditions to allow this authorisation, according to the Council. So I voted for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which relates to an old Council Decision to increase cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The exchange of dactyloscopic data refers to the study of fingerprints for the purposes of criminal identification, registration and investigation.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Council's plan to allow Poland to receive and transmit fingerprint data. The aim is to improve the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime in the European Union by promoting cooperation between Member States. This authorization comes after the Commission verifies that all data protection conditions are met.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will implement the Council’s Decision on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report as it can bring significant progress in the area of crime prevention and counter-terrorism. Essentially, it is about the exchange of fingerprints. If we look at the current influx of refugees, which is already affecting the whole of Europe, progress can also be expected in the area of combating the abuse of asylum.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The report aims to approve Poland's participation in the Prem scheme. The Treaty of Prem was signed in 2005 with the aim of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, allowing signatory states to exchange personal data, genetic or digital, on an individual suspected of intending homicides. The Council's 2008/615/JAI and 2008/616/JAI directives provide that a country's participation in this scheme should be conditioned by a transposition of measures dealing with the protection of personal data into national legislation.  With this report, Parliament is invited to approve Poland's participation in this scheme.  While I am aware of the stakes and the need for concrete action to combat terrorism and cross-border crime, I am not convinced that such a mechanism can effectively combat this without endangering the right to privacy, so I abstain.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to step up the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking this opportunity to express my involvement and participation in the conduct and results of the national elections in Poland these days, I reiterate my sensitivity to security in Europe and, in this case, to the countries of eastern Europe, which are facing all the problems of the migration crisis with a strong impact.  That is why I am voting positively in relation to the automated exchange of dactic data.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the decision to include Poland in the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data. I hold the exchange of dactyloscopic data crucial in strengthening security throughout the European Union. This data from national fingerprint databases should be available to all Member States of the European Union for inspection and search and continuous exchange of dactyloscopic data should be carried out between countries.  This could avoid lengthy investigations and searches for the perpetrators of certain crimes. Such an exchange can certainly contribute to the successful detection and prevention of organised crime that is more and more present in Europe and terrorism, which has unfortunately become a global threat today.  Poland, as a member of the European Union, sees this security exchange of data as useful and considers that it should be organised at the necessary high level in order to effectively strengthen security and prevent organised crime. For all of the above, I support this decision.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. As with Sweden and Belgium, this report aims to allow Poland to receive and transmit personal data. As it happens, Poland meets the conditions to allow this authorisation, according to the Council. So I voted for it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The fight against terrorism and cross-border crime are important elements of interstate cooperation within the EU, and I believe that in this light the exchange and availability of personal data, in this case dactyloscopic, i.e. fingerprints, should be seen. However, it is also important to demand that such cross-border cooperation take place only on condition that the national laws of the countries involved have fully implemented rules on the protection of personal data. Since these conditions in Poland are met, I support this draft.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support colleague Monica Flašíkova Beňova's report on the launch of automatic data exchange with respect to dactyloscopic data (fingerprints) in Poland. The aim is to fight terrorism and cross-border crimes and facilitate and strengthen cross-border cooperation through the exchange of information between agencies responsible for preventing and investigating crimes.  One of the objectives of the European Union is to provide citizens with a high degree of security in the areas of freedom, security and justice through the development of joint procedures between Member States in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. It highlights the importance of precise information for effective international cooperation in the Member States and for promoting a fast, efficient and inexpensive way of exchanging data. The report is in line with the decision to intensify cross-border cooperation, in particular in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, to supply the personal data provided for in this decision in order to maintain general data provisions.  Poland completed a data protection questionnaire and a questionnaire on dactyloscopic data exchange. Furthermore, the successful pilot ride was carried out by Poland with Austria and on the basis of the overall evaluation report, on 13 July 2015, the Council concluded that Poland had fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6. Decisions 2008/615/PUP.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to combat international crime and terrorism, the competent authorities must be able to exchange police information quickly and efficiently, in particular DNA profiles and fingerprints. This exchange makes it possible to ascertain quickly whether information on a particular person is recorded in the databases of the Member States. The initiation of procedures in Poland to ensure the automated exchange of dactic data increases the effectiveness of cross-border cooperation between European police forces in the fight against terrorist crimes and illegal migration. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to strengthen European action in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, the European Parliament has adopted the text authorising the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Poland.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of understanding that cooperation and the exchange of information are decisive factors in strengthening the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP rejects the notion that greater EU integration will help detect and prevent crimes. We note that a number of serious criminals from EU Member States have entered Britain and committed serious crimes, with the UK powerless to stop them. We note that Interpol and other organisations are better experienced and more appropriate forums for criminal cooperation than any EU scheme.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In accordance with Article 25(2) of Decision 2008/615/JHA, the transmission of personal data under that decision may be initiated only where the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of that decision have been incorporated into national law in the territory of the Member States participating in that transmission. On 13 July 2015 the Council concluded that Poland fully implemented the general data protection provisions set out in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. Consequently, for the purposes of automated consultation of fingerprint data, Poland should be enabled to receive and transmit personal data under Article 9 of Decision 2008/615/JHA. That is why I voted favourably on this report necessary to give approval to the exchange of fingerprint data with Poland.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which endorses the Council's plan to launch the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data in Poland. Such systematization of trade and strengthening cross-border cooperation will be useful in law enforcement and counter-terrorism.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This legislative motion for a resolution aims at launching the automated exchange of fingerprints with Poland, with a view to authorising Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision No 2008/615/JAI. The main objective of this measure is to deepen cross-border cooperation in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. Following the Council's assessment and like the other two reports on this same issue (concerning Sweden and Belgium), it was found that Poland fulfils the criteria necessary to operate the exchange of typoscopic data, since the general data protection provisions laid down in Chapter 6 of Decision 2008/615/JAI are also complied with and the pilot experience with Austria on this matter (such as Sweden) has also been complied with, so I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report on the Council's draft implementation decision on the launch of the automated data exchange on fingerprint data in Poland. The Council's proposed implementation decision is aimed at allowing Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with the 2008/615/JAI decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the European Union's desire to strengthen cross-border cooperation between Member States in order to combat organised crime, and that is why I am voting in favour of the European Council's decision to authorise Poland to receive and provide fingerprint data. I believe that the exchange of information is a valuable tool that allows the supervisory and police authorities to protect and guarantee the safety of every European citizen.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Poland responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Poland has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I do not wish to see UK citizens’ fingerprint data shared with foreign nations.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Like the previous two countries we voted on for this automated data exchange, I voted in favour of this Council draft and support the further cooperation of the Polish Republic in these matters.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Supporting the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime requires certain steps to be taken. One important step in this fight is cooperation in the exchange of information on dactyloscopic data with Poland.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report regarding cross-border exchange of dactyloscopic data (the study of fingerprints for the purposes of criminal identification, registration and investigation) in an attempt to combat terrorism and cross-border crime. Following pilot projects, evaluations have shown no hindrance to EU data protection standards.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The aim of this draft Implementation Decision of the Council is to initiate an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland. International exchange of dactyloscopic data is the key to fighting cross-border crime. The ultimate objective is to support Poland in the fight against cross-border crime and to step up cooperation in law enforcement in the EU. Decisions referred to in Article 25(2) of the Code of Art Decisions 2008/615/PUP are taken on the basis of a questionnaire-based assessment report. The questionnaire drawn up by the relevant Council working group concerns any automated data exchange and must be completed by the Member State, thus considering that it meets the requirements for data sharing in the relevant data category.  Also taking into account the application of the Prüm Decision and the European Information Exchange Model, I support this draft Council with a view to launching an automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland. In my view, the launch of automated exchanges of dactyloscopic data in Poland can significantly contribute to deepening cross-border cooperation, in particular in countering terrorism and cross-border crime.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As the United Kingdom did not participate in the original Council Decision with regard to automated exchange of dactyloscopic data, and is therefore not taking part in the adoption of this Decision, I abstained on this report.  While I support the objectives of the Decision, which are to have more Member States cooperating in the fight against serious crime and terrorism, the provisions on the exchange of DNA and fingerprint material relate closely to many of the elements of Prüm Treaty which the UK has not yet implemented.  Under the Prüm Treaty, a Member State can ask another state to check key personal data (and car registrations) against their database as part of a criminal investigation. I have significant concerns regarding certain civil liberties and data protection elements, and the cost implications related to its implementation.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The exchange of fingerprint data as a measure to prevent criminal offences but above all possible terrorist acts is in the right direction. The clause provided for in the Treaty, as regards the discretion (if the relevant criteria are met), of each Member State for the implementation of the exchange, is a positive step, in particular for the protection of sensitive personal data and privacy, as provided for in the Charter of Human Fundamental Rights. Poland succeeded in the evaluation and the submission of the data protection assessment questionnaire was successful.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The extension of the Schengen Convention to the Member States of Central and Eastern Europe was an important moment for strengthening European construction. Achieving free movement within the European Union is one of the key gains in the European integration process. The free movement of people has allowed our citizens to move without restrictions outside the borders of their own countries and without being stopped by the borders of the Member States. This freedom, however, also entails a number of risks with regard to the movement of third-country citizens or immigrants from neighbouring countries, as has become evident in recent times. For these reasons, the establishment of a fingerprint database, comprising the fingerprints of those entering the European area, has become an imperative necessary measure. Poland's accession to the group of Member States already implementing these measures is an important step, extending the European security area to a significant part of Central Europe. Therefore, the approval of this document is necessary to prevent the entry into the European space of individuals who may prove to be a real threat to our citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted on the Council's proposed implementation decision on the launch of the automated exchange of data on fingerprint data, following the informed advice of the political group.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the case of Sweden and Belgium, I also voted in favour of launching an automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland, authorising it to receive and supply personal data. This act follows Council Decision 2008/615/JHA, which incorporates the substance of the so called ʽPrüm Treaty’. The initiative between Belgium, Bulgaria, Germany, Spain, France, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Austria, Slovenia, Slovakia, Italy, Finland, Portugal, Romania and Sweden focuses on stepping up cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism, cross-border crime and illegal migration. In order to strengthen freedom, security and justice, it recommends making full use of new technologies and enabling reciprocal access to national databases.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 I supported the report on the draft Council implementing decision on the launch of automated exchange of dactyloscopic data in Poland, because this will allow Poland to receive and send data on the deepening of cross-border cooperation, particularly in the area of combating terrorism and cross-border crime, which will ensure greater security for EU citizens.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed Council enforcement decision is intended to allow Poland to receive and transmit personal data. In the context of this decision on deepening cross-border cooperation, particularly in the fight against terrorism and cross-border crime, the transmission of personal data provided for by the decision can only take place after the implementation in national law on the territory of the Member States concerned by this transmission of the general data protection provisions set out in this decision. On the basis of the general assessment report presented to it, the Council concluded on 13 July 2015 that Poland had fully implemented the general data protection provisions. I voted FOR this text

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report in order to combat terrorism and cross-border crime and strengthen cross-border cooperation.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament refers to the draft decision implementing the Council on the launch of automated data exchange with regard to fingerprint data in Poland.  Automated access to fingerprint data (palm prints, latent fingerprints, etc.) is regulated in Council Decision 2008/615/JHA on enhancing cross-border cooperation, in particular in the field of combating terrorism and cross-border crime. The aim of this decision is to accelerate cross-border police and judicial cooperation between European Union countries in criminal matters by improving the exchange of information between authorities responsible for preventing and investigating criminal offences. The launch of automated data exchange with regard to fingerprint data may be carried out only after the general provisions on the protection of personal data have been implemented in the national legislation of the Member States. Verification of compliance with this condition shall be carried out on the basis of an evaluation report based on a questionnaire, an evaluation visit and a pilot test. These criteria were successfully met by Poland, therefore the Council gave a favourable opinion to Poland to receive and provide personal data for the purpose of automated search for fingerprint data.  Through the legislative resolution, Parliament approved this Council decision.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained. Our group has always supported clear criteria to ensure the protection of personal data. In this regard, given the links that this report has with previous facts and the minimum protection in the field of personal data, it is proposed to abstain.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. – I have voted in favour of the three reports on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Sweden, Poland and Belgium. This time, Parliament is at last being properly consulted on the automated exchange of dactyloscopic data. The Green group had insisted already in 2008 on the inclusion of data protection standards into the Decision and proper consultation with the Parliament. Now we can formally agree to automated data exchange.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on automated data exchange with regard to dactyloscopic data in Poland because I believe it is important to strengthen cross-border cooperation, particularly in combating terrorism and cross-border crime, and to work on strengthening cross-border law-enforcement cooperation in the EU.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In accordance with Decision 2008/615/JHA on the intensification of cross-border cooperation, in particular with regard to the fight against terrorism and organized crime, the provision of personal data (including fingerprints) should not be carried out until the general data protection provisions have not been implemented in the legislation of the Member States concerned.  On the basis of a general assessment report submitted to the Council, the Council concluded that the Member State had implemented the general provisions on data protection and therefore authorises it to receive and provide fingerprints in accordance with this Decision. For all the above, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.  .

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report on the exchange of fingerprint data in Poland responds to Decision 2008/615/JHA, according to which the exchange of data to combat cross-border crime and terrorism must be subject to compliance with European data protection provisions in State law. In this case, Poland has met all relevant requirements. We have always opposed that decision on cross-border police cooperation, because we understand that it does not guarantee effective protection but can be used for the criminalisation of migrants or for the uncontrolled storage of personal data. However, this particular report refers to compliance with data protection requirements with which we do agree. We have therefore abstained in the vote.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In December 2008, the European Commission presented a proposal for the establishment of the 'Eurodac' system for the purpose of the effective implementation of the Dublin Convention. This proposal is currently part of the Asylum package.  Eurodac is a common processing of personal data, used since 15 January 2003, and includes an automatic fingerprint recognition system. The purpose of this processing is to determine the Member State which, under the Dublin Convention, is responsible for the examination of an application for asylum lodged in one of the EU States. This draft Council implementing decision on the launch of the automated exchange of type-scopic data is part of this logic.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report promotes the fight against terrorism and crime prevention. Automated exchange will simplify the prosecution of criminals. I therefore supported the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I repeat that I voted in favour of the draft Council implementing decision on the launch, this time in Poland, of the automated exchange of dacticoscopic data because, as I have already said in the case of Sweden and Belgium, I am convinced of the need for joint action in the fight against terrorism and organised crime, which operate at European level. All this, however, cannot be separated from full respect for fundamental rights and freedoms.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, the ECR, I voted in favour of this report. The ECR supports the accession of Sweden, Poland and Belgium to the automated exchange system of dactyloscopic data. Poland, Belgium and Sweden have completed the data protection and dactyloscopic (i.e. fingerprint) data exchange questionnaire and carried out successful pilot projects. On the basis of a comprehensive evaluation report, the Council decided on 13 July 2015 that these Member States had fully implemented the general data protection rules. I support my group's position on this issue and have accordingly voted in favour of this report.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In the vote, I supported the decision to start an automated data exchange in Poland for dactyloscopic data. This is one of the pragmatic steps to improve cooperation within the European Union in the effective fight against terrorism and international crime. Poland has already adapted its legislation to EU solutions for the protection of sensitive data and the exchange of fingerprint data. Moreover, very importantly, this has been confirmed in practice by carrying out an effective pilot operation with Austria. This means that Poland will be entitled and prepared to transfer personal data to the authorities of other EU countries, as well as receive similar information itself. This is undoubtedly beneficial in the fight against crime.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to Decision No 2008/615/JAI on the deepening of cross-border cooperation, the fight against terrorism and crime, the provision of personal data provided for in the context of that decision cannot take place until the general data protection provisions have been transposed into national law. The Council proposal aims to authorise Poland to receive and transmit personal data in accordance with Council Decision No 2008/615/JAI from the date of its entry into force. These three reports relate to the Prüm Convention which was signed on 27 May 2005 in Prüm (Germany) between seven Member States - Austria, Belgium, France, Germany, Luxembourg, Spain and the Netherlands. The objective of the Prüm Decision is thus to intensify and accelerate exchanges of information between authorities, contributing to this, for example, the possibility of comparing, for example, a particular DNA profile with profiles recorded in existing automated databases in the Member States. We know that, on the pretext of combating terrorism and crime, the EU has been putting together a surveillance system that safeguards the freedoms and guarantees of individuals. This measure goes in similar logic from what we voted against.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent The circumstances that have been spoken about in this draft legislative resolution are fully applicable to any other area of our daily lives. Travel providers, food producers a range of contract ers and a number of other institutions often do not provide all the information necessary to enable the consumer to make a fully informed choice. More than that, even if something is included in the operating rules of companies employed by commercial practice and in the list of free rights available to their customers, they may refuse to fulfil their obligations. This is not right: it must be fought against and, in particular, in the case of travel service providers, their customers must clearly understand how much they are paying, and whether or not there are any additional services for which they would have to pay at a later stage for whatever obvious reason. I therefore support this document. Thank you!

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – (the beginning of the speech is incomprehensible) to the directive, which was written at a time when shopping was much simpler and when everything could not be done online. People have become increasingly interested in independently selecting travel packages, various benefits, and it is essential to ensure the protection of their rights, so amending this Directive was necessary.  But I would also like to point out that the protection of entrepreneurs in tourism should also be taken into account so that our decisions do not have far-reaching consequences on the competitiveness and profitability of the hotel industry. It is good that the warnings of the profession were heeded in order to avoid possible problems that would lead to a burden on new benefits, which would then increase the price of products and services, and many hotels would not be able to pay these new benefits and would stop offering specific products, by which Croatia is already a recognizable tourist destination. I also hope that this proposal for a directive will not lead to a different VAT calculation of some hotel products, to the detriment of hoteliers, but also to the detriment of of course end users, tourists. I therefore call for a serious debate on tourism to be opened in the European Parliament, as it is an economic branch that has been unfairly neglected.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I support this report as well, particularly as currently two-thirds of package travel sales take place online. This is a huge increase in recent years, so an updated directive suitable for the digital age is much needed. This proposal meets the challenges of both the modern environment and traditional sales. Package travel is becoming increasingly popular, and this directive protects both the consumer and businesses by setting clear standards for liability, cancellation, reimbursement and a limit for post-contractual price increase. If a package travel service goes bankrupt, measures in place mean that payments already made by customers are secured through clear insolvency provisions.  Dá bhrí sin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar cabhróidh sé le suas le 120 milliún duine a bhíonn ag taisteal gach uile bhliain agus a cheannaíonn ticéid agus mar sin de ar an idirlíon. Tabharfaidh sé cosaint dóibh agus cabhróidh sé leo gan EUR 430 milliún a chailliúint gach uile bhliain.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this Directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive because, given the changes in the tourism market and the growing tendency of consumers to book their holidays online, it was necessary to modernise and adapt the legislation to the digital age. With the adoption of that directive, the rights of consumers are strengthened: first, by covering new booking models ̶ pages linked to ̶, package trips consisting of various travel services (flight, hotel or car rental) and purchased online will have the same protection as packages contracted from travel agencies, since such linked offers in which the customer's name , payment details and email address are transferred from one supplier to another and a second contract is concluded less than 24 hours after the purchase of the service, shall be considered as a package trip for the purposes of the law. And secondly, when receiving detailed information about their rights, travelers will have more options to cancel the contract, and must have clear information in advance about who is responsible in case of problems. They will also enjoy greater protection in the event of insolvency of employers.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is part of the process of adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel services, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Council Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC. The Council proposal reflects Parliament's concerns that consumer rights should be harmonised in the field of this tourism regulation.  Therefore, our position is favourable.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of rejecting the amendment on package travel and assisted travel benefits. This text, which aims to promote as much as possible the services of travel at "click range" in order to stimulate the market, has the consequence of distorting competition in the market and centralizing supply to the detriment of SMEs. Further, I regret that the harmonisation of legislation, the implementation of the single market, and the distortion of competition for the benefit of powerful economic actors are missing themes from this text.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which primarily dealt with the scope of protection for travellers when purchasing combinations of travel services. My reasons for abstaining were threefold. First, the scope provided for full harmonisation such that the rights of travellers and business competitiveness received equal protection. It is my belief that consumers’ rights cannot be best served when business competitiveness needs to be served as well through full harmonisation. Second, the consequence of price change in the report is such that in case of a change in the cost of fuel, a traveller may be asked to pay more money. There was however no provision in the text that allowed the alternate to benefit the traveller in case the price of fuel decreased. Finally, in Ireland the tourism industry consists mostly of SMEs. According to this report, these SMEs would have to take out insolvency protection on behalf of larger providers than themselves when they come to be classified as a package travel provider, or, a Linked Travel Arrangement. This report does not adequately protect a tourism industry dominated by SMEs and for this reason, I abstained.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the outcome of the agreement between the Council and the European Parliament, as this proposal revises the legislation on package travel after 25 years, strengthening consumer rights, updating the provisions on the basis of the case law, experience and technological developments of the last 25 years.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to reject the Council's position of harmonizing national legislation on package travel and assisted or related travel benefits. This will, of course, be done in the context of the creation of a single digital market. These package trips include a set of services offered to the customer at a fixed price by a tour operator. The report recommends encouraging this activity on the Internet in order to stimulate the market. However, such a centralization of the supply of related services risks distorting competition at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that will not be able to compete with large groups.  I therefore voted in favour of the amendment rejecting the Council's position.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I note that the British government has described these changes as being ‘far from perfect’. I also note that the legislation explicitly calls for maximum harmonisation of this directive. I therefore supported the rejection amendment.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to grant more rights to travellers purchasing organised travel. Online sales and low-cost airline services have changed their buying habits, so many organised trips currently do not fall within the scope of EU rules in force since 1990. In order to ensure adequate protection for travellers, the updated rules will clarify the provisions of organised travel, which consists of different services purchased together (flights, accommodation and car rental). It is important that, regardless of whether an organized trip is purchased at an office or online, travellers are given the same consumer protection. Tour operators will also have to provide their customers with detailed information on the future trip and clearly identify who will be responsible for the proper execution of the package.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this Directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Let those who consult VoteWatch make no mistake: I voted in favour of the amendment tabled by the EFDD group which called for the rejection of this directive, which risks once again favouring the heavyweights of the sector at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report which helps to better protect European citizens who buy package holidays online.  This will allow them to avoid inconveniences related to an unjustifiable price increase, the bankruptcy of its operator, exaggerated hourly changes or unforeseen events.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. The agreement on package holidays is a step in the right direction, but it is not yet perfect. We would have liked to have seen much better consumer protection for click-through bookings, where consumers also book an overnight stay via the airline's website, for example. We must also be careful not to compromise the many SMEs in the sector. The new regulations must therefore be evaluated quickly and thoroughly and, if necessary, adjusted by the European Commission. Now, however, we must look ahead. The agreement takes protection for travellers to the next level and also protects them from online reservations. It is now up to the Member States to convert this agreement as sensibly as possible into national legislation.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text proposes a harmonisation of legislation relating to package travel and "assisted" or "linked" travel services. This is an additional implementation of the Digital Single Market. This means that it is easy to promote online travel services. If the intention is correct, this system can lead to abuses, notably by a centralization of the offer that would harm the SME/SMEs to the detriment of large groups (see Google which has been guilty of favouring its partners or subsidiaries and thus distorting competition).  The associations have also warned of the pressures exerted by the transport industry lobbies, since the desire to improve actually leads to further harmonisation of the internal market. I therefore voted in favour of the recommendation to vote on the amendment to reject the EFDD in order to avoid harmonisation of legislation and to avoid the risk of abuse of dominant position and distorted competition for the benefit of large groups.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of rejecting the Collin-Langen report on 'package tours and related tourist services'. It is a confused and unclear text, especially as regards the definition of 'linked services'. The disastrous effects of european regulations passed too lightly, such as the Services Directive, are unfortunately clear to everyone. That is why I did not support this measure, the effects of which on professional groups such as tour guides, alpine guides or ski instructors are unclear and potentially harmful.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. It was necessary to review the legal framework governing package travel contracts. This proposal aims to clarify and modernize the scope of protection and information of travellers in the purchase of these services, improving their rights in accordance with the changes brought about online. The new rules will increase transparency and strengthen consumer protection over online travel services.  The Eurochamber has been able to ensure that the protection of travellers against the insolvency of the employer covers all reasonably foreseeable expenses and all payments made by the traveller in relation to the package. The rights of travellers have been clarified, in particular on price reduction, compensation (including non-material damage) and misconduct of the contract. The burden of proof has been shifted to the organizers. In addition, the deadline for filing a complaint has been extended by two years. In 2018, an adjustment to the definition of 'travel package' will be checked if necessary. For all this, among other issues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it supported a new directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and associated travel arrangements. From now on, whether an organized trip is purchased in the office or online, travelers will be given the same protection.
