Tourists will have more opportunities to cancel the trip free of charge, and tour operators will have to provide more detailed information about the future trip and those responsible for it. Parliament has also included a provision that holds different services purchased together, such as flights, accommodation and car rental, on an organised trip. Even if different travel services are purchased in a single payment, whether online, in an office or by phone, such an order will be subject to the same rights of travellers as organised travellers.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Internet sales have significantly changed booking patterns, so many self-organised journeys are now not subject to EU rules from the 1990s or do not clearly define passengers' rights. For this reason, I voted in favour of amending the EU consumer protection rules on travel, as this will in future be subject to the same rules for organised trips booked online, including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals, as they are purchased at a travel agency. Under the amended rules, before holidaymakers sign the contract, tour operators or travel vendors must clearly explain that it is a package. In addition, the passenger should be informed of his rights and of who bears the financial responsibility in the event of a problem. It is to be welcomed that the EP has also included in the new rules that tour operators are obliged to inform passengers in advance of the planned departure and arrival times and the nature of any additional costs that may arise.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that the proposed directive has been adopted as, in my opinion, it will contribute to a better tourism offer in the EU.  Tourism is one of the most important industries in the EU. The areas of offer of packages covered by the Directive represent a significant part of the travel market, which has been exceptionally unchanged since the adoption of the currently current Package Travel Directive. Today's travel services are not only a combination of traditional tourist packages, but adapt to the individual. Today's passenger is also significantly more demanding than it used to be, so the market needs to adapt accordingly.  Today, the internet also plays an important role in the supply of tourist arrangements, where the market for such products is changing extremely rapidly. Therefore, the legislation must follow the development of package travel, especially online, to protect passengers or consumers even more intensively and to reduce administrative burdens for providers of such services, especially SMEs.  I am convinced that the adopted directive undoubtedly meets these criteria and provides a quality basis for the continued growth of European tourism!

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ We buy as much as 35 percent of our trips online, implying that we are protected. However, the truth is different. Citizens who bought trips were not protected, and cancellation fees or changes in their reservation are generally about 3 times more expensive than those who buy trips in agencies. Customers thus lose about 1 billion euros a year.  My fellow citizens often complain to me that some websites where they book hotels or buy transport tickets charge a higher commission in Croatia than in other Member States. It's a problem I keep warning about. The new directive will allow the buyer to see the components of the final price and make the whole process more transparent. Also, the trader is obliged to provide contacts for emergencies and contingencies which will reduce fraud.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendment to reject this text because to claim to improve the legislation on package travel and assisted travel is a false pretext for further harmonising the internal market at a time when the tourism sector is already very protective of the consumer.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ On the Collin-Langen (IMCO) ‘Package travel and linked travel arrangement’, I abstained. Whilst I acknowledge that there were positive aspects to this report, especially regarding improving and protecting consumer rights, there were lingering concerns, particularly on the level of harmonisation involved for implementation, as it is based on the assumption that it is suitable for all 28 Member States. Also, at the European Council of Ministers during the summer Ireland withdrew its support, citing that it risks hindering innovation and competition. There are also data protection concerns, and the degree of compensation for consumers around cancellations of packages by a travel organiser was not adequately addressed.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. As part of the creation of a digital single market, this proposal aims to harmonize national legislation on package travel and assisted or related travel benefits. This type of trip brings together a set of services offered to the customer at a fixed price by a tour operator. In particular, the text proposes to promote this activity on the Internet in order to stimulate the market. Only this report does not give sufficient weight to the excesses that could result from the application of this measure. The centralisation of the supply of related services risks distorting competition at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) who will not have the means to compete with the most powerful economic players. They also claim to improve consumer protection to better accelerate the convergence of national legislation. That is why I voted to reject this resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The considerable efforts made over the years in the Union to strengthen the right to information of its citizens are steps that must be supported by law-making in all areas providing services. All the more so we need to talk about transparency and fair information regarding the provision of services by private individuals to other individuals, because in this equation those in need of protection are the beneficiaries of services, and the Union must provide them with an optimal framework in which they can exercise their right to free movement, guaranteed by the EU Treaties.  I support the Commission's position on how this framework for the deployment of travel services will be ensured and aligned with democratic rules in order to protect those who use the services. I voted in favour of establishing fair commercial practices by creating a legal framework in which entities that market their online services do not offer additional services in a hidden, unclear or ambiguous manner, such as concealing the option of not booking additional services. I believe that it is only in this way that we can speak of a right to effective information and real transparency in the provision of services.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of withdrawing the proposal. The text is strongly unfavorable to tour guides and other related categories such as alpine guides and ski instructors.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the ep draft legislative resolution on the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and associated travel services, amending Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 2006/2004 and Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC (09173/3/2015 – C8-0281/2015 – 2013/0246(COD)). The amendment to the Regulation aims to modernise the rules on package travel services, including personalised combinations of travel services, in particular those purchased online, while at the same time increasing legal certainty and transparency for both travellers and businesses. Another benefit is to reduce harm to consumers by granting additional rights to terminate a contract and to establish stricter rules on price increases, while at the same time ensuring more fair competition between travel undertakings.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive because, given the changes in the tourism market and the growing tendency of consumers to book their holidays online, it was necessary to modernise and adapt the legislation to the digital age. The adoption of that directive strengthens the rights of consumers: first, by covering new booking models ̶ ̶-linked pages, package trips consisting of various travel services (flight, hotel or car rental) and purchased online will have the same protection as packages contracted from travel agencies, as such linked offers in which the customer's name , payment details and email address are transferred from one supplier to another and a second contract is concluded less than 24 hours after the purchase of the service, shall be considered as a package trip for the purposes of the law. And secondly, when receiving detailed information about their rights, travelers will have more options to cancel the contract, and must have clear information in advance about who is responsible in case of problems. They will also enjoy greater protection in the event of insolvency of employers.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package tours and related tourist services. Tourism plays a major role in the Union's economies, and travel, holidays and package tours account for a significant part of the tourism market. However, the market has undergone profound changes in recent years, as traditional distribution channels have been joined by the Internet, which has changed the offer of tourist services, making them increasingly personalized. Many of these combinations are not covered by the framework laid down in Directive 90/314/EEC and it is essential to update it. The new directive not only extends protection to all recent developments in the sector, but considerably increases transparency and strengthens legal certainty for travellers and professionals. I have therefore chosen to approve this text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report which primarily dealt with the scope of protection for travellers when purchasing combinations of travel services. My reasons for abstaining were threefold. First, the scope provided for full harmonisation such that the rights of travellers and business competitiveness received equal protection. It is my belief that consumers’ rights cannot be best served when business competitiveness needs to be served as well through full harmonisation. Second, the consequence of price change in the report is such that in case of a change in the cost of fuel, a traveller may be asked to pay more money. There was however no provision in the text that allowed the alternate to benefit the traveller in case the price of fuel decreased. Finally, in Ireland the tourism industry consists mostly of SMEs. According to this report, these SMEs would have to take out insolvency protection on behalf of larger providers than themselves when they come to be classified as a package travel provider, or, a Linked Travel Arrangement. This report does not adequately protect a tourism industry dominated by SMEs and for this reason, I abstained.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of rejecting the Council position in this Report as I believe that this proposal does not sufficiently cover the concerns of the whole spectrum of the tourist industry and might go against the actual competitiveness of the tourism sector.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission launched an initiative in 2010 called 'Europe, the world's leading tourist destination' to give new impetus to tourism. Since May 2013, however, the Commission has stopped drawing up implementation plans and it is therefore difficult to assess the progress made now. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which calls for an implementation report to verify the actions taken, including the use of financial resources. One of the main problems with European tourism legislation is precisely that the resources allocated to it are truly derisory and that most of the actions undertaken require funds in different funding programmes that are not integrated into each other.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am glad we have adopted this second reading agreement and am proud that I had a part in making sure it was good for both consumers and businesses. I can only repeat my regret that it will not come into force sooner. My thanks to the Latvian Presidency and our Rapporteur.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It concerns the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and linked travel arrangements, which amends Council Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the EFDD Group's proposal to reject this measure. By representing tourist services as the most popular category of products purchased online, the European legislator has intervened to adapt the protection of travellers to the challenges posed by new technologies. To this end, the European Commission has proposed a regulation amending Directives 2006/2004/EC and 2011/83/EU and replacing Directive 90/314/EEC. The report makes it clear that this is a directive of complete harmonisation in the interests of consumers and service providers. The new provisions apply to the online and offline business travel sector and substantially change the insolvency protection mechanism. Travellers are also offered the option of replacing their own with an equivalent package if the organiser unilaterally alters a major element of the travel contract. The proposal establishes sanctions and clarifies the scope of passenger protection for the purchase of combinations of travel services by including different forms of online packages and organised travel in the definition. The derogations on ancillary contracts are being extended to extend them to the ancillary services provided as part of the package, and the concept of 'assisted travel organisation', renamed the 'linked travel organisation', is clarified.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that, in order to best protect the very important tourism sector in Europe, it is very important to block those practices through which tourist services, which offer online packages, offer additional services in a hidden, obscure or ambiguous way. I always stand up against any kind of fraud in order to have a Europe that is as serious, transparent and clean as possible, especially in a sector such as tourism where Europe has a serious competitive advantage and cannot lose it because of a lack of confidence. It is a question of protecting companies that, on a daily basis, are designed to offer services to tourists, but it is the greatest bastion of defence of our lands, so rich in history and culture, but often impoverished by unfair commercial practices.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The current rules governing package travel packages are manifestly obsolete in the face of the new realities of the digital age and the paradigm shift in the travel market.  European consumers were less protected, as existing standards do not provide for these situations or cover them in an unclear way as they are designed only for traditional package travel. The current status quo, of non-application to online travel and of dispersed legislation from Member States for their regulation, creates uncertainty among consumers as to their rights, also creating doubts among operators as to their responsibilities and fragmenting the Internal Market. I support the Collin-Langen Report for considering the reform of the Package Travel Directive urgent, and an agreement has been reached between the EP and the Council that balances a high level of consumer protection and the promotion of a free space for the movement of goods and services across borders.  Consumers must be at the heart of the Internal Market, and greater transparency and enhanced consumer protection are now recognised and, on the other hand, the desired harmonisation that provides fairness for businesses.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation because I agree with the changes that are intended to be made in the area of tourist packages and services. Firstly, digital modernisation is essential in our era to make services more competitive. Of particular importance is the change in the insolvency mechanism, which provides greater protection for travellers. In addition, even clarifying the concept of "assisted travel" that becomes "connected travel" allows travelers to take an equivalent package when the organizer unilaterally modifies a main element of the travel contract. This new legislative amendment will make it possible to increase consumer protection and to make tourist services more modern and competitive.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Malta, along with other Member States, has expressed serious concerns on this proposal during all stages of the discussions of this file. In this regard a common statement was co-signed by Belgium, Estonia, Ireland, Malta, the Netherlands and Slovakia when the vote for a political agreement during the Competitiveness Council was taken. The aspects of this proposal are at odds with the aims of the Digital Single Market Strategy which seeks to overcome barriers to the full utilisation of the internet and digital technologies for the benefit of consumers and businesses alike. The proposal risks stifling innovation and hindering the competitiveness of our tourism sector, ultimately creating higher prices and less choice for consumers.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is part of the process of adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel services, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Council Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC. The Council proposal reflects Parliament's concerns that consumer rights should be harmonised in the field of this tourism regulation.  Therefore, our position is favourable

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The extraordinary wealth of Europe's artistic and landscape heritage makes the tourism industry an important element for growth in Europe. However, this industry must remain competitive, including through greater protection for travellers. The European Parliament resolution, which comes after a long legislative process, guarantees greater harmonisation and transparency of the rules on package tours and related tourist services and greater protection for travellers, thereby strengthening the European tourism market. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The rise of the digital world and the increase in internet sales have significantly changed booking habits, so many self-organised journeys are now not subject to EU rules from the 1990s or do not clearly define passengers' rights. For this reason, I voted in favour of the amendment of EU consumer protection rules on travel, as this will strengthen the protection of travellers. In the future, the same requirements will apply to packaged trips booked online including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals as are purchased at a travel agency.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of rejecting the Council position because I have serious concerns on the proposal as it stands. While I acknowledge that the old package travel directive is in need of revision due to enormous changes in the travel market, and while I support the improvement of consumer protection and insolvency protection I could not support this report due to the inclusion of practices that can harm the Maltese touristic industry. A regulation needs to be smart and self-explanatory and must be enforceable, however I have doubts whether this is the case with this proposal. The main concern is that the new Directive might lead to burden and bureaucracy for SMEs in Malta, advantage third countries, and create a high degree of legal uncertainty especially due to the broad and ambitious definitions on what constitutes a package. Therefore also after reviewing the position of the main interested parties I voted against this directive.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a Europe of the free movement of citizens, guaranteeing their right to be well informed about the services they can receive during travel in Europe and beyond is necessary and beneficial for all parties. In addition, travellers must have access to adequate means to be able to remedy problems during the period in which they benefit from those services, whether they are travelling as such or a stay, in particular in the case of services purchased over the internet.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The approval of the agreement reached with the Council on package tours and assisted tourist services updates and makes more effective the European legislation governing the area of travel package purchases, which is still blocked by Directive 314 of 1990, when the Internet and online purchases were not widespread.   I welcome the fact that the directive has strengthened the level of consumer protection by comparing the purchase of travel packages and traditional tourist services with those online. In particular, the rules that have been approved today will allow 120 million travellers to purchase personalized packages, enjoying the same rights and protections as those who buy pre-packaged packages or assisted tourist services. The change and evolution of the needs of consumers and businesses in the travel market, due to the advent of the digital age, made it necessary for the European institutions to re-act. With the adoption of the new directive, consumers will now be guaranteed greater protection and information of their rights.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes a series of measures to offer online buyers of "package travel" (booking an all-in-one trip) the same level of legal protection as travellers who pass through a travel agency. Tour operators will now be required to provide approximate departure and return times and an indication of the nature of any additional charges. Travellers will be able to cancel a contract and get their money back if the price goes up by more than 8% or if "inevitable" events such as natural disasters or terrorist attacks hit the destination. They will also be able to obtain clear information in advance about the person in charge as a last resort in the event of a problem. Considering that this report strengthens the protection of consumers when shopping on the internet, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. With the adoption of this text, Parliament wanted to guarantee European consumers a high level of protection when it comes to package travel contracts and assisted travel services. Harmonised rules at European level help boost consumer confidence and promote tourism, a sector of major importance for European economies. In particular, I felt it was important to fill the legal loopholes regarding travel packages and services sold online.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – More and more holidaymakers are booking a combined holiday package online. In addition to a plane ticket, they suddenly reserve a rental car and book a hotel night. The adoption of the Directive will improve the protection of the 120 million European travellers who book package holidays online. The new duties will reduce the damage to travellers in the European Union by EUR 430 million annually. Travellers will have more opportunities to cancel their trip free of charge in the event of an unannounced higher cost or natural disaster or terrorist attack.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Internet sales have significantly changed booking patterns, so many self-organised journeys are now not subject to EU rules from the 1990s or do not clearly define passengers' rights. For this reason, I voted in favour of the amendment of the EU consumer protection rules on travel, as this will in future be subject to the same rules for organised travel booked online, including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals, as they are purchased at a travel agency. Under the amended rules, before holidaymakers sign the contract, tour operators or travel vendors must clearly explain that it is a package. In addition, the passenger should be informed of his rights and of who bears the financial responsibility in the event of a problem. It is to be welcomed that the EP has also included in the new rules that tour operators are obliged to inform passengers in advance of the planned departure and arrival times and the nature of any additional costs that may arise.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal was intended to promote all-inclusive travel via the internet. By harmonising European legislation to allow for greater development of this method of selling travel, this text attempts to stimulate the tourism economy. While it is beneficial for travel providers to see their approaches facilitated, allowing them to be more efficient in the market, we must nevertheless be careful that these practices do not induce clientelism resulting in an abuse of a dominant position vis-à-vis local actors.  Nor should this development be done solely through digital technology, without any physical presence. None of these arguments have been developed in this text. That is why I will vote in for the amendment to reject this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I definitely support this report. This reform clarifies and improves the situation of consumers, while reducing barriers for travel operators in the provision of information and proposing improvements to national insolvency protection schemes.  What did not exist until now in the Package Travel Directive and had to be adapted to market developments and changes is the lack of consumer protection when buying a 'package service'. When this package service is bought online, some protections, such as repatriation in the event of a tour operator's insolvency, have not been available until now.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament rejects the Council's position at first reading, so we too agree with that position of the European Parliament. In particular, we must prevent unfair commercial practices by certain companies providing travel services and during the provision of these services they also provide other services online in a vague, ambiguous and covert manner. For the above reasons I voted against the recommendation for second reading.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Internet sales have significantly changed booking patterns, so many self-organised journeys are now not subject to EU rules from the 1990s or do not clearly define passengers' rights. For this reason, I voted in favour of amending the EU consumer protection rules on travel, as this will in future be subject to the same rules for organised trips booked online, including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals, as they are purchased at a travel agency. Under the amended rules, before holidaymakers sign the contract, tour operators or travel vendors must clearly explain that it is a package. In addition, the passenger should be informed of his rights and of who bears the financial responsibility in the event of a problem. It is to be welcomed that the EP has also included in the new rules that tour operators are obliged to inform passengers in advance of the planned departure and arrival times and the nature of any additional costs that may arise.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. The new holiday package regulations will apply to two types of contract: those offered by operators or designed by the traveler and a new booking method, called "linked trips", in which the buyer is guided, for example after booking a plane ticket, to hire a new service, such as a rented car, via a link. This better regulation of package travel will allow travelers to have more cancellation options, and they must have in advance clear information about who is responsible in case of problems. Before the traveler acquires any contractual liability, the seller must make it clear that he is contracting a package and inform the user of his rights and which entity is responsible in case something goes wrong. In addition, consumers will be able to cancel their package trip and recover their money if the total price rises more than 8% or for exceptional and unavoidable circumstances at the destination. With the new rules, consumer rights are strengthened by covering new booking models and receiving detailed information about their rights, not forgetting the interests of the industry.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Package Travel Directive dates back to 1990 and is drawn up in view of the fact that the vast majority of Europeans book their holidays through travel agencies and not over the internet. It was important to have an update, adapting the Directive to the digital age, and strengthening consumer rights, such as terminating the contract if the price increase exceeds 8%, of being repatriated in the event that the tour operator goes bankrupt and receives assistance if something goes wrong during the holidays. Personalised journeys are not covered by existing rules or are ambiguously covered, so that consumers are not sure of their rights and operators do not know exactly what their obligations are. This update means that 120 million more consumers who purchase these personalised travel formulas will also be protected, according to European Commission data.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the rejection amendment on this text, because the resolution does not protect the consumer and the actors from abuses of a dominant position.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive sets out the objective of clarifying and modernising the scope of traveller protection in relation to the purchase of package travel and related travel services. The European Commission proposes that the operator should have the right to increase the price depending on fuel costs, taxes and exchange rate fluctuations, which clearly puts the consumer in a fragile situation. On the other hand, the organiser/retailer is obliged to provide insolvency protection in order to ensure the repatriation of travellers and reimbursement of payments made. However, this obligation only prevails for organised travel organisers and retailers offering the purchase of combined travel services. Despite all this, this proposal solves some of the problems that currently exist, since the Directive is obsolete, given the emergence of digital operators, which creates conditions of disadvantage for many SMEs in the sector, which is why, even if this proposal is not fully positive, in its current version which deserves the agreement of the Council and the European Commission, we voted against the EFDD group's proposal to simply reject the amendment of the Directive, which would make any improvement in the current situation impossible.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour, however with many reservations for consumer protection.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ major changes have been made in the last 25 years in the area of travel services, in particular online sales, and a thorough revision of the legal framework governing package travel contracts is therefore important. This review will benefit consumers, but also service providers. The review will bring more effective rules to protect passengers when the service provider is in breach, stricter rules for traders as long as the package does not meet consumer requirements, and last but not least, improving passenger protection in the event of impossible return due to unforeseen facts and circumstances.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tourism is a vital and fundamental sector for Italy and veneto, my region. I am voting to withdraw the proposal which, as is all too often the case, is against our citizens.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament rejects the Council's position at first reading, so I too agree with that position of the European Parliament. In particular, we must prevent unfair commercial practices by certain companies providing travel services which, during the provision of these services online, simultaneously provide other services in a vague, ambiguous and covert manner. For the above reasons I am voting against the recommendation for second reading.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it aims to protect consumers. Planning travel online is something millions of my constituents do every year and I am glad that they are now better protected. This recognition of digital provision for travel has been long overdue and I welcome its implementation.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. With the revision of the package travel directive, we have a much-needed revision of the 25-year-old legislation in this area. Too often, flights, hotels and rental cars are purchased on the Internet with a single click, and if one of the services fails, sellers like to claim that they were merely intermediaries. That must not be allowed to happen. Our citizens deserve better protection when they book different travel services with a provider. As Social Democrats, we support making travel providers responsible if parts of the package they have purchased are not delivered. For me, consumer protection is paramount, and that is why I fully agree with the directive.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The package travel proposal represents a positive solution for consumers and businesses. I strongly support more effective rules on insolvency protection for travellers in case of the trader’s insolvency; stricter liability of traders in case of underperformance of the package; improved pre-contractual information requirements and termination rights; and better protection in cases where the traveller’s return is impossible because of unavoidable and extraordinary circumstances. I believe that the compromise reached after a difficult negotiation regarding definitions of linked travel arrangements and travel packages represents a satisfactory result. It is very important that the definition of linked travel arrangements has been widened in order to ensure adequate protection for travellers. Moreover, I welcome the obtaining by the European Parliament of an appropriate review process by 2018 of these definitions by the European Commission, accompanied if necessary by legislative proposals, in order to verify ‘whether an adjustment or broadening of the definition of travel packages is appropriate’.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Internet sales have significantly changed booking patterns, so many self-organised journeys are now not subject to EU rules from the 1990s or do not clearly define passengers' rights. For this reason, I voted in favour of the amendment of the EU consumer protection rules on travel, as this will in future be subject to the same rules for organised travel booked online, including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals, as they are purchased at a travel agency. Under the amended rules, before holidaymakers sign the contract, tour operators or travel vendors must clearly explain that it is a package. In addition, the passenger should be informed of his rights and of who bears the financial responsibility in the event of a problem. It is to be welcomed that the EP has also included in the new rules that tour operators are obliged to inform passengers in advance of the planned departure and arrival times and the nature of any additional costs that may arise.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Directive because, given the changes in the tourism market and the growing tendency of consumers to book their holidays online, it was necessary to modernise and adapt the legislation to the digital age. The adoption of that directive strengthens the rights of consumers: first, by covering new booking models ̶ ̶-linked pages, package trips consisting of various travel services (flight, hotel or car rental) and purchased online will have the same protection as packages contracted from travel agencies, as such linked offers in which the customer's name , payment details and email address are transferred from one supplier to another and a second contract is concluded less than 24 hours after the purchase of the service, shall be considered as a package trip for the purposes of the law. And secondly, when receiving detailed information about their rights, travelers will have more options to cancel the contract, and must have clear information in advance about who is responsible in case of problems. They will also enjoy greater protection in the event of insolvency of employers.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Directive on package travel and linked travel services because it was necessary to modernise and adapt the legislation to the digital age. With the adoption of that directive, consumer rights are strengthened. First, new linked page booking models and package trips consisting of various travel services (flight, hotel or car rental) and purchased online will have the same protection as packages contracted from travel agencies; Combined travel for the purposes of legislation shall be considered as such linked offers in which the customer's name, payment details and email address are transferred from one supplier to another and a second contract is concluded less than 24 hours after the purchase of the service. And secondly, consumers will receive detailed information about their rights: they will have more options to cancel the contract and must have clear information in advance about who is responsible in case of problems. They will also enjoy greater protection in the event of insolvency of employers.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament recommendation for the Council second reading on the European Parliament and Council directive on package tours and related tourist services because I believe that the evolution of the market for tourist services offered online requires an adaptation of existing legislation.  I believe it is essential for the EU to put in place strong legislation that protects the rights of travelling consumers, combats unfair commercial practices and false commercial announcements and also guarantees public authorities. More transparency and more controls, therefore, for package tours purchased online. This is a complex issue because of the different notions of "tourism package" in different countries. That is why the European Parliament's push for greater uniformity of legislation is important. Important are the forecasts relating to the insolvency of the tour operator, the rights of travellers in terms of price reduction, compensation for intangible damage, extension of the deadline for filing complaints and non-compliance with the contract. I therefore call on the Council to adopt the package quickly and definitively at second reading, in order to put these guarantees in black and white to protect all European citizens and tourist enterprises themselves.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report on package holidays and related travel services today, as the rapporteur's approach and the Council's position do not go far enough to better protect consumers from unfair practices in this area.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have worked to protect citizens when booking travel over the Internet. An increasing proportion of trips are now booked online. Here, too, it is important to ensure that citizens are protected. For example, the unconscious booking of additional travel options must be prevented. This requires uniform standards and rules. At the same time, this must not lead to over-regulation of small and medium-sized tourism enterprises.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This was our Group’s (EFDD) motion, which I supported. The legislation aims to update consumer rights in the package travel sector. Last year, HMG’s report called these changes ‘far from perfect’, and the legislation specifically calls for the MAXIMUM harmonisation of this directive. I and my party reject this.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of the travel package proposal which guarantees more effective rules on insolvency protection for travellers in case of the trader’s insolvency; stricter liability of traders in case of underperformance of the package; improved pre-contractual information requirements and termination rights, and better protection in cases where the traveller’s return is impossible because of unavoidable and extraordinary circumstances.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The Directive regulating package travel was 1990. It was time to update European legislation to take into account the growing role that the internet plays in the configuration of citizens' travel, who no longer go so far to a travel agency but prefer to personalize their trips by hiring transport and accommodation on different websites. Today's new Directive clarifies and modernises the scope of protection for travellers who purchase combinations of travel services for the same trip or vacation, ensuring that they are better informed about the services they purchase and offering them clearer solutions if something goes wrong.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this report, a report that significantly updates and subsequently reaffirms basic protection for consumers when booking a series of travel services. In an increasingly digital age, it is imperative that we address the imbalance in protections and regulatory requirements between online and more traditional modes of transaction. Only once this is achieved can we move towards an increased single market in this sector and facilitate greater and more efficient levels of cross-border selling and buying. Improvements to the rules applying to national schemes of insolvency protection are also a welcome development in addition to the proposed deregulation in respect of business-to-business sales. When combined, this report will contribute to a more clearly defined and further-reaching package travel directive. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of the Council’s position.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the amendment, which rejects this proposal on package travel and related travel benefits as a whole. The text presented, which is part of the Digital Single Market, aims to harmonize legislation in the area of travel service providers that market their services online.  The main aim is to combat hidden, unclear or ambiguous additional services, for example, which aim to hide from consumers that certain services may not be booked. However, the text presented misses the main problem. It does not oppose the abuses of dominant position that have been gradually introduced by the most powerful digital operators. These abuses take the following form: the consumer who searches the Internet for a travel service is offered "arrow" choices, i.e. search engines give him answers from companies that are contractually linked to them. Sometimes the companies that are promoted in this way are themselves part of the same group of companies as the search engine. The result is that the most important economic players are obviously favoured at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the UKIP amendment, which prevented this legislative resolution from going to second reading. By not passing this amendment, and taking into account the legislative procedure, there was no vote on the report, but automatically moves on to second reading. This Resolution contains positive aspects such as consumer protection, more information and solutions regarding the contracting of travel and vacation packages. However, there are aspects that need to be improved, and that through the IMCO Commission, such as extending the scope of this legislation, resolving ambiguities in cases of tariff change, economic compensation, etc.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D)
text: Writing. With the revision of the package travel directive, we have a much-needed revision of the 25-year-old legislation in this area. Too often, flights, hotels and rental cars are purchased on the Internet with a single click, and if one of the services fails, sellers like to claim that they were merely intermediaries. That must not be allowed to happen. Our citizens deserve better protection when they book different travel services with a provider. As Social Democrats, we support making travel providers responsible if parts of the package they have purchased are not delivered. For me, consumer protection is paramount and that is why I fully agree with the directive.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My fellow Labour MEPs and I have voted in favour of this report. This report, ‘Package travel and assisted travel arrangements’, will guarantee more effective rules on insolvency protection for travellers in case of the trader’s insolvency; stricter liability of traders in case of underperformance of the package; improved pre-contractual information requirements and termination rights; and better protection in cases where the traveller’s return is impossible because of unavoidable and extraordinary circumstances. This represents a positive solution for consumers and businesses, ensuring better protection for both.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against  because I do not support the recommendation approval for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and linked travel arrangements, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Directive because, given the changes in the tourism market and the growing tendency of consumers to book their holidays online, it was necessary to modernise and adapt the legislation to the digital age. The adoption of that directive strengthens the rights of consumers: first, by covering new booking models ̶ ̶-linked pages, package trips consisting of various travel services (flight, hotel or car rental) and purchased online will have the same protection as packages contracted from travel agencies, as such linked offers in which the customer's name , payment details and email address are transferred from one supplier to another and a second contract is concluded less than 24 hours after the purchase of the service, shall be considered as a package trip for the purposes of the law. And secondly, when receiving detailed information about their rights, travelers will have more options to cancel the contract, and must have clear information in advance about who is responsible in case of problems. They will also enjoy greater protection in the event of insolvency of employers.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Internet sales have significantly changed booking habits, so many self-organised journeys are now not covered by EU rules laid down in the 1990s or do not clearly define passengers' rights. For this reason, I voted in favour of amending the EU consumer protection rules on travel, as this will in future be subject to the same rules for organised trips booked online, including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals, as they are purchased at a travel agency. Under the amended rules, before holidaymakers sign the contract, tour operators or travel vendors must clearly explain what kind of package it is. In addition, the passenger should be informed of his rights and of who bears the financial responsibility in the event of a problem. It is to be welcomed that the EP has also included in the new rules the mandatory pre-informing of the planned departure and arrival times and the nature of any additional costs incurred by tour operators.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal for a directive on package travel and assisted travel arrangements. I accidentally supported the amendment to reject the Council position at first reading and have since corrected my vote. It has become necessary to adapt the legislative framework established by the 1990 directive to online market developments, remove ambiguities and close legislative gaps given the evolution of the travel market and the ever increasing role played by the internet in how consumers research, organise and purchase travel products. This directive will increase consumer rights with stricter controls on price surcharges, a requirement to pass price reductions and compensation for non-material damages, etc., as well as covering business travellers under the directive so that SMEs and independent workers can also benefit from its protection.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report as such a level of harmonisation is in the best interests of EU consumers. The report strengthens travellers’ insolvency protection and also gives travellers the possibility of taking up an equivalent package when the organiser alters a main component of the package travel contract unilaterally. This considerably strengthens consumer rights and protection.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Internet sales have significantly changed booking habits. Today, many self-organised journeys are not covered by EU rules from the 1990s or do not clearly define the rights of passengers. For this reason, I voted in favour of amending the EU consumer protection rules on travel. Thus, in the future, the same requirements will apply to internet-booked package travel, including flights, hotel reservations or car rentals, as purchased at a travel agency. Under the amended rules, tour operators or travel vendors must clearly explain when a package is switched on before holidaymakers sign the contract. In addition, the passenger should be informed of his rights and of who bears the financial responsibility in the event of a problem. It is to be welcomed that the EP has also included in the new rules that tour operators are obliged to inform passengers in advance of the planned departure and arrival times and the nature of any additional costs that may arise.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The travel market has changed dramatically in recent years with the move towards online booking. A revision to the legislation is therefore necessary to strengthen the rights of travellers in Europe and bring new booking models within the scope of the rules. This is a positive proposal for consumers and businesses. It will guarantee more effective rules on insolvency protection for travellers in cases of trader’s insolvency and well as stricter liability for traders in case of underperformance. Importantly, travellers will have the right to cancel the contract and get a refund if the price increases by more than 8% or if unavoidable events strike the place of destination.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, since the adoption of the Package Travel Directive in 1990, the tourism market has developed impressively as a result of the opportunities provided to consumers by the widespread use of the Internet. Nevertheless, many of the tourist services provided ended up in the "grey zone".  The need for a review of legislation in this area is evident. I believe that the proposal to update the current European Union rules on holiday packages meets the needs of both consumers and businesses in this fast-growing sector, adapting this regulation to modern market specificities and removing legislative gaps. From a consumer point of view, the amendment proposal provides clearer protection for the rights of European consumers. Furthermore, the proposal for amendment establishes equal opportunities for operators by removing barriers to cross-border trade. I therefore support the amendment of the Package Travel Directive and believe that it will improve our economy by allowing tourism businesses to expand their reach while improving consumer protection through clearer and harmonised rules.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Writing. Tourism is playing an increasingly important role in Europe's economy, and package holidays are also becoming increasingly popular. The fact that this type of travel is booked over the Internet shows a high level of customer confidence in online services. New markets, above all, also means new challenges. For example, there has been a failure to show any additional costs incurred for so-called package holidays. This is where the directive creates legal clarity. All additional costs associated with a package holiday, as well as the option to opt out of these additional costs, must be clearly visible to the consumer. At the same time, the directive aims to ensure the functioning of a single internal market and is an excellent example of the European Union not only pursuing economic objectives, but also acting in the interests of the European consumer.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt parliament and council directives on package travel and related travel arrangements, amending Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013; 2006/2004 and Directive 2011/83/EU and the repeal of Council Directive 90/314/EEC, as this accepts the Council's position at first reading.  Tourism plays a key role in the European economy and is an important driver of growth in all Member States. I believe that it is necessary to raise the level of safety between traders and consumers and to improve the functioning of the internal market in this area. A level playing field should also be ensured and legal barriers removed so that the sector can develop in line with other policies and objectives of the European Union, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to harmonize national legislation on package travel and assisted or related travel benefits, as part of the creation of a digital single market. These package trips include a set of services offered to the customer at a fixed price by a tour operator. In particular, the proposal proposes to promote this activity on the Internet in order to stimulate the market. However, this report, such a centralization of the supply of related services, risks distorting competition at the expense of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which will not be able to compete with large groups.  I therefore voted in favour of the rejection amendment.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and my fellow MEPs have voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. I believe that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. With the revision of the package travel directive, we have a much-needed revision of the 25-year-old legislation in this area. Too often, flights, hotels and rental cars are purchased on the Internet with a single click, and if one of the services fails, sellers like to claim that they were merely intermediaries. That must not be allowed to happen. Our citizens deserve better protection when they book different travel services with a provider. As Social Democrats, we support making travel providers responsible if parts of the package you have purchased are not delivered. For me, consumer protection is paramount and that is why I fully agree with the directive.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE)
text: Writing. The ÖVP delegation in the EP rejected the EFDD amendment because we have achieved improvements for small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers have been given more protection. I was aware of the problems of the catering and hotel industry and, through constant exchanges with rapporteur Collin-Langen, the WKÖ, consumer advocates and stakeholders, I have listened to the concerns of the industry. As President of the SME Intergroup, I have organised an event with HOTREC to openly discuss the concerns of the local gastronomy and hotel industry. The entire burden of a balanced, practicable directive rested with the EP because the Austrian Federal Government did not have a common negotiating position and therefore failed in the decision-making process. It is not enough to oppose this. The EP was able to ensure that a package holiday is not justified until the tourist service accounts for at least 25% of the total package holiday. The clarification of what does not fall within the means of a tourist service is also a success. After three years, the EC will review how the Directive, and in particular the click-through provision, have been implemented and whether changes are necessary. Some poisonous teeth have been drawn from the directive, but uncertainties remain in the absence of a clear definition and too low a percentage for tourist services. Political room for manoeuvre must now be used to the best of its ability to ensure a practicable implementation for the catering and hotel industry in Austria.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the many advantages and objectives of the European Union is the unrestricted movement of people, goods and services across the borders of the Member States. Citizens are increasingly using the wide range of opportunities offered by the digital world, and this also applies to the purchase of travel on the Internet. However, it is very important for citizens to know their rights and opportunities when making such purchases. That is why, at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg, I supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council, which strengthens and extends the rights of travellers and obliges every traveller to inform each traveller in a transparent and comprehensible manner of their rights, thereby strengthening consumer protection. This proposal provides for clear provision of information before the traveller enters into a contract and purchases the travel package, so, in case of difficulties, the traveller knows clearly who will be responsible and what rights are applied to him. Travellers' right to terminate the contracts in question is also extended. This is an excellent benefit for EU travellers and also for the tourism industry, as the outdated regulation is being changed to transparent, uniform rules that will boost confidence and, consequently, trade.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I stood behind the Travel Package because it seeks to protect consumers as well as businesses by improving pre-contractual information requirements and termination rights, increasing the effectiveness of insolvency protection for travellers in the case of trader’s insolvency. Trader liability will be reinforced in the case of underperformance of the package and consumers will be better protected in the case of impossible return due to unavoidable and extraordinary circumstances.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Writing. The rejection of the EFDD amendment by me is based on the necessary improvements for small and medium-sized enterprises and consumer protection. I am aware of the problems facing the hotel and catering industry and I take them very seriously: in order to take into account the interests of these industries, I have been in close contact with rapporteur Collin-Langen. In addition, I discussed with numerous stakeholders from WKO, Consumer Protection and representatives of the sectors concerned. Since no common position could be achieved at national level of government, the responsibility lay solely with the European Parliament. We have now been able to ensure that a package holiday is only available once the tourist service accounts for at least 25% of the total package holiday. In addition, it is now also gratifying that the exemptions for the tourist service are clearly defined and clearly regulated. We are therefore on the right track! The review of the EC after three years will show how the Directive has actually been implemented and whether further adjustments will be needed. In any case, in the political discourse, I will continue to work for implementation in the interests of the catering and hotel industry, in particular with regard to increasing the percentage of the tourist service in the entire package holiday.

name: Stelios Kouloglou
text: (GUE/NGL), in writing. ‒ This report proposes a review of the existing regulation in order to strengthen the control of torture tools. The main points of this report are: the prohibition of online and offline marketing, to set up a regular reporting, to review the system by the European Commission and to consider that EU exports to third countries do not contribute to inhuman practices. Last but not least, the European Union will also have to update it lists with goods and substances which are banned for exports. I voted in favour of this report, since it improves the Commission’s proposal.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – If it is justified to introduce and maintain regulation at European level in a service sector, this is absolutely the case for tourism and related sectors. The amendment tabled by the EFDD proposes to reject the legislation, which is unacceptable to me because it is contrary to consumer protection principles. The regulation of tourism as a cross-border economic and welfare sector is, by definition, only possible at international level.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against this recommendation. The new provisions provide for the application of harmonisation rules, both to the online and offline sector, for business travel in the interests of consumers and businesses. Although the effort to make the rules in this area even more coherent is to be welcomed, I believe that the regulation for the protection of consumers and tour operators is already effective and does not require changes that would alter its current good functioning.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this text. This is a case of the EU responding and adapting to the changing and ever-modernising environment, where packaged sales and linked travel arrangements are becoming more and more popular. The new directive provides better consumer protection by setting clear standards on cancellation terms that limit post-contractual price increase to 8% (and establishing the right to cancel the arrangement free of charge in case of higher increases in price), ensuring the return of payments to customers in case of bankruptcy of a service provider though insolvency provisions, and so on. These new rules will protect the 120 million Europeans that use combined travel arrangements. The Commission estimates that the implementation of the new rules will reduce damages to consumers by about €430 million annually.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission is considering harmonizing legislation on package travel and "assisted" or "related" travel benefits to facilitate online travel services. This is therefore an increased implementation of the Digital Single Market. If such an initiative can be welcomed at first glance, this system is likely to lead to a number of negative abuses and externalities, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which will face increased centralization of supply that would support large groups (Google notoriously favours its partners and subsidiaries).  The associations are also critical, in particular, of the pressure exerted by the transport lobbies. However, the vote in this case concerns an amendment to reject the Council's proposal in order to avoid abuses of dominance and distorted competition for the benefit of large groups.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The vote here was on an amendment to reject the text.  This report seeks to harmonize legislation on package travel and "assisted" or "linked" travel benefits. While these easily accessible all-in-one travel offers are convenient for everyone, they distort competition in the holiday provider market. Indeed, this text seeks to facilitate the orientation of our choices in our digital searches, and to focus the attention of the consumer on predefined partners, highlighted by sites such as Google... All this is done for the benefit of large groups, and logically to the detriment of SMEs, which cannot align themselves with such a centralization of supply. Two factors, evaded from the debates, motivated my vote: the implementation of the Digital Single Market, which this report would strengthen, and the position of dominance and distortion of competition to the detriment of the smallest companies, which it would develop. For these two reasons, I voted for the rejection amendment, and therefore AGAINST the text itself.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Directive because, given the changes in the tourism market and the growing tendency of consumers to book their holidays online, it was necessary to modernise and adapt the legislation to the digital age. The adoption of that directive strengthens the rights of consumers: first, by covering new booking models ̶ ̶-linked pages, package trips consisting of various travel services (flight, hotel or car rental) and purchased online will have the same protection as packages contracted from travel agencies, as such linked offers in which the customer's name , payment details and email address are transferred from one supplier to another and a second contract is concluded less than 24 hours after the purchase of the service, shall be considered as a package trip for the purposes of the law. And secondly, when receiving detailed information about their rights, travelers will have more options to cancel the contract, and must have clear information in advance about who is responsible in case of problems. They will also enjoy greater protection in the event of insolvency of employers.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is part of the process of adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel services, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Council Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC. The Council proposal reflects Parliament's concerns that consumer rights should be harmonised in the field of this tourism regulation.  Therefore, our position is favourable.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The text presented to adapt the combined trips - those that have several elements, such as flight and car rental - and services assisted in travel to the digital age has been greatly supported by my political group for several reasons.  First, current legislation dates back to 1990, when the tourism market has changed enormously with the Internet and online bookings. The new regulations will guarantee travelers the same protection as if they had purchased their package trips from a travel agency. In addition, consumers will benefit from the coverage of new booking models, have more information about their rights and may modify or cancel their trips for exceptional reasons at the destination such as natural disasters, and still recover the money.  It is estimated that up to 120 million tourists who purchase package travel will benefit from the new regulations and that their losses will be reduced to 430 million euros per year.  I therefore consider that this recommendation fully complies with the objective of modernising the previous Directive and that is how I voted in its favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Tourism plays a central role in the European economy with 1.8 million mainly small and medium-sized enterprises, employing 5.2 percent of the total workforce. The European Commission has proposed to modernise the Directive to better protect travellers when purchasing packages and related travel arrangements. This would also ensure a better functioning of the internal market.  It is necessary, inter alia, to regulate the provisions on the content and presentation of packages and the issuance of their certificates and to determine the possibility of changing the prices of the arrangement. I supported Birgit Collin-Langen's report on the importance of raising passenger protection and strengthening trust in organised travel.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 It would certainly be more logical that this type of "ticks" — which marks any paid services on the company's online — are not automatically selected. If the consumer wants to choose one, he or she will do it for himself. While profit-making is one of the main principles of the existence of companies working with commercial practices, as well as in any other economic system, it must be carried out in conditions appropriate to the principles of law and fairness. The reputation of such companies and their profits will otherwise suffer, as customers will, at least simply, try to start using the services of competitors, even if they pay more and the unscrupulal company has a monopoly status.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the proposed Council Directive strengthens consumers' rights in the area of package travel for online bookings when consumers can put together the services requested. Requirements and conditions for prior consumer information are intensifying, the liability of traders and the protection of consumers against insolvency of organisers and service providers are increasing. Ultimately, transparency in the provision of tourism services will be guaranteed, unfair commercial practices by service providers will be eliminated and consumer legal protection will be increased.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 In my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 26/10/2015, I expressed specific reservations about this recommendation for second reading.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. We voted against this rejection amendment. If this amendment had passed the position of the European Council would have been invalidated and the procedure discontinued. This text proposes a harmonisation of legislation relating to package travel and 'linked' travel services. "Linked" means these services to which we are directed when booking trips. As part of the development of the Digital Single Market, this text would make it possible to make travel services as easy as possible at a "click-through range". Although starting from good intentions, this text unfortunately ignores the risks of abuse: in fact this strategy of "linked" services allows providers to favour their own partners and subsidiaries, thus distorting competition. We oppose this drift.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that as a result of this vote, package holidays, consisting of a flight, hotel or car-hire and purchased online for an all-in price or through linked webpages, will get the same protection as packages bought in travel agencies.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The tourism sector has changed considerably since the adoption of the directive in 2004. In particular, because more and more consumers prefer to purchase tours via the Internet, where the seller is able to assemble a trip precisely "tailored" to each individual customer, which, however, also entails a number of risks in the form of unclear, misleading or incomplete information provided by the seller of the products offered. The aim of the amendment to the Directive must be to increase transparency and ultimately to increase the protection of the client, i.e. the consumer. The Directive therefore introduces, for example, the obligation to notify passengers before making a payment whether they have chosen a package travel service or linked travel services and, in this case, the level of protection. I agree with the large majority of the elements contained in the amended text, e.g. that key information, such as on essential elements of travel services or prices, included in advertising materials, on the organiser's website or in the catalogues in the context of pre-contract information provision, should be binding unless the organiser reserves the right to change these elements and clearly and clearly communicates this to the passenger before the conclusion of the contract. Furthermore, the right of the passenger to withdraw from the contract should be clearly stated. I supported the text.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote against the amendment tabled by the EFDD Political Group, which proposed rejecting the Council's proposal, I intend to show my willingness to move forward with the legislative process of Mr Collin-Langen's report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report improves the legal status of holidaymakers, this is at the expense of disproportionately high additional burdens, in particular for small and medium-sized travel service providers.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The 1990 Comprehensive Travel Offer Directive (including transport, accommodation and other services) should be revised in view of the development of online offerings and the complexity of these offers. The proposed legislation oscillates between a desire to protect consumers and harmonization aimed at limiting "unnecessary" compliance costs for businesses. In the end, it helps to better inform travellers, especially about remedies and compensation in case of problems. But many cases are not covered by the directive, for example when the offer of transport plus accommodation is offered by a carrier (as is the case for SNCF). In addition, many loopholes persist: the overall supply price can be revised upwards if the price of fuel rises. An offer can be terminated at the last minute and without compensation if the minimum number of participants is not reached...  In short, the directive allows companies to continue to put the important details of their offer in small print, at the very bottom of the contract.  I abstain so as not to oppose the meagre progress contained in this text.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament approved the revision of the Package Travel Directive (established in 1990). This legislative update is of great relevance in an increasingly digital age, in which consumers are increasingly reserving trips over the internet. It is essential that there is enhanced adequacy and vigilance of consumer rights in a balance with the protection of freedom of movement.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As tourism plays an important role in the Union's economies, with around 10% of its gross domestic product, together with related sectors, reflecting the political agreement reached by the European Parliament and the Council with a view to the successful and prompt adoption of the Directive. The current rules on this issue date back to 1990, when there was no internet, airlines were not liberalised and the tourism market was mainly offered ready-made holidays. Today, however, according to statistics, almost a quarter of holidaymakers buy tailor-made holidays, with 35 per cent of all travel sales taking place online.
