I therefore consider it very necessary that the 120 million holidaymakers who buy tailor-made leave have the same rights as holidaymakers who opt for ready-made packages, which will ensure that the directive is adopted. It will also introduce much-needed legal clarity and certainty for businesses, throughout the Union market. The protection afforded under member states' rules will thus be more comparable, thus strengthening the basis for mutual recognition.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the improvement of consumer protection in the field of dynamic packages and the revision of the Package Travel Directive, but in my opinion the final text of the Directive voted on 27 October would lead to extra burden and bureaucracy for SMEs in Malta and create a high degree of legal uncertainty, especially due to the broad and ambitious definitions on what constitutes a package instead of improving the situation for consumers and SMEs. I therefore voted against the results of the second reading agreement of the revision of the Package Travel Directive.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. Tourism plays a central role in today's European economy. The European tourism sector, with its 1.8 million enterprises (mostly small and medium-sized enterprises) and the employment of 5.2% of the workforce, is one of the engines of growth in the EU. The European travel and tourism sector produces around 10% of the EU's GDP, including related areas. At the same time, the tourism market has made significant progress since the adoption of Directive 90/314/EEC.  In offering travel services, the Internet has become an increasingly important mediator. Many of the services thus offered fall within the grey area of law or are simply outside the scope of Directive 90/314/EEC. It is therefore necessary to modernise Directive 90/314/EEC in order to adapt the legal framework to the development of the market, to filter out ambiguous provisions and to close legal loopholes. To this end, the Commission has proposed the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council. The European Parliament has adopted its position on this proposal at first reading. In view of this, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection recommended that the EP support the Council's position at first reading at second reading. I voted accordingly on the draft.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The revision of the Directive on package travel and related travel services, which dated from 1990, was approved today. This recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading adapts this directive to the digital age and to the fact that 60% of consumers book and buy their holidays over the Internet.  Travellers using the Internet will now be better protected from their contract and should also have an emergency telephone number or a contact point with the organiser or travel agency. Strengthening your consumer rights also covers the issues of receiving assistance if something goes wrong during the holidays, being repatriated in the event that the tour operator goes bankrupt and terminates the contract if the price increase exceeds 8%.   I voted in favour of this proposal which Member States must transpose in two years into national legislation, and the new rules will apply six months later.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission is considering harmonising legislation on package travel and "assisted" or "related" travel benefits to facilitate online travel services. This is therefore an increased implementation of the Digital Single Market. If such an initiative can be welcomed at first glance, this system is likely to lead to a number of negative abuses and externalities, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which will face increased centralization of supply that would support large groups (Google notoriously favours its partners and subsidiaries).  The associations are also critical, in particular, of the pressure exerted by the transport lobbies. However, the vote in this case concerns an amendment to reject the Council's proposal in order to avoid abuses of dominance and distorted competition for the benefit of large groups.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The travel package proposal represents a positive solution for consumers and businesses. It will guarantee more effective rules on insolvency protection for travellers in case of the trader’s insolvency; stricter liability of traders in case of underperformance of the package; improved pre-contractual information requirements and termination rights; and better protection in cases where the traveller’s return is impossible because of unavoidable and extraordinary circumstances.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on package travel and assisted travel benefits. Developments in the travel market, including the growing trend in online bookings, called for the adaptation of the 1990 directive. The new directive broadens the definition of package travel to include most travel bookings including various elements (theft, hotel booking, car rental, etc.).  It includes "related services," for which the user's data is automatically taken up between the different stages of the booking by one or more companies with commercial links. The provisions passed will allow travellers who purchase package holidays online to enjoy the same protection as services purchased at a travel agency.  In addition, it will be possible to cancel a package trip free of charge if its price increases by more than 8% or if "inevitable" events such as natural disasters or terrorist attacks hit the destination. Three nights will also have to be offered to the holidaymaker when exceptional and unavoidable circumstances prevent his repatriation.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome this report, as the EU is once again bringing in consumer-friendly legislation on a subject that affects millions of citizens.  In our accelerated world, we increasingly choose to travel by browsing the Internet to select a destination, accommodation, plane or other vehicle, or other services related to freedom. This has already been recognised by the service providers, and more and more package offers can be found, often at a much better price than those offered by traditional travel agencies. What's more, you get all this from your armchair at home - with far greater choices than if you went into a traditional office. However, it is high time to strengthen consumer protection in this area as well. I therefore consider it extremely important that, under the new rules, service providers are obliged to inform the consumer in detail and transparently of all the terms of the contract, since clicking on the Internet can easily make surprising grand totals and that the customer can withdraw from the contract if the price of the package service is increased by 8 %.  In addition, in anticipated circumstances, you will also be entitled to 3 extra days of accommodation insurance for such bookings.  I think the European Parliament has done a good job with this report, because we have managed to make the original Commission proposal much more consumer-friendly in the negotiations.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this recommendation that will revise the Commission staff working document entitled ‘Guidance on the implementation/application of Directive 2005/29/EC on unfair commercial practices’. The Commission will inform Parliament on how its views have been taken into account when the revised Guidance is adopted.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this package as I believe it is in the interests of all Europeans to have a streamlined, modern and secure legislation on travel packages and arrangements. Tourism is one of the most stable and important sectors of the economy in all of the EU. Tourist numbers are only increasing across the board and revenues made from this industry are helping to keep tens of thousands of families financed. As more and more packages are trans-border, as more intra-Union and external travellers want to see more, to travel more, we need to have a full set of regulations that allow agencies, travel operators, transport companies and the tourists themselves a full range of options and modern terminology, protect their rights, ensure compensation and security and boost this sector of the economy. I believe this document makes an important step in this direction so I voted in its favour!

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that travellers who build their own holidays and buy accommodation or a ticket through linked websites, for example, will have the same right to protection in the European Union as clients of travel agencies. The new rules take into account the increase in the number of people taking holidays according to their needs over the Internet with interconnected service providers. For example, if passengers are guided through a web link to book additional services, such as car hire, after booking a flight, they will be treated as a package agreement. Organisers and retailers will need to make it clear to passengers that they are packaged and to inform them who is responsible in the event of complications.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – On the Collin-Langen (IMCO) ‘Package travel and linked travel arrangement’, I abstained. Whilst I acknowledge that there were positive aspects to this report, especially regarding improving and protecting consumer rights, there were lingering concerns, particularly on the level of harmonisation involved for implementation as it is based on the assumption that it is suitable for all 28 Member States. Also, at the European Council of Ministers during the summer Ireland withdrew its support, citing that it risks hindering innovation and competition. There are also data protection concerns, and the degree of compensation for consumers around cancellations of packages by a travel organiser was not adequately addressed.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report. Although the report improves the legal status of holidaymakers, it only improves the legal situation of holidaymakers, but only at the expense of disproportionately high additional burdens, particularly for small and medium-sized travel service providers.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Travellers who book a package online will henceforth be legally protected as those booking makers at a travel agency. This is a necessary step in a situation where the internet has become such a common option to buy trips.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.  It should be noted that the scope of the current legal regulation has become unclear and obsolete when online purchases are increasingly being acquired. New rules are therefore needed to make it easier and safer for passengers in the EU. Travellers must enjoy the same protection regardless of whether the trip is purchased at the office or online, and travellers will be granted the same protection. The EU must have harmonised common rules on mandatory protection for travellers. A high level of consumer protection is necessary. Particular attention must be paid to cases where travel operators or service providers become insolvent.   It should be noted that, in order to improve competition in this market, companies in the travel sector need to be treated equally. In addition, businesses should reduce financial and administrative burdens and remove legal barriers to cross-border trade.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for his work, However, I reiterate the need to better guarantee the protection of consumers who purchase online tourist services. I therefore voted against.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Each of us has at least once found ourselves in a situation of refusing a credit card or not being able to solve accommodation at the point of arrival at a destination, due to unforeseen circumstances. It may have happened to you that rent-a-car charges you insurance higher than renting a car without special explanation or on the grounds that you have not understood a service provider who is not the same company from which you rent a car, and who has not told you how you should read the lowercase letters on the website to which there is no link.  Such experiences are traumatic if you are several thousand kilometers from your home in a country where you may also have a language barrier. Although we Croats do not have the money for frequent travel around the world, I believe that the experience and service we offer in Croatia must be great for our guests, not traumatic because of the irresponsible behavior of tourist agencies. That is why I welcome this new directive and the improvements it brings towards consumers.  Unfortunately, it does not solve issues of protection of hoteliers' rights when cancelling last-minute tourist arrangements or fully protects the interests of this sector, which is a plume of Croatian tourism, which is why I think it is necessary to conduct a detailed discussion on tourism in the European Parliament.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission is considering harmonizing legislation on package travel and "assisted" or "related" travel benefits to facilitate online travel services. This is therefore an increased implementation of the Digital Single Market. If such an initiative can be welcomed at first glance, this system is likely to lead to a number of negative abuses and externalities, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which will face increased centralization of supply that would support large groups (Google notoriously favours its partners and subsidiaries). The associations are also critical, in particular, of the pressure exerted by the transport lobbies. However, the vote in this case concerns an amendment to reject the Council's proposal in order to avoid abuses of dominance and distorted competition for the benefit of large groups.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the draft directive because it seeks to establish clearer, more modern and effective guidelines for the protection of travellers and for providing information to potential buyers of travel packages. The most significant provisions are the possibility of protection for passengers from possible insolvency of the organizer in case of unforeseen circumstances, which would cover all reasonable foreseen costs and payments of passengers related to the package, and higher passenger rights and greater liability of the tour operator in cases of improper implementation of the contract, sudden price changes and the need for compensation in case of material and intangible damages.  In the event of incorrect implementation of the contract, the burden of proof is on the tour operator, as well as the obligation to find the traveller a suitable alternative arrangement, or to provide compensation within two weeks in the event that such an alternative arrangement is unable to offer. The proposal for a directive also provides for a clearer provision of pre-contractual information and information on the rights to terminate contracts to be provided to customers.  By adopting such a directive, we would provide our citizens with the opportunity to enjoy the rights that belong to them carelessly and less stressfully within the common internal market of the European Union, to move freely and deservedly spend their free days travelling and getting to know new countries and cultures.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. Tourism today plays a central role in the European economy. With 1.8 million companies, mainly SMEs, employing 5.2% of the total workforce, the European Tourism Industry is key to EU growth, as the overall contribution of European travel and tourism, including related sectors, accounts for around 10% of EU GDP. The Internet is becoming an increasingly important medium for the supply of tourist services, so it is necessary to adapt the legislative framework on the market, eliminate ambiguities and close legal gaps.  The proposed directive seeks to clarify and modernise the scope of passenger protection when purchasing a combination of tourist services for the same trip or holiday by bringing in its scope of various forms of online packages and travel arrangements. The report aims to ensure that passengers are better informed about the services they buy and provide them with clear assistance in case of difficulties. It also regulates the possibility and consequences of price changes, contains additional obligations for rights for the passenger and the necessary support of passengers, regulates the responsibility of the organizer and the obligation to provide assistance to passengers.  I support this report to improve the functioning of the internal market and achieve a high level of consumer protection through the harmonisation of Member States through legislative, regulatory and administrative regulations on packages and other combinations of tourism services.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Council Directive 90/314/EEC guarantees the right of consumers to receive essential information before and after the signing of a contract for the purchase of a travel package. Travellers are now increasingly interested in personally choosing all the elements of their tourism package, but the rules in force do not adequately cover online purchases. For this reason, the European Commission has proposed a regulation amending Directives 2006/2004 and 2011/83/EU and replacing Directive 90/314/EEC. The Commission's proposal lays down precise sanctions and clarifies the scope of passenger protection for the purchase of combinations of travel services (for the same trip or package) including different forms of online packages and organised travel. The new rules will cover the additional 120 million consumers who prefer to book their package tours online. I believe it is necessary to adapt the existing legislative framework to developments in the tourism sector in order to eliminate grey areas and fill regulatory gaps. In this way, the EU will be able to respond best to the demands of its citizens related to the use of the Internet in the tourism sector. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report concludes the negotiations between the institutions accompanying the second reading on the revision of the Directive on package travel, holidays and excursions. This directive has been in force for more than twenty years and is seen as an effective and useful tool for consumer protection in the travel and tourism industry. The revision of the Directive aims to adapt legislation to new practices in the tourism industry, m.in. moving away from comprehensive holiday packages for self-organised holidays via the Internet. Such reservations are not covered by the protection provided for by the Directive, for example in the event of a return of the consumer to the country in the event of bankruptcy of the travel company. The aim of the Directive is to resolve this conflict while maintaining the ability of online travel providers to innovate and offer consumers the best deals. That is why I supported the amendment, which will clarify and improve the situation of consumers, while reducing the burden on package organisers.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposed reform of the travel package. Its main content was its adaptation to the current digital era, which I consider to be an appropriate measure within the European single market. Many citizens of my country regularly use travel services, especially from neighbouring countries, and i therefore consider better consumer protection in this area to be necessary.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. As a result of the development of ICT and the emergence of new mobile applications, the production, distribution and booking practices of package and assisted travel have changed. In this context, the Commission has proposed a new directive to adapt the original European text to new market practices. I have approved these amendments that will provide a renewed legislative framework for this type of service.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that it is important to harmonise the rights and obligations arising from package travel contracts and related travel services in order to create a genuine internal market for consumers in this area.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. With the revision of the package travel guideline, we have a long overdue revision of the 25-year-old legislation. More and more often, flights, hotels and rental cars are purchased on the Internet with a single click, and if one of the services fails, sellers like to claim that they were merely intermediaries. That must not be allowed to happen. Our citizens deserve better protection when they book different travel services with a provider. As Social Democrats, we support making travel providers responsible if parts of the package they have purchased are not delivered. For me, consumer protection is paramount, and that is why I fully agree with the directive.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP has voted in favour of rejecting the Council position at second reading. Whilst we are great advocates of increasing consumer rights, we are against the full harmonisation that this directive requires. In 2014 a UK government report had stated that this proposal was ‘far from perfect’. UKIP believes that if national governments had the opportunity to update their own consumer protection laws they would be able to pass legislation that is the best fit for their consumers.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, the European Parliament voted on a directive that will allow the 120 million European citizens who book their combined trips online to have the same protection as those who book at a travel agency. The rules were until then enshrined in a 1990 law, a bygone era when the internet was not even born! The new legislation now takes into account the new way travellers plan their combined travel using new technological tools and erases this unfairness in the treatment of consumers.  Thanks to these new rules, the traveller will benefit from a whole range of rights in case of problems: repatriation and reimbursement in case of bankruptcy of the tour operator, taken care of by the organizer of 3 nights in case of an inevitable and unpredictable event such as a natural disaster or a terrorist attack that would prevent the traveler from returning home on time. Travellers will also be allowed to cancel their trip without incurring additional costs if their price increases by more than 8% or if the main characteristics of the trip such as the date of the trip, the flight schedule or the tourist accommodation category are significantly changed.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. While package travel has been soaring in Europe for more than a decade, it was necessary to update EU legislation on the practice of offering several services, including transport and accommodation, sold by package.  I have the well-favoured directive which aims to strengthen the rights of package travel consumers by offering greater flexibility in the cancellation of travel, particularly when the price of the package increases by more than 8%, and the obligation for tour operators to provide more information on the rights and responsibilities of travellers. It is undeniable that these measures will boost tourism in Europe and that is why I welcome the adoption of this text.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position on package travel and assisted travel benefits. On the contrary, I wanted this House to be able to give the green light to this text, which usefully modernises a 1990 directive, to adapt it to new ways of buying travel and to the growing trend of individual online shopping. Thus, in two and a half years, very concrete rights will apply to consumers who book themselves a flight, a car or a stay in a "package" without going through a conventional travel agency.  These include more information on rights ahead of the booking process, more protection against bankruptcy cases, the possibility of taking into account as a condition for the cancellation of exceptional circumstances, such as natural disasters or terrorist attacks, or the right to cancel in the event of an unjustified price increase (of more than 8%). Moreover, the economic interests of operators, travel agencies and hotels have been taken into account, with the reduction of certain administrative burdens and the interest of establishing uniform rules in the Union.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. It was necessary to review the legal framework governing package travel contracts. This proposal aims to clarify and modernize the scope of protection and information of travellers in the purchase of these services, improving their rights in accordance with the changes brought about online. The new rules will increase transparency and strengthen consumer protection over online travel services.  The Eurochamber has been able to ensure that the protection of travellers against the insolvency of the employer covers all reasonably foreseeable expenses and all payments made by the traveller in relation to the package. The rights of travellers have been clarified, in particular on price reduction, compensation (including non-material damage) and misconduct of the contract. The burden of proof has been shifted to the organizers. In addition, the deadline for filing a complaint has been extended by two years. In 2018, an adjustment to the definition of 'travel package' will be checked if necessary. For all this, among other issues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. From now on, consumers who purchase an airline ticket or travel services online will receive the same level of protection in the future as those who use a travel agency.  We have today definitively approved the adaptation of the package travel and assisted travel benefits directive. With this revised legislation, the rights of travellers in Europe are generally strengthened. New booking models are now included in its scope and travellers are informed in detail of their rights.  Among other innovations, this legislation provides for: - the right of the consumer to cancel a package trip whose price would have increased by more than 8% without justification; - the consumer's right to enjoy three nights of accommodation covered by the organiser if the consumer is prevented, for an unforeseen reason, from returning home; - consumer protection against the bankruptcy of package travel organisations; - the possibility offered to the traveller to cancel a contract without charge in exceptional circumstances.  Member States will have two years to transpose this directive into domestic law, which responds to the urgent need to modernise the old directive dating back to 1990.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. Tourism and, in particular, travel, including related sectors, account for around 10% of the Gross Domestic Product of the European Union. The adoption in 1990 of Directive 90/314/EEC on package travel recognised the importance of the rights of European travellers when they purchased package holidays, typically made up of transport and accommodation. However, it is 2015 - in the digital age and with a different and much more complex transport market structure than in 1990, when the Internet practically did not exist. With the widespread use and liberalisation of air transport, it has become essential to revise the Directive, giving greater clarity and breadth to its content and scope, as well as greater protection to European consumers in this segment of package travel and related travel services. In concrete terms, I stress the need for measures to adapt to the digital age, the rights of assistance and repatriation in the event of bankruptcy, the termination of the contract in the event of an unjustified increase in price, and I support this report which, in addition to sustaining an urgent revision of the Directive, also promotes regulatory harmonisation of the internal market and ensures the protection and protection of consumers and businesses.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on package travel and assisted travel benefits.  Package holidays may include a flight, hotel reservation or car rental purchased online by a traveller himself. From now on, thanks to this directive, these travellers will be able to enjoy the same protection as when they use a travel agency. Given the growing trend of online shopping, we needed to work on modernizing the old directive dating back to 1990.  The new text, adapted to our times, will strengthen the rights of travellers and their access to complete information, while taking into account the economic interests of travel agencies, hotels and operators.  This report represents the finalization of an agreement at second reading; States will now have two years to transpose these rules into national law.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the European Commission's proposal to introduce a new regulation to replace Directive 90/314/EEC and to amend Directives 2006/2004/EC and 2011/83/EU as I believe that this regulation is ineffective and comprehensive.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the UKIP amendment, which prevented this legislative resolution from going to second reading. By not passing this amendment, and taking into account the legislative procedure, there was no vote on the report, but automatically moves on to second reading. This Resolution contains positive aspects such as consumer protection, more information and solutions regarding the contracting of travel and vacation packages. However, there are aspects that need to be improved, and that through the IMCO Commission, such as extending the scope of this legislation, resolving ambiguities in cases of tariff change, economic compensation, etc.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resulting text of the Package Travel Directive because it is necessary to adapt the rules to existing trends in the increased use of the Internet as a means of taking holidays, from travel to accommodation to additional services, such as renting a car at the place of residence. Consumers who order travel services via travel packages and over the Internet will benefit from the same level of protection as those who use the services of traditional travel agencies. I consider the important provisions that have been enforced by the European Parliament, in particular, to provide clear and clear information on travel offer and liability in the event of complications, the possibility of withdrawing from the contract in the event of a substantial change in the terms and conditions, or a higher level of protection for passengers in the event of a return due to unavoidable and unexpected situations.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is part of the process of adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel services, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Council Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC. The Council proposal reflects Parliament's concerns that consumer rights should be harmonised in the field of this tourism regulation.  Therefore, our position is favourable.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Over the past few years, the role of travel agencies has been reduced as a result of the growth in the supply of cheap flights and sales of online package tours. The previous 1990 directive on assisted package tours is seen as an example of the success and usefulness of consumer protection for package travel. Since the way travellers plan and buy their journeys has since changed substantially, a revision of the legislation was needed in order to broaden the definition of "package tours" and include self-booked tourist services on the net. I therefore voted in favour of this reform, which will certainly provide consumers and travellers with greater protection, including the possibility of withdrawing from the contract under exceptional and unavoidable conditions, an opportunity that has not been provided for until now.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the EFDD amendment, which was a proposal to reject the Council position. As this was a second reading there was no final vote.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the travel package proposals because they represent a positive solution for both businesses and, very importantly, consumers. It will mean that there will be more effective rules on insolvency problems and guarantee stricter liability of traders in the cases of underperformance of the package.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Travel Directive is useful legislation for consumer protection. Due to the increase in the use of online commerce in this area, it needs to be revised. I therefore voted in favour of rejecting the amendment which required the European Parliament to reject the Council's position at first reading and to suspend the entire review process.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒The key task of the European Union is to create a regulatory framework to ensure sufficient protection for consumers to be able to travel reliably anywhere in the Union. At the same time, a level playing field should be ensured for travel companies in order to achieve as much market competitiveness as possible.  The Commission has proposed a review consisting mainly of clarification of the scope and definition of packages and 'assisted travel arrangements', information on consumer obligations and contract content, consumer protection rules against illiquidity of employers, rules in the event of a contract modification, etc.  Since the key point of my Political Group is to reach high standards of consumer protection, while avoiding complex provisions that threaten the situation of small traders in the travel agency sector, I voted against the proposal to abolish Amendments 1 by the Council in plenary. I believe that with this agreement we are able to strike a balance between consumer rights and the need to preserve small traders and we could remove the tradition of unfair commercial practices of "large" employers.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ tourism plays a very important role in the Union's economies, as evidenced by the fact that around 1.8 million mainly small and medium-sized enterprises operate there and employ about 5.2% of the total workforce. I also consider it no less important that tourism and its related sectors account for around 10% of EU GDP. I am glad that, thanks also to the Package Travel Directive and the agreements linked to travel services, the quality of tourism services has recently been increased. Unfortunately, we continue to see the fact that there are still tourism service providers that are abusing consumers thanks to unfair commercial practices. I supported the resolution because I believe that, in order to protect consumers across the EU, it is necessary to take measures to prevent tourism service providers from marketing services that offer in a hidden, unclear or ambiguous way. I believe that the higher quality of tourism services provided will increase passenger confidence and demand both inside and outside the EU, while increasing certainty, flexibility and choice. I also expect that ambiguities and loopholes in tourism legislation will be gradually eliminated, thereby confirming that the EU is the world's leading tourist destination.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. By amending the Package Travel Directive and helping to organise travel, we have made sure that consumers are better informed about the service they buy.  The Directive ensures that consumers obtain all key information before and after the signing of the package travel contract. They shall be given greater protection in the event that the price of a package trip increases without due reason, or if there are any other changes, such as the time of departure and arrival of the trip.  Consumers are also protected if the price of the whole package rises by more than eight per cent, because that is when they can choose not to go on the trip and the money is returned to them. Consumers are also protected in the event of the organiser's insolvency.  In the light of all the writings, I believe that the revision of the regulation is a good one, and I am pleased that, together with the Council and the Commission, after hard negotiations, we have managed to reach a compromise and come up with a good text of the regulation that will serve both consumers and businesses.  For the reasons set out above, I support the regulation and voted against the amendment tabled by the EFDD Group, which was intended to reject the position of the European Council and, consequently, the new regulation.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on package tours and related tourist services, which adapts a European directive to protect travellers dated 1990 to changes in the travel market, with particular reference to booking trips online. The revision of the legislation that we have passed leads to a significant strengthening of the rights of travellers who buy tourist services online. In fact, those who buy a tourist package on the internet with the formula "all inclusive" or through linked web pages, will receive the same protection as those who buy a tourist package at travel agencies.  In addition, travellers will be given more options to cancel a contract, through more information about their rights and who is responsible in the event of problems, such as the insolvency of the service provider. I particularly welcome the rapporteur's approach, which has combined consumer protection with the economic interests of industry, such as tour operators, travel agencies and hotels.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 Package holidays are offered holidays where various elements, such as transportation, accommodation and activities, are included in the price. There is already a European directive dealing with this issue, but it dates back to 1990 and is no longer current because certain market structures, such as the use of the Internet, are not included in the text. The new directive aims to ensure that there is a healthy balance between consumer protection and the need to protect retailers in this sector. After a second reading by Parliament, the text gives a clear description of these package holidays and of the differences with linked travel arrangements. This ensures a clear demarcation of the different sectors, so that consumers are informed in a more transparent way. For me, it was important that consumers remained protected, while at the same time avoiding that retailers, who often offer better and sustainable travel arrangements, are being overwhelmed by large companies that take over the market completely. Since this balance is included in the text, I support this directive. It is necessary, however, that all this is followed up so that these measures do not remain empty and are properly applied.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are responding to the expansion of the digital business and the associated new types of services. Customers will no longer be discriminated against on the basis of whether they order the service on a regular basis or via the Internet. I see this as an important step towards the completion of the single market.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I abstained in writing ‒ I abstained from voting on the proposal. While I welcome the measures aimed at reducing administrative burdens, I do not agree with the introduction of new regulations to 'protect' the customer. The best protection of the customer is competition on the market. However, increasing the regulatory burden increases barriers to market entry and thus ultimately damages competition. Moreover, any 'protection' is ultimately paid for by customers themselves, whether in the form of higher prices or in the form of lower quality services.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted against the recommendation for second reading on package travel and travel assistance. Nowadays, in the age of computerisation, we have a number of models of online travel bookings that are not covered by the existing 1990 directive. We therefore need a new directive covering all new and additional elements. However, we have done too little to address unfair commercial practices and the persecution of these. Online, we face providers offering their services in an ambiguous and vague way, thus misleading passengers. We should pay more attention to this, particularly in terms of detection and prevention.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament rejects the Council's position at first reading. In particular, we must prevent unfair commercial practices by certain companies providing travel services and during the provision of these services they also provide other services online in a vague, ambiguous and covert manner.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The tourism industry, unfortunately usually underestimated, is very often a generator of economic growth in most countries and has a significant impact on GDP levels. The European Union should therefore work for the development of this sector. One of the most important elements should be, firstly, support, mainly in access to external sources of finance, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. On the other hand, steps must be taken to deregulate the tourism sector. At the same time, it is important to bear in mind consumers of travel services who, because of the specificities of the sector, require special protection. As we know, combining all these elements and proper balance and maintaining symmetry in the entrepreneur-client relationship in the travel industry is extremely difficult.  I believe that the Council's position at first reading on package travel and related travel services was not appropriate, which is why I have chosen to vote against the recommendations for the Second Reading of the European Parliament, and I believe that in the future we will be able to find a compromise that takes into account the interests of both providers and recipients of travel services.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ In the 20 years since these regulations were introduced, the travel industry has greatly changed. Gone are the days when holidaymakers would visit their local travel agency and place faith in the comprehensive travel insurance on offer. Today people are using the internet to find the best deals, often doing so by booking many months in advance – it is a great example of the free market providing choice and competition. Consumers should, however, feel confident that they are protected in cases where a product that is sold fails to conform to what is ultimately provided, and against company bankruptcy. The measures outlined in this report deliver those protections and so I am pleased to vote in favour.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. It was time to dust off Eu-law. We wanted to ensure that holidaymakers combining their own "packages" holidays from travel services sold online are better protected because they do not have the same coverage as those who go through traditional travel agencies. This is a step towards better protection of European consumer rights

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this report, because I appreciate its contribution to the better protection of citizens who buy their holidays online. The aim of the report is to adopt a directive on package travel and linked travel arrangements, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC. The revised laws improve consumer rights, by putting in place stricter controls on price surcharges, a requirement to pass on price reductions to customers, compensation for non-material damages and refunds of all payments in case providers go bankrupt.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 A lot has changed over the course of these 25 years, including in the tourism sector. That is why I voted in favour of Mrs Collin-Langen's report. Consumers, thanks also to the rapid development of digital technologies, are always looking for customized combinations and products suitable for their needs and expectations. That is why we need to modernise European rules, so that all consumers are protected and can freely decide what type of travel contract to sign, without fear of incurring ambiguous or unclear clauses. The improvements to the text made by Parliament are very significant as regards the contractual and pre-contractual information at the heart of the measure. We need to ensure that people and users know what they are buying and what their rights are.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Recommendations for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assistance in the organisation of travel, I did not support the amendment of Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Directive 2011/83/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council and the repealing of Council Directive 90/314/EEC because it contains certain items which could provide additional services in a disguising, vague or ambiguous manner, such as hiding the possibility of not choosing additional services, to certain travel service providers marketing their services online.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the UKIP amendment, which prevented this legislative resolution from going to second reading. By not passing this amendment, and taking into account the legislative procedure, there was no vote on the report, but automatically moves on to second reading. This Resolution contains positive aspects such as consumer protection, more information and solutions regarding the contracting of travel and vacation packages. However, there are aspects that need to be improved, and that through the IMCO Commission, such as extending the scope of this legislation, resolving ambiguities in cases of tariff change, economic compensation, etc.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Two axes do not satisfy our positions and are prohibitive to the approval of the text: - the harmonisation of legislation and the implementation of the single market, especially through digital; - the risks of abuse of a dominant position and distortion of competition for the benefit of powerful economic actors. The text does not address any of these topics.  I voted in favour of the amendment to reject the text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since I agree with the proposal for a Council resolution, I did not support the EFFD proposal which I intend to reject.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the UKIP amendment, which prevented this legislative resolution from going to second reading. By not passing this amendment, and taking into account the legislative procedure, there was no vote on the report, but automatically moves on to second reading. This Resolution contains positive aspects such as consumer protection, more information and solutions regarding the contracting of travel and vacation packages. However, there are aspects that need to be improved, and that through the IMCO Commission, such as extending the scope of this legislation, resolving ambiguities in cases of tariff change, economic compensation, etc.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – Given that there have been significant changes in tourism, in particular with the increase in the number of internet users, it is clear that the existing legislation on package travel from 1990 does not correspond to the current situation. Today's consumers are increasingly interested in choosing different elements of package travel themselves, often from a number of dealers of related travel services, doing so online. This results in so-called 'grey areas' where consumers are uncertain about what protection they are entitled to when problems arise, but traders are uncertain about their obligations.  Also in Latvia, unfortunately, there have been cases where a traveler arrives at his destination, it is found that the promised hotel or service is far from what was promised. On the other hand, contacting the travel agency, especially if the trip was purchased on the Internet, reveals that it is bankrupt or unreachable.  I am therefore pleased that the renewed legislation will protect even more European travellers, covering those who reserve their holidays through digital media. These travellers will not only be better informed about their rights, but are also protected when there are unforeseen problems before or during the journey. The updated rules require that before the traveller enters into a contract, organisers and traders will have to clearly indicate what is included in the package, inform about the rights and also indicate who will be responsible for the various difficulties.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text concerning package travel and linked travel arrangements, as it brings regulation up to date with the developments in the travel market. The new rules will extend the protection of the 1990 EU Package Travel Directive to cover not only traditional package holidays, but also to give clear protection to 120 million consumers who book other forms of combined travel, e.g. a self-chosen combination on a website of a flight plus hotel or car rental, which is something very common nowadays. There will always be protection in cases where travel services are advertised as a package or when they are offered at a total or inclusive price. These provisions bring benefits to consumers, as they are expected to reduce damages to consumers by about €430 million a year due to the reinforced rights. At the same time, these provisions bring benefits to the businesses too, as they will reduce administrative burdens and bring down compliance costs for traders from €11 to €8 per package sold.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report is part of the process of adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on package travel and assisted travel services, amending Regulation (EC) No 2006/2004 and Council Directive 2011/83/EU and repealing Council Directive 90/314/EEC. The Council proposal reflects Parliament's concerns that consumer rights should be harmonised in the field of this tourism regulation.  Therefore, our position is favourable.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcomed this move, as it highlights the need for a European tourism sector that is sustainable, responsible and accessible across Europe. Tourism is a vital cornerstone of the Welsh economy, bringing in UKP 1 billion in Cardiff alone. It is crucial that consumer concerns in this area are recognised. Labour will continue to work with consumer groups, safety organisations and industry representatives to prevent rare but devastating cases where inadequate health and safety rules have led to tragedies, including deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning. We need to work hard together to ensure rigorous safety standards across Europe, so that all holiday makers can have the peace of mind that their dream holiday is not going to turn into a nightmare.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'European legislation on the protection of citizens who order package holidays or travel arrangements has been in place for some time. However, this protection did not yet exist for people who booked travel, transport, hotels, etc. separately, for example via the Internet. That is why I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The purpose is to ensure that the traveller, when purchasing related travel services, is protected in the event of insolvency of the operator providing the related travel service. The traveller will therefore have the right to be repatriated if the insolvency of the passenger transport operator means that the traveller is trapped at his destination.  Moreover, before concluding the contract giving rise to the related service, the operator must inform the traveller, by means of standard forms, that he will not benefit from the rights guaranteed by the Directive, except for insolvency protection. They are positive elements but that do not touch on the real problem of private monopolies in the area of transport that have come to occupy the public service and have become a siser of public resources to the detriment of the quality and universality of the service.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Although the report improves the legal status of holidaymakers, this is at the expense of disproportionately high additional burdens, in particular for small and medium-sized travel service providers.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text because I firmly believe in the importance of the Internet for the promotion of tourism. In order to develop this sector, it is necessary to protect consumers of tourist services bought online. We have clarified the rights of travellers in cases of price reduction, compensation for material damage and more. It is an important step forward in defining tourist rights in the digital age.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. With the revision of the Package Travel Directive, we have a much-needed revision of the 25-year-old legislation in this area. Too often, flights, hotels and rental cars are purchased on the Internet with a single click, and if one of the services fails, sellers like to claim that they were merely intermediaries. That must not be allowed to happen. Our citizens deserve better protection when they book different travel services with a provider. As a Social Democrat, I support making travel providers responsible if parts of the package they have purchased are not delivered. For me, consumer protection is paramount, and that is why I fully agree with the directive.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I agree with this report, because, indeed, the Internet is a tool that has a great impact today and has caused many business areas to have had to restructure their offer and even their activities, to adapt to this new digital age. Specifically, in the travel sector this impact is appreciated, as more and more people organize and book their trips through this tool.  With this, the type of trip has also varied, as the Internet offers the possibility to contemplate a much higher range of travel possibilities, which translates into fully customized packages. The problem is that until now there were no laws that completely covered this customer profile and this placed them in a delicate situation. That is why I think it is very positive that the EU has decided to update its legislation, as it will be very positive for European citizens because it benefits them and gives them security.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of this directive strengthening the rights of consumer-travelers when negotiating and completing tours. When negotiating and especially completing tours, the traveler goes completely into the hands of a travel agency, whether it is transport, accommodation or meals. I am convinced that a clear definition of what means by a trip, improving protection in the event of the insolvency of the tour provider or clarifying the scope of the information provided before the conclusion of the contract will not only lead to the satisfaction of travellers, but consequently also to an increase in the volume of tours.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the agreement reached by Parliament and the Council on a new framework for package travel, as the new directive adapts the old rules adopted in 1990 to the possibilities of today's digital market, when many consumers buy travel services on the Internet. In today's digital age, it is important that consumers who buy travel on the Internet are as well protected as those who buy them from travel agencies. Consumer protection will now apply not only to travel packages purchased from travel agencies, as has been the case up to now, but also to so-called 'package travel', which the consumer buys over the Internet, mainly through websites offering various travel services, such as airline tickets, hotel reservations and car rental. The same will apply to the services advertised and sold by the trader to the customer after he has already purchased from his essential service (e.g. an offer to rent a car that appears on the airline's website after buying a plane ticket). The new rules concern areas such as travellers' right to terminate the contract and receive comprehensive information on who should take responsibility in difficult situations. Until now, it was not clear from which operator to claim responsibility and how the traveller is protected in various problematic situations, and the new directive introduces more clarity.

name: Дамиано Дзофоли (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome today's vote, which allows us to take a further step towards updating the existing European rules, dating back to 1990, on package tours. Many products available today are not covered by the 1990 directive and in other cases remain in a legally grey area. Therefore, given the growth in the supply of cheap flights and online sales, which have changed the way travellers buy their journeys, new legislation is essential to protect customers who buy package tours online, so that they have the same guarantees as those who pass through conventional travel agencies. Among the safeguards that will ensure effective consumer protection, it is important to highlight the availability of all specific information before signing a contract and the possibility of cancelling a package in case, before departure, its price should increase by more than 8%. Thanks to the new directive, it will then be possible to extend the definition of a tourist package to include many services that can now be booked online but which were not included in the 1990 legislation.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal for a Directive expresses the objective of clarifying and modernising the scope of traveller protection when purchasing related travel services. The European Commission proposes that the operator should have the right to increase the price depending on fuel costs, taxes and exchange rate fluctuations, which clearly puts the consumer in a very fragile situation. On the other hand, the organiser/retailer is obliged to provide insolvency protection in order to ensure the repatriation of travellers and reimbursement of payments made. However, this obligation only prevails for organised travel organisers and retailers offering the purchase of combined travel services. Although the proposal on the table by the European Council and the European Commission is not entirely positive, particularly for those buying trips, we voted against the EFDD group's proposal to reject the amendment to the Directive, a directive that is obsolete – given the emergence of digital operators – and which puts SMEs in the sector at a disadvantage.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it introduces important innovations for those who package their own personalised tourist package, offering a greater guarantee to the user and defining the responsibilities of the seller. Among the improvements we find the cancellation of the holiday without penalty if the cost of the package increases by 8%, a maximum of three additional free nights if the return trip suffers delays due to particularly adverse weather conditions, repatriation and total refund in the event of the seller's insolvency. The travel package directive was necessary because the legislation in force dates back to 1990, when the only existing packages were those created by tour operators. Today, thanks to the Internet, the consumer can instead customize the package offered, choosing transport, hotels and other services, such as car rental, with the consequent difficulty of identifying the person responsible for the individual services within the package.  The new directive therefore covers packaged packages packaged by the tour operator, customized packages assembled by the consumer and purchased by a single operator and assisted organisation, that is, the combination of services sold by a single intermediary but as separate services, to which the principles laid down in the directive of twenty-five years ago are also extended.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I have just voted to ban mobile phone roaming charges. The new law will see a decrease in charges from next April by 75%, with a complete ban on extra charges in June 2017. This is great news for all of us and means that soon, when we travel within the EU, we can use our phone just the same as if we were at home. Recent research by uSwitch shows that currently one in six people holidaying in Europe came back to a phone bill that was GBP 100 higher than normal. So this change will make a big difference to all our lives. Labour MPs have been at the forefront of the drive to end this roaming rip-off. Soon all of us will be able to post holiday photos on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram without worrying about a huge bill. This is just one of the ways in which we in Britain are winning a better deal thanks to European action and highlights once again why we are better off in the EU.

name: Jens Rohde (ALDE).
text: Madam President! When we had the debate this morning, a number of colleagues felt that the agreement was not sufficient in the telecommunications package. The agreement on the end date for roaming came far too late in 2017, and that's true - Parliament proposed in december 2015 - and the net neutrality section was by no means enough. It was claimed that the agreement would even dilute the current net neutrality. With that argument, they used the agreement to table a number of amendments. It is just telling that if all the amendments – or rather, if only one of the amendments had gone through – then the agreement would have fallen and we would have had nothing. We had nothing about roaming, no end date and not a single word in European net neutrality legislation. And that is why I chose to vote against the amendments, despite . . .

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I co-signed and voted in favour of the amendments that would have guaranteed net neutrality across the EU. This was a unique opportunity for the European Parliament to make its power and its presence felt. It is important to say that there were some good outcomes from today’s vote: we will be putting an end to roaming charges, and I agree with my colleague, Jens Rohde, that we had to take a decision here in Parliament, but I am disappointed because I believe we could have gone further. We should have taken this opportunity to define net neutrality as the principle by which all internet traffic is treated equally without discrimination, restriction or interference, independent of its sender, recipient, type, content, device, service or application. Finally, it is important to say that Member States like the Netherlands can adopt regulations and enshrine net neutrality in their own domestic law.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Of course, I agree and welcome the abolition of roaming charges from 2017 and the decision of the European Parliament. Even the most hardline EU skeptics are obviously happy about this, and they also agree that, of course, there are decisions that must be taken at European level in order to make life easier and better for the people of Europe. What we disagree on is what the reporter said as a commentary on how wonderful the European Union is, because that is what it took to abolish roaming charges. We do not believe that an increasingly dictatorial, increasingly centralising European Union, which is extracting more and more sovereignty from nation states, is necessary to eliminate roaming charges. Why can't this be done in a much looser bond or in a cooperative way, and a number of other similar decisions.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I supported this report, which regulates the issue of the Single European Market for Electronic Communications. We often have a debate in our nation states about the benefits that the European Union brings to citizens, what specific benefits it brings to them. This is precisely an example of when the creation of a single market within the European Union, in this case the electronic market, benefits individual citizens. Citizens will not have to pay roaming charges from mid-2017. These fees have already fallen quite significantly, there will be none, and this is proof that the single internal market brings positive benefits to citizens, to consumers. Among other things, studies show that when a citizen in a foreign state uses the Internet, he uses a mobile phone, then uses these services much less precisely because of roaming charges. So the abolition of fees will also lead to greater use of mobile networks.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I also consider it very important that we decided at second reading today to adopt a regulation on the open internet and the rights of users of electronic communications services. This is particularly important from the point of view of consumers, finally, as has already been said here, the agreement on the abolition of roaming charges will apply, however late, but it will apply. It is a sure tax on the compromise that had to be built here. This is important so that we are able to build a digital single European market and that the European Union is competitive. I am also glad that the Eurosceptics recognise that, after all, without this agreement, the consumer in Europe would also be very impoverished, and that perhaps the European Union has an important role to play in this. I did not vote in favor of the proposals, which I considered important, for example, the definition of internet neutrality. I think that in the future there is scope, of course, to monitor the impact and improvements of this regulation.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent The innovations affected by this legislative resolution are undoubtedly among the most expected among the citizens of the European Union. While it was initially planned to abolish the roaming surcharge by the end of this year, it is now June 2017 that is the final implementation deadline.  In April 2016, prices for calls, text messages and internet data will fall even further. Roaming charges will amount to no more than a quarter of the current tariff ceiling. And that's good, and that's welcome! But within the community, travellers from European Union Member States will then no longer have to pay more than at home. Of course, the principle of free competition will continue to exist, and any user will be able to choose any provider that he or she enjoys, but it is likely that the number of people who buy different SIM cards will be significantly reduced. Of course, there are a number of issues remaining in the context of this plan, but this initiative is undoubtedly to be welcomed. Thank you!

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the agreement which I voted on and which we have just adopted enshrines an idea of Europe, the Europe which removes barriers to communications between citizens, a united Europe. Thanks to this agreement we will say goodbye to roaming. This will benefit citizens in their travels in Europe, but it also opens doors for our companies for the development of applications and services. This agreement also enshrines net neutrality. I wish the concept had been picked up. However, if we have to choose between words and principles, I choose to enshrine the principle of net neutrality, of equal and non-discriminatory treatment, which is precisely what the report contains. We are therefore facing a step forward in a commitment to the digital leadership of the European Union.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this is my last contribution right now. So I think it is a good one because this is a day of celebration – celebration for the European Union, because we have shown very clearly that, when we work together, we can do so for the benefit of all citizens of Europe – and indeed all businesses – and particularly, as has been said, we are saying goodbye to roaming. This is something we have fought long and hard for, and it shows also the power of the European Parliament and the European Union that it can take on big businesses and defeat them for the benefit of consumers, because the roaming charges, which were excessive, are now going to end in 2017. That is certainly something to celebrate. Also, as my colleague and rapporteur Pilar del Castillo said, it guarantees open internet, equal access and protects consumers. People have different views on net neutrality, but that is also enshrined in it from our point of view and I think most people agree with that.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, since 1999 when UKIP MEPs first arrived at the European Parliament, we have never voted in favour of EU legislation, in favour of giving powers to Brussels. Regarding roaming charges, may I just say that, contrary to the belief that only the EU can achieve this, it simply is not true. I use Three for my mobile phone. During the summer I went to the USA and was able to use every feature on my phone at no extra cost. I travelled to five different states, yet despite the fact that America is not in the EU, Three was able to get a roaming-free deal across America. Why do we need the EU to legislate on this? There are always unintended consequences to legislation. Being forced to lose a lucrative revenue stream, the telecoms companies will recoup these costs from those who do not have the privilege of a jet-set lifestyle.

name: David Coburn (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, depending on your phone company, there may be no roaming charges at all – and that includes places like Australia – but that very much depends which company you are using. That, for the socialists among you, is the free market in action.  Market forces, not state intervention, better regulate the market. If the state – or indeed a socialist superstate, this one in particular – regulates the jet-setters’ phone calls, the lost profits may well be transferred elsewhere, namely, to the poor soul on the Clapham omnibus or the Edinburgh tram. Ill thought—out consequences come from interfering in the free market. UKIP is utterly opposed to interfering in the free market.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, what do Australia, Indonesia, Hong Kong, the USA, Israel, Switzerland, Macau, New Zealand and Sri Lanka have in common? I can call back to the UK from any of those countries free of charge from my mobile phone already. In fact, there are more non-EU than EU countries on the list of countries where I can do that. It is based on consumer demand; it is based on the free market; it responds to the needs of consumers. I can do the same from Italy, France and Spain, within the European Union. Why? Because they are countries where the consumer demand exists. But I cannot do that from Brussels. I cannot do that from Belgium, because frankly the needs of the MEPs are not quite enough to sway that with consumer demand just yet. By legislating on this, what we end up doing is we force companies to do something where there is not the demand, which is uncompetitive. When you force companies to do something which is uncompetitive, you put prices up for everybody. That is not right, it is not fair for the average person on the street, and yet Labour still use that as example of why they think the EU is a good thing.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. The European Parliament voted today on a new EU law prohibiting additional roaming charges for mobile use in other EU countries. It is a welcome message for the citizens of Europe, who will now not be hit by sky-high bills simply because they happen to cross the border between two Member States.  The new telecoms package also includes rules on access to fast internet and so-called net neutrality (open internet). The law ensures that we will not get the internet at two speeds (blocking or slowing down the internet for a particular content is banned) and thus forces internet service providers to treat traffic on equal terms. I voted in favour of the package as a whole, because it takes into account the citizens' right to an open and free internet, while preserving the possibility for certain services (such as emergency services) to take precedence as long as they are not provided at the expense of the quality of the open network.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The legislative proposal 'European single market for electronic communications' has been sold to citizens as a great step forward, as the end of roaming costs and as the much-awaited neutrality of the Internet. The reality is not like this: first of all there is no motivation to postpone everything to 2017, other than to take more time. The roaming changes clothes, in fact, companies will be allowed to "spread" it on all users and in case you exceed the stay abroad of the specially created "average user" will become chargeable to the individual user. Net-neutrality no longer exists, there will be a lucky few (the Big ones of the network) who will enjoy a fast band, while the others will only have to resign themselves. To this follows the possibility for the manager to "censor" any page by degrading it to its own unquestionable "liking" to the slowest band. The amendments voted on were mainly aimed at affirming the neutrality of the Internet and eliminating ambiguous or openly negative exceptions. My vote on these amendments was positive, but unfortunately they were all rejected.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report represents the final approval at first reading of the Council's position on the European single market in electronic communications. This proposal authorises the final approval of an act which will have a significant impact on the Member States of the Union since it harmonises electronic communications regulations. However, this harmonization is done without sufficient guarantees to allow net neutrality and allowing abuses by operators, such as roaming fees. This is why our position is contrary to this approval.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was broken into two parts. The first part was a vote to reject the Council’s position and the second part consisted of 12 Amendments, which I co-signed, to reinstall crucial definitions and references to the principle of net neutrality throughout the text. I voted in favour of all parts. My reasons for rejecting the Council’s position were that during the course of negotiations, the text of this report was significantly watered down. The abolition of roaming charges initially foreseen for December 2015 was postponed until June 2017.
