On top of this, all references to net neutrality were deleted from the text, leaving the door completely open to a two-speed internet, an internet that would allow ISPs to discriminate between internet traffic to the detriment of smaller companies, newspapers and blogs. As the Council’s position was completely inadequate in terms of protecting net neutrality and respecting the need to abolish roaming charges as early as possible, I voted to reject it.

name: Max Andersson (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the amendments protecting net neutrality and against the proposal because I am concerned that net neutrality risks being undermined by this decision. I care for an open internet where companies and people are treated equally.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question is a recommendation from the European Parliament on the regulation of the activities of Internet service providers and the end of roaming charges within the Union. In this recommendation, Parliament returns to the Council's position.  Two aspects are to be noted: 1. part of the text aims to eliminate roaming charges, which are imposed on consumers when they make communications from abroad. I voted in favour of abolishing them from 2017, with the understanding that consumers will not be able to abuse them by subscribing to subscriptions in a Member State where they are not domiciled and where these subscriptions are less expensive. Thus, the removal of roaming charges is accompanied by exceptions that will allow operators to limit this use so that they are not penalized; 2. Another part of the text is supposed to defend "net neutrality". However, in many respects, it is not being respected. ISPs will be able to discriminate between encrypted and unencrypted files, between online television and other video platforms, etc.  I therefore voted in favour of amendments that guarantee net neutrality.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it aims to ban roaming rights for mobile telecommunications and fair access to the internet.  I welcome the vote on this measure, which has been demanded by European citizens for many years. Finally!

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ˗ abolish the roaming charge. The updated rules provide that, from June 2017 on, the Commission will be able to provide a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. The EU will abolish the roaming charge. They also propose to restrict the ability of internet access service providers to block or slow down the operation of competitors' applications. From 15 June 2017, mobile operators will not be able to apply an increased tariff for mobile phone calls, text messages and data transmission when they go to another EU country. For its part, as of 30 April 2016, the maximum allowable allowance per minute of a call abroad will not exceed €0.05, ˗ €0.02 per message, and a megabyte of data transmitted ˗ €0.05. The new rules will, at the same time, oblige internet service providers to manage all traffic in the same way, i.e. not to block or slow down the activities of certain senders or recipients or the applications they use, unless it is necessary for court decisions, while maintaining network security and combating cyber attacks.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. As far as a second reading was concerned, there was no final vote on the text itself, but only on the amendments. However, let us recall the overall objective: a revision of the regulation on the regulation of the activities of internet service providers and, in particular, the end of mobile internet roaming charges in the EU, which is a good thing. However, the first aspect of the regulation is rightly challenged by many consumer associations. Indeed, it allows ISPs to grant preferred flows - paying - to companies. However, national regulators will have very little leeway against this practice. This calls into question the principle of "net neutrality" which requires that all flows and speed of access to all sites be treated indiscriminately.  I therefore voted in favour of all the amendments aimed at guaranteeing this neutrality, which were ultimately rejected by the votes of the EPP and S-D MEPs, i.e. by the European UMPS...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Despite some weaknesses, I support the agreement reached with the Council on the Single Market for Electronic Communications as it brings great progress in the perspective for the consumer. Indeed, we have secured an end to roaming charges for calls, SMS and data in the EU for July 2017. We have also guaranteed net neutrality in this agreement by ensuring a non-discriminatory, transparent open internet with clear rights for end-users. Under the agreement, blocking, degradation or discrimination of online content will be prohibited and exceptions to this general principle will be well defined, for example, to counter a cyber attack and prevent traffic congestion.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. The proposed regulation aims to put in place harmonised rules to ensure access to an open internet, protect users' rights and eliminate additional roaming charges.  In particular, I voted in favour of the many amendments aimed at strengthening net neutrality.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this text. It is certainly a step forward from the current costs that European citizens have to bear when they find themselves using their roaming operators, but the fact remains that roaming costs will not be completely eliminated as the sustainability clause will remain, which will allow each operator to charge a surcharge to the extent necessary to recover the costs of providing services.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Roaming charges have acted in recent years as a tax on the free movement of persons, a kind of extraprofit, and the European Parliament has been pushing for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. Abolishing roaming charges is the dismantling of the tax that hinders the free movement of people, the first step towards a common Europe! With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality Internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. Internet access gives SMEs equal opportunities throughout the EU. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I have long advocated internet liberalisation, which is why I voted AGAINST the proposed recommendation to confirm the Council's position and thus to ensure net neutrality.  Unfortunately, the decision taken by the majority is, in my view, affordable for the principles of the free market and, potentially, free access to information, two principles on which today's European Community stands. It must strive towards a single market and not a fragmented telecommunications market. In addition, the decision taken also means a lower standard currently in force in Slovenia, where net neutrality is prescribed by law. The decision taken thus gives internet access providers the possibility of selectively controlling internet traffic to the end-user, thus putting at the forefront the commercial services which they market themselves. I also find it inappropriate to find the fact that the Regulation on roaming on public communications networks in the European Union has also found itself in the same document, which in 2017 finally eliminates so-called roaming in the EU, which, of course, I strongly support.  However, such regulation of the mobile telephony sector should not be an excuse for the simultaneous adoption of an unspoied and harmful directive in the field of electronic communications surveillance.  That is why I supported the amendments rejecting the Council's position or unambiguously guaranteeing internet neutrality.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal on the single market in electronic communications, which I strongly support, during its long process that began in 2013 has seen the European Parliament show a great determination, the fruits of which we are finally reaping today. The abolition of roaming charges and the network access guarantees provided for in the document have been found to have a widespread positive effect on consumers, small and medium-sized enterprises, start-ups and different organisations. The abolition of roaming charges will follow a gradual path leading to their final cancellation in mid-2017 (15 June 2017). After that date, all European consumers will see the same price applied, whether in their country of origin or travelling to Europe, for calls, SMS and mobile data. Supporting today's vote is an important step towards implementing the Digital Single Market Strategy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Parliament was put in a position where they had to decide whether to accept roaming and vaguely determined net neutrality or accept nothing, so the whole process will take several more years. Roaming is a big project that will make consumers great savings. The Commission estimated that the decrease in profits that teleoperaters will experience will actually be bexed by the fact that a large number of consumers will only now start using roaming.  Due to the unpleasant surprises that knew how to greet us all on the bill upon returning from our trip, most of us relied on wireless internet in cafes and hotels. The amendment is of great importance for the Common Digital Market project and that is why I nevertheless supported the proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation aims to put in place, among other things, harmonised rules to guarantee access to an open internet, the protection of users' rights and the elimination of additional roaming charges.  I voted in favour of many amendments to strengthen net neutrality.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was broken into two parts. The first part was a vote to reject the Council’s position and the second part consisted of 12 Amendments, which I co-signed, to reinstall crucial definitions and references to the principle of net neutrality throughout the text. I voted in favour of all parts. My reasons for rejecting the Council’s position were that during the course of negotiations, the text of this report was significantly watered down. The abolition of roaming charges initially foreseen for December 2015 was postponed until June 2017. On top of this, all references to net neutrality were deleted from the text, leaving the door completely open to a two-speed internet, an internet that would allow ISPs to discriminate between internet traffic to the detriment of smaller companies, newspapers and blogs. As the Council’s position was completely inadequate in terms of protecting net neutrality and respecting the need to abolish roaming charges as early as possible, I voted to reject it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of approving this document because I believe that the introduction of this regulation is a fundamental step towards the completion of the single market, which will safeguard access to an open Internet, protect users' rights and put an end to roaming surcharges.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Finally, following the successful outcome of the work of the ITRE Committee and the long interinstitutional negotiations, it is possible to harmonise the rules aimed at safeguarding free access to the Internet, protecting users' rights and putting an end to the unfair surcharges of international roaming.  Thanks to this vote, the EU, for the first time, can have legislation that establishes net neutrality and limiting the risks of arbitrary blocking or throttling on the private connections of European citizens. Although full protection of the ultimate net neutrality and complete equal treatment of private connections is still to be achieved in their entirety, the measure represents an important milestone and a stimulus to greater commitment to respect for digital citizenship and net neutrality in Europe.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to revise the regulation on the regulation of the activities of internet service providers and the end of mobile internet roaming charges in the EU. The text will give providers the opportunity to give companies better internet access. This proposal therefore calls into question the principle of "net neutrality" that all flows and speed of access must be treated indiscriminately.  Even if the rapporteur advocates abolishing roaming charges, it is essential to understand that this proposal is part of the data economy package that will introduce a single European regulator in place of ORECE. This will lead to a horizontal concentration of the market, with a reduction in the number of players at the expense of the purchasing power of consumers.  I therefore voted against rejecting the Council's proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The field of communications has been a challenge for the European Union in the steps taken to create a common area of trade and to provide its citizens with equal rights as consumers and beneficiaries of services. It is inconceivable in this century that European regulations do not include uniform policies on telephone and internet services, which are even the most widely used means of communication between Union citizens.  I support these policies which provide for ensuring access to the open internet for all citizens and eliminating all roaming charges on public mobile communications networks. I also support the legal framework within which these policies will be implemented, with gradual regulation necessary, which does not lead to an economic imbalance in the sectors of the providers of these services, but which support step by step the aim of removing all financial communication obstacles within the EU. I voted in favour of achieving such objectives, considering the need for the creation of a transit framework, which is achieved precisely by introducing harmonised rules guaranteeing access to open internet, protecting users' rights and eliminating surcharges for roaming services.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is no final vote at second reading. The regulation eliminates roaming from 15 June 2017 unless sustainability clause. In any case, the total cost may not exceed 0.19 cents for calls made, 0.60 cents per SMS and 0.20 cents for data.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the importance of the implementation of the European Single Market for the profound development of all Member States, I believe that the achievement of a European single market for electronic communications is in line with the principles of the Union. In accordance with Article 3 of the Treaty of the European Union, the Union establishes an internal market. It acts for the sustainable development of Europe, based on balanced economic growth and price stability, a highly competitive social market economy that aims towards full employment and social progress, and a high level of protection and improvement of the quality of the environment. One of the key things provided for in this article is the promotion of scientific and technical progress. I believe that this promotion can only be achieved in the context of a universal service within the EU that gives the same rights to users of communication and the Internet. I therefore support the second reading of the report on the European Single Market for Electronic Communications.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the creation of a single European market for electronic communications.  This text will allow the total elimination of roaming charges from 2017. The cost of telephone communications from one Member State to another will then be similar to the cost of national communications.  It was the European Parliament that, in negotiations with the Member States, insisted on the elimination of roaming charges. This regulation directly benefits European citizens and is a significant step forward in the establishment of a coherent and effective single market.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down measures concerning access to an open Internet. Indeed, I am convinced that obtaining 'harmonised rules to safeguard access to an open Internet, to protect users' rights and to put an end to roaming surcharges' means giving due weight to freedom of expression and ensuring a solid basis for a 'European social area', now based on the mobility of people and the mobility of their communications, which must take place in a context of net neutrality. In any case, the tortuous path does not escape: international roaming has in fact obtained a regulation by means of a different, cautious and progressive path compared to the other areas of the ITCs. It needed support from the parallel development of a "European consciousness", oriented towards promoting, by all means, digital data flows.  For European legislation that is protective and that exalted growth, transparency of processes, legal clarity, uniform application of the legislative framework, equal operating conditions and – in this case – net neutrality are therefore imperative.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was broken into two parts. The first part was a vote to reject the Council’s position and the second part consisted of 12 Amendments, which I co-signed, to reinstall crucial definitions and references to the principle of net neutrality throughout the text. I voted in favour of all parts. My reasons for rejecting the Council’s position were that during the course of negotiations, the text of this report was significantly watered down. The abolition of roaming charges initially foreseen for December 2015 was postponed until June 2017. As the Council’s position was completely inadequate in terms of protecting net neutrality and respecting the need to abolish roaming charges as early as possible, I voted to reject it.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it outlines provisions such as the abolition of the roaming charges, greater protection of consumer rights and higher quality digital services which bring us closer to full implementation of the Digital Single Market strategy.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The key content of the report is internet roaming and neutrality. In the latter respect, the text avoids directly addressing the essential issue of net neutrality; Instead, it replaces it with an ambiguous and indefinite concept of 'open access', stuffed with exceptions, which does not offer European citizens the necessary guarantees of identical treatment of all services circulating on the network.  It therefore opens up the possibility of reinforcing the already predominant positions of large operators and service providers, and of comparatively obscuring certain content providers by means of disadvantage. In fact, it creates the possibility of offering 'privileged lanes' on the Internet, on the sole basis of the commercial exploitation of the network: we deviate from the public service character, offered on equal terms to all service and content providers, which should distinguish the Internet. That is why we voted in favour of all the amendments tabled in plenary, because they focus above all on affirming the neutrality of the Internet and on eliminating ambiguous or openly negative exceptions.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the adoption at second reading of the draft regulation on the single market for electronic communications. In my opinion, this text is an ambitious reform of electronic communications.  Among the provisions included in this text, I welcome the abolition of telephone surcharges for calls in Europe. The end of roaming will significantly change our communication habits and make it a little easier for citizens to move around our common space.  With regard to net neutrality, the text seems to me to achieve a satisfactory balance, since it allows the development of innovative services while introducing a binding principle for operators and well-framed traffic management rules.  In general, this reform will only be fully satisfactory once measures are followed to deploy broadband in the EU and, above all, to rethink the accountability regime for digital platforms. Only such a framework will ensure fair competition between all players in the digital market.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I supported the proposal because I made a promise to my voters that we would end roaming in Europe, and today we did just that. Could the law have been better? Yes. I regret that the Council did not accept to make it 100% clear that net neutrality must be respected in Europe and by all companies. But I believe the overall package is better than no package at all which would have happened if we had adopted the amendments. This is why, while I agree with the ideas included in the amendments tabled, I had to abstain during the votes. But rest assured the fight for better protection of the consumers on the internet is not over.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would have liked to vote for a stronger regulation reform today, but this was the only possible compromise on the table to get EU wide progress. That is why I chose not to block the compromise struck between the institutions. Conservatives in Parliament tend to raise the banner of freedom to do business without hindrance across the EU’s national borders, but drag their feet when the profits of big providers are at stake, even when they make no more economic or legal sense. It has taken the S&D group many years of persuasion to introduce progressive roaming caps in successive EU regulation reviews for us to finally have a deadline to scrap roaming, including a final reduction between 2016 and June 2017. Still, we had to accept fair-use caveats and special circumstances where companies may need to be able to recover costs, as EU governments insisted. We managed to impose equal internet traffic treatment across all 28 EU countries. National regulators will be empowered to ban the advantage given to certain, select apps when mobile operators charge consumers no cost for their data use. I am confident we will be able to evaluate, build upon and strengthen this reform soon, as innovation in the sector is only bound to accelerate.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome and reward the initiative of the Commission and the European Parliament to proceed with the abolition of roaming charges

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the EFDD Group's proposal to reject this measure. This regulation helps to enhance the role of ICT, which is responsible for 50% of productivity gains in all sectors in recent years and the creation of five jobs for every two lost, as a key element in smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.  In order to achieve a single market in electronic communications, citizens and businesses must have access to electronic communications services wherever they are provided in the Union, without cross-border restrictions or unjustified additional costs. Companies providing electronic communications networks and services can operate and provide their products and services, regardless of their place of establishment or that of their customers in the EU.  The regulation promotes the harmonisation of rules aimed at safeguarding access to an open internet, putting an end to the inconvenience caused by the roaming surcharge. A single market in electronic communications can stimulate competition, investment and innovation, thereby increasing competitiveness in infrastructure and price quality.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it thinks big, as this Europe needs to do. Beyond the headlines, which focus only on net neutrality and the abolition of roaming, the proposal deals in detail with one of the major issues relating to the internal market: the creation of pan-European players in the telecommunications market. We are playing a big part of our future in this sector, and we cannot break the market further into small pieces, but we need large, solid and investment-ready companies. Broadband is a highway that needs to be built, and the e-commerce that will come with it is the greatest possibility for our excellent businesses. Finally, I would like to congratulate Mrs Pilar del Castillo Vera on her work.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal aims to adopt measures concerning open internet access. It also aims to amend Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users’ rights relating to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile communications networks within the Union. The regulation seeks to create unified rules to protect open internet access, with the aim of ceasing roaming surcharges. The protection of users’ rights whilst they make use of the internet is of growing importance in Europe and elsewhere. The safeguarding of open internet access is crucial for the functioning of the European Single Market and protects electronic communications throughout the Member States.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. I share the disappointment of so many who would have preferred a clearer wording with regard to net neutrality. Nevertheless, Article 3(3) on traffic treatment determines principles of equality and non-discrimination which I subscribe to. Refusing the compromise that was reached between Parliament and the Council would mean three things: 1. Return to point "0" and wait a few more years for a new directive; 2. The absence of any European standard in the meantime (with the market fragmented into 28 national legal systems... The Digital Internal Market calls for legal certainty and harmonisation of standards); 3. To refuse other positive points contained in the same legal act, such as the end of roaming, which, if refused the Directive, would continue for several years. European regulation is therefore preferable, if not perfect, than 28 different ones.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this regulation, which represents a real step forward in protecting consumers and businesses, especially start-ups and SMEs. Finally, from June 2017, the ban on roaming charges will be in place, in the use of mobile phones throughout the EU. As early as 2016, however, there will be a reduction in costs on a transitional period, under the control of national regulatory authorities. There will also be clearer and, above all, harmonised rules between the various Member States for the use of the Internet, which extend its access while protecting users' rights.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This agreement is one of the first steps towards the idea of a Digital Single Market within the Union. The treatment of traffic which should be equal and non-discriminatory in the provision of internet access service and also in the safeguarding of related end-users’ rights. In reality the end users shall have the right to access and distribute information and content; the providers of internet access service should treat all traffic equally without discrimination; and traffic should not be based on commercial considerations but rather on the technical quality of the service. However, at the same time, the text agreed has also explicitly allowed the telecom operators and content providers to agree on dedicated ‘quality of service’ levels to provide the so-called ‘necessary services’. This provision was very important for the final agreement.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report represents the final approval at first reading of the Council's position on the European single market in electronic communications. This proposal authorises the final approval of an act which will have a significant impact on the Member States of the Union since it harmonises electronic communications regulations. However, this harmonization is done without sufficient guarantees to allow net neutrality and allowing abuses by operators, such as roaming fees. This is why our position is contrary to this approval

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market in electronic communications is at the heart of the digital economy and is of fundamental importance for growth and employment. The European Parliament's resolution aims to harmonise rules for safeguarding access to an open Internet, to protect users' rights and to put an end to roaming surcharges. I voted in favour of this resolution because it promotes the role of electronic communications as an element for innovation and connectivity in all sectors of the economy, as well as promoting user protection.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The abolition of roaming charges is one of the great results of the European Union, which will benefit all citizens. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing cross-border business by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for Citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest.  In order to smooth the transition between the regulations, a transitional period has been set – this transitional period will begin on 30 April 2016. During this period, the provider may add a surcharge to the domestic charges, but this should not be higher than the previous roaming charge. With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to ensure that roaming for calls, SMS and data within the EU will be abolished by 15 June 2017. With this legislation, for the first time ever, the net neutrality principle will be enshrined in all the 28 national legal systems and will be obliging internet service providers across Europe to treat all internet traffic equally without discrimination, restriction or interference, irrespective of the sender and the receiver, the content, the application or services used. The proposal guarantees also that blocking, throttling, degradation or discrimination of online content, applications and services by internet service providers will be prohibited. This is the final stage to ending EU roaming charges and to guaranteeing net neutrality by ensuring a strong open internet with non-discriminatory traffic, transparency and clear end—user rights.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The legislative text voted does not address the major divisions within the European telecommunications market, protects users very weakly and maintains the privileges of large operators. In fact, under the proposed scheme, operators can reduce their roaming costs and there is a risk that citizens will even end up subsidising the costs of this image operation. Of course, the M5S could not agree with this approach. In addition, with regard to net neutrality, the public and democratic service character that the M5S considers should distinguish the Internet is different. We also disagree with the overall 'barter' that takes place in the text, where net neutrality is exchanged for the 'fake end' of roaming. These are issues with a completely different political impact: the network influences everyone's lives, while roaming only influences short journeys within the Union of a minority of citizens. The delegation's explicit proposal was to separate both issues, now legislating on a real end to roaming and opening a more participatory and informed discussion on net neutrality.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes to ban roaming charges related to the use of mobile phones abroad (voice calls, SMS/MMS or data) from June 2017.  A transitional period has been agreed from April 2016 to June 2017, during which fees may not exceed 0.05 euros per minute for voice calls, 0.02 euros for SMS (text messages) and 0.05 euros per megabyte for the use of mobile internet.  The report also clarifies the rules on the right to access the internet, prohibiting providers from blocking or slowing down access to content, applications or internet services, unless a court decision permits or if this decision is aimed at preventing network congestion or combating cyber attacks.  Considering that the single market for electronic telecommunications is an essential step forward in completing the construction of the internal market and facilitating the daily life and mobility of citizens in Europe, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The adoption of this text by the European Parliament completes an important first step towards a single European market for electronic communications.  I have supported this text which illustrates the Europe of the major projects, the one we support and which we encourage. The end of roaming, roaming charges, from 15 June 2017 is one of the flagship measures of this legislation.  This measure will then directly benefit European citizens by allowing them to use their mobile phones at no extra cost when travelling in other EU Member States.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this recommendation because I am convinced that a single market for telephony and internet services benefits both businesses and consumers. It is also a great advantage that one of the most important liberal demands – the abolition of roaming – is finally becoming a reality. Furthermore, the principle of net neutrality is strongly enshrined, which is important for an open Internet that should give innovation and new start-ups every opportunity.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The TMS Regulation will introduce a system of harmonised rules aimed at safeguarding free access to the Internet, protecting users' rights and ending roaming surcharges. I voted in favour of this recommendation because I believe it is important for the Commission to approve the Council's position without further amendment, in order to ensure net neutrality by definitively removing those 'artificial borders' created by roaming surcharges.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. It is essential that the Union makes progress towards achieving a genuine single market for telecommunications.  Roaming charges and difficulties in accessing content on the internet from one Member State to another are obstacles that EU citizens travelling to the EU face every day. It also damages trade between Member States.  The agreement between the European Parliament and the Council is a good compromise. Roaming charges will end in 2017 and the principle of net neutrality is enshrined in the text of the compromise. The European Union will have to ensure that this regulation is properly implemented by the Member States, but will also have to go further in creating a 'connected continent'.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for the Del Castillo report on the European Single Market for Electronic Communications (MUT).  Indeed, this agreement provides for the end of roaming by June 15, 2017. The cost of calls abroad will therefore correspond from that date to the rates of a domestic call. Whether we are professionals, students or ordinary travellers, we are done with exorbitant phone bills after a stay in a neighbouring European country!  This is a victory for the European Parliament, since the Council, at the beginning of the negotiations in March 2015, offered only a free roaming package for 7 days, with 5 megabytes, 5 minutes of calls received, 5 minutes of calls made and 5 SMS every day.  Also within the framework of this report, the agreement creates the first pan-European rules to guarantee net neutrality (or open internet). This agreement thus guarantees equal access for all without discrimination and prohibits any blockage, slowing down or degradation of the flow. Similarly, we have strictly supervised internet service providers, who will have to guarantee the privacy of users and the protection of personal data.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Roaming charges have acted in recent years as a tax on the free movement of persons, a kind of extraprofit, and the European Parliament has been pushing for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality Internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the new telecommunications package.  The abolition of roaming charges was long overdue by all European citizens, but also by start-ups and SMEs. Thanks to the vote on the telecoms package, this will be effective from 15 June 2017 and European citizens will finally be able to move freely without incurring additional charges for mobile telephony and network access (calls, SMS, data) throughout the European area.  I welcome the vote, although I would have liked to see a more ambitious and clearer agreement on the other major issue of this legislation: net neutrality. Of course, the adopted text provides the legal guarantee of an open internet in Europe, which should avoid the risk of having a two-speed internet, but I consider that Parliament's initial position on the principle of net neutrality was more ambitious, clearer and more precise.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Roaming charges have acted in recent years as a tax on the free movement of persons, a kind of extraprofit, and the European Parliament has been pushing for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality Internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Castillo Vera - European single market for electronic communications: I am in support of this report to end roaming charges, as a way of allowing consumers to freely replicate their domestic usage patterns when periodically travelling in the EU. These new open internet rules will preserve net neutrality, help drive innovation and, of course, should please British holidaymakers.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 End roaming from June 2017! It's about time! I support this proposal, but more importantly, in the meantime, to monitor the prices of international calls with different operators, will they not increase in order to compensate?  I think this is a topic that will continue to be discussed. The report also included part of the Open Internet debate The new rules ensure that when service providers manage traffic on the web, this is done on a non-competitive basis to ensure the openness of the Internet.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We agree with the European Parliament to reject the Council's position at first reading. We must not allow regulators to decide the future of the internet in Europe. The report does not satisfy ensuring internet access and protecting the rights of European citizens. This text is unclear and can allow interpretations that can lead to discrimination on the internet, removing the freedom of expression, economic growth and innovation. Finally, it does not and does not directly promote the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Roaming charges have acted in recent years as a tax on the free movement of persons, a kind of extraprofit, and the European Parliament has been pushing for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality Internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Jill Evans (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation to safeguard open internet access and end roaming surcharges. It is in the interests of Welsh consumers and small businesses in Wales to ensure that internet access remains a free and equal playing field.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. The M5S is opposed to the interinstitutional text negotiated by the trialogue, which very weakly protects users and maintains the privileges of large operators. The issue of net neutrality is not being addressed, on the contrary, it is being replaced by the vague concept of 'open access', which devises from the public service character offered on equal terms to all service and content providers, which in the opinion of the M5S should distinguish the Internet. We also disagree with the overall 'barter' that has taken place in the text, where net neutrality is exchanged against the 'fake end' of roaming. These are issues with a completely different political and citizen impact: the network is increasingly influencing everyone's lives; while roaming only influences the relatively short journeys within the Union of a minority of citizens. We tried, in the trialogue, to separate the issues, legislating now on a real end to roaming and opening a more participatory and informed debate on net neutrality, but in vain. In plenary, where there is no vote on the second reading, the M5S supported the amendments aimed at affirming the need for internet neutrality, as requested by thousands of citizens.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the text agreed by the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union in the trilogues last June because I believe that the end of roaming charges is a major victory for the European project and also a major victory for citizens living in border regions or who often have to travel to other Member States of the Union.  In addition to the reduction in roaming charges in 2016 and their abolition in 2017, a very important aspect for the internal market is the establishment of open internet access throughout the EU, without blocking or slowing signal quality due to the location or type of data being exchanged by the user, something that is certainly of great importance for Europeans.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this agreement with the Member States of the Council. It is gratifying that we have finally succeeded in abolishing roaming charges in europe, even if it is later than I would have liked. I would also have liked to have seen much stronger wordingon net neutrality, an issue that I, many colleagues in the ALDE Group and my representatives that the Center Party parliamentarians have fought for in the negotiations. I regret that, despite the pressure, we were no longer able to put pressure on the Member States. I do not think it would be responsible to vote in favour of the amendments that were put to the vote in plenary in this area, because it risked bringing down the whole proposal. Then we would have been back to square one, and I do not think the countries would have given in more in new negotiations.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Regulation on the telecommunications market includes the first provisions at European level to safeguard open internet access, requiring operators to treat all traffic fairly when providing online services. Roaming surcharges charged when a person uses their mobile phone in another EU country to make calls, send SMS or access the Internet will be abolished on 15 June 2017.  However, when roaming exceeds the limits of reasonable use, a small fee may be charged. This fee may not exceed the ceiling of wholesale tariffs that operators pay for the use of networks in other EU countries. The reduction in roaming charges will take place on 30 April 2016. The maximum level of surcharges will be 0.05 euros per minute on calls, €0.02 per SMS and €0.05 per megabyte of data. These amounts correspond to the ceiling of wholesale tariffs. Operators will have to treat all traffic fairly when providing internet access services in accordance with net neutrality rules. These rules aim to prohibit internet service providers from blocking or slowing down their competitors' content, applications or services.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today we are voting at second reading on a text on the Single European Market for Electronic Communications, which comes out of a trialogue, the conclusions of which we did not agree with. We are dealing here with a text which is a glaring example of institutional propaganda which does not correspond to reality.  The text unjustifiably postpones the entry into force of the measures adopted until 2017; the measures taken will not lead to the end of roaming per se, as wholesalers will continue to pay for it, thus passing these costs on to the end user in a different way; and finally, the regulatory package is subject to conditions and exceptions that further weaken it. As if that were not enough, net neutrality is greatly undermined. An ambiguous and indefinite concept of 'open access' is introduced, full of exceptions, which does not offer European citizens the necessary guarantees of identical treatment of all services circulating on the network.  The conditions are being created for the strengthening of dominant positions and the public service character that we believe should characterise the Internet is being ignored. For these reasons, we have voted for amendments aimed at overturning the outcome of a trialogue with which we do not agree at all.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. By grounding the illusions of some when voting at first reading as a result of the negotiations, the real intentions of this regulation are now even clearer. It is worth remembering the reasons that, at first reading, justified our vote against. We are facing a giant step in deepening the process of liberalisation of the sector, which favours the major powers and their multinationals at the expense of jobs and workers' rights. The attempt to take the internet by the colossi of the sector (to the extent of the interests of which this legislative proposal is made) is redefined more clearly, irreparably, contrary to what is said by the rapporteur and other supporters of this proposal, its neutrality. By itself, this already justified our vote against. But other reasons exist for the rejection of this proposal, which, once again, right and social democracy supported jointly. Take the case of the so-call end to roaming charges – predictably done at the expense of the people of the countries with the largest tourist inflows, such as Portugal, who will pay with the increase of the respective fees the costs of the end of roaming. To this end, the so-called regulators have been alerted, without the European Commission having so far seen a satisfactory response.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the establishment of a European single market for electronic communications because, in a context of digital globalisation such as the one we live in, it is necessary to urge legislative harmonisation and move towards the progressive abolition of 'digital customs'.  Reducing roaming charges will first demonstrate the effectiveness of these measures. Once the transition period, which will end in June 2017, is exceeded, the objective is the complete abolition of these roaming costs, in order to eliminate the differences between Member States and to provide greater fluidity to the European digital market.  On the other hand, it is essential to protect consumers in this process, first ensuring the principle of equitable and non-discriminatory treatment and secondly the protection of end-user personal information.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: On 30 June 2015, following lengthy trilogue negotiations, european Parliament representatives reached an agreement with Member States on regulations for the single market for electronic communications. For consumers in the European Union, this will mean the abolition of high charges for SMS, calls and data from 15 June 2017. From April 2016 to June 2017, mobile operators will be able to cut prices up to four times the reality consumers face today. The single market for electronic communications will also include net neutrality, which will be reflected for the first time in the legal systems of the Member States and will commit all Internet service providers in Europe to access all internet bands and operations equally.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I agree with the European Parliament to reject the Council's position at first reading. We must not allow regulators to decide the future of the internet in Europe. The report does not satisfy ensuring access to the internet and protecting the rights of European citizens. This text is unclear and can allow interpretations that can lead to discrimination on the internet by stifling freedom of expression, economic growth and innovation. Finally, it does not and does not directly promote the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D)
text: Writing. Although Parliament was able to achieve far-reaching improvements in the negotiations at first reading, and in addition to the abolition of roaming, it was even possible to enforce a legal anchoring of net neutrality, the current report no longer contains these improvements. The final version now provides for the use of both a kind of 'roaming' and the use of so-called special services on the 'open Internet'. While it has been added that the quality of the regular Internet connection in bandwidth and speed must not suffer as a result of this, the special services may be routed as "pay-for-priority" services as a priority against payment. Net neutrality, i.e. equal treatment of all data packets and content on the Internet, will not be abolished, but it will nevertheless create a kind of two-tier Internet. This report does not thus fulfil the position adopted by Parliament on several occasions in various resolutions on net neutrality. At the same time, the regulation does not provide more legal certainty, but raises more (legal) questions than it resolves legally.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the long awaited abolition of roaming surcharges and the safeguards for net neutrality in EU law. This agreement will finally allow European customers to replicate their average mobile domestic consumption while periodically travelling in the Union. This is the end of a long battle that we started many years ago to end EU roaming charges, to break the logic of artificial borders for mobile communications inside the European Union, and to guarantee net neutrality by ensuring a strong open internet with non-discriminatory traffic, transparency and clear end-user rights. The result of our commitment is that mobile phone retail roaming surcharges for calls, SMS and data within the EU will be abolished by 15 June 2017, provided that the wholesale prices review will be applicable on this date, and that the freedom and the right of European citizens to access or distribute internet content will no longer depend on the rules of the country in which they live.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the measure voted on today we have finally eliminated the odious roaming costs for 500 million European citizens. In this way, we have made the freedom of movement of European citizens even stronger, eliminating what was still trapping like an invisible wall, forcing tourists and cross-border workers to intolerable additional costs that were completely unjustified. At the same time, we were the first region in the world to create a regulation that would protect free and non-discriminatory access to the Internet.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome this important vote, which takes an important step towards the full integration of the internal market in telecommunications. The most symbolic result, at last, is the abolition of roaming, a long-awaited measure that is the best business card in a Europe that is concrete and attentive to the needs of its citizens.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement with the Council on the Regulation on the Digital Single Market, because the regulation, which will enter into force shortly, will represent an important step forward in order to eliminate the bottlenecks that still exist, which hinder the development of the digital single market (abolition of roaming charges, introduction of European rules on net neutrality). As early as 2013, with the Commission's proposal for a regulation, it was clear that a pragmatic regulatory approach would be chosen, choosing to phase out obstacles to the digital single market, the introduction of a single authorisation for cross-border suppliers, coordination in spectrum allocation, harmonisation of access products necessary to provide electronic communications, and the protection of end-users. While it may be a not entirely satisfactory agreement, it is undoubtedly the best possible agreement in the interests of end-users, particularly as regards the abolition of roaming. Nevertheless, it is regretted that the complete abolition of roaming will not take effect since mid-2017. Finally, I welcome the new introduction of specific European legislation on non-discriminatory access to the internet, which will continue to make the Internet a platform open to innovation.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today against the amendments tabled by the other groups on the report on the European internal market in electronic communications, as I share the Council's position. Europe needs more security, more its own infrastructure when it comes to the cross-border benefits of electronic communications. That is good for our citizens.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I welcome the outcome of today's European Parliament vote on the final form of the EP-Council regulation on the European single market for electronic communications. We have thus completed the final stage of legislative work on the introduction of regulations that will ensure internet neutrality and the abolition of roaming charges throughout the Community.  These issues have been in place for a long time. Finally, the abolition of roaming charges within the EU is scheduled for June 2017. The regulation is the result of lengthy negotiations by Parliament and efforts to improve consumer rights within the EU. In 2014, the Commission presented the results of a survey which showed that 94% of Europeans restrict the use of internet services when travelling abroad – precisely because of the cost. The European Union should make continuous efforts to ensure the well-being of its citizens. These regulations will remove outdated business practices in the telecommunications market and remove the barriers that have previously prevented the free use of digital services.  Access to the internet is a human right and the digital future is one of the pillars of a modern and strong Europe. Harmonisation of rules on networks and roaming connections is particularly important as it affects millions of EU citizens and will have a significant impact on their lives.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The abolition of roaming charges is a great success, especially for us in the german-Dutch border region. But even if you are on holiday in other EU Member States, you will soon be able to make calls to Germany at domestic costs. This is an excellent example that shows the benefits that Europe can have for every single citizen.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this historic deal to end roaming charges across Europe. From 15 June 2017, people travelling in the EU will not have to pay additional roaming charges. The end of roaming charges will be a huge benefit to holidaymakers and business travellers across the EU.  The deal also ensures that, for the first time, the net neutrality principle will be enshrined into 28 national legal systems and will oblige internet service providers across Europe to treat all internet traffic equally without discrimination, restriction or interference and irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content, the applications or services used.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this regulation that will put an end to roaming charges in the EU as of June 2017, allowing European Union citizens to travel across the EU without paying extra communication surcharges. The Parliament has fought for it and we will have it. This is an example of how the European Union can bring concrete benefits to its citizens.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe that the internet must remain open and neutral. With this in mind, the end of roaming is a welcome and celebrated step for consumers. Indeed, successive reductions in roaming prices have consistently proven to be one of the most tangible positive news stories of EU intervention, and the latest agreement was also welcomed by the Prime Minister. As a member of the Conservative party, I am naturally sceptical towards market intervention but I remain both satisfied that regulatory intervention is necessary in this instance as well as reassured that appropriate safeguards have been put in place to prevent mandated losses to operators and also an increase in domestic tariffs. Furthermore, in view of the growth of internet traffic, the new rules ensure that when providers manage traffic it is on a non-competitive basis to guarantee the openness of the internet. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of the Council’s position.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal to expel the Commission's proposal. We are therefore against the Pilar del Castillo report because, although it puts an end to roaming within the EU (desirable), the European Parliament has also voted on a much more worrying but less public issue: net neutrality within Community borders. In this regard, and following the initial draft agreement that the Commission published in June this year, the European Parliament voted against all the amendments to a bill which precisely came to ensure a single market that guarantees electronic communications and, above all, to prevent operators from prioritising traffic on their own terms , giving to the fret with the egalitarian and free network that we know now.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position adopted at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing measures concerning open internet access and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and related to electronic communications networks and services of users' rights and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 on roaming in public mobile communications networks within the Union. I believe that the negotiated agreement is beneficial for the citizens of the European Union, because it will ensure that consumers will not be charged roaming charges from June 2017. The compromise also includes rules to secure an open internet that complies with the principle of net neutrality.

name: Karoline Graswander-Hainz (S&D)
text: Writing. Although Parliament was able to achieve far-reaching improvements in the negotiations at first reading, and in addition to the abolition of roaming, it was even possible to enforce a legal anchoring of net neutrality, the current report no longer contains these improvements. The final version now provides for the use of both a kind of 'roaming' and the use of so-called special services on the 'open Internet'. While it has been taken into account that the quality of the regular Internet connection in bandwidth and speed must not suffer as a result of this, the special services may be routed as "pay-for-priority" services as a priority against payment. Net neutrality, i.e. equal treatment of all data packets and content on the Internet, will not be abolished, but it will create a kind of two classes of internet. This report does not thus fulfil the position adopted by Parliament on several occasions in various resolutions on net neutrality. At the same time, the regulation does not provide more legal certainty, but raises more (legal) questions than it resolves legally.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. While every citizen can travel to another Member State, whether they can travel there for personal or professional reasons, it is unacceptable that within the European single market they should be forced to pay roaming charges when they cross a border and find themselves on a new mobile network! Now it's done! The final abolition of roaming on June 15, 2017! After 10 years of negotiation, four successive European laws and months of hard negotiations!  Regarding net neutrality: for the first time, the text sets out, in European legislation, the principle of net neutrality and the right of every European to access web content without being discriminated against, thus retaining the characteristic of an open platform that the internet presents. Let us be clear, if the text does not go as far as I would have liked, it is a real victory if we look back a few years, where it was unthinkable to simply raise this issue. We will continue our fight in this direction.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this Report which marks the end of a long battle to end EU roaming charges and to break down artificial borders for mobile communications inside the EU. The introduction of a Single Market for Telecoms in Europe will mean all European countries will have to incorporate rules on net neutrality, which will oblige internet service providers across Europe to treat all internet traffic equally without discrimination, restriction or interference and irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content, the applications or services used.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text. This is good news for all our fellow citizens who still doubted the usefulness of Europe: the agreement provides for the end of roaming charges from 15 June 2017. The cost of calls abroad will therefore correspond from that date to the rates of a national call!  This is a victory for the European Parliament that responds to a concrete concern of all citizens and I welcome it. The agreement also creates the first pan-European rules to ensure net neutrality. As such, it guarantees equal access for all without discrimination.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which brings major advances for mobile phone and internet users: the ban on roaming charges and net neutrality. The reduction and then ban on roaming charges by 2017 (the additional fees paid to telephone operators when crossing borders) is a real victory for citizens' purchasing power and European mobility. Net neutrality then (ensuring that all data flows receive the same processing on the internet) ensures that the internet remains a public space. Until now, there have been no binding European rules in this area. This report now enshrines net neutrality in the UNION's 28 legal systems.  While the European right was ready to accept a weak concept of neutrality, the Socialists and Democrats obtained the clearest possible definition. We also obtained four safeguards to prevent "specialized services" from becoming a gateway to neutrality.  Finally, although we would like this text to clearly prohibit the practice of zero rating (this point has been excluded from the negotiations), it will give weapons to challenge certain technical practices arising from it.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against the Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down measures concerning open internet access and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users’ rights relating to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile communications networks within the Union. Due to the fact that the Parliament had to give in on a very complicated mechanism to ensure the sustainability of certain operators, even though the principle of this safeguard clause was shared, the design is very complicated.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Roaming charges have acted in recent years as a tax on the free movement of persons, a kind of extraprofit, and the European Parliament has been pushing for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services.
