In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This hugely important proposal on the ‘Telecoms Single Market’ contained a number of items including an end to rip-off roaming charges by June 2017 and huge savings by April 2016. It also contained some references and guarantees on net neutrality but crucially not enough to ensure it was guaranteed in all situations. I, along with other MEPs co-sponsored 11 amendments to guarantee net neutrality. I firstly voted against an amendment from the EFDD which called for the European Parliament to reject the entire package. If this amendment had gone through, roaming charges would have continued which would have been a field day for telecom companies and the rip-off of consumers would have continued. Furthermore, the limited steps towards net neutrality would also have gone with absolutely no deal. We then voted on all 11 amendments regarding net neutrality which I supported. Unfortunately they were defeated by a large majority. The outcome now is an end to roaming charges and limited provisions on net neutrality. The battle continues on net neutrality but it is important to note that Member States can ensure this principle as the Netherlands has done, so this is an issue for both Member States and the EU.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report as it is of significant importance to establish a successful and functioning European Digital Single Market. Ultimately, we should aim to create an integrated and secure digital market in which digital giants are unable to abuse their dominant positions. Free competition on the internet will boost innovation, which will in turn boost growth and job creation. I believe this report encourages these key principles.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The gradual reduction in roaming charges for the use of mobile phones in other European countries is to be welcomed. If, by mid-2017, small premiums are still allowed compared to prices in the domestic market, these will be completely eliminated after this cut-off date, thus enabling cross-border mobile communication at no additional cost. The legal anchoring of net neutrality is a prerequisite for fair competition in the digital economy. Given the loss of importance of the European IT industry, it is high time to create a digital single market based on common standards that enables European companies to achieve growth rates similar to those of their foreign competitors. Both the free access of all citizens to all contents of the Internet and the equal treatment of all data packets without paid prioritisation must be ensured. Prioritisation may be necessary for technical, non-commercial, reasons, but only proportionate, non-discriminatory and temporary. The national supervisory authorities remain responsible for ensuring fair competition. Despite existing criticisms, I voted in favour of the relevant compromise proposal in order to ensure the timely creation of a digital single market and Europe's competitiveness in digitisation. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Roaming charges have in recent years acted as a tax on the free movement of persons, as an extraprofit. For this reason, the European Parliament has been calling for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the EP has helped citizens and businesses doing cross-border business by introducing price ceilings. Now it will finally be possible for Citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. With Parliament's decision today, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality internet access. However, this should not be at the expense of the basic Internet service. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the report on the European Single Market for Electronic Communications, which is a major gain for European consumers. Indeed, the abolition of roaming roaming charges is confirmed by 15 June 2017 and net neutrality is specified. Thus, from 30 April 2016 until 15 June 2017, travellers travelling to another EU country will pay a surcharge of 0.05 euros (compared to 0.19 euros currently) per minute for their calls from abroad. They will have to pay 0.02 euros (compared to 0.06 euros) for SMS and 0.05 euros (compared to 0.20 euros currently) per MB of data. This transitional period will allow operators to gradually prepare for the second and final phase, namely the complete elimination of roaming charges from 15 June 2017. This is a great victory for the European Parliament, which has succeeded in flexing the strongly recalcitrant Member States to the benefit of consumers.  Finally, this is a concrete achievement of what Europe can bring to its citizens. More freedom, more modernity, more mobility.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am disappointed that Parliament has failed to uphold the concept of net neutrality. EU legislation on roaming charges has largely been positive and is an area where the EU has a genuine positive impact on the lives of ordinary citizens. It is reckless to undermine this good work by abandoning the principle of net neutrality.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation by Parliament and the Council on the establishment of measures on access to the open internet and on amending Directive 2002/22/EC and Regulation (EU) No 2002/22/EC. 531/2012, as I strongly support the creation of a single market for electronic communications that is necessary.  In this context, the abolition of roaming charges is essential to actually ensure the common market, consistency and to abolish unjustified additional costs, as well as the principle of internet neutrality. In my view, it is necessary to protect consumers and ensure that operators comply with the prescribed rules. Therefore, I support this recommendation accepting the Council's position at first reading.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is a recommendation of the European Parliament on the regulation on the regulation of the activities of internet service providers (ISPs) and the end of roaming charges within the EU. Parliament looks back at the Council's position, and two points are to be highlighted: 1. part of the provisions of the report aim to eliminate roaming charges, which are imposed on consumers when they make communications from abroad. I voted in favour of abolishing them from 2017, with the understanding that consumers will not be able to abuse them by subscribing to subscriptions abroad, in Member States where they are cheaper. Thus, the removal of roaming charges is accompanied by exceptions that allow operators to limit this use; 2. Another part of the provisions of the report is supposed to defend "net neutrality". However, in many respects, it is not respected. ISPs will be able to discriminate between encrypted and unencrypted files, between online television and other video platforms, etc.  Therefore, I voted for the amendments that guarantee the neutrality of the internet.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – My MEP colleagues and I in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The proposal accepted in 2014 by the EP established that roaming would disappear on 15/12/2015. Unfortunately, the legislation is not decided in Parliament, but in the so-called 'trilogs' (negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament). In this case, the big parties have given the Council and the big companies the opportunity to have the end of roaming delayed until June 2017. In addition, companies will still be able to charge charges in cases in principle exceptional, thus leaving de facto some doors open to roaming. On the other hand, as regards the principle of net neutrality, the situation is similar: many gaps and open doors so that, for example, large companies/suppliers maintain some margin of decision according to their interests, even to alter the speed of the internet. EH Bildu today tried to ensure that the trilogue agreement was not accepted, so roaming disappeared in 2015 as European citizenship has long demanded and was approved in the House. The Verts/ALE Group's attempt has not succeeded, hence we voted on 12 more amendments to try to improve the Council's proposal.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which represents a major step forward for the Digital Single Market. It abolishes roaming or roaming charges between Member States and guarantees a neutral and more open internet.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D)
text: Writing. Although Parliament was able to achieve far-reaching improvements in the negotiations at first reading, and in addition to the abolition of roaming, it was even possible to enforce a legal anchoring of net neutrality, the current report no longer contains these improvements. The final version now provides for the use of both a kind of 'roaming' and the use of so-called special services on the 'open Internet'. While it has been added that the quality of the regular Internet connection in bandwidth and speed must not suffer as a result of this, the special services may be routed as "pay-for-priority" services as a priority against payment. Net neutrality, i.e. equal treatment of all data packets and content on the Internet, will not be abolished, but it will nevertheless create a kind of two-tier Internet. This report does not thus fulfil the position adopted by Parliament on several occasions in various resolutions on net neutrality. At the same time, the regulation does not provide more legal certainty, but raises more (legal) questions than it resolves legally.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. – The vote in this particular item is one of the most important when it comes to the discussion about the digital future of Europe. It is true that we were more ambitious than the final text reflects, but the S&D group managed, through fierce negotiations lasting for months, to secure that the forthcoming Digital Single Market strategy will be based on a solid foundation.  We have managed, on behalf of the European citizens, to abolish roaming charges across Europe, starting from 15 June 2017. Additionally, the non-discriminatory basis of our internet and digital activities is secured via the provisions included in the text regarding net neutrality.  It goes without saying that we had been aiming to higher standards, but this text, though not perfectly reflective of the S&D group’s perception, is a solid concrete step in the right direction, towards which S&D is leading the way.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. Net neutrality is designed to ensure that all Internet traffic is treated equally, regardless of sender, recipient, type, content, device, service, or application, without discrimination, restriction or interference. The basic principle of net neutrality is particularly indispensable for consumers and start-ups. Services, innovation, research and development are directly dependent on such net neutrality. This principle must be accepted, as must this report.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the main and primary objectives and challenges of the European Union has always been a truly unied market where people, goods and services can flow freely across the internal borders of the European Union, thus ensuring both the sustainability and competition of industries, as well as the possibility of providing citizens with the widest possible choice and lower prices. Unfortunately, despite the efforts, this market is still fragmented in different areas and there are various constraints and obstacles preventing the single market from functioning effectively. This is also the case in the telecommunications market.  The adopted regulation provides, firstly, for the abolition of roaming surcharges in the EU from 2017 on which consumers will benefit, as there will be no need to overpay for negotiations while in an EU country. It is very important that this regulation also provides for a review of wholesale roaming prices by the middle of next year, as without it it would be difficult to ensure that prices in local home markets will not have to be raised, and this review will be a step closer to greater convergence in the telecommunications market in the EU. Secondly, that regulation also lays down rules on the principle of net neutrality, which requires internet providers to treat all types of content on an equal footing without discrimination and blocking for commercial purposes, and will provide an incentive for service providers to invest in the future.  In the light of all these arguments, I supported a regulation abolishing roaming surcharges and net neutrality in the EU at the European Parliament's plenary session in Strasbourg.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR)
text: In writing. After promising the abolition of roaming charges for 2014 and 2015, here is a new promise for... summer 2017. This agreement does not live up to the commitments made to citizens in 2011.  Europe could have been a truly interconnected continent and this agreement could have been truly historic. It should have provided for an immediate, total and unconditional abolition of roaming costs and a good definition of net neutrality. Unfortunately, that is not the case.  ISPs are still saving time, already changing their tariff schedules to cover the shortfall, including all-inclusive packages. As a matter of time, all internet users are involved, while most never travel abroad and don't even know what roaming charges are. By giving in to private operators, the Union forgets that the internet does not belong to the providers of access, but to the intangible common heritage of humanity.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It opens the door to the European single market for electronic communications. Abolishing roaming fees is overdue, but now it shall be accomplished by July 2017. It will make travelling and working in the EU easier and cheaper. In a way it is a symbolic act of truly open Europe, a victory that benefits all European citizens and fosters equal opportunities for European enterprises. Net neutrality as presented in the report, seems to be sufficient to protect the interests of an open and non-discriminatory internet. I echo the concern of various representatives of the internet community. Risks will always remain, as net neutrality could be implemented in different ways and on different ethical levels. Nevertheless, I remain optimistic and trust that all the stakeholders, especially the European Parliament, have taken such risks into account. In order to go on with the European digital market and related legislative acts that will soon be proposed by the Commission, we need to have regulated the European electronic single market. If we had started bargaining again, it would have jeopardized possibly the whole process, delaying the whole European digitalisation process.

name: Jan Keller (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Of course, I welcome the compromise reached in the report on the single market for electronic communications. After the delays caused by the Council, the European public will finally see the long-promised abolition of roaming charges. It is commendable that the rapporteur-general and his shadow colleagues have made this a common priority. With regard to net neutrality, I supported some of the amendments tabled by the Greens and GUE/NGL groups because, in my opinion, they more clearly define net neutrality while allowing Member States to strengthen the proposed measures. It is important that Europe sets out fair barriers to network transmission.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which marks the end of a long battle to end EU roaming charges and to break down artificial borders for mobile communications inside the EU.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The present compromise proposal from the trialogue procedure regulates, on the one hand, the gradual abolition of roaming charges within the EU and, on the other hand, uniform standards for an open internet across the EU. The gradual reduction in roaming charges for the use of mobile phones in other European countries is to be welcomed. If, by mid-2017, small premiums are still allowed compared to prices in the domestic market, these will be completely eliminated after this cut-off date, thus enabling cross-border mobile communication at no additional cost. The legal anchoring of net neutrality is a prerequisite for fair competition in the digital economy. Given the loss of importance of the European IT industry, it is high time to create a digital single market based on common standards that enables European companies to achieve growth rates similar to those of their foreign competitors. Both the free access of all citizens to all contents of the Internet and the equal treatment of all data packets without paid prioritisation must be ensured. Prioritisation may be necessary for technical, non-commercial, reasons, but only proportionate, non-discriminatory and temporary. The national supervisory authorities remain responsible for ensuring fair competition. Despite existing criticisms, such as the non-clear ban on zero ratings, I voted in favour of the relevant compromise proposal in order to ensure the timely creation of a digital single market and Europe's competitiveness in digitisation.

name: Στέλιος
text: Κούλογλου (GUE/NGL), in writing. ‒ The main point of this report is to create a single market for electronic communications in order to have access to electronic services without cross-border restrictions or costs. One key aspect is ‘net neutrality’, which means that all internet traffic must be equally treated. The ‘net neutrality’ aspect is an important improvement, for consumers’ rights in order to open internet access. The abolition of roaming charges is also a positive change. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I support the provisions contained in the Recommendation for second reading of the document establishing measures for the European Council's position on the EU Regulation on roaming in public mobile communications networks within the Union and the single market for electronic communications. Among the many positive decisions taken in the documents covered by this recommendation, the most important is the one concerning the abolition of roaming charges in the EU as early as July 2017. At the same time, from April 2016, the current fees will once again be reduced – already significantly low compared to non-European countries. At a time of very intensive electronic communication, the practically constant use of the phone mainly for data transmission over the Internet, this decision is of great importance and is, in addition to the possibility of passportless travel, one of the key symbols of community and integration in the European Union.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this vote we have finally established that the ban on roaming charges when using mobile phones within the European Union will come into force from June 2017. As early as 30 April 2016, roaming surcharges will be limited and will allow citizens to have lower rates than those applied. This vote is important because it opens up significant new opportunities for consumers and mobile operators. Furthermore, by ensuring the application of the principle of net neutrality in all 28 countries of the European Union, we have placed a barrier before those who want, driven by economic interests, a two-speed Internet. In this way, we have demonstrated our desire to protect the equal treatment of citizens on the internet as well.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Today's vote is a great achievement of Parliament and the European institutions, to the benefit of the citizens.  In an increasingly globalised and interconnected world, digital communication is the essential tool for the development of daily life. We have today officially signed an agreement that will have immediate and direct consequences for the lives of European citizens, because as early as April 2016 text messages, calls and data for the use of the Internet via mobile devices roaming in Europe will cost much less. In addition, from June 2017, they will be eliminated altogether and we could call and navigate throughout Europe at the cost provided by our national operator. This is an important victory which enables us to achieve a genuine common market in electronic communications.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of a very important piece of EU legislation. This new law, when implemented, will have a positive impact that citizens of the EU will be able to experience themselves in their day-to-day life. This law will put an end to roaming charges as of 15 June 2017. A barrier that has been a hindrance in our single EU market, where people  could move between countries freely but could not use electronic communications as they would do at home, will be abolished. People will be able to pay the price they pay at home for texts, calls and mobile data everywhere in the EU.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Net neutrality is one of the founding principles of the internet that data exchanged on it, like users, must be treated equally. In practical terms, an internet service provider cannot restrict access to certain sites or promote others by modulating connection speeds. The same logic applies to the customers of these. The proposed text creates loopholes in this principle which cannot bear any ambiguity. It proposes three cases in which an ISP could circumvent this principle: a court ruling, defense against cyber-attacks, and traffic management. Of course, the merits of a court decision cannot be disputed, but the other two criteria leave ample room for interpretation and may allow operators to offer preferential offers to users as well as to businesses, thus circumventing the principle of net neutrality. On the contrary, the internet must be seen as a universal service, as the post office, as it is necessary today for everyday tasks, such as administrative or civic procedures. That is why I supported all the amendments that sought to reintroduce the strength of this principle.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The regulation proposed by this recommendation included in the Castillo report is intended to implement harmonized provisions to ensure access to an open internet, protect users' rights and eliminate additional roaming charges. I therefore voted in favour of the multiple amendments aimed at strengthening net neutrality.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to Parliament's decision to adopt the Council's position, because it does not guarantee net neutrality, i.e. equal access to the internet to which I am very attached. I am outraged that Parliament has rejected the amendments that would have ensured it. Once again, powerful lobbies have prevailed over the aspirations of the peoples.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market. .

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report represents the final approval at first reading of the Council's position on the European single market in electronic communications. This proposal authorises the final approval of an act which will have a significant impact on the Member States of the Union since it harmonises electronic communications regulations. However, this harmonization is done without sufficient guarantees to allow net neutrality and allowing abuses by operators, such as roaming fees. This is why our position is contrary to this approval

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The approved report aims to introduce harmonised legislation that will ensure free access to the Internet, the protection of user rights and end the cost oversteer of additional surcharges or roaming.  On the first point, internet access should be equitable and non-discriminatory for all users. In addition, traffic may not be based on commercial considerations but must be subject to the technical quality of the service.  On the other hand, the Regulation addresses the protection of consumers only in respect of such free access and roaming provisions and additional costs. From now on, consumers will be notified that they may be being victims of these costs by sending a message and/or making or receiving calls.  Finally, it has been agreed to permanently eliminate roaming costs by June 15, 2017 although a transition period has been introduced to facilitate the transition from one phase to the other. Once again, we are facing one of these giant steps of the European Union to make it closer to its citizens.  For all of the above and the benefits that the agreement will bring, I am in favour.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The present compromise proposal from the trialogue procedure regulates, on the one hand, the gradual abolition of roaming charges within the EU and, on the other hand, uniform standards for an open internet across the EU. The gradual reduction in roaming charges for the use of mobile phones in other European countries is to be welcomed. If, by mid-2017, small premiums are still allowed compared to prices in the domestic market, these will be completely eliminated after this cut-off date, thus enabling cross-border mobile communication at no additional cost. The legal anchoring of net neutrality is a prerequisite for fair competition in the digital economy. Given the loss of importance of the European IT industry, it is high time to create a digital single market based on common standards that enables European companies to achieve growth rates similar to those of their foreign competitors. Both the free access of all citizens to all contents of the Internet and the equal treatment of all data packets without paid prioritisation must be ensured. Prioritisation may be necessary for technical, non-commercial, reasons, but only proportionate, non-discriminatory and temporary. The national supervisory authorities remain responsible for ensuring fair competition. Since original restrictions have been removed from the text as part of the trial, the compromise agreed does not constitute a threat to net neutrality. That is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This Regulation introduces harmonised rules to protect open internet access in order to protect users' rights and abolish the additional roaming cost. Parliament underlined its position after the first reading on 3 April 2014, and on 2 September 2014. The ITRE Committee has opened interinstitutional negotiations.  Parliament and the Council's negotiating teams, with the participation of the Commission, reached an informal agreement. The text of the agreement was presented at the ITRE Committee and approved with an overwhelming majority. I supported the recommendation of Pilar del Castillo Vera, for the protection of internet neutrality so that every citizen can access content online without discrimination.  I consider it a great achievement to abolish roaming charges completely, which croatian citizens will feel directly during their stay outside the country.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 My Colleagues in the European Parliament have approved by an overwhelming majority the legislative package, including the final abolition of roaming charges and ensuring net neutrality. I am convinced that this is an important step towards removing the constraints on the digital single market and a more connected Europe.  Work on a phased reduction in prices for conversation, messaging and mobile internet began in 2007. Solutions such as these illustrate the immediate benefit of well-thought-out supranational European solutions, which have the real potential to facilitate and improve the daily lives of millions of European citizens. Last but not least, this is the Union in its best light.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I support the approval of the agreement on the telecoms package, which will allow for the introduction of clearer and more transparent rules on internet access, clarify the rights and obligations of users of electronic services and lead to the abolition of roaming charges from June 2017. Removing existing barriers to electronic services will help to build a functioning digital single market in the Union, where citizens, businesses and service providers can use and provide electronic services without cross-border restrictions and unjustified costs and administrative burdens.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position and at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down measures on access to the open internet and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users' rights with regard to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 1493/1999. 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile networks within the Union, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015, and because this recommendation for second reading is complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. This was a text at "second reading", so there was no final vote. However, I supported the amendments tabled by our colleagues from the EFDD, the GUE and the Greens, which aim to protect net neutrality, a neutrality called into question by the provisions of the text.  It should not be forgotten, however, that this text is part of a larger package, aimed at concentrating the market in a few majors, which can then easily ally with the United States, via TTIP.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D)
text: In writing. As of June 15, 2017, these retail roaming charges will be prohibited. This is a significant step forward for Europeans' purchasing power and an encouragement to European mobility. Until now, there were no binding pan-European rules on net neutrality: only two European states (the Netherlands and Slovenia) had legislation. With this regulation, the principle will be enshrined in 28 national legal systems: this is a major step forward for all Europeans.  The text is based on a principle requiring equal treatment of traffic in line with the strong position that Parliament had defended at first reading. Several safeguards have been introduced so that "specialized services" do not allow to circumvent or cannibalize "neutral" Internet access. Because the adoption of a single amendment risked bringing down the agreement and would have taken us in the best of circumstances into another perilous negotiation, at worst into a deadlock in the event that the Council refused to prolong the procedure, I made a choice of responsibility: to achieve a solid result, even if it is not perfect, rather than to project an ideal result that would , in the current state of power relations, is not attainable.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that we were able at first reading to reach agreement for the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down measures concerning open internet access and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users’ rights relating to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 on roaming on public mobile communications networks within the Union.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have supported the abolition of roaming charges from the outset. However, in my view, the result achieved in the Council has essentially nothing to do with the original ambitious targets set by the European Parliament in 2011. The resulting text still leaves room for charges, only with a different name. At the same time, it is crucial for me to fight for the introduction of the principle of so-called net neutrality, which simply means the principle of equalness of data transmitted over the Internet, that is, Internet providers have to treat traffic on their networks in the same way, i.e. they cannot offer internet services to users from certain companies more quickly and have them pay for it from these companies. Internet neutrality means that all data transmitted over this line is sent with the same priority. Therefore, there cannot be a situation where, for example, one data package takes precedence over another based on the content, origin, or type of service. The opposite of net neutrality would be a situation where a company could subscribe to the prerogative for its services at the expense of the services of other companies. This would lead to a slowdown in competition, which could not afford to pay the fee. In its negotiations with the Council, it has become clear that it is unwilling to accept a clear definition of the concept in the proposal. For this reason, I could not support the text in its current form.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The reduction in extra costs since 2016 and the European Union's stop to international roaming since June 2017 mark what will be the evolution of communication for all European citizens. I voted in favour of a principle that absolutely must be recognised, that of net neutrality.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Del Castillo Vera report because it is synonymous with two significant advances in the field of electronic communications: the end of roaming charges and the consecration of the principle of "net neutrality". With the vote of this report by the European Parliament, the costs of "roaming" will be severely limited from 30 April 2016, and then abolished outright on 15 June 2017. In short, voice calls and text messages from another EU country will soon cease to be overcharged. I am satisfied with this achievement because it is a simple and concrete example of what the European Union can and must do to make a tangible difference in the rights and purchasing power of Europeans.  Finally, the Del Castillo Vera report enshrines the principle of "net neutrality" in the national laws of the Twenty-Eight. Through this principle, it is in fact the equal treatment of all data flows that is ensured on the internet: no operator will be able to restrict or limit European consumers' access to the service or application of their choice. I agree with this development.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The Internet has become a thoroughly commercialized space where competition and the preservation of the acquis dominates collaboration and innovation. The European Parliament's decision to water down the principle of net neutrality therefore supports this, in my view, negative development. This decision weakens not only the small start-ups, which can no longer compete with the large, financially strong owners of important infrastructures, but above all the European start-ups themselves, which do not have the risk capital that is provided .B in the United States.

name: Emma McClarkin (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I voted today in favour of the Telecommunications package, and I welcome the ending of mobile roaming, I am disappointed with the lack of appreciation for the role of network parental controls under these net neutrality rules. Although there is a window in which national legislation can be put in place to avoid an EU blanket prohibition on these tools, it is disappointing to see that the EU has once again overreached and put itself at odds with a tool that parents desperately need in today’s digital world to protect their children online.  Fifty-four percent of UK parents operate such controls, and the EU has once more sent a message that they know what is best for their children.  We must enable families and parents to monitor and safeguard their children from dangers online. Parents should retain the right to choose what appropriate content is through parental controls. We must not cast parents as the threat, but rather embrace these tools as a potential solution to online dangers. This is a reasonable and flexible security mechanism.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the rapporteur as I believe it is a fair and balanced outcome following long discussions between the EU institutions that will ensure equal treatment of internet traffic and allow innovation to flourish. The principle of net neutrality will be preserved. Internet service providers will be required to treat all traffic equally when providing internet access services, without discrimination, restriction or interference, irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content accessed or distributed, or the applications or services used. Certain provisions are made for services requiring a specific level of quality, but this is on the condition that they do not interfere with the open internet and are not to the detriment of the availability or general quality of internet access services for end users. Some traffic management is necessary in order to allow information to flow freely, rather on the technical quality of the service. Providers of internet access services should inform end-users in a clear manner on how the traffic management practices may influence the quality of the internet access service, end-users’ privacy and the protection of personal data. Additionally providers should inform end users of the speed normally available and the remedies in case of non-compliance.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report aims to define the framework for the future single market for electronic communications in which citizens and businesses could access electronic communications services wherever they are provided in the EU, without cross-border restrictions and at no additional cost, and where electronic communications networks and services could operate without territorial restrictions.  This regulation, which is essential to the liberalisation of the sector, could nevertheless have confirmed the principle of 'net neutrality', i.e. ensuring that telecom operators do not discriminate 20s to their users' communications, but remain mere transmitters of information. But the term has been carefully avoided.  This regulation could also have finally put in place the end of roaming charges (or "roaming") but, on the contrary, it postpones its application to June 2017 (compared to December 2015 as originally planned). In the end, the text deregulates everything that can be done, leaving operators free to act as they see fit in this new market. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question is a recommendation from the European Parliament on the regulation of the activities of Internet service providers and the end of roaming charges within the Union. In this recommendation, Parliament returns to the Council's position. Two aspects are to be noted: 1. part of the text aims to eliminate roaming charges, which are imposed on consumers when they make communications from abroad. The MEMBER voted in favour of abolishing them from 2017, with the understanding that consumers will not be able to abuse them by subscribing to subscriptions abroad, in Member States where they are less expensive. Thus, the removal of roaming charges is accompanied by exceptions that allow operators to limit this use; 2. Another part of the text is supposed to defend "net neutrality". However, in many respects, it is not being respected. ISPs will be able to discriminate between encrypted and unencrypted files, between online television and other video platforms, etc.  I therefore voted in favour of amendments that guarantee net neutrality.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. This report means the abolition of roaming charges in June 2017, a reduction in tariffs as early as 2016 and open internet access, where operators will be required to treat all traffic equally. In a very important conciliation effort by rapporteur Pilar del Castillo, it is ensured that the open market will fulfil its role as a free market without frontiers, where the imposition of a roaming system is not justified.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it proposes to eliminate all roaming charges by June 2017 which is a key point for European consumers and an important step towards achieving a true single digital market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament legislative resolution laying down rules for a single European market for electronic communications aims to harmonise the rules in order to ensure access to an open Internet, to protect end-users' rights and to abolish roaming surcharges. I am very pleased that we have finally succeeded in approving the ban on roaming charges in the EU since June 2017, which have long hampered the deepening of the internal market in telecommunications and which, above all, have burdened ordinary citizens and small businesses. I believe that a free and fast internet accessible to every EU citizen will contribute to the development of innovation and competitiveness in the internal market.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The result of Telecoms Single Market Package is one of the most impactful achievements of the EU in improving the life of its citizens. This is the end of a very long battle for the European Parliament that started many years ago. This is the end of roaming charges and the beginning of EU-wide rules on net neutrality whilst strengthening consumer rights in the Telecoms Single Market. I voted in favour of banning roaming charges in Europe as from 15 June 2017.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the amendments tabled by my ALDE group colleague Marietje Schaake on net neutrality. These amendments, which I also co-signed, were aimed at restoring Parliament's strong position at first reading. In its original position, Parliament planned to introduce stronger provisions on net neutrality at European level. Unfortunately, the resistance of the Member States was too great and we were unable to impose our position in the trialogue negotiations. Unfortunately, the amendments were not adopted in today's vote either – but the reason for this is not the lack of motivation of the parliamentarians, but their knowledge that such a position would never lead to agreement with the Member States. Although the European Parliament was not able to make all the demands in the negotiations, the results achieved take us a great step further towards a complete internal telecommunications market. The biggest success is the abolition of all roaming charges for TRAVELLERS in the EU from 15 June 2017, whether for calls, texts or mobile data. This achievement, too, was accompanied by considerable opposition from the Member States and was achieved, thanks in particular to a strong campaign by the Liberals in the European Parliament.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for a piece of legislation that will finally put an end to roaming charges and promote the principle of net neutrality in the rules that guide the management of internet traffic. It is a significant package that brings more freedom to European citizens. Firstly, starting from 15 June 2017 we will be free to use our mobile phone anywhere in Europe just as much as we do in our home country. Secondly, it is about freedom to access legal internet content without discrimination and therefore keeping our internet open. This is an important step forward for our Digital Union.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on harmonised rules to be introduced to ensure open internet access, protect users' rights and eliminate roaming charges. Parliament and the Council's position at first reading differed considerably and a tripartite consultation took place from 23 March 2015. The unofficial agreement reached on 30 June 2015, approved by the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy on 22 July 2015, is unacceptable to me.  My party, the Democratic Coalition, and I personally believe that digital development, the Internet should serve to create jobs, develop the economy and increase the chances. The proposal allows INTERNET service providers to arbitrarily restrict certain services and distinguish between subscribers. It threatens the democratism of the Internet and can be detrimental to innovation. I therefore voted against this proposal and will continue to do so if a motion is against digital development and the democratic nature of the Internet.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. Over the past few months, the European institutions have been in deep negotiations to reach an agreement on the future of the telecommunications market, and the European Parliament is now in a position to vote on the final package agreed. I therefore vote in favour of this Agreement which aims to introduce harmonised rules to ensure open access to the Internet, protect users' rights and end existing surcharges. I would also like to safeguard the fact that the principle of internet neutrality is enshrined, thus allowing equal access for all to information, without any interference in online traffic. It is also important to mention the end of roaming in June 2017, which after so many obstacles and negotiations is thus in a position to end, facilitating communications between citizens and businesses.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The regulation proposed by this recommendation included in the Castillo report is aimed at the implementation of harmonised provisions to ensure access to an open internet, protect users' rights and eliminate additional roaming charges. I therefore voted in favour of the multiple amendments aimed at strengthening net neutrality.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report which marks the end of a long battle to end EU roaming charges and to break down artificial borders for mobile communications inside the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which allows the introduction of net neutrality and the abolition of 'roaming' into European legislation.  From 15 June 2017, calls, text messages and internet browsing made on mobile phones or tablets during trips to the EU will no longer be overcharged. I supported this measure from the beginning of the legislative process, because it will restore purchasing power to European households. From 30 April 2016, roaming charges will not exceed 5 euro cents per minute for voice calls, 2 cents for SMS and 5 cents per megabyte for mobile internet use.  As far as net neutrality is concerned, the new legislation guarantees equal treatment of Internet users. However, exceptions are made when it comes to responding to court decisions, combating cyberattacks or preventing network congestion. An operator may continue to offer an improvement in the quality of the internet for certain services, provided that this does not affect the overall quality of the internet.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome this recommendation on universal service and rights in the field of electronic communications networks and services. The innovation of current legislation will, in fact, ensure greater consumer protection in terms of net neutrality and the reduction of roaming costs.  The new regulation, by reducing the surcharges on SMS, data packets and calls applied to consumers travelling through the EU, will facilitate further harmonisation and unification of European telecommunications markets, as well as, of course, greater consumer protection.  The report is the result of three months of intense and difficult triangular negotiations with the European Commission and the Council. That is why, in an attempt to prevent a further lengthening of time, I fully support the regulation without supporting any other amendments. In fact, the legislative proposal, while representing only a first step towards the establishment of a genuine single market in telecommunications, is an excellent compromise and will allow citizens to enjoy these benefits directly.  As far as net neutrality is concerned, the draft legislation, by ensuring equal treatment and preventing any discrimination against access to and speed of network navigation, will ensure greater fairness of service for all European citizens.

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it helps to end roaming charges. This is a victory for Parliament for the benefit of consumers.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think this report once again shows the right direction. The right direction to which we are committed on the basis of the fundamental values of the EU, which, unfortunately, we are violating because of the economic and business interests at the moment. Member States and the EU. For example, in public forums, it is often the case that the EU receives the Nobel Peace Prize when its member countries engage in intensive arms trade with dictatorships in third countries. Our stand for the death penalty, torture and inhuman treatment is extremely important. However, it is perverse when poisons in deadly syringes originate from the union. Just like if technical assistance comes from here. This report is therefore important because it aligns our political convictions with the rules that are permissible in business. Congratulations to the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation that will introduce harmonised rules to safeguard open internet access, to protect users’ rights and to end roaming charges.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the adoption of a regulation on the regulation of the single market Telecom. This agreement represents the end of a long battle to end EU roaming charges, to break the logic of artificial borders for mobile communications within the European Union and to guarantee net neutrality by ensuring an open, strong internet with non-discriminatory traffic, transparency and clear rights for end-users. Overcharging for calls, SMS and roaming data within the EU will be eliminated by 15 June 2017, after a transitional period from April 2016 to June 2017.  As the S&D coordinator for the ITRE Commission, I support the adoption of this regulation which benefits European citizens.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text, despite the fact that it is far from perfect. Yet I believe that the key provisions contained in here are not something we can afford to postpone for much longer. It is true that the successive negotiations on this have managed to both water down some of the important proposals concerning consumer protection and digital rights as well as to lessen the accuracy of the text. At the same time, even in its current state, the Council position does indeed respect the key issue of a free Internet, data roaming and the creation of a true European single digital and telecommunications market.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the abolition of roaming charges on 14 June 2017. Since the phasing out of roaming charges, I promise to increase the use of mobile services when travelling abroad. Statistics show that half of people do not use data services on their mobile when staying abroad and instead log on to the Internet differently than through their mobile phone. There will be no longer a reason for this forced change in consumer behaviour, as consumers will not be discouraged by higher prices for telephone services when they stay abroad. The end of roaming charges may have come sooner, but in a situation of complicated negotiations with the Member States, this is a compromise that I consider to be a successful outcome. Strengthening the consumer's rights is also the obligation for the connection provider to inform the connection provider before signing the contract of the minimum and maximum data transfer speeds it can expect. If the connection provider does not comply, this will be the reason for withdrawal.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This vote was broken into two parts. The first part was a vote to reject the Council’s position and the second part consisted of 12 Amendments, which I co-signed, to reinstall crucial definitions and references to the principle of net neutrality throughout the text. I voted in favour of all parts. My reasons for rejecting the Council’s position were that during the course of negotiations, the text of this report was significantly watered down. The abolition of roaming charges initially foreseen for December 2015 was postponed until June 2017. On top of this, all references to net neutrality were deleted from the text, leaving the door completely open to a two-speed internet, an internet that would allow ISPs to discriminate between internet traffic to the detriment of smaller companies, newspapers and blogs. As the Council’s position was completely inadequate in terms of protecting net neutrality and respecting the need to abolish roaming charges as early as possible, I voted to reject it.

name: Maria Noichl (S&D)
text: Writing. – In the vote on 27.10.2015 in Strasbourg on the European internal market in electronic communications, I voted in favour of all the amendments and thus voted against the trilogue result. I see net neutrality as the basis of a fair democratic Internet.  I was unable to agree to this text for two reasons: 1. First of all, I consider the linking of roaming charges with net neutrality, as is the case in this draft law, to be an undemocratic approach. This questionable combination of two different issues meant that, in the name of abolishing roaming charges, we should have voted against clearly defined and secured net neutrality.  2. It is true that the text submitted makes it clear that all traffic must be treated equally. However, a clear definition of net neutrality is sought in vain. A two-speed Internet that no longer treats data equally is distorting competition and discriminates against citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises. Freedom of information and communication and the safeguarding of diversity on the Internet are at stake in this text.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of net neutrality in this vote. I am in favour of an open Internet. It is also important to ensure that all traffic must be treated equally, regardless of sender and recipient, type, content, or application, without discrimination, restrictions or interference.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. In addition to banning roaming charges from June 2017, the second important development is the introduction of clear EU-wide principles for internet access. This ensures that there is no discrimination between internet services.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE)
text: in writing. The agreement we have approved after tough negotiations is an important step in building the digital single market.  Citizens will finally stop paying more in roaming mobile communications.  Moreover, despite the Council's initial opposition, the European Parliament has succeeded in including for the first time a mention of the principle of net neutrality.  Despite all this, from UPYD we consider that the two-year delay in the calendar to eliminate roaming is unfair and intolerable. We live in a Union without physical and economic borders, so it is not understood that the economic interests of operators are above the interests of citizens and the very idea of European construction. As for the mention of neutrality, it is a progress but insufficient if what we want is to ensure the full protection of rights and freedoms in the network. We will continue to defend the Internet in the European Parliament as a global public good which must be managed in the common interest and we will therefore work for a better and complete definition of net neutrality.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of this report. In order to achieve a digital single market, the EU must not be subject to a roaming charge.  The EU must have access to the open internet and the principle of net neutrality has been properly implemented.  All internet traffic must be treated equally. In addition, an effective mechanism for protecting the open internet is necessary. Common rules on electronic communications shall apply to this end. The new legal regulation will help to ensure the openness of the Internet while avoiding fragmentation of the internal market as a result of measures adopted by individual Member States.  Internet providers should not block or slow down the operation of competitors' applications. It is therefore necessary to ensure that all flows are managed in the same way by service providers. All internet traffic should be treated in the same way. Particular attention should be paid to the right of consumers to access and the right to disseminate the selected content on the Internet.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the regulation aimed at shaping the EU's single capitalist market in electronic communications networks and services. The Regulation promotes even greater dominance of the major monopolistic groups of the internet industry, which will mean the concentration and monopolisation of related services, resulting in the imposition of new and increased existing financial burdens on users, as well as the control of the network and the services provided. The reactionary substance of the regulation is an attempt to hide behind the abolition of roaming charges, which is also seen as a communication firework of the EU and its unpopular policy. The JRC calls for the immediate abolition of roaming charges, without any other burden on users. There are all the technological conditions for the immediate abolition of fees, which at the request of the business groups was extended for June 2017 and we see, with the unsan compensation of course for the business groups, which will make up for the loss of their collection from the increase in the use of mobile telephony and its applications abroad. A prerequisite for the people to enjoy the enormous achievements of technological and scientific progress is to get their hands on power and means of production.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for his work, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament wants to ensure a single European market for electronic communications and to make it easier for consumers and service providers to use and provide these services. The establishment of a single market allows for the abolition of roaming, which means eliminating unnecessary costs for our citizens. When it comes to consumer protection, I support the obligation to provide all necessary information before concluding the contract, as well as the possibility of terminating the contract at no additional cost after the expiry of 6 months after the signing of the contract, and I certainly support the facilitation of the change of service provider.  Also, for citizens of the European Union, especially Croatia, in which three companies treat their users in a way that is unthinkable to those in Germany or Belgium, and especially when it comes to the early termination of a contract that lasts at least 2 years or changes of operators that, due to the monopoly on the DTK network, one of them takes an impermissible long time, the arrangement of this area is really necessary. In addition to citizens, facilitated action would also be possible for service providers, which I also find useful for Croatian citizens. Greater competition prevents the possibility of cartel mergers and consensual pricing of services, which croatian citizens without special evidence other than high prices of monthly bills often suspect. I am in favour of competition from more operators because services are always better then and with a higher offer of different options, prices are cheaper and users are more satisfied.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The regulation proposed by this recommendation included in the Castillo report is intended to implement harmonized provisions to ensure access to an open internet, protect users' rights and eliminate additional roaming charges. I therefore voted in favour of the multiple amendments aimed at strengthening net neutrality.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In the last year, major progress has been made in the area of protecting the freedom of electronic communication, and efforts by Parliament and the Council to ensure open internet access and abolish roaming charges are the crown of the process. I fully support harmonisation of rules in this area at EU level.  In June 2017, all roaming charges for calls, SMS and data traffic on mobile devices in the EU will be abolished, a great achievement of the Socialists and Democrats group who have opened up this problem and have consistently insisted over the years on tackling it. Furthermore, I support a regulation that ensures internet openness, i.e. its neutrality, and would force internet service providers to treat all network traffic equally.  In addition, all forms of blocking, degradation and discrimination against online services, content and applications will be strictly prohibited by this proposal, which is a significant improvement in the area where such practices often go unhindered and unpunished, with the absence of harmonised regulation at Union level.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The importance of the proposal presented by the European Commission, which aims to achieve a single market in electronic communications, lies mainly in the fact that citizens and businesses will have the right to have access to electronic communications services wherever they are within the EU, without cross-border restrictions or unjustified additional costs.  In particular, I believe that the decision to put an end to the surcharges on telephone roaming is of great importance. From 15 June 2017, roaming charges in the EU for calls, the sending of text messages and for the use of the Internet via mobile devices will be prohibited. I welcome this type of initiative, which has a direct positive impact on the daily lives of millions of European citizens. In addition, they are very important in order to promote competition, stimulate investment in broadband and increase the construction of new generation technological infrastructures. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The text of the agreement concluded at second reading lays down rules on the abolition of roaming charges when travelling within the EU from June 2017 and the introduction of rules for securing the open Internet in the EU, in line with the principle of 'net neutrality'.  From June 2017, mobile phone charges when travelling in the EU will be the same as at home – if you have a monthly subscription to phone calls, SMS or data for free use abroad within the EU, the fee will be the same as at home, without any additional charges. These rules will prevent abuse, such as when a customer buys a SIM card in another EU country where prices are lower to use at home. The Regulation also introduces important measures to protect consumers, in particular ensuring access to information on their roaming rights and the use of funds and the power to detect possible breaches of the open Internet rules. I therefore support the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The EU now guarantees a high mobility of trade in people, goods and services to some extent. In this context, and in order to increase the performance of the single market, the EU has decided to strengthen the opening up of electronic communications.  The European Parliament has adopted the report on the European single market for electronic communications. This includes abolishing roaming charges and strengthening the European framework for net neutrality.  I voted in favour of this text because it is now essential to open up this sector while securing a European control framework that protects freedoms without compromising the growth of European businesses.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I consider the abolition of roaming as another factor to stimulate the free movement of people.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. Although Parliament was able to achieve far-reaching improvements in the negotiations at first reading, and in addition to the abolition of roaming, it was even possible to enforce a legal anchoring of net neutrality, the current report no longer contains these improvements. The final version now provides for the use of both a kind of 'roaming' and the use of so-called special services on the 'open Internet'. While it has been taken into account that the quality of the regular Internet connection in bandwidth and speed must not suffer as a result of this, the special services may be routed as "pay-for-priority" services as a priority against payment. Net neutrality, i.e. equal treatment of all data packets and content on the Internet, will not be abolished, but it will create a kind of two classes of internet. This report does not thus fulfil the position adopted by Parliament on several occasions in various resolutions on net neutrality. At the same time, the regulation does not provide more legal certainty, but raises more (legal) questions than it resolves legally.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We in UKIP voted against the EU Commission proposal to create an EU legislative framework on the European digital market as we believe our national representatives would do a much better job deciding whether to implement such legislation for the UK. We believe in the importance of maintaining the freedom we currently enjoy on the internet. We believe that all internet traffic should be treated equally, without discrimination, restriction or interference. For this reason, we object to the creation of new EU regulation on net neutrality and roaming. With regard to roaming, we believe that this proposal is deeply regressive, favouring well-heeled frequent travellers and disadvantaging typical users. Some telecom operators have in fact admitted that the loss in revenue will be pushed onto domestic users. Non-roaming customers will be subsidising frequently roaming customers and this will increase costs for the majority.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. On Tuesday, Parliament approved the text on the European Single Market for Electronic Communications. This is the kind of legislation that has a concrete impact on the lives of European citizens. This text will eventually allow a total ban on roaming charges for the use of mobile phones abroad in the EU by June 2017. This means that calling abroad or browsing the internet via your smartphone in another Member State will no longer be extra. A first transition cap will be effective from April 2016 and will reduce the current extra costs, which are 0.19 euros per minute for outgoing voice calls, 0.06 euros for SMS and 0.20 euros per megabyte for the use of mobile internet.  This initiative was introduced by former Liberal Commissioner Neelie Kroes in 2010. This is therefore an important step taken by Parliament. Less ambitious, the "open internet" component calls on internet service providers to ensure equal treatment of data flows on the net. On this equally important part, I regret that the negotiations have resulted in an ambiguous and equivocal agreement, which is not up to what was hoped for for the Union's single telecommunications market.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. After long negotiations with the Council and an intense mobilization of the ALDE group in Parliament, I welcome the adoption of the regulation on net neutrality and the end of roaming charges by the European Parliament. One of the measures in this text aims to eliminate the "roaming" fees between Member States from 15 June 2017. The abolition of these fees, which specifically relate to the exchange of SMS, calls and the use of the mobile internet from another Member State, is another step in the success of the single market. The introduction of the principle of net neutrality would allow all users to be equal in traffic management. This new directive will benefit businesses, cross-border workers and European citizens who will no longer have to worry about roaming surcharges every time they travel to one of the 28 EU countries.  In addition, by requiring Internet service providers to provide clear and accurate information on the level and quality of speeds, this regulation meets citizens' transparency requirements.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. The new telecom package is presented as a victory for consumers when it is simply the other way around. This package represents a real threat to net neutrality, the founding principle of freedom of expression and information on the internet.  If the European Parliament had initially voted to enshrine this principle in legislation, the final compromise negotiated with the Council of the Union produced a completely different result. Not only is net neutrality no longer mentioned, but worse, the agreement allows internet service providers to introduce "special services" and implement internet traffic management, de facto threatening net neutrality.  The proponents of the telecom package also announce the so-called "end of roaming charges". Pure lie. Indeed, if roaming charges are abolished earlier than expected, loopholes and exceptions in the legislation will allow operators to recover their shortfall by other means, to the detriment of consumers. National authorities will be responsible for verifying and interpreting the application of the rules, which may lead to a myriad of national exceptions.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. Like 499 of my colleagues, I voted against the request to reject the telecommunications legislative package. This agreement, which had been reached after long and intense negotiations and with many key points, should not be rejected. Firstly, the end of roaming charges for calls, texting or mobile internet use in another EU Member State (or EEA country) from June 2017. Before that, ceilings have already been set and will already be a significant step forward from next April. Even if the "end of roaming" will arrive a little later than hoped, it was highly anticipated and is undoubtedly a great victory for consumer-users. On the more delicate point of open internet and net neutrality, one can see the glass half full or the glass half empty, as often. I have decided, and I welcome the fact that we have been able to legally register the principle of open internet and net neutrality, which is directly applicable in all Member States.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This Regulation is of maximum importance because it is the unequivocal expression of the benefits of the European project. The S&D Group has been calling for the abolition of roaming costs for years. With this agreement, which I have supported, that wish will come true on June 15, 2017. It is true that the abolition has not been achieved at the end of this year, but we have managed to bend the resistance of some Member States that did not want the abolition of roaming before 2018 or a significant reduction in prices for the transitional period, as has been achieved since April 2016. This will benefit citizens in their travels around the Union, but also businesses, especially SMEs. Moreover, this agreement enshrines the principle of net neutrality for the first time in the 28 Member States. We would have wished that the Council had not made it impossible to include the concept in the agreement. But Parliament's definition has been enshrined to ensure equal and non-discriminatory treatment of all internet traffic. The agreement is a step, but much work remains to be done to move towards the digital single market.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. My vote in favour of the "telecom package" is mainly motivated by the desire to see roaming charges for calling, texting or surfing the net from another EU country abolished.  It is now up to the Commission to allow this abolition to be effective by reforming the "wholesale roaming market" by June 2017. If we are convinced by the European project, as I am, and if we want to defend the mobility of Europeans, we must avoid having an additional price to pay to be able to communicate from abroad.  In addition, net neutrality must be enshrined, so that the treatment of all forms of internet traffic by companies providing access to the internet is the same. No exceptional regime - in view of the conditions set out in the regulation - can be a vector of discrimination, at the risk of creating a two-speed internet.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The re-initiation of negotiations in the telecommunications sector gained a new élan with the Latvian Presidency in April this year. However, the mandate given by the Council was limited to issues relating to roaming, internet neutrality, access and consumer rights, leaving out, for example, the reform of the body of European regulators for electronic communications. From the compromise reached between Parliament and the Council, I would like to point out the legal harmonisation on the digital single market, the end of roaming from June 2017 and the reduction of tariffs as early as 2016 (with the wholesale tariffs of €0.05 per minute on calls, €0.02 per SMS and €0.05 per megabyte of data). In terms of open internet access, I stress the equal treatment that operators should provide to all consumers of electronic content and applications, preventing them from blocking or conditioning services, except in exceptional situations, which, I believe, could have been better specified. In view of the above, I believe that, since the regulation is not the ideal regulation, it is always preferable to harmonise the rules of the European electronic communications market than a random myriad of disparate national legislation, so I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which lays the groundwork for a genuine European single market for telecommunications. Phone calls, texting and mobile internet use abroad in the European Union will no longer be overcharged from 15 June 2017. The end of roaming charges in mid-June 2017 is a real step forward that will bring European citizens closer together and connect. This is a great victory for Parliament, which has been in the negotiations since 2013, in order to ensure better communication conditions for consumers, businesses and SMEs.
