At the same time, net neutrality measures will also be put in place. The aim is to ensure that no content or debit is deliberately discriminated against or degraded by internet service providers. The adopted text allows the blocking of content only for judicial reasons, security or network congestion. The abolition of roaming charges and the regulation at European level of an open internet are considerable advances in bringing Europe into the era of digital communications in the 21st century and facilitating the connection between European citizens. European consumers will be able to reap the greatest benefits.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Single European Electronic Communications Market as the new regulation will remove roaming surcharges by mid-2017 and ensure access to an open Internet.   Specifically, the legislation provides for: the complete abolition of the costs of overpritrying the use of mobile phones abroad, whether for telephone calls, SMS or Internet browsing; that the treatment of traffic is the same and non-discriminatory, while recognising the quality of service for the so-called "necessary services"; the creation of a service that will inform about roaming costs until it is completely abolished; greater data protection and better quality of access to services.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal to expel the Commission's proposal. We are therefore against the Pilar del Castillo report because, although it puts an end to roaming within the EU (desirable), the European Parliament has also voted on a much more worrying but less public issue: net neutrality within Community borders. In this regard, and following the initial draft agreement that the Commission published in June this year, the European Parliament voted against all the amendments to a bill which precisely came to ensure a single market that guarantees electronic communications and, above all, to prevent operators from prioritising traffic on their own terms , giving to the fret with the egalitarian and free network that we know now.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resulting form of the so-called telecoms package, because it will bring two essential benefits to consumers. This is the latest step in a long-running effort by the Group of Social Democrats in the European Parliament to end roaming charges and break illogical artificial borders for mobile communications within the EU. Equally important is the provisions on ensuring net neutrality through an open internet based on non-discrimination, transparency and clear rights of end consumers. For the first time ever, european legislation will introduce a rule that internet access service providers must treat all traffic equally.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report represents the final approval at first reading of the Council's position on the European single market in electronic communications. This proposal authorises the final approval of an act which will have a significant impact on the Member States of the Union since it harmonises electronic communications regulations. However, this harmonization is done without sufficient guarantees to allow net neutrality and allowing abuses by operators, such as roaming fees. This is why our position is contrary to this approval

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to today's vote, from June 2017, increases due to roaming in the use of mobile phones will finally be prohibited and clearer rules on the right of internet access will be established.  For the first time, there will also be specific EU legislation to protect the right of every European citizen to access content on the Internet without discrimination. Internet service providers will have to consider how best to meet demand and will not be able to block or slow down the reception of content, applications or services offered by specific companies, other than to avoid network congestion or cyberattacks.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ My Labour colleagues and I voted in favour of this report, which finally marks an end to this long, long battle to see the end of roaming charges in the EU and to break down these unnecessary and artificial borders for mobile communications inside the EU. The introduction of a Single Market for Telecoms in Europe will mean all European countries will have to incorporate rules on net neutrality, which is a victory for civil liberties for European citizens. ISPs must treat all internet traffic equally and without discrimination, restriction or interference ... irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content, the application or service used.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this resolution, which lays down rules for ending roaming charges when travelling within the EU in June 2017 and which also lays down rules to ensure an open Internet in the EU in accordance with the principles of net neutrality 'Net Neutrality'.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the proposal for a regulation that Parliament managed to negotiate after two years, because a date has finally been set for roaming charges to cease to apply in the EU. As early as April 2016, a transitional period will apply when operators will have to reduce charges up to four times, and from 15 June 2017 they will be abolished altogether. In the meantime, it will be necessary to see to it that the Commission concludes the reform of wholesale roaming charges in a timely manner. The compromise reached with the Council is a necessary step towards operators looking for ways to provide citizens of Member States with services that would allow them to move more freely around the EU.  In addition, we agreed on the need to keep the Internet open by laying down rules on net neutrality. Until now, many EU countries have had no legislative regulation of the Internet, which may prevent all users from having equal access to content shared on the Internet. We will require ISPs to treat each content in a non-discriminatory manner so that certain content is not inappropriately blocked. Any regulation of the data transmitted must be transparent and not a question of commercial interests. It is unacceptable for small business websites to be disadvantaged because a corporation pays for priority data transmission. Websites and platforms should be treated equally, any content shared on the Internet should be equal.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. As a Member of the Greens/EEAS Group, I am in favour of net neutrality and am against monopolistic behaviour in telecommunications. I also believe that there is no need to charge for the transfer of data abroad.  The text, which was approved by Parliament after its first reading, envisaged the complete removal of the data transfer surcharge by 2015. After negotiating with the Council, we have reached a compromise so that this can only be done in 2017 by adding a clause on the review of wholesale tariffs.  The directive was intended to remove surcharges for data transmission, but the current text does not allow and even adds an additional regulatory burden. Furthermore, I believe that the directive is a poorly defined area of net neutrality.  In order to avoid ambiguity, the Greens/EEAS, together with the GUE, have tabled amendments that have put in place a solution and clearly defined the neutrality of the Internet, its use and what services are allowed under this.  I believe that we need a correct and precise definition of internet neutrality and clear rules on the application of it, which is why I supported the amendments tabled by the Group of the Greens/EEAs and GUE.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the new regulation on the European telecommunications market, in which Parliament approves the end of roaming costs in the EU from 15 June 2017, on the basis of a difficult agreement with the Member States. In addition, the regulation introduces a common framework on the right of access to the Internet, in the spirit of sharing and free trade that has animated the global ecosystem of the network since its inception. This spirit, embodied in the principle of net neutrality, has allowed the evolution of the web to become, according to Tim Berners-Lee, "a central infrastructure of our time that pervades every sector, from the economy to the private life of individuals".  Therefore, while agreeing with the important objectives achieved by the final text, I have chosen to further underline my position in favour of net neutrality by voting for an amendment calling for even more defined common rules so that the Internet continues to be an open and horizontal platform, capable of promoting everyone's right to access and distribute information, or to exercise free choice in the use of applications and services. , avoiding fragmentation due to different national regulations. Only by further strengthening the freedom and openness of the network will Europe be able to establish itself as a competitive, prosperous and just society.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'The package put to the vote today was another offshoot of Neelie Kroes' proposals to liberalise and harmonise the telecommunications market. However, little remained of the proposed package and the negotiations between the Council, the EP and the Commission were mainly on roaming and net neutrality. Today, our amendments on net neutrality were voted down by a majority of the EP. This jeopardizes freedom and innovation on the Internet and puts consumers and small online start-ups at risk. This creates a two-speed internet, with privileged access for those who can afford it. This means class discrimination on the Internet, which is opposed by new online start-up companies. On the other hand, direct roaming charges will be abolished from 15 June 2017, but there are provisions attached to this, such as the definition of 'fair use'. After all, it will determine how much consumers still have to pay when they are up there. Also, if a provider fails to cover the roaming costs incurred in special circumstances, it can still pass on costs to consumers. Since our green amendments on net neutrality failed and I cannot agree with this package, I voted against it.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The present compromise proposal from the trialogue procedure regulates, on the one hand, the gradual abolition of roaming charges within the EU and, on the other hand, uniform standards for an open internet across the EU. The gradual reduction in roaming charges for the use of mobile phones in other European countries is to be welcomed. If, by mid-2017, small premiums are still allowed compared to prices in the domestic market, these will be completely eliminated after this cut-off date, thus enabling cross-border mobile communication at no additional cost. The legal anchoring of net neutrality is a prerequisite for fair competition in the digital economy. Given the loss of importance of the European IT industry, it is high time to create a digital single market based on common standards that enables European companies to achieve growth rates similar to those of their foreign competitors. Both the free access of all citizens to all contents of the Internet and the equal treatment of all data packets without paid prioritisation must be ensured. Prioritisation may be necessary for technical, non-commercial, reasons, but only proportionate, non-discriminatory and temporary. The national supervisory authorities remain responsible for ensuring fair competition. Despite existing criticisms, such as the non-clear ban on zero ratings, I voted in favour of the relevant compromise proposal in order to ensure the timely creation of a digital single market and Europe's competitiveness in digitisation.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Free and fast internet should be accessible to every EU citizen. Thanks to today's decision, it will no longer be possible for the operator to block certain services for no reason or to mislead the consumer about the speed of its connection. The definitive dismantling of roaming, in turn, will bring further savings for citizens and entrepreneurs.

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D)
text: Writing. I have spoken out against the nonsensical link between roaming and net neutrality. Net neutrality has not only been neglected in the negotiations, but has also not been sufficiently defined in this report. There is a danger that the door will be opened to a two-speed Internet, thereby undermining the fundamental principle of the free Internet. Unfortunately, the amendments which would have ensured a clear definition of net neutrality were unsuccessful. That is why I did not vote in favour of the draft yesterday. The European Commission has tried to combine two laws with a package solution. In order to agree to the abolition of roaming charges, we should have sacrificed net neutrality. I find that undemocratic. I don't want fast lanes on the internet. All traffic must always be treated equally. That is why we must not leave the neutrality and openness of the network to the forces of the market.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report which marks the end of a long battle to end EU roaming charges and to break down artificial borders for mobile communications within the EU. The introduction of a Single Market for Telecoms in Europe will mean all European countries will have to incorporate rules on net neutrality, which will oblige internet service providers to treat all internal traffic equally without discrimination, restriction or interference and irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content, the applications or services used.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ New growth opportunities and economies of scale can improve the return on investment in high-speed networks while fostering competition and global competitiveness. However, operators in the EU cannot make sufficient use of them. Fragmented national markets have narrowed down customers' choices, no innovative services are available to them and they still pay a high price for calls across national borders or for roaming within the EU.  Common high levels of consumer protection across the Union should be ensured and common trading conditions, including measures to phase out additional roaming call charges and measures to protect access to the open internet. The overall objective of this proposal is to move towards a single market for electronic communications where citizens and businesses can access electronic communications services from anywhere in the Union, without cross-border restrictions or unjustified additional costs.  A single market for electronic communications would promote competition, investment and innovation in the field of networks and services by fostering market integration and cross-border investment in networks and the provision of services. At second reading, there was no final vote, but I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position and against amendments to the Council's proposal.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the recommendation for second reading on the European single market in electronic communications. I voted against it because of the inappropriate definition of net neutrality. I support the openness and neutrality of the Internet. In Slovenia, the Electronic Communications Act has high standards in the field of net neutrality. I am opposed to the levelling of standards at issue and I support the free market in the area of the Internet and free access to information. The end user must have the choice and therefore access and dissemination of information must be accessible to all.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's Legislative Resolution of the European Parliament on the European Single Market for Electronic Communications, as it represents, above all, a long-awaited and necessary step towards the abolition of roaming charges. I regret that the explicit definition of net neutrality did not get into the agreed compromise, but this principle has been reflected in the specific provisions of the compromise, and I consider the abolition of roaming charges throughout the European Union to be an important example of the added value that the European Union can bring. The abolition of roaming charges applies to calls, sms and data services and will occur from 15 June 2017. Today's vote is thus an important moment in the process of building a European digital single market. In the future, however, it is important that the European Commission closely supervises the proper implementation of these rules so that the desired effect is actually achieved.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately the legal framework proposed is in several places unclear and has legal loopholes. With regard to roaming charges, while the whole debate had begun with a request for a complete abolition, the text finally tabled by the Council refers to the abolition of charges only for a certain volume of 'reasonable use', to be determined by the Commission. The most problematic and dangerous thing, however, is that companies are given the opportunity to come in retrospect and charge their customers additional fees for not covering their total costs.       Also particularly negative is the lack of reference to the need to ensure the neutrality of the internet, which implies that its public character is at risk. For us, telecommunications and the internet are public social goods to which we must all have equal access. We cannot therefore support them becoming tools to strengthen large companies and their profits.       In fact, the aim of the new regulation is to strengthen the competitiveness of the Union. The big companies will be the winners from the liberalisation of the telecommunications market. Finally, a negative development is that the new regulation will give the powers that the Member States currently have to the Commission.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report does not satisfy ensuring internet access and protecting the rights of European citizens. This text is unclear and may allow interpretations that can lead to discrimination on the Internet by thus indirectly abolishing freedom of expression, economic development and innovation.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the amendments to the report which clearly contributed to ensuring net neutrality without compromise, as this is in the fundamental interest of all European citizens. Any decision that goes against this threatens digital development, and thus european competitiveness. Therefore, I cannot support proposals and ideas that go against this principle.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This regulation says that all internet traffic must be treated in the same way but allows the opposite to be done, as it establishes a wide range of exceptions to the rule, allowing the possibility of managing data traffic and/or establishing fast fast lanes. They will presumably only be traveled by direct traffic to sites that can pay to make user access faster and easier. I voted to reject the regulation as a whole, as it kills net neutrality in the EU. I voted in favour of the amendments aimed at preventing all these exceptions. They were rejected. Without net neutrality, Google and Facebook would not have been able to take the first, difficult steps towards popularity: as net neutrality is now being thoed, the EU is actuallying the emergence of innovative European platforms that can compete with the US giants. The abolition of roaming contained in the regulation is also limited: conditional, and subordinated to the interests of telecommunications companies. This is the second reason why I voted no: the unconditional abolition of roaming would be a necessary act to make Europe a connected continent.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This report relates to many areas of legislation that are of great importance, net neutrality among them, but for me, and for many I suspect, the stand out point is an end to mobile phone roaming charges from June 2017 across the entire EU. This is exactly the type of legislation that the EU should be about – helping consumers, removing barriers, and furthering the single market. Some in this House have sought to paint the changes as a market intervention that will provide cut-cost international roaming to a jet-set elite whilst leaving poorer, domestic customers to pick up the costs as service providers increase the price of basic tariffs to offset losses. This is complete nonsense. This was a legitimate concern during negotiations and so the legislation has been crafted with sufficient safeguards to prevent this from happening. This is a good news EU story and I am pleased to have voted in favour.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. MEPs will have to vote on Tuesday on a text at the centre of much covetousness: the abolition of roaming telephone charges but also the introduction of European principles on net neutrality: great progress in prospect for the consumer. However, some European governments (Council), obeying telecom operators, have weakened the legislative proposal to limit the shortfall of these large companies. The final round of this fight will be played on Tuesday to offer consumers the best possible legislation.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament decided to approve the agreement reached with the Council on so-called Telecoms package today. One of the main issues of this agreement was the end of roaming charges by mid-2017. Roaming has been one of my priorities for a long time, therefore I decided to support this agreement. The result is great news for the European public, and is a key element of our future digital single market. However I still have some provisions towards the agreement. I am still convinced that the end-date of the roaming should be earlier than mid-2017. The text has been diluted on issues like net neutrality, so I decided to co-sponsor amendments tabled on this matter. However support of tabled amendments would entail annulment of the agreement, which would greatly delay the entire process. Furthermore there would be no guarantee to obtain a better deal with Council. Therefore I decided not to vote in favour of any of the amendments tabled in a second reading.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The Castillo Vera report is a symbol of the European Parliament's commitment to digital freedoms. While the Council had disfigured this text at first reading with the complicity of the EPP rapporteur, we have reached an alternative compromise which clearly defends net neutrality and will put an end to the extra costs of data roaming.   After seeing the costs of data roaming gradually fall between 2016 and 2017, consumers will no longer be overcharged by mobile operators from 2017 and will pay for their communications in the European Union at the cost of a local call.  While it was the subject of 28 different regulations, the principle of net neutrality is finally recognised at the Community level. From now on, internet service providers will have to treat all traffic equally.  Although the text remains perfectable on the issue of specialized services or "zero-rating", i.e. the exclusion of certain services from the consumption of internet flows, it poses safeguards with increased control of these practices and the impossibility of a "mini-internet". I have chosen to support this report, without amendment, in order to make these great strides in the Council, for our fellow citizens.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Roaming charges have acted in recent years as a tax on the free movement of persons, a kind of extraprofit, and the European Parliament has been pushing for their abolition for years. Since 2007, the European Parliament has helped citizens and businesses doing business across borders by introducing price ceilings, and now it is finally possible for citizens of the European Union to talk to each other on domestic tariffs from 15 June 2017 at the latest. With today's decision by parliament, the issue of net neutrality has also been regulated. In this context, operators will be obliged to treat all traffic equally and will be prohibited from blocking or slowing down the transmission speed of different services. In addition, it will be possible to sell special services that guarantee high-quality Internet access, but not at the expense of basic Internet service. As a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation, I voted in favour of the Council's position at first reading, which could result in the abolition of roaming charges.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ Recommendations for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down measures relating to access to the open internet and amending Directive 2002/22/EC on universal service and users' rights in relation to electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 1095/2010 on the protection of electronic communications networks and services and Regulation (EU) No 1095/2002 I do not support the proposal because the proposal does not contain an accurate definition of what constitutes and covers the concept of 'net neutrality'.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: Writing. •u2012 The abolition of roaming charges is expected for a long time. The common market in Europe has existed for years and it is unreasonable to continue to maintain borders where life itself has reversed their need. The abolition of restrictions on telephone in other countries is necessary for companies to function in the common market and will be directly benefiting all consumers. I therefore support this initiative. I am also in favour of the universal implementation of the principle of net neutrality, as it has currently been implemented in practice by only a few EU Member States.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal to expel the Commission's proposal. We are therefore against the Pilar del Castillo report because, although it puts an end to roaming within the EU (desirable), the European Parliament has also voted on a much more worrying but less public issue: net neutrality within Community borders. In this regard, and following the initial draft agreement that the Commission published in June this year, the European Parliament voted against all the amendments to a bill which precisely came to ensure a single market that guarantees electronic communications and, above all, to prevent operators from prioritising traffic on their own terms , giving to the fret with the egalitarian and free network that we know now.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The present compromise proposal from the trialogue procedure regulates, on the one hand, the gradual abolition of roaming charges within the EU and, on the other hand, uniform standards for an open internet across the EU. The gradual reduction in roaming charges for the use of mobile phones in other European countries is to be welcomed. Prioritisation may be necessary for technical, non-commercial, reasons, but only proportionate, non-discriminatory and temporary. The national supervisory authorities remain responsible for ensuring fair competition. Despite existing criticisms, such as the non-clear ban on zero ratings, I voted in favour of the relevant compromise proposal in order to ensure the timely creation of a digital single market and Europe's competitiveness in digitisation.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 If significantly belatedly, slipping against the original proposal and leaving certain loopholes, the previously stated intention to reduce the unjustified roaming burden on European consumers as soon as possible has been achieved. That is why I supported its adoption. However, on the issue of internet neutrality discussed in the common package with the introduction of the roaming charge, I did not support the proposed legislation, as it, in my view, restricts open and free use of the net and at the same time reduces the opportunities for Hungarian start-ups to flourish.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the proposal to expel the Commission's proposal. We are therefore against the Pilar del Castillo report because, although it puts an end to roaming within the EU (desirable), the European Parliament has also voted on a much more worrying but less public issue: net neutrality within Community borders. In this regard, and following the initial draft agreement that the Commission published in June this year, the European Parliament voted against all the amendments to a bill which precisely came to ensure a single market that guarantees electronic communications and, above all, to prevent operators from prioritising traffic on their own terms , giving to the fret with the egalitarian and free network that we know now.

name: Владимир Уручев (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I was extremely pleased to vote for the adoption of my colleague Pilar del Castillo's report and the historic compromise reached with the Council on the abolition of roaming charges across the European Union from mid-2017. , as in their own countries, without fear of uneven bills from mobile operators. As early as April next year, we will be able to talk from abroad for no more than 10 stotinki, send texts for no more than 4 stotinki and exchange data for no more than 10 stotinki per megabyte. Net neutrality, the loss of which has raised great concerns among many citizens and businesses, is regulated in a very acceptable way by obliging service providers to treat all internet traffic equally. The abolition of roaming charges is also a decisive step towards the creation of the Digital Single Market, which is one of the EU's grandiose projects, alongside the creation of a European Energy Union. It is such projects that are necessary to maintain europe's unity and attractiveness and its prosperity.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE)
text: Writing. – The abolition of roaming tariffs has been waiting for the citizens of the European Union for a long time. It is gratifying that the Latvian Presidency of the Council of Europe managed to reach an agreement, thus bringing this issue to an end.  Although the EU has already limited the ceiling on roaming tariffs in the past, they were still high enough, especially for the use of data services. Therefore, most travelers have so far chosen not to use or use the phone to a minimum when outside their country. The benefits of ending roaming charges will be significant: this will strengthen the EU's competitiveness, provide consumers with lower prices and open up new opportunities for businesses. It is estimated that around €520 billion could benefit from an orderly telecommunications sector.  From a consumer point of view, it is important that using the phone while travelling or doing business in other EU countries will no longer incur additional costs, as the tariffs will be exactly the same as at home.  The principle of net neutrality ensuing the new law is also important. This will ensure that internet speeds will not be adapted to who pays more to the connection provider, as all types of Internet content, programmes and services will have to ensure the same traffic speed.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report represents the final approval at first reading of the Council's position on the European single market in electronic communications. This proposal authorises the final approval of an act which will have a significant impact on the Member States of the Union since it harmonises electronic communications regulations. However, this harmonization is done without sufficient guarantees to allow net neutrality and allowing abuses by operators, such as roaming fees. This is why our position is contrary to this approval

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. For the N-VA, the EU has great added value for achieving a digital single market. It will help to increase competitiveness and create growth and jobs, with strong guarantees on privacy and data protection. Roaming charges may be eliminated from 2017, but this does not mean that national and international operators will be connected free of charge. These costs will be passed on to the consumer in a different way. Unfortunately, this is not being illuminated enough. The overall picture is positive and fits within the realisation of the internal market. However, we must not forget that consumers who do not travel, if at all, will pay the costs for those who travel abroad several times a year. The N-VA is satisfied that net neutrality is becoming more and more clearly defined. We strive for opportunities for operators to offer new (specialized) services with guaranteed quality, insofar as they guarantee that the regular internet remains of adequate quality.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report which marks the end of a long battle to end EU roaming charges and to break down artificial borders for mobile communications inside the EU, that have hampered cross border communication and mobility for too long. The introduction of a Single Market for Telecoms in Europe will mean all European countries will have to incorporate rules on net neutrality, which will oblige internet service providers across Europe to treat all internet traffic equally without discrimination, restriction or interference and irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content, the applications or services used. This is an important victory for all users of the internet in Europe, and I am proud to have backed this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'Not only was it time for European citizens to be able to communicate with each other by mobile phone at no extra cost on EU territory, but it was also necessary that we paid attention to so-called net neutrality. I voted in favour of this recommendation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current document is a step forward in deepening the single market for electronic communications, with a view to its complete liberalisation. It favours the major powers and sharpens the interest of multinationals in obtaining a monopoly on electronic communications, a course that will be destroyed more jobs and to the detriment of the interests of workers who will be subject to greater pressures to reduce wages and other rights. On the other hand, the principle of neutrality has suffered a significant samend. Indeed, with this proposal, from May 2016, Internet providers can actually prioritise specialised services, citing exceptions such as periods of heavy traffic (peaks), but not only. On the other hand, it provides for the controversial zero rate . The possibility of potential abuse of all these exceptions is therefore open.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The Internet has become a thoroughly commercialized space where competition and the preservation of the acquis dominates collaboration and innovation. The European Parliament's decision to water down the principle of net neutrality therefore supports this, in my view, negative development. This decision weakens not only the small start-ups, which can no longer compete with the large, financially strong owners of important infrastructures, but above all the European start-ups themselves, which do not have the risk capital that is provided .B in the United States.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on the digital single market because, despite the group's suggestion, this is a fundamental issue and has reached an unsatisfactory conclusion. This report is the result of lengthy conciliations from the previous parliamentary term.  I believe that my work must begin here, monitoring the situation with a view to revising the report and promoting a different awareness of 'digital culture' from the position of the Member States. The states that make up the European Union cannot leave the bar on the real infrastructure of the future to the United States. We need to do more, starting today.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, along with Labour Party colleagues, voted in favour of this report which is the outcome of a long battle on important issues like net neutrality and abolishing roaming charges. The introduction of a single market for electronic communications in Europe means all European countries will have to incorporate rules on net neutrality, which will oblige internet service providers to treat all internet traffic equally without discrimination, restriction or interference and irrespective of the sender and receiver, the content, the applications or services used. A free and fair internet is crucial today as it is for the world of tomorrow. Freedom of expression, social empowerment, education, and inclusion depend on it. It is now up to national governments and regulators to push standards upwards from the European norm, and for civil society to remain active and vigilant on the subject.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. Although Parliament was able to achieve far-reaching improvements in the negotiations at first reading and, in addition to the abolition of roaming, even enforcing a legal anchoring of net neutrality, the current report no longer contains these improvements. The final version now provides for the use of both a kind of 'roaming' and the use of so-called special services on the 'open Internet'. While it has been taken into account that the quality of the regular Internet connection in bandwidth and speed must not suffer as a result of this, the special services may be routed as "pay-for-priority" services as a priority against payment. Net neutrality, i.e. equal treatment of all data packets and content on the Internet, will not be abolished, but it will nevertheless create a kind of two-tier Internet. This report does not thus fulfil the position adopted by Parliament on several occasions in various resolutions on net neutrality. At the same time, the regulation does not provide more legal certainty, but raises more (legal) questions than it resolves legally.

name: Kerstin Westphal (S&D)
text: Writing. – The telecoms package is about the end of roaming on the one hand. As a member of the Committee on Consumer Protection, it has been a major concern for me from the outset to abolish overpriced mobile phone tariffs. At the same time, there is also the issue of net neutrality – a link between two independent issues, which I very much regret. I am against all discrimination on the Internet – all data packets must be treated equally and everyone must have equal access to the Internet. Unfortunately, net neutrality is not clearly formulated in the telecoms package. Knowing that any (adopted) amendment on net neutrality would have overturned the whole package, I am nevertheless one of the group of Members who voted in favour of the relevant amendments in the plenary vote. We wanted a clear and Europe-wide set of net neutrality. Unfortunately, a (conservative) majority in the House voted against these amendments. Meanwhile, the fight for net neutrality will continue - we will take up the issue again as soon as we discuss the 'Digital Single Market'. There I will fight again for the concept of net neutrality to be tightened up in Europe.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported Parliament's position on an agreement that will allow automatic exchange of information between the EU and Switzerland on the bank accounts of its citizens from 2018 on. This means that hiding cash in Swiss accounts in order to avoid paying taxes in the European Union will be more difficult for EU citizens. Tax fraud will be more difficult, which will bring more money to state budgets, for example, for education or health care. The agreement to combat tax fraud and tax evasion was signed by the European Union and Switzerland on 27 May 2015. The information covered by the agreement concerns not only citizens' income, for example in the form of interest and dividends, but also account balances and proceeds from the sale of financial assets. Switzerland will apply stricter data exchange arrangements under the Agreement. Tax administrations in Member States and Switzerland will be able to better identify taxpayers, enforce their tax laws in cross-border situations and investigate suspected tax evasion. With Parliament's consent, the agreement must be unanimously approved by both the EU Member States and the Swiss Parliament.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. In the first place, I must say that I am pleased with the adoption of the report. In a world governed by globalization, or what is the same, by the integration of the various international societies into a single global market, it was necessary for the European Union to be updated to identify itself with this concept. Until now, there have been significant barriers between Member States in reference to the online market, which made online commercial activities very difficult and hindering. That is why I believe that the creation of a single digital market in the EU will be a great progress for its evolution, because it will not only facilitate the sale of goods and services online, but will also produce significant benefits and, with it, new jobs.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the interinstitutional agreement between Parliament and the Council expressed here today. I believe that this agreement will bring tangible benefits for our businesses and consumers, and I am pleased that a battle fought for a long time by my political group, the end of the roaming regime, has finally been successful.  We have today adopted a balanced regulation that breaks down artificial national borders and barriers, thus taking an important step towards the creation of a fully unified telecommunications market. I find the agreement particularly satisfactory because, in addition to the aforementioned end to roaming costs for European citizens, the new telecommunications regulation will also guarantee an open and non-discriminatory Internet on the basis of the principle of net neutrality.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The JRC voted against the regulation aimed at shaping the EU's single capitalist market in electronic communications networks and services. The Regulation promotes even greater dominance of the major monopolistic groups of the internet industry, which will mean the concentration and monopolisation of related services, resulting in the imposition of new and increased existing financial burdens on users, as well as the control of the network and the services provided. The reactionary substance of the regulation is an attempt to hide behind the abolition of roaming charges, which is also seen as a communication firework of the EU and its unpopular policy. The JRC calls for the immediate abolition of roaming charges, without any other burden on users. There are all the technological conditions for the immediate abolition of fees, which at the request of the business groups was extended for June 2017 and we see, with the unsan compensation of course for the business groups, which will make up for the loss of their collection from the increase in the use of mobile telephony and its applications abroad. A prerequisite for the people to enjoy the enormous achievements of technological and scientific progress is to get their hands on power and means of production.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have already advocated the abolition of roaming during my election campaign and I am glad that we are one step closer to it with this approved report. Furthermore, I consider it important that the EU continues to work on the development of digital technologies and remains at the top of the world in this field. I consider the agreed compromise to be a good start.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Positively, after heavy efforts by the Latvian Presidency, it was possible to reach agreement between the Council and Parliament on the new telecoms package on the abolition of roaming surcharges and the first open internet rules in the EU. It foresees that roaming charges in the EU will be significantly reduced as of 30 April 2016, but from 15 June 2017 these charges will be completely abolished: so the consumer will be able to use mobile telephony services at the same cost as at home when the consumer is in other EU countries. This gradual reduction in charges is also particularly important in order for telecommunications operators not to charge these charges at local mobile prices. The second important element is open internet rules, which require operators to care for all traffic on an equal footing when providing internet access services, allowing data to be blocked or speeded up only in exceptional cases (e.g. when it is necessary to prevent cyber attacks or traffic bottlenecks). While the new framework may wish to see stronger principles of open internet and net neutrality, so that all internet traffic is treated equally, regardless of the sender, receiver, type, content, device, service or application, it would now be necessary to amend and effectively reject the difficult agreement reached by the Council and Parliament, which in turn would also mean dragging the stripe to the intended abolition of roaming charges, which would make life easier for many European and also Latvian consumers.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report. From the outset, I fully support the abolition of roaming charges, the date of which has stabilised in this report for June 2017, with a gradual reduction since April 2016. At the moment, when, thanks to the free movement of people within the European Union, a large number of people live and work in another Member State, it is only a logical step that high roaming charges for calls, messages or data should be abolished.  At the same time, I believe that the abolition of roaming charges is an important step towards the gradual creation of the Digital Single Market.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The abolition of roaming charges in the European Union is becoming a reality. This is not an immediate decision, as it will be in full force from June 2017, but from 1 April 2016 customers will experience a marked price reduction. This decision and the benefits for EU citizens of this show how much good can be done when the efforts of the EU institutions are directed at solving a specific problem that really makes life difficult for the citizens of the Member States. The situation where free travel is linked to the costs to be incurred for absurdly high roaming charges, particularly as regards data transmission, did not comply with the requirements of the digital age. Fortunately, the resistance of telecommunications companies has been overcome and this issue has been regulated. However, the proposed solutions are not absolute and contain a number of safeguards to protect the market from so-called shopping tourism. This solution meets the specific needs of persons travelling within the European Union, but is not intended to introduce a competition mechanism between telecommunications operators operating in the Member States. On the basis of the benefits of these changes for the citizens of the European Union, I voted in favour of this solution. I believe that this is a good forecast for the future and a preview of the positive changes that will bring about the work on the Digital Single Market in the EU.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This document deals with the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Directive 2002/22/EC and Regulation (EU) No 531/2012 in the framework of the 'single market for electronic communications'. This report aims to deepen the single market for electronic communications in the EU. According to its advocates, electronic communications companies will be able to operate and provide the service wherever their customers are established. However, this is fundamentally a giant step in deepening the process of liberalising the sector that favours the major powers and sharpens the interest of multinationals in gaining a monopoly on electronic communications. The Regulation has positive aspects related to the abolition of the roaming tariff and the neutrality of the Internet. The positive aspects do not, however, erase a path of liberalisation whose consequences will far outweigh them. We voted against it.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The shared text, which emerged from the negotiations between Parliament and the Council, seems unsatisfactory.  On the one hand, the end of roaming is postponed to 2017, on the other hand the rules are designed in such a way as to allow telephone operators to spread lost earnings on other tariffs, to the detriment of consumers. This does not undermine the privileged positions acquired over the years by telephone companies and lacks the courage to defend the interests of the community effectively.  Furthermore, we agree to throw away the possibility of clearly and clearly establishing net neutrality, which is essential if we are to create a truly free, competitive market, dedicated to innovation and transparency. The concept of net neutrality is being replaced by an ambiguous definition of 'open access' which does not put all European citizens on an equal footing when accessing services and content available on the internet. This situation makes it possible to strengthen the dominant positions of large operators and service providers, obscuring independent suppliers with disadvantageous treatment.  I therefore voted in favour of the amendments, in order to restore a clear definition of 'net neutrality' that is a real guarantee of freedom and equality for all citizens.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Eu Member States should not be allowed to transport things, goods in external countries, with which they may carry out the death penalty, or torture, inhuman and cruel treatment. I really like this report and the message of it. Especially if we think that the death penalty violates the right to life, torture violates the right to human dignity. But the same fundamental rights are violated by wars, and in particular by unjust proxy wars, to which European citizens have nothing to do with or would not have anything to do with it. And where they kill people, civilians, women, children, etc. I wonder why, in this respect, prohibitions are not being set up or why it is not clear under what conditions and in what strictly regulated cases weapons and other instruments to assist in wars can be exported from Eu Member States.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I support this report. Last time we debated the ban on the death penalty everywhere in the world. We, as Europeans who protect human rights, are fighting the death penalty, the torture and humiliation of people. If we do not want to just stay on the word and speak out against the death penalty and criticise China, Iran or Saudi Arabia for the huge number of death sentences, we must also do something concrete. And this report just leads to the fact that we are able to restrict exports ourselves, restrict the export of goods or even ban the export of goods that can be used for torture or the death penalty, i.e. our economic interests here go a little sideways, and we primarily defend human rights, life and the dignified treatment of man. I agree with that and support the report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent In the first plenary session in Strasbourg in October, the oral question of the death penalty, which was put to the Council of Ministers by my colleague Leina Valenciano on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, was already discussed.  I would like to repeat what I said a few weeks ago. In today's world, especially given the always-existing possibility of the death penalty being imposed on people who may have nothing to do with the crimes committed against them at all, it is an inappropriate practice to renount. The death penalty is an inappropriate practice and every year hundreds, even thousands, of people in the European Union lose their lives, and while many of them have indeed committed all-bloody crimes, the death penalty should not be the only punishment. Life imprisonment can often be a much more effective method of punishment. Thank you!

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I personally advocate respect for human life and oppose the death penalty and have supported the adoption of this Regulation, which also reflects the European Union's commitment to the death penalty. I see the Regulation on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment as a civilizational reach and a significant example of the consistency by which the European Union seeks to prevent and aggravate trade in said goods. Amending this Regulation meets the challenges of time and adopts a new list of prohibited products. Unfortunately, we are still witnessing numerous executions of death sentences in the world, their numbers are growing year after year and I personally consider every death sentence inhumane. It is clear that the adoption of this Regulation will not abolish the death penalty, but I hope it will affect to make its execution less possible.  I support this amendment and continue to advocate the continuation of the European policy of advocating the abolition of the death penalty on a global front.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the EU is not just a marketplace. It should, and does, defend international human rights standards. We reject the use of torture and the death penalty. Indeed, the vast majority of MEPs voted for its abolition last month in this Chamber. The way we trade with the rest of the world must reflect these fundamental values. The changes proposed by the Commission and amended by MEPs today and in the Trade Committee in which I sit will improve existing EU legislation. This text will ensure that no EU company can profit from torture by oppressive regimes, and that no EU company trading in execution or torture equipment can access the EU market. I supported the report tabled and I support EU action in this field, because I support a European Union which puts its principles into action.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I take a very dim view of torture and anything which could be used for torture around the world, and I recognize the difficulties which this report is trying to prevent and protect against in that respect. With the issue of capital punishment, my views are also fairly well known: I am no fan of the death penalty per se. But, at the same time, I believe that it is the sovereign right of other countries across the world to make their own decisions as to whether or not they should or should not have the death penalty. I do not believe it is for us to impose a particular worldview upon those other nations. I also have concerns that, for example, America can no longer get particular chemicals used in executions, and now they are using methods which have actually ended up being more painful rather than less, so I have a concern about unintended consequences. Overall, therefore, I felt it best to abstain on this report.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to incorporate Parliament's position into the Commission's proposal on trade in products which can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Parliament's position reinforces the prohibition of this type of trade, including with regard to transit and export rules and services associated with this type of trade. That's why I voted for it.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on the proposed regulation on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  This proposal aims to amend Regulation 1236/2005 of June 2005, which aimed to prevent and prohibit all exports of this type of equipment, by extending the ban to brokerage and transit services.  Opposed to any form of torture, I was in favour of the current legislation. However, I do not think that a hardening of it was necessary.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report established the European Parliament's position on the negotiations with the Council on the rules to be governed by trade in products which may be used to carry out the death penalty.  The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats, in alliance with other political groups, has succeeded in introducing a provision in the regulation allowing customs authorities to confiscate all items which may not be included in the regulation but are suspected of being used to commit the death penalty or torture.  That is why I voted in favour of the report and the amendments as set out in the Committee on International Trade.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. In June 2005, the European Union banned all exports of equipment whose purpose is torture or the application of the death penalty. Since then, the marketing of such goods has been subject to restrictions and a regime of authorisation by the relevant national authorities.  This report is intended to tighten the legislation and extend it to brokerage and transit services. In addition, the text includes prison overcrowding, lack of medical care or prohibition of contact with the outside world in the definition of torture. Although opposed to torture, the tightening of the existing system is irrelevant.  I therefore abstained on the Commission's proposal.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to condemn the use of torture and the death penalty and the trade in goods aimed at inflicting cruel treatment. This trade is contrary to the values proneed by the European Union.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to further strengthen the EU'˗ s role as a key and responsible global player in the fight against the abolition of the death penalty and torture. It aims to strengthen the provisions on additional services related to the transport of goods, as well as transit, technical assistance and commercial marketing. Member States should be able to prohibit or suspend the transfer of security-related goods which clearly cannot be used for any purpose other than execution, torture or other ill-treatment. I also support the proposal to set up a coordination group for equipment, to establish a periodic review mechanism, for a more systematic exchange of information and reporting in order to improve supervision and the effective implementation of this Regulation.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I abstained on this text, which is based on a nais angelism, notably by extending the concept of "torture" excessively: prison overcrowding, lack of medical care, prohibition of all contact with the outside world, etc.  Will Ms Schaake soon claim that deprivation of liberty is an unbearable torture of criminals held in prisons?

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I have obviously supported the proposal as amended by the Committee on International Affairs to strengthen the legal framework on the prevention of torture, and in particular to prevent the export of goods and substances that could be used for the execution of such acts.  The CURRENT EU ban on trade in certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment would therefore have its scope extended. The Union maintains a strong principled opposition to torture, the abolition of which is one of the main priorities of the Union's human rights policy.  Torture is a cruel and inhumane act. Thirty years after the historic adoption of the Convention against Torture, and despite the almost universal condemnation of the practice, torture remains a global scourge. There is therefore an urgent need to act to reverse this trend and to strengthen all means in this direction.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on this text is positive. Given how complicated and sensitive the control of trade in the goods in question is, especially those with dual use, I believe it is important to do so as precisely as possible and without unnecessary burdens limiting trade in goods with legitimate end-uses. These controls must also be flexible and adapt to technological developments and developments at world level.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this report from the Committee on International Trade, which concerns the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of inflicting capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment or treatment. While it is indeed laudable to seek to prohibit the transit of goods subject to export and import bans in order to prevent the transfer of elements to inflict inhuman treatment, Mrs Schaake's report does not set clear limits on the concept of torture, which is now infinitely extended at the risk of running into the limits of the principle of reality. On the other hand, I fear the temptation to make criminal legislation uniformity at the expense of member states' sovereignty.  Because of these questions about the applicability of the text in its current form, I therefore preferred to abstain.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting because I believe that an excessive extension of the scope of the legislative proposal risks making companies pass on the costs of the positive opposition to third countries that apply torture.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2006, the Regulation was adopted prohibiting the export of a number of products which have no other practical use other than to apply the death penalty, torture or other abuse, and imposes prior authorisation for the export of another list of products, in principle lawful, but which could also be used at destination for unwanted purposes. However, due to the emergence of new risky products, such as anesthetics used in third countries for lethal injection, and rapid technological changes, it is necessary to improve their effectiveness and include instruments that could be used at destination as instruments of torture and the death penalty, even if they had not originally been manufactured or marketed in the EU for that purpose.  The Socialists have also succeeded in the proposal prohibiting technical assistance and commercial intermediation services and including a generic clause, which allows Member States to prevent the export of other goods, not provided for in the Regulation, on which there is a well-founded suspicion that they could be used for torture or capital punishment in the country of destination. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has given Parliament its position on trade in certain goods that could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. EU export controls are an instrument of external trade policy, serving a number of more important policy objectives. The Anti-Torture Regulation is a unique instrument contributing to the protection of human rights by controlling goods and activities that are used or could be misused for executions, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to a long-term EU policy aimed at abolishing the death penalty and preventing torture worldwide.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Torture and physical punishment of individuals, whether it is done by terrorists or prescribed by the laws of individual countries, does not fall into the 21st century.  Despite the fact that humanity has made enormous progress throughout history in eradicating such acts, we still face horrific cases of torture or physical punishment on a daily basis. If we expect such actions to happen from societies that do not have the same value system as the Western part of which we are, we must in no way tolerate that this is happening here.  I therefore welcome the efforts to overhaul the control of trade in torture equipment in the EU and to ban the production of such equipment. EU export controls, including lists of military equipment, dual-use items, firearms and torture equipment, are also crucial in such a way as to make controls as effective as possible.  I believe that measures such as the introduction of a ban on brokerage services for prohibited goods and clearer controls on the use of medical products for injection-in execution and greater exchange of information between countries on transactions in trade in such goods strengthen controls to an appropriately high level.  Torture and physical punishment cannot be eradicated, but we can limit it. I therefore support all measures that lead in this direction. One of the measures is the proposed directive.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report, which aims to contribute to the abolition of the death penalty worldwide. Moves such as banning the trade in items that can be used as means of torture by various regimes, as well as the control of lethal drugs, will at the very least make it harder for them to procure the necessary items. More importantly, a clear message will be sent that EU member states are fiercely opposed to the death penalty in the world.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulation against Torture" (Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005) is the single instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are used (or could be misused) to practice the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  Today we need to update both the list of marketable substances and articles and the list of countries where trade is possible. The European Union must continue to be active in defending the dignity and value of human life and in the fight for the abolition of the death penalty in the world. A useful act in this regard, as well as morally coherent and dutiful, is to prevent the transit and/or marketing of objects and substances that can be used to torture or apply the death penalty to countries that do not respect human rights or where the death penalty is still provided for by the current judicial system.  The EU's leading role in the world in protecting human rights and improving the quality of global justice also passes through this House today.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Since June 2005, EU law prohibits any export of material whose sole purpose is torture or the application of the death penalty. There are certain restrictions on the marketing of goods that could be used to impose the death penalty or for torture. It is up to the national competent authority to issue the authorization. The report calls for tougher legislation and extend it to brokerage and transit services. In addition, the text includes prison overcrowding, lack of medical care or prohibition of contact with the outside world in the definition of torture. We are absolutely opposed to the use of torture. That is why we were in line with the current legislation that provided for the tools used for this purpose. Nevertheless, we consider that it was not necessary to harden it. That is why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The right to physical and mental integrity is effectively guaranteed to every citizen of the Union, but in order to be consistent and to continue effectively the fight against torture and other inhumane punishment and treatment throughout the world, we must ensure that the States with which the Union collaborates also comply with these democratic principles.  This amendment to the Regulation ensures our consistency, as institutions of this Union, and the desire to continue the fight, by establishing controls at the EU's external borders, precisely in order to prevent the export of possible elements with potentially lethal and inhumane uses.  I voted in favour of the report on both the prohibition of trade in goods and related 'single-use' technical assistance for torture and execution, as well as a system of authorisation for 'multifunctional' goods that could be used for torture and execution by lethal injections. I am convinced that there will continue to be as close a collaboration as possible between all the committees involved in strengthening Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, so that the EU's objectives of protecting human dignity and life, also contained in the Treaty of Lisbon and the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, are achieved and respected beyond its borders.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 While I agree with the objectives of the legislative proposal, I consider it appropriate that its adoption should not entail excessive burdens for companies trading certain products for legitimate purposes and not related to torture or the death penalty.  I abstained on an un balanced text, but I agree with its aims.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. According to the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, the death penalty and torture must be abolished. In the EU Member States, both practices are formally prohibited. One of the Union's duties is to disseminate these principles to the rest of the world. It is therefore important to regulate the trade in goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing the death penalty or torture. Through this legislation we guarantee trade with third countries that respect European values. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, because it is necessary to prohibit in the most decisive way all exports or imports of goods that can be used to impose cruel penalties, and to increase monitoring of export authorisations for goods that could be used for those purposes. Europe has been an area free of the death penalty since 1997 and must also be an area free from torture and inhuman and degrading practices. The Member States must in no way be indirectly complicit in those who still impose this type of punishment in the world.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which strengthens the existing Anti-Torture Regulation, imposing EU-wide export controls on items that can be used for torture and execution such as drugs used in lethal injections.  In particular, I voted in favour of the establishment of an Anti-Torture Coordination Group which is a reviewing and reporting body with representatives from all EU Member States, but without any new powers or transfer of powers away from the Member States.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I welcome the Commission’s proposal to extend restrictions on certain goods that could be used to torture or punish inhumanely. Sale of such goods should be monitored by relevant authorities in order to prevent any illegal practices.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulation against Torture" is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are used, or could be misused, to carry out the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Legitimate. An EU-wide approach that ensures a level playing field is essential in this respect. At the same time, the report points out the need to ensure that export control regimes are valid in the long term and flexible in order to be able to adapt quickly to technological developments and developments in the world.  In accordance with what is expressed in the text and having accepted some important amendments tabled by our group, including the need to have an obligation to provide information also at trade fairs for the sale of these products, I voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I oppose capital punishment. While I do not wish to force any country to change its laws, I do not think we should supply them with the tools to carry out those laws.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Yesterday's debate has once again enabled us to see a fundamental aspect of the European Union's culture highlighted: respect for human rights. While recognising the importance of international commercial transactions, especially those of medical or parapharmaceutical goods, the Union cannot put the requirements of trade before those of the protection of fundamental rights, and must therefore do everything in its power to prevent the facilitating of infringements of these rights through trade in goods that are functional to them. The Union's contribution is strong in the conviction that every single effort to abolish the death penalty throughout the world is essential to contribute to a fairer world, based on respect for the life and dignity of the individual. Similarly, we must reject torture, which is expressly prohibited by Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights, which has been a point of reference for all of us for 65 years. The Union, in all its work, is fighting for the abolition of the death penalty, and this proposal follows the path marked by years of battles for human rights. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report stressed that exports at EU level are tools of foreign trade policy and serve a number of broader policy objectives. Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 is hereby amended as follows: It is a unique instrument which contributes to the protection of human rights through checks on the species and activities used or which could be misused for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to the EU's established policy of globally eliminating the death penalty and preventing torture.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is based on a proposal for a European Commission regulation on the need to prohibit or restrict trade in goods that could be used to impose the death penalty. In the course of the group negotiations within the inta committee, which is responsible for the substance, I have repeatedly stressed the need to ensure uniform rules with regard to exports of these products from the EU. In the same way, however, I have repeatedly stressed the need to take into account the demands of all the parties involved so that the activities of those European companies that produce and market lawfully do not become prejudicial, avoiding the provision of unnecessary limits. At the end of an in-depth analysis of the text in committee and during meetings at group level, the text as negotiated seemed to me to be very balanced, which is why I decided to vote in favour of the report.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because it is a unique instrument for the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are or could be misused to practise the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman and degrading treatment or punishment.  I think it is important to ensure the right combination of legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture purposes and to effectively control items with potential lethal uses. In this respect, it is essential to ensure uniformity in export controls.
