The rapporteur is in favour of an approach involving necessary and proportionate controls without unnecessary burdens limiting trade in goods with legitimate end-uses. I think these points are important in trying to put an end to certain inhuman practices, which should have nothing to do with today's society.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal is crucial for the continued respect that the European Union demonstrates for universal human rights. In limiting the access to goods and substances used to torture and commit capital punishment, these regulations ensure the lives and wellbeing of all are protected. This regulation recognises the importance of impeding entities profiting from the violation of human rights by inter alia selling equipment intended to facilitate capital punishment. Updating the list of death-penalty ‘safe states’ is an important step in encouraging countries to continue treating human rights with due care and respect. The new rules avoid excessive regulation or bureaucratic burdens for legitimate medicine use. The proposal previously only regulated medicinal products for capital punishment but now also regulates for products used for torture or for other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 is a single instrument contributing to the protection of human rights by monitoring the products and activities that are used, or they may be used abusively to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, and its review is an important step in the objective of further strengthening the EU's role as a major player in the fight against the death penalty and in the eradication of torture. I support the Schaake Report as it considers it necessary to update the checklists, ensuring an appropriate combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent the production, trade and use of torture goods or products used for lethal, inhuman or degrading purposes. Such controls should, however, be proportionate, not creating superfluous burdens restricting trade which have a legitimate purpose, and should take into account the judgments of international courts, the deliberations of the relevant UN bodies or the reports of the European Committee for the Prevention of Torture, Punishment or Degrading Treatment, etc..

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the increasing complexity of external trade, it is necessary to strengthen the European Union's external action instruments by changing export controls, which will have to be more flexible and able to adapt rapidly to technological developments and world developments.  It is necessary to promote legislative, administrative and judicial measures to prevent and prohibit the production and trade in goods for torture and items that could potentially be used for lethal and inhuman use. I therefore welcome the review of this regulation, as it aims to further strengthen the role of the European Union as a world leader in the fight against the practice of the death penalty and to eliminate inhuman and degrading treatment using torture. National authorities are required to carry out checks and checks on goods and to exchange information on exports of the products covered by the regulation concerned.  By amending this regulation, it would be desirable to strike the right balance between the legitimate interests of the producing companies and the potential uses of certain articles for the purposes of torture and capital punishment. Export controls should be necessary and proportionate, without unnecessary burdens limiting trade in legitimately used goods.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal is meant to amend the Anti-torture Goods Regulation of previous that the Parliament implemented to stem the trade of certain goods that have no other practical use except for capital punishment, torture or other inhuman cruel acts. It is important to control the export of goods which are used for the death penalty and torture. However, the requests arising from some EU companies for not hindering legitimate trade are also well—founded. A careful balance has to be found between legitimate interests of companies and possible use of certain products for capital punishment.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The "Regulation against Torture" contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities that are used or could be misused to practice the death penalty or inflict torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment. The report provides for long-term control regimes, which must be flexible in order to be adapted to technological developments in the world. In order to ensure compliance, a list has also been drawn up specifying the prohibited articles, thus giving greater clarity to exporters and importers. It has also been requested, where possible, to monitor online marketing services that could contribute to the spread of goods that can be used for torture.   I am voting in favour, given the very nature of the measure as it helps to eliminate the death penalty throughout the world.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to incorporate Parliament's position into the Commission's proposal on trade in products which can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Parliament's position reinforces the prohibition of this type of trade, including with regard to transit and export rules and services associated with this type of trade. That's why I voted for it.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report concerns an amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 prohibiting trade in torture equipment. The European Commission, with its legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision, adopted in 2010. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make trade in goods that can be used for such purposes subject to the prohibition of goods not used for anything other than torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break regulations. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in such 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The revision of this regulation aims to contribute to the elimination of the death penalty worldwide and prevent torture through EU-wide controls on exports of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injection. This revision includes adding export licencing controls for lethal drugs and prohibiting trade in new items which have become regularly used for torture by certain regimes such as spiked batons, electric shock sleeves and cuffs, for example. I am totally against capital punishment and as these restrictions might help in deterring such executions I gave it my full support in plenary.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of a single market at European level and the globalisation of trade transactions, which are becoming increasingly complex, EU controls on trade in torture instruments are proving to be extremely important. On the other hand, the European Parliament's efforts to prevent torture contribute primarily to the protection of human rights. The role of member states is also vital, and monitoring of the implementation of Member States' commitments and their obligation to report and exchange information is necessary. I believe that it is necessary to ensure consistency of EU export controls so that products do not suffer a duplication of controls, but checks and possibly sanctions must be effectively complied with.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 8 October 2015, the European Parliament adopted a resolution against the death penalty, reaffirming the principles of defence of the right to life and the prohibition of the death sentence set out in Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Within the broader framework of the fight against the complete abolition of this practice, the European Union must continue to play an active role in prohibiting trade in goods that could be used for the death penalty, such as medicines used for lethal injections in third countries. In the same way, it must continue to strongly oppose the trade in instruments used for torture and for inflicting inhuman or degrading treatment.  The revision of this regulation seems very timely because, 10 years later, it allows the updating of product coverage and the inclusion of an all-encompassing clause together with the ban on the transit of these goods into the EU, demonstrating the strong will to achieve the objectives of the regulation. I voted strongly in favour of the revision of this regulation, as I firmly believe that the European Union must continue to play a leading role in the active defence of human rights, implementing and updating all the instruments at its disposal for this purpose.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes to revise the regime prohibiting exports and imports of goods for torture and executions and the authorisation regime for goods that may be diverted for use in torture. The aim is to prevent controlled property from being used to impose the death penalty by lethal injection on the one hand. We intervened with the EPP Group to avoid further constraints on European exporters of certain goods affected by the proposal, but whose trade is lawful. Considering that this report is balanced, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I am in favour of amending the regulation on the trade of certain goods that may be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is essential that the export of goods that can be used to impose the death penalty or torture be strictly controlled. By this vote, we then gave a strong position of Parliament for the continuation of negotiations.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is essential to support the Eu ropean Union's policy of eliminating the death penalty and preventing torture. When the legislation is revised, I think it would be appropriate to provide for the updating of the lists of goods subject to controls.  It is essential to prohibit trade in torture instruments and to effectively control items with potential lethal uses, avoiding the introduction of unnecessary burdens that would risk restricting trade in legitimately used goods. In this respect, I agree with the need for an approach aimed at ensuring uniformity and flexibility in controls, without subjecting products to double inspections and ensuring a rapid adaptability to technological developments.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. This regulation updates the 2005 list of goods and substances prohibited for export or subject to customs clearance as likely to be used for torture or death penalty purposes. The list has been expanded to include new products but also related services, such as online catalogues for the distribution of these goods. The transit of these goods through the territory of the European Union will also not be allowed. Finally, certain substances may only be exported to countries that have not ratified the International Convention on the Abolition of the Death Penalty after authorisation.  It will be up to each EU Member State to implement the regulation and thus grant export permits for controlled goods, conduct border controls and decide on sanctions in the event of a breach. That is why the European Commission must ensure, without excessive bureaucratic burdens or restrictions on the legitimate use of medicines, that the rules are fair throughout Europe.  In adopting this report, the European Parliament reaffirms the importance that the European Union must attach to respecting and promoting human rights in the world.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission, with its present legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision of 17 June 2010 amending the Anti Torture good regulation EC/1236/2005. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break regulations. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in such 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Europe has an important role to play in the fight against torture and the abolition of the death penalty. The 2005 Anti-Torture Regulation already establishes an export control system for products that are or can be used in cases of capital punishment or torture. In particular, an export ban is imposed on countries that have not yet abolished the death penalty. The current regulations, however, contain a number of deficiencies that are highly time to address.  I therefore voted in favour of this proposal because the technical updates proposed by the Commission are essential and aim to ensure stricter controls. The idea includes expanding the current EU ban to include services, finance, transport and insurance. The aim is also to prohibit the transit of goods banned by the EU and listed in the 2005 regulation. In addition, we have revised the annex, which lists safe countries to which exports of controlled medical substances do not require authorization.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission, with its present legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision of 17 June 2010 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods applicable in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break regulations.  At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in such 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposed regulation concerned the trade in goods that could be used to impose capital punishment or torture. In wishing to ban these goods in the Union, Europe is using this opportunity to extend the concept of torture disproportionately. Considering isolation, lack of care and prison overcrowding as torture, Europe is going too far. Thus, by moving away from the original definition, it will be able to condemn wrongly and through Member States, which are nevertheless struggling to improve the conditions of detention. States must maintain their free exercise of sovereignty. As this proposal is contradictory and contains many overly general amendments, I abstained in the vote.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Schaake report in order to strengthen EU-wide controls in the trade in equipment that could be used for capital punishment or to abuse human rights, whilst also enabling simplified procedures for legitimate trade. The input of the UK delegations has amended this report in order enable the use of certain drugs usable in lethal execution, subject to EU export controls.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as a whole, as amendments are needed to ensure a ban on the sale of items that can be used for killing, torturing and degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission, with its present legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision of 17 June 2010 amending Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on 'Anti Torture good regulation'. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break the rules. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in such 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: José Inácio Faria (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this report, my vote was naturally against the safeguarding of human rights, the right to life and the right of citizens not to be exposed to cruel or inhuman treatment. The MPT is a humanist party and, as such, will always be on the side of those who oppose the death penalty and torture. As president of the MPT and as a Liberal MEP, I voted against free trade in this type of substance, used for practices that should no longer take place in the 21st century.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The Anti-Torture Regulation is a single instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It also lays down a ban on trade in 'single-use' products intended for torture and executions and their technical assistance, as well as a system for authorising fair products which can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection. I agree that it is important to ensure an appropriate combination of eu legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures in order to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods, and to effectively monitor products that may be used for lethal or inhuman purposes.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, which aims to combat torture, is an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It aims to contribute to achieving the goal of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for the trade of listed products. The Regulation lays down a ban on trade in "single-use" products intended for torture and execution, as well as a system of authorisation of fair products which can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection. In a context where external trade operations are increasingly complex, the effective implementation of national authorities' controls, checks, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions is essential. The rapporteur recalls the need to adequately monitor the implementation of Member States' commitments, including their obligation to present and exchange information through a secure and encrypted system on refused authorisations and notifications. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it attempts to tackle the issue of torture.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the main objective of the revision of the regulation in question is to eliminate the death penalty and prevent torture through more rigorous control of imports of torture goods and drugs used in lethal injections. This review adds licensing controls on lethal drugs and prevents the trafficking of such new items, which are demonstrably used for torture by various government regimes.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report as I am not satisfied with the text proposed by the Commission. I believe that more drastic instruments could be adopted concerning the trade in certain items that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the revision of this regulation which aims to contribute to the elimination of the death penalty worldwide and prevent torture through EU-wide controls on exports of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injection. The revision includes adding export licencing controls for lethal drugs and prohibiting trade in new items which have become regularly used for torture by certain regimes such as spiked batons, electric shock sleeves and cuffs for example. The so call ‘catch all clause’ will make it boundary for customs authorities to seize any good, whether listed in the regulation annexes or not, if there are reasonable grounds to believe that its final use will be for the purpose of torture. Finally, I welcome the establishment of a Union General Export Authorisation for countries that have undertaken firm international commitments and the use of urgency procedure to amend the lists of banned/controlled items, which will allow the EU to react more quickly to emerging trends and human rights crackdowns in the future.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission, with its present legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision of 17 June 2010 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods applicable in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break regulations. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in such 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Europe, which guarantees the dignity and rights of individuals, must first and foremost safeguard and respect the lives and well-being of its citizens, using every measure at its disposal – administrative, judicial and legislative – to prevent trade in and misuse of goods and instruments for the purposes of torture, ill-treatment, mortifying or cruel actions against human beings. I therefore fully agree with and offer my full support to the Commission's proposal for a more stringent revision of Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's position on the proposal for a revision of Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005, better known as the 'regulation against torture' and relating to trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Legislation is an important piece because it contributes to the protection of human rights; its revision is long overdue, and updating the lists of goods subject to controls is a step in the right direction. The EU must therefore continue along the path of combating the death penalty and torture through policies combining prohibitions and authorisation requirements for the trade in these weapons.  Given the complexity of foreign trade in a globalised world, it is therefore appropriate to combine EU judicial and external legislative measures with administrative sanctions, but also to raise awareness of the marketing of these goods and, in general, against the death penalty and torture.  Finally, I hope that we will reach an agreement with the Council in good time and that the EP will be able to defend this position to the full.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Trade in certain goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other treatment or punishment' and the amendments tabled by the committee responsible, as I share the position that, in a region of the world that prohibits the death penalty, there is also no market for products that are used for it.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. There is rightly no death penalty in the European Union. It is therefore consistent to prevent exports of goods used to carry out the death penalty.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not condone capital punishment, but I do not think it is the job of pious MEPs to preach to other nations about what they can and cannot do. An unintended consequence of banning materials that may be used for capital punishment is that, in the USA, there have been some gruesome scenes as a swift execution has been impossible, causing needless suffering and distress. What next?  Banning rope?   In the end, the rapporteur asked for the vote to be cancelled so it could go back to the committee.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I welcome the strengthening of this legislation designed to ensure the EU is not complicit in torture, and to fulfil the EU’s commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture throughout the world. Updates to this legislation will ensure EU companies do not profit from torture in oppressive regimes, and send a strong signal that those who trade in execution and torture goods, including technical assistance and supplier services, that they cannot access the EU market. In particular, I welcome new measures to improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions and strongly stand behind the EU ban on trading drugs intended for the death penalty.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 establishes an export control regime aimed at preventing products exported from the EU from being used to inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. In order to provide clarity on the purpose and modalities of these controls, a specific chapter on export controls should be inserted to prevent controlled products from being used to apply the death penalty. In addition, we voted to extend this control regime to products in transit. We thus improve a Regulation which is consistent with the values of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because we consider it common sense that we do not allow our companies to trade in third countries with materials that we have banned in Europe because they are related to inhuman or torture practices. In this report, the European Parliament calls for a ban on the sale, marketing and advertising (included in its online variants) of those goods, as well as the prohibition on the transit of those goods through the territory of the Union.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I, alongside my fellow Labour MEPs, have voted in favour of this report. As Labour MEPs we welcome the strengthening of this legislation designed to ensure the EU is not complicit in torture, and to fulfil the EU’s commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture throughout the world. Updates to this legislation will ensure EU companies do not profit from torture in oppressive regimes and sends a strong signal to those who trade in execution and torture goods that they cannot access the EU market. In particular we welcome new measures to improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions. We strongly stand behind the EU ban on trading drugs intended for the death penalty which Labour MEPs and the European Union stand firmly against.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on  trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other treatment or punishment because I condemn the death penalty and torture wherever it occurs. With this vote I support vital technical updates that ensure tighter controls and a level playing field in Europe, without creating excessive bureaucratic burdens or restrictions on legitimate medicine use. This regulation is one piece of the bigger legislative puzzle that should ensure Europe is a strong global player that leads in terms of values such as respect for universal human rights.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission, with this legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision of 17 June 2010 amending Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in goods subject to the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. The work of customs authorities should be facilitated in order to take effective action against operators who break the rules. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was very happy to support the updating of this important regulation which aims to eradicate the involvement of EU—based companies in the trade of goods which could be used for capital punishment or torture. The EU is committed to eliminating both torture and the death penalty globally but regrettably both practices still occur with trade in torture tools booming. Although the Commission has twice updated the lists of products covered by the regulation, loopholes still exist. This latest proposed update was strengthened by amendments from the Parliament which I supported which aim to widen the current EU ban to include services, finance, transport and insurance and also ban transit of prohibited goods via the EU. The introduction of a ‘catch all clause’ which allows additional authorisation requirements to be imposed swiftly for goods not covered by the regulation ensures that additional safeguards against risks are in place and allows the regulation sufficient flexibility to react to changing technologies. An important qualification of the clause is that medicinal products not be covered even where they could be used for the purpose of capital punishment to prevent the restriction of legitimate use of medicinal products.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it positively contributes to the long—standing EU policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and the prevention of torture. The report helps achieve these aims by combining the prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods. It governs a ban of trade in ‘single use’ torture and execution items and related technical assistance and an authorisation system for ‘multi-purpose’ items that could be misused for torture and executions by lethal injections.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The Anti-torture Regulation controls the items that are used or misused for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Annex II governs the ban in trade of ‘single-use’ execution and torture items and remains unchanged, and Annex III deals with an export authorisation system for ‘multi-purpose’ items that could be misused (such as restraint chairs, beds fitted with straps and acoustic devices for the purpose of crowd/riot control). In order to avoid superfluous burdens restricting trade of products which have legitimate use, a Union General Export Authorisation for countries that have taken international commitments is established. The European Parliament has removed the following countries from the text proposed by the Commission, as they still retain the death penalty in their legislation: Benin, Liberia, Madagascar, Mongolia, São Tomé and Principe. It has also added Gabon because it ratified the Second Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. A specific list of items provides clarity and eases compliance, and Parliament’s proposal to include an urgency procedure providing for immediate application of the Commission act will ensure that the annexes are updated swiftly with new products and technologies. This proposal was very likely to pass and I supported it.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the European People's Party, I welcome the report. It is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break regulations. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We very much welcome the strengthening of this legislation, which will ensure the EU is not complicit in torture. It will also fulfil our commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture, throughout the world. We must do everything we can to ensure EU companies are not profiting from torture in oppressive regimes. In particular, we welcome new measures which will improve the speed of reacting to suspected transactions involving goods used for execution and torture. Labour MEPs strongly support the EU ban on the trade of drugs intended for use in executions.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is outrageous that unscrupulous dealers have been able to find loopholes in EU trade rules to allow the export of goods used in torture or for the death penalty. This has allowed European brokers to sell the equipment, the open promotion of previously prohibited equipment such as body-worn shock devices, the marketing of security equipment to police - such as electro-shock stun guns, shock batons and shock shields, and the Introduction of new technologies and devices on to the market even if these items could be used in the death penalty, torture or other ill-treatment.  I am proud to have supported Amnesty International’s ‘Grasping the Nettle’ report and ‘Stop Torture’ campaign to strengthen the EU’s controls and today to have voted to support proposals which will now combat the European Union’s complicity in what is a violation of human rights. I am proud that our Human Rights Sub-Committee has played a key role in bringing this forward and I urge the Commission and Council to come to quick agreement with Parliament to enact today’s vote.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this report, which closes a number of loopholes in the existing law. The EU is founded upon the respect for human rights regardless of what UK Tories may argue to the contrary. It is therefore essential that we restrict the trade in goods which could be used in torture.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, on the basis that I support the fundamental value and policy of the European Union on opposing any form of torture.  It is essential to ensure legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures that will prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods that can be used for torture purposes and control those that have potential inhumane use. In addition, it is necessary to adapt to the growing technological changes and initiate information sharing and strong synergies between the actors involved. In my view, however, it is necessary to carry out proportionate controls in the form of preventing excessive burdens that would limit legitimate trade.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Since June 2005, the European Union has banned all exports of equipment whose purpose is torture or the application of the death penalty.  The marketing of such goods is subject to restrictions, and a regime of authorisation by the competent national authority.  This report calls for tougher legislation and extend it to brokerage and transit services. In addition, the text includes in the definition of torture, prison overcrowding, lack of medical care or the prohibition of all contact with the outside world. We fight all forms of torture. However, the tightening of the existing arrangement, by the proposed provisions, is not necessary.  So I abstained.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it will restrict the export to third countries of European goods that could be used to inflict capital punishment, torture or other inhumane treatment. Fighting such acts is fundamental and part of my commitments as a European elected official.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report must be rejected. It leads to a disproportionate extension of the scope of the provision. At the same time, it places an excessive burden on manufacturers and exporters and excessively increases the control burden on the part of the authorities.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly supported this report due to the importance of its subject matter: preventing the supply and trade of instruments of torture and cruel punishment in the EU. We are committed to standing against acts of torture, and thus will do all that is necessary to prevent such cruel and inhumane acts from taking place. An urgency procedure to allow immediate bans of such products has been introduced, as well as a ‘catch-all procedure’ so as to stop any export where there is reasonable concern that the goods in question would be used for torture.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The Anti-Torture Regulation refers to products and goods that may be abused for torture, the execution of the death penalty or other cruel, inhumandegrading degrading treatment or punishment. Annex II regulates the prohibition of trade in "single-use" goods and remains unchanged and Annex III deals with an authorisation system for the export of "multi-purpose" items that could be misused. In order to avoid unnecessary trade burdens that could restrict the trade of products, the European Commission authorises the export of these goods to countries that comply with international agreements and obligations. Countries that still carry out the death penalty and do not comply with these agreements and obligations are not authorised, including Benin, Liberia, Madagascar, Mongolia and Sao Tomé and Principe. A specific list of products and goods provides clarity and facilitates compliance. This proposal was adopted and I voted in favour.

name: Stelios Kouloglou
text: (GUE/NGL), in writing. ‒ This report proposes a review of the existing regulation in order to strengthen the control of torture tools. The main points of this report are: the prohibition of online and offline marketing, to set up a regular reporting, to review the system by the European Commission and to consider that the EU exports to third countries do not contribute to inhuman practices. Last but not least, the European Union will also have to update it lists with goods and substances which are banned for exports. I voted in favour of this report, since it improves the Commission’s proposal.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Mrs Schaake's report. This proposal is aimed at amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be misused for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The 'regulation against torture' is part of the EU's long-pursued policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. I therefore believe that this proposal is in line with my principles of respect for the dignity of the human person and human rights.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schaake report concerns the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of inflicting capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment.  It envisages prohibiting the transit of goods prohibited from exporting and importing in order to prevent the transfer of elements enabling it to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment and treatment. The text specifies that no derogation could be granted if there is good reason to believe that the assets raised could be used for the purpose of torture or the death penalty.  However, if we can only subscribe to this desire not to participate, even indirectly, in the practices akin to torture by the provision of lethal means, it seems to me that the extension of the concept of torture is far too great, which will cause problems when applied. To show my doubts, I have decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I fully support this report, which aims to contribute to the abolition of the death penalty worldwide and the prevention of torture through EU control of exports of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injections. In particular, I welcomed the introduction of a clause allowing customs to detain any goods included in the annexes or not which are suspected of being used for torture.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to incorporate Parliament's position into the Commission's proposal on trade in products which can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Parliament's position reinforces the prohibition of this type of trade, including with regard to transit and export rules and services associated with this type of trade. That's why I voted for it.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Anti-Torture Regulation regulates the products and goods that may be misused for torture, the execution of the death penalty or other cruel, inhumandegrading degrading treatment or punishment. Annex II regulates the prohibition of trade in "single-use" goods and remains unchanged and Annex III deals with an authorisation system for the export of "multi-purpose" items that could be misused. In order to avoid unnecessary trade burdens that could restrict the trade of products, the European Commission authorises the export of these goods to countries that comply with international agreements and obligations. Countries that still carry out the death penalty and do not comply with these agreements and obligations are not authorised, including Benin, Liberia, Madagascar, Mongolia and Sao Tomé and Principe. A specific list of products and goods provides clarity and facilitates compliance. This proposal was adopted and I voted in favour.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation No. 1236/2005 is a single instrument contributing to the protection of human rights by controlling cases and activities that can be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It is important to properly harmonise legislative, administrative and judicial measures that will effectively control goods with potential lethal or inhumane intent. I supported MP Marietje Schaaka's report on the necessity of fighting the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, because the right to life is the innate right of every individual, as established in Croatia by the Christmas Constitution in 1990.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Union subscribes to the values and protection of universal human rights, including the rejection of the death penalty and torture as inhuman and degrading punishment. To this end, it is essential for the Union to strengthen the control and export of goods and substances that can serve precisely these inhumane methods of enforcement. The introduction of control and prohibition of trade in such goods and services on reasonable suspicion of their misuse and the introduction of a general Union export authorisation in countries that have accepted commitments of the European Convention on Human Rights and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights will strengthen the Union's position and objectives in the field of abolition of the death penalty and the prohibition of torture.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This report is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I warmly welcome this report. The ‘Anti-torture Regulation’ contributes to the long standing EU policy of eliminating death penalty worldwide, and of preventing torture. It helps achieve these goals by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods. It governs a ban of trade in ‘single-use’ torture and execution items and related technical assistance and an authorisation system for ‘multi-purpose’ items that could be misused for torture and executions by lethal injections.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a report aimed at contributing to the protection of human rights through the control of goods or activities that are used or could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The EU has long pursued a policy aimed at ending the execution of the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. It seeks to achieve these objectives on the basis of prohibitions linked to licensing requirements for the trading of listed goods. It follows a prohibition on the trafficking of 'single-use' goods intended for torture and the execution of the death penalty, and the associated technical assistance (Annex II) and the system for approving 'dual-use' goods which could be misused for torture and the execution of the death penalty by lethal injection (Annex III). I believe that the overhaul of EU-wide controls on trade in torture instruments should have been carried out a long time ago and is a step in the right direction, which is why I supported the report in the final vote.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Through the Schaake report, the European Parliament has been asked to vote on updating an "anti-torture" European regulation, initially implemented in 2005, which lists goods and substances whose export to third countries is either prohibited (electric chairs, etc.) or severely controlled (certain chemicals, in particular). As a result of recent technological developments, an upgrade of the texts was necessary to include new products that could be used to impose the death penalty, such as sticks intended to administer electric shocks.  The Schaake report, undeniably ambitious, goes beyond the drafting of a limited list. By introducing catch-all and "final destination" clauses, the text allows the European Union to ban the export of all goods reasonably suspected of being used to inflict cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment in third countries. Such products will not only be banned from exporting, but also from transit within the Union. In line with my support for this text in the INTA committee, and because I am convinced that our trade policy can contribute to the global elimination of the death penalty, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. I strongly oppose and condemn any use of torture, torture, and the goods used for this purpose. Nevertheless, the report goes far too far, as it gives the Commission further powers and places an additional burden on exporters and customs authorities.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. EU law prohibits the sale of property for torture or executions and provides for an authorisation and control regime for "multi-use" goods that may be misappropriated for this purpose.  Since 2011, states have also controlled sales of drugs that can be used by lethal injection for the death penalty, as in the United States. Parliament has come to make important changes to this legislation, such as banning the advertising of these goods, but also their transit through the Union. In response to particularly rapid technological developments in this area, the exchange of information between states may allow new elements to be added to the list of prohibited goods.  I welcome this text which defends the universal requirement for the abolition of the death penalty. I'm voting for. I nevertheless denounce the fact that the Union, which claims to defend this principle in its trade and international agreements in particular, does not do much about it when it comes to the United States of America and the TAFTA.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the report on trade in certain goods which may be used to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inpartoran or degrading treatment or punishment. It is important that there is a clear and systematic approach to the instrument, which combines prohibitions with licensing requirements for the trade of certain products. The export control mechanism is and should be at the service of a wider set of objectives, as the rapporteur states.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report to push forward the negotiations with the Council in order to reach a first reading agreement and once again show the Union’s commitment to a moratorium and eventual end to the death penalty internationally.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Companies operating in the European Union are still trading in a wide range of equipment that can be used for torture or other ill-treatment of human beings, so I welcome the report on the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the provisions in force to date on trade in certain goods that can be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I consider it to be a further step towards implementing the Union's long-standing policy of abolishing the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture. However, if these efforts are to sound credible, the EU must start on its own and prevent companies on its territory from making money from human suffering. The statistics so far show at least 2,466 people in 55 countries who were sentenced to death in 2014, with the number of death sentences and executions continuing to rise this year. We can't just be a spectator in this situation. I appeal all the more to the EU's combination of legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to ban the production and trade of such goods.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of revision of the Regulation on Trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other treatment or punishment. I fully support the main elements of the legislative revision aimed at contributing to the elimination of the death penalty worldwide and prevention of torture through EU-wide controls on exports of torture goods and drugs used for lethal injection. I am in favour of adding export licencing controls for lethal drugs and prohibiting trade in new items which have become regularly used for torture by certain regimes such as spiked batons, electric shock sleeves and cuffs for example.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the revision of the EU ‘Anti-torture Regulation’ which will make it more effective in preventing export of goods which could be used for torture, death penalty and other inhuman treatments. I support the extension of the scope of the regulation so as to include services related to the export of ‘torture goods’ such as marketing, transport, insurance and financial services; the ban of transit of ‘torture-goods’ via the EU and the introduction of a ‘catch-all’ clause which would impose authorisation requirements for other goods not included in the relevant Annexes to the Regulation but whose use could be suspicious. A more effective Anti-torture Regulation will not only better reflect the EU values as embedded in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights but will also enable us to more coherently export such values to the rest of the world.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has proposed the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council with a view to a amendment to Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods applicable in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 contributes to the global eradication of the death penalty and torture by introducing a ban on means and technical assistance for torture and execution only and by creating a licensing system for products suitable for torture and execution in the event of misuse. The review of EU control over the trade in torture equipment has long been timely. The Commission is now proposing to strengthen the control of torture equipment. I fully agree with the aims of the motion and therefore voted in favour of it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 establishes the control of trade in certain goods which may be used to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inotheror or degrading treatment or punishment.  Strengthening the role of the European Union in fighting for the principle of human dignity is necessary by revising this regulation and its provisions, thereby respecting the basis of European values provided for in the Treaty on European Union and the Charter of Fundamental Rights.   The proposed amendments are intended to focus on the conditions under which transfers of goods, technical assistance and marketing are carried out. In the field of external trade operations, Member States should strengthen the ability to suspend or prohibit the transfer of products that are used for lethal or inhuman purposes. Legislative conditions should be created to provide an effective regulation of this type of trade. I am voting in favour of the proposal put forward, as it aims to strengthen protection against human rights violations and aims to ensure balanced and controlled conditions of international trade, while respecting the legitimate interests of companies and the possible use of such products.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schaake report concerns the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 on the trade in certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment. It envisages prohibiting the transit of goods prohibited from exporting and importing in order to prevent the transfer of elements enabling it to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment and treatment. The text specifies that no derogation could be granted if there is good reason to believe that the assets raised could be used for the purpose of torture or the death penalty.  However, if we can only subscribe to this desire not to participate, even indirectly, in the practices akin to torture by the provision of lethal means, it seems to me that the extension of the concept of torture is far too great, which will cause problems when applied. To show my doubts, I have decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the strengthening of this legislation designed to ensure the EU is not complicit in torture, and to fulfil the EU’s commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture throughout the world. Updates to this legislation will ensure EU companies do not profit from torture in oppressive regimes, and send a strong signal that those who trade in execution and torture goods, including technical assistance and supplier services, that they cannot access the EU market. In particular we welcome new measures to improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions. I strongly stand behind the EU ban on trading drugs intended for the death penalty, which Labour MEPs and the European Union stand firmly against.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the trade in certain goods that could be used to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The purpose of this text is to ensure compliance with the ban on the import or export of such goods by strengthening the necessary controls. It is about ensuring respect for human dignity, a fundamental value enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the decision not to proceed with the vote in plenary, in order to facilitate the immediate start of negotiations in the trialogue.  The purpose of this Commission proposal is to identify the assets that can be used to torture and impose the death penalty. The proposal reflects, in fact, the European Union's fundamental values with regard to human rights. This is part of the wider project to increase coherence between the principles of the European Union and its external action. In the name of trade, the European Union cannot, in fact, risk the exchange of goods produced on its territory harming its ethical rules.  In detail, I am particularly in favour of the inclusion of an annex specifying the goods that will have to be the subject of in-depth control and, therefore, of a possible ban. I also welcome with optimism the establishment of a general authorisation at EU level regulating exports to those countries whose irreproachability in this area is debated.  Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to strongly call on the Commission not to stop at the innovation of this regulation but, on the contrary, to continue, in all the necessary forums, in order to prevent corporal punishment and torture from being accepted in the rest of the world, even before they are carried out.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I think this report once again shows the right direction. The right direction to which we are committed on the basis of the fundamental values of the EU, which, unfortunately, we are violating because of the economic and business interests at the moment. Member States and the EU. For example, in public forums, it is often the case that the EU receives the Nobel Peace Prize when its member countries engage in intensive arms trade with dictatorships in third countries. Our stand for the death penalty, torture and inhuman treatment is extremely important. However, it is perverse when poisons in deadly syringes originate from the union. Just like if technical assistance comes from here. This report is therefore important because it aligns our political convictions with the rules that are permissible in business. Congratulations to the report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report, which will contribute to the long—standing EU policy of eliminating the death penalty worldwide and of preventing torture. It will achieve these goals by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text and I believe Ms Schaake did a very good job in her work on this Council Regulation. It is absolutely unacceptable to contemplate that third countries are importing from EU countries technologies, substances and even ITC solutions which they then use to violate basic human rights, infringe personal freedoms, survey and harass politicians, civil society activists and, worst of all, conduct torture and implement capital punishment. Member States obviously don’t do enough in this area and allow their companies to sell such goods and we simply cannot justify making a profit on the violation of all we hold dear in Europe!

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the tightening of the rules on trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other treatment or punishment. I consider them part of an effective fight against human rights violations in the world. I expect that streamlining EU policy in this area will, for example, result in the establishment of an anti-torture coordination group under the Presidency of the Commission, which will include direct cooperation and exchange of information, consultation with exporters, intermediaries and other relevant stakeholders, and the submission of a written annual report to the European Parliament.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report on the trade in certain goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other treatment or punishment makes it difficult, on the one hand, to place on the market goods that can cause suffering to people. On the other hand, however, it also entails a significant increase in bureaucracy and contains requirements that are difficult to implement in practice. I abstained because the discrepancy between better handling of certain goods that can be used to carry out the death penalty and the practical feasibility and the increase in bureaucracy in this report is too great.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the amendments aimed at strengthening the draft. It is important to strengthen the EU's fight against the death penalty and the abolition of torture in the world. The Regulation contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling goods that may be used for the execution of the death penalty or for torture. Hopefully, the trilogy will produce the desired result.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I believe that trade in goods that could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment should be prohibited. In particular, the scope of the Regulation must include medicinal products used for the execution of death by lethal injection.  In addition, it is essential that brokering services relating to goods which are prohibited from being exported and imported are prohibited. Nor should such goods be authorised for transit. The customs authorities should make use of the early warning system for the exchange of relevant information.  It should be noted that the EU should also seek to control other services related to these goods in addition to technical support and brokering services.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I join my personal commitment to that of the whole Union in the campaigns undertaken to eliminate the death penalty in the world and prevent acts of torture, and I particularly agree with the rapporteur's proposal on the need for ever more thorough controls between Member States in view of the increasing complexity of international trade interactions. In the hope that progress will be made in good time and that we will welcome the efforts that the European Union is making in this area.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Despite the ban, companies still sell products that can be used for capital punishment or torture. That is why the Commission has made a proposal which is currently under review by Parliament. But for some changes to take place to lead to improvement, the shortcomings in the original regulation should be addressed. The regulation calls for preventing the trading or exchange of products that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other degrading treatments or punishments.  I believe this is a good decision because there needs to be control over the import and export of such products. The European Union does not support the death penalty and torture and will not participate in the implementation of such punishment in any way, and this means that it will not even deliver such products to countries where the death penalty is still being carried out and where various tortures are still taking place. In order to prevent the execution of the death penalty, the flow of products enabling this enforcement must also be prevented. This regulation, which also brings a list of prohibited products, contributes to this goal.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Schaake report concerns the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of inflicting capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading punishment or treatment. It envisages prohibiting the transit of goods prohibited from exporting and importing in order to prevent the transfer of elements enabling it to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment and treatment. The text specifies that no derogation could be granted if there is good reason to believe that the assets raised could be used for the purpose of torture or the death penalty. However, if we can only subscribe to this desire not to participate, even indirectly, in the practices akin to torture by the provision of lethal means, it seems to me that the extension of the concept of torture is far too great, which will cause problems when applied. To show my doubts, I have decided to abstain in the vote on this text.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The amendment to Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 aims to strengthen the EU's role in the fight against the death penalty and the elimination of torture. This amendment aims to introduce targeted clauses to ensure the end-use of certain goods, in particular medicines, which could be used in practice for the purpose of administering the death penalty, torture practices or other ill-treatment. The text provides for sanctions for economic operators who do not comply with certain obligations. In addition, the EU undertakes to carry out the relevant controls in a proportionate manner and without unnecessary burdens that may restrict trade. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the adoption of this motion for a resolution, which is also prompted by my total opposition to any form of death penalty.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to better control exports and ensure high protection of human rights, the European Parliament has adopted a text aimed at amending the current regulation regulating trade in certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel punishment or treatment. I voted in favour of this text because it is important to prevent such business practices.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider it crucial to prohibit trade in goods likely to be used to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inpartororan or degrading treatment or punishment.  I voted in favour because I consider the text fair and balanced.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Capital punishment is something different nations can have differing views on. However, it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries. We feel that trade should be about trade only, and not a drum on which the EU can politically beat out its political agenda.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In 2006, the Regulation was adopted prohibiting the export of a number of products which have no other practical use other than to apply the death penalty, torture or other abuse, and imposes prior authorisation for the export of another list of products, in principle lawful, but which could also be used at destination for unwanted purposes. However, due to the emergence of new risky products, such as anesthetics used in third countries for injection, lethal, and rapid technological changes that have taken place, it is necessary to improve their effectiveness and include instruments that could be used at destination as instruments of torture and the death penalty, even if they had not originally been manufactured or marketed in the EU for that purpose.  The Socialists have also succeeded in the proposal prohibiting technical assistance and commercial intermediation services and including a generic clause, which allows Member States to prevent the export of other goods, not provided for in the Regulation, on which there is a well-founded suspicion that they could be used for torture or capital punishment in the country of destination. That is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Following Parliament's resolution of 17 June 2010, the Commission published a proposal to amend the "Torture Property Regulation" (Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 on the trade of certain goods that could be used for the purpose of imposing capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment).  I have, of course, supported this text in Parliament, which proposes, in addition to the current regime prohibiting exports and imports of goods for torture and executions (Annex II) and the authorisation regime for goods that can be diverted for use in torture (Annex III), to extend these restrictions to all goods likely to be used for capital punishment and torture.  In particular, the provision of brokerage services and the provision of technical assistance for one of the listed assets should be prohibited if the broker or technical assistance provider is aware that the goods concerned are or may be intended to inflict the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, where checks are carried out to prevent such use.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support this report, which seeks to amend Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which may be used to apply the death penalty, inflict torture, other cruel, inpart or degrading treatment or punishment. The European Parliament has stressed in the last five years of this Regulation that it would need to be adapted to the current reality, given the strong evidence of the use of medicines exported by the EU for the practice of the death penalty in third countries.  As such, I welcome the amendment of Annexes II and III to the Regulation concerning lists of prohibited and regulated goods, as well as the revision of the Regulation itself, highlighting, as a positive aspect, the control of exports used for illicit purposes, the prohibition on the provision of brokerage services related to goods whose marketing implies the practice of the death penalty, torture or other cruel treatment and the exchange of information between customs authorities. Although we are faced with amendments that are not consensual and which involve the challenge of the business world, which claims legitimate trade, I think it is essential to strike a careful balance between this business interest and the full guarantee of effective control of the use of certain products for illegitimate purposes.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which is a continuation of Parliament's resolution of 17 June 2010. In the text, MEPs called on the Commission to amend the 2005 regulation on the trade of certain goods that could be used to impose capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. This text deals with the Commission's new proposal and several points are being modernised: the list of substances and goods that could be banned for export is amended; certain services are concerned, such as marketing, financial services or transportation services, which can contribute to the dissemination of these goods; and the transit of such products in the EU is prohibited.  The text also calls for the establishment of a "coordination group against torture" to coordinate Member States' decisions and exchange information.  In the end, it is a balance that ensures respect for the values defended by the Union while avoiding unnecessary constraints for exporters; It should also be noted that a clause will allow the regulation to be adapted to technological and geopolitical developments in the world.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report on the trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other treatment or punishment because I am opposed to any act of torture and capital punishment. The Member States of the European Union must ensure ever more scrupulous controls on medical products that could be used to torture or kill human beings. I welcome the Commission's decision to insert a new annex indicating which products need more control before being placed on the market.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained because, while I agree with the aims of the legislative proposal, I consider it appropriate that its approval should not impose excessive burdens on companies that trade certain products for legitimate purposes and absolutely not related to torture or the death penalty.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because we consider it common sense that we do not allow our companies to trade in third countries with materials that we have banned in Europe because they are related to inhuman or torture practices. In this report, the European Parliament calls for a ban on the sale, marketing and advertising (included in its online variants) of those goods, as well as the prohibition on the transit of those goods through the territory of the Union.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to incorporate Parliament's position into the Commission's proposal on trade in products which can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Parliament's position reinforces the prohibition of this type of trade, including with regard to transit and export rules and services associated with this type of trade. That's why I voted for it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe it is important to ensure legislative, judicial and administrative measures to prohibit the production, trade and use of goods that could be used for the death penalty or for other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment for torture purposes. The 'regulation against torture', establishing prohibitions and authorisation requirements for trade in certain items intended for multiple uses, is part of the European policy to eliminate the death penalty and prevent torture throughout the world.
