I believe that this regulation is a good instrument for achieving the most appropriate strategic objective of protecting human rights.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The revision of this Regulation to make the export of goods likely to be used to impose the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment makes a necessary evolution of the existing legislative framework. It seeks, however, to create excessive bureaucratic barriers, which could make it difficult to export goods that can be used for various uses, a balancing solution. It therefore imposes a ban on the end that is given to goods, thereby ensuring a use in conformity with the protection of human rights. It is a path that calls for and involves European companies and their partners across borders for a commitment to the defence of human rights. It entails a fundamental ethical dimension: the responsibility for the transactions of this type of goods is not exhausted at the time of delivery of the goods, accompanies it until use. This Regulation was also a demonstration that the European Union assumes its role as a defender of human rights beyond its borders. It is therefore another step in strengthening the EU's role as the world's leading responsible player in the fight against the death penalty and in the eradication of torture.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. Capital punishment is something free nations can have differing views on. However it is not for the EU to weaponise and politicise its trade policies to try and force countries which disagree with it on the practise to stop capital punishment. We note the way the EU has materially interfered on the side of criminals in capital cases in other countries.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report by the European Parliament, which strengthens the control of exports of goods that can be used to impose the death penalty or inflict torture, because it is important to mobilise trade policy in a decisive battle of the European Union and humanist culture. This proposal for a Regulation deserves the clear political support of the European Parliament, in particular the idea of establishing a General Union Export Authorisation for countries that make firm international commitments and the introduction of an urgent procedure allowing for a rapid updating of the checklists. Parliament's report further improves the system as it increases the number of controlled products by allowing trade in goods, including those not explicitly listed in the Regulation, to be stopped by the customs authorities if there are reasonable grounds to believe that the products will be used to apply the death penalty, inflict torture or other ill-treatment. I have therefore supported this contribution from the European Parliament because it makes EU trade policy more faithful to the European commitment to human rights and ensures that European companies are not complicit in inhumane practices.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the strengthening of this legislation. I have been a long-time opponent to the death penalty and so too in the EU. I voted in favour of this legislation because it will ensure to a greater extent that the EU is not complicit in torture or capital punishment. EU companies must not be able to profit from torture, whether knowingly or unknowingly. The new measures in this legislation will improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ according to an assessment by international civil society organisations, torture and ill-treatment still exist in 131 countries around the world and the death penalty is still practised in 58 countries. I regret that the trade in certain goods that can be used for capital punishment, torture or other treatment or punishment is also substantially signed under this unfavourable situation. I supported the resolution because I believe that the report is the right step and I believe that the right combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures can prevent the trade in goods that can be used for torture or capital punishment. However, I expect that, on the basis of this report, measures will be taken that will not only contribute to the protection of human rights, but will also create sufficient conditions for the effective implementation of controls and the application of sanctions by national authorities. I also believe that, in order to strengthen European values, brokers in the Union will be prohibited from providing brokering services in respect of goods the export and import of which are prohibited.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Torture Prevention Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 is a unique instrument which contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of goods and activities used or potentially misused for the purpose of carrying out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment.  By combining the ban with the list-listed trading permit requirements, the regulation contributes to the EU's longstanding policy of abolishing the death penalty worldwide and preventing torture.  The report draws attention to the need to modernise legislation in this area. In particular, it mentions the updating of checklists, the coherence of EU export controls (including lists for military equipment, dual-use items, firearms and torture equipment without duplying surveillance) and strengthening controls on torture equipment (inserting a specific Annex IIIa, introducing a ban on brokerage services for prohibited goods, extending the prohibition of brokerage services and technical assistance for controlled goods).  I agree with the approach of necessary and proportionate control without unnecessary burdens restricting trade in goods and legitimate end-use on which the modernisation of legislation is based.  As external trade transactions are becoming more complex and effective implementation of controls, checks on penalties, guidance and awareness is urgently needed, I voted in favour of the report by the European Parliament.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I fully support the revision of the regulation that helps eliminate the death penalty in the world through tighter control over trade in certain goods that could be used for practices related to capital punishment or torture. The new regulation introduces controls on export licences for certain medicinal products intended, for example, for lethal injections and other objects regularly used by certain authoritarian regimes for the purpose of torture and degrading treatment of prisoners. Thanks to the large majority that has been formed in Parliament on the Commission's proposal, we have extended the scope of the regulation to include a clause under which the customs authorities will have to seize all goods that give rise to a reasonable reason to believe that they are being used for torture purposes. As previous attempts to introduce such export controls have not been successful, I believe that this is an important measure for the defence of the European Union's values in the world in order to protect human life against the unfortunately still too widespread practice of the death penalty. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The Anti-Torture Regulation regulates the products and goods that may be misused for torture, the execution of the death penalty or other cruel, inhumandegrading degrading treatment or punishment. Annex II regulates the prohibition of trade in "single-use" goods and remains unchanged and Annex III deals with an authorisation system for the export of "multi-purpose" items that could be misused. In order to avoid unnecessary trade burdens that could restrict the trade of products, the European Commission authorises the export of these goods to countries that comply with international agreements and obligations. Countries that still carry out the death penalty and do not comply with these agreements and obligations are not authorised, including Benin, Liberia, Madagascar, Mongolia and Sao Tomé and Principe. A specific list of products and goods provides clarity and facilitates compliance. This proposal was adopted and I voted in favour.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. I welcome the strengthening of this legislation designed to ensure the EU is not complicit in torture, and to fulfil the EU’s commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture throughout the world. In particular, I welcome new measures to improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions. I strongly support the EU ban on trading drugs intended for the death penalty, which Labour MEPs and the European Union stand firmly against.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No. 1236/2005 a ban is imposed on the export of goods which have no practical use other than for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, and export controls of certain goods which may be used for those purposes.  In addition to the current prohibitions on imports and exports of items that could be used for torture or execution of the death penalty (Annex II) and a permit system for objects that could be used for torture (Annex III), the Commission proposes to insert Annex IIIa, to prevent controlled goods from being used to carry out the death penalty by injecting lethal injection, increasing restrictions on mediation and technical assistance, and introducing the possibility of an urgent procedure for amending Annexes I, II and III.  Taking into account the fundamental rights and principles recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular respect and protection of human dignity, the right to life and the prohibition of torture and inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, I voted to postpone the final vote on the proposal and to return the report to the home committee.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on trade in certain goods that could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. I support the ban on the production and use of goods for torture and trade in goods, and we therefore need a recast of EU surveillance of this trade. The EU must be given all instruments for rapid and effective supervision. A unified and group approach is needed.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I am firmly opposed to capital punishment. However, I do not believe that trade policy is the best instrument for expressing this opposition. We must ensure that trade in pharmaceutical products for legitimate and lifesaving purposes is not impeded due to their misuse by some countries for this abhorrent practice.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report as a whole needs amendments. For this reason, at yesterday's meeting it was decided to reintroduce all the proposed amendments to the relevant parliamentary committee for consultation with the Council.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission, with its present legislative proposal, confirmed parliament's previous decision of 17 June 2010 amending the Anti Torture good regulation EC/1236/2005. The European People's Party welcomes the amendment, as it is important to regulate and make conditions for trade in goods that can be used for torture and the execution of the death penalty. Customs authorities should be able to take effective action against operators who break regulations. At the same time, we must also take into account that these restrictions do not hinder legal trade in such 'dual-use' goods. It is very important to strike a balance between the legitimate interests of the operators concerned and the restrictions contained in the proposal.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which, following years of preparation, will allow the modernisation of the nearly 10-year-old regulation, in line with the European Parliament's previously stated intention. In addition to the annex containing prohibited articles for exclusive purposes (which can only be used for torture or execution), I consider it an important specific feature of the Commission's proposal to update the Annex listing and authorising the marketing of dual-purpose articles, taking into account new pharmaceutical instruments and substances. Similarly, a targeted end-user clause is an important control tool.  In general, I find it reassuring that legislative modernisation places due weight on the aspects of effective control, regular review of sales and procedures and a more efficient exchange of information, all without unnecessary disruption or obstruction of the normal flow of goods. Overall, I believe that, with my vote and this decision of the European Parliament, we have also contributed to the European Union retaining its international guiding role in global efforts to reduce the death penalty and eradicate the practice of torture.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Union is a leading and responsible global body for combating the death penalty and eliminating torture. The European Parliament's report seeks to strengthen the current rules on so-called anading services related to the transfer of goods, as well as transit, technical support and commercial introduction of goods that could be used for capital punishment. The amendments made in the report, which provide for the creation of a mechanism for periodic review and a more systematic exchange of information and reporting in order to strengthen the supervision and effective implementation of the Regulation, seem to be clearly correct amendments to the Commission's proposals.  In my opinion, all efforts to eliminate the death penalty and prevent torture should be introduced and promoted in all AREAS of EU policy , particularly in trade policy, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of Parliament's report.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is asking to revise the current regulation, aiming to contribute to the efforts to eliminate death penalty worldwide and prevent torture through EU-wide controls on exports of torture goods and drugs, which are used for lethal injection. This revision includes adding export licencing controls for lethal drugs and prohibiting trade in new items which have become regularly used for torture by certain regimes, such as: spiked batons, electric shock sleeves and cuffs, to name few examples. I welcome the enlarged scope of the report that expends the list of medical products from being used for capital punishment by lethal injection.  I also welcome the establishment of a Union General Export Authorisation for countries that have undertaken an urgency procedure to amend the lists of banned, or controlled items, which will allow the EU to react more quickly to emerging trends and human rights crackdowns in the future. The EU has been advocating the elimination of the death penalty around the world for many years. This report, which I voted in favour of, represents a very positive step in our efforts to achieve this goal.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. Export controls, which apply throughout the UNION, are instruments of foreign trade policy that contribute to the achievement of a wider range of strategic objectives. Regulation (EC) 1236/2005 "against torture" is a privileged means of strengthening the protection of human rights by subjecting to controls the goods and activities used, or likely to be diverted, to inflict the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It thus contributes to the European Union's long-standing policy of abolishing the death penalty worldwide and combating torture. Combining prohibitions and authorisation obligations for the trade in goods listed in its annexes, it contributes to the achievement of these objectives. It establishes a regime prohibiting the exchange of goods specifically for torture and executions and related technical assistance (Annex II) and an authorisation regime for "multi-use" goods that may be diverted for use in torture and executions by injections of lethal chemical agents.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims at strengthening the controls of torture tools. The report seeks to amend Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 concerning trade in certain goods which could be used for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, known as the ‘Anti-torture Regulation’. The ‘Anti-torture Regulation’ contributes to the EU policy of eliminating death penalty worldwide, and of preventing torture. It helps achieve these goals by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for trade in listed goods. It governs a ban of trade in ‘single-use’ torture and execution items and related technical assistance and an authorisation system for ‘multi-purpose’ items that could be misused for torture and executions by lethal injections.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to eliminate the death penalty worldwide and prevent torture, while respecting human rights, the European Union must ensure the right combination of legislative, administrative and judicial measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of goods for torture purposes and to effectively control articles with potential lethal and inhuman uses. That is why I voted in favour of Mrs Schaake's report: I believe it is essential to promote an EU-wide approach that guarantees uniformity in export controls; these schemes must be valid in the long term and be flexible in order to be able to adapt rapidly to technological developments and technological developments in the world. In order to facilitate these controls, lists of specific items need to be created at EU level in order to provide greater clarity to exporters and importers and to limit the danger of the sale of certain items.  In addition, the implementation by local authorities of controls, audits, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions is of paramount importance.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 on trade in certain goods which could be used to carry out the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment, I supported it because it is necessary to ensure control over such goods, in order to try to prevent their use and thus contribute to the protection of EU citizens and human rights.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because we consider it common sense that we do not allow our companies to trade in third countries with materials that we have banned in Europe because they are related to inhuman or torture practices. In this report, the European Parliament calls for a ban on the sale, marketing and advertising (included in its online variants) of those goods, as well as the prohibition on the transit of those goods through the territory of the Union.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 EU-wide export controls are a foreign trade policy instrument for broader policy purposes. Regulation (EC) No 1236/2005 against torture is a unique instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that can be used in the course of the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. The Regulation against Torture contributes to the global eradication of the death penalty and torture, which is a long-aspirations of the EU. It helps to achieve these objectives by combining prohibitions with the licensing requirements for trade in listed products. It introduces a ban on devices and technical assistance for torture and the execution of the death penalty only, and establishes a licensing system for products suitable for torture and lethal injection executions in the event of misuse. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The abolition of the death penalty and inhuman and degrading treatment is among the priorities of EU human rights policy.  Commission Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999(3), as last 1236/2005 lays down Community rules governing trade with third countries in goods which may be used to impose capital punishment, torture and other inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment and technical assistance for the use of such goods. The revision of EU controls on trade in torture instruments had long been necessary, with checklist updates being steps in the right direction.  The European Parliament's report supports the revision of Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999. 1236/2005, stressing the importance of strict controls on those goods and products that could be used for torture or capital punishment. This review will allow us to ensure that there is protection of the right to life and a prevention of torture. At the same time, we will be able to know whether the products are used for legitimate or other purposes, such as medical ones.  I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report because we consider it common sense that we do not allow our companies to trade in third countries with materials that we have banned in Europe because they are related to inhuman or torture practices. In this report, the European Parliament calls for a ban on the sale, marketing and advertising (included in its online variants) of those goods, as well as the prohibition on the transit of those goods through the territory of the Union.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it contributes to the protection of human rights through the control of items and activities that are used for or could be misused for capital punishment, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. As the protection of human rights is one of the core values of the EU, it is important to ensure a right combination of EU legislative, administrative, judicial and external measures to prevent and prohibit the production, trade and use of torture goods and effectively control items with potential lethal and inhumane uses.  These trade instruments are elements of a comprehensive approach which uses all of the EU’s instruments for external action, but it is essential at the same time to ensure the coherence of the EU’s export controls to overcome the absence of multilateral export control regimes in the field of torture goods. I believe these measure contribute to the long-standing EU policy of preventing torture and abolishing the death penalty worldwide.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Union, through this Regulation, reaffirms its policy of eliminating the death penalty in the world. We are talking about one of the EU's priorities in human rights policy. Both my person and the European People's Party have repeatedly expressed a position contrary to the death penalty and any kind of torture, also being in favour of defending the importance of controlling exports of products that may serve these purposes. I therefore consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The objective of this report is to incorporate Parliament's position into the Commission's proposal on trade in products which can be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. Parliament's position reinforces the prohibition of this type of trade, including with regard to transit and export rules and services associated with this type of trade. That's why I voted for it.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am happy to vote in favour of this report. It is important that we make sure that we strengthen EU protections against the trade in certain goods that can be used in torture and capital punishment. These activities go against the ideals of the European Union and while we cannot force non-member states to reject them, we can do all we can to ensure that Europe is not aiding and abetting states that which to carry out these acts. Furthermore, European companies must be prevented from profiteering on the back of the policies of these states and in particular I welcome the new measures that will improve the speed and efficiency of our reactions to any such transactions. I stand by my belief that the death penalty is wrong and this is a step towards ensuring that this practice is phased out globally.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. I strongly oppose and condemn any use of torture, torture, and the goods used for this purpose. Nevertheless, the report goes far too far, as it gives the Commission further powers and places an additional burden on exporters and customs authorities.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the regulation on trade in certain goods that could be used for the death penalty, torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.  With the revision of the regulation, the European Union is strengthening export controls, in particular those of medicines that can be used for lethal injections, banning brokerage services for prohibited goods and facilitating exports to countries that have made and implementing strict international commitments. I am convinced that the European Union must play a leading and world-leading role in the fight against the death penalty and torture, and the revision of this regulation is another important step forward, as well as a clear signal to all our international partners.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Together with my group, I voted in favour of the report on 'trade in certain goods that could be used for the execution of the death penalty, torture or other treatment or punishment'. The Anti-Torture Regulation contributes to the protection of human rights. By monitoring instruments and measures that could be used for torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment, the regulation is a clear advocate for the protection of human rights. Reference is made to the particular importance of legal access to medicines and medicines. A system of regular reporting and verification will be set up to adequately monitor the implementation of Member States' obligations. The prerogative of this regulation is the protection of human rights – and I clearly agree with that.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a human rights campaigner, I welcome the strengthening of this legislation designed to ensure the EU is not complicit in torture, and to fulfil the EU’s commitment to standing against the death penalty and torture throughout the world.  Updates to this legislation will ensure EU companies do not profit from torture in oppressive regimes, and send a strong signal that those who trade in execution and torture goods, including technical assistance and supplier services, that they cannot access the EU market. In particular we welcome new measures to improve the speed and efficiency of reacting to suspected transactions. I also strongly stand behind the EU ban on trading drugs intended for the death penalty, which Labour MEPs and the European Union stand firmly against.  This legislation is a key example of the EU using its trading power for humanity.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. The European Union has long been committed to the universal abolition of the death penalty. In order to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to prevent any support measures that mean the continuation of the death penalty. As a defender of human rights, I wholeheartedly support this proposal. There is a need for stronger controls on the export of goods that could possibly be used as torture or killing scares in the event of death sentences. No Member State may export medicines that can be used in third countries to carry out the death penalty. Nor must a Member State take part in the provision of technical aids for torture or killing. It is essential to draw up an action plan to respond as quickly as possible to current developments in the area of the funds used.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank Mrs Schaake and all the rapporteurs of this report. The Commission's proposal is entirely relevant, we cannot allow European companies to export goods that can be used to apply capital punishment or torture, but they cannot pay fair for sinners; that is why I believe that the overall authorisation system will ensure that this does not happen. Giving European companies an annual seal of quality will speed up the administrative procedures to which they are subjected, while controlling the export of goods likely to be used to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or inhumane treatment. It is very important to control exports of goods that may be used for these purposes; but it is also not to put obstacles and obstacles on European exporting companies, we must seek a fair balance. That is why I support this proposal.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the vote on the legislative resolution has been postponed, I supported both the Commission's proposal and the amendments by the Committee on International Trade. I think that this proposal confirmed the European Union's clear condemnation of the death penalty, cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. In addition to the ban on trade in goods as defined in the proposal itself, I also supported a ban on transit, the provision of technical assistance and support, as well as marketing services, and, last but not least, I also voted in favour of a provision giving Member States the possibility of prohibiting the trade and transit of goods which, although not expressly mentioned in the proposal, can ultimately serve such purposes.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1236/2005, which aims to combat torture, is an instrument that contributes to the protection of human rights by controlling products and activities that are used, or may be used, abusively to apply the death penalty or inflict torture or other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. It aims to contribute to achieving the goal of eliminating the death penalty and preventing torture by combining prohibitions with licensing requirements for the trade in the listed products. The Regulation lays down a ban on trade in 'single-use' products intended for torture and executions and their technical assistance and a system for authorising products that can be misused to inflict torture and carry out executions by lethal injection.  In a context where external trade operations are increasingly complex, the effective implementation of national authorities' controls, checks, sanctions, guidelines and awareness-raising actions is essential. The rapporteur recalls the need to adequately monitor the implementation of Member States' commitments, including their obligation to present and exchange information through a secure and encrypted system on refused authorisations and notifications. We voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an objective improvement in the obligations for the exchange of information in the tax field. Although this report continues to allow european evasors to use tax havens, it is an undeniable improvement. The report acknowledges the damage caused to SMEs by large companies that locate their profits in this type of paradise. From our point of view, the exchange of information is a necessary but not sufficient condition in correcting the tax abuses that occur in Europe. However, we recognise the value of this small step forward and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which contained a number of important, progressive provisions. This report emerged from the Luxleaks scandal. The aim is to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information between tax administrations regarding advance cross-border rulings and advance pricing arrangements and to strengthen existing EU legislation. Furthermore, the GUE/NGL rapporteur managed to further strengthen the Commission proposal in a number of key areas including strengthening reporting requirements – i.e. immediate exchange of information.  My Group tabled an alternative compromise stating that all rulings should be publicly available and not only stored somewhere in a central Commission database in an aggregated form. The Greens and EFDD supported GUE/NGL on this issue, but unfortunately it was rejected in committee.  Nevertheless, given that the report was still an improvement compared to the Commission proposal and especially compared to the Council position which was adopted even before the ECON vote took place, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as I believe that the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation will significantly help to enhance the transparency of financial transactions and prevent the existence of tax havens created by companies lacking transparency and knowledge of tax regulations in force in each Member State.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The idea of this report is to obtain transparency on practices that have led to scandals such as the Luxleaks. This means introducing automatic exchange between Member State administrations, so that large companies are discouraged from resorting to often legal but unethical practices ("tax dumping").  The Ferber report reinforces some elements of the Commission's text. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to combat tax evasion.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims˗ an automatic exchange of information on tax rulings in EU countries. Under the new rules, EU countries will be required to exchange information on tax decisions and benefits granted to multinationals. This proposal was made in response to the Luxleaks scandal of 2014, when the practice of granting Luxembourg tax credits to multinational corporations was revealed through investigative journalism. I believe that the new rules should not only apply to cross-border solutions, as national tax decisions can also affect other EU countries.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which, for the most part, calls on Member States to communicate to their European partners the changes in their tax regulations. This exchange of information is part of the logical collaboration between neighbouring countries and allies.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. For the Socialist Group, I was responsible for this issue, which will organise the automatic exchange of tax information. The aim is to ensure an automatic exchange of information on advance tax rulings made with regard to tax arrangements. The report calls for a broadening of the scope and conditions for the automatic and compulsory exchange of information, but it also stipulates that all advance tax rulings, even before this directive comes into force, must be disclosed, and also that in the event of omission and refusal to exchange information, sanctions are put in place.  I also called for a harmonised tax identification at European level, that is, to ensure that every company has a European tax number so that it can be found more easily.  I hope that we will be able to convince the states of the importance of tackling multinational tax evasion. Indeed, in this system, apart from a few countries and the multinationals themselves, no one wins and the Member States lose considerable public resources, and the redistribution of wealth cannot therefore take place.  I fervently hope that the Commission, which investigates multinationals, can continue to investigate practices that must no longer exist.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have positioned myself in favour of this text, which aims to strengthen the proposal for a directive on the automatic exchange between administrations of the Member States' tax or related measures. After the LuxLeaks scandal, the European Parliament's ECON committee wanted to go further in transparency to combat tax dumping. In particular, the Ferber report proposes that the exchange be done retroactively, up to ten years back for the rescripts. Unfortunately, Parliament's opinion here has little weight in the face of the Ecofin Council, which met on 6 October, has taken a much lighter stance in terms of constraints on this subject. The Ministers of Economy and Finance of the Member States have thus buried this principle of retroactivity, leaving the possibility for States with the most opaque practices in this area, such as Luxembourg, to clean up. In any event, this report has the merit of seeking to clean up tax competition within the Union and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although this directive does not put an end to the problem of tax evasion within the European Union, I see it as a positive contribution in the direction of a more fruitful exchange of information between Member States. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. I have voted in favour of the report. In an earlier calculation commissioned by the Commission, the annual losses in tax evasion in EU Member States were estimated at SEK 9 000 billion. In particular, large companies account for the majority of tax evasion. 9 000 billion is compared with the eu countries' total budget deficit in 2012 of around SEK 4 600 billion, i.e. only half of what tax waste costs. It is therefore good that the Commission intends to tighten up legislation and the mandatory automatic exchange of information on taxation matters. For several years, the EU country of Luxembourg has distinguished itself in particular in organising its tax legislation to help big business evade tax in other EU countries. I note that the Luxembourg Prime Minister, while the country was tailoring tax avoidance laws to big business, was called Jean-Claude Juncker. Today he is the President of the European Commission and must therefore act against precisely the conduct that he himself engaged in a few years ago. It will therefore be important to keep a close eye on the Commission. In the vote on the report, I voted in favour of proposals requiring Member States to send information to the Commission and other Member States on new draft legislation on taxation. The purpose of this exchange of information shall be a single one; to make it more difficult, and preferably impossible, to prevent tax avoidance by big business.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has presented Parliament's position amending the Council Directive on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The problem posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased significantly and is of great concern at Union and global level. Under the current rules of law , Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, Member States share very little information between themselves on their tax rulings. The lack of transparency in tax rulings is used by certain companies to artificially reduce their tax contributions.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on the mandatory exchange of information in the field of taxation, as I believe that action in this area is welcome and necessary.  Automatic exchange of information between Member States must become mandatory, as aggressive tax optimisations, mainly used by the largest multinationals, are increasing.  The Lux-leaks affair has revealed a number of anomalies in member states' control mechanisms in the area of taxation and the brutal practices used by multinationals to avoid tax. Measures are therefore needed to improve the mutual exchange of information to help reduce tax evasion and make transactions that arise from the business of companies more transparent. Tax avoidance causes wider social damage and has a negative impact on people's well-being, since many countries are unable to provide public services to the extent they could due to the loss of income from tax evasion. And, on the other hand, large companies are also increasing profits and rewarding owners at the expense of such neced practices. There is, of course, nothing wrong with this, if this is achieved in a fair and just manner.  Of course, by adopting this report, we will not miraculously solve all the problems in the area of tax avoidance. However, this report is a good way forward for further work, which must aim at the complete elimination of tax evasion.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Clarity and transparency are two important principles that must guide fiscal discipline at European level. A year after the Luxleaks scandal, it is a positive sign that we are voting on a concrete piece of legislation to address this issue. The report, which I support, provides for the extension of these principles through an extension of the exchange of information. All valid tax rulings are taken into account, the exchange of information is required immediately and not on a quarterly basis and, lastly, additional information may be requested from the States. These provisions are an indication of a real commitment and in the right direction to ensure greater clarity, which benefits the Member States as well as european citizens.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which contained a number of important, progressive provisions. This report emerged from the Luxleaks scandal. The aim is to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information between tax administrations regarding advance cross-border rulings and advance pricing arrangements and to strengthen existing EU legislation. Furthermore, the GUE/NGL rapporteur managed to further strengthen the Commission proposal in a number of key areas including strengthening reporting requirements – i.e. immediate exchange of information.  My Group tabled an alternative compromise stating that all rulings should be publicly available and not only stored somewhere in a central Commission database in an aggregated form. The Greens and EFDD supported GUE/NGL on this issue, but unfortunately it was rejected in committee.  Nevertheless, given that the report was still an improvement compared to the Commission proposal and especially compared to the Council position which was adopted even before the ECON vote took place, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I firmly believe that the introduction of the obligation to automatically exchange information in the tax field is an important step in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance by increasing coordination between the administrations of the various Member States.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The LuxLeaks scandal has revealed that many multinationals have benefited from ultra-beneficial tax arrangements in Luxembourg through highly paid audit firms. Tax dumping, particularly in Luxembourg, Switzerland and Ireland, has deprived many Member States of significant tax revenues. That is why the Commission has introduced a proposal for a directive to introduce the automatic exchange of information between national tax administrations. The purpose of this proposal is to discourage large groups from using these processes. This text is once again going in the right direction. Nevertheless, we regret that the Ecofin Council has abandoned the idea of retroactivity in data exchanges. Moreover, the entry into force of this text has been postponed, thus giving the legal services of multinational firms the opportunity to adapt their tax optimization methods to the new European legislation. Finally, although it helps to intensify the exchange of information between Member States, this directive does not better regulate the tax practices of these unscrupulous companies.  I voted in favour of this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax field envisages establishing the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of information on cross-border tax rulings. The issue of tax fraud and evasion has always been a challenge for the European Union, and joint action aimed at effective communication by Member States about their tax rulings is needed. Currently, administrative cooperation in the field of taxation is a poor one, with Member States neglecting responsibility for the transmission of tax decisions, which has a negative impact on the Union's fight against tax fraud. I believe that transparency in the tax rulings taken by the Member States should guide the fight against tax evasion, and that a permanent, prompt and transparent exchange of information between Member States is needed, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of the draft legislative resolution on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax field, considering it an appropriate one in view of the current challenges.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The measure stems from the so-called Luxleaks scandal and one of its aims is to combat the effects of fraud and evasion, as well as the proliferation of tax havens within the EU as well. I have chosen to promote the exchange of information between Member States.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The recent tax scandals in Europe have exposed many loopholes in European taxation. The lack of transparency in this area has led to unfair competition and is a hindrance to the completion of an effective single market. The first victims are European citizens and SMEs.  It was time to work towards greater cooperation and transparency in tax matters. The mandatory and automatic exchange of information on cross-border tax rulings is a first step in this regard. As a result of this agreement, Member States will be less inclined to engage in unfair competition in the tax field.  Of course, it will be necessary to be particularly vigilant about the compliance of this legislation by the Member States. I voted in favour of this text.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field.  Globalisation and the increasing mobility of taxpayers can make it difficult for Member States to properly establish the tax base for individuals and businesses, favouring tax avoidance and evasion and thereby undermining the functioning of the internal market.  This problem can only be tackled effectively if the Member States decide to act together, providing for an effective system of cooperation between national tax administrations. Council Directive 2011/16/EU was adopted to respond to the need for Member States to strengthen administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. The proposed amendment aims to make this dialogue between tax agencies even more effective and comprehensive, by establishing a mandatory automatic exchange of information on cross-border preventive rulings and prior agreements on transfer prices.  To date, this exchange of information is still very limited and therefore, also in order to strengthen it, I have decided to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which contained a number of important, progressive provisions. This report emerged from the Luxleaks scandal. The aim is to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information between tax administrations regarding advance cross-border rulings and advance pricing arrangements and to strengthen existing EU legislation. Furthermore, the GUE/NGL rapporteur managed to further strengthen the Commission proposal in a number of key areas including strengthening reporting requirements – i.e. immediate exchange of information.  My Group tabled an alternative compromise stating that all rulings should be publicly available and not only stored somewhere in a central Commission database in an aggregated form. The Greens and EFDD supported GUE/NGL on this issue, but unfortunately it was rejected in committee.  Nevertheless, given that the report was still an improvement compared to the Commission proposal and especially compared to the Council position which was adopted even before the ECON vote took place, I voted in favour of this report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because I support the exchange of information between different tax administrations in order to ensure transparency and eliminate tax avoidance. Greater cross-border cooperation will help us tackle such problems more efficiently and with better results.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the ECON Committee we supported a number of compromises which went in the direction of improving the automatic, rapid and effective exchange of information in this area. Unfortunately, we would have liked to see greater transparency, guaranteed by the fact that we have a public register accessible to all, in which data relating to the tax agreements signed were compulsorily entered. We therefore proposed an alternative compromise, but it was rejected. The vote of the M5S delegation today is therefore negative, although we accept some improvements made in relation to the current situation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, the European Parliament, having regard to the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs, approves the Commission's proposal as amended.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I decided to vote in favour of amending Directive 2011/16/EU, implemented by Directive 2014/107/EU. The previous framework, which defined the legal framework for administrative cooperation on the exchange of information, required the exchange of a very small amount of information on tax rulings.  Directive 2014/107/EU is based on the principles of the resolution of 21 May 2013, in which Parliament underlined the leading role that the EU should play in the fight against unfair tax practices. It introduces a new article, defining the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of information on types of cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements. This obligation is extended to rulings issued in the ten years preceding the date on which the proposed directive takes effect and which are still valid on the date of entry into force of the Directive. The proposed directive also provides for the possibility for the Commission to establish a secure central register in which the information communicated under the directive can be recorded.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In countries like Italy, the tax burden has reached unbearable levels. It is not so much a question of how much you pay in relation to income, but of what you receive in return: services that are often of poor quality, a generally inefficient public administration, a ballast for businesses rather than support. However, evasion and avoidance are not a solution: in order to make what is there work better, investments must be made, and that is why we need resources. I voted in favour of this directive because I believe that everyone must participate, within reasonable limits, in cleaning up their country's finances and that attempts to curb so-called 'fiscal optimisation' are legitimate.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition are a serious European and global problem. The report proposes an amendment to Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax field in order to promote the sharing of relevant data through administrative cooperation between Member States.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is necessary to strengthen the instruments and mechanisms established by the directive, defining the conditions and scope for the compulsory automatic exchange of information on certain types of cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements.  The aim of amending the directive is to ensure greater transparency in tax matters and to give greater clarity and effectiveness to tax transfer procedures.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Council Directive 2011/16/EU, adopted in place of an earlier Directive (77/779/EEC), aimed to respond to the need for Member States to strengthen administrative cooperation in the field of taxation through a mandatory automatic exchange of information on preventive (cross-border) rulings and prior agreements on reference prices.  The European Parliament's objective was to remove any reference in the directive to the cross-border dimension of rulings in order to reduce reporting times. The directive did not include the adoption of a public register accessible to all in which all data relating to the agreements signed were entered, which would have ensured greater transparency.  For these reasons, I am voting against the line that has prevailed so far, and I believe that if transparent measures were taken and properly applied, the problem of tax avoidance and evasion could indeed be resolved.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an objective improvement in the obligations for the exchange of information in the tax field. Although this report continues to allow european evasors to use tax havens, it is an undeniable improvement. The report acknowledges the damage caused to SMEs by large companies that locate their profits in this type of paradise. From our point of view, the exchange of information is a necessary but not sufficient condition in correcting the tax abuses that occur in Europe. However, we recognise the value of this small step forward and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The mandatory automatic exchange of tax information between national tax authorities improves administrative transparency, reduces practices harmful to competition and provides legal certainty for both taxpayers and economic actors. I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution, which welcomes the Commission's proposal and increases its ambition by extending its scope to national tax decisions as well.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution to have automatic exchange of information. Transparency on taxation matters is important. I voted against two amendments which call for public disclosure of advance rulings and advance pricing arrangements in an online public central directory.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's proposal for an efficient exchange of information and the efficient processing of tax information between Member States, but there are still a number of important practical difficulties, such as the discretion available to the issuing Member State to decide which other Member States should be informed.  Furthermore, the monitoring system is not sufficiently effective, which is why it makes it difficult for the Commission to identify any infringement of the requirement for the exchange of information on advance cross-border decisions and advance pricing agreements.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the European Parliament's unfavourable opinion on the Council of Ministers' decision to maintain a low level of tax transparency. This decision applies in particular to the tax rescript, which is a procedure allowing citizens and businesses to obtain their situation under tax law from the administration.  The Council of Ministers restricts the scope of the text to cross-border rescripts and limits the European Commission's supervisory power. On the contrary, Parliament wants to make it automatic and compulsory to exchange information on the "cross-border tax rulings" they issue to multinational companies.  Considering that this decision is a missed opportunity to strengthen the fight against tax evasion between the Member States, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to ensure an automatic exchange of information on advance tax decisions taken with regard to tax arrangements. It is important that the European Union takes strong measures to strengthen its fight against fraud and tax evasion. In particular, I am in favour of the European Commission being able to put in place sanctions for non-compliance with this legislation.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as part of the response to the Luxleaks schandal and my determination not to tolerate tax fraud and illegal tax avoidance. I am an advocate for a fair distribution of the tax burden between citizens and companies.  I am happy to see a swift implementation of the information exchange. Another important point is that the Commission will develop a secure central directory so that sensitive data can be protected. The Commission should publish to the public a summary of the main tax rulings agreed in the previous year, based on information contained in the secure central directory but in compliance with the confidentiality provisions.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report sought to enable the introduction of an automatic exchange of tax data between Member State administrations. By encouraging, through this transparency, states not to misuse procedures that create a tax competitiveness gap, this report is moving in the right direction. While a more watered-down version will surely prevail (this Parliament report is only for advice), it is important to combat all forms of tax or para-legal fraud, and this report is a good example. Attached to the greater honesty of taxpayers and businesses, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as although I am in favour of aiding tax authorities in quickly identifying tax illegalities, I cannot support the extension of the scope of the EP to all rulings that does not take into account the rules governing data protection and commercially—sensitive information.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs on this dossier, my colleagues and I have made efforts to limit the scope of the Directive so as not to create a system for the exchange of information which, instead of facilitating public administrations, overwhelms them with documentation for processing.  Unfortunately, the amendments we adopted did not find their impact in the adopted report of our colleagues in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. For this reason, and because I do not believe that the final compromise option will achieve the objectives set, I voted against the report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This project will cost European taxpayers EUR 2.1 billion within four years. But the results are not guaranteed.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal, which requires Member States to automatically exchange information on advance cross-border tax rulings, is part of a series of initiatives to prevent tax avoidance by businesses. The new rules should apply from 1 January 2017. The truth is that Member States share very little information with each other about their tax agreements, and it is up to them to decide whether a tax agreement can be relevant to another EU country. The lack of transparency about tax agreements is exploited by certain companies to artificially reduce their tax contribution. However, it could have gone further, notably in increasing transparency. The Directive requires Member States to automatically exchange information on "cross-border" advance tax rulings, leaving out purely national tax rulings.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend the 2011 Directive on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity for opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to review those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called tax rulings that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions for not giving the information, as 'official secrecy' for which it should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.).

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of amending Directive 2011/16/EU is to include the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. To this end, it is intended to be established an administrative cooperation between the tax authorities (TA) of the Member States, with regard to the mandatory automatic exchange of information on prior cross-border tax agreements and prior transfer pricing agreements. The proposal also provides that Member States receiving information may request more detailed information. It should be noted that previous agreements between TAs and companies – such as those at the basis of the scandal known in Luxembourg ("Luxleaks"), in which the current President of the European Commission was directly involved - are a widespread practice, alongside phenomena of erosion of the tax base and the transfer of profits. This proposal could put some grains in a gear that deprives sovereign states and their peoples of large millions of euros of resources owed to them by multinationals when paying taxes on profits. Resources that are supinged to workers and their families through an unbearable tax burden. There are still to be addressed issues such as tax havens, these authentic disappeared public resources, authentic havens of crime and money laundering.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ As usual when it comes to anything to do with finance, this doesn’t go as far as I’d like to see it go. I would have preferred more transparency, that all rulings should be available to the public, not buried somewhere in a central Commission database in an aggregated form. Nevertheless, it is a major improvement on the existing situation, making mandatory and automatic what had been optional, the exchange of information on tax matters, notably with regard to advance tax rulings for companies. Doors that previously had been wide open aren’t being slammed shut, as they should be, but at least they are gradually being closed. I voted in favour for what is now a much improved situation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ the European Union should play a leading role in global negotiations on combating tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax havens, in particular with regard to promoting the exchange of information. Member States do not sufficiently exchange their tax positions and are often unaware of cross-border tax rulings issued in another European Union country that could affect their own tax bases. The lack of transparency in tax matters is consequently used by some companies in order to artificially reduce their tax contributions. The European Commission therefore wants to introduce a new article into the existing directive defining the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of information on cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements. This obligation extends to opinions issued during the 10 years prior to the date of entry into force of the proposed Directive, which are still in force on the date of entry into force of the Directive.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report. Ecofin's text is a decent starting point, although as a critical note I must point out the mammoth delay.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this plan, because within four years it will cost European taxpayers EUR 2.1 billion and the results are not guaranteed.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Mandatory automatic exchange of information on cross-border tax rulings as this strays too far into Member States’ competency in tax matters. Whilst it is right to take action against tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning it is the remit of the Member States to legislate. Once more, the Commission and Parliament call for more Europe when it is not necessary.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The challenges posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition should be indeed one of the EUs concerns. Therefore, I strongly support the call to increase transparency and to fight against all the earlier mentioned challenges by extending the scope of the Directive to all tax rulings and not just to the cross border ones. In order to increase effectiveness, the Commission shall develop a secure central directory where information to be communicated in the framework of this Directive must be recorded in order to satisfy the automatic and mandatory exchange of information. In case of Member States non-compliance, I welcome the proposal to introduce sanctions and establish penalties for refusal or omission of information exchange. Also, in order to increase the Directive’s efficiency, I believe that the publication of a summary containing the main tax rulings exchanged is necessary.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report setting out the Position of the European Parliament on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending the current directive on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, because I fully agree with the signal of clarity and transparency that the EP has sent to the Council in the field of tax competition. I also think it is important that this resolution should be adopted at the same time as another important signal from the TAXE Special Parliamentary Committee on Tax Rulings. The review is important because, among other things, it requires Member States to cooperate, requiring the immediate communication of all tax agreements between Member States and multinationals. Nevertheless, the Commission should have been given the management of a platform designed for the centralised collection of information. I also hope that we will go beyond cross-border rulings, that tax evasion and avoidance will become a real fight within the Member States and that distorting tax competition between EU Member States will be put an end to.  At a time when European citizens have been asked to make great sacrifices, it is a question of social justice for multinationals to pay taxes where profits are made and not in countries that practise tax dumping.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Commitment to the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation', because it is in the interests of our families, citizens, taxpayers and small and medium-sized enterprises that we put an end to the multi-billion dollar tax tricks of multinational scoundans in Europe. This can only be done if the data is exchanged appropriately. Keep it that way!

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Every year, the EU loses a significant share of taxes due to opaque corporate structures covering several countries. It is therefore important to step up cross-border cooperation.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Here we go again: more assaults on the Member States, and making us all act as a United States of Europe. In this case, making Member States pass taxation code changes past the Commission in advance. It is a strange sovereign nation that must ask permission first.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of automatic exchange of information on tax rulings because transparency is key when it comes to cracking down on aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion.  For far too long, governments have been able to make secret agreements with companies about how much tax they’ll pay, with no scrutiny from other Member States or the public as a whole.
