That needs to change, and while the Commission’s proposals are welcome, we in the Parliament believe they can and should go further.  Now the onus is on the Council – and the UK government – to show that they are serious when they say they want to stamp out these practices once and for all.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. The fight against tax evasion and evasion is one of C's priorities in Europe, as undeclared and unrecumbered incomes result in a significant reduction in national tax revenues and are a sign of insolidarity and irresponsibility. That is why I support a resolution which calls for greater transparency and exchange of information in the field of taxation, in accordance with OECD rules, and in which the European Parliament expresses its firm determination not to tolerate tax evasion and tax evasion and to advocate an equitable distribution of the contributory burden among citizens and businesses.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field. The European Parliament has long played a leading role in the debate on combating tax fraud and avoidance. We are calling for greater transparency in the area of tax rulings, but beware of the scope. Tax rulings and price-setting agreements can have a cross-border dimension, even if they relate to purely national transactions.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report and the legislative resolution in question, which is one of the results of the Luxleaks (leaks that exposed the agreements between the State of Luxembourg and multinationals facilitating tax avoidance). It provides for the obligation for States to transmit their agreements with multinationals on taxes to the Commission. We would have wanted the agreements to be made public and not just transmitted to the Commission, but this was rejected by the majority groups.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with other MEPs in the S&D group, I voted in favour of automatic exchange of information on tax rulings because transparency is absolutely vital when it comes to cracking down on tax avoidance and tax evasion. For far too long governments have been able to make secret agreements with companies about how much tax they will pay with no scrutiny from other Member States or the public as a whole. This needs to change. While the Commission's proposals are welcome, as Labour MEPs in the Parliament, we believe they can and should go further. It is over to David Cameron and the rest of the Council now to show that they are serious when they say they want to stamp out these practices once and for all.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation because  that would help to fight the cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition. Tax base erosion is considerably reducing national tax revenues, which hinders Member States in applying growth-friendly tax policies, causes distortions of competition to the detriment of undertakings – particularly SMEs – which pay the correct amounts of tax and shifts taxation towards less mobile factors such as labour and consumption.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report setting out the Position of the European Parliament on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the thrust of this report and believe we need to ensure mandatory automatic exchange of information regarding cross border rulings and advance pricing arrangements, right now Member States can exchange information on tax rulings in a spontaneous way and therefore the majority of Member States do not exchange any information. This proposal will ensure quicker exchange of information and there will be a secure central directory containing this information – all steps in the right direction because citizens and SMEs need to see real action on behalf of the EU when it comes to multinationals paying their fair share of taxes.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report as it a positive step towards increased transparency within the EU. The report is a step in the right direction in order to tackle the challenge posed by cross—border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report deals with the exchange of intergovernmental tax rulings between the administrations of the Member States. This information will be exchanged automatically, more comprehensively and more quickly in the future. ALFA is in favour of transparent and therefore honest competition, both between companies and between states. The measures proposed in the report are likely to increase transparency in European tax competition and to reduce distortions in the taxation of different categories of companies. The disclosure of information to the Commission is necessary in order to fulfil its role as guardian of intergovernmental competition. I strongly support these concerns and have therefore voted in favour of the report. Incidentally , and this is my ceterum censeo – I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, as I believe that this area requires greater transparency, clarity and efficiency.  Therefore, cross-border exchange of information on taxation is necessary, i.e. administrative cooperation between Member States in order to ensure an efficient internal tax system, but also one at Union level. I believe that the European Union needs to take a global leadership role when it comes to combating tax evasion, tax avoidance and tax havens, and I therefore support this report.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this as UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report in the interests of transparency and efficiency. Indeed, this text will allow for the automatic exchange of information between states concerning advance tax rulings towards tax arrangements that allow, in particular, to be low taxed.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There has been a request by the social democrats for many years to have automatic exchange of information mainly in the field of issues related to tax rulings and state aid. There is still a long way to go before the Council shows the same sensitivity to the issue and moves in the direction proposed by the EP. However, the EP's decision is in the right direction as the issue of fiscal transparency is a crucial part of any attempt at fiscal consolidation and normalisation of internal competition disharmony.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. An agreement on the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings represents a major step forward in avoiding aggressive tax planning and unfair tax competition. This leads to greater transparency, with the result that profits are ultimately taxed where they are generated. This approach is a step in the right direction and I therefore agree with it.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Taxation in the European Union has been a very topical issue in recent years and will continue to be the case. It is precisely the complexity, importance, importance and differences in national tax policies of the 28 Member States that have become one of the biggest challenges facing the EU. I support greater coordination between EU Member States on the issue of tax rulings, which is why I voted in favour of this proposal for an advisory report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. However, I believe that it is very important to maintain the tax legislation of the Member States as an exclusive national competence. The EU therefore needs more transparency and cooperation between Member States on tax rulings in the EU. The complexity of taxation and the various national laws make it possible for both international corporations and smaller companies to successfully develop schemes to maximise the full payment of taxes, thereby distorting competition and promoting unequal rules of play between Member States. Greater transparency and coordination could prevent tax revenues from one country from being unfairly reduced as a result of the tax policy applied by another Member State.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution as it calls to increase transparency and fight against aggressive tax planning.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report deals with the exchange of intergovernmental tax rulings between the administrations of the Member States. This information will be exchanged automatically, more comprehensively and more quickly in the future. The Commission should also have access to this data in the future and establish a central register. Tax rulings are used to inform companies about the tax treatment of certain business activities. A tax ruling is a useful tool insofar as it enables a company to have planning certainty. However, the Luxleaks revelations made it clear that tax rulings can also be misused. As a result, selective tax advantages have been granted in some cases to companies operating internationally by means of tax rulings. This puts SMEs operating exclusively locally and nationally at a significant competitive disadvantage. ALFA is in favour of transparent and therefore honest competition, both between companies and between states. The measures proposed in the report are likely to increase transparency in European tax competition and to reduce distortions in the taxation of different categories of companies. The measures are also likely to provide a more transparent framework for the fundamentally desirable competition between Member States and thereby strengthen it. The disclosure of information to the Commission is necessary in order to fulfil its role as guardian of intergovernmental competition. I strongly support these concerns and voted in favour of the report.

name: Stelios
text: Kouloglou (GUE/NGL), in writing. ‒ This report is to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information between Member States in tax matters, after the LuxLeaks scandal. This report is an improvement in the following areas: deletion of the ‘cross-border’ element, immediate exchange of information and an improvement regarding the Council's position. This is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – In the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, the European Parliament is also expressing its determination, through this report, not to tolerate tax fraud and tax avoidance, and to stand up for a fair distribution of tax burdens between citizens and companies, which I fully agree with. In its previous resolution, the European Parliament stressed the need for the EU to take the lead in the fight against tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax havens. One of the most effective ways of doing this is to improve the exchange of information, in particular in relation to member states' tax rulings.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report's proposed extension of the scope of automatic exchange of information from cross-border interpretations to all tax rulings and the suggestion of an immediate exchange of information in place of a periodic procedure will require more work from the national tax services. I am also aware that an increase in the amount of information exchanged will also need to introduce a number of changes to national reporting requirements. However, if it is at stake to stop tax fraud or the use by certain entities – especially large corporations with strong backgrounds in the form of global law firms – of existing loopholes in the legal systems in order to avoid paying taxes at the place where they do business, Then I am sure that it is reasonable to expect the state administration to adapt its procedures to the requirements of the situation. Existing technological solutions and the increasing digitisation of the work of administration create the conditions when state offices can and should be required to operate much more efficiently than before. The European Parliament's report is consultative on solutions already agreed within the Council. However, even in this situation, it is important for representatives of European societies to send a strong signal demanding more advanced solutions from Brussels and the national authorities in the fight against aggressive tax avoidance by large capital.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I have decided to give a positive opinion on Mr Ferber's report. I believe that the European Union must lead the way in the fight against tax evasion, and that is why we need to strengthen the European regulatory framework in this area. To this end, this proposal aims to amend Directive 2011/16/EU, so as to oblige national tax authorities to exchange information on their internal regulatory updates in terms of tax transparency on a quarterly basis.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The Ferber report relates to the Council's proposed directive amending the 2011/16/EU directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of tax information.  This text follows the LuxLeaks scandal over the tax avoidance of large companies in Luxembourg with the approval of the Luxembourg authorities (remember that Mr Juncker, the current President of the Commission, was finance minister and prime minister of that country for more than 25 years). It aims to ensure that the directive, and therefore the compulsory exchange of information, applies to all advance tax decisions (rulings), while the Commission is content with advance decisions on cross-border matters and prior agreements on price transfer.  Similarly, the Commission (which, let us recall, has at its head a person whose head we have every reason to believe that it was aware of the Luxembourg situation...) proposes that this compulsory exchange should not be retroactive, when Parliament wants to apply it to all the agreements and rulings still valid to date.  This text is a step forward in the face of the Commission's lower-case position and echoes the OECD's position on tax evasion. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it introduces an automatic exchange of tax information. It thus marks a step forward in the fight against tax dumping by certain European states, notably Luxembourg.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report setting out the Position of the European Parliament on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an objective improvement in the obligations for the exchange of information in the tax field. Although this report continues to allow european evasors to use tax havens, it is an undeniable improvement. The report acknowledges the damage caused to SMEs by large companies that locate their profits in this type of paradise. From our point of view, the exchange of information is a necessary but not sufficient condition in correcting the tax abuses that occur in Europe. However, we recognise the value of this small step forward and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report deals with the exchange of intergovernmental tax rulings between the administrations of the Member States. This information will be exchanged automatically, more comprehensively and more quickly in the future. The Commission should also have access to this data in the future and establish a central register. Tax rulings are used to inform companies about the tax treatment of certain business activities. A tax ruling is a useful tool insofar as it enables a company to have planning certainty. However, the Luxleaks revelations made it clear that tax rulings can also be misused. As a result, selective tax advantages have been granted in some cases to companies operating internationally by means of tax rulings. This puts SMEs operating exclusively locally and nationally at a significant competitive disadvantage. ALFA is in favour of transparent and therefore honest competition, both between companies and between states. The measures proposed in the report are likely to increase transparency in European tax competition and to reduce distortions in the taxation of different categories of companies. The measures are also likely to provide a more transparent framework for the fundamentally desirable competition between Member States and thereby strengthen it. The disclosure of information to the Commission is necessary in order to fulfil its role as guardian of intergovernmental competition. I strongly support these concerns and voted in favour of the report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Aggressive tax planning, tax fraud, tax avoidance and privileged cross-border tax treatments damage the European Union by €1,000 billion annually. With the loss of these funds, Member States are unable to channel additional resources into growth drivers. It further burdens labour and manufacturing and slows down economic growth, development and new employment.  The European Commission's legislative proposal to automatically share information between Member States in the area of taxation is an important step towards combating unfair tax practices and encouraging fair and transparent tax competition in the European Union. The European Parliament's proposal, i.e. this report, significantly improved the Commission's original proposal.  I supported the European Parliament's report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament advocates the fight against tax fraud, tax avoidance and promotes a fair distribution of the tax burden on all citizens and entrepreneurs. A significant proportion of tax evasion is represented by the hiding of financial assets in financial institutions located mainly in tax havens, where, together with a non-transparent financial environment, the anonymity of ownership of firms and money in accounts is guaranteed. However, the large financial cases linked to tax evasion also concern the EU-based institution, an example of which is the largest Swiss bank, Credit Suisse Wegelin, which eventually disappeared as a result of the heavy fine. However, in the fight against tax fraud, EU governments are still pulling the short end. This ultimately damages the economy and economy of the Member States and of the Union itself. The proposed Council Directive aims, through the exchange of information in the field of taxation, to step up the fight against tax fraud and to introduce more transparent tax rules that will strengthen taxpayers' legal certainty while also increasing the investment and employment package.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on their proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the mandatory exchange of information in the field of taxation, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015 and because tax evasion and avoidance are the modern scourge of euro area economies. Multinational companies have emerged as champions, which through the system of intra-group transactions avoid paying taxes of many billion euros. Euro. Their allies are the various tax havens and some euro area Member States engaged in tax dumping and unfair practices, thus giving multinationals vital space not to pay multi-billion euro in taxes. In countries such as Greece, the total amount of the aid was EUR 1 million. Luxembourg with the so-called 'Lux Leaks' and the Netherlands give cover to German and other multinationals in order to avoid tax. And all this at a time when Mr. Dijsselbloem is waving his finger at Greece and demanding a new tax-free resalto in the pockets of the impoverished Greek people. Moreover, the troika in Greece whistles indifferently and disguises all Greek governments that refuse to take advantage of the Lagarde list and tax Greek oligarchs who have illegal deposits in Switzerland.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. It aims to establish full transparency on tax rulings and related measures. This will discourage states and companies that over-use it. The entry into force of this directive has been postponed, which will give some States (Luxembourg, Ireland, the Netherlands) time to put an end to the most "contestable" agreements. In the long run, it is hoped that the competition will be more frank, on rates alone.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field. The aim of the report is to extend the automatic exchange of information at both EU and global level. The exchange of information in the tax field is one of the instruments for strengthening the fight against tax fraud and evasion.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal on mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 In particular in the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, the European Parliament is firmly committed to not toleration of tax fraud and tax avoidance and will advocate that the tax burden be fairly distributed among citizens and companies. Problems caused by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition are increasing significantly, taking centre stage in the EU. Tax avoidance reduces Member States' revenues and also distorts competition to the detriment of SMEs in particular. Today we discussed the report, which enshrines the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax field as one of the possible tools to combat tax avoidance. Since my amendment has also been adopted, which guarantees that tax rates will not be harmonised – I believe that this issue should definitely remain the responsibility of individual Member States – I voted in favour of the report.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are facing a directive that will lead to greater transparency and tax clarity. It introduces a new article to the existing directive, defining the conditions and scope for the automatic and compulsory exchange of information on certain types of tax rulings. I therefore voted in favour, so that these objectives can be achieved as a matter of urgency.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. In 2015, the renewed fiscal will finally spread to the European institutions: in February, the special committee TAXE began its work; In March, the Commission presents a first legislative proposal; in June, a second, and at the same time, the revision of several flagship directives is under way.  With regard to the central element of LuxLeaks, the "tax criteria", states were - until now - only obliged to exchange these advance decisions if they were under a discretion. In fact, there were almost no rescripts in the administrations, which the Ferber report aims to end by introducing an automatic exchange of tax information. Parliament has reached the most ambitious compromises on this text, which is crucial in the face of the Council, whose margins of ambition are being cut by unanimity. Parliament therefore reiterated its call for the broadest cooperation: exchange of all the rescripts still in force. In addition, it is imperative that the Commission have access to these exchanged texts in order to carry out investigations where appropriate. Anxious to bring these demands that we share in the TAXE committee, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The establishment of a public directory in which all information is available from all EU citizens must be strongly opposed. That is why I did not support this report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Advance tax rulings are information that tax authorities give to taxpayers about how their taxes will be calculated. These decisions are made to provide legal certainty to taxpayers, often confirming the tax treatment of a large or complex business transaction.  It is the lack of transparency on these "case-by-case" tax rulings that allows large companies to artificially reduce their taxation, as seen in the LuxLeaks case. The text proposes to remedy this by making it mandatory to communicate these decisions via a quarterly report to the Commission containing specific information. I regret that these reports are not made public and remain in the hands of the Commission. Nevertheless this goes in the direction of greater tax control and I am voting for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the proposal requiring Member States to automatically exchange information on advance cross-border tax rulings with the aim of preventing tax avoidance by companies. This is a very important proposal for a directive, when it is estimated that corporate tax avoidance deprives the public budgets of EU Member States of several billion euros per year.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the automatic exchange of information will increase the level of transparency and combat cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ I consider it natural for companies to pay taxes in profit-making countries and to respect the laws of the state where they operate. The EU-wide systematic and compulsory procedure, such as the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, aims to combat tax fraud and relief, tax havens and is intended to ensure greater transparency in this area across the EU. The Commission has proposed to establish a timetable for information on tax opinions, and Member States should issue quarterly reports on tax opinions and transfer pricing. It also proposed the creation of a secure central register where information would be recorded. The European Parliament has introduced a number of amendments that could make this proposal even more effective and introduce more transparency into taxation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ After the Luxleaks scandal, it was obvious that lack of transparency on tax rulings is being exploited by certain companies in order to artificially reduce their tax contribution in Member states where they operate. Exchange of information of cross-border tax rulings is very limited, not mandatory and does not live up to the needs today to gather tools to create a more transparent and responsible tax regime in Europe. Therefore, with some small reservations and vote against certain amendments, I voted in favour of the mandatory automatic exchange of information on types of cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing arrangements. In my opinion this will increase transparency and fight against aggressive tax planning.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Yet another vote completing the legal architecture of Europe allowing the disciplining of financial transactions and limiting the scope for tax evasion and fraud.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission has submitted a proposal to the Council to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, as amended by Directive 2014/107/EU, as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The proposal would add a new article to the current Directive, which sets out the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic sharing of information on tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements with certain types of cross-border implications. This obligation shall be extended to decisions issued in the 10 years preceding the entry into force of the proposed Directive which are still in force at the time of its entry into force. The Council should consult the European Parliament under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union before deciding. In its report, Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the Commission's proposal with a number of amendments. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Luxleaks scandal has led to a proposal for a directive to introduce automatic exchange between Member States' administrations of tax rulings or related measures (validation of transfer prices, various arrangements). The idea is to have transparency about these practices, in order to discourage states and companies from over-using them (tax dumping).   Parliament has strengthened certain aspects of the text. The exchange would be retroactive, up to 10 years back for the rescripts, and their access would have been extended. The Ecofin council, meeting on 6 October, took a much less-than-mentioned position. It is his version that will take precedence, with Parliament issuing only an advisory opinion.   States have thus renounced retroactivity and have also postponed the entry into force of the directive, giving the most compromised members (Luxembourg, Ireland, the Netherlands) time to put an end to the most questionable agreements and present a polished image. Exchange remains a step forward in these often opaque practices.  It is therefore necessary to support this report by deploring that Ecofin has so far departed from it.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament stressed in its Resolution of 21 May 2013 that the European Union should take a leading role in global debates on the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and tax havens, especially with regard to the promotion of information exchange. Currently, with Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in force, Member States share very little information with each other on their tax agreements. The amendment, as aresulted by Directive 2014/107/EU, introduces a new article in the Directive setting out the scope and conditions for the automatic and mandatory exchange of information on cross-border tax agreements and transfer pricing agreements. This obligation shall be extended to agreements established in the 10 years preceding the date on which the proposed Directive takes effect and which are still valid at the date of entry into force of the Directive. I believe that this Commission proposal will be an important step towards increasing tax transparency and continuing to combat cross-border tax avoidance.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Ferber report relates to the Council's proposed directive amending the 2011/16/EU directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field.  This text follows the LuxLeaks scandal over the tax avoidance of large companies in Luxembourg with the approval of the Luxembourg authorities (remember that Mr Juncker, the current President of the Commission, was finance minister and prime minister of that country for more than 25 years). It aims to ensure that the directive, and therefore the compulsory exchange of information, applies to all advance tax decisions (rulings), while the Commission is content with advance decisions on cross-border matters and prior agreements on price transfer. Similarly, the Commission (which, let us recall, has at its head a person whose head we have every reason to believe that it was aware of the Luxembourg situation...) proposes that this compulsory exchange should not be retroactive, when Parliament wants to apply it to all the agreements and rulings still valid to date.  This text is a step forward in the face of the Commission's lower-case position and echoes the OECD's position on tax evasion. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of automatic exchange of information on tax rulings because transparency is absolutely vital when it comes to cracking down on aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion. For far too long, governments have been able to make secret agreements with companies about how much tax they will pay, with no scrutiny from other Member States or the public as a whole. That needs to change, and while the Commission’s proposals are welcome, we in the Parliament believe they can and should go further.  It is over to David Cameron and the rest of the Council now to show that they are serious when they say they want to stamp out these practices once and for all.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this report because cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition have reached considerable proportions.  We are convinced that the EU must take a leading role in the global debate on combating fraud, circumvention and tax havens, in particular as regards promoting the practice of the constant exchange of sensitive information and data. Unfortunately, we have to note that, in the current regulatory framework, Member States do not spontaneously exchange their tax data. The Commission's proposal aims to define the scope and conditions for automatic exchange.  The position adopted in the ECON Committee goes even further, it is even more ambitious, because we are calling for the scope to be extended to all decisions, not just so-called cross-border issues; we are opposed to any period of retroactivity; we are convinced of the need to introduce possible sanctions in the event of non-compliance with the rules.  All tax decisions will have to be catalogued in a central register, to which the Commission will have full and unconditional access. Finally, a summary of the main tax decisions exchanged should be published. We hope that we will also have the support of all the political groups in plenary.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased considerably and has become a major focus of concern within the Union and at global level. I have voted for this report that will introduce a new Article into the existing Directive, setting out the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of information on types of cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing arrangements.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ To combat tax evasion and tax avoidance, in light of the fact that legal personalities can take advantage of differences in tax rates and tax bases in different Member States, it is necessary that the Member States work together and share information. The Commission has proposed that any rulings that relate to cross-border transactions must be securely shared among the Member States, so that exploitation or other negative effects can be more easily discovered and prevented. Cross-border rulings that have occurred in the last 10 years should also be shared, so that any recent indiscretions can be duly handled. This proposal is an excellent start to limiting the manipulation of tax laws, and takes great strides to improve transparency and communication between member-states. Though there are further strides still to be taken in the fight against fraud and tax evasion, this is a definite step in the right direction for the European Union, a step that will benefit the tax revenue of each individual Member State.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which contained a number of important, progressive provisions. This report emerged from the Luxleaks scandal. The aim is to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information between tax administrations regarding advance cross-border rulings and advance pricing arrangements and to strengthen existing EU legislation. Furthermore, the GUE/NGL rapporteur managed to further strengthen the Commission proposal in a number of key areas including strengthening reporting requirements – i.e. immediate exchange of information.  My Group tabled an alternative compromise stating that all rulings should be publicly available and not only stored somewhere in a central Commission database in an aggregated form. The Greens and EFDD supported GUE/NGL on this issue, but unfortunately it was rejected in committee.  Nevertheless, given that the report was still an improvement compared to the Commission proposal and especially compared to the Council position which was adopted even before the ECON vote took place, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted against this report because it goes too far and gives the Commission further powers. In addition, exporters and customs authorities will be burdened with additional burdens. A public register will also be set up in which all information from all citizens can be accessed at any time. In my opinion, this report goes far too far and is unacceptable to me in this form.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I am voting in favour of this report, which is making a significant step forward in the fight against tax evasion, fraud and tax havens. It proposes to approve the amendment of the 2011/16/EU Council Directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field.  The new directive will make it systematic to exchange information on advance tax returns, drawn up by each Member State, which can have a direct or indirect impact on the tax bases of other member countries. Thus, the amendments would require Member States to provide specific information on these declarations each quarter, including a description of the criteria used to set transfer pricing in tax matters or a clear identification of the states likely to be affected.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Tax fraud and tax evasion are a major problem both in the EU and globally. In order to address this, it is necessary to increase the exchange of information between countries. This directive seeks to address this issue and lays down the scope and conditions for the mandatory exchange of information on cross-border tax rulings. At the same time, the mandatory exchange of information should be extended to all tax rulings and not necessarily only to tax rulings with cross-border implications. It is also important that the relevant exchange of information is rapid and in a secure environment.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI)
text: Writing. – The Directive on the exchange of information between Member States on favourable tax decisions for enterprises will not restrict the provocative tax privileges of transnational business groups and the immunity of monopolies. The final text limits its initially limited scope to cross-border cases only, extends the time at which the information is exchanged and reduces it to a period of five years before the tax authorities are obliged to disclose their relevant decisions. As the directive itself acknowledges, decisions by national tax authorities granting all kinds of tax privileges and exemptions to large groups are 'legitimate', in accordance with their national legislation. The ultimate law of every capitalist state and every urban government is to protect with its legislation capitalist property and capital gains. The very nature of the EU, based on the freedom of movement of capital, legitimises and serves the tax immunity of business groups, for which the EU institutions hypocritically and provocatively shed crocodile tears. Peoples can live without monopolies and without exploitation when they decide to put an end to their power, taking into their own hands the wealth they produce.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As you know, the problem of cross-border tax avoidance is close to my heart and I believe that greater transparency in the area of tax rulings is necessary in order to solve this problem that all Member States within the Union are facing. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Supported this report only because I believe that the system of information exchange between Member States' tax administrations is an important instrument for preventing tax evasion and combating fraud. Banking secrecy and the protection of personal data is considered an obstacle to its full application. Losses in Member States due to tax evasion reach €1,000 billion annually.  At a time when workers' wages are falling, companies are closing and workers are being laid off, at a time when pensions and welfare benefits are also decreasing, I consider it necessary to allow tax collection without introducing new taxes and not increasing existing ones. The exchange of information, experience and knowledge between tax administrations of states is important and will be carried out in order to strengthen the fight against tax avoidance.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Ferber report relates to the Council's proposed directive amending the 2011/16/EU directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of tax information. This text follows the LuxLeaks scandal over the tax avoidance of large companies in Luxembourg with the approval of the Luxembourg authorities (remember that Mr Juncker, the current President of the Commission, was finance minister and prime minister of that country for more than 25 years). It aims to ensure that the directive, and therefore the compulsory exchange of information, applies to all advance tax decisions (rulings), while the Commission is content with advance decisions on cross-border matters and prior agreements on price transfer. Similarly, the Commission (which, let us recall, has at its head a person whose head we have every reason to believe that it was aware of the Luxembourg situation...) proposes that this compulsory exchange should not be retroactive, when Parliament wants to apply it to all the agreements and rulings still valid to date. This text is a step forward in the face of the Commission's lower-case position and echoes the OECD's position on tax evasion. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with colleague Markus Ferber's report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. In its resolution of 21 May 2013, the European Parliament stressed that the EU should take a leading role in global debates on combating tax fraud and tax avoidance and promote information sharing. Member States generally do not share their tax solutions with other countries, which is why they are often unaware of tax solutions in neighbouring countries that could affect their systems. The lack of transparency in this area results in fraud by companies wishing to reduce their tax charges. This requires increasing transparency, through the introduction of a new article in the current Directive which sets out the scope and conditions for the mandatory automatic exchange of tax access data.  A useful solution is also the introduction of strict deadlines, by which all Member States should send data on cross-border tax solutions to others every three months. The Commission's plan to create a central database should continue to be elaborated, where all information will be stored.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Combating fraud, tax avoidance and tax havens is one of the EU's main challenges. To meet this challenge would be to ensure greater fairness and protection for honest citizens. At present, Member States are exchanging a very small amount of information on tax rulings. In this way, the competent authorities of each Member State often do not become aware of tax rulings in another State or of cross-border tax rulings. All this is being exploited by some companies to artificially reduce their tax contribution.  My vote in favour of the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU is favourable because this proposal aims to achieve greater transparency in tax matters, precisely defining the scope and conditions for the compulsory automatic exchange of information on certain types of tax rulings.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the commitment of the EU and Member States to the action plan on the erosion of the tax base and profit transfer within the OECD and the G20, the EU decided to update the European legal texts.  In this context, Parliament adopted the text amending the 2011/16/EU directive on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field. I voted in favour of this decision because I believe that it is now essential to better regulate these exchanges of sensitive information, both in the interests of citizens and businesses.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that transparency and exchange of information in tax matters need to be increased in order to avoid, among other consequences, distortion of competition.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is in favour of tax transparency as a means to prevent secret tax deals being done between large multi-national corporations and countries like Luxembourg. However, the report includes amendments that would force Member States to provide the information to the EU Commission (rather than simply making it public) and would have retroactive effect – for these reasons UKIP abstained.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. The tax differentials between the Member States of the European Union have, together with the free movement of capital and people, encouraged the use of tax optimisation and evasion by certain multinational firms. These practices are harmful to the public finances of EU countries and profoundly affect cohesion between Member States. It is enough to remember the "LuxLeaks" scandal in which an EU State was accused of tax dumping by the other Member States, for having benefited from these optimisations, by introducing an advantageous tax system.  While these practices are not always illegal, they are nonetheless intolerable in view of the values esperantis of the European Union and the spirit of cooperation that follows.  That is why I have spoken in favour of a directive on tax rulings aimed at making the exchange of information in this area between the countries of the European Union automatic and compulsory. This measure should restore transparency and strengthen the competitiveness of SMEs, taxing the added value of each player where it is created.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report setting out the European Parliament's position on the proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, which aims to include in its scope the automatic exchange of information on secret tax agreements.  The approved text contains the following main elements: (a) Automatic exchange of information is not limited to decisions considered 'cross-border'.  b) Full retroactivity with the opaque pacts still in force, regardless of when they were signed. c) Possibility of sanctioning States in case of non-compliance. d) Storage of all resolutions in a database to which the Commission has full access. (e) Granting publicity to summaries of the main tax rulings.  I hope the Council will take this into account. It is also important to extend and revise those aspects of the Directive not related to so-called 'tax rulings' that have become outdated (unjustified exceptions not to give the information, as 'official secrecy' for what should be nothing more than confidential information in accordance with data protection regulations, etc.)

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, this report - which I have of course supported - was an opportunity for the European Parliament to express its deep determination not to tolerate tax evasion and evasion and to advocate a fair distribution of the tax burden between citizens and businesses.  The challenge of cross-border tax avoidance and harmful tax competition has taken on a new dimension and has become a major concern within the Union and at the global level. This is what the European Parliament already stressed in its resolution of 21 May 2013.  There is now an urgent need to continue efforts and increase transparency. In order to achieve this, it is necessary to strengthen the tools and mechanisms created by the Council's 2011/16/EU Directive on Administrative Cooperation, an issue in the adopted report.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The challenge posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased considerably and is a cause for concern for governments at European and global level. The European Parliament has always stressed the need for the EU to take a leading position against fraud, tax evasion and tax havens, and to that extent greater administrative cooperation and transparency in cross-border tax agreements is particularly important, enabling information to be exchanged between Member States, avoiding potential negative effects on their tax bases, while reducing the impacts of tax avoidance. I am in favour of the adoption of this report on a special legislative consultation procedure, which deals with the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on the automatic exchange of mandatory information in the field of taxation.  I would like to highlight as a positive aspect the introduction of a new article on the scope and conditions for the automatic and compulsory exchange of information on cross-border tax agreements and transfer pricing agreements between Member States, highlighting, as a negative point, the wasted opportunity to include purely national agreements and advance transfer pricing agreements in this context.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which gives the European Parliament's position on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field.  Fraud and tax evasion remain intolerable and a fair distribution of the tax burden between citizens and businesses must be found.  Unfortunately, the Council did not wait for the European Parliament to vote, as an agreement had already been reached in the Council at the beginning of October; It should also be noted that this agreement is less ambitious than the position adopted by the European Parliament. For example, the European Parliament wanted the scope of the directive to apply to all tax rulings and not just cross-border tax rulings.  In the end, the text stresses the importance of immediately exchanging information and calls for improved transparency towards citizens by asking the Commission to publish a report once a year summarising the main issues.  We must continue these efforts on tax transparency.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field, as I believe that we need greater cooperation and harmonisation between Member States in tax matters.  Tax competition must become an instrument for development and global growth, and the European Union must work constantly to prevent and combat tax evasion. The proposal for a Directive 2014/107/EU would amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation and would ensure that Member States have an automatic and compulsory exchange of information on cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the measure has among its aims to combat the effects of fraud and evasion, as well as the proliferation of tax havens within the Union as well.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report and the legislative resolution in question, which is one of the results of the Luxleaks (leaks that exposed the agreements between the State of Luxembourg and multinationals facilitating tax avoidance). It provides for the obligation for States to transmit their agreements with multinationals on taxes to the Commission. We would have wanted the agreements to be made public and not just transmitted to the Commission, but this was rejected by the majority groups.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an objective improvement in the obligations for the exchange of information in the tax field. Although this report continues to allow european evasors to use tax havens, it is an undeniable improvement. The report acknowledges the damage caused to SMEs by large companies that locate their profits in this type of paradise. From our point of view, the exchange of information is a necessary but not sufficient condition in correcting the tax abuses that occur in Europe. However, we recognise the value of this small step forward and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. It is important that the best way to share information between tax authorities can be foreseen and contribute to strengthening healthy tax behaviour on the part of large enterprises. Tax evasion produces significant losses, which inevitably make national budgets felt and result in an burden of taxes on the gold economic agents and, in particular, on workers. This text helps to prevent budgetary losses resulting from tax abuse by large companies and thus to foster a greater margin of comfort from national budgets, which are currently under pressure.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as although I believe nation states should be open and transparent about taxation I do not wish to see the Commission involved in how the UK manages its corporation tax.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of automatic exchange of information on tax rulings because transparency is absolutely vital when it comes to cracking down on aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion. For far too long, governments have been able to make secret agreements with companies about how much tax they’ll pay, with no scrutiny from other Member States or the public as a whole. That needs to change, and while the Commission’s proposals are welcome, we in Parliament believe they can and should go further.  It’s over to David Cameron and the rest of the Council now to show that they are serious when they say they want to stamp out these practices once and for all.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the case of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation, I abstained in the vote because the resolution contains a number of contradictory proposals. I clearly condemn tax fraud and the hasne behind mamona unfair tax practices. On the other hand, the fight against fraud must not be a pretext for unjustified EU interference in Slovakia's tax policy. That is the question of subsidiarity. Each EU country must be able to set the conditions for foreign investors on its own.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I already spoke in this House when I discussed the annual tax report in March 2015 about the need to harmonise tax policy and eliminate inconsistencies between national rules. I can responsibly state that I remain a fierce opponent of tax evasion, tax fraud and tax avoidance. I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that, also on the basis of these proposals and measures, effective exchange and processing of tax information can be achieved, which will have a strong deterrent effect against the introduction of harmful tax practices. I trust that, by adopting these measures, we will follow up on the conclusions of the European Council of 18 December 2014 and continue our efforts to combat tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning at global and European level. I expect Member States to take sufficient measures to help remove any obstacles to the mandatory automatic exchange of information on binding opinions on the setting of the valuation method in order to effectively monitor the application of automatic exchange of information.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 The number of tax fraud and evasion has been increasing in recent years and has serious implications for member states' tax revenues. As a result, they lose billions of euros a year and are forced to raise taxes. We have recently seen the disclosure of hundreds of examples of exploitation of differences in tax systems. The Commission correctly concluded days ago that, in the case of Starbucks and Fiat, there was selective tax advantages and, consequently, unlawful State aid.  Following this example, the EU must continue to take a leading role in the fight against tax fraud and evasion. These are not only illegal, but also immoral, which has a very bad impact on the functioning of the internal market. In the end, it is SMEs that pay the highest price, because they are forced to operate in tax systems that are unfair and where multinationals gain an undue competitive advantage through manipulation. I welcome the Commission's proposal as it represents a step towards greater transparency. I am convinced that the mutual control of countries, as highlighted by the report, could have a strong deterrent in the implementation of exploitative tax practices, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today of Parliament's opinion on the proposal for a directive on the automatic sharing of tax information between Member States, a proposal put forward by the Commission following the Lux Leaks case to ensure greater coordination and coordination between Member States in tax matters. With this text, we as a Parliament have criticised the agreement reached by the Economic and Financial Affairs Council on 6 October, which we consider to be a missed opportunity towards real fiscal justice for European citizens. The Council's position restricts both the scope of the draft directive on automatic trade, limiting it to cross-border tax systems only, the Commission's access to this information and the irretroactivity of the directive on tax systems already in operation. Faced with such an una ambitious position, we believe that the proposals put forward by the Commission and Parliament must be taken seriously in order to ensure the greatest possible transparency for the benefit of citizens and national tax authorities.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Fair competition is not possible without transparent information on the tax burden. As a neutral body, the Commission should have the right to intervene in the event of suspicion of favouring one investor over another. At the same time, the principle of fiscal sovereignty must be maintained at national level.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of automatic exchange of tax rulings because transparency is absolutely vital when it comes to cracking down on aggressive tax avoidance and tax evasion. For far too long, governments have been able to make secret agreements with companies about how much tax they’ll pay, with no scrutiny from other Member States or from the public as a whole. That needs to change, and while the Commission’s proposals are welcome, we in the Parliament believe they can and should go further. It’s over to David Cameron and the rest of the Council now to show that they are serious when they say they want to stamp out these practices once and for all.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The draft directive proposes to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, in order to ensure the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation with regard to cross-border impact and previous transfer pricing agreements. The challenge caused by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has increased significantly in recent years and is considered a serious problem, both in the Union and globally.  In particular, decisions on tax-motivated structures lead to a low level of taxation of artificially high amounts of income in the country that issued the previous opinion, and may lead to an artificial reduction in the amount of taxable income in other countries involved. I fully support this report as it provides for increased transparency and would give Member States and the Commission access to all relevant information so that they can take action against further illegal tax policy practices.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: I did not support the proposal in writing ‒ as it unreasonably includes court decisions in the field of taxes that do not in any way concern cross-border transactions. The proposal thus unnecessarily increases the administrative burden and, moreover, poses fundamental risks in the area of the protection of personal data.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. For the first time since the Luxleaks affair, we discussed concrete tax legislation in plenary. As one of the EU institutions, we must send a clear signal that we are in favour of clear, transparent and fair tax legislation. I welcome the Commission's proposal that tax rulings of cross-border importance should be automatically communicated to the relevant Member States. However, I would like to draw attention to the need to be closely monitored so that member states do not knowingly apply tax law against other Member States.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ While I support the Commission’s swift response to the challenges posed by cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition by the exchange of information for cross-border tax rulings and would like to aid tax authorities in quickly identify tax illegalities. I cannot support the EP’s change of scope to include a public exchange of all rulings through a central register. This does not take into account rules governing data protection and commercially sensitive information.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, which contributes to ensuring a smooth and continuous system of mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation.  I welcomed the amendment to the report which states that the European Parliament does not tolerate tax fraud and tax avoidance and advocates a fair distribution of the tax burden between citizens and companies. I also agree with the addition that appropriate and effective penalties should be developed in the event that Member States fail to share tax rulings and decisions or agreements on ex ante pricing agreements. Only in this way can transparency be ensured, which is a prerequisite for increasing legal certainty and tax justice and encourages the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, investment and innovation. The LuxLeaks scandal has shown that a lack of transparency causes serious damage to Member States and imposes unfair tax burdens on decent taxpayers, including companies that have not received special treatment. We expect the automatic exchange of information on tax exemptions within the EU to put an end to the illegitim procedures of individual Member States and to contribute to the development of a stable tax system.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Fair competition is the engine of development, but for that to be the case, all the principles of equal business competition in the global market must be respected. One of the key elements is the fair implementation of the tax liability. Cooperation between states in this area is therefore important and necessary. The Commission's proposed amendments to Directive 2011/16/EU on mandatory exchange of information in the field of taxation are the right step towards improving the current law. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report and I believe that the Council will take the right decisions as soon as possible, which will benefit the Member States, but ultimately – and the businesses themselves.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Increasing transparency and fighting against aggressive tax planning is one of the issues the Parliament has taken the lead on. The current legal framework (Directive 2011/16/EU), gives Member States the discretion to decide whether a tax ruling might be relevant to another EU country.  This creates a situation where a Member State can issue tax rulings without being aware to other tax rulings issued elsewhere in the EU, which may impact their own tax bases. Moreover, as the information exchanged between the Member States is very limited and not mandatory, we are falling short from creating a more transparent and responsible tax regime.  Amending this current legal framework will increase required transparency. The current report supports the Commission's proposal, which sets the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic exchange of information on types of cross-border tax rulings and transfer pricing arrangements.  The Parliament calls to extend the scope of the Directive to all rulings, exchange all valid tax rulings already before the entry into force of the Directive, and introduce sanctions in case of non-compliance. The adoption of this report will prevent companies from exploiting loop holes to artificially reduce their tax contribution, therefore I voted in favour of it.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text and I salute my colleague, Hugues Bayet, for his pointed analysis. The ball is now clearly in the hands of the Member States whose latest proposals, on 6 October, lacked ambition. This is because we know from the European Commission's decision that some tax agreements are not only immoral but also illegal. These are illegal state aid that leads to unfair competition.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because an increase in transparency concerning tax rulings is needed. The report seeks to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation, as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. The reason is that currently, Member States share very little information with one another about their tax rulings. As a result, they do not spontaneously exchange their tax rulings and are often unaware of cross-border tax rulings issued elsewhere in the EU which may impact their own tax bases. To bring more transparency, the mechanisms established by Council Directive 2011/16/EU need to be enhanced. Regarding some of the European Parliament’s amendments to the Commission proposal, it agreed that the Directive should apply to all tax rulings and not just cross border rulings and advance pricing arrangements, since purely national transactions can also have cross-border effects.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. In the wake of the LuxLeaks scandal, Pierre Moscovici proposed a first package of measures to combat tax dumping. The main one is to make it compulsory to exchange information on tax rulings - including tax giveaways - between Member States and the Commission, with a 10-year retroactivity. The Council, at first reading, chose to reduce retroactivity to five years and refused to allow the Commission access to this information, depriving it, in fact, of any ability to investigate.  The European Parliament has reacted: we propose in this report that all existing tax rulings should and automatically be placed on a platform accessible to the Commission, without criteria for retroactivity.  I strongly support this report, because the fight against tax dumping is a priority for me. The favours granted to multinationals jeopardize public finances and our social standards. But we must go further by adopting a European tax on multinationals, the only instrument capable of ending the race for the lowest tax in Europe.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation because, although it is severely impaired from the commission's original proposal, it brings about an improvement of tools and mechanisms to increase transparency over tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition, companies will no longer be able to exploit the system and artificially reduce their tax liability.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report and the legislative resolution in question, which is one of the results of the Luxleaks (leaks that exposed the agreements between the State of Luxembourg and multinationals facilitating tax avoidance). It provides for the obligation for States to transmit their agreements with multinationals on taxes to the Commission. We would have wanted the agreements to be made public and not just transmitted to the Commission, but this was rejected by the majority groups.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The report deals with the exchange of intergovernmental tax rulings between the administrations of the Member States. This information will be exchanged automatically, more comprehensively and more quickly in the future. The Commission should also have access to this data in the future and establish a central register. Tax rulings are used to inform companies about the tax treatment of certain business activities. A tax ruling is a useful tool insofar as it enables a company to have planning certainty. However, the Luxleaks revelations made it clear that tax rulings can also be misused. As a result, selective tax advantages have been granted in some cases to companies operating internationally by means of tax rulings. This puts SMEs operating exclusively locally and nationally at a significant competitive disadvantage. ALFA is in favour of transparent and therefore honest competition, both between companies and between states. The measures proposed in the report are likely to increase transparency in European tax competition and to reduce distortions in the taxation of different categories of companies. The measures are also likely to provide a more transparent framework for the fundamentally desirable competition between Member States and thereby strengthen it. The disclosure of information to the Commission is necessary in order to fulfil its role as guardian of intergovernmental competition. I strongly support these concerns and voted in favour of the report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The LuxLeaks scandal has led to a proposal for a directive, presented in the spring by Commissioner Moscovici, to introduce the automatic exchange of information between Member States' administrations on the tax rules or related measures they grant (validation of transfer prices or various schemes).  The idea is to have transparency about these practices, although most often legal, in order to discourage states and companies from over-using them (tax dumping). I voted to adopt this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The problem of cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition has become an increasingly serious challenge in recent years and has come to the fore in the European Union and worldwide. In its resolution of 21 May 2013, the European Parliament stressed the need for the EU to take the lead in the global discussions on combating tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax havens, in particular on promoting information exchange. Under the current legal framework, Member States share very little information on their tax rulings. The draft directive adds a new article to the current Directive, which sets out the scope and conditions for mandatory automatic sharing of information on tax rulings and transfer pricing agreements with certain types of cross-border implications. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Traian Ungureanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the tax field provides that all prior tax decisions of a Member State having a cross-border dimension are to be made available to the other Member States through an automatic exchange of information. The European Parliament's report supports the Commission's proposal, making a number of improvements in the scope of mandatory information exchange, the way decisions are communication and transparency towards citizens. With its vote, Parliament wants to send a clear message in favour of transparency, clarity and fair tax competition in the European Union.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report and the legislative resolution in question, which is one of the results of the Luxleaks (leaks that exposed the agreements between the State of Luxembourg and multinationals facilitating tax avoidance). It provides for the obligation for States to transmit their agreements with multinationals on taxes to the Commission.
