We would have wanted the agreements to be made public and not just transmitted to the Commission, but this was rejected by the majority groups.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text in order to express my strong determination not to tolerate tax fraud and tax avoidance, as well as to advocate for a fair distribution of the tax burden between citizens and companies. Considering that there are different national administrative practices, I believe that advanced tax rulings facilitate the consistent and transparent application of the law and an efficient exchange and processing of tax information. Additionally, the resulting peer pressure would have a strong deterrent effect against the introduction of harmful tax practices and would allow Member States and the Commission to have all the relevant information at their disposal in order to take action against such practices. These measures definitely contribute to greater transparency and to the prevention of tax frauds.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation to ensure a mandatory automatic exchange of information aimed at combating the challenge of cross-border tax evasion or unfair tax competition, which are of great importance to Europe these days. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against this report, in which Parliament expressed its position on the revision of the directive on the compulsory automatic exchange of information in the tax field, which was made necessary in order to respond more effectively to the challenges posed by the phenomenon of multinational tax avoidance that erupted with the LuxLeaks scandal.  While proposing some progress, this report does not in fact aim for the only weapon available that is really effective in combating aggressive tax avoidance practices, namely the full transparency of information relating to tax rulings, tax agreements between multinationals and governments that have developed precisely thanks to secrecy.  We have fought for the creation of an easily accessible public register of all information and data relating to tax rulings, an instrument of simple implementation, strongly supported by civil society, but which has not found the consensus of that part of Parliament that is more sensitive to the interests of multinationals and strong powers. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it represents an objective improvement in the obligations for the exchange of information in the tax field. Although this report continues to allow european evasors to use tax havens, it is an undeniable improvement. The report acknowledges the damage caused to SMEs by large companies that locate their profits in this type of paradise. From our point of view, the exchange of information is a necessary but not sufficient condition in correcting the tax abuses that occur in Europe. However, we recognise the value of this small step forward and that is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In the wake of the Offshoreleaks, Luxleaks and Swissleak tax scandals, the European institutions appear to be engaged in this battle against tax fraud and evasion. However, we must ensure that all the measures and proposals in progress are not a mere legislative adornment, and that everything is still the same. If we do not: The council's proposal on the automatic exchange of information represents a clear retreat from initial expectations; – The regulation of exchange of information with Switzerland has several subterfuges to its compliance; – The work of the TAXE Commission has always been hampered. Thirteen governments, including those in the Netherlands, Luxembourg and the United Kingdom, denied access to documents from the "Code of Conduct" group; – The reservations in making tax agreements and declarations by multinational countries public are evident. These are indications that lead us to doubt the real political will to tackle the problem. Not least because the further we go, the clearer the commitment of the main figures and parties supporting the EU institutions, starting with the presidents of the European Commission and the Eurogroup.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The establishment of a public directory in which all information is available from all EU citizens must be strongly opposed. That is why I did not support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The directive under discussion is one of several initiatives, ostensibly to prevent tax avoidance. But companies are only responsible to their owners and to the tax office, but not to the EU authorities. Tax competition is now to be abolished through the European harmonisation of tax bases and the creation of the 'glass enterprise'. I strongly oppose both and therefore voted against this resolution. I deny the public's right to information on corporate tax affairs, citing a simple circumstance: they are not public entities, but private entities. Listed companies must publish stock exchange-relevant information. That's enough. However, this EP resolution is a further step towards controlling entrepreneurship and eliminating tax competition between Member States. Harmonisation of the tax base is only the first step. Entrepreneurial freedom is monitored, for example through the planned establishment of a Union-wide register of beneficial owners to identify possible cases of tax avoidance and profit shifting. The strategic objective behind the politically correct demand for tax transparency of companies is not only the "glass entrepreneur", but the "glass citizen".

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The document put to the vote is a non-binding position for the Council on the proposal presented by the European Commission. With a view to effectively tackling cross-border tax avoidance, aggressive tax planning and harmful tax competition, the Commission has proposed to amend Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in order to increase the transparency of administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. In response, the European Parliament proposed to extend the scope of Directive 2011/16/EU to all tax rulings, without limiting itself to those interpretations that may have a cross-border effect. There is therefore a concern that a significant increase in the circulation of information will force a change in national reporting requirements. In addition, Parliament has proposed the creation of a central database for annual reports. In view of the excessive scale of reporting obligations imposed on Member States, as well as concerns about the secrecy of the data disclosed in the annual reports, I have spoken out against Parliament's position on this issue.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – Combating tax avoidance and abusive tax planning is one of the European Union's priorities, as confirmed by the December 2014 European Council Conclusions. It is also an important issue on which solutions must be sought on a global scale. It is essential to ensure the obligation for EU national tax authorities to automatically exchange information on cross-border tax agreements and previous transfer pricing agreements they make to businesses; the objective has to be to increase the transparency of these agreements.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Council Directive 2011/16/EU was adopted in place of a previous Directive on mutual assistance between Member States (Council Directive 77/799/EEC) in order to respond to the need for Member States to strengthen administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. The aim of proposal 2011/16/EU was to strengthen effective and comprehensive administrative cooperation between tax administrations by establishing a mandatory automatic exchange of information on (cross-border) preventive rulings and prior agreements on transfer prices.  The main objective of the European Parliament, through this report, is to remove any reference in this directive to the cross-border dimension of rulings, that is to say, to broaden their scope, and at the same time to improve the timing of their communication, although I would have preferred a broader retroactive evaluation period. I would also have liked to see greater transparency, guaranteed by the fact that we have a public register accessible to all, in which the data relating to the tax agreements signed were compulsorily entered. That is why my final vote was negative, although I accepted some improvements made in relation to the current situation.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI)
text: Writing. – The Directive on the exchange of information between Member States on favourable tax decisions for enterprises will not restrict the provocative tax privileges of transnational business groups and the immunity of monopolies. The final text limits its initially limited scope to cross-border cases only, extends the time at which the information is exchanged and reduces it to a period of five years before the tax authorities are obliged to disclose their relevant decisions. As the directive itself acknowledges, decisions by national tax authorities granting all kinds of tax privileges and exemptions to large groups are 'legitimate', in accordance with their national legislation. The ultimate law of every capitalist state and every urban government is to protect with its legislation capitalist property and capital gains. The very nature of the EU, based on the freedom of movement of capital, legitimises and serves the tax immunity of business groups, for which the EU institutions hypocritically and provocatively shed crocodile tears. Peoples can live without monopolies and without exploitation when they decide to put an end to their power, taking into their own hands the wealth they produce.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of amending Directive 2011/16/EU is to include the automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation. In this regard, it is intended to be established an administrative cooperation between the Tax Authorities of the Member States with regard to the mandatory automatic exchange of information on prior cross-border tax agreements and advance transfer pricing agreements. We do not agree with the justification that the need for mandatory automatic exchange is essentially justified in order to promote the proper functioning of the single market. Nevertheless, we consider the objective to be positive and we have therefore voted in favour.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving the management of the implementation of the Artemis Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year as there is no significant irregularity in the evaluation.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against granting the discharge on the implementation of the joint venture budget ARTEMIS for the 2013 financial year.  Indeed, this joint venture, set up in 2007 with the aim of defining and implementing a research programme for the development of technologies essential for computer systems, has been subject to some criticism, notably those of the European Court of Auditors, which has expressed doubts about the transparency of its funding.  While points have been improved since the first report, others persist. In particular, the European Court questions the legality and regularity of these transactions. In addition, we have seen a very slow pace of payments with a 69% post-fiscal correction rate of 69%.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote concerns the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL), formerly known as Artemis, funded in part by the EU, Member States and industrialists. The purpose of the vote was threefold: 1. "give discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year"; 2. Approve and validate the company's accounts; 3. comment on the management and strategy of the company.  The company funds research projects in the field of new technologies. Since the first discharge report, several aspects have been corrected or improved. Nevertheless, two elements still pose a real problem: on the one hand, the pace of payments and, on the other hand, the fact that the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of transactions. I therefore objected to the granting of discharge and to Parliament's motion for a resolution, which lacks firmness.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against discharge as I fundamentally disagree with the way that the money has been spent.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour, as advocated by the relevant committee on the merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of ecsel assurance, the Joint Undertaking has made good progress in implementing an action plan to remedy the weaknesses identified by the Court. In addition to the national funding authorities, the company's ex-post audit strategy has been improved, a specific audit reporting format has been introduced and a more systematic quality assessment of these audits has been carried out. At the same time, information on the requirements of the financial programmes and best practices was exchanged. Policies for the management and prevention of conflicts of interest have also been improved and a comprehensive database has been set up covering all information relating to conflicts of interest and actions taken to resolve them. As ARTEMIS and ENIAC no longer exist separately, any recommendations relating to improvements to audit procedures will have to be implemented by the already new ECSEL Joint Undertaking, so it is important to give it time and discharge.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Parliament postponed on 29 April its decision to grant discharge to the director of the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year and called for measures to be taken to rectify the errors identified. In particular, the European Parliament had noted that Artemis had not complied with the discharge authority's 2014 recommendations and had not adopted a clear policy for the prevention and management of conflicts of interest. On the basis of the report provided by the Director of Artemis on 25 June 2015, the Committee on Budgetary Control decided that improvements had been made, for example, ex post audits and audit strategies, or progress in the management of insurance provided by national funding authorities. So I voted in favour of discharge.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report by Mr Czarnecki aims to grant discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis. Founded in 2007, ARTEMIS is a joint venture - a project with EU funding and private sector funding - with the aim of defining and implementing a research programme for the development of technologies essential for embedded it systems in several application areas. However, there are many questions about the operation of this company: not only is the pace of implementation of payment credits, after the budgetary correction, only 69%, but also, like ENIAC, another joint venture with which ARTEMIS merged in 2014, irregularities have already been found by the Court of Auditors, particularly in terms of transparency. , particularly with regard to the audit strategies of national financial authorities. That is why, in view of these strong presumptions, it was impossible for me to vote in favour of this discharge, and I therefore objected to it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with the positions taken in the Czarnecki report. I have therefore chosen not to vote in favour of the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After not obtaining the approval of the management of its accounts in April, Artemis has achieved this in this Plenary after the new information provided and the appearance of its director before the Committee on Budgetary Control. On this occasion, however, as the report adopted in Parliament, to which I have given my support, the Court of Auditors found that the 2013 annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking faithfully present their financial situation as of 31 December 2013 and the results of their operations and cash flows at the end of the year. It also finds improvements in audit systems, with the Court directly receiving additional information from the national financial authorities from which 95% of the subsidies granted to the undertaking come, as well as progress in the implementation of the action plan aimed at resolving the deficiencies found by the Court. It also points out that the company developed a new methodology for calculating the residual error rate, similar to that used by the Commission's jointly managed financing services, with the residual error rate below 1%.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it grants Parliament discharge in 2013 the implementation of the 2013 budget for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. For the ten-year period 2007, the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established to define and implement a research agenda for the development of key technologies related to embedded computing systems in various fields of application, in order to promote the union's competitiveness and sustainability and to facilitate the emergence of new markets and the use of technologies for the benefit of society.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure, the commission decided to grant the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking assessed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, strengthened the application of conflict of interest rules and transparency, and revised its internal control systems. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget is a normal procedure, both in private companies and in public institutions, where this task is carried out by elected officials.  The rapporteur noted that the proposed corrections were thus taken into account in the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking, following the recommendations of the Discharge European Parliament.  The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 for a period of 10 years with a view to defining and implementing a research programme for the development of key technologies for embedded computing systems in different fields of application, with the aim of improving European competitiveness and sustainability in the design of new markets and social applications.  On the basis of the findings of the Court of Auditors of the EU, which gave a positive assessment of ARTEMIS's financial performance, a report was prepared, which I was happy to support.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking has used the funds allocated for its operation, for the year 2013, in accordance with the provisions and in compliance with the budgetary rules.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Artemis joint venture, like all joint initiatives, is a project that has been funded by both the private sector and the European Union. Established in 2007, Artemis was to develop a research programme for the development of new technologies for computer systems in order to increase the competitiveness of EU Member States. The European Parliament had already postponed the discharge for the 2013 financial year because of irregularities that the Court of Auditors had found. The report states that the joint venture had done what was necessary to regularize their situation. However, the Court of Auditors has reservations and is not in a position to rule on the legality of the transactions carried out. This is why the Commission will be assessing Artemis' activities since its inception as part of the 2014 landfill. In this context, the interest of financing this project with European taxpayers' money seems to me to be very slim. So I voted against granting the discharge.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The budget report for the 2013 financial year of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking shall summarise its financial situation by 31 December 2013, presenting both the results of its operations and the cash flows in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules.  However, I cannot fail to be concerned about the Court of Auditors' reservations about the legality and regularity of subsidiary transactions in the annual accounts, given that the Joint Undertaking has failed to assess whether the ex post audit strategy is a sufficiently valid instrument to ensure the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.  In response to the Court of Auditors' reservations, the Joint Undertaking presented an action plan presenting measures to remedy the deficiencies identified, which is why I was in favour of the discharge report for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, in the belief that these inaccuracies would be resolved as a result of the action plan.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against granting discharge for ARTEMIS.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.  This company was established to strengthen the Union's competitiveness through a research agenda on the development of technologies essential to it systems embedded in various fields of application. Subsequently, ARTEMIS merged with ENIAC to create the joint technology initiative "Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership" (ITC ECSEL), which started its activity in June 2014 for the next decade. The annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 appear to be the result of fair financial and budgetary management. Internal control systems have also achieved effective results. That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This discharge was a second report in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. I voted in favour of this procedure as it was a mere formality and no significant irregularity had been detected.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I was concerned with the budgetary and financial management as well as the internal audit which were not carried out according to the expected standard.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote against granting discharge because, although ARTEMIS has tried to improve its situation, I am opposed to the proliferation of joint ventures.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, having regard to the final annual accounts of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, having regard to the second report of the Committee on Budgetary Control, grants discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking with regard to the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision approving the closure of the artemis joint undertaking accounts for the financial year 2013 and granting discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.  With regard to financial and treasury management and the control system, the Court of Auditors did not see any problematic aspects. The Joint Undertaking shall adopt as required the rules on the prevention and management of conflicts of interest and transparency. There is a high productivity of search results together with compliance with the discipline on the protection and transfer of research results.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Ryszard Czarnecki on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. This enterprise was established in December 2007 for a period of 10 years in order to define and implement a "research agenda" for the development of technologies essential for IT systems; the aim is to strengthen the Union's competitiveness and sustainability and to allow the emergence of new markets and new social applications.  Following the line of the group, I supported my colleague's report which, in view of the final annual accounts, calls for the company's accounts to be closed.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 with the aim of defining and implementing a "research agenda" for the development of key technologies for computer systems embedded in various fields of application, in order to strengthen the Union's competitiveness and sustainability and allow the emergence of new markets and new social applications.  The annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 faithfully present, in all material respects, its financial position at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended that date, in accordance with the provisions of the Financial Regulation of the Joint Undertaking. I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal, which provides for discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has proposed, in the first instance, to postpone the granting of discharge to the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. It is therefore now a question of voting for the final granting or otherwise of discharge.  Discharge was not granted because the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, had issued a judgment with reservations. ARTEMIS has therefore made progress in implementing the action plan to address the shortcomings identified by the Court by implementing the practical arrangements for ex-post audits in relation to administrative agreements signed with national financing authorities (AFN). Furthermore, as a result of the merger with the ENIAC Joint Undertaking, ENIAC's general policy on conflict of interest prevention and management now also applies to the joint venture and the disaster recovery plan for the Joint Undertaking's shared IT infrastructure has been approved. The report therefore calls on Parliament to vote in favour of granting discharge. Although ARTEMIS has tried to improve its situation, in order to show its disagreement with the proliferation of joint ventures, I think it is appropriate to vote against granting discharge.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving the management of the implementation of the Artemis Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year as there is no significant irregularity in the evaluation.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking assessed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, strengthened the application of conflict of interest rules and transparency, and revised its internal control systems. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. That is why I supported the granting of the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting discharge to ARTEMIS because based on a report provided to CONT which showed that improvements have been made including in the ex—post audits and audit strategies, the progress in managing the assurances provided by National Funding Authorities as well as on development of new methodology for residual error rate estimation. I fully support such accountability measures and I feel confident in giving my support to this discharge now that the requested changes have taken place.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the granting of discharge for the 2013 budget year to the artemis joint venture, following an initial refusal by the European Parliament at the April 2015 session. This refusal was based on reservations from the Court of Auditors, which found that Artemis had not complied with the recommendations made by the discharge authority in 2014 and had not adopted a comprehensive policy of prevention and management of conflicts of interest.  In June 2015, the joint venture presented a new report to the European Parliament on progress. After review, Parliament considers that the progress in the management of insurance provided by national funding authorities and in the development of a new method of estimating the residual error rate is satisfactory.  In support of the conclusions of this report, I voted to grant the 2013 discharge.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of granting the discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year. The Court of Auditors found that the financial situation of the joint venture Artemis was faithfully represented in its annual accounts for the 2013 financial year.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the normal discharge procedure, and the commission decided to grant the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking assessed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, strengthened the application of conflict of interest rules and transparency, and revised its internal control systems. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This second report concerned the discharge on the execution of the company's budget, or joint Artemis initiative, created in 2007 and developing on-board electronic systems. While the other initiative with which it has merged, Eniac, is already being challenged in problems of transparency in its internal budgetary functioning, it seems necessary to put into perspective the relevance of this funding in view of its low added value. Concerned about the rational use of public funding in general, particularly when it does not seem relevant, I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the information provided on the financial figures does not justify the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure, the commission decided to grant the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking assessed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, strengthened the application of conflict of interest rules and transparency, and revised its internal control systems. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 for a 10-year period with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research programme' for the development of key technologies in the field of IT systems incorporated in different areas of application in order to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union and enable the emergence of new markets and social applications. Contributions to the Company were EUR 181 454 844 by the Union and EUR 341 842 261 by the Member States, corresponding to a level of 1.88. The 23 national funding entities that shared information on their audit strategies account for 95% of all grants awarded. The guarantees provided by the national systems have been positively assessed in the countries representing 54 % of the grants granted, while the assessments for other countries are at an advanced stage of implementation, resulting in grant coverage of 84 %. The Company developed a new methodology for calculating the residual error rate, with the first assessment based on the 157 audited transactions resulting in a result of 0.73%, while a recent update based on 331 transactions resulted in 0.66%, below the materiality threshold of 2%. I approved the report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 for a 10-year period with the aim of defining and implementing a "research programme" for the development of key technologies in the field of IT systems incorporated into different areas of application, "in order to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the EU and enable the emergence of new markets and social applications". With the ENIAC and ARTEMIS Joint Undertakings merged and launched in June 2014, they have set up the joint technology initiative in the field of "Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership" (ECSEL), which will operate for ten years. The Court of Auditors stated that the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for 2013 accurately reflected its financial situation as at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulation. That is why we are following the rapporteur's positive opinion on discharge. The Commission shall carry out an assessment of the activity of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking until the date of the establishment of the ECSEL Joint Technology Initiative, as provided for in Council Regulation (EC) No 74/2008 on the establishment of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The replies provided by the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ENIAC Joint Undertaking) were considered to be satisfactory so I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this report is a 2013 discharge for ARTEMIS.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the discharge report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the proposal on the implementation of the artemis joint venture budget for the financial year 2013. The information provided on the financial figures does not justify the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking and does not cover the gaps identified in the corresponding previous one which came to the vote in plenary on 31 March 2015.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. Following a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was voted by a large majority.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. The Joint Technology Initiative ARTEMIS (Advanced Research and Technology for Embedded Intelligence and Systems) supports research on the subject of the "invisible computer". This includes so-called "embedded" computer systems, which are used to operate other machines. I voted against the discharge because I believe that industry itself can finance such projects. This does not require a 'common EU company', financed from taxpayers' money.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for 2013.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this call for more money to be wasted on more failing IT projects.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I have voted to grant discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors, including, importantly, the introduction of new ex—post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting the discharge to ARTEMIS today as this report recently submitted to the CONT Committee, shows that shortcomings from previous years have been addressed and that EU funds have been spent in a transparent manner. Therefore, it had my support today.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This second report concerns the discharge of the 2013 EU budget of the Artemis Joint Undertaking, which carries out a research programme for the development of key computing technologies and recently merged with ENIAC. The evaluation is positive, although it barely employed 69% of the expected resources, but technical implementation was not significantly affected. The Joint Undertaking has had positive results in terms of job creation and patent production. As there are no re-worthy irregularities on the accountability side, being a routine procedure, we voted in favour.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted, alongside my colleagues in the EPLP, to grant discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors including, importantly, the introduction of new ex post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, as it grants Parliament discharge in respect of the implementation of the 2013 budget for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. In my opinion, the purpose of this undertaking is to define and implement a research agenda for the development of key technologies related to embedded computing systems in various fields of application, in order to promote the union's competitiveness and sustainability and to enable the emergence of new markets and the use of technologies in the public interest.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided to grant the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking assessed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, strengthened the application of conflict of interest rules and transparency, and revised its internal control systems. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report granting the discharge as the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking assists in the crucial development of key technologies for embedded computing systems across different application areas in order to strengthen EU competiveness and sustainability and to allow for the emergence of new markets and societal applications.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided to grant the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking assessed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, strengthened the application of conflict of interest rules and transparency, and revised its internal control systems. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the second resolution report for the implementation of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year, as the annual accounts are orderly and in accordance with financial rules, while the basic transactions are legal and regular.  Progress in implementing the action plan was also identified and a new methodology was developed to assess the residual error rate. In my view, it is of significant importance to establish an Internal Audit Department that contributes to a fair budgetary business. In addition, conflict of interest procedures and the principle of transparency have been improved, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the company Artemis, financed by the EU budget, the private sector and the Member States.  Improvements are desirable, particularly in the rate of payments. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the company's operations.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times of the contributions that the Union make. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. I and my fellow UKIP MEP’s cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. The Artemis company followed the recommendations of the European Parliament and the Court of Auditors to improve auditing and avoid conflicts of interest in the company. I therefore voted in favour of this report granting it discharge.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. Although the resolutions set out the problems quite clearly, the decision taken on the basis of the problems is incomprehensible. For my part, therefore, it is not possible for me to adopt it in a positive way.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to grant the discharge, as the organisation has taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was created in order to strengthen the Union's competitiveness and sustainability and enable the emergence of new markets and new social applications.  I have chosen to vote in favour of the discharge of ARTEMIS because the Court of Auditors has stated that the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 faithfully present artemis' financial position at 31 December 2013. Furthermore, following the merger of the artemis and eniac joint ventures, I agree with the Commission's decision to carry out an assessment of the artemis joint venture's activities until the date of the creation of ITC ECSEL.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to grant discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis (which is a computer systems development company) for the 2013 financial year.  However, while some contentious issues have been improved since the first discharge, other problems persist, such as the legality and regularity of transactions, as noted by the Court of Auditors or the very slow pace of payments. I have therefore decided to vote against this report, which I think is far too lenient.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA cannot give the green light to the discharge of individual parts of the European budget until the full accounts have been approved by the European Court of Auditors.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving the management of the implementation of the Artemis Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year as there is no significant irregularity in the evaluation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 for a period of 10 years to identify and implement research programmes for the development of key technologies embedded in computer systems. The ultimate objective is to increase the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union and create new markets.   I supported the resolution for the implementation of ARTEMIS's budget for the 2013 financial year, as the European Parliament's decision to grant the sentence was taken on the basis of a decision of the Court of Auditors. The Court of Auditors acknowledged progress in the implementation of the action plan by ARTEMIS, in particular in the area of internal surveillance systems, monitoring and reporting on the protection, dissemination and transfer of research results and prevention of conflicts of interest.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting against the Second Report on the discharge in respect of the implementation of the artemis joint venture budget for the financial year 2013 because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this discharge grant. Created in 2007, Artemis is to define and implement a research program for the development of technologies needed for embedded computer systems in various application areas.  Artemis' discharge had already been postponed by the European Parliament in the previous vote because of various irregularities noted by the Court of Auditors, in terms of transparency, guarantees and methods for estimating errors. Artemis promised to correct these errors. However, the Court of Auditors still expresses doubts about the regularity and legality of the transactions underlying the annual accounts. It also notes a very slow pace of payments.  In these circumstances, we oppose the granting of this discharge.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to grant the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking discharge in respect of the implementation of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking’s budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the final annual accounts of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 and having regard to the Court of Auditors' report on the annual accounts of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, Together with the replies of the Joint Undertaking, Parliament approved the closure of artemis' accounts for the financial year 2013 by granting discharge to the Executive Director of ECSEL for the implementation of artemis' financial statements for the financial year 2013. For these reasons, I voted in favour of discharge in respect of the implementation of artemis' budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors, in its declaration for the financial year 2013, certified the legality and regularity of the artemis joint venture's operations. In view of previous assessments and statements attesting to the reliability of the company, I voted in favour of the report granting discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report describes the problems well, but it is not clear which decision should be made on the basis of this description. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Parliament's budgetary discharge power should enable it to enforce the budgetary commitments made by all European institutions and agencies. However, both the Commission and the Council take almost no account of Parliament's votes, including when it refuses discharge. It is a symptom of the democratic impotence of Parliament in the Union.  The discharge on the joint venture ARTEMIS was adjourned last April due to deficiencies in the conflict of interest prevention procedure. The company has now provided assurances on this point. But since the 2013 budget was once again implemented in a particularly chaotic manner, any discharge given for this exercise is problematic.  Indeed, in that year, the Commission and the Council managed to set aside and defer 1 billion surpluses while the Union had accumulated 20 billion unpaid. This savage application of austerity is unacceptable and absurd. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. There is talk of the discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the company Artemis, financed by the EU budget, the private sector and the Member States. Important points remain to be improved, particularly regarding the pace of payments. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the company's operations. Therefore, I am voting against granting discharge. With regard to the motion for a resolution, I am voting against it, considering the report too lenient.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report and the rapporteur’s conclusions to support the discharge, as progress has been made in implementing the action plan aimed at remedying the deficiencies identified by the Court of Auditors.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the Discharge Report The European Parliament grants discharge to the Executive Director of the current ECSEL Joint Undertaking, established in 2014, for the implementation of the budget of the former ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking, established in 2007 for 10 years, for the financial year 2013. This is research into the development of key technologies for embedded computer systems to strengthen the Union's competitiveness. Following the Court's approval of the accounts and the fulfilment by the national authorities of the conditions for the co-financing of an undertaking, Parliament notes that sufficient assurance has been given as to the legality and regularity of the operations carried out by the undertakings.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting discharge for 2013 to the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU budget supports the implementation of a number of policies and programmes. In accordance with the priorities set out by the European Parliament and the Council in the MFIN, the Commission shall provide technical support to specialised agencies for the implementation of specific programmes, activities and projects.  The Brussels-based ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was set up in 2007 by Council Regulation (EC) No 74/2008 for a period of 10 years. Its main objective is to implement a joint technology initiative for embedded computing systems.  The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking has submitted its final annual accounts for the financial year 2013. For the financial year 2013, the European Court of Auditors certified in a statement the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. In its recommendation of 17 February 2015, the Council in favour of the discharge for the Joint Undertaking on the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013. Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control recommended that parliament grant discharge for the implementation of the ARTEMIS joint venture budget for the financial year 2013. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. ARTEMIS was established in December 2007 for a 10-year period with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research programme' for the development of key technologies in the field of IT systems incorporated in different areas of application in order to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union and enable the emergence of new markets and social applications. In June 2014, ENIAC and ARTEMIS were merged to create the joint technology initiative in the field of 'Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership' (ECSEL) over the ten-year operating period. Given that the Court of Auditors has stated that Artemis' annual accounts for 2013 reflect exactly, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2013 and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with its financial regulation, this report deserves my vote in favour. I believe that all the institutions of the European Union must be transparent and fully accountable to citizens in relation to the funds granted to them as Union institutions.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to grant discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis (which is a computer systems development company) for the 2013 financial year. However, while some contentious issues have been improved since the first discharge, other problems persist, such as the legality and regularity of transactions, as noted by the Court of Auditors, or the very slow pace of payments. I have therefore decided to vote against this report, which I think is far too lenient.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted to grant discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors, including, importantly, the introduction of new ex post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which authorizes the 2013 budget discharge for the joint venture Artemis. Last April, this discharge was adjourned because the Court of Auditors had not obtained reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the company's annual accounts.  The report submitted in September to report on the measures taken to better implement Artemis' budget gave satisfaction to the discharge authorities. As a result, the Committee on Budgetary Control recommended granting this discharge.  The budgetary discharge, which can be granted, postponed or refused by the European Parliament, constitutes the final control of the annual budget. This process represents the political component of budget implementation control. It is based on the reports of the Court of Auditors and on the clarifications provided by the agencies concerned. The discharge decision may be accompanied by recommendations to improve certain aspects of budget implementation.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for his report that will further support ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking (‘the Joint Undertaking’) which was initially set up in December 2007 for a period of 10 years to define and implement a ‘Research Agenda’ for the development of key technologies for embedded computing systems across different application areas in order to strengthen Union competitiveness and sustainability and to allow for the emergence of new markets and societal applications.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in 2007 for a period of 10 years to define and implement a 'research agenda' for the development of key technologies for integrated IT systems in different application sectors. The aim of ARTEMIS is to strengthen competitiveness and sustainability within the Union and to facilitate the emergence of new markets and applications in society. In 2014, ARTEMIS and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking merged with a view to the creation of the joint technology initiative 'Electronic Components and Systems for a Leadership of Europe' (ECSEL), whose work will continue for 10 years. The total financial contributions from the Member States of ARTEMIS should be at least 1,8 times the Financial Contribution of the Union and the contribution in kind of research and development organisations participating in projects during the duration of the Joint Undertaking shall be equal to or greater than the contribution of the public authorities. As Vice-President of the Committee on Budgetary Control and as S&D Coordinator for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I support the granting of discharge for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE)
text: in writing. – The two dossiers (ENIAC and ARTEMIS) for discharge 2013 were considered jointly in the Committee on Budgetary control since in 2014 ARTEMIS and ENIAC have been merged into one agency- ECSEL JU. However, the Court of Auditors (CoA) has risen up particular shortcomings of the two. First of all, the CoA issued a qualified opinion for the third consecutive year questioning the ex post audit strategy with respect to the legality and regularity of the transactions of the ENIAC JU. Furthermore, it criticized ARTEMIS JU on failing to respect the 2014 recommendations of the discharge authority and did not adopt a comprehensive policy for the prevention and management of conflicts of interests.  Considering all that, the European Parliament postponed the grant of discharge 2013 of the agencies on the 29th April 2015 and required a new more detailed report. After measuring the progress in the latter, including the new methodology for residual error rate estimation, a discharge was finally given. However, in my opinion, we need to finance fewer but bigger priorities keeping in mind efficiency and results. Europe does not like useless projects. This should be taken into account by MS, but by institutions as well.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report and the associated discharge, as the company's problems are set out quite clearly. However, the next steps are not clearly comprehensible, so there is a lack of convincing ideas for troubleshooting.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. This is the discharge.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times the contributions that the Union makes. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States’ contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for his work, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since artemis' annual accounts for 2013 were found to correspond to the company's real business for 2013 and the financial situation of the company at the end of the 2013 financial year, and given the importance of this company for research and development of technological initiatives, I support the 2013 start-up for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.  In this regard, I welcome the ECA's report on budget and finance management for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking, assessing the positive efforts made by the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking following our initial conditional opinion to address the shortcomings we observed as progress in implementing the action plan, as well as a new methodology for assessing the error rate developed by the company to counter errors in auditing finances.  I welcome the establishment of the Internal Audit Committee, as well as a database covering all data that may be related to conflicts of interest. Taking into account the decision taken to merge the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking with the ENIAC Joint Undertaking into a joint technological initiative for the electronic components and systems for Europe's leadership, I consider it of utmost importance that the business operations of the undertakings in the period preceding the merger are transparent, especially in financial terms and that there are no doubts of a conflict of interest.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to grant discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis (which is a computer systems development company) for the 2013 financial year. However, while some contentious issues have been improved since the first discharge, other problems persist, such as the legality and regularity of transactions, as noted by the Court of Auditors, or the very slow pace of payments.  I have therefore decided to vote against this report, which I think is far too lenient.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 to identify and implement research programmes for the development of key technologies for embedded computer systems in various areas of application, and started its own work in October 2009. Artemis and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking were subsequently merged to create a joint technology initiative for electronic components and Systems for Europe's leadership (ECSEL).  The Joint Undertaking has made progress in implementing an action plan aimed at correcting the shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors in its conditional opinion, with guarantees from national systems positively assessed for countries representing 54 % of the grants awarded, in particular progress on ex-post and audit strategies, cooperation with national funding authorities and the development of a new methodology for assessing the residual error rate.  A comprehensive conflict of interest prevention policy was also promised. The average of 211.5 publications and 16.6 patents for every €10 000 000 of Union grants demonstrates the high productivity of the results of the joint undertaking survey and its compliance with all the requirements expressed so far by the coordinators of the Seventh Framework Programme, which is why I support the allocation of the release.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support REPRESENTATIVE Ryszard Czarnerk's report on the implementation of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year, whereas the Court stated in its report on the agency's annual accounts for the 2013 financial year that the financial documentation for 2013 represents its financial situation as of December 31, 2013, and that the results of its operations and cash flows for the end of the year are in line with the provisions of its financial rules.  Based on the audit conclusions, it was confirmed that practical ex-post audit mechanisms have been put in place in relation to the administrative agreements it has signed with national funding authorities. At the same time, I welcome the fact that the Court of Auditors, precisely to supplement the information obtained by the Joint Undertaking, has worked with national funding authorities to express its opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions on which the accounts are based.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In April this year, the European Parliament proposed postponing the budgetary discharge for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking due to insufficient ex post audit measures. It made the additional discharge subject to the introduction of a number of measures, including ex post audit measures concerning administrative agreements signed with national funding bodies, which include the introduction of a specific reporting form and are complemented by an evaluation of national guarantee schemes by the Joint Undertaking and visits by the Court of Auditors to national funding bodies. In addition, the Court received verified information directly from participating Member States. In addition, the Joint Undertaking has developed a new methodology for estimating the residual error rate, with an error rate of around 0,7 % well below the generally tolerated rate of 2 %. During 2014, the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was merged with another EU ENIAC joint venture to create a joint technology initiative for electronic components and systems for Europe's leadership (ECSEL). As shadow rapporteur for the 2014 joint venture discharge, I am therefore continuously following developments in both enterprises (ARTEMIS and the incoming ECSEL). Within the Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of the discharge in the context of the changes implemented, just as I supported it in the October plenary session.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking has made the necessary progress to remedy the shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors. The procedure was closed following the statement of the reliability, legality and regularity of the relevant transactions, submitted by the Court of Auditors, with regard to the annual balance sheet of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. I am voting in favour of granting discharge for the financial year 2013.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the publication of the new report of the Court of Auditors on the joint venture Artemis, I voted in favour of the discharge relating to the implementation of the budget for the 2013 financial year. The recent report provides sufficient evidence of the legality and regularity of Artemis' accounts.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By giving discharge to an institution or agency, the European Parliament approves the proper use of the public money in budgetary implementation, achieved in compliance with regulations. Upon a recommendation from the Council, Members of the European Parliament are called upon to exercise control over the management of appropriations by deciding on discharge on the basis of the Court of Auditors' reports. Thus, and after evaluating the reports of the Court of Auditors and the Parliamentary Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of this Decision, which gives discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Artemis was set up in 2007 for a period of 10 years, the total funding over 10 years is worth EUR 2.5 billion.  The purpose of this project is to set up embedded computer systems across different areas of application with the intention to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability across Member States.  There is a call for the contributions from the Member States to be at least 1.8 times the contributions that the Union makes. The Union contribution for 2013 equates to EUR 181 454 844 and the Member States contribution amounts to EUR 341 842 261. We cannot support this given that there is pressure on the Member States to support this programme, and that competitiveness should be left to the markets.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. After not obtaining the approval of the management of its accounts in April, Artemis has achieved this in this Plenary after the new information provided and the appearance of its director before the Committee on Budgetary Control. On this occasion, however, as the report adopted in Parliament, to which I have given my support, the Court of Auditors found that the 2013 annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking faithfully present their financial situation as of 31 December 2013 and the results of their operations and cash flows at the end of the year. It also finds improvements in audit systems, with the Court directly receiving additional information from the national financial authorities from which 95% of the subsidies granted to the undertaking come, as well as progress in the implementation of the action plan aimed at resolving the deficiencies found by the Court. It also points out that the company developed a new methodology for calculating the residual error rate, similar to that used by the Commission's jointly managed financing services, with the residual error rate below 1%.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. After analysing the accounts, I note that the rate of implementation of payment credits after the year-end budget correction was 69%. According to the joint venture, part of the explanation comes from delays in issuing payment certificates by national funding authorities. I would also like to recall the report of the Court of Auditors which states that the annual accounts of the joint venture for the 2013 financial year faithfully presented, in all their significant aspects, the financial situation of the joint venture as of 31 December 2013. The same applies to the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended that date. For all these reasons, I have decided to vote in favour of the 2nd Czarnecki report and to give discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to grant discharge to the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year. Last April, the joint venture Artemis was denied the granting of the discharge for 2013 due to the lack of a comprehensive policy for the prevention and management of conflicts of interest. Since then, Artemis has submitted a report to Parliament out of the progress made. In view of Artemis' decision to commit to reforms in its policy of prevention and management of conflicts of interest, I voted in favour of granting discharge.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report as I agree with the European Parliament in approving the closure of the artemis joint venture accounts and granting discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of artemis' budget for 2013.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This second report concerns the discharge of the 2013 EU budget of the Artemis Joint Undertaking, which carries out a research programme for the development of key computing technologies and recently merged with ENIAC. The evaluation is positive, although it barely employed 69% of the expected resources, but technical implementation was not significantly affected. The Joint Undertaking has had positive results in terms of job creation and patent production. As there are no re-worthy irregularities on the accountability side, being a routine procedure, we voted in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving the management of the implementation of the Artemis Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year as there is no significant irregularity in the evaluation.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it is spending vast amounts of UK taxpayers’ money, and this should be decided in the UK Parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted to grant discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings; this one, ARTEMIS, has taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in accordance with the principle that discharge for any part of the EU budget should only follow after the EU budget as a whole has received a favourable opinion from the European Court of Auditors.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
