text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution granting discharge for 2013 to the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. This undertaking was established in December 2007 for a period of 10 years to define and implement a research plan on the development of key technologies for embedded computer systems in different fields of use, in order to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union and allow for the emergence of new markets and societal applications. The Joint Undertaking became operational on its own in October 2009. The total financial contribution of the Member States of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking should be at least 1,8 times the Union financial contribution and the in-kind contribution of the research and development organisations participating in projects which will be equal to or greater than the contribution of public authorities during the duration of the Joint Undertaking. The Court stated that the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for 2013 faithfully reflects, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2013 and the results of its operations and cash flow are in line with the provisions of its Financial Regulation.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament deals annually with the legality, regularity and effectiveness of the implementation of the budget of the European institutions, agencies, joint undertakings and other EU services in the budget discharge procedure.  The CONT Committee and then the Members of the April plenary session postponed the granting of discharge for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking in respect of the 2013 budget, as for the third year in a row (i.e. for 2011, 2012 and 2013) the Court of Auditors issued a reservation opinion on the legality and regularity of transactions. In the meantime, Parliament has received new information on improvements in this Joint Undertaking, which, as early as 2014, after joining ENIAC in the ECSLE Joint Undertaking, actively launched its action plan to address the shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors and Parliament in previous years, as well as a new ex-post audit strategy and an improved procurement system. This is certainly the reason why I supported the discharge report for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking in the vote, but I would like to stress that the company must continue to work hard to improve the shortcomings identified. It is not enough that the implementation of the budget is purely legal and correct, and it is increasingly important that prudent spending achieves long-term positive effects on the economy, society and the environment.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the creation of enterprises that aim to research in the development of key technologies. Such joint ventures will help us strengthen the Competitiveness and Sustainability of the Union and enable the penetration of new markets and the creation of new societal applications.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of granting discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors, including, importantly, the introduction of new ex-post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account, inter alia, the Council's recommendation of 17 February 2015 on the resolution to be obtained by the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013- and its own Decision of 29 April 2015 on the postponement of the Decision on the Release for the Financial Year 2013, as well as the replies of the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking), the European Parliament shall, in its report, give a statement to the Executive Director of ecsel Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the ARTEMIS Joint Budget for the financial year 2013 and approves the closure of the closure of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 and approves the closure of the artemis business books for the same financial year.   Furthermore, the European Parliament notes that the Commission will carry out an evaluation to assess artemis activity by the date of the establishment of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking. I fully support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ given that the European Union budget contains an unacceptable number of errors year after year, and as a result the European Court of Auditors could not confirm its effective use, I voted against this discharge.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2013 discharge for the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking. The Court of Auditors' report showed that the company adequately demonstrated its financial situation, including operating results and all cash flows in 2013. I also welcome the commitment by the Artemis Joint Undertaking to address the shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors in its reservation opinion and for the Court of Auditors to supplement the information provided by the Joint Undertaking by the national funding bodies.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this discharge and will not vote in favour of the discharges for any part of the EU budget until the budget as a whole receives a positive statement of assurance from the Court of Auditors. However the ARTEMIS joint undertaking is a beneficial programme for scientists across the EU and should continue to be funded at an EU level.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the information provided on the financial figures does not justify the discharge of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recommends granting discharge to the Director of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.  With this text, the Parliament recognizes that the ARTEMIS JU has taken the necessary steps requested to redress the shortcomings the Parliament Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) identified, particular, the fact that ARTEMIS JU failed to respect the 2014 recommendations of the discharge authority, by not adopting a comprehensive policy for the prevention and management of conflict of interests.  However, following the revised report submitted by the Director of ARTEMIS to CONT, on June 2015, the  committee decided that improvements have been made, i.e. in the ex post audits and audit strategies, the progress in managing the assurances provided by National Funding Authorities as well as on development of new methodology for residual error rate estimation.  I agree with the Committee’s decision to grant discharge to ARTEMIS, and therefore I voted in favour of the report in plenary.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the discharge text. The result of a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was voted on by a large majority.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, regarding an analysis of the accounts of the Artemis Joint Undertaking and comprising two decisions and a resolution on it. The first decision seeks to grant discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking in respect of the implementation of the budget of the Artemis Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. The second aims at the approval of the closure of Artemis’s accounts. Thirdly, with respect to the implementation of the budget, the resolution provides observations on budgetary and financial management, internal control systems, prevention and management of conflicts of interests and transparency and monitoring and reporting of research results. The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was set up in December 2007 for a period of 10 years to define and implement a ‘Research Agenda’ for the development of key technologies for embedded computing systems across different application areas in order to strengthen EU competitiveness and sustainability.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the Budget of the Artemis Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 because, in the View of the Court of Auditors, the Joint Undertaking adequately showed its financial position, operating results and cash flows as at 31 December 2013.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This second report concerns the discharge of the 2013 EU budget of the Artemis Joint Undertaking, which carries out a research programme for the development of key computing technologies and recently merged with ENIAC. The evaluation is positive, although it barely employed 69% of the expected resources, but technical implementation was not significantly affected. The Joint Undertaking has had positive results in terms of job creation and patent production. As there are no re-worthy irregularities on the accountability side, being a routine procedure, we voted in favour.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Court considers that the Joint Undertaking's 2013 annual accounts reflect, in all material respects and in accordance with the provisions of the Joint Undertaking's Financial Regulation, the financial situation of 31 December 2013 and the outcome of the economic and cash events that took place by the end of the year. That is why I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This second report concerns the discharge of the 2013 EU budget of the Artemis Joint Undertaking, which carries out a research programme for the development of key computing technologies and recently merged with ENIAC. The evaluation is positive, although it barely employed 69% of the expected resources, but technical implementation was not significantly affected. The Joint Undertaking has had positive results in terms of job creation and patent production. As there are no re-worthy irregularities on the accountability side, being a routine procedure, we voted in favour.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Parliament decision of 27 October 2015 on the discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. The resolution addresses the Budgetary and Financial Management, internal control systems, prevention and management of conflicts of interests and transparency and monitoring and reporting of research results. These decisions are necessary to provide adequate monitoring and transparency of the work and its outcomes.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a matter that was postponed during last April's plenary meeting when Parliament observed that the Artemis Joint Undertaking had failed to follow certain 2014 recommendations from the authority responsible for approving management and had not adopted a comprehensive policy on the management and prevention of conflicts of interest. A report on the progress made since the first report was deposited in June. On that basis, the rapporteur states in his report that the progress made has been positive and is therefore in favour of approving artemis's management. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against the decision to grant discharge to the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking: the Court of Auditors, in its report on the company's annual accounts, issued a judgment with reservations. The Court was unable to assess whether ex-post audits provided sufficient guarantees as to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, i.e. the information available on the application of the Joint Undertaking's ex post audit strategy was not sufficient for the Court to determine whether this key control worked effectively.  Here, too, we are faced with inefficient control systems and, although the new ECSEL-JU joint venture in which ARTEMIS merged has improved the control systems, I think it is appropriate, with my vote, to emphasise that controls must not in any way be undermined by suspicion. The expenditure of public money absolutely must be clear and transparent: if there is any doubt, then we must be more assiduous and rigorously vigilant there.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving the management of the implementation of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking budget for the 2013 financial year as there is no significant irregularity in the evaluation.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking (hereinafter referred to as the Joint Undertaking) was established in December 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research programme' for the development of key technologies in the field of IT systems incorporated in different areas of application in order to strengthen the competitiveness and sustainability of the Union and allow the emergence of new markets and social applications , having started operating autonomously in October 2009. According to the Joint Undertaking, and in accordance with the Staff Regulations and implementing rules, the CVs and declarations of interest of the Executive Director and managers of the Joint Undertaking have been published on its website. A database has also been set up bringing together all identified information on conflicts of interest and measures taken in this context, which is regularly maintained.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report describes the problems well, but it is not clear which decision should be made on the basis of this description. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking, set up in 2007, aims to strengthen and strengthen the Union's competitiveness in the field of sustainability and technology and has played a decisive role in the development of key technologies for embedded IT systems in various fields of application. A further step forward was taken with the merger of ARTEMIS and ENIAC to establish the joint technology initiative "Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership" (ITC ECSEL), whose activity was launched in 2014. Supporting the action of the two joint ventures is essential to support the European Union's research and development activity as well as to provide the necessary tools to ensure the emergence of new markets and new social applications. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the discharge for the implementation of the Artemis Joint Undertaking budget for the financial year 2013. As the budget has not yet received a positive assurance from the Court of Auditors, I reject this draft report. One of the main problems was the retrospective review of the administrative arrangements and the remaining error rate.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking was established in December 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research programme' for the development of key technologies in the field of IT systems incorporated into different areas of application. As the ENIAC and ARTEMIS Joint Undertakings were merged and launched in June 2014, they have set up the joint technology initiative in the field of 'Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership' (ECSEL), which will operate for ten years. The Court of Auditors stated that the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for 2013 accurately reflected its financial situation as at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulation. We voted in favour of discharge.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving management in the implementation of the 2013 budget of the Institute of Innovation and Technology. However, I would like to point out that it is necessary not to overlook certain aspects which are improveable in my view, which have to do mainly with the quality of the certificates issued, or with a number of delays in the delivery of documents demanded by Parliament. We therefore want these small anomalies to be corrected in the evaluation of future budgets.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against granting the discharge on the implementation of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology's budget for the 2013 financial year. While the institute has made progress in training employees, improving its planning and monitoring procedures for budget implementation, and public procurement procedures, the Court of Auditors says for the second year in a row that it has received no reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of subsidy transactions. We can also note the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff. In addition, the question of the results and the added value of this institute may arise.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote gives a discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to support technological innovation in research, education and the economy, and thus promote economic growth and promote competitiveness. However, in this area, as in so many others, the European Union has failed: relocations, mass unemployment, deindustrialization, etc. Other important points remain to be corrected, including the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the institute's operations.  I therefore opposed the granting of discharge and voted against Parliament's report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against discharge as I fundamentally disagree with the way that the money has been spent.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for it as the committee recommended on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to grant discharge in respect of the 2013 budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. As the Institute has improved the instructions given to auditors and in June 2013, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. provided updated instructions to knowledge and innovation communities, the institute's grant beneficiaries and improved its procurement procedures and prepared a procurement manual, and I support its discharge.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. On 29 April, the European Parliament postponed its decision to grant discharge to the director of the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year and called for measures to be taken to correct the errors identified, notably in the area of subsidies and public procurement. The rapporteur points out that the institute has significantly improved its procurement procedures since 2013 and that no errors were found in 2014. It notes that the EIT has taken steps to reduce the high turnover of staff and that the Commission's internal audit department has noted a series of improvements in grant management. I therefore supported the granting of the discharge for the 2013 financial year.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to the granting of the discharge for the 2013 budget year for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. The first report on this institute, which is supposed to support technological innovation in research, education and economics, had already been pointed out about the opacity of the company's subsidy operations. While the rapporteur states that there has been progress in the training of employees or in the procedures for planning and monitoring budget implementation, the Court of Auditors remains concerned, having received no assurance or reasonable evidence regarding the legality and regularity of subsidy operations. Indeed, it should be noted that audit certificates are currently issued by firms hired by the direct beneficiaries of these grants, which would cover at least 87% of grant expenditures. These disturbing practices therefore prevented any vote in favour of granting discharges.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas for the second year running the Court of Auditors considers the quality of the certification of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology to be compromised, since it was issued by audit firms chosen by the beneficiaries of the grants themselves, I did not intend to endorse discharge to the EIT with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After not obtaining the discharge of its accounts in April, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology has achieved the discharge in this House following the new information provided and the appearance of its director before the Committee on Budgetary Control. On this occasion, however, as set out in the report adopted in Parliament, to which I have given my support, Parliament notes that there have been improvements in ex post audit verification systems, as well as in public procurement procedures, and that a proactive attitude has been taken following the detection of errors by the Court of Auditors. It also highlights the adoption of a methodology for grant agreements equal to that of the rest of the Horizon 2020 framework programme programmes, which are reasons, interwise, for approval.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it grants Parliament discharge in respect of the implementation of the 2013 budget to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. In its accompanying observations, Parliament notes that the improved instructions have helped to improve the quality of audit certificates received as a result of the 2013 grant operations for which payments were made in 2014. Parliament notes, on the basis of the information provided by the Institute, that, since 2013, The Institute has improved its procurement procedures and has taken an active response when the Court of Auditors found errors.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the normal discharge procedure, the commission decided to grant discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. In fact, the EU Agency has managed the problems identified in the first discharge report on the merits according to the commission's assessment, reviewed its procurement procedures and implemented 18 of the 25-point action plan. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the EIT in plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I also supported the discharge of the Budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for 2013.  As regards the Institute's financial performance, the Court of Auditors of the EU has in the past found certain inconsistencies in grant transactions, which were subsequently corrected. The Institute has ensured better quality of audit reports, more appropriate certification methods and ex-post verifications for grant transactions in order to ensure the legality and regularity of transactions.  In addition, the Institute also provided for the improvement of public procurement procedures and carried out a review of its internal procedures in accordance with public procurement rules. The Institute's internal audit service also provided the Institute with due regard for its recommendations. It follows from the foregoing that the Institute has responded appropriately to the comments of the control institutions, so that discharge is the only correct solution.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) has used the funds allocated for its operation, for the year 2013, in accordance with the provisions and in compliance with the budgetary rules.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology is supposed to promote the competitiveness of EU Member States by supporting innovation and research. Despite serious improvements in employee training and compliance with public procurement procedures, the Court of Auditors says for the second year in a row that it is unable to rule on the legality and regularity of transactions that affect 87% of subsidy expenditure. Audit certificates are issued by independent firms.  In this context, the interest of financing this project with European taxpayers' money seems to me to be very slim. So I voted against granting the discharge.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The budget report for the 2013 financial year of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) presents its financial situation in a comprehensive manner by 31 December 2013, presenting both the results of its operations and cash flows in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules. Following the Court of Auditors' report, reasonable assurances were obtained as to the reliability of the Institute's annual accounts, but, similar to the situation of the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking, insufficient audit evidence could be obtained as to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. However, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology provided improved instructions to the auditors responsible for certification in June 2013, also communicating instructions to knowledge and innovation communities, beneficiaries of the Institute's grants. As a result, there is an improvement in the level of insurance obtained. I conclude by pointing out that the Institute's efforts during the 2013 financial year generated a budget implementation rate of 96.97 % and that the implementation rate of payments in relation to payment appropriations was 96.86 %, which is why I voted in favour of the report on discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against the measure granting discharge for the EIT: the Court of Auditors itself considers the quality of certification to be compromised as it is issued by independent audit firms entrusted by the beneficiaries of the grants.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, as the Court of Auditors has attested in its statement to the reliability, legality and regularity of the reporting operations carried out by the Institute.  In fact, since the 2014 grant agreements, the Institute has used the same audit certification methodology as all other programmes covered by the Horizon 2020 Framework Programme. In addition, the Authority has introduced additional ex post audits for grant operations, as a second level of guarantee of their legality and regularity, carrying out "on-the-ground" audits of about 40% of the disbursements provided for in the 2013 agreements. On the basis of the sound financial management of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, I have chosen to vote in favour of discharge in respect of the implementation of its budget.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This Discharge was a second report in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. I voted in favour this procedure as it is a mere formality and no significant irregularity has been detected.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree with granting discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology has managed successfully to present its accounts clearly as well as improve many of its procedures relating to monitoring and planning of budget implementation procedures.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote against granting discharge because, although the EIT has tried to improve its situation, I am opposed to the proliferation of joint ventures.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, having regard to the final annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013 and having regard to the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control, grants discharge to the Director of the EIT with regard to the implementation of the Institute's budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a decision approving the closure of the accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013 and granting discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the implementation of the Institute's budget for the financial year 2013. Progress has been made in the ex-post verification system, procurement procedures and financial and monetary management; progress that would lead to the omit certain shortcomings highlighted by the Court of Auditors in its report on the financial year 2013.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Czarnecki on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. Since 2013, the Institute has improved its procurement procedures, and in 2010 it cancelled the two framework contracts; it also reviewed internal procedures, circuits and models in order to fully adapt to the relevant public procurement rules, paying particular attention to sound planning and needs assessment. In the final analysis, the Institute took on additional procurement functioning in 2015 and carried out a series of training on the subject for its staff. These points lead me, in line with my group, to vote in favour of the 2013 discharge of the EIT.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors' report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the financial year 2013 shows that it is unable to obtain a reasonable guarantee for the second consecutive year on the legality and regularity of grant transactions. However, the recent improvements in the EIT in terms of planning and control for the implementation of the budget lead me to vote in favour of this proposal, which provides for discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has proposed, in the first instance, to postpone the granting of discharge to the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. It is therefore now a question of voting for the final granting or otherwise of discharge.  Discharge was not granted because the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, found that it had not obtained a reasonable guarantee for the second consecutive year of the legality and regularity of grant transactions. In addition, the Court considered the quality of certification to be compromised as it, which accounted for around 87% of grant expenditure, had been issued by independent audit firms entrusted by the beneficiaries of the grants themselves.  The Institute introduced additional ex post audits for grant operations, as a second level of guarantee of the legality and regularity of grant transactions, and carried out "on-the-ground" audits to cover approximately 40% of grants under the 2013 grant agreements. The report therefore calls on Parliament to vote in favour of granting discharge. I prefer to vote against it in order to show my disagreement with the proliferation of agencies.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving management in the implementation of the 2013 budget of the Institute of Innovation and Technology. However, I would like to point out that it is necessary not to overlook certain aspects which are improveable in my view, which have to do mainly with the quality of the certificates issued, or with a number of delays in the delivery of documents demanded by Parliament. We therefore want these small anomalies to be corrected in the evaluation of future budgets.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the normal discharge procedure, the commission decided to grant discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT), based in Budapest. The EU Agency has assessed the issues identified in the first discharge report on its merits, reviewed its procurement procedures and implemented 18 of the 25-point action plan. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. At the plenary session of the European Parliament, I supported the granting of the exemption of the EIT.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EIT has a vital importance in terms of delivering the goals of EU’s policies to promote Technology and Innovation. EIT management has shown the clear improvement in their shortcomings including the inclusion of complementary ex-ante verifications for grant expenditure and also improvements in the vacancy management. Considering that the required amendments were made and the identified shortcomings were addressed I voted in favour of the discharge for the European Institute for Innovation and Technology.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the granting of discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 budget year, following an initial refusal by the European Parliament at the April 2015 session. Parliament had pointed to an error rate on expenditure above the acceptable threshold, resulting from audit problems and significant errors affecting public procurement. The quality of ex ante and ex post audits was also considered insufficient.  In June 2015, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology presented a new report to Parliament on progress. After review, Parliament considers that progress in ex-ante and ex post audits, procurement procedures and obtaining audit certificates is satisfactory.  In support of the conclusions of this report, I voted in favour of granting the 2013 discharge.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of granting discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology on the implementation of the Institute's budget for the 2013 financial year. This decision was justified in particular by the improvement of the planning and monitoring procedures for budget implementation.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the normal discharge procedure, and the commission decided to grant discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. In fact, the EU Agency has managed the problems identified in the first discharge report on the merits according to the commission's assessment, reviewed its procurement procedures and implemented 18 of the 25-point action plan. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the EIT in plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report concerned the discharge on the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to promote growth and promote competitiveness. This joint initiative, which for the second year in a row has been denied the confidence of the Court of Auditors in the regularity of grant operations, raises the question of the relevance of this funding. Concerned about the reasoned use of public funding in general, particularly when these have been explicitly questioned by the Court of Auditors, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 My fundamental position relating to the discharge of any part of the budget is also covered by that of my ECR group, namely that it should not be given until the budget as a whole receives a positive assessment from the Court of Auditors.  In this case, the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, found for the second year in a row insufficient assurance on the legality and regularity of grant-related transactions.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the information provided on economic figures does not justify the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the normal discharge procedure, the commission decided to grant discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. In fact, the EU Agency has managed the problems identified in the first discharge report on the merits according to the commission's assessment, reviewed its procurement procedures and implemented 18 of the 25-point action plan. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the EIT in plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, considered, for the second consecutive year, that it did not have sufficient guarantees as to the legality and regularity of the operations relating to grants and added that the quality of the certificates, which cover about 87 % of subsidy expenditure , was compromised by the fact that they were issued by independent audit firms contracted by grant beneficiaries. However, it is also true that the Office carried out on-the-spot audits covering around 40 % of the grants paid under the 2013 grant agreements, and these audits resulted in a recovery of EUR 263 239, with a total audited amount of EUR 29 163 272. The Office has improved its procurement procedures since 2013 and adopted a proactive approach following the Court's error-in-law.  I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, considered, for the second consecutive year, that it did not have sufficient guarantees as to the legality and regularity of the operations relating to grants. According to the Court, the quality of certificates, which cover about 87% of subsidy expenditure, was compromised by the fact that they were issued by independent audit firms contracted by grant beneficiaries; recalls, furthermore, that in order to address the gaps related to the quality of audit certificates, the Office improved the instructions provided to the auditors responsible for certification and forwarded the updated instructions to the 'Knowledge and Innovation Communities' (KICs), recipients of the Institute's grants, in June 2013. According to the Office's information, it has improved its procurement procedures since 2013 and adopted a proactive approach after the Court's finding of errors, in particular by terminating the two framework contracts concluded in 2010 and 2012, in which recourse to the procedure for negotiation was considered irregular, by revising its procedures, circuits and internal models. We have followed the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as no significant irregularity has been detected.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this report is the 2013 discharge for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the discharge report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, as it is incomplete in implementing the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013. The information provided on economic figures does not justify the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) has a vital importance in terms of delivering the goals of the EU’s policies to promote technology and innovation. EIT management has shown a clear improvement in their shortcomings. This report aims  at redressing the identified shortcomings in the discharge to the Director of the EIT for the financial year 2013. I welcome the many improvements of the EIT’S report that make it possible for us to endorse the discharge, such as the newly introduced complementary ex-ante verifications for grant expenditure, which added a second layer of assurance on the legality and regularity of grant transactions; the redesigned procurement procedures since 2013 with a proactive approach towards the detection of errors; the obtainment of the audit certificates on the costs of EIT’s beneficiaries; and the review of the portfolio of beneficiaries’ complementary activities.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report 'Discharge 2013: European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT)' today because I consider the taxpayers' money spent on this to be too high and call for greater industry involvement through third-party funding. I also propose that the Institute, together with a European University, be accommodated in the buildings of the European Parliament in Brussels as soon as Parliament has opted for the only sensible and contractually acceptable 'single seat' in Strasbourg.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for 2013.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against a call for more staff and more money for a bureaucracy that wants more powers over our nation.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I have voted to grant EIT discharge as it has shown significant progress including a comprehensive revision of the internal procedures and rules to fully comply with public procurement legislation, increased capacity and more staff training. It has also put in place a staff appraisal and re-classification system to provide a better career perspective to EIT staff and reduce turnover.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The granting of the discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) was today approved by a large majority. I supported the discharge as improvements to identified shortcomings were made, for example, a revision of internal procedures and extra employee training.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the 2013 budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. The results are encouraging: the European Institute of Innovation and Technology has been able, through the audit, to improve the instructions given to auditors, as well as the quality of audit certificates. The institute carried out field audits recovering EUR 263 239 and improved its procurement procedures.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 financial year. Approval is supported without mentioning a few comments. These refer to the quality of certificates issued; a series of reporting delays; high labour turnover due to job precariousness was also observed, although this poor indicator has recently moderated.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted with my colleagues in the EPLP to grant EIT discharge as it has shown significant progress, including a comprehensive revision of the internal procedures and rules to fully comply with public procurement legislation, increased capacity and more staff training. It has also put in place a staff appraisal and re-classification system to provide a better career perspective to EIT staff and reduce turnover.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. The Institute, among others, implemented the following actions: developing a vade mecum on procurement which includes checklists for different procurement procedures and specific contracts under framework contracts, and requiring the procurement function to verify all requests for service before requesting an offer, which provides an additional layer of control.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided to grant the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. In fact, the EU Agency has managed the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, reviewed its procurement procedures and implemented 18 of the 25-point action plan, according to the commission's assessment. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the EIT in plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report in order to help address the shortcomings related to the quality of audit certificates which were previously compromised as they were issued by independent audit firms contracted by the grant beneficiaries. This report will also help correct previous problems identified by the analysis of staff exit interviews which highlighted a lack of clear career perspective, a difficult working environment and an unattractive salary package which led to a high turnover of staff. This will help strengthen middle management.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided to grant the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. In fact, the EU Agency has managed the problems identified in the first discharge report on the merits according to the commission's assessment, reviewed its procurement procedures and implemented 18 of the 25-point action plan. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the EIT in plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the second resolution report for the implementation of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology budget for the 2013 financial year, as the planning and monitoring procedures for budget implementation were improved. Accordingly, public procurement procedures were improved and no irregularities were found and a fundamental review of internal procedures was carried out.  It also increased the quality of audit certificates obtained for those grant transactions in 2013, for which final payments were made in 2014.  The budgetary and financial management of the Institute has been lawfully and properly done, and I believe that the statement will allow for the smooth continuation of work.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to support technological innovation in research, education and economics.  Improvements are desirable, particularly with regard to the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the institute's operations.  I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. I and fellow MEPs are unable to support this this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the EIT had already been postponed by the European Parliament. This report provides discharge following significant improvements made by the Institute in its budget and procedures.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. Although the resolutions set out the problems quite clearly, the decision taken on the basis of the problems is incomprehensible. A positive adoption is therefore not possible for me

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to grant EIT discharge as it has shown significant progress including a comprehensive revision of the internal procedures and rules to fully comply with public procurement legislation, increased capacity and more staff training.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The report emphasises that, starting with the 2014 grant contracts, the Institute uses the same audit verification methodology as all other horizon 2020 programmes. The use of a more detailed and consistent verification methodology has further improved the level achieved during ex ante checks. The report is admissible in view of the Court's statement of assurance of the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2013 and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the Court of Auditors' report, which stressed that it had not obtained reasonable guarantees for the second year running on the legality and regularity of grant transactions for the financial year 2013, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) has shown that it has made improvements with regard to the planning and control procedures related to budgetary implementation. In addition, the link between planned activities and resource allocation has been strengthened, connecting the annual work programme with the annual budget. The institute's efforts therefore lead me to support the report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this Czarnecki report is to grant the discharge for the 2013 budget year for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to support technological innovation in the fields of research, education and economics.  As with the joint venture Artemis, there have been some improvements. However, others, such as the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff, persist. Moreover, the reluctance of the Court of Auditors on the question of the legality and regularity of certain operations has motivated my opposition to this text.  So I voted against it.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA cannot give the green light to the discharge of individual parts of the European budget until the full accounts have been approved by the European Court of Auditors.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving management in the implementation of the 2013 budget of the Institute of Innovation and Technology. However, I would like to point out that it is necessary not to overlook certain aspects which are improveable in my view, which have to do mainly with the quality of the certificates issued, or with a number of delays in the delivery of documents demanded by Parliament. We therefore want these small anomalies to be corrected in the evaluation of future budgets.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This text collects and approves the 2013 management of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology. It recognizes an improvement in audit certificates by employing a more detailed and coherent certification methodology, which has increased the reliability of the results obtained, which now follow the same methodology as the other Horizon 2020 programme programmes.  There is an improvement in planning and control related to the implementation of the budget as well as the absorption capacity of the first set of knowledge and innovation communities (JRCs) for the period 2010-2014. There is also an effort on the part of the Institute to alleviate the high turnover of staff and recognizes the commission's internal audit service (UPS) visit in December 2014 to investigate progress in the implementation of open recommendations.  For all these reasons, I am in favour of this Resolution.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament approved the implementation of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology budget for the 2013 financial year on the basis of a report by the Court of Auditors. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) supports technological innovation in research, education and business with a view to promoting sustainable economic development and competitiveness in Europe. While the Court found insufficient quality of audit certificates supported, the implementation of the EIT budget for the 2013 financial year alone due to the improvement of the process by the Institute. Among other things, public procurement and internal audit were improved, better transaction checks were introduced, the Institute's portfolio was audited and the planning and monitoring process for budget implementation improved.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the Second Report on discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. The Institute is expected to support technological innovation in research, education and economics.  Its objective is to promote economic growth and promote competitiveness. Its discharge had been postponed by the European Parliament in the previous vote and, according to the report, the Institute has made progress in terms of employee training, in public procurement procedures and in its procedures for planning and monitoring budget implementation.  However, for the second year in a row, the Court of Auditors states that it has not obtained reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of subsidy transactions. In these circumstances, we oppose the granting of this discharge.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology discharge in respect of the implementation of the Institute’s budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the statement of assurance of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the related transactions submitted by the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013, in accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and in view of the Court of Auditors' report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, together with the Institute's replies, I considered it appropriate to vote in favour of closing the accounts of the European Institute for the financial year 2013 by granting discharge to the Director of the European Institute innovation and technology for the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Due to the positive assessment expressed by the Court of Auditors in its report on the use of the budget allocated to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report describes the problems well, but it is not clear which decision should be made on the basis of this description. That is why I abstained from voting

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Parliament's budgetary discharge power should enable it to enforce the budgetary commitments made by all European institutions and agencies. However, both the Commission and the Council take almost no account of Parliament's votes, including when it refuses discharge. It is a symptom of the democratic impotence of Parliament in the EU. The discharge on the joint venture european Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) was postponed last April due to the lack of reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of the Institute's grant operations. The company has now met these requirements, but the 2013 budget has once again been executed in a particularly chaotic manner, any discharge given for this exercise is problematic. Indeed, in that year, the Commission and the Council managed to set aside and defer 1 billion surpluses while the EU had accumulated 20 billion unpaid. This savage application of austerity is unacceptable and absurd. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. There is talk of the discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to support technological innovation in research, education and economics. Important points remain to be improved, including the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the institute's operations. Therefore, the Member votes against granting the discharge. Regarding the motion for a resolution, the Member voted against it, considering the report too lenient.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the granting of a discharge as the rapporteur and Committee on Budgetary Control concluded that enough progress has been made by the European Institute of Innovation and Technology to address Parliament’s concerns regarding audit issues and material procurement errors.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing ‒ the European Parliament grants discharge to the Director of the EIT on the basis of the report in respect of the implementation of the Institute's budget for the financial year 2013, but Parliament made its remarks in the resolution before forwarding the decision. In 2013, for the second year in a row, the EIT did not certify before the Court a report on the legality and regularity of the Institute's grant operations. I am therefore pleased that the quality of the Institute's audit certificates has improved after 2014, following instructions from the Court of Auditors. The EIT has improved budget implementation procedures and introduced additional controls for grant operations to ensure a higher degree of certainty on legality and regularity. On the basis of the conditions and instructions issued by the Court of Auditors, Parliament approved the EIT's accounts for the financial year 2013 and granted discharge.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The EIT has a vital importance in terms of delivering the goals of EU’s policies to promote technology and innovation. EIT management has shown a clear improvement in their shortcomings. Therefore, I voted in favour of granting discharge for 2013 to European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT).

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU budget supports the implementation of a number of policies and programmes. In accordance with the priorities set out by the European Parliament and the Council in the MFIN, the Commission shall provide technical support to specialised agencies for the implementation of specific programmes, activities and projects. The Budapest-based EIT was established by Regulation No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council. The Institute aims to contribute to sustainable Economic Growth in Europe and to improving European competitiveness by increasing the innovation capacity of the Member States and the EU.  The EIT has submitted its final annual accounts for the financial year 2013. For the financial year 2013, the European Court of Auditors certified in a statement the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. In its recommendation of 17 February 2015, the Council in favour of granting discharge to the Institute for the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013. Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control recommended that parliament grant discharge for the implementation of the EIT budget for the financial year 2013. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, considered, for the second consecutive year, that it did not have sufficient guarantees as to the legality and regularity of grant operations, this report lists the recommendations and procedures accepted by the European Institute of Innovation and Technology to comply with the procedures relating to budgetary implementation. I believe that all the institutions of the European Union must be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union in relation to the funds granted to them as Union institutions. As set out in the report, I approve the closure of the accounts for the 2013 financial year of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this Czarnecki report is to grant the discharge for the 2013 budget year for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to support technological innovation in the fields of research, education and economics. As with the joint venture Artemis, there have been some improvements. However, others, such as the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff, persist. Moreover, the reluctance of the Court of Auditors on the question of the legality and regularity of certain operations has motivated my opposition to this text. So I voted against it.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted to grant EIT discharge as it has shown significant progress including a comprehensive revision of the internal procedures and rules to fully comply with public procurement legislation, increased capacity and more staff training. It has also put in place a staff appraisal and re-classification system to provide a better career perspective to EIT staff and reduce turnover.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which authorises the 2013 budget discharge for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT). Last April, this discharge was adjourned because, for the second year in a row, the Court of Auditors had not obtained reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of the institute's grant operations. The report also highlighted irregularities in contracting procedures. Since the adjournment of the discharge, the EIT has presented a new strategy and has shown a real willingness to dialogue with the European Parliament.  The report he submitted to report on the measures taken to better implement his budget gave satisfaction to the discharge authorities. As a result, the Committee on Budgetary Control recommended that the accounts be closed. The budgetary discharge, which can be granted, postponed or refused by the European Parliament, constitutes the final control of the annual budget. This process represents the political component of budget implementation control. It is based on the reports of the Court of Auditors and on the clarifications provided by the agencies concerned. The discharge decision may be accompanied by recommendations to improve certain aspects of budget implementation.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the 2013 discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology that starting from 2014 uses the same audit certificate methodology as all other programmes under the Horizon 2020 framework programme.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE)
text: in writing. – On the 29 April, the European Parliament decided to postpone his grant for discharge for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the year 2013 due to numerous shortcomings in the reporting and fulfilment of budget obligations.  Among the most serious shortcomings the rapporteur highlights the combined error rate regarding the audit issues and material procurement errors (between 2% and 3% of total 2013 expenditure, which is above the materiality threshold of 2%), the insufficient quality of ex- ante and ex-post verifications, irregular public procurement procedures etc. Consequently, the European Parliament required a more detailed report considering the problematic issues. The latter was provided to the Committee on Budgetary control (CONT) on the 29th June. The newly introduced complementary report already included serious progress on the ex-ante verifications for grant expenditure, redesigned procurement procedures since 2013 with a proactive approach towards the detection of errors etc. The collaboration of the EIT agency and willingness to improve were taken into account by CONT and the second report already supported the grant of discharge. This is a clear sign how work between institutions should be simplified and intensified. Europe should use its budget focusing on results, integrity and producing higher returns.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report and the associated discharge, as the Institute does indeed produce positive results for the European scientific landscape. At the same time, too uncritical waste of funds is being dealt with here too.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Although the motion for a resolution draws attention to a number of parameters in the EIT's accounts, including the subject of the audit, it is considered that previous recommendations have generally been taken into account and the situation has improved, such as follow-up audits and internal reviews.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I take note of the financial situation and the status of the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology and I welcome the improvements that have been made. I am voting in favour without hesitation.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ How it was found that the annual accounts for 2013 correspond to the real business of the Institute for 2013 and the financial condition of the Institute at the end of the financial year 2013, and given the importance of this company for research and development of technological initiatives, I support the 2013 start-up for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.  In this regard, I welcome the COURT's report on budget and finance management for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology and assess the positive efforts made by the European Institute of Innovation and Technology to maintain quality in research and to achieve the objectives set. I also believe that the European Institute of Innovation and Technology needs to be a leader in innovation and new technologies, so that the EU can be competitive in all areas due to the growing challenges that are occurring both in Europe and in the world.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The purpose of this Czarnecki report is to grant the discharge for the 2013 budget year for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, which is supposed to support technological innovation in the fields of research, education and economics. As with the joint venture Artemis, some points have improved, but others, such as the low budget implementation rate due to the very high turnover of staff, persist. Moreover, the reluctance of the Court of Auditors on the question of the legality and regularity of certain operations has motivated my opposition to this text. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Institute of Innovation and Technology is one of the European Union's most important bodies in the field of achieving the objectives of promoting technology and innovation, so it is of utmost importance that significant progress is observed in their operations in view of the EcA's 2013 report.  Following the found insufficient quality of audit certificates, our guidance to the Institute resulted in a significant increase in the quality of audit certificates obtained for grant-related transactions in 2013, introduced a more detailed and consistent methodology for audit certificates, and for the purpose of further assurance on the legality and regularity of grant transactions, the Institute introduced additional ex-post checks on these transactions.  In addition, the Institute carried out a detailed review of its internal procedures and templates and improved budget planning and monitoring procedures, mitigated high staff fluctuations and established a system of evaluation and reclassification. The Commission's Internal Audit Service confirmed further improvements in public procurement procedures and in the annual grant process at the Institute, after which 18 of the 25 actions in the action plan were identified.  The implementation of the remaining seven measures is still ongoing and will, in all likelihood, be successful, which is why I support the issuance of a release.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Parliament's decision to grant a resolution for the implementation of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology budget for the 2013 financial year. As the Court of Auditors found in its report on the annual accounts of the Institute that it lacked the quality of audit certificates for around 87 % of grant expenditure, the Institute introduced additional ex-post checks on grant transactions in order to obtain further assurance as to the legality and regularity of those transactions.  In order to address shortcomings in the quality of audit certificates, the Institute improved the guidance to the auditors issuing certificates, resulting in a significant increase in the quality of audit certificates obtained for grant-related transactions. Also, the Institute has improved its procurement procedures and adopted a more active approach. On the basis of such public procurement procedures, no irregularities were observed in 2014. At the same time, the process of planning and overseeing the implementation of the budget has also been improved, which prescribes a more rigorous verification of all proposed measures.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report, which I voted in favour of already within the Committee on Budgetary Control. The European Institute of Innovation and Technology has been through a difficult period in recent years and a number of serious errors have been found in its management, which is why the European Parliament decided in April this year to postpone the discharge, with proposals for concrete improvements expected in the identified areas. This postponement was made in the knowledge that during 2014 there were a number of significant improvements, in particular in terms of public procurement procedures, major changes in the monitoring and control methodologies, i.e. the current economic situation was already significantly better in April than what the 2013 analyses showed. The European Parliament has therefore decided, after considering additional information and analysing the real situation at the Institute, to grant discharge, including a list of conditions and measures that led to improvements in 2014 and in the spirit of which the Institute's work continues.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) has achieved in its budgetary operations the legality, accuracy and soundness objectives necessary to receive discharge for the financial year 2013. The Court of Auditors of the EU presented, in accordance with Article 287 TFEU, a detailed report on the EIT accounts. This annual report does not detect any irregularities that are noteworthy. That is why I welcome the granting of discharge for the financial year 2013 of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.
