name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In April 2015, the Court of Auditors expressed doubts about the legality and regularity of EIT's subsidy operations, particularly in relation to contracting procedures. However, the EIT has put in place a new strategy that provides for more regular and rigorous implementation of the budget. In this new context, the European Parliament has approved the discharge on the implementation of the budget for the 2013 financial year.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By giving discharge to an institution or agency, the European Parliament approves the proper use of the public money in budgetary implementation, achieved in compliance with regulations. Upon a recommendation from the Council, Members of the European Parliament are called upon to exercise control over the management of appropriations by deciding on discharge on the basis of the Court of Auditors' reports. Thus, and after the reports of the Court of Auditors and the Parliamentary Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of this Decision, which gives discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the implementation of the Office's budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call to increase staff and financial resources to meet EU political objectives in relation to budget and financial management. Strengthening middle management levels is also a concern in relation to the increase of cost. An initial community budget contribution of EUR 308.7 million has helped launch and will continue to support the EIT for the 2008–2013 periods. We cannot support this due to the fact that it is linked with other innovation EU projects that pursue EU political aims and objectives.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. One of the founding powers of our Parliament is its budgetary power. We approve the budget and ensure that public funds are used properly, including through the budget discharge.  Last April, we postponed the approval of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology's (EIT) spending for 2013, due to questions about the relevance of audits. The EIT had to demonstrate that the verification of its payments and procurement procedures had been improved. We were provided with information on the legality and regularity of grant operations, as well as on improving planning and monitoring procedures for budget implementation. That is why I voted in favour of this text which grants budget discharge for the EIT accounts in 2013.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. After not obtaining the discharge of its accounts in April, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology has achieved the discharge in this House following the new information provided and the appearance of its director before the Committee on Budgetary Control. On this occasion, however, as set out in the report adopted in Parliament, to which I have given my support, Parliament notes that there have been improvements in ex post audit verification systems, as well as in public procurement procedures, and that a proactive attitude has been taken following the detection of errors by the Court of Auditors. It also highlights the adoption of a methodology for grant agreements equal to that of the rest of the Horizon 2020 framework programme programmes, which are reasons, interwise, for approval.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. While it is true that the Court of Auditors stated for the second year in a row in its report that it had not obtained reasonable assurance as to the legality and regularity of grant transactions, it should be noted that the Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) has introduced ex post-additional audits of grant transactions. In addition, we have also received information from the EIT that tends to show that public procurement procedures have improved since 2013. It also appears that the EIT has taken a more proactive approach to the court's response to error detection. Finally, it is clear that the planning and monitoring procedures for the budget implementation of the EIT are better.  For all these reasons, I have decided to vote for the second Czarnecki report, thus granting discharge to the Director of the EIT on the implementation of the budget for the 2013 financial year. It should be noted, however, that I support the comments made on internal audits.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following parliament's decision of 29 April 2015, by which the decision to discharge the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the implementation of the 2013 financial year has been postponed, we see that, after this date, the quality and observance of budgetary and regulatory legislative principles has improved substantially in this Institute. To this much contributed the action of the current Director, as well as the consulting process carried out by the internal audit service, which brought an improvement of procedures that is reflected in the approval of the closure of the accounts of this Institute (for the financial year 2013) by the European Parliament, which had my vote in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. On 29 April, the European Parliament decided to postpone its decision to grant the discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the 2013 financial year. In particular, Parliament had identified some shortcomings concerning problems related to audits and certain errors affecting public procurement.  As a result of these failures, the EIT provided Parliament on 29 June with a new report providing new evidence and some explanations. As a result, new audits have taken place, public procurement procedures have been revised and some improvements in the management of vacancies have been made, among other things.  In view of these new elements, I supported this report which grants the 2013 discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the 2013 discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology as I support the European Parliament's decision to approve the closure of the Institute's accounts and to grant discharge to the Director of the EIT for the implementation of the 2013 budget.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 financial year. Approval is supported without mentioning a few comments. These refer to the quality of certificates issued; a series of reporting delays; high labour turnover due to job precariousness was also observed, although this poor indicator has recently moderated. This procedure is a mere formality and no significant irregularities have been detected on the accounting side, which is what is said here, so there is no reason to vote against it. It's been voted in favour.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving management in the implementation of the 2013 budget of the Institute of Innovation and Technology. However, I would like to point out that it is necessary not to overlook certain aspects which are improveable in my view, which have to do mainly with the quality of the certificates issued, or with a number of delays in the delivery of documents demanded by Parliament. We therefore want these small anomalies to be corrected in the evaluation of future budgets.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it is spending vast amounts of UK taxpayers’ money, and this should be decided in the UK Parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted to grant EIT discharge as it has shown significant progress, including a comprehensive revision of the internal procedures and rules to comply fully with public procurement legislation, increased capacity and more staff training. I has also put in place a staff appraisal and re-classification system to provide a better career perspective to EIT staff and reduce turnover.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in accordance with the principle that discharge for any part of the EU budget should only follow after the EU budget as a whole has received a favourable opinion from the European Court of Auditors.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the Court of Auditors did not find adequate assurance on the legality and regularity of the Institute's grant operations for the second year in a row in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. According to the Court, the quality of good practices is called into question as they were issued by independent audit firms hired by the grant beneficiaries themselves, covering around 87 % of the expenditure on grants. It is therefore good that the Institute has introduced additional ex-post controls for grant operations as a second degree of certainty on the legality and regularity of grant operations. The Institute also carried out 'on-the-spot' audits on around 40 % of the grants paid under the 2013 grant agreements. Since 2013, the Institute has improved its procurement procedures and taken a proactive approach following the court's finding of errors. The Institute has improved planning and monitoring procedures in relation to the implementation of the budget and has taken further necessary measures to improve its management overall. That is also why I voted in favour of the 2013 discharge for that institute.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the activities of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, because innovation and technology are an important part of our economy and only thanks to them can our economy move forward and compete with other world powers.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted to grant EIT discharge as it has shown significant progress including a comprehensive revision of the internal procedures and rules to fully comply with public procurement legislation, increased capacity and more staff training. It has also put in place a staff appraisal and re-classification system to provide a better career perspective to EIT staff and reduce turnover.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the final annual financial statements of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 financial year and the EcA's report on the Annual Financial Statements of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 Financial Year, together with the Institute's replies, the European Parliament shall issue a statement to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the implementation of the Institute's budget for the 2013 Financial Year 2013 and approve the closure of the accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. I fully support this report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2013 discharge for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT). Despite some comments on the legality and regularity of transactions by the Court of Auditors, I am thinking, in particular, of the legality and regularity of the transactions related to grants, we can see that budgetary management and financial management have improved compared to the previous year. Indeed, as the Court has held, the Institute has improved the planning and monitoring of the procedures relating to the implementation of the budget, since those procedures now include a more detailed assessment of all proposed activities with a budgetary impact.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this discharge and will not vote in favour of the discharges for any part of the EU budget until the budget as a whole receives a positive statement of assurance from the Court of Auditors. However, I fully support the work of the European Institute for Innovation and Technology and consider it to be a hugely beneficial programme for helping scientists get their research into the market place.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the information provided on economic figures does not justify the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the adoption of the report and the granting of the 2013 discharge, in the hope that the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (based in Hungary, Budapest), which plays an important role in europe's future economic and scientific development (based in Hungary, Budapest), can continue to operate smoothly in transparent, efficient budgetary-management conditions. I have taken into account the fact that, according to the report, the management of the EIT has effectively remedied the shortcomings previously noted by the European Court of Auditors, and the corrections have improved the efficiency and transparency of management and administrative management over the past year. In particular, according to the report, the Institute's procurement policy has improved considerably, financial management has been tightened, and more purposeful management of personnel and staff has reduced excessive staff turnover. Thus, in view of the strengthening of internal control, there is reason to hope that the above-mentioned expectations for the management of the EIT will also be met with a lasting impact on the current financial year.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recommends granting discharge to the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the financial year 2013.  With this text, the Parliament recognises that the EIT has taken the necessary steps requested to redress the shortcomings the Parliament Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) identified related to the combined error rate on the audit issues and material procurement errors between 2% and 3% of total 2013 expenditure, which is above the materiality threshold of 2%, the insufficient quality of ex ante and ex post verifications as well as irregular public procurement procedures. However, following the progress report published by the EIT on 29 July, 2015, the Committee decided that improvements have been made, i.e. newly introduced complementary ex-ante verifications for grant expenditure, redesigned procurement procedures since 2013 with a proactive approach towards the detection of errors; improved the planning and monitoring procedures related to the budget implementation which include a more rigorous assessment of activities, increased absorption capacity of the first-wave beneficiaries and introduction of additional second wave beneficiaries. The EIT management has shown the clear improvement in the shortcomings identified by CONT, therefore I voted in line with CONT's decision to grant discharge to EIT for 2013.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the discharge text. The result of a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was voted on by a large majority.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of two decisions and a resolution regarding the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) 2013 discharge. The first decision grants the Director of the EIT discharge in respect of the implementation of the Institute’s budget for the financial year 2013. The second approves the closure of EIT’s accounts for the financial year 2013. The resolution provides comments on legality and regularity of EIT’s transactions, on budget and financial management and on internal audit.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, as the Institute, in the opinion of the Court of Auditors, adequately displayed the financial situation, carried out the work in accordance with the laws and instructions and improved the planning and monitoring of procedures relating to the implementation of the budget.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 financial year. Approval is supported without mentioning a few comments. These refer to the quality of certificates issued; a series of reporting delays; high labour turnover due to job precariousness was also observed, although this poor indicator has recently moderated. This procedure is a mere formality and no significant irregularities have been detected on the accounting side, which is what is said here, so there is no reason to vote against it. It's been voted in favour.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In view of the Council recommendation on discharge for the Implementation of the Budget for the Financial Year 2013 for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology and the replies of the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology, I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report deals with the discharge of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the 2013 financial year. Approval is supported without mentioning a few comments. These refer to the quality of certificates issued; a series of reporting delays; high labour turnover due to job precariousness was also observed, although this poor indicator has recently moderated. This procedure is a mere formality and no significant irregularities have been detected on the accounting side, which is what is said here, so there is no reason to vote against it. It's been voted in favour.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision on the discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, and on the decision of the closure of the accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013 because the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, found for the second consecutive year no reasonable assurance on the legality and regularity of the grant transactions and noted that the quality of the certificates was compromised as they were issued by independent audit firms contracted by the grant beneficiaries.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In April 2015, Parliament postponed the decision to approve the management of the Director of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT) for the 2013 financial year, also calling for a report clarifying a number of points on this issue. In June 2015, the European Parliament received a report on the progress made by the EIT since the first report. Following the study of this report, the Committee on Budgetary Control decided to approve management by a large majority. In the view of this decision, I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this matter.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against the decision requesting discharge to the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013: firstly, discharge was not granted because the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the EIT, found that it had not obtained a reasonable guarantee for the second consecutive year of the legality and regularity of grant transactions. In other words, the Court considered the quality of certification to be compromised as it, which accounted for around 87% of grant expenditure, had been issued by independent audit firms entrusted by the beneficiaries of the grants themselves. We are faced with a practice that is unfortunately too widespread in this Union: the controllers are directly dependent on the controlled, and although the EIT is trying to remedy the situation, I believe that my vote against granting discharge should be interpreted as a strong signal against all the obscure managements that dot the European bodies.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of approving management in the implementation of the 2013 budget of the Institute of Innovation and Technology. However, I would like to point out that it is necessary not to overlook certain aspects which are improveable in my view, which have to do mainly with the quality of the certificates issued, or with a number of delays in the delivery of documents demanded by Parliament. We therefore want these small anomalies to be corrected in the evaluation of future budgets.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The funding allocated by the Office to the KICs in the period 2010-2014 did not exceed the ceiling of 25 %, as set out in the framework partnership agreements between the KICs and the Office, and the Office has improved the planning and monitoring of procedures relating to budgetary implementation.  In June 2014, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) published a follow-up audit report on the state of implementation of the action plan resulting from the 'Limited grant management review – Preparation of annual grant agreements'. The IAS closed two of the original six recommendations and another recommendation was reclassified from 'critical' to 'very important'.  In December 2014, in order to analyse the progress made in implementing the open recommendations, the IAS acknowledged that further improvements have been made to the annual grant allocation process and that all detailed actions submitted to the IAS during the visit, whether completed or ongoing or planned, adequately address the risks highlighted in the Restricted IAS review.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report describes the problems well, but it is not clear which decision should be made on the basis of this description. That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Institute of Technological Innovation has implemented the procedures for supervising and programming the budget.  The Institute's decision to take a more rigorous view of all activities whose expenditure exceeds EUR 50 000 is welcomed. The EIT has demonstrated its willingness to implement serious planning of human and financial resource needs in order to plan all its activities in a precise and transparent manner.  Another important element is the ever closer link between planned activities and the allocation of resources, as well as an ever-growing link between the work programme and the budget. In view of the clear improvements in financial and budgetary management, I voted in favour.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the discharge for the implementation of the budget of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013. As long as the Court of Auditors has not reviewed the budget, I am voting against the discharge. For the second year in a row, no reasonable assurance of the legality and regularity of the enterprises could be found.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the European Institute of Innovation and Technology for the financial year 2013, considered, for the second consecutive year, that it did not have sufficient guarantees as to the legality and regularity of the operations relating to grants. According to the Court, the quality of certificates, which cover around 87 % of subsidy expenditure, was compromised by the fact that they were issued by independent audit firms contracted by grant beneficiaries; recalls, furthermore, that in order to address the gaps related to the quality of audit certificates, the Office has improved the instructions provided to the auditors responsible for certification. In June 2014, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) published a follow-up audit report on the state of implementation of the action plan resulting from the 'Limited grant management review – Preparation of annual grant agreements'. The IAS closed two of the original six recommendations and another recommendation was reclassified from 'critical' to 'very important'. In December 2014, in order to analyse the progress made in implementing the open recommendations, the IAS acknowledged that further improvements have been made to the annual grant allocation process. We voted for it.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.    The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.  The Association for European Nanoelectronics Activities (AENEAS) is also involved in a joint undertaking to contribute EUR 30 million. Member States are expected to make a contribution of 1.8 times that of the EU contribution. We cannot support such programmes that clearly put pressure on Member States at a time of severe financial difficulty with other priorities that are far more essential for the citizens of Europe.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This time I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 enIAC Joint Undertaking budget, which was postponed on 29 April. On this occasion, Parliament halted discharge in the implementation of the budget as the CONT Commission asked THE ENIAC Company to submit more elements on its accounts and on the regularity of various transactions.  This extra information was considered satisfactory by the CONT Commission, so I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against granting the discharge on the implementation of the ENIAC joint venture budget for the 2013 financial year. Indeed, this joint venture created in 2007 with the aim of bringing together European research in nanoelectronics has been subject to some criticism, notably those of the European Court of Auditors, which has expressed doubts about the transparency of its funding.  While points have been improved since the first report, others persist. In particular, the European Court questions the legality and regularity of these transactions. In addition, we believe that an evaluation of the company's activities since 2007 is necessary. This will only take place in the context of the 2014 landfill. We can therefore ask ourselves the question of the results and the added value of this joint initiative and the value of its funding in the European budget.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote gives a discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the joint venture ENIAC, financed by the budget of the EU, Member States and private sector actors. This joint venture aims to promote the development of nanoelec electric systems.  The purpose of the vote was threefold: 1. "gives discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the execution of the budget of the joint venture ENIAC for the 2013 financial year"; 2. Approve and validate the company's accounts; 3. comment on the management and strategy of the company.  I believe that the evaluation of ENIAC's activities since 2007 is necessary. Therefore, I voted against the granting of discharge and against the report, which does not go to the bottom of it enough.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against discharge as I fundamentally disagree with the way that the money has been spent.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour, as advocated by the relevant committee on the merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the basis of ecsel assurance, the Joint Undertaking has made good progress in implementing an action plan to remedy the weaknesses identified by the Court. In addition to the national funding authorities, the company's ex-post audit strategy has been improved, a specific audit reporting format has been introduced and a more systematic quality assessment of these audits has been carried out. At the same time, information on the requirements of the financial programmes and best practices was exchanged. Policies for the management and prevention of conflicts of interest have also been improved and a comprehensive database has been set up covering all information relating to conflicts of interest and actions taken to resolve them. As ARTEMIS and ENIAC no longer exist separately, any recommendations relating to improvements to audit procedures will have to be implemented by the already new ECSEL Joint Undertaking, so it is important to give it time and discharge.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.    The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.  The Association for European Nanoelectronics Activities (AENEAS) is also involved in a joint undertaking to contribute EUR 30 million. Member States are expected to make a contribution of 1.8 times that of the EU contribution. We cannot support such programmes that clearly put pressure on Member States at a time of severe financial difficulty with other priorities that are far more essential for the citizens of Europe.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. On 29 April, the European Parliament postponed its decision to grant discharge to the director of the joint venture Artemis for the 2013 financial year and called on him to take measures to rectify the errors identified. On the basis of the report provided to the Committee on Budgetary Control on 25 June 2015, improvements were observed, notably in the prevention and management of conflicts of interest and the monitoring and communication of research results.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Like its colleague ARTEMIS, the joint venture ENIAC suffers from a high level of opacity regarding its audit strategies. ENIAC, which has aimed since its inception in 2007 to bring together European nanoelectronics research, has received 65% of financial contributions from the private sector, while Member States' contribution should not exceed 1.8%. Last April, Parliament had already postponed the discharge for ENIAC because of the concerns raised by the Court of Auditors, in particular regarding irregularities in the methods of estimating the error rate, but also, and above all, about doubts about the regularity and legality of the transactions underlying the annual accounts. It is also telling that the Commission wishes to carry out an assessment of ENIAC's activities, even if it does not take place before the 2014 discharge. In any event, these uncertainties regarding this joint venture, whether they are uncertainties related to its added value and/or its management, have led me to reject the granting of this discharge.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to endorse the discharge to the ENIAC Joint Undertaking because of the reservations expressed by the Court of Auditors on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. After not obtaining the discharge of its accounts in April, the ENIAC Joint Undertaking has achieved this in this Plenary following the new information provided and the appearance of its director before the Committee on Budgetary Control. On this occasion, however, as the report adopted in Parliament, to which I have given my support, it is estimated that the actions carried out by the company have strengthened the independence of audit controls, additional checks carried out by the firm itself have been put in place in the after- and an action plan has been put in place to end the deficiencies identified by the Court of Auditors , so you are granted approval.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it grants Parliament discharge in 2013 to the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. For the ten-year period 2007, the ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up to define and implement a research agenda for the development of key nanoelectronic technologies in various fields of application. The attached comments note that the ARTEMIS joint ventures and ENIAC were merged in 2014 to establish the Interconnection of Electronic Components and Systems (ECSEL JTI) for European leadership, which will continue for 10 years. The observations also note that the European Court of Auditors stated that the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for 2013 correctly presented the financial situation of the Joint Undertaking as at 31 December 2013 and the results of its operations and its cash flows at the end of the year, in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules and the rules adopted by the Accounting Officer of the Commission.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure, and the commission decided to grant the discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking handled the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, according to the commission's assessment, and strengthened the application of the rules on conflicts of interest. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As I pointed out in the previous statement of reasons, granting discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget is a normal procedure, both in private companies and in public institutions, where this task is carried out by elected officials.  The rapporteur also noted compliance with the rules in the 2013 ENIAC Joint Undertaking discharge report, as previously identified by the Court of Auditors of the EU. The company also took due account of the proposals of the supervisory institutions in order to fulfil the conditions for the discharge of the budget.  The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was established in 2007 for a period of 10 years. The purpose of the company was to define and implement a research programme for the development of key competences for nanoelectronics in different fields of application.  In May 2014, ENIAC merged with ARTEMIS into the newly created ECSEL technology platform, which also operates according to the rules. On the basis of the findings of the Court of Auditors of the EU, which gave a positive assessment of ENIAC's financial performance in 2013, a report was prepared, which I was also pleased to support.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the ENIAC Joint Undertaking has used the funds allocated for its operation, for the year 2013, in accordance with the provisions and in compliance with the budgetary rules.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The joint venture ENIAC, like all joint initiatives, is a project that has been financed by both the private sector, the European Union and the Member States (1.8% i.e. the legal limit allowed). Founded in 2007, ENIAC was intended to be at the forefront of research in the nanoelectronics field.  The European Parliament had already postponed the discharge for the 2013 financial year in April because of irregularities that the Court of Auditors had found. The report states that the joint venture had done what was necessary to regularize their situation. However, the Court of Auditors has reservations and is not in a position to rule on the legality of the transactions carried out. This is why the Commission will be evaluating ENIAC's activities since its inception as part of the 2014 landfill. In this context, the interest of financing this project with European taxpayers' money seems to me to be very slim. So I voted against granting discharge.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this Discharge Report 2013: ENIAC Joint Undertaking because this report led to the consolidation of the European Union's accounts for the 2013 financial year, thus helping Member States to manage and develop nanoelectronics. The report shall be based on the consolidated accounts of the European Union for the financial year 2013, a document drawn up on the basis of information provided by the EU institutions, bodies and agencies in accordance with Article 129(2) of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union, including the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. The EU budget is also the funder of a wide range of policies and programmes implemented across the EU, in line with the priorities of the European Parliament and the Council in the Multiannual Financial Framework, with the Commission carrying out programmes, specific activities and projects in this area with the technical support of specialised agencies and also of certain joint ventures. ENIAC's joint tasks aim to establish a jointly agreed research agenda in the field of nanoelectronics, with a view to future studies in the field, for the adoption and development of key competences in this area.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote against granting discharge. The audit procedures, according to the Court of Auditors itself, would not be reliable and truthful.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.  This company was established in 2007 to define and implement a "research agenda" for the development of skills essential for nanoelectronics in various fields of application. Subsequently, ARTEMIS merged with ENIAC to create the joint technology initiative "Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership" (ITC ECSEL), which started its activity in June 2014 for the next decade. The annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 appear to be the result of fair financial and budgetary management. Internal control systems have also achieved effective results.  That is why I have chosen to vote in favour of discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the closure of the ENIAC’s accounts for 2013 and in favour of the resolution. This was a second report in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the approval for the closure of ENIAC’s accounts. Their financial report was presented in a clear manner. Additionally, amongst others the Joint Undertaking managed to fulfil the requirements regarding public and private contributions as outlined in its statute.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought it appropriate to vote against granting discharge because, although ENIAC has tried to improve its situation, I am opposed to the proliferation of joint ventures.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, having regard to the final annual accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 and having regard to the second report of the Committee on Budgetary Control, grants discharge to the Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking with regard to the implementation of the eniaco joint venture budget for the financial year 2013, which we consider to be correct and we vote in favour.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of the measure approving the closure of the accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 and granting discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.  Financial and treasury management does not show any problems. Progress is recognised in the implementation of a plan to remedy the shortcomings of the control system highlighted by the Court of Auditors in its opinion with reservations. It welcomes the high productivity of research results and compliance with the discipline on the protection and transfer of research results.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to grant discharge to the ENIAC Joint Undertaking contained in Mr De Clercq's report. Ryszard Czarnecki. This joint venture merged in 2014 with ARTEMIS to create the joint technology initiative "Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership" which will be operational for a decade. As a group, we have chosen to support the discharge of this company, and that is why I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.    The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was established on 20 December 2007 with the aim of defining and implementing a "research agenda" for the development of skills essential for nanoelectronics in various fields of application.  According to the Court of Auditors, the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 faithfully present, in all material respects, its financial position at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended that date, in accordance with the provisions of the Financial Regulation of the Joint Undertaking and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer. I am therefore voting in favour of this proposal, which provides for discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, with the sole recommendation that effective measures be taken to control the movement of this company, following the merger agreement with artemis joint venture.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has proposed, in the first instance, to postpone the granting of discharge to the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. It is therefore now a question of voting for the final granting or otherwise of discharge.  Discharge had not been granted because the Court of Auditors, in its report on the annual accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, had given a favourable opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts due to the inability to assess whether the ex-post audit strategy, which relies heavily on national financing authorities (NSAs) for the audit of project expenditure statements , provide a sufficient guarantee as to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. The Joint Undertaking has made progress in implementing the action plan to remedy the shortcomings identified by the Court in its judgment subject to reservation, and the report therefore calls on Parliament to vote in favour of granting discharge. Although ENIAC has tried to improve its situation, in order to show its disagreement with the proliferation of joint ventures, I believe it is appropriate to vote against granting discharge.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This time I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 enIAC Joint Undertaking budget, which was postponed on 29 April. On this occasion, Parliament halted discharge in the implementation of the budget as the CONT Commission asked THE ENIAC Company to submit more elements on its accounts and on the regularity of various transactions.  This extra information was considered satisfactory by the CONT Commission, so I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The ENIAC Joint Undertaking has assessed the merits of the problems identified in the first discharge report, and has strengthened the application of the rules on conflicts of interest. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. That is why I supported the granting of the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting discharge to ENIAC following the improvements that ENIAC made including improvements in the ex post audits and audit strategies, the progress in managing the assurances provided by the National Funding Authorities as well as the development of new methodology for residual error rate estimation.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes the granting of discharge for the 2013 budget year to the joint venture ENIAC, following an initial refusal by the European Parliament at the April 2015 session. This decision was based on the opinion of the Court of Auditors, which had issued, for the third year in a row, a reservation questioning the ex post audit strategy relating to the legality and regularity of the operations of the joint venture ENIAC. In June 2015, it presented a report to Parliament on progress. After review, the rapporteur considers that the review of the framework for ex-post audits and strategies is satisfactory. In support of the conclusions of this report, I voted to grant the 2013 discharge.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of granting the discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the implementation of the ENIAC joint venture budget for the 2013 financial year. Efforts have indeed been made following the european Parliament's latest decision to adjourn this discharge. The joint venture ENIAC worked on an action plan to address the shortcomings that had been highlighted by the Court of Auditors.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the normal discharge procedure, and the commission decided to grant the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking handled the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, according to the commission's assessment, and strengthened the application of the rules on conflicts of interest. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This second report concerned the discharge on the execution of the company's budget, or joint ENIAC initiative, created in 2007, in the nanoelectronics sector. While the collective initiative with which it merged, Artemis, is already being challenged in problems of transparency in its internal budgetary functioning, it seems necessary to put into perspective the relevance of this funding in view of its low added value. Concerned about the rational use of public funding in general, especially when it does not seem relevant to me, I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 Here I also voted against the discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. My principled position relating to the discharge of any part of the budget is also covered by that of my ECR Group, namely that it should not be given until the budget as a whole receives a positive assessment from the Court of Auditors.  The Court's preliminary report provides for opportunities for conflicts of interest and needs to be cleared.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the information provided on the financial figures does not justify the discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure, and the commission decided to grant the discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking handled the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, according to the commission's assessment, and strengthened the application of the rules on conflicts of interest. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.    The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.  The Association for European Nanoelectronics Activities (AENEAS) is also involved in a joint undertaking to contribute EUR 30 million. Member States are expected to make a contribution of 1.8 times that of the EU contribution. We cannot support such programmes that clearly put pressure on Member States at a time of severe financial difficulty with other priorities that are far more essential for the citizens of Europe.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 ENIAC was established on 20 December 2007, for a period of 10 years, with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' for the development of key competences in the field of nanoelectronics, across the different areas of application, with the maximum contribution for the 10-year period allocated by the Union to the Joint Undertaking, EUR 450 000 000 from the budget of the Seventh Framework Programme for Research. The ENIAC and ARTEMIS Joint Undertakings were merged to create the joint technology initiative in the field of 'Electronic components and systems for European leadership', with 23 national funding entities sharing information on their audit strategies, representing 95 % of all grants awarded. The Joint Undertaking has made progress in implementing the Action Plan to address the shortcomings identified by the Court, and the guarantees provided by national systems have been positively assessed in countries representing 54 % of the grants granted, while evaluations for other countries are at an advanced stage of implementation, resulting in grant coverage of 84 %. I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up on 20 December 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' for the development of key competences in the field of nanoelectronics, across the different areas of application, acquiring financial autonomy in July 2010. In the Court of Auditors' view, the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for the financial year 2013 accurately reflect, in all material respects, its financial situation at the end of 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulations and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's Accounting Officer. A seminar on guarantees was organised, which brought together representatives of the Court, the Commission and the Commission's Internal Audit Service, as well as representatives of national funding entities operating in the Joint Undertaking, highlighting the requirements of European programmes, and enabled the exchange of information and good practice with national funding entities. It should be stressed the creation of a database bringing together all the identified information on conflicts of interest and the measures taken in this context. We have followed the rapporteur's proposal.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as  no significant irregularity in accountability has been detected in the recent evaluation.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this report is the 2013 discharge for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the discharge report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2013 discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking, as this report is incomplete. The data and information presented with regard to the financial figures do not justify the exemption.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this discharge as the 2013 budget still has not been granted approval from the Court of Auditors. I cannot pass this budget because an ever increasing bill for my constituents is not acceptable. We should be looking for cost-saving measures and not just accept the budget if the Auditors cannot.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the discharge of ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. Following a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was voted by a large majority.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted against the report 'Discharge 2013: Joint Enterprise ENIAC' today because I believe that, despite the approach of a public private partnership, we are still investing too much taxpayers' money in the European Research Platform for Nanoelectronics. Here, I expect significantly more financial commitment from industry and the recruitment of further third-party funds.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the discharge of ENIAC for 2013.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Here we go again, EUR 3 billion to be spent on R&D projects that the private sector should be doing, not government.  Socialism failed, continues to fail, and yet we have a bunch of MEPs here who think it is the utopia.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ President, I have voted to grant discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors, including, importantly, the introduction of new ex post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As with ARTEMIS, today I also supported granting the discharge to ENIAC. ENIAC and ARTEMIS merged to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership joint technology initiative. These organisations have taken measures to demonstrate that EU funding is properly spent and in a transparent manner.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. It is true that the Court of Auditors has previously given a clear opinion on the annual accounts, but the Joint Undertaking has made considerable progress in implementing the action plan to balance the shortcomings identified. It is also true that we must thank the private sector, which has contributed a massive amount of funding to the joint venture, funding that has more than compensated for the reduction in contributions from the Member States.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The recommendation of the CONT Commission is to approve the management of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for 2013, following its postponement on 29 April. The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was requested to provide further elements to the CONT Commission on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of their management. The responses provided by the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ENIAC Joint Undertaking) have been considered satisfactory. We voted in favour of the closure of the 2013 accounts and in favour of the Resolution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted, alongside my colleagues in the EPLP, to grant discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors including, importantly, the introduction of new ex-post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, as it supports the closure of the accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 and instructs its President to forward this Decision to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking, the Council, the Commission and the Court of Auditors.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided to grant the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking handled the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, according to the commission's assessment, and strengthened the application of the rules on conflicts of interest. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report granting the discharge as the ARTEMIS Joint Undertaking assists in the crucial development of key technologies for embedded computing systems across different application areas in order to strengthen EU competiveness and sustainability and to allow for the emergence of new markets and societal applications.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.    The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.  The Association for European Nanoelectronics Activities (AENEAS) is also involved in a joint undertaking to contribute EUR 30 million. Member States are expected to make a contribution of 1.8 times that of the EU contribution. We cannot support such programmes that clearly put pressure on Member States at a time of severe financial difficulty with other priorities that are far more essential for the citizens of Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided to grant the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. In fact, the Joint Undertaking handled the problems identified in the first discharge report on its merits, according to the commission's assessment, and strengthened the application of the rules on conflicts of interest. As a result, the commission decided to grant discharge and close the accounts. I also supported the granting of the exemption of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking at the plenary session of the European Parliament.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the second ENIAC budgetary resolution report for the ENIAC financial year 2013, because it was established that the budgetary and financial management of the company had been lawfully and properly done. Furthermore, operations and cash flows for 2013 are in line with the financial and accounting rules of the company.  Ex-post audit mechanisms have also been put in place as regards administrative agreements concluded by the undertaking with national funding authorities. In my view, however, it is of particular importance that the company has improved the conflict of interest prevention system and increased transparency.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the discharge on the implementation of the 2013 budget of the joint venture ENIAC, financed by the EU budget, the private sector and the Member States. I consider that an evaluation of ENIAC's activities since 2007 is necessary, which will only take place in the context of the 2014 landfill. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the company's operations.  I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.    The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.  The Association for European Nanoelectronics Activities (AENEAS) is also involved in a joint undertaking to contribute EUR 30 million. Member States are expected to make a contribution of 1.8 times that of the EU contribution. Fellow MEPs and I cannot support such programmes that clearly put pressure on Member States at a time of severe financial difficulty with other priorities that are far more essential for the citizens of Europe.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because the joint ventures ENIAC, after being adjourned by the European Parliament, have made significant improvements to its budget and procedures.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting against this report. Although the resolutions set out the problems quite clearly, the decision taken on the basis of the problems is incomprehensible. A positive adoption is therefore not possible for me

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to grant the discharge, as the organisation has taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. – ENIAC was established on 20 December 2007 for a period of ten years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' for the development of skills essential for nanoelectronics in various fields of application. I have chosen to vote for the 2013 budget release as it has been established that the annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 comply with the provisions of the Financial Regulation of the Joint Undertaking. In agreement with the Court of Auditors, I believe that further evaluations of national guarantee systems are needed following the merger of the joint ventures ENIAC and ARTEMIS.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to grant discharge for the 2013 fiscal year to the joint venture ENIAC, which is responsible for the development of nanoelectronics systems. As with previous landfills, there are improvements in some areas, but the evaluation of ENIAC's activities since 2007 will only take place in the 2014 landfill. I can therefore only vote against this text in the absence of an assessment of the activities of this joint undertaking for which the Court of Auditors has expressed its reluctance on the legality and regularity of certain transactions.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA cannot give the green light to the discharge of individual parts of the European budget until the full accounts have been approved by the European Court of Auditors.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This time I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 enIAC Joint Undertaking budget, which was postponed on 29 April. On this occasion, Parliament halted discharge in the implementation of the budget as the CONT Commission asked THE ENIAC Company to submit more elements on its accounts and on the regularity of various transactions.  This extra information was considered satisfactory by the CONT Commission, so I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was established in 2007 for a period of 10 years and its main purpose is to identify and implement research programmes for the development of key knowledge in nanoelectronics. In 2010, ENIAC won financial independence. The European Parliament approved the implementation of the ENIAC joint venture budget for the 2013 financial year on the basis of the Court's decision on the reliability of the accounts. As the Court also confirmed the progress of the ENIAC in implementing the action plan with a view to correcting the errors we made in our conditional opinion, I supported the budget implementation resolution.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the second reading vote on the discharge for the implementation of the eniaco joint venture budget for the financial year 2013 because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted against granting the waiver. The joint venture ENIAC aims to serve as a platform for nanotechnology research. This 10-year project is to define and implement a research program on the development of essential skills for nanotechnology. As with Artemis, the discharge of ENIAC had already been postponed by the European Parliament in the previous vote because of various irregularities noted by the Court of Auditors, in terms of transparency, guarantees and methods for estimating errors. ENIAC promised to correct these errors. However, the Court of Auditors still expresses doubts about the regularity and legality of the transactions underlying the annual accounts. In these circumstances, we object to the granting of this discharge.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to Grant the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking discharge in respect of the implementation of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking’s budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Defined by the final annual accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, and in view of the Court of Auditors' report on the annual accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, I voted in favour of approving the closure of ENIAC's accounts for the financial year 2013 and granting discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report granting discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, in view of the positive report presented by the Court of Auditors on the annual accounts, together with the replies of the Joint Undertaking.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Since the rapporteur attests to the company's proper use of funds, I can only agree to the discharge of the company.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Parliament's budgetary discharge power should enable it to enforce the budgetary commitments made by all European institutions and agencies. However, both the Commission and the Council take almost no account of Parliament's votes, including when it refuses discharge. It is a symptom of the democratic impotence of Parliament in the EU.  The 2013 discharge was denied to the joint venture ENIAC last April because of the reservations of the Court of Auditors on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the joint venture. Guarantees have been provided by the company, but once again the 2013 budget has been implemented in a particularly chaotic manner, any discharge given for this exercise is problematic. Indeed, in that year, the Commission and the Council managed to set aside and defer 1 billion surpluses while the EU had accumulated 20 billion unpaid. This savage application of austerity is unacceptable and absurd. I'm voting against it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. There is talk of the discharge on the implementation of the 2013 joint venture enIA budget, financed by the EU budget, the private sector and the Member States. The Member considers that an assessment of ENIAC's activities since 2007 is necessary, which will only take place in the context of the 2014 landfill. In addition, the Court of Auditors questions the legality and regularity of the company's operations. Therefore, the Member votes against granting the discharge. Regarding the motion for a resolution, the Member voted against it, considering the report too lenient.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report to grant the discharge as the rapporteur highlights the progress that ENIAC and ARTEMIS joint undertakings have made in tackling the audit strategies and other concerns raised by the Court of Auditors.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 Discharge was granted to the Executive Director of ECSEL in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 on the basis of a decision of the Court of Auditors on the correctness of the annual accounts. However, it should be recalled that the Court issued a qualified opinion on the legality and regularity of operations, and the Joint Undertaking introduced practical arrangements for ex-post audits to obtain sufficient certainty. I am pleased that the company has held a seminar on assurance in the presence of representatives of the Court of Auditors, the Commission and other active representatives of national funding bodies. I consider it important to note that member states' contributions were below 1.8 times the Union contribution and that the lower contributions were offset by higher private sector contributions. The Commission shall carry out an evaluation of ENIAC's activities until the date of establishment of the ECSEL STI.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I followed the Committee’s decision and voted in favour of granting discharge for 2013 to ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The EU budget supports the implementation of a number of policies and programmes. In accordance with the priorities set out by the European Parliament and the Council in the MFIN, the Commission shall provide technical support to specialised agencies for the implementation of specific programmes, activities and projects.  The Brussels-based ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up by Council Regulation (EC) No 72/2008 for a period of 10 years. Its main objective is to create and implement a generally accepted research plan in the field of nanoelectronics. To this end, it raises funds from the public and private sectors, from which it supports R&D projects.  The ENIAC Joint Undertaking has submitted its final annual accounts for the financial year 2013. For the financial year 2013, the European Court of Auditors certified in a statement the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. In its recommendation of 17 February 2015, the Council in favour of the discharge for the Joint Undertaking on the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013. Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control recommended that parliament grant discharge for the implementation of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget for the financial year 2013. I supported the proposal accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was established on 20 December 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' for the development of key competences in the field of nanoelectronics, across the different areas of application. In July 2010, ENIAC acquired financial autonomy. In June 2014, the ENIAC and ARTEMIS Joint Undertakings were merged to create the joint technology initiative in the field of 'Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership' (ECSEL) with a ten-year operating period. Given that the Court of Auditors has stated that ENIAC's annual accounts for 2013 reflect exactly, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulation , this report on the closure of ENIAC's accounts for the financial year 2013 deserves my vote in favour. I believe that the institutions of the European Union must be transparent and fully accountable to citizens in relation to the funds granted to them as Union institutions.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to grant discharge for the 2013 budget year to the joint venture ENIAC, which is responsible for the development of nanoelectronics systems. As with previous landfills, there are improvements in some areas, but the evaluation of ENIAC's activities since 2007 will only take place in the 2014 landfill. I can therefore only vote against this text in the absence of an assessment of the activities of this joint undertaking for which the Court of Auditors has expressed its reluctance on the legality and regularity of certain transactions.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which authorizes the 2013 budget discharge for the joint venture ENIAC. Last April, this discharge was adjourned because the company had submitted insufficient assurances about the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying its annual accounts, resulting in a reserved opinion from the Court of Auditors. The report submitted in September to report on the measures taken to better implement ENIAC's budget gave satisfaction to the discharge authorities. As a result, the Committee on Budgetary Control recommended granting this discharge. The budgetary discharge, which can be granted, postponed or refused by the European Parliament, constitutes the final control of the annual budget. This process represents the political component of budget implementation control. It is based on the reports of the Court of Auditors and on the clarifications provided by the agencies concerned. The discharge decision may be accompanied by recommendations to improve certain aspects of budget implementation.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The ENIAC Joint Undertaking (JU) is a public-private partnership focusing on nanoelectronics that brings together ENIAC Member/Associated States, the European Commission, and AENEAS (an association representing European R&D actors in this field). I have voted for this report on the 2013 discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As Vice-President of the Committee on Budgetary Control and as S&D Coordinator for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I support the granting of discharge for the implementation of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget for the financial year 2013. ENIAC was established in 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' to develop key competences for nanoelectronics in different application sectors. ENIAC has made progress in implementing the action plan to address the shortcomings identified by the Court in its view with reservations. On the basis of the information provided by the Joint Undertaking, we note that a level of 211.5 publications and 16.6 patents for every EUR 10 000 000 granted by the Union in the form of grants demonstrates a high productivity of the results of its research activities and that that level meets all the requirements expressed so far by the coordinators of the Seventh Framework Programme (FP7).
