name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The resolution on the 2013 discharge: Joint undertaking ENIAC presents the problems of joint undertakings well and highlights the grievances. Unfortunately, the only decisions taken on the basis of this resolution are incomprehensible. Nevertheless, I voted in favour of the resolution as I welcome its critical and revealing nature.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In the Court's opinion, the accounts correctly reflect the financial situation of ENIAC.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am satisfied with the action of the company ENIAC and how its financial instruments have been used, not only as a European citizen, but also as a citizen of one of the founding countries. I welcome the fact that the contributions of the Member States have complied with the threshold imposed by the rules in force. I can confirm that I will vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account that the Court found that the annual accounts of the ENIAC joint undertaking for the financial year 2013 correspond to the situation of the undertaking on 31 December 2013 in all significant respects, and since the data on the financial interests of the company's accounting have since been collected and given to the public, I support the 2013 statement for the ENIAC joint undertaking.  In doing so, I welcome the Court's decision to take further steps to obtain sufficient assurances on audits, considering that the transparency of the joint undertaking's operations must be not only its primary interest and objective, but also a guiding principle in every aspect of the company's operations. Taking into account the decision to merge the ENIAC joint venture with artemis joint undertaking into a joint technological initiative for electronic components and systems for Europe's leadership, I consider it of utmost importance that the company's operations in the run-up to the merger are transparent, especially in financial terms and that there are no doubts about conflicts of interest.  As our report showed regularity in the transactions carried out, sufficient audits were carried out in the national authorities of the Member States and the Staff and Enforced Rules Regulations were complied with in terms of transparent disclosure and availability of information on the financial interests of the management of the joint undertaking, the conditions for granting a release have been met.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to grant discharge for the 2013 fiscal year to the joint venture ENIAC, which is responsible for the development of nanoelectronics systems. As with previous landfills, there are improvements in some areas, but the evaluation of ENIAC's activities since 2007 will only take place in the 2014 landfill. I can therefore only vote against this text in the absence of an assessment of the activities of this joint undertaking for which the Court of Auditors has expressed its reluctance on the legality and regularity of certain transactions.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was established in 2007 for a period of 10 years to identify and implement a "research programme" to develop key knowledge in nanoelectronics for various areas of application. After the Court of Auditors gave a conditional opinion on the legality and regularity of the basic transactions, the joint undertaking established practical ex-post audit mechanisms in cooperation with national funding bodies, and the guarantees of national systems were positively assessed for countries representing 54% of the grants awarded.  It also found that the contribution of ENIAC Member States was below the level of 1.8 % as required by the joint enterprise statute, with these lower contributions from Member States more than offset by increased private sector contributions covering 65 % of total costs. Progress has also been made in developing a methodology for assessing the residual error rate.  For all of the above, the ENIAC joint undertaking is given a resolution for the implementation of the budget. The company has shown that it complies with all the requirements expressed so far by the coordinators of the Seventh Framework Programme, which is why I support the issuance of a release.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. In accordance with the facts and findings of the Court of Auditors, which confirm that the results of operations and cash flows for the end of the year of the ENIAC joint undertaking comply with the provisions of its financial and accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer, I support this report.  Despite the Court's conditional opinion on a sufficient guarantee of the legality and regularity of the basic transactions presented in the annual financial statements, the joint undertaking has put in place practical ex-post audit mechanisms in relation to the administrative agreements it has concluded with national funding authorities, which includes the introduction of a specific reporting and assessment form for national insurance schemes.  At the same time, progress has been made in implementing the action plan, and a guarantee workshop has been organised to share information and best practices with national information authorities, where representatives of the Court, the Commission and the Internal Audit Service have also met. It is evident that a large number of measures have been taken in the work and elimination of the problems of the joint venture and I believe that the measures taken will bring further progress.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 ENIAC is one of the so-called EU joint ventures involving other partners (in this case EU Member States), has financial autonomy but is subject to EU budgetary discharge. The granting of the 2013 budget discharge to the ENIAC Joint Undertaking was postponed in April this year. The reason for the postponement was, in particular, the European Court of Auditors' repeated concern about the ex post audit strategy, which relies heavily on the project cost statements of the national funding authorities, thus providing insufficient certainty as to the legality and regularity of the transactions carried out. In the meantime, ENIAC has taken significant measures to improve the situation, introducing, inter a view, a specific reporting form to increase this certainty and complemented by the Joint Undertaking's evaluation of national guarantee schemes and visits by the Court of Auditors to national funding bodies. The Committee on Budgetary Control, of which I am a member, has assessed the additional information as sufficient for discharge. That is why I voted both in committee and in plenary for discharge. I am continuously monitoring the situation with regard to EU Joint Ventures from my position as shadow rapporteur for the 2014 DISCHARGE of EU Joint Ventures.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Each year, Parliament assesses the implementation of the budget in order to grant discharge. In view of the Court of Auditors' report on the achievement of the objectives by the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ENIAC Joint Undertaking), which presented its financial position at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended that date, I have decided to vote in favour of granting discharge.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the publication of the new report of the Court of Auditors on the joint venture ENIAC (which became ECSEL in 2014 after merging with ARTEMIS), I voted in favour of the discharge relating to the implementation of the budget for the 2013 financial year. The recent report provides sufficient evidence of the legality and regularity of ENIAC's accounts.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By giving discharge to an institution or agency, the European Parliament approves the proper use of the public money in budgetary implementation, achieved in compliance with regulations. Upon a recommendation from the Council, Members of the European Parliament are called upon to exercise control over the management of appropriations by deciding on discharge on the basis of the Court of Auditors' reports.  Thus, and after evaluating the reports of the Court of Auditors and the Parliamentary Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of this Decision, which gives discharge to the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking for the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ There is a call for private investors to contribute to this programme as well as Member States. Lower contributions from Member States were more than compensated by private investment; this is not welcome from our perspective due to the fact that we are concerned that our public and private sectors are not intertwined with EU political aims and objectives.   The project will end in 2017 and by that time it is estimated that EUR 3 billion will be spent on R&D projects.  The Association for European Nanoelectronics Activities (AENEAS) is also involved in a joint undertaking to contribute EUR 30 million. Member States are expected to make a contribution of 1.8 times that of the EU contribution. We cannot support such programmes that clearly put pressure on Member States at a time of severe financial difficulty with other priorities that are far more essential for the citizens of Europe.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. After not obtaining the discharge of its accounts in April, the ENIAC Joint Undertaking has achieved this in this Plenary following the new information provided and the appearance of its director before the Committee on Budgetary Control. On this occasion, however, as the report adopted in Parliament, to which I have given my support, it is estimated that the actions carried out by the company have strengthened the independence of audit controls, additional checks carried out by the firm itself have been put in place in the after- and an action plan has been put in place to end the deficiencies identified by the Court of Auditors , so you are granted approval.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Today, I have decided to vote in favour of the Czarnecki report granting discharge to the executive director of the joint venture ECSEL on the implementation of the ENIAC joint venture budget for the 2013 financial year. There are three reasons for this vote. First, the Court of Auditors found that the annual accounts of the joint venture for the 2013 financial year accurately presented the company's financial situation as of December 31, 2013. The same applies to the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended that date.  Secondly, with regard to the Court of Auditors' remark about the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts, the joint venture stated that it would take steps to obtain sufficient assurances as to the audits carried out by those national authorities. Finally, the company made progress on the implementation of an action plan to correct the deficiencies identified by the Court of Auditors.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. The vote on this text follows the European Parliament's decision to postpone the granting of the 2013 discharge to the joint venture ENIAC.  Indeed, the ex-post audit strategy concerning the legality and regularity of the operations of the joint venture ENIAC had been called into question.  Following the identification of this problem, the joint venture ENIAC submitted a report on progress and changes.  Given the improvements in ex-post audits and audit strategies and the introduction of a new method of estimating the residual error rate, I voted in favour of granting the 2013 discharge to the joint venture ENIAC.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to vote in favour of approving the closure of ENIAC's accounts for the financial year 2013 and I support the European Parliament's decision to grant discharge to the Executive Director of ECSEL for the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The recommendation of the CONT Commission is to approve the management of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for 2013, following its postponement on 29 April. The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was requested to provide further elements to the CONT Commission on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of their management. The responses provided by the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ENIAC Joint Undertaking) have been considered satisfactory. We voted in favour of the closure of the 2013 accounts and in favour of the Resolution.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This time I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 enIAC Joint Undertaking budget, which was postponed on 29 April. On this occasion, Parliament halted discharge in the implementation of the budget as the CONT Commission asked THE ENIAC Company to submit more elements on its accounts and on the regularity of various transactions.  This extra information was considered satisfactory by the CONT Commission, so I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it is spending vast amounts of UK taxpayers’ money, and this should be decided in the UK Parliament.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ ENIAC and ARTEMIS merged to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership joint technology initiative. I have voted to grand discharge, as I did with ARTEMIS, to this end and hope that they will continue to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in accordance with the principle that discharge for any part of the EU budget should only follow after the EU budget as a whole has received a favourable opinion from the European Court of Auditors.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: In writing ‒ the ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up on 20 December 2007 for a period of 10 years to define and implement a research plan for the development of key competences for nanoelectronic in different fields of application. Financial autonomy was acquired by the Joint Undertaking in July 2010. The Court noted that the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for 2013 faithfully express, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2013 and the results of its operations and cash flows at the end of the year are in line with the provisions of its Financial Regulation and with the accounting rules approved by the Commission's accounting officer. The Joint Undertaking has established practical arrangements for ex-post audits as regards administrative agreements signed with national funding bodies. These practical measures include the introduction of a separate statement and are complemented by an evaluation of the national assurance schemes by the Joint Undertaking and visits by the Court of Auditors' national funding bodies. I supported the motion for a resolution on the 2013 discharge for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament deals annually with the legality, regularity and effectiveness of the implementation of the budget of the European institutions, agencies, joint undertakings and other EU services in the budget discharge procedure. The CONT Committee and then the Members of the April plenary session postponed the granting of discharge for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for 2013, as for the third year in a row (i.e. for 2011, 2012 and 2013), the Court of Auditors issued a reservation on the legality and regularity of the transactions. In the meantime, Parliament has received new information on improvements in this Joint Undertaking, which, as early as 2014, after joining ARTEMIS in the ECSLE Joint Undertaking, has actively launched its action plan to address the shortcomings identified by the Court of Auditors and Parliament in recent years, as well as a new ex-post audit strategy and an improved procurement system. This is certainly the reason why I supported the report on the discharge for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking in the vote, but I would like to stress that the company must continue to work hard to improve the shortcomings identified. It is not enough that the implementation of the budget is purely legal and correct, and it is increasingly important that prudent spending achieves long-term positive effects on the economy, society and the environment.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development and promotion of joint ventures are important if we want the European Union to be one of the world's technological leaders. I therefore support the creation of such a joint venture, which focuses on the development of key competences for nanoelectronic.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of granting discharge for the EU’s Joint Undertakings ENIAC and ARTEMIS, which merged in June 2014 to create the Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership (ECSEL) joint technology initiative. The organisations have taken measures to show that EU funds are spent in a correct and transparent manner. The second report on discharge for 2013 indicates that sufficient steps have been taken to address the main issues raised by the Court of Auditors, including, importantly, the introduction of new ex-post audit mechanisms in order to verify the agreements with the national funding authorities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Taking into account, inter alia, the final annual accounts of the ENIAC joint undertaking for the 2013 financial year, As well as the Court's report on the ENIAC joint venture's annual accounts for the 2013 financial year, together with the replies of the joint undertaking, the European Parliament shall provide a statement to the EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR of ECSEL for the implementation of the ENIAC joint venture budget for the financial year 2013 and approve the closure of the ENIAC joint venture's accounts for the financial year 2013 and ENIAC for the financial year 2013.  I support this report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2013 discharge for the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. In its report, the Court of Auditors found that the Joint Undertaking ended 2013 in accordance with the provisions of its financial rules and accounting rules. I welcome that, by the Court's definition, the Joint Undertaking has put in place practical arrangements for ex-post audits of administrative agreements signed with national funding bodies and has introduced a specific reporting form.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 As regards the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the information provided on the financial figures does not justify the discharge of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the discharge text. The result of a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was voted on by a large majority.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ As in the case of Artemis Joint Undertaking and EIT, I also endorsed the two decisions and a resolution regarding the ENIAC Joint Undertaking. The first decision grants the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking discharge in respect of the implementation of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking’s budget for the financial year 2013. The second decision approves the closure of the accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013. The resolution summarises ENIAC’s budgetary and financial management and prevention and management of conflicts of interests and transparency. The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up on 20 December 2007 for a period of 10 years to define and implement a ‘research agenda’ for the development of key competences for nanoelectronics across different application areas.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of eniac's budget for the financial year 2013 because, in the Court's view, the Annual accounts, results and cash flows were presented fairly in all respects, and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking also established practical arrangements for ex-post audits.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The recommendation of the CONT Commission is to approve the management of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for 2013, following its postponement on 29 April. The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was requested to provide further elements to the CONT Commission on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of their management. The responses provided by the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ENIAC Joint Undertaking) have been considered satisfactory. We voted in favour of the closure of the 2013 accounts and in favour of the Resolution.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the Court's view, the Joint Undertaking's 2013 annual accounts reflect, in all material respects and in accordance with the provisions of the Financial Regulation of the Joint Undertaking and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer, the financial situation of 31 December 2013 and the outcome of the economic and cash events to the end of the year. That is why I supported the report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The recommendation of the CONT Commission is to approve the management of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for 2013, following its postponement on 29 April. The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was requested to provide further elements to the CONT Commission on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of their management. The responses provided by the Executive Director of the ECSEL Joint Undertaking (formerly the ENIAC Joint Undertaking) have been considered satisfactory. We voted in favour of the closure of the 2013 accounts and in favour of the Resolution.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, on the closure of the accounts of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 and in favour of the resolution with observations forming an integral part of the decision on discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013, because I believe it is important to acknowledge the role of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking and because I agree that the statement concerning the 2013 annual accounts of the Joint Undertaking was presented fairly in all material respects. Also, its financial position as of 31 December 2013 and the results of its operations and its cash flows for the year-end are in accordance with the provisions of its Financial Rules.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a matter that was postponed during last April's plenary meeting when Parliament observed that the Court of Auditors, for the third consecutive year, issued a qualified opinion questioning certain aspects of the ENIAC Joint Undertaking.  A report on the progress made since the first report was available in June. On that basis, the rapporteur states that the progress made has been positive and is therefore in favour of approving the management of ENIAC. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted against the decision to grant discharge to the ENIAC Joint Undertaking: the Court of Auditors, in its report on the company's annual accounts, stated that ENIAC had carried out a limited examination of the declarations of expenditure, and therefore the Court was unable to conclude whether the key audit of the ex-post audit was working effectively. This limited examination was therefore not in itself sufficient to provide a guarantee of the error rate indicated by the joint venture. That is why Parliament did not grant discharge in the first instance. There must be no slightest suspicion as to how the money was spent, and the lack of an effective control system prevents me from trusting ENIAC.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This time I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 enIAC Joint Undertaking budget, which was postponed on 29 April. On this occasion, Parliament halted discharge in the implementation of the budget as the CONT Commission asked THE ENIAC Company to submit more elements on its accounts and on the regularity of various transactions.  This extra information was considered satisfactory by the CONT Commission, so I voted in favour of approving the management in the implementation of the 2013 ENIAC Joint Undertaking budget.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up on 20 December 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' for the development of key competences in the field of nanoelectronics, across the different areas of application, acquiring financial autonomy in July 2010. In the Court of Auditors' opinion, the Annual Accounts of the Joint Undertaking for the financial year 2013 accurately reflect, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the financial year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulations and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's Accounting Office.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Since the rapporteur attests to the company's proper use of funds, I can only agree to the discharge of the company.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent merger of the ARTEMIS and ENIAC joint ventures led to the creation of the 10-year joint technology initiative "Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership" (ITC ECSEL). ENIAC has played, and will all the more so after the merger, played a decisive role in the development of technological research on European territory. The resources allocated to this company are an essential support for the development of advanced European technologies and for an area in which Europe cannot but invest if it is to remain competitive in the global financial market. In recent years, efforts and progress have also been made, both in terms of financial and budgetary management and in terms of compliance with transparency criteria. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the subject of discharge for the implementation of the budget of the Joint Undertaking ENIAC for the financial year 2013. Until the budget is audited with a positive result by the Court of Auditors, I cannot support the report. A qualified opinion on the legality and regularity of transactions was published, which highlights the annual accounts. This is because one is incapable of finding out whether the retrospective verification provides sufficient insurance for these transactions. In addition, there is a remaining error rate and the risk of potential conflicts of interest.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The ENIAC Joint Undertaking was set up on 20 December 2007 for a period of 10 years with the aim of defining and implementing a 'research agenda' for the development of key competences in the field of nanoelectronics, across the different areas of application, acquiring financial autonomy in July 2010. The ENIAC and ARTEMIS Joint Undertakings were merged to create the joint technology initiative in the field of 'Electronic Components and Systems for European Leadership' (ECSEL) which entered into operation in June 2014 and will operate for ten years. In the Court of Auditors' opinion, the Joint Undertaking's annual accounts for the financial year 2013 accurately reflect, in all material respects, its financial situation as at 31 December 2013, as well as the results of its operations and cash flows for the year ended on that date, in accordance with the provisions of its financial regulations and the accounting rules adopted by the Accounting Office of the European Commission. We voted in favour of discharge.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of not approving management in the implementation of the budget of the Council and the European Council for 2013. This is not the first time this has happened, since the Council refuses to present to the European Parliament those elements necessary for us to exercise our right to count. Because of this lack of cooperation which undermines the principle of transparency, I voted in favour of Parliament's position, so as not to approve the management in the implementation of the Council and European Council budget for the 2013 financial year.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report which calls for the council to refuse discharge. Indeed, the latter once again refuses to cooperate and provide information regarding the use of its budget. Parliament deplores this practice, which places the European Parliament, the only institution elected by direct vote and with budgetary power, particularly in the area of discharge, in a lower position. The report stresses that all institutions should be transparent and accountable and are accountable for the implementation of their budgets.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This vote is intended to deny a discharge on the implementation of the EU budget for the 2013 financial year. I voted for that refusal. The Council does not cooperate fully with Parliament and does not provide detailed information on the use of the appropriations. Parliament's budgetary powers are called into question by this attitude. In its report, Parliament stresses that expenditure must be controlled in the same way as other institutions. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal to refuse discharge, due to the various failings of the Council, which are well known.  I opposed the granting of discharge for the same reason.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report, as advocated by the committee responsible for the substance.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which does not endorse the implementation of the 2013 budget of the EP and of the Council. So far, discharge procedures have been in difficulty for years due to the Council's non-cooperation. Effective budgetary control requires cooperation between Parliament and the Council, but the Council continues to refuse to provide answers to Parliament's questions. Council expenditure would be checked as carefully as the expenditure of other institutions. Failure by the Council to provide the documents requested by Parliament violates, in particular, the right of Union citizens to information and transparency.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report briefly states that the Council's request for discharge is not granted by Parliament for the year 2013. Every year since 2009, the Council has made a request for budgetary discharge to Parliament, which parliament has consistently refused since 2009. This is because Parliament is not convinced that the Council is managed in a transparent manner and has not answered a number of questions, e.g. in relation to property purchases and real estate developments. I agreed with the rejection of the request for exemption and therefore voted in favour.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects. The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty o the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. After Parliament's decision of 29 April 2015, the Committee on Budgetary Control decided to refuse discharge to the Council because of a lack of transparency in the finances and the refusal to provide the information it requested. The discharge was refused for 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012. The rapporteur recalls that he invited the Council to provide him with reports on the progress of construction projects and a detailed breakdown of the expenses incurred so far. Information was also requested on the ongoing administrative modernization. Since the rapporteur did not receive the requested information and the Council had to comply with budgetary control like any other institution, I voted against granting the discharge.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this common-sense report, which reminds the Council of its duties on budget transparency.  The text calls for the Council to be refused discharge, and rightly so: despite the democratic legitimacy available to Parliament - the only European institution to be elected by direct universal suffrage - the Council persists in its opacity and refuses to cooperate with European elected representatives by providing them with essential information about its expenditure. I therefore congratulate the rapporteur on this courageous text, which reminds us that all The European institutions, particularly because of the impact they have on the lives of millions of citizens, must be accountable and transparent when it comes to the implementation of their budget.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the continuing lack of cooperation on the part of the Council and the European Council with Parliament on the budget issue and considering that both the real estate affairs of these institutions and the administrative modernisation process are still outstanding, I voted not to grant discharge.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report and, therefore, against granting discharge to the European Council and the Council since, as the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control once again shows, Parliament does not have the information to do so. We must regret the continuing difficulties that have arisen in the discharge procedures to date, due to a lack of cooperation on the part of the Council. It should be recalled in this regard that Parliament refused to approve the management of the Secretary-General of the Council in the implementation of the 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012 budgets.  Council expenditure must be monitored in the same way as that of the other institutions, as a prerogative of Parliament, in accordance with Articles 316, 317 and 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  The failure to present the requested documents to Parliament first affects the right to information and transparency of European citizens and, as the report points out, is a worrying symptom of a certain lack of democracy in the Union institutions.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it does not confirm to the Secretary-General of the Council discharge in the framework of the 2013 budget of the European Council and the Council. In its accompanying remarks, Parliament recalls its call on the Council to submit progress reports on construction projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs incurred so far. Urges the Council also to provide a detailed written explanation detailing the total amount of appropriations used to purchase the Residence Palace building, the budget items under which these appropriations have been used, the contributions that have been paid so far and the contributions still to be paid. Finally, Parliament again invited the Council to provide information on its administrative modernisation process, in particular on the specific measures taken to implement that process and on the expected budgetary implications of the Council.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided not to exempt the Council because the European Council had not cooperated with the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control during the discharge procedure for years. It does not give Parliament access to certain documents necessary for the conduct of the closure, it does not answer the questions sent. For this reason, in the plenary vote, approving the commission's proposal, I voted in favour of refusing to grant the Council discharge.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Unlike the exemplary behaviour of the remaining consumers of the EU budget to which we have been discharged, discharge is a completely different story for the Council.  It must be said loud and clear that the Council does not deserve discharge in any way. Ignoring the European Parliament's calls for proper reporting and compliance with the rules of proper financial conduct by the Council is unacceptable.  It is inconsistent, if not hypocritical, for Member States to require their citizens and businesses to comply with the rules concerning the use of budgetary resources or compliance with tax legislation, whereas they themselves systematically break such rules within the Council. The Council has not received discharge since 2009, which shows an under-incepable attitude towards Parliament and, he does, also for European citizens who have been violated by the right to information and transparency.  Parliament has thus been waiting for satisfactory information for many years on the progress of real estate projects, material consumption and administrative modernisation. But there's no such information, and it's not. I therefore voted in favour of the proposed resolution rejecting the budget discharge to the Council of the EU and the European Council, and in the future I hope that the Council will show greater respect for Parliament and, therefore, to the European citizens we represent in this House.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Council gave no explanation for the increasing level of under-utilised appropriations and commitments carried over to its 2013 budget, despite Parliament's express request. I therefore believe that discharge of the 2013 budget should not be granted to the European Council and the Council.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Yet funded by the taxes of European taxpayers, the European Council re-offends by refusing to provide details of the expenses it carries out. His behaviour is unacceptable in the eyes of the Peoples of Europe to whom the European Union has imposed austerity measures of unprecedented violence, with a massive reduction in public spending and a sharp increase in taxation, thus throwing a considerable part of our fellow citizens into poverty. It is not surprising to see Europeans moving away from the European institutions when we see that they are acting with this feeling of total impunity, as if these technocrats not elected by universal suffrage were not accountable. This lack of transparency is a real scandal. That is why I am in favour of this report, which proposes to refuse the granting of discharge to the Council.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report refusing discharge. Outstanding issues: real estate affairs, the administrative modernisation process, the continuing lack of cooperation with Parliament.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II – European Council and Council. Parliament is the only institution of the Union to be directly elected, which is also why it is responsible for granting discharge in respect of the implementation of the General Budget of the European Union. All the Union's institutions should be transparent and fully accountable to citizens about the way in which the funds at their disposal are spent, and in this respect the Council's items of expenditure must also be monitored.  Yet the Council persists in denying Parliament the delivery of the documents requested each year, first of all undermining the right to information and transparency vis-à-vis the citizens of the Union, as well as being a worrying symptom of a certain democratic deficit within the Union's institutions which does not make Parliament able to take an informed decision on granting discharge.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of refusing discharge to the Council and in favour of the accompanying resolution. The Council continues to refuse to answer any questions from the European Parliament, nor does it submit all relevant papers. The Council upholds its position that the so-called ‘Gentlemen’s Agreement’ between Council and Parliament from 1970 means that Council and Parliament will not scrutinise the implementation of their respective sections of the budget. In practice this means that the Council will not answer any questions or submit all the relevant papers. In addition to this, the Council argues that it is granted discharge for its budget qua the decision to grant the Commission discharge. This is in stark contrast to the current interpretation of the TFEU and subsequent practice where each heading of the budget is granted discharge individually in order to maintain transparency and democratic accountability. Furthermore, the Commission has (politely) rejected to take responsibility for the Council’s budget. This lack of transparency in the use of taxpayers’ money is unacceptable.  For this reason I voted in favour of the report, which postpones the decision to grant discharge.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report as the Council failed to reply to the questions and requests regarding the discharge exercise. The level of transparency was not satisfying and the Council failed to provide sufficient explanations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 For the seventh consecutive year, the European Parliament has proposed postponing the granting of discharge to the Council's budget, i.e. we must vote on whether or not discharge should be granted definitively. This report confirms that Parliament is not in a position to take an informed decision on granting discharge and therefore calls for discharge not to be granted to the Council.  Considering that the right of European citizens to transparent information comes first, I voted in favour of this report. I would point out that my vote in favour of the report in this case means that discharge is refused. Finally, I would like to point out that Parliament is the only European institution directly elected by the citizens, and the Council's continuing refusal to provide Parliament with the necessary documents is a refusal on the part of the citizens to ensure the proper administration of European funds and poses a serious problem of democracy.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, having regard to the EU General Budget for the financial year 2013 as well as the consolidated annual accounts of the EU for the financial year 2013, as well as the second report of the Committee on Budgetary Control, shall not grant discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council with regard to the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2013.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the decision refusing discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2013. I believe that the Council's failure to submit the requested documents to Parliament is worryingly pre-elinging the right of European citizens to information and transparency. I believe that this practice contributes to exacerbating the loss of public awareness of the EU institution.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr McDerman's report. Ryszard Czarnecki concerning the 2013 discharge of the budget of the European Council and the Council. The report stresses that the institutions are individually responsible for the implementation of their budgets, but the rapporteur insists that The Council's expenditure must be monitored in the same way as that of the institutions and communicated in every detail to those who may have an interest in being informed.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the institutions of the European Union have administrative autonomy, they have the task of cooperating and acting transparently in order to fully account for the management of the funds entrusted to them by the citizens of the Union. I therefore believe that discharge should be refused in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2013.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 For the seventh consecutive year, the European Parliament has proposed, in the first instance, to postpone the granting of discharge to the Council's budget. It is therefore now a question of voting for the final granting or otherwise of discharge.  The report confirms that Parliament is not in a position to take an informed decision on granting discharge and therefore calls for discharge not to be granted to the Council. Article 335 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union recognises that the institutions of the Union enjoy a certain degree of administrative autonomy in matters relating to their functioning: this autonomy implies an equivalent degree of responsibility and accountability to Parliament, which is the only body directly elected by the citizens and one of its tasks is precisely to grant discharge. The Council's continuing refusal to provide Parliament with the necessary documents is a refusal on the part of citizens to ensure the proper administration of European funds and poses a serious democratic problem. The Council seems to want to wage a power struggle to maintain its supremacy over Parliament, without taking into account the right of European citizens to transparent information.  For the reasons listed above, I am voting in favour, thus refusing to grant discharge to the Council.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of not approving management in the implementation of the budget of the Council and the European Council for 2013. This is not the first time this has happened, since the Council refuses to present to the European Parliament those elements necessary for us to exercise our right to count. Because of this lack of cooperation which undermines the principle of transparency, I voted in favour of Parliament's position, so as not to approve the management in the implementation of the Council and European Council budget for the 2013 financial year.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against granting discharge to the Council due to lack of transparency in the finances and continued refusal to provide information in response to the Parliament's questions. Discharge was already refused for the financial years 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012. It is regretful that the Council did not provide any explanation on the increasing underspending and carry—overs of commitments in its 2013 budget when all institutions should cooperate to ensure the smooth functioning of the discharge procedure.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report proposes to refuse the granting of discharge for the 2013 budget year to the European Council and the Council, following an initial refusal by the European Parliament, by a large majority and for the seventh consecutive year, at the April 2015 session. Having received no response to the questions and requests made during this discharge exercise and the precedents by the European Council and the Council, Parliament once again proposes to refuse the granting of discharge.  In the face of this repetitive and ubuesque situation, various options for updating the rules for granting discharge to the Council, the budgetary authority, enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, should be considered. In support of the conclusions of this report, I voted against granting discharge for the 2013 budget year.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Not all the actions required for the closure of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II – European Council and Council have been completed.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By this vote, the European Parliament refused to discharge the Secretary General of the Council on the implementation of the Budget of the European Council and the Council for the 2013 financial year. It is indeed essential that the European Council and the Council be more transparent about the use of the allocated funds. We call for better cooperation from the Council with a view to granting this discharge.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report, aimed at refusing the granting of discharge to the Council of Europe, aims to put an end to the budgetary actions of an un-elected body. The only body with real legitimacy, the European Parliament is nevertheless placed as a mere giver of advice on the granting of these discharges. In the memory of the expression that there can be no taxation without representation, it seems to me inappropriate that such a mode of operation can still exist in a Europe that poses as a champion of democracy. I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 The rapporteur's proposal not to discharge the European Council and the Council in respect of the implementation of the 2015 budget was supported by me. My principled position relating to the discharge of any part of the budget is also covered by that of my ECR Group, namely that it should not be given until the budget as a whole receives a positive assessment from the Court of Auditors.  Here, however, we are also seeing further complications: the Council has not cooperated with Parliament and has not conducted the necessary dialogue.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 22 September 2015, the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on the second discharge report of the institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure, and the commission decided not to discharge the Council. The European Council has not cooperated with the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control during the discharge procedure for years. It does not give Parliament access to certain documents necessary for the conduct of the closure, it does not answer the questions sent. For this reason, in the plenary vote, approving the commission's proposal, I voted in favour of refusing to grant the Council discharge.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Institutions of the Union shall be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union in relation to the funds entrusted to them as union institutions, and both the European Council and the Council should be subject to democratic accountability to the citizens of the Union, since they are beneficiaries of the general budget of the European Union. Parliament asked the Council to report on the state of progress of real estate projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs recorded to date, as well as the provision of information on its administrative modernisation process, in particular on the concrete measures taken to this end and on the impact foreseen in the Council budget. It is also regrettable that the Council has not provided any explanation for the increasing level of underused appropriations and commitments carried over in its 2013 budget.  I voted in favour.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As has been customary, Parliament once again refuses to give discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council, while maintaining the reasons. Much is said about "transparency" and much is required in this matter (some) of the Member States. However, the Council, the EU's supranational decision-making body which integrates representatives of the governments of the different Member States, appears to be immune to such "requirements", as since 2010 it has not responded to the questions and requirements for clarification, either on the increasing level of underused appropriations and commitments carried over in its 2013 budget, or on the state of progress of real estate projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs recorded to date. Once again, council expenditure is left unexamined by the only institution elected by direct suffrage, responsible for the discharge decision for the implementation of the general EU budget, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. The rapporteur acknowledges some of the democratic deficit, which we have always denounced, reflected in this Council's attitude of not submitting the requested documents, and is a cause for concern. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of supporting this report in order to NOT grant discharge to the Council.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ this report is about granting discharge for 2013 to the European Council and the Council.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the discharge report.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the proposal of the General Budget Committee, as the Council has not yet submitted to Parliament the documents requested, thus jeoparding the right of Union citizens to information and transparency. For this reason, not all the actions required for the closure of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II – European Council and Council have been completed.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the discharge of the EU general budget – European Council and Council for the financial year 2013. Following a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was adopted by a large majority.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'Discharge 2013: EU general budget – European Council and Council', because, thanks in part to the successful objections of my ECR Group, the report, despite the approval given, is putting its finger on the wounds that gape year after year in the financing of the EU from our citizens' taxes.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have agreed to the discharge of the EU's overall budget.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Another call for More EU! And more money! I voted against this for obvious reasons.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I joined many colleagues in voting against granting the 2013 European Council and Council discharge due to a lack of transparency, namely given that the Council has refused since 2009 to give information regarding its finances.  The best example of good practices have to be set at institutional level in order to earn citizens’ trust and confidence. Moreover, we need to see a more open dialogue between Parliament and the Council, which this report also urges.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have decided to vote in favour of not approving the management of the Council and the Council of the EU. The Council refuses to provide the necessary elements in order to be able to properly examine the Council's expenditure. There have been systematic difficulties encountered in the Council approval procedure to date due to lack of cooperation; Parliament refused to approve management in 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012, and was postponed in 2013. Without faithful information, the EP is unable to make an informed decision to approve the accounts.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I regret that the Council has again refused to provide any explanation on the increasing underspend and carry-overs of commitments in their 2013 budget. We agree with the Commission that all EU institutions should be subject to the Parliament’s discharge exercise. As Labour MEPs we insist that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on Discharge 2013: EU general budget – European Council and Council because it reminds the Council of Parliament’s call for progress reports on building projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs incurred to date and urges the Council to provide a thorough written explanation detailing the total amount of appropriations used in the purchase of the ‘Residence Palace’ building, the budget items from which those appropriations were drawn, the instalments that have been paid thus far and the instalments that remain to be paid.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided not to exempt the Council because the European Council had not cooperated with the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control during the discharge procedure for years. It does not give Parliament access to certain documents necessary for the conduct of the closure, it does not answer the questions sent. For this reason, in the plenary vote, approving the commission's proposal, I voted in favour of refusing to grant the Council discharge.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I decided to support this report, which proposes to refuse the discharge as it is necessary to consider different possibilities to update the rules on granting discharge laid down in the TFEU.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control voted on 22 September 2015 on the second discharge report of institutions which did not receive discharge during the ordinary discharge procedure. The Commission decided not to exempt the Council. The European Council has not cooperated with the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control during the discharge procedure for years. It does not give Parliament access to certain documents necessary for the conduct of the closure, it does not answer the questions sent. For this reason, in the plenary vote, approving the commission's proposal, I voted in favour of refusing to grant the Council discharge.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the second resolution report for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Part II - the European Council and the Council, as this refuses to give a statement to the Secretary-General of the Budget Implementation Council.  I believe that greater cooperation between the Council and the European Parliament is needed, in particular in delivering the information requested to increase transparency and democratic processes. In some actions, the Council undermines the right of EU citizens to have information available, and I therefore believe that greater openness and clarity is needed in the procedures taking place between the EU institutions.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. There is talk of the discharge on the implementation of the EU's general budget for the 2013 financial year. Once again the Council refuses to cooperate with Parliament and to explain the use of the appropriations. Thus, Parliament's budgetary powers are questioned by the Council. The discharge is therefore refused, so I voted for it.   The report, which is critical, stresses that spending must be monitored in the same way as other institutions.  I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and fellow MEP’s will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposed to deny discharge to the European Council and the Council. Indeed, these two institutions provide no explanation for the use of their budgets. However, as EU institutions, they must be subject to democratic control like all other European institutions and agencies.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The resolution clearly sets out the problems of discharge for the Council. The Council must become more democratic and be more open in its dealings with its expenditure and, above all, the practice of budgeting less and less, and then massively increasing it again in retrospect for various projects. The resolution is therefore to be welcomed and I agree with it accordingly.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the proposal to refuse discharge. I regret that again the Council has refused to provide any explanation on the increasing underspending and carryovers of commitments in their 2013 budget. We insist that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. As you know, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union gives Parliament an important role in the discharge of the budget. Although each body has administrative autonomy in matters relating to the functioning of its institution, I believe that a greater degree of cooperation and transparency between Parliament, the European Council and the Council is necessary. On the basis of this, I have chosen to vote in favour of the report, convinced that the dialogue between the institutions is a positive signal to be sent to the citizens of the Union.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to deny discharge to the European Council and the Council of Ministers for the 2013 budget year, which I think is perfectly legitimate given that the Council refuses to cooperate and provide the European Parliament with information on the use of the appropriations. This puts the European Parliament in a position of inferiority and the Council in a different position from that of the other institutions, which is not justified. I therefore voted in favour of this critical text, which puts all institutions on an equal footing when it comes to controlling expenditure.

name: Sander Loones (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The N-VA cannot give the green light to the discharge of individual parts of the European budget until the full accounts have been approved by the European Court of Auditors. This means that the ECR will vote in favour of the draft report, which will refuse to grant discharge.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of not approving management in the implementation of the budget of the Council and the European Council for 2013. This is not the first time this has happened, since the Council refuses to present to the European Parliament those elements necessary for us to exercise our right to count. Because of this lack of cooperation which undermines the principle of transparency, I voted in favour of Parliament's position, so as not to approve the management in the implementation of the Council and European Council budget for the 2013 financial year.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament refused to provide a resolution for the implementation of the general budget for the 2013 EU financial year, namely the European Council and the Council. The main criticism is financial opacity and the lack of adequate explanations from institutions. The outstanding issues also relate to reports relating to construction projects, the process of modernling its own administration and its budget implications, and the increase in unused funds and transfers made in the 2013 Council budget. I supported the rejection of a resolution for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council, as I consider transparency and accountability to citizens to be important characteristics and values of the European Union, in particular financial transparency.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting on this No. No. A8-0269/2015 second report by Mr Czarnecki, by which he does not grant discharge to the European Council in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, because mr Czarnecki's report does not provide an exemption to the European Council for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013. Czarnecki is complete and documented and for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted for this report which insists that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions and that the fundamental elements of such scrutiny have been laid down in its discharge resolutions of the past years.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this refusal to grant discharge. Once is not customary, this report calls for refusing the granting of discharge. We support this decision because the Council, concerned by this discharge, has for years refused to cooperate and provide information on its expenditure. It is the duty of any institution of the European Union to be fully transparent. This attitude casts doubt on the legality and legitimacy of the Council's operations!

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to ensure transparency and democratic accountability to eu taxpayers, I voted in favour of the report refusing to grant discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2013.  We are facing a worrying democratic deficit within the Union's institutions.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The resolution clearly sets out the problems of discharge for the Council: it must become more democratic and more open in its handling of its expenditure, and, above all, renounce the practice of repeatedly wanting to reduce the budget, only to then massively increase it again in retrospect for various projects. I therefore support the report.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. One of Parliament's few exclusive budgetary powers is to give discharge to the European institutions once their budgets have been implemented. Last April, Parliament had softly decided to postpone its decision on the Council's discharge for its 2013 budget. He hoped for improvements that never came. The Commission continues to provide no explanation as to whether or not to use part of its budget. Even though he is the first to demand ever more rigour in the implementation of the European budget. For example, for the past 10 years, there has been a great deal of uncertainty surrounding the construction of the Council's future sumptuous building, which is estimated to cost more than 300 million euros. This report therefore decides to refuse to grant the Council any discharge for the 2013 budget, as has been the case with all its budgets since 2009. As Parliament stands, this refusal to discharge has no impact. The rapporteur therefore legitimately suggests changing the rules for granting landfills. A wish stake among others. Nevertheless, I vote for this refusal to discharge to encourage this beginning of parliamentary resistance.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. There is talk of the discharge on the implementation of the EU's general budget for the 2013 financial year. Once again, the Council refuses to cooperate with Parliament and to explain the use of the appropriations. Thus, Parliament's budgetary powers are being called into question by the Council. The discharge is therefore refused and the member votes for it. The report, which is critical, stresses that spending must be monitored in the same way as other institutions. Therefore, the member votes for it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the rapporteur’s opinion to refuse the granting of the discharge as the Council has yet to address questions posed by the Parliament in the current and the previous discharge exercises.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: in writing \ u2012 The proposal for a Decision of the European Parliament not to grant discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2013 is based on insufficient transparency of real estate projects. All the Institutions of the Union have a democratic responsibility towards the citizens of the Union and their own responsibility to fulfil their own budget. I regret that the Council has not yet submitted to Parliament the requested documents, given the need for good cooperation between the institutions and the democratic oversight that Parliament provides. I therefore consider it necessary to postpone the discharge decision, as Parliament cannot take an informed decision. I join the call on the Council to provide a thorough written explanation.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to refuse discharge again to the Council due to lack of transparency in the finances and continued refusal to provide information in response to the Committee’s questions in the way in which other institutions and bodies regularly do. Discharge was already refused for the financial years 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In relation to the Consolidated Annual Accounts of the European Union for the financial year 2013, the European Court of Auditors presented its annual report on the implementation of the budget for the financial year 2013 and certified in a statement the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2013 and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. In its second report, Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control recommended that Parliament deny discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the Budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2013. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on discharge for the implementation of the general EU budget for the financial year 2013 is illustrative of the lack of cooperation and communication between the Council and Parliament, in particular in the council's failure to provide any explanation for the increasing level of underused appropriations and commitments carried over in its 2013 budget. It is important to note that the council's non-submission of the documents requested from Parliament essentially undermines the right of Union citizens to information and transparency. I believe that the Union institutions must be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union in relation to the funds entrusted to them as Union institutions. The European Council and the Council, as union institutions, should be subject to democratic accountability to union citizens, as they are beneficiaries of the general EU budget. I consider it essential that there is greater cooperation between Parliament and the Council in order to achieve effective budgetary control. I support the report's position in that it is not possible for Parliament to take a duly reasoned decision on the granting of discharge.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to deny discharge to the European Council and the Council of Ministers for the 2013 budget year, which I think is perfectly legitimate given that the Council refuses to cooperate and provide the European Parliament with information on the use of the appropriations. This puts the European Parliament in a position of inferiority and the Council in a different position from that of the other institutions, which is not justified. I therefore voted in favour of this critical text, which puts all institutions on an equal footing when it comes to controlling expenditure.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I regret that again the Council has refused to provide any explanation on the increasing underspending and carryovers of commitments in their 2013 budget. We agree with the Commission that all EU institutions should be subject to the Parliament’s discharge exercise. We insist that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which rejects budgetary discharge to the European Council and the Council for the 2013 financial year. The budgetary discharge, which can be granted, postponed or refused by the European Parliament, constitutes the final control of the annual budget. This process represents the political component of budget implementation control. It is based on the reports of the Court of Auditors and on the clarifications provided by the agencies concerned. The discharge decision may be accompanied by recommendations to improve certain aspects of budget implementation. With regard to the European Council and the Council, a large majority in the Committee on Budgetary Control felt that the lack of answers to the questions put forward by the European Parliament justified the refusal to grant this discharge. I voted in accordance with the opinion of this committee.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
