text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on the 2013 discharge of the European Union’s general budget.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE)
text: in writing. – For the seventh year the European Parliament postpones its decision for grating discharge for the Council. For the seventh year same questions have been raised and again more detailed information has been required. Many questions are left unanswered. With the Lisbon treaty, the European Parliament gained co-decision budget power and the other institutions should refer to that. My appeal is that rules should be applicable to everyone. We, the institutions should be an example for the MS. How can we expect integrity, accountability and fast reactions from them, if we don't fulfil the criteria ourselves? Our role is not only to talk the talk but to walk the walk to a better EU budget and results for the people in Europe.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The Council's general budget for 2013 included numerous items which, in my opinion, were unnecessary and which were already signs of overly careless use of financial resources at that time. In the end, this does not benefit the citizens of the Union, but is at their expense and is thus unsustainable. I voted against the budget because, in many places, the budget was not used in the interests of the citizens.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The activities of the EU institutions must be transparent and be responsible to EU citizens for the use of EU funds. The institutions must cooperate with each other in the discharge procedure, so far it is flawed with regard to the Council.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am very concerned here to stress the need for transparency not only on the part of the Council, but on the part of all the European institutions as regards their expenditure. Similarly, I believe that the level of control over each other and cooperation in the field of informing citizens must be high. Firm on my positions, I am voting in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Taking into account the Decision of the European Parliament of 29 October 2013, On 23 April 2015 on the discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013 and the Resolution with comments that are an integral part of that Decision, and accordingly the European Parliament's decision to postpone the 2013 discharge vote, I agree that the Council must make the same effort in the annual discharge procedure, as well as the other institutions.  I also consider the separation of the Council and the European Council budget very important, as this can certainly contribute to better transparency and also to increasing the accountability of both institutions. It is for these reasons that I supported this decision rejecting the resolution for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Part II - the European Council and the Council, and an accompanying resolution explaining the reason for the rejection of the sentence. I hope that the message sent by the European Parliament will encourage the Council and the European Council to address the outstanding issues on which the European Parliament insists.  I would like to recall that Article 15(3) of sub-paragraph 3 of the TFEU establishes that each institution, body, office or agency ensures the transparency of its conduct. Parliament asks only that council expenditure be monitored in the same way as those of other institutions, and that key elements of this scrutiny have been identified over the past years.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This Czarnecki report aims to deny discharge to the European Council and the Council of Ministers for the 2013 budget year. This seems to me to be perfectly legitimate, given that the Council refuses to cooperate and provide the European Parliament with information on the use of the appropriations. This puts the European Parliament in a position of inferiority and the Council in a different position from that of the other institutions, which is not justified. I therefore voted in favour of this critical text, which puts all institutions on an equal footing when it comes to controlling expenditure.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Parliament's refusal to grant a statement to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the Budget of the European Council and the Council, notably for persisting in the opaqueness in finances and in refusing to provide relevant information to the Budget Committee. The Council did not provide any explanation for the increase in unused funds and the transfers carried out in the Council budget for 2013, and its refusal to provide Parliament with the requested documents undermines the right of Union citizens to information and transparency.  The Council should provide an exhaustive written explanation specifying the total amount of appropriations used for the purchase of the Résidence Palace building and the budget items from which those funds were transferred, and information should be made public on the process of modernisation of its own administration and on the expected impact on its budget. Council spending must be monitored in the same way as that of other institutions, as set out in the resolutions on resolutions from previous years.  Since Parliament is the only directly elected body in the Union by citizens and is responsible for making a solution in relation to the implementation of the general budget of the European Union, it is necessary that it acts in accordance with its duties in order to maintain transparency and democratic accountability towards the citizens of the European Union, its taxpayers.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided not to support the granting of budgetary discharge to the European Council and the Council for 2013. The two institutions have breached the principles of transparency for several times and have not provided explanations on a number of serious facts. For example, the Council refused to inform the European Parliament of past and future costs and expenditure relating to buildings, and in particular the costly Residence Palace project. Furthermore, it has not yet explained the increasing level of unused funds, carry-overs of commitments and the state of modernisation of governance in these institutions. The European Parliament is an institution which has the exclusive right to grant discharge. If the Council is going to ignore this fact, it is as if it undermines the democratic principles on which the European Union is founded. In the event that the European Parliament does not have sufficient information, it will not be able to exercise that power. It is inconceived that, at a time when the European budget is being stretched to the last thread and when most taxpayers are in a difficult financial situation, member states' representatives should behave so irresponsibly. The European Council and the Council must be subject to the same scrutiny that all other European institutions are subject to. I very much hope that this refusal to discharge both the European Council and the Council will lead to a more accommodating position on the sharing of information on the implementation of the general budget and that the necessary formal dialogue will be re-established as soon as possible.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal to refuse discharge in respect of the implementation of the General Budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013 concerning the European Council and the Council. Whereas all the Institutions of the Union should be as transparent as possible and fully accountable to citizens about the management of the funds entrusted to them; Taking into account the various agreements between the European Parliament and the Council and taking note of the comments made by the Court of Auditors on this subject for the financial year 2013 concerning doubts about the progress of certain real estate projects, I agree with the requests of the Court of Auditors and the European Parliament. The latter consider it necessary, before granting discharge, to resolve certain outstanding issues which, to date, have not yet received an adequate response. I find it worrying that the Council has not submitted the required documents to Parliament. This behaviour is not in line with the principles of loyal interinstitutional cooperation, but above all undermines the citizens' right to information and transparency.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As in the previous few years, Parliament has not once again granted discharge to the Council. I find this moment worrying, and I think that there needs to be changes in this field that will bring about a settlement of this unsatisfactory situation for at least next year.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The Council and the European Council have not yet answered all of the European Parliament's questions regarding the implementation of the EU's general budget for the 2013 financial year. In this context, the European Parliament has decided to refuse the discharge. I voted for this decision and I expect the Council and the European Council to work more closely with Parliament.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 By giving discharge to an institution or agency, the European Parliament approves the proper use of the public money in budgetary implementation, achieved in compliance with regulations. Upon a recommendation from the Council, Members of the European Parliament are called upon to exercise control over the management of appropriations by deciding on discharge on the basis of the Court of Auditors' reports. Therefore, and after analysing the reports of the Court of Auditors and the Parliamentary Committee on Budgetary Control, I voted in favour of this Decision, which gives discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2013.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We will be voting against this discharge due to the fact that it is a resource that enables the EU to function and push its wider EU message to promote political objectives. Any form of ‘more EU’ will be confronted by us and certainly will be questioned in relation to funding and finance. There are calls to have updates relating to administrative modernisation and ascertain information on building projects.  The EU is seeking to update the rules on granting discharge in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, and expects Parliament to meet the criteria of the rules before discharge is granted.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution which refuses to discharge the implementation of the European Council and Council budget for 2013. Our Assembly has a right of budgetary control which it exercises through the discharge, a procedure by which we close the EU's budgetary exercise for a given year. It aims to ensure that European public funds are used properly by EU institutions and bodies. However, we face systematic difficulties during the Council's discharge procedures, due to a lack of cooperation on the part of the Council, particularly in the transmission of information and the requested explanations. For example, we refused to give discharge to the Council for the 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012 and now 2013 financial years.  Such an attitude by the Council is regrettable, especially since it constitutes an infringement of the right to information and transparency towards the citizens of the Union.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report and, therefore, against granting discharge to the European Council and the Council since, as the report of the Committee on Budgetary Control once again shows, Parliament does not have the information to do so. We must regret the continuing difficulties that have arisen in the discharge procedures to date, due to a lack of cooperation on the part of the Council. It should be recalled in this regard that Parliament refused to approve the management of the Secretary-General of the Council in the implementation of the 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012 budgets.  Council expenditure must be monitored in the same way as that of the other institutions, as a prerogative of Parliament, in accordance with Articles 316, 317 and 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.  The failure to present the requested documents to Parliament first affects the right to information and transparency of European citizens and, as the report points out, is a worrying symptom of a certain lack of democracy in the Union institutions.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Like a large majority of my colleagues, I have decided to vote in favour of the Czarnecki report and, therefore, to refuse the granting of discharge to the Secretary General of the Council on the implementation of the European Council and Council budget for the 2013 financial year. I voted in favour of refusing to grant this discharge because I believe it is the Council's duty to be as transparent as it is about the funds entrusted to it. In addition, I note that the Council has provided no explanation for the progress of the under-utilization of appropriations and deferrals of commitments in its 2013 budget. Finally, I can only deplore the systematic difficulties encountered during the discharge procedures. Indeed, I should recall that Parliament refused to grant discharge to the Secretary General of the Council for the 2009,2010, 2011 and 2012 financial years. In view of all these elements, it was not possible for me to vote in favour of granting discharge to the Secretary General of the Council.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which again refuses to grant discharge to the European Council and the Council.  This text reminds us that it is necessary to consider different options for amending the rules for granting discharge in the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union. Indeed, I supported this text because it is necessary to update these rules. Moreover, it is regrettable that while Parliament has already invited the European Council and the Council to engage in an open and formal dialogue with the other institutions, the Council has not responded to the requests made.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the general budget of the European Union – European Council and Council as I support the European Parliament's decision to refuse discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the financial year 2013.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have decided to vote in favour of not approving the management of the Council and the Council of the EU. The Council refuses to provide the necessary elements in order to be able to properly examine the Council's expenditure. There have been systematic difficulties encountered in the Council approval procedure to date due to lack of cooperation; Parliament refused to approve management in 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012, and was postponed in 2013. Without faithful information, the EP is unable to make an informed decision to approve the accounts.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of not approving management in the implementation of the budget of the Council and the European Council for 2013. This is not the first time this has happened, since the Council refuses to present to the European Parliament those elements necessary for us to exercise our right to count. Because of this lack of cooperation which undermines the principle of transparency, I voted in favour of Parliament's position, so as not to approve the management in the implementation of the Council and European Council budget for the 2013 financial year.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it is spending vast amounts of UK taxpayers’ money, and this should be decided in the UK Parliament.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 There were repetition difficulties in discharge procedures. The European Council did not cooperate with the European Parliament and did not enter into an appropriate dialogue. That is also why I voted in favour of not granting discharge.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the 2013 general budget discharge for 2013 for the European Council and the Council, including with a warning of outstanding issues. In the resolution, we call on the Council to present reports on the progress of real estate projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs incurred. We also invited the Council to provide a thorough written explanation detailing the total amount of appropriations used to purchase the Residence Palace building, the budget lines from which the funds and instalments that have been paid so far and which have yet to be paid have been drawn down. The Council is to report on its administrative modernisation procedure, in particular as regards the specific implementing measures relating to this process and the anticipated impact on the Council's budget. In the resolution, we regretted the problems that recur in the discharge procedures, which arose as a result of the Lack of cooperation on the part of the Council.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Europe faces complex challenges in the areas of foreign affairs, migration and security. And as a result, the Council is becoming more and more operational in its operation, and this has implications for its budget as well. For 2016, despite the overall downs in the European budget, we are depricing the Council of more resources for its operation.  It has been six months since Parliament postponed the granting of discharge to the Council. Unfortunately, we have still not received any information that would allow us to make a competent assessment of the implementation of its budget. In addition, we are once again about the interpretation of the 1970 friendly agreement. It's high time we cut this bureaucratic game. We cannot simply prolong this agreement indefinitely. Over the last 45 years, Europe has changed dramatically. Today, more than ever, citizens expect spending transparency and accountability.  Parliament's report definitively refuses to grant discharge to the Council, and I believe that this is the only right move, which is why I voted to support it. Since it is not enough to react only in a backward way, we must properly sanction this problem in the 2016 budget.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. I regret that again the Council has refused to provide any explanation on the increased underspending and carryovers of commitments in their 2013 budget. We agree with the Commission that all EU institutions should be subject to Parliament’s discharge exercise. We insist that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. For the seventh year in a row, the April Plenary Session postponed the dismissive period for the European Council and the Council, whose refusal is requested again with this report. The rapporteur considers it necessary to consider alternative options to update the approval of the notified by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). Furthermore, it is considered that an open and formal dialogue between Parliament and the Council would send a positive message to the citizens of the Union. Without prejudice, the rapporteur regrets that the Council has not in the meantime offered answers to questions and requests from this and previous discharge procedures. I fully support this report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2013 discharge for the EU general budget - European Council and Council. I support the 2013 discharge, but I am concerned about some of the outstanding issues. We are facing a lack of citizens' trust in the European Union and its institutions, so it is necessary to be very careful and vigilant in all practices. I agree with the view in the report that the non-handing of the requested documents to Parliament by the Council undermines, in particular, the right of Union citizens to information and transparency and is becoming a cause for concern, as it is evidence of a certain democratic deficit in the Union institutions.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not all the actions required for the closure of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II – European Council and Council have been completed

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The discharge report of the European Council and Council in the financial year 2013 repeats similar trends from past years, regarding the budgetary transparency of the Council. Since 2009, the Council refused to provide information on its dealing with finances, particularly on its increasing underspending and carry—overs of commitments in their 2013 budget. The current report reminds the Council that all institutions are fully part of the follow-up process to the observations made by Parliament in the discharge exercise, and that all EU Institutions should cooperate to ensure the smooth functioning of the discharge procedure. It further emphasises the Parliament’s prerogative to grant discharge to each heading of the budget individually in order to maintain transparency and democratic accountability towards taxpayers. Lastly, the report insists that the expenditure of the Council must be scrutinised in the same way as that of other institutions and that the fundamental elements of such scrutiny have been laid down in its discharge resolutions of the past years. I believe it is unacceptable for the Council to conduct itself in such matter, particularly in the post Lisbon Treaty, when the Parliament's powers have increased. This is why I voted against granting discharge to the Council in 2013.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the discharge text. The result of a consensual compromise between the political groups, the agreement was voted on by a large majority.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision and a resolution pertaining to the EU general budget. As a result of the decision, the Secretary-General of the Council is refused the grant of discharge in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2013. The resolution insists that an effective budgetary control exercise requires cooperation between Parliament and the Council and make several calls to the Council. It asks for a thorough written explanation detailing the total amount of appropriations used in the purchase of the ‘Residence Palace’ building and for information on Council’s process of administrative modernisation.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. The second report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II – European Council and Council, was supported.  Parliament's decision not to grant discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council in respect of the implementation of the budget of the European Council and of the Council for the financial year 2013 is correct, as I believe that the Council should pass on the required documents to Parliament and, by not doing so, undermines, in particular, the right of Union citizens to information and transparency and is becoming a cause for concern, as it is witnessing a democratic deficit in the EU institutions.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have decided to vote in favour of not approving the management of the Council and the Council of the EU. The Council refuses to provide the necessary elements in order to be able to properly examine the Council's expenditure. There have been systematic difficulties encountered in the Council approval procedure to date due to lack of cooperation; Parliament refused to approve management in 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012, and was postponed in 2013. Without faithful information, the EP is unable to make an informed decision to approve the accounts.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since all the institutions of the Union must be transparent and accountable to European citizens with regard to the funds entrusted to them as eu institutions, I supported the report, in agreement with the recommendations made in this regard.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We have decided to vote in favour of not approving the management of the Council and the Council of the EU. The Council refuses to provide the necessary elements in order to be able to properly examine the Council's expenditure. There have been systematic difficulties encountered in the Council approval procedure to date due to lack of cooperation; Parliament refused to approve management in 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012, and was postponed in 2013. Without faithful information, the EP is unable to make an informed decision to approve the accounts.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the decision on the discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II, and on the resolution with observations forming an integral part of the decision on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II.  The text acknowledges that all Union institutions ought to be transparent and fully accountable to the citizens of the Union for the funds entrusted to them as Union institutions and that, whereas Parliament is the sole directly elected body among the Union institutions, it has responsibility to grant discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union. At the same time I believe it is necessary to stress that the Council continues to fail to provide answers to Parliament’s questions and this needs to be improved.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. For the seventh consecutive year, the April plenary postponed discharge. In the report, the rapporteur proposes to refuse again the discharge of the European Council and the Council in the implementation of the budget, as this Parliament has not had an answer to the questions asked to the Council both in this and in previous years. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of this report which reasonedly rejects discharge.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the decision not to grant discharge to the Council: this is the seventh year in a row that the European Parliament has decided to send out this politically strong signal against the Council's decision not to recognise Parliament's role in the discharge procedure. In essence, the Council refuses to answer the questions that Parliament sends to all the institutions and bodies of the European Union on the reporting of expenditure. In this way, the Council denies european citizens access to data on its administrative expenditure, effectively ruling out the possibility of democratic control over the use of European citizens' money. Parliament is the only directly elected body and one of its tasks is precisely to grant discharge after checking that expenditure is correct. Not recognising its role means diminishing all European citizens in their democratic role as voters.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of not approving management in the implementation of the budget of the Council and the European Council for 2013. This is not the first time this has happened, since the Council refuses to present to the European Parliament those elements necessary for us to exercise our right to count. Because of this lack of cooperation which undermines the principle of transparency, I voted in favour of Parliament's position, so as not to approve the management in the implementation of the Council and European Council budget for the 2013 financial year.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament, once again, refuses to discharge the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council for the same reasons as always. Much is said about "transparency" and much is required in this matter (some) of the Member States, particularly in budgetary and economic policy. However, the Council, the EU's supranational decision-making body involving representatives of the governments of the different Member States, appears to be immune to such "requirements", as since 2010 it has not responded to the questions and clarification requirements, either on the increasing level of underused appropriations and commitments carried over in its 2013 budget, either on the state of progress of the real estate projects and on a detailed breakdown of the costs recorded to date. Once again, council expenditure is left unexamined by the only institution elected by direct suffrage, responsible for the discharge decision for the implementation of the general EU budget, in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The resolution clearly sets out the problems of discharge for the Council: it must become more democratic and more open in its handling of its expenditure, and above all renounce the practice of wanting to reduce the budget again and again, and then massively increase it again in retrospect for various projects. I therefore support the report.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because the Council does not guarantee the necessary transparency in providing financial information and reporting expenditure, as the other institutions do.  Parliament has asked the Council to provide detailed information on the progress of real estate projects and the management of expenditure incurred so far, but has not received a reply. Transparency, in these cases, is an essential value.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the European Parliament's resolution on discharge for the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section II - European Council and Council. Like the report, I reject any discharge for the implementation of the budget. Difficulties are repeatedly encountered in this procedure. The Council does not cooperate with Parliament, nor does it enter into dialogue with it. Parliament has refused to exonerate the Secretary-General.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 For the seventh consecutive year, the European Parliament has proposed, in the first instance, to postpone the granting of discharge to the Council's budget. The report confirms that Parliament is not in a position to take an informed decision on granting discharge and therefore calls for discharge not to be granted to the Council.  The diatribe, which is still legally 'obscure', mainly concerns the fact that the Council does not recognise Parliament's role as the ultimate discharge referent and therefore refuses to reply to Parliament's questionnaire on the reporting of expenditure.  The report starts by pointing out that the Council has not provided any explanation for the increasing level of under-utilised appropriations and commitments carried over in its 2013 budget. In addition to raising the issue of administrative transparency, the Council's attention is also drawn to the need to make costs for the 'Europe' and 'Residence Palace' buildings transparent.  That is why I think it is right to refuse discharge to the Council.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have decided to support the refusal to grant the discharge for the year 2013 to the European Council and the Council. The institutions have not been granted the discharge for several years now and rightly so. I consider it unacceptable that one of the main European Institutions, whose decisions influence millions of people in Europe, does not act in a clear and transparent manner, lacks integrity and considers itself to be above the Union’s rules. The Council and the European Council have repeatedly refused to cooperate with the discharge authority, they ignore the questions posed by the authority with regard to regularity of their budget implementation, they are unwilling to reveal the expenses related to their building projects and they were not able to adopt the internal whistleblowing rules. Therefore, I voted against the discharge for the Council and the European Council and I urge the institution to take this matter rather seriously.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. As it has been almost a habit, Parliament has once again refused to give discharge to the Secretary-General of the Council for the implementation of the budget of the European Council and the Council, while maintaining the reasons previously mentioned.  Much is said about "transparency", particularly in budgetary and economic policy. However, the Council, the EU supranational decision-making body that integrates representatives of the governments of the different Member States, appears to be immune to such "requirements", as since 2010 it has not responded to the questions and requirements for clarification, either on the increasing level of underused appropriations and commitments carried over in its 2013 budget, and on the state of progress of real estate projects and a detailed breakdown of the costs recorded to date. We voted in favour of refusing to give discharge.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Analyzing the recent Ebola epidemic that broke out in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia, i applaud the international NGOs, who immediately realized the seriousness of the situation by taking the front line to fight the virus that was spreading. The rest of the world has stood by and watched, probably hoping that the outbreaks will go out on their own. The late intervention caused thousands of deaths and, as we can well remember, a risk of infection that went beyond Africa's borders. At the moment, the interventions imposed by the IMF and the World Bank only worsen an already tragic situation because, in fact, they require budget cuts in the public sector, for example in health. The cost of dealing with humanitarian emergencies is far greater than the investments that can avoid them. The report calls for lessons to be learned from this experience of the Ebola virus and denounces the unjustifiable international silence. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the impact of Ebola on impoverished countries as it seems to us to introduce a number of elements which allow us to place the cause of the problem and how to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future. First, it welcomes the work of non-governmental organizations and negatively the response of governments and international institutions. Second, the effect of the International Monetary Fund's adjustment plans and illegitimate debts to southern countries on their health systems are recognized. It also condemns the monopoly of large pharmaceutical companies on patents that prevent universal access to medicines and the importance of universal access to health, calling for a new model of research and development based on principles of equality and solidarity. For all this, we have supported a Resolution that includes the right to public health and the need for fair trade to make access to medicines available to all.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report to establish a post-Ebola action plan by strengthening health systems in developing countries. The text also stresses the need for the EU to promote effective and equitable funding in medical research and innovation, and calls for special attention to women who are often more vulnerable to the virus through their professional activities. This report therefore goes in the right direction because it advocates the development of local infrastructure to prevent epidemics and thus develop a more efficient health system. It also aims to reinvigorate the economies of these countries to allow them more autonomy in the management of health crises.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very good report criticising the slow response from national governments and the WHO to the Ebola crisis last year and proposing measures to ensure developing countries are equipped to deal with a similar scenario in future. It identifies the structural adjustment programmes imposed on third-world countries, and their resulting debt and reduced investment in public services, as a key contributing factor to the crisis, and calls for increased investment in national and global health systems. It also welcomes the creation of an effective vaccine this year and calls for it to be affordable and accessible to every person in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia.  I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that the Ebola virus crisis should be a lesson for the whole of Europe in order to promote investment in the health of third countries and to help third countries such as Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea strengthen their economies and promote development themselves in their countries. Although Ebola may now be absent from the news headlines, all those involved must assume their responsibilities in the post-Ebola era.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to learn from the Ebola crisis. In particular, it insists that health infrastructure in West Africa be developed and modernised. For this reason, I voted for this resolution although I regret the tendency of this text to over-dramatize the Ebola crisis, as if the health problems facing African countries were new.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for urgent guarantees of access to the new vaccine, which has proven to be 100% effective in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone. Caution is always the order of the day. The disease is not completely eradicated due to the complex nature of the virus.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution addresses and defends many of the principles I have been advocating in the field of the European Union's foreign policy. As the world's most important player in development and humanitarian aid, he has a special responsibility to promote the right of universal access to health care, requiring that he be one step ahead of all other actors. I think it is extremely important that, in this context, the European Union seeks to act on two fronts: on the one hand, in terms of development aid, which includes essential investments in the field of health, and, on the other hand, in terms of the indispensable assistance for the economic recovery of the countries most affected by the Ebola epidemic. Because I see these and other aspects in this text, I will vote in favour and hope that it will be adopted.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on Ebola. As of March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been the biggest victims of the Ebola epidemic that mankind has ever seen. The current Ebola crisis has raised structural weaknesses in several countries, reminding those responsible in the European Union that it is necessary to abide by the determination of at least 20% of their public assistance to develop key social sectors, in particular health.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report analyses the history and consequences of the epidemic in the three West African countries affected, where the Ebola virus has caused a serious humanitarian crisis. It is important to support the reform and structural design of the health systems of the three countries, both internationally and globally. I do not believe that the European Union should solve this problem alone by desicing a larger amount from the common budget to finance the health infrastructure, staffing and training and salaries of these countries. At the same time, it is important to point out the serious responsibilities of the IMF and the World Bank, since an important condition for lending to help these countries was the need to minimise health spending and structural developments. It is time for these organisations to provide real support for the development of health systems. In view of the amendments adopted, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I did not object to this report, although it is based on many erroneous principles, in this case those of its rapporteur, the Luxembourg liberal Charles Goerens.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this resolution, which stresses the need to deploy additional resources to help the most affected countries, particularly Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. Even if the epidemic seems to be coming to an end, the events of the last few months must remind the Union and its Member States of the need to help the development of social and medical services in these countries, which cannot cope alone with an Ebola epidemic.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I have positioned myself in favour of this report, which is a good move in the face of the management of the Ebola crisis, i.e. towards the promotion of long-term solutions for a development objective. The text aims to establish an action plan after the epidemic, based in particular on strengthening the health systems of developing countries, particularly for the countries most affected by the virus, i.e. Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. To do this, investments must first focus on the establishment of social security and public health systems while emphasizing the expansion of the necessary medical training and care infrastructure. Moreover, a genuine investment effort in research and innovation is essential to the development of these countries. Lucid, rapporteur Charles Goerens recalls the Commission's mismanagement of this crisis, which has only taken the measure of things too late.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the Ebola epidemic that has hit Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea hard, I support Mr Goerens' report, which calls on the European Union to help African countries with development and economic recovery measures to prevent a repetition of humanitarian disasters such as Ebola. That is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Ebola crisis mainly affects countries living in extreme poverty and vulnerability, with almost non-existent health systems. The European Union, as a world leader in development, has a responsibility and duty to promote the right to universal health care. The key pillars of this cooperation are based on ensuring WHO financial support, promoting effective and fair R&D funding and dissociating these costs from the final price of medicines, strengthening national health systems and facilitating universal access to health and medicines, as well as supporting the establishment of a regional infectious disease research centre in West Africa. We must stress the vital importance for the countries most affected by this crisis— Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea — of receiving aid in order to launch their economies. Finally, this report calls for a lack of funding for humanitarian action, especially investment in the health sector, and thus to build the recovery capacity of the affected countries. That is why I supported this report.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it seeks to assess the Ebola crisis and to understand the long-term lessons and to identify ways to strengthen health systems in developing countries in order to prevent future crises. In the report, parliament is therefore critical of the slow international response to the crisis in its first months, but notes the actions and commitments made by the EU and its Member States since March 2014 to help halt the spread of Ebola. Parliament welcomed the creation of a new vaccine in record time, 100% effective in vaccination in Guinea since 23 March 2015, and calls for the availability of this vaccine at an affordable price for all persons in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Finally, Parliament called on all relevant countries, in particular the governments of developing countries, european institutions and international organisations, to learn from this crisis, as well as to take into account the negative impact of the IMF and World Bank structural adjustment programmes on the health sector in developing countries, and to develop effective international health crisis management measures.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although media attention to the Ebola crisis and the epidemic is waning, we cannot lower our guard in the face of a virus that continues to take victims and from whose management, above all, we must learn many lessons.  The management of the epidemic by local health services and international institutions has shown us how much more work remains to be done to achieve effective health systems in the countries most affected by the disease, how necessary it is to fill the existing structural deficiencies in prevention, hygiene standards, medical infrastructure and equipment, sufficient and adequately trained health personnel. , as well as access to medicines and basic health care.  The EU has long been at the forefront of the commitment to universal health coverage, and the report we have voted on continues in this direction, reiterating its desire to allocate at least 20% of development aid to basic social services, including health as a priority.  Of course, it is also crucial that the Commission and the international community undertake to coordinate and strengthen parallel efforts in the research and production of effective medicines and vaccines not only against Ebola, but also against other infectious diseases that are life-threatening and likely to develop into further epidemics.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Ebola epidemic in West Africa in 2014 is the largest and most complex outbreak of this viral disease in history and has affected many countries and resulted in thousands of patients and deaths. More than 20,000 people are affected, notably in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone and the disease has spread from Africa to two other continents where isolated cases have been reported. The escalation of the epidemic has not only caused a health crisis that has claimed thousands of lives, but also social and economic pressure and political instability in the affected countries and the wider region. I call on all participants, in particular the governments of developing countries, European institutions and international organisations to draw lessons from this crisis, and to develop effective methods to combat health crises of international proportions.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very good report criticising the slow response from national governments and the WHO to the Ebola crisis last year and proposing measures to ensure developing countries are equipped to deal with a similar scenario in future. It identifies the structural adjustment programmes imposed on third-world countries, and their resulting debt and reduced investment in public services, as a key contributing factor to the crisis, and calls for increased investment in national and global health systems. It also welcomes the creation of an effective vaccine this year and calls for it to be affordable and accessible to every person in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia.  I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I am convinced that the Ebola crisis, although it has ultimately been adequately addressed, especially as regards the containment of the epidemic to the African continent alone, has, however, brought to light the shortcomings of the international response. It is therefore important that we learn the right lessons in order to improve our response capacity in order to prevent a repeat of disasters of this kind in the future.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been victims since March 2014 of the most serious Ebola outbreak in recent history. The lack of sanitation, proper information and border control has encouraged the spread of the virus in the area.  We cannot ignore the fact that all three countries involved are characterised by severe poverty, as is seen both by the UNDP's low human development index and by the average life expectancy of less than 60 years. Social distress and poverty affect more than 80% of the population and schooling rarely exceeds 3 years of walking. The extreme vulnerability to the epidemic of the populations of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea is therefore due to the seriousness of the situation of their countries.  It is therefore clear that they cannot emerge from the crisis on their own. The European Union not only has a moral duty to support them, but also has an interest in striving to stop epidemics which, if neglected, would spread uncontrollably outside their areas of origin at obvious additional human and economic costs.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to implement a post-Ebola action plan to strengthen the health system of the least developed countries, especially those most affected by this epidemic such as Sierra Leone, Liberia or Guinea, in which this goal must become the budgetary priority of national authorities.  The rapporteur focuses on two points in particular, namely the training of qualified staff and the construction of quality infrastructure. It also advocates helping these states to fund medical research and supporting administrations in their role of supporting and supporting local populations, especially women who are more vulnerable to this type of endemicity.  We believe it is our duty to help African countries overcome the health crises they face, in particular with the aim of securing the populations on the ground. In order to do this, it is essential to support them on the ground so that the funds granted directly benefit the inhabitants of the regions concerned. So I voted for this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ebola epidemic first occurred in the sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea, which are the most affected states, where the average life expectancy does not exceed 60 years, schooling rarely lasts more than three years, and about 80% of the citizens of these states live in extreme poverty. These indicators show the vulnerability of populations in these states that cannot go through this crisis alone. The European Parliament's mission is to oversee executive power, assume the role of legislator and give political impulses as a world leader in development. It also has a special responsibility to promote the right of universal access to healthcare.  The current Ebola crisis has revealed the structural weaknesses that still persist in some countries, but at the same time underlines the need for EU leaders to meet their goals of allocating at least 20% of public aid to the development of basic social sectors, giving priority in particular to health. That is why I voted in favour of the report, wanting to stand in solidarity with the states affected by this destructive virus.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The report calls on the Commission to help the countries affected develop their public health systems so that they are able to respond to basic health needs and provide themselves with the necessary infrastructure to ensure that all their citizens have access to public health.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the Ebola crisis, which contains the long-term lessons to prevent future crises and to facilitate the development of a long-term strategy to help the hardest-hit countries plan an effective and rapid mechanism for reacting to health emergencies.  Strengthening national health systems is the only realistic and effective strategy that can prevent unexpected effects of infection, such as Ebola, and the emergence of such emergencies in the future. The Ebola crisis, with its enormous burden of death and suffering, has highlighted the structural gaps that exist in many countries and also reminded us of the responsibilities of the European Union, which realised the seriousness of the situation too late.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which criticises the slow response from national governments and the WHO to the Ebola crisis last year, proposing measures to ensure developing countries are equipped to deal with a similar scenario in the future.  This report identifies the structural adjustment programmes imposed on third-world countries, and their resulting debt and reduced investment in public services, as a key contributing factor to the crisis, and calls for increased investment in national and global health systems. It also welcomes the creation of an effective vaccine this year and calls for it to be affordable and accessible to every person in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because it provides lessons learned on the Ebola crisis and ways on how to improve our help to developing counties in order to strengthen their healthcare systems. The latest epidemic also showed us how little we know about the virus and that we need to focus more on research in this area.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to see the experience of the Ebola virus as a lesson, in order to be able to provide ready answers in similar cases in the future. Indeed, if, in the present case, international NGOs – including Emergency – have shown great responsiveness, the same cannot be said of the Union and, in general, of the international community. The slowness is at the root of many thousands of deaths.  I voted strongly in favour of this report.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome today's adoption of the resolution on the Ebola crisis. Now that we are starting to see the end of this epidemic, we need to take on responsibilities to help the countries that have been affected by this tragic disease. By implementing development aid measures we can support the social and healthcare systems, particularly in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. These countries are ones recorded to be at the bottom of the United Nations Development Programme human development index. Their health and education systems are severely disrupted and the Ebola crisis has left the population in seriously vulnerable conditions.  Even though the news are not reporting about the situation on the ground as often as it used to, it does not mean that the problems are resolved, far from it. The Ebola crisis has set these countries back economically at least 5 to 10 years.  The repercussions of non-functioning health and education systems will lead to further poverty, deprivation and a continued threat to global public health. This will no doubt have a knock-on effect on migration towards other African and EU countries.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's report stresses that it is very likely that a food crisis will follow after this Ebola epidemic. It therefore calls on the Member States, the Commission and the international community to invest in long-term development to ensure that rural households and the future food security of West Africa are not threatened. All interested parties are also strongly and strongly called on to promote the training of citizens in health matters, focusing on the issue of traditional customs which are not consistent with combating the spread of the epidemic in the population.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I thought I was in favour of the report on the Ebola crisis. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been victims of the largest Ebola epidemic that humanity has ever known and which to date has 11 000 victims. The three countries in question rank last according to the UNDP Human Development Index.  Faced with these structural deficits, the international community has shown inexcusable shortcomings in global governance, taking too long to react. It was not until September 2014 that Christos Stylianides, the new Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, was given the mandate of the EU Coordinator on Ebola, the European Council showed the strong political will to come to terms with the difficult situation. The rapporteur points out that humanitarian NGOs, with their indisputable level of know-how, were the most effective players in the first months of the fight against the virus, proving better prepared than institutional actors to deal with the emergency.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I agree with the photograph taken by the rapporteur. It is clear that Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia cannot cope on their own. The complexity of the problem is an almost impossible challenge for these states, which have serious structural deficiencies in the field of health. Commissioner Stylianides has been tasked with tackling Ebola in research, innovation, crisis management and sending medical personnel to the area. Once the division of tasks has been established, I think it would be appropriate, as the EU, to evaluate post-Ebola as of now; The European Union must be on two levels: firstly, on development aid and secondly on aid for the economic recovery of the countries in question. I think that, in general, the crisis caused by the epidemic has also brought to light shortcomings in the European Union in terms of humanitarian aid; In this respect, I think it is very important to improve in order to get the EU's strength out of European borders.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report takes into account that children and young women have become seriously marginalised as a result of the Ebola crisis and that it has seriously threatened women’s engagement in the work force. Many orphaned children face barriers to education as a result of the crisis. They also face a regression in access to health care due to stigmatisation. The report notes the insufficient amount of healthcare staff in areas such as Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, and the deaths of almost 500 healthcare professionals as a result of the disease. For going forward it is imperative to provide more information and education on preventative measures. Education should also be used as a tool to break the barriers of stigmatisation faced by so many recovering patients, and/or children of those patients. The report calls on the international community to provide help in disseminating information that could lead to a greater awareness and prevent future outbreaks of the disease.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been victims of the most serious Ebola outbreak ever known.  At local, regional, national and global level, the Ebola crisis is systemic.  However, the international community has long understood the seriousness of the situation and react, with NGOs being more effective, better informed and better able to be on the front line in the fight against Ebola. I support this report, because I believe it is essential that, on the basis of this experience, we must start preparing the post-Ebola period now. In this sense, the European Union must act on two fronts: on the one hand, in terms of development aid, which includes essential investments in the field of health, and, on the other hand, in the indispensable assistance for the economic recovery of the three countries. The European Development Fund (EDF) programme for these three countries should be reassessed in the light of the multiple challenges created by the Ebola crisis. I welcome the EU's willingness to devote at least 20 % of public aid to the development of basic social sectors, giving priority to health.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ebola epidemic has disrupted the entire African region over the past two years, particularly Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. The international community intervened late, probably initially underestimating the real gravity of the crisis. Today we have understood that it is no longer possible to improvise but that some important structural gaps need to be filled. Firstly, we need to think about how best to make the best use of the capacities of humanitarian actors in the future, review EDF programming and also the CFP in order to adequately finance EU humanitarian actions, but above all fund, as has been done over the last two years, research projects aimed at combating Ebola through the development of vaccines, rapid diagnostic tests and clinical trials. We must also not forget that, in order to eradicate Ebola, it is not only the improvement of health systems that is sufficient, but also concrete support from the entire international community to deal with the threats to the economy and to political and social stability affecting the countries involved.  Having said that, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report highlights the important role played in the first months of the Ebola crisis by the various humanitarian NGOs (including MSF, Red Cross, Emergency and others) which have demonstrated not only the ability to interpret the serious situation, but have also been the most effective and operationally experienced actors, addressing the fight against Ebola on the front line. While NGOs have been shown to be responsive and timely, international institutions and organisations have shown ineffectiveness, inadequacy and slowness in mobilising aid. In addition, the absence of the WHO and the lack of research and development on drugs, diagnoses and vaccines have caused millions of deaths. The aim of the report is to see the experience of the Ebola virus as a lesson to enable immediate responses from the EU to be provided in the future; the preparation and experience on the ground of the various NGOs can be beneficial. The report also argues that strengthening national and regional health systems is an integral part of global health governance. For all these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the impact of Ebola on impoverished countries as it seems to us to introduce a number of elements which allow us to place the cause of the problem and how to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future. First, it welcomes the work of non-governmental organizations and negatively the response of governments and international institutions. Second, the effect of the International Monetary Fund's adjustment plans and illegitimate debts to southern countries on their health systems are recognized. It also condemns the monopoly of large pharmaceutical companies on patents that prevent universal access to medicines and the importance of universal access to health, calling for a new model of research and development based on principles of equality and solidarity. For all this, we have supported a Resolution that includes the right to public health and the need for fair trade to make access to medicines available to all.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The parliamentary report draws lessons from the Ebola crisis in Africa in 2014. The Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea in March 2014 was the largest crisis of its kind to date, challenging the African region concerned, but also the international community and European countries involved in dealing with the crisis. The report looks to the future in order to prevent epidemics with great loss of life and to provide rapid assistance. To this end, the EU should seek to improve health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with adequate tangible and personnel means for immediate response should be laid down. Investments in health promote economic development, making it an important factor in eradicating poverty. Among other things, the report calls on Member States to contribute to the establishment of the General Health Fund (UHC) and is confident that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with its investments. In agreement with the aims of the report, I supported the adoption of the report, following the people's party line.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which deals with Ebola and what Europe needs to do in the post-Ebola period. The post-Ebola stage will have been reached once there have been no more new cases for 42 days. Once this happens, the EU’s response will need to be twofold: first, development aid will need to include investment in health, and second, it will be vital for the three countries which were mostly affected to receive aid with a view to kick-starting their economies. I believe that all those involved must demonstrate the vision they need to enable them to assume their responsibilities in the period that follows.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report reflects on the post-Ebola period based on lessons learned during the Ebola crisis. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been the victims of the largest Ebola epidemic on record. This epidemic poses a real challenge for the three states whose health and education gaps are structural. The report makes a series of recommendations aimed at improving the response of the international community and the European Union to emergency aid. Considering that long-term support, through a development assistance plan focused on health investments, is also needed, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which deals with the lessons to be learned from the Ebola crisis. Parliament rightly criticises the slowness of the international community in dealing with this epidemic, as well as the fragility of its response. In particular, I would argue that, in addition to emergency aid, the European Union must provide development assistance to the health sector in the countries affected by the epidemic.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Ebola crisis has hit West Africa hard. The epidemic has killed more than 9,000 people and the World Health Organization (WHO) has just registered new cases in Guinea. In the face of this crisis, the international community's response has been too slow. We need to learn from that.  We need to put in place, at European level, a permanent rapid response mechanism to respond immediately to health crises. This mechanism should be able to mobilise, in a short time, experts and medical personnel with logistical means and mobile teams of rapid action.  Today, countries such as Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea do not have an adequate health system to deal with a pandemic of this magnitude and are dependent on international solidarity. It is therefore the responsibility of the European Union to help the affected populations.  We also need to focus on prevention. Many contaminations could have been prevented by following basic hygiene rules. This involves information and awareness campaigns across the affected territories and neighbouring territories.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, sierra leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for Europeans involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with the right tangible and personnel means for rapid response should be laid down. The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, making it an important factor in eradicating poverty. The report calls on member states to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with its investments. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is imperative to improve international governance in the management of health crises, especially as it is increasingly likely that a food crisis will occur as a result of this epidemic (an epidemic that has had devastating effects on smallholder farmers). This crisis served as a reminder to EU leaders of the need for them to remain true to their goal of allocating at least 20% of official aid to the development of basic social services, giving priority to health care. It has also shed light on the structural problems still well present in a number of countries. An important element in my opinion is access to medicines because at present two billion people around the world do not have access to the vaccines or treatments they need to stay alive and healthy. I believe that access to medicines and research and development in this area must be a priority to meet the needs of patients, whether they live here or in developing countries.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. March 2014 - The largest Ebola crisis to date has erupted in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for the European countries that have been involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with the right tangible and personnel means for rapid response should be laid down.  The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, thereby becoming an important factor in the eradication of poverty. The report calls on Member States to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with their investments. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ian Duncan (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in order to amend and increase the response rate of the EU during international crises, in particular in light of the recent Ebola crisis. As an international partner we need to continue to provide critical support to help staff treatment centres and labs, and help rebuild economies affected by this crisis.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I fully agree with the rapporteur that the international response to the humanitarian crisis has been ineffective and too slow. The EU needs to strengthen its role as an important development actor not only for humanitarian reasons, but also because it is also a problem of the European Neighbourhood Policy.  The prolonged state of insufficient structural funding and the lack of investment in public health is detrimental not only to local society, but also to society and economies in general. Because a so-called "local problem" is not adequately addressed, international actors are undermining not only humanitarian principles, but also causing further problems.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, as most of the adjustments and regulations and policies implemented in the past by the European Union have resulted in contributions to inefficient health systems as well as to incorrect management of funds, since they have resulted in unreliable NGOs, resulting in unnecessary waste of resources which, if properly and correctly allocated, would lead to tangible results in the fight against diseases such as Ebola. Therefore, because there is no transparent procedure to ensure that the money received by certain NGOs is properly allocated, we are obliged to vote against the report. What needs to be done to properly tackle diseases such as Ebola is better coordination and strengthening of Member States' health systems.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, sierra leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for Europeans involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with the right tangible and personnel means for rapid response should be laid down. The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, making it an important factor in eradicating poverty. The report calls on member states to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with its investments. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again.
