But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been victims of the most serious Ebola outbreak in human history. The permeability of borders has favored the passage of the virus from one country to another. The three countries concerned are among the last of the UNDP classification with regard to the human development index. Their average life expectancy does not exceed 60 years, schooling rarely exceeds three years and about 80% of its citizens live in extreme poverty. It is therefore clear that these three countries will not be able to solve the problem on their own.  The European Parliament remains true to its tradition and recalls that its mission is to control the executive power, exercise its prerogatives as legislators and give political impulses. As regards the fight against Ebola, the European Union must therefore address the challenges that are being addressed. I agree that the current Ebola crisis reveals the structural gaps that still exist in many countries and, on the other hand, reminds eu leaders of the need to persevere in their willingness to devote at least 20 % of official aid to the development of the basic social sectors, giving priority to health.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report analyses the Ebola crisis in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea-Conakry and seeks to draw lessons from it. The report is contradictory, including clearly positive aspects, others not so much, and also some negative aspects. It is important that, for the first time, the disastrous effects of IMF and World Bank interventions on the deterioration of the health and education systems of these and other most vulnerable countries are recognised. Positive recommendations are made regarding increased development aid by the EU and its Member States, the need to reorient the priorities of the European Development Fund, aswelling them to the real priorities of these countries (public services, in particular health, support for small production, family farming, among others), and access to medicines, pointing out the problem of the "patent dictatorship". But the report is not always coherent in defending universal and free access to health services. If in some paragraphs this need is made explicit, in others more ambiguous formulations such as "comprehensive" services are chosen. On the other hand, the model of public-private partnerships, advocated for the area of medicines, overlaps with the desirable preponderance of a strong public capacity in this area. In recognizing the efforts of countries and organizations to combat the epidemic, there is a lack of an indispensable reference to Cuba.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. The Ebola virus crisis has demonstrated the need to strengthen cooperation with developing countries beyond the emergency aid that can be provided at the height of the health crises in these countries.  Thus, the European Union's action must be at the level of development cooperation, in order to strengthen local health systems, a necessary condition on the other hand to contribute to the reduction of poverty. I therefore voted in favour of the report, convinced that it is necessary to lay the foundations for long-term cooperation capable of preventing future crises, with an emphasis on strengthening local health systems, in order to help give these countries a greater degree of autonomy in the management of such crises.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because it  welcomes international efforts to alleviate the international debt burden of the countries affected by Ebola.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been struggling with the worst Ebola crisis in history. It is more than obvious that these three countries will not cope with this epidemic on their own and the peoples of the countries concerned have been put in an extremely vulnerable situation. As a world leader in development, the European Union has a special responsibility in establishing and improving the healthcare system in the countries concerned. Even if we can successfully combat the Ebola epidemic, it is very important that we also think about health development, investment in health and the development of the economy in the countries concerned. Cooperation between the European Union and the African countries concerned can only be successful if there is a rapid development of the economy and healthcare.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which provides for measures to help Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea, which are victims of the largest Ebola epidemic ever experienced.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report, as most of the adjustments and regulations and policies implemented in the past by the European Union have resulted in contributions to inefficient health systems as well as to incorrect management of funds, since they have resulted in unreliable NGOs, resulting in unnecessary waste of resources which, if properly and correctly allocated, would lead to tangible results in the fight against diseases such as Ebola. Therefore, because there is no transparent procedure to ensure that the money received by certain NGOs goes in the right direction and not in the pockets of some deft ones, I am obliged to vote against the report. What needs to be done to properly tackle diseases such as Ebola is better coordination and strengthening of Member States' health systems.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the lessons from the Ebola crisis in the hope that institutions can be better prepared in future. In times of cross-border crises an international response is needed to facilitate help in conjunction with Member States. Therefore, we must build upon our reaction to Ebola in order to save more lives in the future.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Ebola crisis was possible due to shortcomings in the health systems of the affected countries, and has therefore both highlighted the structural problems that are still to be found in a number of countries and served as a reminder to EU leaders of the need for them to stay true to their goal of allocating at least 20% of official assistance to the development of basic social services, giving priority to healthcare. In the future, we must make sure that our investments are carefully planned and are targeting the real needs. We need to start discussing the ways in which the best use can be made of the humanitarian organisations’ capabilities in the future. Moreover, it will be vital for the three countries to receive aid with a view to kick-starting their economies.  All actors involved must demonstrate the vision and assume their responsibilities in the next months, even though Ebola faded from the news headlines a long while ago.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, sierra leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for the European countries that have been involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with the right tangible and personnel means for rapid response should be laid down.  The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, thereby becoming an important factor in the eradication of poverty. The report calls on Member States to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with their investments. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. Not even two years after the outbreak of the devastating epidemic that has dramatically affected West Africa, it is time for a thorough reflection on the socio-economic actions that Europe can take to facilitate post-emergency socio-economic recovery in the most affected territories and on the need to develop a ready and long-term health action plan capable of dealing with any warning that may arise in the coming years in EU or third countries. The appointment of the EU Coordinator for Ebola was a strong signal of Europe's commitment to international health care actions, but Europe must now be forward-looking and concrete, investing in post-Ebola development plans for the territories most affected by the virus – Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia – by specifically providing for special reprogramming in the European Development Fund.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr Goerens' report on the Ebola crisis: the long-term lessons and how to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises.  The Ebola epidemic has shown that the health systems of some African countries, including Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea in particular, are completely incapable of responding adequately to any type of health emergency and it is clear that it is not possible to guarantee the population even an adequate minimum level of medical care.  Despite the serious delays in understanding the seriousness of the emergency by international bodies, the mobilisation and commitment of the European Union meant that the epidemic was almost completely eradicated and that it did not have even more serious consequences in the rest of the world.  After the emergency phase, I believe it is essential to open a phase of reflection at international level, taking into account development aid aimed at the health sector and the organisation of health systems in the African countries most affected by epidemics.  Finally, I reiterate the need to invest in scientific research into rare and neglected diseases and to guarantee access to medicines regardless of income as well as universal health coverage.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report 'The Ebola crisis: long-term lessons and measures to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises', as I welcome the approach of a detailed review of the experience. As the author of a similar report in the ACP delegation, I call, among other things, for a halt to the medical brain drain from developing countries, for much more EU involvement in the development of comprehensive medical care in the countries concerned, and for the establishment of 'emergency centres' around the globe to guarantee faster intervention.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The Ebola crisis has highlighted how quickly diseases can spread from remote areas to Europe. It has also been shown that there are still diseases that cannot yet be adequately combated. This requires active support from the European Union.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is time that we learn a few things, one, that we need to support those people on the ground immediately: to act, and act quick.  And two, that it is the poorest nations on the planet that suffer the most from these kinds of crises. Disastrous trade deals and fishing policies have made them even poorer and more prone to such disasters. Let us be compassionate, let us be civilised and let us let them trade out of their poverty.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which shows investment in basic healthcare is a vital pillar of development. The Ebola crisis has exposed this dramatically in West Africa, with a terrible toll on their societies. The countries need investment to build their own healthcare systems. I support the call for Universal Health Coverage, which is achievable as part of the new Sustainable Development Goals adopted by world leaders in New York in September. The framework has been set and now we need the action to achieve the right to health for all.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of this report on the Ebola crisis. Without doubt, the Ebola outbreak presented an enormous challenge to medical authorities in affected countries. I am pleased to see that a vital aspect of the report is quick access to proven vaccines. The populations of Liberia and Sierra Leone should be guaranteed access to new vaccines which have proven to be completely effective in Guinea. In order to minimise and even prevent further outbreaks in developing countries, we simply must strengthen their health systems and learn from the mistakes of the past.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as it contains key elements for understanding the Ebola epidemic of 2014 and 2015, which has left nearly 12,000 deaths worldwide. The report, for example, underlines the importance of robust public health systems in dealing with such epidemics, denounces the austerity in Health that African countries followed by the mandate of the Adjustment Programmes of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the 1980s and 1990s, and calls for exploring alternatives to the current model of drug research and development to overcome the logic of the pursuit of the benefit and respond to the demands of global health as a fundamental human right.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As Labour MEPs we believe that investment in basic healthcare is a vital pillar of development. The Ebola crisis has exposed this dramatically in West Africa, with a terrible toll on their societies. The countries affected by this crisis need investment to build their own healthcare systems. The Ebola crisis has both highlighted the structural problems that are still to be found in a number of countries and served as a reminder to EU leaders of the need to provide assistance in the development of basic social services, with the priority going to healthcare. Labour MEPs are fully behind the call for universal health coverage, which is achievable as part of the new Sustainable Development Goals adopted by world leaders in New York in September. The framework has been set and now we need the action to achieve the right to health care for all.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report on the Ebola crisis: the long-term lessons and how to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises. I believe that the European Parliament, as always, has made it clear that its task here is to scrutinise the executive, to take on its role as legislator, and lastly to provide a political impetus. I strongly believe that we can insist that the EU should press ahead with its efforts, so that others can follow its example. The EU’s voice must be heard, particularly in this, the year of development.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, sierra leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. The report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for Europeans involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, there is no need for additional emergency preparedness, but the EU should in future seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems. The conditions for a permanent European system should be laid down which, if a rapid reaction is required, have adequate tangible and personal means. The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development and thus play an important role in eradicating poverty. The report calls on Member States to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with their investments. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it is very important to learn from the scale and complexities of the Ebola crisis. It is an opportunity to reflect on the post-Ebola period and develop strategies in order to strengthen health and educations systems in developing countries. The international community, in areas of research, innovation and crisis management, should learn from the Ebola outbreak in order to better prepare for potential future epidemics.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As the former EU Chief Observer for elections in Sierra Leone, it was with deep sadness that I saw the people of that country which has suffered so much endure yet more suffering through the explosion of the Ebola crisis. Already there was not a single operating theatre in the country if any of the election observers for whom I was responsible, needed urgent hospital treatment. For the people of Sierra Leone themselves, their country was simply unprepared for the crisis that Ebola created. Therefore, I very much welcome today’s resolution on the long-term lessons to be learned from the crisis and to make recommendations to strengthen health systems across African developing countries. I call on the European Commission to help Sierra Leone and the other two countries most affected to develop their own health systems in order for them to be able to meet basic healthcare needs and to build up the infrastructure required to ensure that all their citizens have access to healthcare. If the debate which followed the Ebola crisis promotes this objective, perhaps something good can have come from something which was so terrible for all affected.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Ebola crisis in parts of Africa has been quite frightening and lessons must be learned from these horrific circumstances. Access to medicine should be based on need, not financial resources.  I welcome this report.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for Europeans involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the document, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should in future seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems. The conditions for a permanent European system with the means of rapid response should be laid down. The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, making them an important factor in eradicating poverty. The document calls on Member States to contribute to the establishment of the so-called General Health Fund and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Ebola Crisis Report: long-term lessons and solutions to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises because Ebola is a threat that can threaten the international community at national, regional and local levels. The fact is that Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have suffered enormous ebola-related difficulties and that economic activity in these countries has been significantly shaken, i.e. countries are in recession.  I therefore believe that targeted, effective and systematic assistance from the international community is needed to help these countries and ultimately contribute to the mitigation of the crisis. In this context, the European Union plays a key role as a global development leader and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to learn from the Ebola crisis. In particular, it insists that health infrastructure in West Africa be developed and modernised.  I voted for it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – I and fellow MEPs abstained on this vote. The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the recent Ebola epidemic in Western Africa, I welcomed this report which provides clear directions for the measures the European Union should take to prevent a future crisis of such an extent. The EU, WHO and other stakeholders must develop capacities in the least developed countries which could promptly respond to epidemics at the initial stage.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which makes a relevant statement on this violent Ebola epidemic. In particular, it calls on the Union to put in place long-term tools to respond to this type of crisis through prevention, development assistance and the creation of a rapid action team.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. According to the rapporteur, the countries affected by the Ebola crisis (Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea) are in an ongoing economic recession. This was different before the crisis erupted, as economic growth was 5% at the time. It is now being argued that these countries should be helped more in a more coordinated way to get out of the recession. This report is positive, given that the EU, together with its Member States, is the world's largest donor of development aid and has provided more than €1.39 billion in financial assistance to help contain Ebola virus disease in West Africa. The sooner the three above-mentioned economies are able to generate sufficient financial resources again, the easier it will be to meet health needs. I therefore agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the call for Universal Health Coverage in West Africa. The devastation caused by the Ebola Crisis has brought the realisation that the aforementioned region desperately needs to develop its healthcare system. The objective is to prevent similar outbreaks in the future.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – I supported the report, the main elements of which are the inadequate response of the international community, the shocking effects of border closures and restrictions imposed on the population, the inefficiation of monitoring and alert mechanisms, the slow and inadequate response following the final mobilisation of aid, the complete lack of WHO leadership and the partial lack of research and development on medicines, diagnosis and vaccines. Many of us are under the impression that it is only thanks to Providence that it has not yet become a pandemic.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Goerens report. The Ebola epidemic that erupted in West Africa in 2014 is the largest in the history of the virus. The impact of mortality rates in the affected countries has been further aggravated by the lack of adequate health facilities. The European Union has allocated over EUR 1.39 billion to defeat the virus and help contain the epidemic. I agree with what the report says about the importance of coordinated and effective action by the major international players to strengthen medical research and the production of effective Medicines and Vaccines against Ebola.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This Goerens report is about the Ebola crisis and aims to learn long-term lessons and identify ways to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises. It criticizes the slowness taken at the international level to respond to this crisis and calls on all actors to draw conclusions from the crisis and in particular the harmful role of the IMF and the World Bank on the issue. It also highlights the shortcomings of health systems in developing countries.  I have decided to vote in favour of this text because it is relatively consensual and highlights the imf's deleterious role in these countries.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for it. The report aims to establish a post-Ebola action plan by strengthening health systems in developing countries (including some African states particularly affected by the virus).  This text stresses the empowerment of states in health. From a budgetary point of view, it encourages the countries concerned to prioritize the establishment of social security and public health systems, medical training and the construction of modern hospital infrastructure. On the economic front, it proposes to offer a technical assistant to these countries in terms of their administration, their financing capacity and the equitable redistribution of aid. Finally, on the social level, it emphasizes the special protection afforded to women, who are more exposed to this type of virus for both professional and cultural reasons (they are often responsible for organizing and conducting funeral rites). Far from the financial assistance often seen in humanitarian aid, this is a report that works in the right direction. It encourages the development, economic and administrative empowerment of these countries affected by serious health crises.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the impact of Ebola on impoverished countries as it seems to us to introduce a number of elements which allow us to place the cause of the problem and how to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future. First, it welcomes the work of non-governmental organizations and negatively the response of governments and international institutions. Second, the effect of the International Monetary Fund's adjustment plans and illegitimate debts to southern countries on their health systems are recognized. It also condemns the monopoly of large pharmaceutical companies on patents that prevent universal access to medicines and the importance of universal access to health, calling for a new model of research and development based on principles of equality and solidarity. For all this, we have supported a Resolution that includes the right to public health and the need for fair trade to make access to medicines available to all.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The text presented welcomes the new vaccine tested 100% in Guinea in March this year, and needs to facilitate guinea access to Liberia and Sierra Leone. However, some new cases that have appeared and their mode of transmission, which have not yet been clarified, should not be lowered.  The report urges the international community to develop educational and information campaigns in the affected countries. It is important to emphasize and support the reform announced by WHO in May this year to establish a new emergency programme that will have a new $100 million reserve fund and a number of global reservists to be deployed on the ground.  It is also very important to work on conflict prevention, as these increase the fragility and vulnerability of health systems, and to combat the social stigmatization of the sick and their environment for the future and possible new crises. The response to the Ebola crisis was slow in the first few months, so anything that can be learned from it will deserve my support.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The health system of Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea is marked by a number of shortcomings. Prior to the outbreak, these countries were at the bottom of the HUMAN development index drawn up under the UN Development Programme.  The Ebola crisis also has consequences internationally, and its expansion can be attributed to political failures of affected countries, the absence of World Health Organisation leadership and a lack of research and drug development. Due to the great and severe consequences of Ebola, there is a need to bring together epidemiology, public health and social sciences to draw lessons from omissions.  All participants are invited to develop effective methods of combating international health crises. In particular, the creation of an emergency programme, an organisation of reserve personnel ready to enter the field as soon as possible and the making available of a new reserve fund of 100 million US dollars for emergencies, stands out. It also seeks the establishment of a permanent European Rapid Action Service in the event of such epidemics. I supported MP Charles Goerens' report since Ebola is a serious and often fatal disease. Taught by the 2014 epidemic, we must work primarily on prevention, but also be ready for swift action, with the most important step being strengthening health systems in developing countries.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the current scale of the Ebola infectious disease epidemic in african countries – Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea – demonstrates that these countries are unable to cope, given their economic and economic situation, and in particular the state of social and health services without the assistance of other countries. It is therefore necessary to review and direct EU financial assistance to developing countries so that the funds provided address the country's problems in a targeted way and are not misused for other undesirable objectives. To this end, measures must be taken to increase control over the treatment of the aid granted and to enable it to intervene in a timely manner.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Ebola crisis: lessons learned over time and ways to strengthen health systems in developing countries in order to prevent future crises; for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 26/10/2015, and because since 2014, Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia have been affected by the Ebola virus, however these countries are not only experiencing the Ebola virus crisis but more generally a systemic crisis, since 80% of the population lives in extreme poverty. Of course, the European Union's response to curbing Ebola was not immediate and particularly effective, as were Doctors Without Borders and the Red Cross, which proved more prepared to help Africa's populations. It is necessary to make better use of the potential of these humanitarian organisations on the part of the EU and also to strengthen medical research in order to produce medicines and vaccines for Ebola. In addition, it is necessary to erase the debt of African countries affected by the virus so that they can invest more in their health systems, which have been literally dissolved by the IMF and international loan lenders.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. Dominique Martin voted for this report. The report, which is expected to strengthen health systems in developing countries, particularly those most affected by Ebola (Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea). Intelligently, this report gives budgetary priority to the establishment of social security and public health systems, and to the training of doctors. This text proposes the establishment of a "Marshall Plan" to help revive the economies of these countries and the development of local infrastructure to prevent future epidemics.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Ebola crisis, which is massively challenging in itself has also resulted in another problem – something which, in one of its appeals, Médecins Sans Frontières has referred to as ‘a crisis within a crisis’. Many people with conditions other than Ebola are not going to hospital for fear that they will be infected with the virus. The EU must to try to find a solution to this problem, in close cooperation with our African partners.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report entitled 'Ebola crisis: long-term lessons and how to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises' is favourable to me. The Ebola epidemic, one of the deadliest to date in the world, has killed more than 11 000 people and unfortunately continues to show new cases. Most of the victims were recorded in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. Action is needed to ensure the development of sound public systems in the field of social security and health, the construction of a sufficient number of sustainable and adequately equipped health infrastructures, an adequate number of properly trained health workers, access to sufficient medical supplies and sound health information systems. We need a comprehensive approach covering different areas, such as education and training, hygiene and food safety.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a report that I attach special importance to because of my medical profession. The Ebola outbreak in Africa last year showed that health systems in the most affected countries show huge gaps. The most affected countries, where around 80% of citizens live in extreme poverty, were among the countries with the lowest human development index before the outbreak, according to data from the UN Development Programme survey, and recorded the highest mortality rates in the world for premature babies, adults and children under five, especially treatable diseases. I believe that social inequality needs to be addressed in order to build a solid sustainable public health system, in this sense I welcome the idea of introducing publicly funded universal healthcare, which would be provided free of charge on the ground, and I join the urgent request on the Commission to present, together with partner countries and other donors, the universal health insurance programme as soon as possible , which would guarantee the distribution of health risks. This crisis has also proved systemic in terms of its global management. It took the international community a long time to understand and respond to the gravity of the situation. We have no choice but to learn from the past crisis and take measures to prevent it from happening again. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The scale and complexity of the current Ebola epidemic is a real challenge for the people of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. The European Union must respond to the crisis of the three states by taking responsibility for promoting the right to universal health care. In accordance with what is stated in the report, I believe that the crisis must be overcome not only by investment in health, but also by subsequently contributing to the economic recovery of the three countries.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur points out that the countries concerned (Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea) could have had an economic growth of 5% before the Outbreak of Ebola, but are now in recession. This report should be supported in order to enable these countries to grow again and subsequently to set up their own research institutions.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The text looks back at the international management of the Ebola crisis since its emergence in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea in March 2014. The text criticizes the slowness of the international response. It notes that "health and education systems have deteriorated as a result of structural adjustment programmes imposed by the IMF and the World Bank" and calls for "the vaccine to be made available urgently and securely, at an affordable price for all". I vote for this text.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to learn from the Ebola crisis. In particular, it insists that health infrastructure in West Africa be developed and modernised. For this reason, the Member voted in favour of this resolution, although it is too inclined to dramatize the Ebola crisis, as if the health problems facing African countries were new.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is still little knowledge about the transmission and mutation potential of the Ebola virus. We must recall the european union's commitment to curbthe spread of the Ebola virus and help for the development of logistics and research to respond to the crisis, but the lessons we have learned from the need to strengthen health systems in developing countries should not be forgotten. This type of epidemic requires transnational cooperation to evaluate and manage the outbreak.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is crucial that we examine the lessons learnt. The EU is pushing for quicker mobilisation of health workers and aid, through a WHO reserve fund. The resolution also suggests that the focus should change to development and economic assistance to repair damage caused by the crisis once the situation stabilises.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea were hit by the worst Ebola epidemic in history, so I welcome the resolution on this crisis and consider it important to learn the lessons for the future. As time plays a key role, it is already necessary to name the shortcomings in the healthcare system there. If the European Parliament is aware that women have been more affected by the Ebola virus in these countries, as they accounted for between 55 and 75% of the victims, let us address what led to this. They are the most important part of the medical staff, but there is a lack of basic medical and protective equipment in the system. Worse still, even in areas not affected by Ebola, the fear of infection has caused people to refuse to go for routine treatments. Women have even stopped giving birth in hospitals. This has resulted in an increasing number of non-Ebola-related deaths of women and children. I therefore call on Europe to contribute so that these countries can develop their own public health systems and infrastructure that can ensure access to them for all citizens. However, let us not make part of the funding provided into sexual and reproductive rights, as the resolution mentions, especially if they are understood only as access to contraception and abortion.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since the beginning of the year, the Ebola virus has claimed thousands of lives in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea, Nigeria and Senegal. Although the European Commission has strengthened its immediate support to tackle the crisis, local and international efforts turned out to be inadequate in the containment of this deadly disease for which there is no vaccine.  Even though Ebola faded from the news headlines a long while ago, we should not stop fighting this deadly disease. All those involved must demonstrate the vision they need to enable them to assume their responsibilities in the period that follows. The Ebola crisis has highlighted the structural problems that are still to be found in a number of countries. Therefore, I voted in favour of this non-legislative resolution to provide recommendations for Europe’s response on the development of basic social services, giving priority to healthcare, so that we can avoid future crises like this one.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Development report summarises the lessons learned from the worst Ebola outbreak in world history, which has ravaded Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea since March 2014. It states that the European Union, as the world's most important player in development, has a special responsibility to promote the universal right of access to healthcare. It expects the UNION to act more energetically than other actors. It advocates that the UNION should be at the forefront of research, innovation, the creation of a framework for urgent tasks, the deployment of medical staff, the deployment of an evacuation system and the longer-term efforts for development cooperation. It considers that, in the post-epidemic period, the EU should focus its efforts on two areas: development aid, including through investment in health infrastructure, and support for the economic recovery of the three countries. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The Ebola virus has created an international public health emergency situation in which countries such as Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been victims of the most serious Ebola outbreak in human history. The scope of this disaster is due to political, cross-border, surveillance, diagnosis, research, among others. The European Union must play a leading role in this area, assisting in the progress of a coherent national health system for each of these countries. The development of health systems worldwide, with a particular focus on developing countries, should consist of new investments in infrastructure, surveillance and information systems, supply of medicines, human resources, as well as the management of health services themselves. The role given to NGOs is central, and it is extremely important to value their skills even more in the future. I am in favour of this report, stressing the need for the development of local health systems with the support of the European Union, as well as the implementation of effective information and communication conditions as a means of prevention.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This Goerens report is about the Ebola crisis and aims to draw long-term lessons and identify ways to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises. It criticizes the slowness taken at the international level to respond to this crisis and calls on all actors to draw conclusions from the crisis and in particular the harmful role of the IMF and the World Bank on the issue. It also highlights the shortcomings of health systems in developing countries.  I have decided to vote in favour of this text because it is relatively consensual and highlights the imf's deleterious role in these countries.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Investment in basic healthcare is a vital pillar of development. The Ebola crisis has exposed this dramatically in West Africa, with a terrible toll on their societies. The countries need investment to build their own healthcare systems. Labour MEPs are fully behind the call for Universal Health Coverage, which is achievable as part of the new Sustainable Development Goals adopted by world leaders in New York in September. The framework has been set and now we need the action to achieve the right to health for all.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Ebola epidemic in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. This text stresses the scale and complexity of this crisis in West Africa, which is a real challenge not only for these three states, but also for the international community and the European Union. He recalls that important resources have been urgently mobilised in the fields of research, innovation and crisis management. It also recommends strengthening health systems and good governance in developing countries through public assistance from donor countries to prevent future crises.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Welcome to the report. The European Union must do its u u uts to ensure that a major epidemiological catastrophe of this size does not occur in the future. Learning from the Ebola epidemic – it is very important to make international crisis management action more effective. A quick reaction is therefore essential, since it gains life, who buys time. In addition to the thousands of human lives, the Ebola epidemic has other longer-term consequences. For example, an increase in orphanages – there is a huge number of children who have lost their parents, but their relatives are afraid to take them in because of the possibility of infection. Most of the children affected are also rejected in schools, which can mean a complete interruption of their education. And education is paramount in developing countries. We can't turn our backs on emergency aid. We are talking about countries where the population lacks basic hygiene practices. Without the introduction of adequate water supply and sanitation, it is not possible to prevent the spread of viral diseases. The Marshall Plan will help to develop a health and education system that allows basic needs to be met. We must also not forget the measures that we can take here in Europe. This is what research and development can be like, because the more information we have about Ebola and viral diseases like it, the closer we get to developing antibodies.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been in the grip of the worst ever Ebola crisis. I have voted for this report that will press ahead with its efforts to stop the development of this epidemic.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This is a very good report criticising the slow response from national governments and the WHO to the Ebola crisis last year and proposing measures to ensure developing countries are equipped to deal with a similar scenario in future. It identifies the structural adjustment programmes imposed on third-world countries, and their resulting debt and reduced investment in public services, as a key contributing factor to the crisis, and calls for increased investment in national and global health systems. It also welcomes the creation of an effective vaccine this year and calls for it to be affordable and accessible to every person in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report contained proposals for future action against the epidemic, as well as against certain other bacterial diseases. I voted in favour of this report because around 700 000 people worldwide die each year as a result of infections with multi-resistant bacteria. In addition, before the outbreak of Ebola, there was a 5% economic growth in the affected region, which collapsed dramatically as a result of the disease. In addition to the terrible personal fates, the fight against Ebola can also be won off on a national economic perspective. In this area, as the report states, research is particularly important and, therefore, worthy of support for me.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I support this report which calls for strengthening Western emergency aid policies for countries facing dire health situations. The aim is to recognise the lessons to be learned and the long-term strategies for action that the European Union must draw from the management of the Ebola crisis that has particularly ravaged Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea. The rapporteur calls into question the fiscal policies put in place by the IMF and the World Bank that have indebted these economies. The report also notes, among other things, the need for more concrete and faster action in terms of strengthening national health systems and international aid systems for food security and health infrastructure.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It is important to improve cooperation with humanitarian organisations in order to respond as best as possible in the various hotspots. They often have a better overview of the country and are more operationally prepared to deliver in a crisis area. Development aid to third countries must also be increased; The contribution of all EU countries is important. However, EU development aid in third countries must be targeted and adequately supervised to ensure the rational use of EU development aid funds.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – The Ebola outbreak is the largest and most complex in history. The Ebola crisis has exposed the inefficiency of most health systems.  It should be noted that past adjustments and reforms and biased development policies have led to the inefficiency of health systems. It is therefore essential to learn from this crisis and to develop effective international health crisis management tools and to better coordinate and strengthen health systems in the Member States. In addition, there is a need to self-critically assess the too late response to this crisis, which was not decisive and did not correspond to the true scale of the crisis.  I support the proposal to establish a permanent European Rapid Reaction Group, which can be carried over in the shortest possible time. In the future, such complex challenges cannot be erctous, as the consequences are very dire. It is necessary to completely eliminate this disease.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am involved in the vote on this document. Indeed, I personally dedicate a great deal of my energy, as a representative of the citizens, to health policies, because I firmly believe in the decisive role of the EU in improving the health of Europeans.  In particular, as I recently pointed out to the Commission in a motion for a resolution, the epidemic ebola crisis seems to continue to threaten Europe, and any action aimed at minimising the risk not only on our territory, but also in a targeted way in developing countries and countries of origin of the virus, is well received and necessary.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome and support the tone and content of the resolution on the Ebola crisis. I consider it important that the causes, consequences and progress of crisis management are analysed at the end of each crisis in order to face challenges more preparedly on the next occasion. Unfortunately, the lessons of the previous epidemic of 2001 were clearly not taken seriously enough.  Some 28,515 people were sickened and around 11,313 people died, according to the World Health Organisation for September 2015. I welcome the criticism of the international community's slow response in the first months since the crisis, however, I welcome the mobilisation and commitment of the EU and its Member States to help contain the spread of the Ebola virus, including by taking on greater financial commitments from the European Union and member states in the areas of humanitarian and development aid, logistics and research in response to the crisis.  In particular, I welcome the efforts of scientists to urgently find an Ebola vaccine that has proven to be as effective as possible in Guinea. I believe this vaccine should be available in the disadvantaged areas of Liberia and Sierra Leone. Furthermore, successful prevention of future crises can only be achieved through the organisation of adequate healthcare systems, and I welcome any efforts made by the European Union and the Member States through their institutions in cooperation with the non-governmental sector on this front.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Goerens report is about the Ebola crisis and aims to draw long-term lessons and ways to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises. He criticizes the slowness of the international community in responding to this crisis and calls on all actors to draw conclusions from the crisis, including the harmful role of the IMF and the World Bank on the issue. It also highlights the shortcomings of health systems in developing countries. I have decided to vote in favour of this text because it is relatively consensual and highlights the imf's deleterious role in these countries.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ A number of European and global crises that have since emerged have put the Ebola problem in the background when it comes to public monitoring. But the problem still exists which is why I am particularly pleased that we are discussing this topic and the report I support.  Since the Ebola epidemic that struck West Africa is the largest and most complex in the history of the disease, that nearly 500 healthcare workers have died of Ebola in Guinea, and the exact number of victims of the epidemic is almost impossible to estimate, and that many survivors are subject to stigmatization in the society they come from, we need to react.  I therefore welcome that over the next two years the World Health Organisation budget will be increased by 10% to reach USD 4.5 billion, as well as the reform put in place by the 18th World Health Organisation. On May 15, 2015, the Director of the World Health Organization announced, in particular the development of a new global emergency programme and organisation of reserve staff that can be sent to the field as soon as possible and the making available of a new $100 million emergency reserve fund.  The European Union also needs to contribute, both financially and by educating experts to stop such tragedies in the future in a more timely way.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I agree with colleague Charles Goerens' report on the Ebola crisis. The Ebola epidemic in West Africa has addressed the fact that local and national health systems in low-income countries do not have the resources to fight the disease, and it is the Ebola epidemic in the area that is the largest and most complex in the history of the disease. While the international community has not been prepared for this crisis, it welcomes the development of a new vaccine in record time and stresses the necessity of vaccines being available to everyone in Liberia and Sierra Leone. Lessons need to be learned from this crisis and effective methods developed to combat international health crises. I would also stress the importance of preventive and information campaigns in crisis management, in particular to limit contamination and combat the spread of the disease. In this context, the EU Development Assistance Plan should include promoting resilience, monitoring health status, the medicines supply system, and helping to revive the economies of affected countries. Investments in the health sector are essential for developing countries and are an important factor in driving economic development. In order to develop comprehensive health systems, long-term planning and support the introduction of free universal health insurance is needed. It recalls the importance of strengthening research capacities and providing access to vaccines, and the availability of medicines should not depend on the purchasing power of the patient.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the European Parliament today passed legislation in favour of further support for states affected by the humanitarian crisis caused by the worst ebola outbreak in history. These are mainly Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. In addition to the fight against disease itself, further assistance should be aimed primarily at strengthening health and education systems in the affected countries. The European Union has already invested EUR 1.2 billion in combating Ebola since the outbreak of the crisis. But, as it turned out, concrete steps came too late. The epidemic has taken a huge toll not only on patients, but also on their families. This is also why we need to learn as much as possible from developments and take concrete measures for the future, as the EU should do in similar situations. The focus now needs to be on sufficient support for research and prevention of Ebola and other similarly dangerous diseases.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The three countries most affected by the Ebola virus – Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea – rank last according to the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) Human Development Index. That is why the European Union should do more, both in terms of development aid, including investment in health, and in terms of the essential aid for economic recovery.  Almost two years after the outbreak began, which has claimed more than 11 000 lives since March 2014, I believe it is essential to learn the necessary lessons about the management of this crisis. This sad experience will serve in the future to improve the responses of those sectors engaged in dealing with such health emergencies.  That is why I have decided to support this report, through my vote in favour, because I believe that there is still a great deal to be done to help the countries concerned contain and eradicate the Ebola epidemic.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The rapporteur criticises the response of the international community in the first months of the crisis and stresses the importance of rapid response and the ROLE of the EU as the world's main provider of development aid. The international community should start thinking today about the period that will come after the epidemic has been resolved. The EU response will have to focus on two areas of development aid, including investment in healthcare, as well as the assistance needed to rebuild the ebola-affected countries (Sierra Leone, Liberia, Guinea). I therefore supported the report.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 It happens sometimes that we vote here on resolutions that one thinks are not absolutely necessary. But the very opposite is the question of assessing how the world managed or failed to manage the Ebola crisis. The world must learn, because unfortunately this epidemic was not the last, and we will face similar challenges in the future. For this reason too, I supported the resolution.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Since March 2014, three African countries, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea, have been severely affected by Ebola. The epidemic is still virulent despite European and international actions put in place to help these countries and their populations.  In this context, the European Parliament wished to recall the crucial role of the Union, the world's leading development player, in managing this crisis and helping these countries and the surrounding regions as best as possible. While the Eu can help manage the crisis, its role is also to limit upstream the factors conducive to the development of the virus. By best analysing the Union's role before and during the Ebola crisis, the Union will be able to better define its future role in development aid in this region.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The substance of this report is something we could primarily agree on: that long term lessons should be to prevent more crises like the Ebola outbreak from happening again. But UKIP firmly believes that this should not be dealt with by the EU. Instead this should be dealt with by the appropriate NGOs and other international organisations. For this reason we abstained on this vote.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The Ebola crisis mainly affects countries living in extreme poverty and vulnerability, with almost non-existent health systems. The European Union, as a world leader in development, has a responsibility and duty to promote the right to universal health care. The key pillars of this cooperation are based on ensuring WHO financial support, promoting effective and fair R&D funding and dissociating these costs from the final price of medicines, strengthening national health systems and facilitating universal access to health and medicines, as well as supporting the establishment of a regional infectious disease research centre in West Africa. We must stress the vital importance for the countries most affected by this crisis— Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea — of receiving aid in order to launch their economies. Finally, this report calls for a lack of funding for humanitarian action, especially investment in the health sector, and thus to build the recovery capacity of the affected countries. That is why I supported this report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been the victims of the largest Ebola epidemic ever. The scale and complexity of the current epidemic has been a real challenge for these three states, whose health and education gaps are structural. However, the epidemic has also been a real test for the international community. In particular, the report believes that the EU's long-term response beyond emergency aid should be based first on development aid, which should include investments in health to promote resilience, particularly in the organisation and management of health systems. The adopted text also calls for the establishment of a permanent European rapid action team comprising experts, laboratory support teams, epidemiologists and logistics infrastructure, including mobile laboratories, which can be deployed as soon as possible. I have, of course, supported all of these measures.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The Ebola crisis has shown that, despite some initial delays in the international response, there has been a strong reaction from the European Union and the Member States to combat the spread of the virus, as well as a strong commitment in the fields of humanitarian aid and development aid. In fact, this serious crisis turned out to be a real test for the international community, as Ebola proved to be a systemic epidemic capable of taking on a transnational dimension. For this reason, the contingency plan(s) required/required consistent and responsible international cooperation, bringing together efforts in the areas of research, innovation and crisis management, but also long-term investments to strengthen health systems and governance – especially in terms of public health in developing countries. I therefore support the urgent need for these countries to invest in the health sector, with specialists in the various areas, as well as logistics facilities, which can ensure quality medical care and, at the same time, the importance of reviewing the programming of the 11th European Development Fund, with a view to ensuring that investments in health and good governance become priority areas for all countries with public infrastructure considered fragile.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls for the creation of a permanent rapid response mechanism.  This text draws lessons from the management of the Ebola crisis and provides long-term reflection on assistance to countries affected by health crises. It is essential to put in place such a mechanism to address the slow international response and to respond immediately to health crises similar to the Ebola epidemic.  The report also stresses facilitating access to vaccines and setting up checkpoints in developing countries to monitor the emergence of infectious diseases. This mechanism is a real step forward in preventing the development of pandemics, which is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ebola virus outbreak in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea has killed more than 11 000 people and has revealed major health structural gaps in these countries. It is up to the European Union to help these African states develop a public health system that guarantees the right to health care for every person in need of care. Expressing solidarity with the people who have contracted the Ebola virus and hoping to find appropriate health measures to eradicate this epidemic, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the report urges the Commission to help countries affected by Ebola to develop their public health systems so that they are able to respond to basic health needs and provide themselves with the necessary infrastructure to ensure that all their citizens have access to public health.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as it contains key elements for understanding the Ebola epidemic of 2014 and 2015, which has left nearly 12,000 deaths worldwide. The report, for example, underlines the importance of robust public health systems in dealing with such epidemics, denounces the austerity in Health that African countries followed by the mandate of the Adjustment Programmes of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the 1980s and 1990s, and calls for exploring alternatives to the current model of drug research and development to overcome the logic of the pursuit of the benefit and respond to the demands of global health as a fundamental human right.

name: György Schöpflin (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, sierra leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for the three countries mentioned above, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for Europeans involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with the right tangible and personnel means for rapid response should be laid down.  The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, making it an important factor in eradicating poverty. The report calls on member states to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with its investments. In agreement with the above objectives, following the people's party line, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the impact of Ebola on impoverished countries as it seems to us to introduce a number of elements which allow us to place the cause of the problem and how to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future. First, it welcomes the work of non-governmental organizations and negatively the response of governments and international institutions. Second, the effect of the International Monetary Fund's adjustment plans and illegitimate debts to southern countries on their health systems are recognized. It also condemns the monopoly of large pharmaceutical companies on patents that prevent universal access to medicines and the importance of universal access to health, calling for a new model of research and development based on principles of equality and solidarity. For all this, we have supported a Resolution that includes the right to public health and the need for fair trade to make access to medicines available to all.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ebola epidemic that has plagued Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea since 2014 has dramatically highlighted the serious structural health deficiencies of these three states and recalled the need to step up international financial engagement in the field of humanitarian and development aid. I voted in favour, as the report adopted today has the merit of drawing attention to the challenges of the post-Ebola period and the importance of providing adequate support to the economies of the countries affected by the crisis.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as I do not wish to see the EU getting involved in issues that do not concern it. However I welcome national government efforts to prevent this type of disease outbreak in the future.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Ebola crisis because the European Parliament makes very important recommendations with the aim of strengthening health systems in developing countries and preventing future epidemics (Ebola and other diseases). The report recalls that the current outbreak in West Africa reveals the serious gaps in many countries in all essential services and calls for the proper lessons learned from this crisis. The report recommends and insists on the following points: strengthening EU aid to developing countries in the field of health and other basic social sectors (education and training, sanitation, food security and drinking water); EU assistance to the economic recovery of the three countries most affected by Ebola (Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea); the establishment of a permanent European rapid action team; finally, the creation of a network of monitoring points in developing countries to detect, as soon as possible, new cases of infectious diseases that may become pandemic. The report is an important contribution to the Union's future responses in terms of health crisis prevention and management and therefore deserved my vote in favour.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Ebola crisis has highlighted both the structural problems that we still find in a number of countries and served as a reminder to EU leaders of the need for them to stay true to their goal of allocating at least 20% of official assistance on the development of basic social services, giving healthcare priority. I and other Labour MEPs are fully behind the call for Universal Health Coverage, which is achievable as part of the new Sustainable Development Goals adopted by world leaders in New York in September.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted positively for this report, but this explanation of the vote is a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the current Ebola epidemic has already killed more people than any other in history, and I assume that the affected countries will recover from it long after it has disappeared. Based on the figures reported in the report, the outbreak has affected more than 20 000 people, mainly from Guinea, Sierra Leone and Liberia, and has already spread from Africa to two other continents where isolated cases have been recorded. Although some progress has been made in the fight against the Ebola epidemic and considerable efforts have been made from EU level to contain the disease, I have the feeling that much more could have been done in this area. I supported the resolution because I believe that the measures with which the report comes can help to address fundamental shortcomings and improve more consistent management and coordination in the fight against the spread of the Ebola virus. I was also pleased to receive the information that, in record time, a new vaccine has been developed which has proved to be 100% effective. Nevertheless, I expect the Member States, the Commission and the international community to be more actively engaged in medical research and the production of active medicines and vaccines against the Ebola virus and other emerging diseases.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea are in the last place according to the Human Development Index, and were also in the top spots in the world at early mortality rates for adults and children up to the age of five, mainly due to treatment-related diseases.  In 2014, these countries were engulfed by the Ebola virus of catastrophic proportions. This has been further underd-thrified by the widespread confusion and widespread misunderstanding of the causes and consequences of the Ebola virus. It is the largest and most complex outbreak in the history of this disease, in which the international response was extremely slow in the first months of the outbreak.  The Ebola outbreak has shown that local and national health systems in low-income countries do not have sufficient resources and are not robust enough to respond to an outbreak of an infectious disease such as Ebola. Strengthening global health systems has become an integral part of global health governance.  I believe that all stakeholders, in particular the governments of developing countries, the European institutions and international organisations, should draw appropriate worlds from this crisis and develop effective means of managing international health crises.  I agree that investment in the health sector is an important driver of economic development and contributes to poverty reduction in developing countries, which is why I voted in favour of the report.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. Investment in basic healthcare is essential if development is to be ensured. This has been exposed dramatically in West Africa by the Ebola crisis. There must be investment in order to allow these countries to expand and develop their own healthcare systems. I, along with the other Labour MEPs, am fully behind the call for Universal Health Coverage: the framework has been set and now we need action in order to achieve the right to health for all.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have faced the worst Ebola crisis ever. This report builds on the experience gained during this crisis.  The range and complexity of the current Ebola epidemic pose a real challenge for the three countries mentioned, whose health and education systems are riddled with structural shortcomings. The Ebola crisis has proven to be a systemic problem at local, regional and national levels. Furthermore, it is also a test for the international community and for all those involved in European research, innovation and governance efforts during the crisis, as well as efforts to strengthen health systems and authorities in developing countries.   I support this report because I believe it will help us cope with these and similar crises, and I think that the value of the information gained from experience with this epidemic is invaluable for fighting similar situations in the future.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: in writing ‒ given that epidemics such as Ebola are practically inevitably a problem that transcends the borders of individual EU countries, I support common action to prevent and prevent the spread of similar diseases at European Union level.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on the Ebola crisis: long-term experience. As the report rightly notes, the Ebola outbreak in west Africa has shown that low-income countries find it very difficult to cope with an outbreak of such diseases as Ebola. I support the call for wider access and for the price advantage of a vaccine that has proved 100% effective in the fight against Ebola. The key in all this is that we all draw the right conclusions from this crisis so that we can cope more effectively with similar health crises in the future.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's European Parliament report on the Ebola crisis. I believe that its subtitle 'lessons for the future and how to improve healthcare systems in developing countries in order to prevent future crises' well sums up the European Parliament's intention to evaluate this experience and to focus development aid efforts on helping to stabilise the fragile health system, not just the epidemics of the African countries concerned. These efforts to increase aid to the health sector must be accompanied by the fight against poverty and the promotion of effective and uncorken governance. It is about saving lives, but it is also about minimising the complications that any similar epidemic will cause in the Member States in the areas of tourism, transport in general, in mobilising public health and safety institutions, etc. It is therefore not only about the conditions at the sites of the outbreak and the elimination of causes, but also about the readiness of the competent authorities of individual Member States and their sufficient coordination within the EU in the event of an outbreak.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Most of the adjustments and regulations and policies implemented in the past by the European Union have resulted in contributions to inefficient health systems as well as to incorrect management of funds, since they have resulted in unreliable NGOs, resulting in unnecessary waste of resources which, if properly and correctly allocated, would lead to tangible results in the fight against diseases such as Ebola. What needs to be done to properly tackle diseases such as Ebola is better coordination and strengthening of Member States' health systems.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Since the outbreak last year, Ebola has taken a deadly toll of more than 11,000 lives, mainly in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. That is why prevention, or the prevention of similar epidemics, is so important – all over the world, and not just in Africa. The EP report properly outlines the lessons for the future and the action that the EU should take both within its own continent and in its relations with the countries where the epidemic took place. It is also worth remembering that the tragedy of the countries affected by the epidemic does not end with thousands of deaths.
