Ebola has led to the destruction and suppression of the socio-economic development processes of Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. According to recent estimates, the epidemic has cost the west African economy more than $2.2 billion. Multi-directional support for these countries is therefore needed.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a much welcomed own initiative report concerning the lessons that can be learned from this particular outbreak and how we can prevent disease spread and further loss of life in any future outbreaks. 11 314 people died from the 2014 Ebola outbreak. In total over 15 000 cases were confirmed, three of which were within the EU itself as the UK, Spain and Italy each registered a case. I am pleased to note that, at least in these three cases, there were no fatalities.  As a former medical doctor, I welcome the call for the establishment of a permanent European rapid response capability, comprising experts and laboratory support staff, epidemiologists and logistic facilities. This is an area where expertise and best practice can be best achieved by working together across the EU, in cases where we are fighting mutual threats. The reports highlighting the need to politically and economically support Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea is also to be welcomed. These three countries have been most affected by the outbreak and rebuilding their economies is vital.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It is estimated that the latest Ebola outbreak claimed the lives of at least 11 312 people and infected over 28 457 persons. Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea suffered the most from the crisis. But that, unfortunately, is not surprising. These three countries are at the bottom of the UNDP human development index. Moreover, they are home to some of the worst-funded education and healthcare systems in the world, making the scale of the Ebola epidemic a real challenge. The current report highlights the role of the EU, as a world leader on development, when it comes to promoting the right to universal healthcare. It emphasizes the EU’s leading role in providing development aid to these countries, in order to help revive their economy and support the development of basic social services - with healthcare as a priority. Although Ebola faded from the news headlines a long while ago, this current report, which I voted in favour of, highlights the structural problems that are still found in a number of countries and the responsibilities that still need to be fulfilled in the post-Ebola period.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been the victims of the largest Ebola epidemic ever known. The permeability of borders has led to the passage of the virus from one country to another. The three countries in question are among the last in the UNDP ranking in terms of the human development index. Their average life expectancy is either equal to or less than 60 years, schooling rarely exceeds three years and about 80% of their citizens live in extreme poverty.  With this resolution, we wanted to recall that the current Ebola crisis is both a sign of the structural gaps that remain in many countries and a reminder to European Union officials that they can persevere in their willingness to devote at least 20% of their official aid to the development of basic social sectors, of which health is a priority.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported adoption of this report that follows up on the Ebola crisis that broke out in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea in March 2014. The report argues that health and education systems of these countries suffer from structural shortcomings and the Ebola crisis is therefore systemic. Regarding the long-term response, the report recommends that the EU should focus first on development assistance, which would need to include investment in the health sector to promote resilience, particularly as regards the organisation and management of health systems, health monitoring and information, medicine supply systems, domestic governance and state-building.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Ebola crisis was one of the biggest disasters in recent years. First of all, there was the inadequacy and slowness of the international response in the first months of the crisis. We need to carefully evaluate what has been done and analyse every single aspect of the activities promoted. Mr Goerens has carefully assessed the work of the Commission and international actors, which is why I welcome his report, but I would also like to stress the need to promote medical and social support responses adapted to the specific and differentiated needs of women, men and families. The weakening of health systems due to the epidemic has amplified maternal mortality and reduced prenatal and neonatal care. Already high gender gaps in education have widen due to school closures. We need initiatives to raise awareness of the disease and to debate the prevention and defeat of the disease. Prevention programmes must be aimed primarily at women who, because of their role in the affected countries, have been at the forefront of the fight against Ebola. We also need to create social protection mechanisms for women and a programme for the many Ebola orphans.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. In March 2014, sierra leone, Liberia and Guinea had the largest Ebola crisis to date. This report builds on the experience gained during the crisis. The Ebola crisis has been a major challenge for these three countries, as they have not been prepared to deal with the situation due to the shortcomings of their health and education systems. This has been a huge challenge for the international community and for Europeans involved in dealing with the crisis. According to the report, no further emergency assistance is needed, but the EU should seek to improve the organisation and flexibility of health systems in the future. The conditions for a permanent European system with the right tangible and personnel means for rapid response should be laid down.  The report draws attention to the fact that investments in health promote economic development, making it an important factor in eradicating poverty. The report calls on member states to contribute to the establishment of the UHC (General Health Fund) and to support the Marshall Plan, which can give a strong impetus to the development of countries in need. The report also hopes that the European Development Fund will support the health systems of fragile countries with its investments. Following the People's Party line, in agreement with the above objectives, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the Ebola crisis: the long-term experience and ways of strengthening health systems in developing countries in order to prevent future crises, because I think it is right to help the three poor countries, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea, which are clearly not going to be able to overcome the problems themselves.  These countries have many shortcomings in health and education, and the EU must respond to the challenges faced by these three countries on a daily basis in the fight against Ebola.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as it contains key elements for understanding the Ebola epidemic of 2014 and 2015, which has left nearly 12,000 deaths worldwide. The report, for example, underlines the importance of robust public health systems in dealing with such epidemics, denounces the austerity in Health that African countries followed by the mandate of the Adjustment Programmes of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the 1980s and 1990s, and calls for exploring alternatives to the current model of drug research and development to overcome the logic of the pursuit of the benefit and respond to the demands of global health as a fundamental human right.

name: Mihai Ţurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2014, West Africa experienced the largest epidemic in the history of Ebola disease affecting more than 20,000 people mainly in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone, and then spread to other continents, where isolated cases have occurred. This Ebola virus crisis has highlighted precisely the shortcomings of health systems, particularly in these countries, which do not have sufficient resources to have a sound and efficient health system. Moreover, this crisis has led to increased political instability and social and economic tensions in the affected countries. The efforts of the EU and the other international actors involved in this crisis have led to progress at European and international level, but have not been sufficient to permanently eradicate the Ebola epidemic. In this respect, there is a need to develop a European strategy to improve coordination and collaboration between EU states in the fight against this epidemic, to increase the degree of protection at European level, but also to support developing countries in their efforts to create effective health systems.  I therefore voted in favour of the Goerens Report on the Ebola crisis and the long-term lessons.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. Since March 2014, Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been hit by the worst Ebola outbreak in the history of the world. The interoperability of borders made it easier for the virus to spread from one country to another. The three countries in question are among the last on the UNDP list for the human development index. The average life expectancy of residents is no more than 60 years, schooling rarely exceeds three years, and around 80% of citizens live in extreme poverty.  Partnerships between the European Union and the area in crisis can only be effective if Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone are able to take their development into their own hands as soon as possible. Due to the many challenges posed by the Ebola crisis, the european development fund (EDF) programming for these three countries needs to be reviewed in the future. In addition, it should already be indicated that the risk of structural underfunding in relation to humanitarian actions in the European Union can no longer be ignored in the mid-term review of the MED. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the report as it contains key elements for understanding the Ebola epidemic of 2014 and 2015, which has left nearly 12,000 deaths worldwide. The report, for example, underlines the importance of robust public health systems in dealing with such epidemics, denounces the austerity in Health that African countries followed by the mandate of the Adjustment Programmes of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund in the 1980s and 1990s, and calls for exploring alternatives to the current model of drug research and development to overcome the logic of the pursuit of the benefit and respond to the demands of global health as a fundamental human right.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because the EU has a special responsibility when it comes to promoting the right to universal healthcare. The Ebola epidemic which affected West Africa is the largest and most complex outbreak in the history of the disease. Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been in the grip of the worst ever Ebola crisis. Diseases do not stop at borders, and so the Ebola virus spread very quickly from one country to another.  The text addresses Member States, the Commission, researchers, global organisations and institutions, humanitarian aid workers and medical staff on the ground and all relevant committees, acknowledging the achievements but at the same time emphasising that much more needs to be done in order to prevent future disasters.  The EU should step up its efforts, so that others can follow its example. The EU’s voice must be heard, particularly this year, the year of development, under the slogan ‘Our world, our dignity, our future’.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report that draws on lessons learned about the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. The report calls for the establishment of a rapid European response mechanism that includes experts in the area that can be deployed quickly. It also stresses the importance of investing in the health sector for economic development and poverty reduction in developing countries and calls for the revision of the European Development Fund so that investments in health and good governance become priority areas for all countries with fragile public infrastructure. We are therefore talking about a positive report and I think it is necessary to vote in favour.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Resolution on the impact of Ebola on impoverished countries as it seems to us to introduce a number of elements which allow us to place the cause of the problem and how to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future. First, it welcomes the work of non-governmental organizations and negatively the response of governments and international institutions. Second, the effect of the International Monetary Fund's adjustment plans and illegitimate debts to southern countries on their health systems are recognized. It also condemns the monopoly of large pharmaceutical companies on patents that prevent universal access to medicines and the importance of universal access to health, calling for a new model of research and development based on principles of equality and solidarity. For all this, we have supported a Resolution that includes the right to public health and the need for fair trade to make access to medicines available to all.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We must recognize that imf and world bank programmes have destroyed the fragile health infrastructure in these countries, destroyed public health services, and not only, creating a situation of inability to deal with the progression of the epidemic. It is therefore essential to reverse this process and support the construction of universal and free public health systems; training of specialised health personnel. We must combat the hegemony of pharmaceutical companies in the development of new drugs, the dictatorship of patents; support the development of essential public services, such as in the field of water and sanitation; the external debt of these countries. We welcome, however, and appreciate all the international aid that remains necessary, and it is worth remembering here the giant example of a small country – Cuba – which alone sent more doctors and nurses to the affected countries than all other Western countries.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The rapporteur points out that the countries concerned (Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea) could have had an economic growth of 5% before the Outbreak of Ebola, but are now in recession. This report should be supported in order to enable these countries to grow again and subsequently to set up their own research institutions.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea have been victims of the largest Ebola epidemic in human history since 2014. The vulnerability of these countries and the permeability of borders have facilitated the spread of the virus, with consequent dramatic effects. The response of the international community has been slow and belated, but effective. The EU, through the appointment of a Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid, has sent out a strong signal and strengthened its role of primary strategic importance in crisis management. The role of the European institutions in stifling the epidemic has been fundamental and decisive, but serious analysis of what has happened cannot be ignored. Important for this analysis is the post-Ebola context: it is clear that it is necessary to reprogramme the European Development Fund for these three countries and to avoid a risk of general and structural underfunding of the European Union's humanitarian actions. Europe has a responsibility to these countries and to the international community and must make available the resources necessary for the support activity in the cooperation it promotes. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the Ebola crisis – long-term lessons and measures to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises. In the post-Ebola phase, aid should focus on rebuilding health care and the economy. The European Development Fund's programme for Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea needs to be reconsidered in order to meet the challenges posed by the Ebola crisis. It is good that EU money is being spent wisely here – that is rare enough. As far as the EU is humanitarian, there should be no risk of underfunding. The budget is really large enough for this.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Investment in basic healthcare is a vital pillar of development. The Ebola crisis has exposed this dramatically in West Africa, with a terrible toll on their societies. The affected countries need investment to build their own healthcare systems. Labour MEPs are fully behind the call for Universal Health Coverage, which is achievable as part of the new Sustainable Development Goals adopted by world leaders in New York in September. The framework has been set and now we need the action to achieve the right to health for all. I have been particularly concerned with the impact of the crisis on women and children, who are disproportionately affected when health services are overstretched. In my work on the FEMM Committee and ACP Delegation, I highlight the gender aspects of humanitarian aid and support, and would like to raise these here too.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The vote concerned a resolution which Parliament has taken up on its own initiative. The rapporteur regrets the slow response of the international community in the first months of the Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea. stresses that the European Union, as the main player in providing development aid, should react decisively. Its assistance will be necessary in two areas in particular: the recovery of health care and the economies of the countries affected by the crisis. I support the solutions proposed by the rapporteur aimed at improving the situation in the regions at risk: the creation of a European rapid reaction team of an expert nature and a revision of the programming of the European Development Fund in a way that takes account of the new needs of these countries. The European Union cannot downplay this humanitarian crisis. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. – I personally share the view of the report's promoter, Mr Goerens, that access to medicines should not be conditional only on the purchasing power of patients. It was in the recent Ebola epidemic that we saw that if we let the decision on what medicines to produce, in the economy and the market, it is as if we are going to sleep with a grenade under our pillow. In a globalised world, it's only a matter of time before someone pulls out an insurance policy somewhere. However, in my opinion, the same rule should apply in the European health sector, including in Slovakia.  Of course, medical research is expensive. The cost of developing the drug itself is compounded by huge investments in the education of top professionals, without which new drugs would not exist. However, we cannot charge those who live in poverty with these costs.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. The 2014-2015 Ebola epidemic has been the largest outbreak of the disease to date. It originated in December 2013 in Guinea and subsequently spread to several countries, including some in the EU. Although it has finally been able to be monitored, it has caused a period of great concern among the EU population, a considerable number of contagions and even deaths. That is why I believe that we need no further evidence to ensure that investment is needed in the development of health crisis assistance and prevention programmes, enabling the EU to act quickly and effectively in the face of any new cases that occur in the future. This would create a framework for cooperation between Member States, speeding up all processes. Thank you very much, Mr President.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report, which aims to summarise the lessons and lessons learned during the Ebola epidemic in Africa. It is important to be able to learn from the shortcomings of the past so that we can face such an epidemic in the future. I agree that the EU should pay attention to structural changes in the health system when providing development aid, allowing in the event of an epidemic, and that it should set up rapid response teams to similar health risks. I am also in favour of the idea of a similar Marshall Plan to kick-start developing countries' economies, since only strong economies can afford increased health spending.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on a common European strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian region. The individual countries of these regions share common cultural features as well as a common history, and it is therefore important that they cooperate with each other in all areas, be it the area of territorial, economic or political cooperation. The report identifies gaps and potential difficulties that may result in delays in meeting single market and environmental commitments. The report also looked at promoting so-called blue growth – that is, sea-related sectors, including sustainable fisheries, recreational activities and research.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This report analyses the Ebola crisis in Liberia, Sierra Leone and Guinea. In general terms, the rapporteur considers that the magnitude of the disaster can be attributed to several factors: the political inability of the affected countries to sound the alarm, the inadequate response of the international community, the devastating effects of border closures and restrictions on people, the ineffectiveness of surveillance and alert mechanisms, the slow and poorly adapted response when aid has been mobilised , the who's glaring lack of leadership and the lack of research and development on medicines, diagnostics and vaccines. As a more negative aspect of the report, we can highlight the uncritical tone of the slowinternational response, particularly that of the EU, and the call for the European Commission to launch a broad Public-Private Partnership, with a view to "strengthening national health systems and facilitating the transfer of results to the population", an approach that is contradictory to the objectives it proposes to achieve.  We abstained.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. The resolution on vehicle testing methods has been prompted by the systematic cheating of exhaust values by the Volkswagen Group. I chose on several occasions to vote against my own group, the EPP, in terms of transparency and access to public information on testing methods. I also voted in favour of requests for the companies that cheated to be required to repay any subsidies and subsidies received because of alleged environmental performance. This money is to be regarded as that of taxpayers, and the fraud that has taken place has also distorted competition. I voted in favour of making source codes available to the Commission and the authorities of the Member States, in order to detect possible defeat devices. This must, of course, be subject to strict secrecy in order to avoid leaks and industrial espionage. I voted against the establishment of a federal European supervisory authority, because the shortcomings of individual national authorities cannot be taken as revenue because national control is generally not working.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution on emissions measurements in the automotive sector focuses exclusively on nitrogen oxides and test tests that are recognised as not responding to real driving conditions. Something has therefore finally moved, but the problem with the text is what it does not say, what has been omitted, such as the question of public funds (research aid, State aid, various subsidies) used by manufacturers who have committed infringements. Nor does the text address the possible lack of revenue of states (as they granted tax advantages to theoretically "virtuous" cars). The issue of consumer protection is not addressed and there is also no reference to infringement procedures to be opened against manufacturers who have falsified their tests. The text clearly avoids attacking the car industries. Something had to be done immediately, clear rules were needed to be respected in order to avoid further battles, in which the only ones who would lose out would be the citizens as always. The text is a good starting point, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Clara Eugenia Aguilera García (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it condemns the multinational company Volkswagen for the emissions scandal, demanding guarantees in the measures to be taken to correct the situation caused by it. The Resolution calls for the protecting of jobs in the automotive sector, which under no circumstances can be at risk by the practices of a counterfeit directive. It also draws attention to the role played by the European Commission, which had information on the problem since 2011. Despite not being the best possible resolution, I have decided to vote in favour because it is a touch of attention to the multinational and the authorities involved in the scandal.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this joint motion for a resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it is in fact more a matter of the European industrial strategy than of an issue restricting to the environment or public health. This case serves as a lever to strengthen EU legislation and the Commission's grip on an essential part of European industry.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, as I believe that the deliberate criminal behaviour of any company should not be tolerated because it undermines the quality of European products and threatens the health of the citizens of Europe. In any case, a centralised control mechanism should be set up across the EU so that each state does not protect its illegal industries.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution, hastily drafted by the main Europeanist groups (EPP, S-D, ALDE and Greens/ALE), is the European Parliament's response to the Volkswagen case. It is fortunate that the amendment proposed by the Greens and the radical left calling for the creation of a commission of inquiry has been rejected. Another positive point: with regard to nitrogen oxide emissions, the pollution thresholds not to be exceeded, totally unrealistic, have been raised from 80 mg/km to 168 mg... However, this text contains several elements that run counter to the interests of the European automotive industry, which is already facing increased global competition.  The tone of the proposal is sanctimonious. CO2 emissions are constantly denounced while their role in global warming (largely overestimated warming) is far from scientifically proven.  Finally, the technical characteristics to be respected by the manufacturers are decided in the interest of the power that defines them. It would therefore be normal for standards to remain the responsibility of the Member States rather than the Commission. In the end, this proposal strengthens the Union's powers and exaggerates the negative impacts on the environment of diesel engines. So I voted against it.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to condemn fraud committed by car manufacturers. I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived or misled by false information about the emissions of their vehicles. I welcome the ongoing investigations in several Member States and around the world, and I support the Commission's call to national supervisory authorities to urge them to carry out extensive checks on a wide variety of brands and vehicles.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to ˗ change the testing of car pollution. The European Parliament has long called for a change in the car pollution control system and for real-world testing, not just in laboratories, because the officially declared pollution and fuel consumption indicators did not meet realistic conditions. The Volkswagen scandal has only intensified the EP's fears. This scandal can build confidence in the car industry as a whole, and it is therefore necessary to speed up the introduction of a new method for testing motor pollution.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, as it clearly and intelligiblely discusses issues relating to VW's emissions cheating. The text emphasises the protection of consumers and the enforcement of consumer rights. Additional state claims adversely affecting consumers as a result of fraud should be charged to manufacturers and not to consumers under existing national motor vehicle tax legislation. It is important that the new real-world emission measurements should apply not only to NOx, but also to all air pollutants, as opposed to the Commission's proposal. In a number of cases, the supervisory bodies of the Member States have been criticised, but the Commission's research institute has already provided the Commission with documents from 2011 to 2013, which are not known to Parliament, showing that the fact of fraud was already known to the Commission before the scandal broke, but did not inform the Member States and their supervisory bodies.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text, which considers a strategic industrial issue from a purely ecological perspective in the context of a global trade war. Volkswagen's very real offence relates to the emission of a pollutant, nitrogen dioxide (NOx), while the German car giant's diesel engines have effectively reduced emissions of carbon monoxide, a particle that oxidizes rapidly in the atmosphere to produce carbon dioxide. The text states the importance of choosing a product "based on the comprehensive and impartial technical characteristics provided to it", whereas those characteristics are generally decided in the interest of the power that defines them. These characteristics are thus part of those non-tariff barriers that are at the heart of the TTIP negotiations, and it turns out that the United States has just reduced CO2 emission rights to harm diesel engines. Undoubtedly, this scandal, which started in the United States, serves the interests of our "American partners", to the detriment of European industrialists, at the forefront of diesel engines. Finally, this case serves as a lever to strengthen EU legislation and the Commission's grip on an essential part of European industry.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In the wake of the recent revelations about Volkswagen's cheating, European leaders must seize this opportunity to tighten controls in the automotive sector. It is imperative to strengthen the legislative framework and close gaps, particularly with respect to testing methods, in order to protect public health and consumers.  The European Environment Agency counted as many as 430,000 premature deaths due to poor air quality in 2011 alone. The impact of diesel vehicles in the completion of the EU's greenhouse gas emission targets, combined with the importance of the automotive sector in general, demonstrates the need for action. That is why I support Parliament's motion for a resolution, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to work against circumventing emissions requirements and enforcing consumer rights.

name: Tiziana Beghin (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote on the resolution in general is positive, as the contents as a whole are acceptable. But there are a large number of omissions of key issues that should be considered in defence of the environment, legality, consumers, industry and workers. Examples include: the need for a European authority to establish a European authority for car testing; the detailed investigation of the case, ascertaining why the different signals were not heard; a comprehensive analysis of the adequacy of the use of public funds by the manufacturers responsible for fraud, in order to apply the corresponding sanctions.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Another motion for a resolution stemming from a political-media scandal that, as a result, misses the strategic issue for the automotive industry. In the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, the resolution is based on an erroneous premise: indeed, the diesel engines involved in the infringement emitted more nitrogen dioxide than allowed; however, the text argues that public health is endangered without considering that the cars concerned have, on the other hand, emitted less carbon monoxide, a much more harmful gas. Moreover, the resolution is wrong when it criticises the choices of the European automotive industry and affirms the need to rely on "impartial" technical characteristics: it should be remembered that these technical characteristics constitute genuine non-tariff barriers, which are currently threatened by the United States, which, through TTIP, wishes to impose its own standards to the detriment of its European competitors. Since this resolution wishes to act in emotion and not in the interest of our industry, I therefore voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is partly acceptable, there are still parts that I believe are partisan and deliberately driven towards a non-solution, such as the Commission's proposal to make preliminary tests more in accordance with driving conditions, but does not define which reference values there are in the post-registration period of the vehicle. For all these reasons, I abstained.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it has been responded to by Parliament in response to the recent Volkswagen scandal over the results of counterfeit car pollution tests. Parliament called for a thorough investigation into the falsification of the results of car pollution tests and for the guilty to be punished. The resolution proposes reforming the EU car pollution control system, introducing real-world pollution testing, as well as allowing national authorities to revoke authorisations for vehicles that exceed EU emission limits. Parliament has strongly condemned the car manufacturers' fraud and regrets the disappointment of millions of consumers, as well as further pollution of the environment and the harm to human health. Parliament also fears that this scandal could undermine the competitiveness of the entire EU automotive sector, which contributes to growth, innovation and job creation.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed resolution.  I am convinced that the new standards on fuel consumption and emissions will do us no good if we do not follow the existing ones. They must be taken into account, rather than played out, as happened in the Volkswagen scandal.  This behaviour is unacceptable and throws a very bad light on the entire European car industry. If we want to demand that other countries outside the EU comply with our legislation, it is european companies that should stick to it the most.  The European Commission has already responded to this scandal and has strongly condemned these irregularities and called on EU Member States to launch national investigations into whether vehicles comply with European rules.  It is also worth mentioning the EU strategy to limit fuel consumption and CO2 emissions of heavy goods vehicles (including buses), which represents a path to a low-carbon society and a plan to transform the EU into a low-carbon economy by 2050. There is no doubt, however, that both the Commission and the Member States must make further efforts to correct irregularities, to control more sharply and effectively, and to ensure that consumers who are among the biggest victims of such infringements are properly informed.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The scandal of rigging exhaust tests is actually an attack on the health and consumer rights of citizens and the economy of the European Union and the Member States. "Damage" is the release of nitric oxides, which are especially harmful to the liver, lungs and blood count of citizens. They were cheated into selling more expensive cars that were supposedly less harmful to the environment.  If the scandal is found not limited to Volkswagen vehicles, the consequences for the European auto industry could be unseen. There is almost no Member State that does not produce something that is installed in cars. In Croatia, a country that does not produce cars, over 9000 people work in the auto industry. Consumer confidence has been building for years, and it's losing overnight. Therefore, it is necessary to thoroughly and transparently investigate the whole case and establish a new system that will measure exhaust gases while driving.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, following the scandal involving Volkswagen concerning measurements of car exhaust emissions, it is necessary for the INSTITUTIONS of the European Union to work to punish those who have violated the rules and to prevent future violations. We cannot allow the confidence of millions of consumers to be betrayed in this way.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There can be no tolerance in the face of environmental pollution caused by the automotive industry. Every fraud committed by car manufacturers must be strongly condemned: it is necessary to investigate and punish all those responsible for data handling plants, the authorities of states that have not supervised sufficiently and the promoters of the fraud that has risked compromising the entire automotive sector, with consequent negative repercussions on innovation, employment, growth and savings of millions of citizens, as well as damage to health and the environment caused by excessive polluting emissions.  The Commission must report to Parliament on the outcome of the investigations as soon as possible and apply the appropriate sanctions. Emissions tests must also be strengthened and redesigned, acting on the road as well as in the laboratory, and guaranteed by an EU supervisory authority. A sample of randomly selected car models must, each year, be monitored in normal use activities and laboratory tests, falsification practices such as excessive tyre inflating, removal of external rear-view mirrors, coverage of spaces between body panels to reduce aerodynamic drag, removal of equipment such as stereo system and testing at the highest authorized ambient temperature shall be prevented.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Volkswagen scandal revealed that the German company had configured its diesel engines to evade nitrogen dioxide emission controls. This motion for a resolution addresses this offence only from an environmental perspective, whereas this is a strategic issue between two trading powers, namely Germany and the United States. Furthermore, it does not note that this offence limits the emission of carbon monoxide, a gas that is extremely harmful to the environment. Finally, it is essential to understand that emission limits are non-tariff customs barriers because they are skewed by arbitrary decisions by national authorities which cannot be impartial in this strategic sector.  Although I have no empathy for large groups that are constantly trying to circumvent national laws, I do not think it makes any sense to abandon the commercial aspect of this case. Moreover, the rapporteur is taking advantage of the context to strengthen EU legislation at the expense of Member States, which will lose autonomy in a sector of activity that is highly strategic in terms of jobs. So I voted against it.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector.  With this resolution, Parliament has strongly condemned any fraud committed by car manufacturers and has urged companies to take full responsibility for their actions and to cooperate unconditionally with the authorities in their investigations. It also called for fraud in emissions testing to be thoroughly verified, stressing that the EU emissions testing system should be strengthened to ensure that limits are respected and that vehicles that exceed them are quickly identified.  Given that excess emissions have harmful effects, even very serious ones, on human health and environmental damage, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which dealt with the so-called Volkswagen case. The immediate and strong common reaction to this scandal should be to restore consumers’ trust and to stop these horrendous environmentally hazardous activities in Europe.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as I am concerned about the recent breach of EU market regulations by European companies discovered by the relevant American authorities.  I believe that we need to reassess our control measures, standards and goals when it comes to the automotive industry and make them more realistic.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution contains some serious omissions which clearly have as their objective the preservation of the political and industrial status quo. However, its overall content is acceptable and I have therefore voted in favour of it. However, I would like to highlight the omissions, and therefore the additional actions that need to be taken to protect the environment, legality, consumers, industry (especially car-related SMEs) and workers.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector which, in my opinion, can pave the way for thorough investigations to shed light on the Volkswagen case.  I fully support the call for strengthening of the European emissions control system and the application of real-world driving tests, which are essential for measuring all pollutants and urgent for all those who, like me, defend an innovative and responsible European industry.  The establishment of a European supervisory authority to oversee the registration of vehicles by national authorities is also necessary to protect itself independently against any attempt to infringe.  Finally, I welcome the European Parliament's determination not to condemn diesel technologies in a peremptory way. It was important to mix ambition with realism, at a time when Europe has a technological lead in clean diesel and where many European citizens with modest incomes own diesel vehicles.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution because I believe that we need to assure our citizens that we do care about the interests of consumers, car owners, but also all of us who are exposed to air pollution. The resolution calls on the Commission and other stakeholders involved, notably in the Member States, to adopt measures and take concrete actions which will quickly restore the confidence of consumers, which I consider is currently of utmost importance. Also, we have to bear in mind that this cannot be done while putting too much pressure on the car manufacturers, as they are part of the solution.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Through the Socialist and Democrats Group for years we have been crying out and pushing for realistic testing that assesses real, on-road conditions. It was well known that the current ones and, by extension, the Euro 6 standards, were a joke on everyone who can breathe. Only this week, the first peer-reviewed academic study came out, estimating that 60 premature deaths can be attributed to Volkswagen cars in the US alone When the European automobile industry knows they can dictate policy whenever their bottom line is at stake, championed by the Union’s most powerful country, is it any wonder that they believe themselves free to act like they are above the law?  Ultimately, postponing necessary measures serves only to generate short-term savings for private interests that come at a huge cost to society as a whole. Those who think themselves pragmatic by protecting the industry and the European economy by doing so are seriously deluded. They are postponing the roll-out of clean innovation solutions that are the future of the car industry and others, subsidising the dirtiest kinds of fossil fuels, like diesel, in all sorts of visible and invisible ways. They are lying to themselves and to the public and, in the process, condemning many of us to a premature death.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent scandal of a well-known German car industry not only undermined european consumer confidence, but revealed the numerous shortcomings of the vehicle CO2 emissions measurement system. The effectiveness of EU policy and the credibility of the ambitious reduction limits imposed on the sector have also been undermined to some extent. This is a serious matter, which will have to open up the political debate on the possibility of delegating to an independent body the supervision of tests in order to verify the appropriateness of emissions with the limits set by EU legislation.  If it were decided to ban diesel engines, the future of the car industry would be seriously at risk. My thoughts can only be with all those workers working in this sector. That is why the new real driving emissions test must be regulated without further delay, in order to ensure that the mandatory targets set for the car industry are met and to give European consumers the confidence to buy products that meet the declared values.  We expect transparency in the European Commission's handling of the case and expect it to report on the investigations it will conduct to clarify what happened.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 The report calls on the Commission to ensure that the information provided to consumers under the DIRECTIVE on car labelling in the EU is accurate, relevant and comparable. We believe that labels should be based on emission and fuel consumption values corresponding to actual driving conditions. We are concerned about the discrepancy between the CO2 emissions declared in the official test results and those measured in real driving conditions. At the same time, we call for a rapid agreement on the correlation with the WLTP standard for average CO2 emission targets for the entire fleet.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP joint resolution on measuring emissions in the automotive sector. Air pollution causes over 400 thousand deaths per year in Europe, at an estimated cost of EUR 940 billion per year. The automotive industry is one of the biggest drivers of growth and innovation and contributes to employment in many EU Member States. The EU has set strict limits for NOx emissions with the Euro 5 (limit value 180mg/km) and Euro 6 (limit value 80mg/km) standards.  With this resolution, Parliament strongly condemns any fraud committed by car manufacturers, expresses its concern at the serious delay with which the Commission and the Member States have reacted to the serious and persistent exceedance of emission limits and calls on the Commission to publish the results of the investigations under way in the Member States by 31 March 2016. Finally, the Commission is asked to speed up the introduction of the so-called 'real driving emissions' test.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution. The car industry has a huge impact on employment, and traditionally it has had it mainly in my home region. However, unless decisive action is taken, the current scandal risks undermining the reputation and competitiveness of the entire sector. I also emphasise that air pollution causes over 430 000 premature deaths per year in the EU and has an estimated cost, in terms of health impact, of up to EUR 940 billion per year; NOx is one of the main air pollutants responsible, among other things, for causing lung cancer, asthma and numerous respiratory diseases, as well as forms of environmental degradation such as eutrophication and acidification. Finally, I believe it is essential for the Commission and the Member States to restore consumer confidence quickly through concrete initiatives and to make every effort to defuse the situation.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Air pollution by emission is becoming a serious threat to EU citizens’ health, causing 430 000 premature deaths every year. The report notes that transport continues to contribute to poor air quality in urban areas and 20 Member States are currently not meeting the EU air quality limits. An investigation into vehicle emissions test manipulation is welcomed and extensive checks should be conducted by the relevant national authorities. The Commission should put in place a new Real Driving Emissions test cycle as soon as practicable. These measures will strive to protect the wellbeing of EU citizens who are currently at risk of contracting diseases due to overexposure. This measure will also work to create additional protection for the environment, aiming to regulate emissions.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. On September 18, 2015, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Board (CARB) issued a pollution violation notice for volkswagen group diesel vehicles, and the group later admitted to installing software that was being tested when the car was undergoing testing , reducing the amount of emissions.  I support this Resolution in which the European Parliament condemns any fraud perpetrated by car manufacturers, urging companies to assume all their responsibilities and to cooperate with the authorities in investigations. The European Commission should rethink the current type-approval sregime to ensure that the approvals and certificates of the competent national authorities can be independently verified. The European Commission and the competent authorities of all Member States should have the right to reassess type-approval and certificate of conformities, as well as demand withdrawal and put an end to placing on the market of vehicles when they have evidence of non-compliance with EU emission limit values. The Commission should immediately adopt and implement the new emission testing cycle under real driving conditions.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Immediately after the Volkswagen scandal, the European Parliament debated a motion for a resolution tabled by several political groups, which was intended to represent the political manifesto of commitment to stop the emissions scam implemented by car companies as soon as possible. The text that has arrived in this House had already been the result of tough negotiations between the political groups and contained indications that we can support everything that is expected to happen in the near future, starting with measurements of emissions on the road for the type-approval of vehicles. That is why I voted in favour of its adoption.  At the same time, however, we wanted to enable citizens to know the names of those in Parliament who continue to cover industrial interests. That is why we have tabled in this House the amendments which the large political groups had deleted from the initial text and which provided, among other things, for the investigation to be extended to all brands and for the obligation to repay the tax incentives from which the car manufacturers whose fraud was found had benefited. The name of those who did not want to return public money paid to facilitate the purchase of less polluting cars is so available to anyone who wants to know it.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it condemns the multinational company Volkswagen for the emissions scandal, demanding guarantees in the measures to be taken to correct the situation caused by it. The Resolution calls for the protecting of jobs in the automotive sector, which under no circumstances can be at risk by the practices of a counterfeit directive. It also draws attention to the role played by the European Commission, which had information on the problem since 2011. Despite not being the best possible resolution, I have decided to vote in favour because it is a touch of attention to the multinational and the authorities involved in the scandal.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution calling for an investigation into fraud in tests to measure emissions from cars. We need joint European action and the development of an emission test based on real data, not laboratory data. We cannot stand idly by and watch either the cheating of pollutant emissions affecting people's health or the negative events affecting the European car industry. Improving the control and licensing system can help.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The resolution stresses the need of real driving emissions test to ensure that new cars on EU roads finally meet the Euro 6 limits agreed almost 10 years ago. It also mentions the need to establish an independent EU wide Type Approval Authority that would oversee testing and be truly independent. Finally it also stresses that workers should not pay for the mistakes of the executives and every precautionary measure should be taken to guarantee that no jobs will be lost while the scandal should be seen as an opportunity for the European car industry to invest into more targeted R&D. These are all points which I have brought up in my various recent interventions in the role of S&D spokesperson on the issues of vehicle emissions, hence I have supported this resolution with my vote.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's proposal to present the Commission with a new design of the current type-approval scheme in order to ensure, on the one hand, that type-approvals and certificates of conformity issued by the competent national authorities can be independently verified and reassessed by the Commission, where appropriate, in order to ensure a level playing field at EU level , and, on the other hand, that EU regulations are effectively implemented and the shortcomings of implementing measures are corrected without the necessary increase in administrative burden.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The joint resolution I supported sums up the European Parliament's position on the recent emissions scandal, which involved the car manufacturer Volkswagen and had serious repercussions on the reputation of the entire European production sector. The seriousness of the facts established so far means that the European institutions, together with the Member States, must act urgently and radically. For this reason, I believe it is necessary to define higher common standards and to strengthen the reliability of emissions tests at European level, so as to ensure that an effective real drive emission system is applied without further delay. I also believe that more transparent and careful control systems should be defined, providing for measures such as the creation of an independent European type-approval authority. The European Union cannot allow unfair behaviour by individual producers to call into question the credibility of european manufacturing as a whole. That is why it is necessary to strengthen the European system of supervision and control of consumer goods and to restore full consumer confidence in the quality of 'made in Europe' products as soon as possible.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report reviews national emission caps for certain pollutants to improve air quality and human health. The text introduces new limit values (e.g. sulphur dioxide, ultrafine particles or methane) from 2020 and 2030. It also proposes a binding intermediate target in 2025 for all pollutants except ammonia. Other measures include access to air quality improvement funding and emissions control programs. There has been many oppositions, both on the level of ambition of the reduction targets for 2020, 2025 and 2030, and on the addition of new pollutants. Considering that we do not currently have an effective technical or technological means to reduce emissions of enteric methane (rejection of livestock), I have co-signed an amendment, the content of which was taken up by the plenary to exclude these emissions from the directive, so as not to penalise the agricultural sector. I regret, however, that my amendments to protect small farms and exclude ammonia have not been adopted. Nevertheless, supporting the main objectives of this report, I voted in favour of opening negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. In the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, this text adopted by a large majority in the European Parliament on emissions measures in the automotive sector condemns the fraud committed by car manufacturers. I would argue that there is a need to quickly restore consumer confidence and that a thorough investigation must be carried out into cases of car emissions test fraud. However, it is not for us to undermine the entire automotive sector, which is essential to the European economy, or to condemn the use of diesel definitively.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – In the aftermath of the Volkswagen scandal, it has become clear that the methods we are currently using to measure car emissions are not accurate enough. That is why I voted in favour of this resolution, because it calls, among other things, for an emissions test to be introduced in real driving conditions as soon as possible. This should give consumers a better view of the real consumption and emissions of their car.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. A few weeks ago, the U.S. Federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) revealed a large-scale fraud organized by the Volkswagen Group. The German carmaker is said to have equipped some of its cars with software to hide the actual level of emissions of polluting gases in the event of a check.  Beyond condemning these frauds, the European Commission will need to ensure that testing and controls are strengthened and thus better protect consumers. More than that, I would like to see a commission of inquiry opened to shed light on what happened so that it does not happen again.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. The automotive industry makes a huge contribution to the entire European economy, so the sector must not fall victim to the fraud organised by a few. Car emissions test fraud must be thoroughly investigated and appropriate sanctions applied, but this should not be an opportunity to ideologically set aside diesel. While many of our low-income citizens drive diesel vehicles, while Europe has a real technological lead in "clean" diesel. We therefore urgently need to bring the conditions of the certification tests closer to the actual driving conditions. The Commission should also carry out an overhaul of the vehicle reception system and ensure that receipt and certificates issued by the relevant national authorities can be independently verified and possibly reassessed by the Commission and Member States.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. Every day, new revelations surface about the car emissions test fraud scandal. I supported this resolution because I condemn this organised fraud that has eaten away at millions of people and because I believe it is essential that a thorough investigation be carried out and that appropriate sanctions are taken. We know the devastation caused by air pollution. We have just set new caps for some key pollutants and next month the major climate conference will be held. Excess emissions of pollutants have many harmful effects on human health and cause premature deaths. They also produce environmental damage. The VW scandal also has a significant impact on the reputation and competitiveness of the automotive sector. However, this sector is one of the main drivers of growth and innovation and contributes to employment in a significant number of Member States.  For these reasons, I believe that the whole European emissions control system must be strengthened without further delay, that the Commission must be involved in the ongoing investigations in several Member States and that a supervisory authority should be set up at European level.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because the Volkswagen scandal mainly affects Germany and must be investigated at national level. I agree that the systematic use of illegal devices has a serious impact on the economy and the internal market. I also strongly support that there should be investigations into this and Volkswagen must bear responsibility for what happened.  However, I do not think it is right for the European Commission to conduct this investigation, despite violations of the European directives on maximum emissions from cars. An investigation directly by the European Commission will undermine national sovereignty and intervene in a scandal falling within the national jurisdiction of the states.  The right and most efficient way to tackle this problem in the automotive industry are investigations and cooperation programmes at national level.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution in its entirety on the new measures in the automotive sector and we agree with the imposition of sanctions and fines on VW. The fraud of this company, with its managers responsible, highlighted the weakness of the control procedures applied by the European authorities. Immediate corrective action must be taken without affecting consumers in any way, and the committee must carry out an urgent investigation into this case. The new proposal on emissions of Euro6 vehicles under real driving conditions should also be finalised immediately. Finally, we agree that the legislative measures to be taken should not place undue burdens on European industry.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. In the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, the European Parliament has debated a motion for a resolution tabled by various political groups, which was supposed to be the political manifesto of a commitment to stop the emissions scam by car companies as soon as possible.  The text that has arrived in this House had already been the result of bitter negotiations between the political groups and contained indications that we can support everything that is expected to happen in the near future, starting with the measurement of emissions on the road for the type-approval of vehicles. That is why I voted in favour of its adoption.  At the same time, however, we wanted to give citizens the opportunity to know the names of those in Parliament who continue to cover industrial interests. That is why we have tabled in this House the amendments which the large political groups had deleted from the initial text and which provided, among other things, for the investigation to be extended to all brands and for the obligation to repay the tax incentives from which the car manufacturers whose fraud was found had benefited. The name of those who did not want to return public money paid to facilitate the purchase of less polluting cars is so available to anyone who wants to know it.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I think it is good and important that Parliament should clearly mark against deliberate environmental fraud and against excessively poor testing methods for car emissions. European consumers must be able to trust that the car they buy actually lives up to the emission levels promised. I have therefore voted in favour of the proposal.

name: José Manuel Fernandes (PPE)
text: in writing. Members have always advocated the introduction of measures to improve and harmonise emissions tests to better reflect the actual conditions of use of motor vehicles. Air pollution causes more than 430 000 premature deaths in the EU every year and has an estimated cost of €940 billion due to its health effects. The automotive industry is one of the main drivers of growth and innovation, contributing to employment in a large number of Member States, and in the absence of firm action, the current scandal could undermine the reputation and competitiveness of the entire sector, as it has hit millions of consumers who have been misled and misled. I condone any fraud perpetrated by car manufacturers, and companies should assume all their responsibilities for their actions and cooperate fully with the authorities in investigations, and it is essential that the Commission and the Member States quickly restore consumer confidence through concrete measures, making every possible effort to unwind the situation.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We are facing another scandal denouncing the true essence of capitalism. This case – of which we do not yet know all the contours, nor the implications it has in all its fullness – denotes well the known dominance of economic power over political power. On September 18, 2015, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Atmospheric Resources Council (CARB) issued a notice of violation of pollution standards applicable to Volkswagen AG, Audi AG and Volkswagen Group of America. Knowing that these are practices for years, one may wonder why now the revelation – a question whose answer will not be disconnected from the trade wars between the two biggest colossi of the automotive industry. The European Commission was alerted in 2013, through a report by the Joint Research Centre, to the potential existence of illegal software in diesel vehicles of the Volkswagen Group. Nevertheless, it did not warn the competent national authorities of the Member States about the impact of defeat devices on the reliability of measuring emissions from diesel cars. Basically, it has done nothing, so demonstrating how, despite all the rhetoric associated with environmental issues, it is manipulated by the interests of large multinational companies, which actually command the European Union.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as much mere transparency is needed I this area. How could anyone disagree at this stage.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ after the Volkswagen emissions scandal broke, the European Commission must investigate very thoroughly any potential manipulation of the approval process and tests by Volkswagen as well as other car companies. The European Commission is obliged to take all necessary steps to improve and harmonise the emissions testing process, in order to better take into account the real-world conditions, which are often very different from those of the laboratory where the tests are carried out. It is very important that we continue to work to improve and improve the implementation and enforcement of European legislation, thus eliminating any shortcomings it has. Intentional criminal behaviour by any large and important society must not be tolerated, as it endangers the lives of the people of the Member States, but also undermines their trust.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 This relationship is not objectively balanced. It does not focus on the real problem on the agenda. We are all aware that the parameters set by the EU were unrealistic and not feasible. Not to mention the rules on Euro 5 and Euro 6, which were supposed to save our lungs but whose ineffectiveness has been seen. From this point of view, the Volkswagen problem is therefore serious but relative. The resolution does not make a mark and I will have to abstain.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution in its entirety on the new measures in the automotive sector and I agree with the imposition of sanctions and fines on VW. The fraud of this company, with its managers responsible, highlighted the weakness of the control procedures applied by the European authorities. Corrective measures and checks must be implemented immediately if VW's tactics have been adopted by other European car manufacturers, without affecting consumers in any way, and the committee must carry out an urgent investigation into this case. The new proposal on emissions of Euro6 vehicles under real driving conditions should also be finalised immediately. Finally, I agree that the legislative measures to be taken should not place undue burdens on European industry.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Such frauds as the one exposed by the Volkswagen scandal are truly unacceptable: an action against health and the environment that can neither be tolerated nor forgiven. While we were investing a huge amount of money in technological development for a low carbon footprint we were neither improving nor harmonising our emissions testing adequately to safeguard us from being fooled by these cheaters. It is absolutely necessary for the Commission to investigate any kind of manipulation in this sector, to standardise emission testing at the level of the 28 Member States, to cooperate with nation states to improve their monitoring capacity, and to make all possible efforts to avoid this kind of situation in the future.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it strongly condemns fraud in measuring polluting emissions in cars, fraud committed by Volkswagen by having installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information concerning the emissions of their vehicles; emissions that cause harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that it is not workers who pay the price for manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth, innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the creation of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The recent Volkswagen case has inevitably raised a number of alarms and reflections in the Union and around the world to which we must give voice and response, in order to help us reintegrate EU development and growth plans into a market framework that is not only economically competitive, but also a guarantor of safety for our health and the environment.
