The challenge for the EU, and for its products and activities, is to be able to secure a trade bet for the future that is also concretely sustainable. That is why I agree with the proposal to take a number of measures to ensure that the recent facts established in the Volkswagen case do not happen again and that consumers can regain confidence by consolidating the choice of EU products as a guarantee of a healthy and controlled market.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on measuring emissions in the automotive sector because I believe that the United Parliament must send a strong signal on such an important issue as emissions of pollutants from cars.  The VW scandal has highlighted the shortcomings of the European system: inadequate legislation that has allowed the use of technologies and stratagems to circumvent regulatory obligations, poor controls, the absence of a single supervisory body, and the influence of lobbies. The environment is a common good, as is air quality, hence the need for clear and strict EU rules, which leave no room for discretion, and above all for new European supervisors. I agree with the demands for new checks carried out under real driving conditions, a new EU-wide type-approval process with a single responsible authority, new emission legislation and the rapid implementation of Euro6 engines.  Above all, we call on workers not to pay for management's wrong choices through redundancies, for the company to finance compliance with environmental legislation with its own profits rather than by cutting costs and for employee protection to be ensured at all levels, including at European level.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report 'Emissions measurements in the automotive industry' today because, also in the wake of the VW scandal, I believe that a new, updated and better control method is important. I strongly condemn attempts by individual Members to table amendments in the course of this legislative process, which have been drafted obviously and verifiably by the car industry.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, although unfortunately it does not address all aspects of the problem of exhaust emissions in the automotive industry. It is fierce, suggesting a more ambitious treatment of far-reaching emission limits for new vehicles not only on test stands, but also during the movement of diesel engines that drive them. The resolution omits the damage (environmental and health) to the environment and people caused and continues to be done by older engines. It is almost certain that, for example, Euro 4 and Euro 5 standards, like Euro 6, have not been complied with in practice. There is no call for all Member States to adopt a repair clause in this resolution, yet it can improve the maintenance of low-carbon operating standards throughout the automotive European market.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. It is important that we can reliably evaluate emissions from automobiles, not only in the context of climate change, but also in order to ensure an optimal quality of life in our cities and communities. To achieve this, we need a control system that is realistic and based on practical results.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The EU decided that diesel was clean, and would save the planet for us all!! And so pushed Member States to push diesel.  They then decided that SOx and NOx was going to kill us all, so made those car companies that were now selling shed loads of diesels to reduce the emissions that diesels emit. Good luck with that one. The result... Fiddling, on a mighty scale. How long has the EU known? And how long has our UK Government known? This is a can of worms that must be dealt with, but shows that ill thought out, knee—jerk legislation is the worst kind.  And Europe is pretty good at that.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because we cannot tolerate intentional criminal behaviour from the side of any company, no matter the size. It not only breaks public trust and undermines the quality of European products, but it also causes significant health damage to the European population. That is why I call for the introduction of a real driving emissions test to be implemented by 2017 for all vehicles to ensure that new cars on EU roads finally meet the Euro 6 limits and the establishment of an independent EU Type Approval Authority that would oversee testing. Furthermore, workers should not pay for the mistakes of the executives and every precautionary measure should be taken to guarantee that no jobs will be lost. The scandal should be seen as an opportunity for the European car industry to invest into more targeted R&D so as to move faster towards our next step which is the electrification of the European car fleet.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the research of an NGO, Volkswagen admitted to having installed illegal software to cheat emission tests in the laboratory in at least 11 million vehicles worldwide, thus admitting a fraud affecting millions of consumers.  The same test results were also made available to the EU and national authorities, but no action was taken at the time. A further revelation showed that a 2011 report by the Joint Research Centre, a body of the EU, already pointed out discrepancies between emissions measured in the laboratory and on-road performance. It suggested that this gap could be due to the inadequacy of the test procedure in the EU and to the use of defeat devices.  In the light of such fraud, I welcome this resolution that condemns this fraud, asks for transparency and appropriate sanctions to be taken and urges the Commission to implement Real Driving Emission tests. I also voted in favour of the establishment of a European Parliament Committee of Inquiry in order to conduct an investigation on the responsibility of the Commission and of Member States in the lack of implementation and enforcement of the EU law.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR is deeply concerned about practices by automotive manufacturers which have deliberately set out to cheat emissions standards. This is to the detriment of consumers and the environment, and unfairly damages the reputation of the workers and suppliers linked to those companies. As noted in its own resolution, the ECR is a strong supporter of carrying out investigations in the Member States into possible manipulation of the testing regime. We believe that once those investigations have been concluded, the Commission will be in the possession of facts and analysis that will help shape a reformed type approval system. Until those investigations are complete we do not believe we have all of the facts, and as such we cannot support a resolution which purports to know all of the answers. Regrettably the joint text adopted today puts forward unsubstantiated allegations of Member State and Commission complicity, and prejudges the outcome of those investigations by calling for the establishment of an EU-level type approval regime, wholly out of step with the need for a measured policy based on evidence. The ECR has therefore voted against the text, and commends its own resolution to the Parliament for a more considered view.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution because, according to the research centre under the European Commission, in 2013 the car emission detection tests presented problems because they could enable the use of tricked-out devices that activate or modify emission control systems with the aim of improving their effectiveness during the implementation of the checks. The Volkswagen scandal is the tip of the iceberg of a fraudulent system but it is NOT an isolated case; they have hit the engines of millions of diesel cars around the world, polluting up to 40 times more than allowed, and we consider it vital to change emission control mechanisms to be carried out in real driving circumstances and that this situation is not repeated. Moreover, this Resolution stresses the importance of not employees ultimately paying the consequences of the breaches incurred by the company.

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament this week voted on a strong resolution following the revelations of the "Volkswagen scandal".  First, car emissions test fraud must be thoroughly investigated and appropriate sanctions applied. Secondly, given the scale of this crisis, Europe must necessarily introduce emission tests in a real-life situation, which respect legal emission limits and are fully implemented. Thirdly, Parliament wishes to be fully informed of the work under way at the European Commission and the Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles (CTVM). Finally, I personally regret that our request for a commission of inquiry did not obtain a majority. This would have been an opportunity to mark the occasion, and above all to put in the hands of a body other than the European Commission this responsibility to clear things up.

name: Françoise Grossetête (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. The automotive industry makes a huge contribution to the entire European economy, so the whole sector must not be a victim of the fraud organised by some companies. Car emissions test fraud must be thoroughly investigated and appropriate sanctions applied, but this cannot be an opportunity to ideologically set aside diesel. While many of our low-income citizens are driving with diesel vehicles, while Europe has a real technological lead in "clean" diesel, this would be a serious mistake! We therefore urgently need to bring the conditions of the certification tests closer to the actual driving conditions. The Commission should also carry out an overhaul of the vehicle reception system to ensure, on the one hand, that receipt and certificates issued by the relevant national authorities can be independently verified and possibly reassessed by the Commission and Member States.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of this important resolution for European consumers. It strongly condemns emissions test fraud by car manufacturers and paves the way for in-depth investigations. All this goes in the right direction to shed light on the Volkswagen case. It also calls for a review of emission tests so that they are carried out in real driving conditions by 2017, rather than in the laboratory, and that they are extended to all pollutants. Finally, it suggests considering the creation of a supervisory authority at European level. Although the importance of not placing the consequences of these frauds on employees is underlined (they cannot be held responsible for the actions of the governing bodies), my Socialist colleagues and I would have liked the text to go further. I regret that an amendment on the protection of workers and subcontractors in the automotive sector has been rejected. I also regret the adoption of a diesel amendment. This is a missed opportunity to reverse the trend and support the transition to alternative fuels.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector because the European Parliament considers it regrettable that these excess emissions have caused unnecessary premature deaths, harmful effects on human health, and environmental damage, deplores the serious lack of enforcement of EU internal market regulation and calls on the sector of the automobile industry having engaged in unfair practices to finance and support updates of independent rankings of road vehicles on the basis of environmental performance, among other actions.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report but was disappointed that an amendment to ensure reimbursement of subsidies and tax benefits received on the basis of claimed environmental performance where a defeat device was found was narrowly defeated. This sends the wrong messages to Member States and to companies. EU subsidies must be conditional on a genuine and documented effort to earn them – otherwise the penalties for non-compliance are meaningless. Surely fraud has to be punished at all levels. Secondly there is the thorny question of who is to blame, and if we are to call for enquiries/investigations etc. we cannot prejudge the outcomes. We accepted the need for these enquiries, so saying someone was to blame or not to blame at this point in time is redundant. The time for that debate is when we see the outcome of investigations and not before.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this report because although the automotive industry is one of the key contributors to growth, employment and innovation, decisive action must be taken against the current scandals which risk undermining the reputation and competiveness of the entire sector. Air pollution causes over 430 000 premature deaths in the EU yearly and costs up to an estimated EUR 940 billion annually as result of the health impacts. Up to a third of the EU’s urban population continues to be exposed to levels above the limits or targets values set by the EU and transport continues to be a main contributor to these poor air quality levels.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. Despite several attempts by the ALFA delegation to produce a balanced text, the resolution resulting from the VW scandal contains unfounded accusations of complicity between the Member States and the Commission in the emissions scandal. The request prejudges the results of the ongoing investigations by calling for more EU oversight and new control rights for the Commission with regard to authorisation procedures. Some groups have used the VW scandal to include their own ideological hobby horses, such as .B the suspension of the TTIP negotiations, in this motion for a resolution. We need an agreement between the Member States and the European Commission on uniform standards for future audit procedures. However, we are opposed to further centralisation. Member States and their competent authorities must retain the right to reconsider authorisation procedures and, if necessary, to request recalls of products, provided that they can demonstrate evidence of non-compliance with EU emission levels. It is also important to prevent scandals of this dimension effectively and in an factual way. The manipulation by VW has nothing to do with the lack of representation of the current tests. Rather, the discrepancy between test results and real driving conditions should be minimized. That is why we supported these points in the resolution, but rejected the text as a whole.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We are right to address the global scandal about Volkswagen. I am proud to have campaigned successfully for the EU Non-Financial Reporting Directive – which requires companies to report and thus act on their environmental and other societal impacts. I am quite happy to say that I used Volkswagen who are members of a forum called ‘econsense’, which is the environmental interest group within the German employers group, to lobby internally to help win German support for the EU Directive. And they did do it. So, yes, Volkswagen's corporate governance failed badly. But we should also ask ourselves: why are diesel emission standards so much tougher in America than in Europe? Four years ago the World Health Organisation changed its rating for diesel exhaust from ‘probably carcinogenic to humans’, to ‘carcinogenic to humans.’ So I will not use today’s debate just to have a cheap hit at a car company, but instead to say we must learn from the failure of markets and of the European regulatory system, to recognise the science and adapt accordingly.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector, given that air pollution is the cause of over 430,000 premature deaths in the EU each year and the cost of its impact on health is estimated at €940 billion per year, and as this document is directly related to recently discovered violations of current US pollution regulations for Volkswagen AG, Audi AG and the US Volkswagen Group.  This condemns all forms of fraud by car manufacturers; responsibility is required; regrets the deceived consumers and highlights the problem of regaining consumer trust; welcomes other investigations launched in several Member States; calls on the Commission to adopt and implement a new cycle of real-world testing without delay and to ensure its entry into force for regulatory purposes.  In particular, it underlines the requirement that the Commission 'introduce real-world driving emission testing for all vehicles that have undergone type approval or are registered in 2015 in order to ensure the efficiency of emission control systems. Among other things, it calls on the Commission to ensure that the information provided to consumers under the EU Vehicle Labelling Directive (1999/94/EC) is accurate, relevant and comparable.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution, hastily submitted by the main Europeanist groups (EPP, S-D, ALDE and Greens/FTA), is none other than the European Parliament's response to the Volkswagen case. It is certainly commendable that the amendment proposed by the Greens and the radical left, calling for the creation of a commission of inquiry, has been rejected. It is also to be welcomed that, with regard to nitrogen oxide emissions, the pollution thresholds not to be exceeded, totally unrealistic, have been raised from 80 mg/km to 168 mg. However, this text through some of these provisions contravenes the interests of the European automotive industry, which is already facing formidable global competition.  The rhetoric of the proposal is sanctimonious. CO2 emissions are constantly denounced while their role in global warming (largely overestimated warming) is far from scientifically proven.  Finally, the technical characteristics to be respected by the manufacturers are decided in the interest of the power that defines them. It would therefore be normal for standards to remain the responsibility of the Member States rather than the Commission. Subsequently, this proposal strengthens the POWERS of the EU and exaggerates the environmental effects of diesel engines.  So I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today my MEP colleagues and I voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because, in the wake of the Volkswagen scandal, it was necessary for the European Parliament to remind Member States and the European Commission of their obligations to control pollution and to stress the need to review the current system of car control in Europe.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. It is not possible to agree on this, although it is in principle a balanced resolution with some good proposals that make the emissions test procedure more independent and transparent.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution. Intentional criminal behaviour will not be tolerated as it not only breaks public trust and undermines the quality of European products but it also causes significant health damage to the European population.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. Despite several attempts by the ALFA delegation to produce a balanced text, the resolution resulting from the VW scandal contains unfounded accusations of complicity between the Member States and the Commission in the emissions scandal. The request prejudges the results of the ongoing investigations by calling for more EU oversight and new control rights for the Commission with regard to authorisation procedures. Some groups have used the VW scandal to include their own ideological hobby horses, such as .B the suspension of the TTIP negotiations in this motion for a resolution. We need an agreement between the Member States and the European Commission on uniform standards for future audit procedures. However, we are opposed to further centralisation. Member States and their competent authorities must retain the right to reconsider authorisation procedures and, if necessary, to request recalls of products, provided that they can demonstrate evidence of non-compliance with EU emission levels. It is also important to prevent scandals of this dimension effectively and in an factual way. The manipulation by VW has nothing to do with the lack of representation of the current tests. Rather, the discrepancy between test results and real driving conditions should be minimized. That is why I supported these points in the resolution, but nevertheless rejected the text as a whole.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Statistics show that air pollution causes more than 430 000 premature deaths in the EU each year, so support for the motion for a resolution should not be in doubt. It is well known that nitrogen oxide emitted by diesel cars is one of the main contaminants, causing lung cancer, asthma and a number of respiratory diseases, among others. One third of the EU's urban population is exposed to levels of pollution that seriously threaten their health, and transport remains the main cause of poor air quality and associated health consequences in cities. I have two questions: despite the dangers they have known for decades, why do some states support these cars with tax breaks, or why are masses of thoughtful people buying them at the expense of themselves, their loved ones and the health of innocent passers-by? The VW scandal that has just arisen is just the tip of the iceberg.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Following the Volkswagen cheating scandal concerning falsified emissions controls, the European Parliament adopted a resolution on 27 October.  I supported the motion for a resolution, and I have previously given a speech in Parliament criticising the EU's regulatory insursience on this type of abuse. I also drew attention to the hypocrisy of EU climate policy, 'looking through my fingers at car pollution'. In its resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector, Parliament calls, among other things, for the measures I mentioned in my speech: stricter test requirements, real-world emission measurement, comprehensive control of the automotive market. In addition, Parliament calls for an urgent investigation into car fraud, the scrutiny of other car companies and the role of EU and national authorities in fraudulent conduct.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly supported the joint motion for a resolution on measuring emissions in the automotive sector, which expresses the European Parliament's concern about the recent scandal involving the car manufacturer Volkswagen. I think it is a serious matter that consumers have been misled and that European emission control regulations for diesel vehicles have been repeatedly violated. In particular, it is not acceptable that false information has been provided about vehicles, which have put the health of citizens at risk, as well as the environment in which we live.  I firmly believe that citizens must continue to have confidence in the rules and controls laid down in European legislation, and that is why we will have to carry out more stringent investigations into the results of emission tests, including for the future. I also believe that improved supervision of the implementation of EU environmental legislation is essential, and the establishment of a specific body is of fundamental importance.  The Union and its citizens need a harmonised regulatory system and controls at European level, focusing on strengthening and reliability of emissions tests.

name: Merja Kyllönen (GUE/NGL)
text: Written. – Although not all the points supported by our group were included in the resolution that has now been adopted, I wanted to vote in favour of adopting it, because I consider it important to take immediate Union-wide measures to prevent similar cases. We need a united front in this House behind it. Volkswagen's emissions scam has exposed serious problems both within the car industry and the reliability of the supervisory authorities. It is now necessary to introduce tough measures to restore consumer confidence, both to ensure that transport policy decisions are based on a true picture of the environmental burden on motoring.  The emissions scam was uncovered as a volkswagen case on the American market, but over time it has spread to a Europe-wide tangle that takes away the credibility of the car industry as a whole and the authorities monitoring it. In the run-up to the vote, the Financial Times wrote that the EU Commission had already tipped off about systematic emissions cheats in 2013, but completely ignored the issue. Transport&Environment's report also shows that the delusion in the test results is a phenomenon much wider than nitrogen emissions tests. It is now time for the car industry to assume its responsibilities. However, I think it is important that sanctions are not imposed on the workers' ladder.

name: Илхан Кючюк (
text: alde), in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because the European Union is a guarantor of high environmental standards and if decisive action is not taken, the current scandal risks damageing the reputation and competitiveness of the whole sector.  The automotive industry is one of the key drivers of growth and innovation in Europe and the Commission and the Member States need to quickly restore consumer confidence through concrete actions. It is necessary to revise the current regime and propose new measures to ensure that the implementation of EU regulations can be carried out effectively.

name: Jean Lambert (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ It is with some regrets that I voted against this resolution, as it contains many strong points criticising the industry. I did not vote against because I think it is acceptable for car manufacturers to effectively perpetrate fraud not only with regard to those who buy their products thinking they are doing something to reduce harmful emissions, but to society as a whole, which bears the costs of those emissions. I voted against because I think it entirely wrong that the majority of this House chose to endorse the PPE amendment supporting diesel technology. Ironic indeed, when we will vote on air quality standards tomorrow – knowing that diesel fuel has adverse health effects and that we need to move away this fuel. How can I tell the Mayor of London to clean up our air and then support diesel cars as a way forward? We don't solve one pollution problem by fuelling another.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text. Fraudulent behaviour by automobile manufacturers cannot be tolerated and wrong-doers must be held accountable in order not to damage the reputation of the whole European automotive industry. Excess emissions of particulate matter and ozone concentrations causing well over 400 000 premature deaths annually must be kept down. To do so, the Parliament calls for consideration to be given to an independent EU-level surveillance authority that would oversee the testing and urges the Commission to adopt and implement a new Real Driving Emissions test cycle, as well as implementing them to measure not only the NOx emissions, but also use it to measure all pollutants.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. In this resolution on Volkswagen's rigging of carbon emissions tests, I supported the creation of a parliamentary commission of inquiry. Neither this one nor the amendments against false advertising were accepted.  Conversely, an amendment arguing that diesel is a means of achieving our carbon reduction targets has been adopted. These votes can only be explained by the intense lobbying of German manufacturers of large cylinders. A few days later, the Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles revised its testing guidelines by allowing its own pollution thresholds to be exceeded. With this measure, the creation of a European authority to ensure that testing procedures complied with European standards, which I had also supported, became obsolete. There is an urgent need for a complete overhaul of our probate systems and an independent investigation into the deceptions carried out.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Since the Volkswagen case, we have been certain that fraud has been committed in car type-approval tests, as the limits on nitrogen monoxide emissions have been deliberately exceeded for many years by one of the largest and most powerful car manufacturers.  In the aftermath of the scandal, we asked the European Commission to proceed urgently with the necessary investigations and, above all, to keep Parliament constantly informed of the results of the investigations. In this respect, we had a discussion in the ENVI Committee with the European Commissioner, Mr Bieńkowska, and I believe that we need cooperation between all the institutions as soon as possible in order to find a solution as soon as possible. But we should also ask the Member States, which are responsible for the controls, how it is possible that these cars have passed the type-approval tests.  It is our task to ensure that future generations have the cleanest and least polluted environment, and that is why we will work at 360 degrees, in conjunction with the other European institutions and the Member States, to achieve this objective.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution because it is exploiting the Volkswagen scandal to strengthen the Brussels Commission's grip on the car industry.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution tabled by the EPP, S and D, ALDE and The Greens groups follows the scandal of the German company Volkswagen, accused of rigging its engines to distort pollution tests. At a time when international competition and economic war are raging, particularly against the United States, which has skilfully used this scandal to weigh on European car production, this resolution finds nothing better than to constrain the car industry by strengthening EU legislation and the Commission's grip under the cover of good environmentalist sentiments which the United States does not embarrass. It is clear that such a text will resurface on the situation of Volkswagen workers and SMEs.  How, on the other hand, can the Commission be given more power when it is now known that it was aware of the deception?  I have therefore decided to vote against this text which would harm the European car industry and which is the game of American industry.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Intentional criminal behaviour on the part of any company, regardless of its size, will not be tolerated, as it not only causes a loss of public confidence and undermines the quality of European products, but also causes significant damage to the health of Europeans. In order to prevent similar situations, real driving emissions tests should be introduced by 2017 to ensure that new cars meet Euro 6 emission standards, and an independent European institution responsible for conducting emission tests should be established. Above all, we must prevent the negative effects of this scandal on workers – managers' decisions must not result in job cuts.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. In the electric context of the Volkswagen scandal, this motion for a resolution aims to provide a purely environmental response to a strategic industrial problem. Non-impartial pollutant emission standards, decided in the interest of the power that defines them, an ever more worrying commission's grip on an industrial sector vital to Europe, eu-law that is increasingly intrusive in our businesses... All the reasons were put together for me to vote against this incondic and cynical text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it condemns the multinational company Volkswagen for the emissions scandal, demanding guarantees in the measures to be taken to correct the situation caused by it. The Resolution calls for the protecting of jobs in the automotive sector, which under no circumstances can be at risk by the practices of a counterfeit directive. It also draws attention to the role played by the European Commission, which had information on the problem since 2011. Despite not being the best possible resolution, I have decided to vote in favour because it is a touch of attention to the multinational and the authorities involved in the scandal.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The air pollution figures are alarming and the automotive sector has a lot to do with it. In the European Union, up to 430 000 people die prematurely each year from the effects of such pollution. The costs of the health effects of citizens reach up to EUR 940 billion. It is estimated that up to one third of the urban population in the EU is exposed to levels that exceed the limit values and targets set by the EU.  These figures are more than illustrative in order to indicate that something needs to be done about it, more so after the scandal we have seen by the Volkswagen firm, which has violated pollution rules. The report presented therefore seeks to move towards an increasingly sustainable and efficient system in the use of resources for land transport and others.  In addition, it is absolutely necessary to thoroughly investigate the manipulations that have been carried out in several Member States and other countries around the world on the results of emissions tests. That is why I supported this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. Despite several attempts by the ALFA delegation to produce a balanced text, the resolution resulting from the VW scandal contains unfounded accusations of complicity between the Member States and the Commission in the emissions scandal. The request prejudges the results of the ongoing investigations by calling for more EU oversight and new control rights for the Commission with regard to authorisation procedures. Some groups have used the VW scandal to include their own ideological hobby horses, such as .B suspension of the TTIP negotiations, in this motion for a resolution. We need an agreement between the Member States and the European Commission on uniform standards for future audit procedures. However, we are opposed to further centralisation. Member States and their competent authorities must retain the right to reconsider authorisation procedures and, if necessary, to request recalls of products, provided that they can demonstrate evidence of non-compliance with EU emission levels. It is also important to prevent scandals of this dimension effectively and in an factual way. The manipulation by VW has nothing to do with the lack of representation of the current tests. Rather, the discrepancy between test results and real driving conditions should be minimized. That is why I supported these points in the resolution, but nevertheless rejected the text as a whole.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Diesel vehicle exhausts are the main source of nitrogen oxides for which independent analyses carried out last year showed seven times higher concentrations than the limits set under Euro 6. On the other hand, the automotive industry makes a key contribution to growth and innovation and employs a large number of workers. It is essential to continue investigations to prevent manipulation of exhaust emissions test results and to ensure transparency of investigations. It calls on the Commission to carry out new tests under real driving conditions and for national authorities to apply zero tolerance to so-called 'vehicle test optimisation'. The current type-approval system in the EU and road surveillance also needs to be improved in order to achieve alignment with EU law.  I supported the resolution to protect human health and ecosystems from the harmful effects of air pollution, since Croatia also has a second and third category of air quality in certain urban areas, which is moderately and excessively polluted air.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the emissions measurement scandals in the largest automotive companies in the EU have consequences not only for the economy of these firms, but also for the economy, economy and employment in all the Member States concerned. Lying to consumers, endangering life and the environment reduce citizens' confidence and raise doubts about sufficiently clear, controlled and controllable Union rules. I support the adoption of resolutions so that the Commission should draw consequences from this undesirable situation in the form of measures that make it impossible to deceive and abuse consumer confidence, lay down clear rules and harsh penalties for the non-compliance found, so as to prevent similar phenomena from developing.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against it. This motion for a resolution was made in too hasty response to the Volkswagen scandal. As a reminder, Volkswagen's infringement stems from the excess emission of a pollutant, nitrogen dioxide (NOx) by the diesel engines of its models. This resolution addresses an important strategic industrial issue by addressing it as an environmental problem. Under the guise of protecting the environment, it provides for the obligation to choose a product "based on the comprehensive and impartial technical characteristics provided to it", even though the technical characteristics are anything but impartial! These are non-tariff barriers, which the United States knows how to use to eliminate its competitors.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution, which ‘Strongly condemns any fraud by automobile manufacturers and urges companies to take full responsibility for their actions and to cooperate fully with the authorities in any investigations; deplores the fact that millions of consumers have been deceived and misled by false information regarding emissions from their vehicles’.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a joint motion for a resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector. I believe that this phenomenon must be viewed from several points of view. In any case, any fraud with emission limits should be condemned and thoroughly investigated. Furthermore, the protection of consumers, who must retain the right to choose a product of their choice, should be borne in mind, depending on the complex technical characteristics communicated to it. We must also remember that large multinational supranational firms predominate in the automotive industry, so this is not just an EU problem. It should also be taken into account that the automotive industry in some Member States makes an essential contribution to promoting employment and innovation growth. Small and medium-sized enterprises predominate in the automotive supply industry. The economic strength of many regions of Europe is based on the automotive and automotive supply industries. The current scandal threatens to seriously damage the reputation of the entire industry. We must work to remedy this situation, but preferably with a balanced approach that will not harm the automotive sector even more. Since I believe that the text tabled today is not balanced in this respect, and some of the objectives contained therein are not feasible, I abstained in the final vote on the resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, a balanced resolution with some good proposals to make the audit procedure more independent and transparent. Unfortunately, however, this is again being used to give the EU Commission more rights, which is why it is not possible to give its consent.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which calls for the establishment of common European car emission tests which resemble real driving conditions as much as possible, instead of the lab-based test currently in use in the European Union. This will help prevent fraud and restore trust in the automotive industry.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution condemns Volkswagen's emissions cheating. It therefore asks that "the authorities of the Member States require manufacturers to reimburse all subsidies, tax benefits or other tax incentives". The text also stresses that "before considering redundancies, manufacturers must use their own financial resources, including by refraining from distributing dividends, to cover as much as possible the costs resulting from the violation of applicable legislation".   I vote for this text, regretting that it does not ask (as my group's resolution did) for a halt to the ongoing negotiations on the large transatlantic market, which is based on the harmonisation of these different control systems by 'mutual recognition' and which could increase the level of risk for emissions from particular vehicles.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution, hastily drafted by the main Europeanist groups (EPP, S-D, ALDE and Greens/ALE), is the European Parliament's response to the Volkswagen case. Fortunately, the amendment proposed by the Greens and the radical left, calling for the creation of a commission of inquiry, was rejected. Another positive point: with regard to nitrogen oxide emissions, the pollution thresholds not to be exceeded, totally unrealistic, have been raised from 80 mg/km to 168 mg. However, this text contains several elements that run counter to the interests of the European automotive industry, which is already facing increased global competition.  The tone of the proposal is sanctimonious. CO2 emissions are constantly denounced while their role in global warming (largely overestimated warming) is far from scientifically proven.  Finally, the technical characteristics to be respected by the manufacturers are decided in the interest of the power that defines them. It would therefore be normal for standards to remain the responsibility of the Member States rather than the Commission. Thus, this proposal strengthens the Union's powers and exaggerates the environmental effects of diesel engines. So the mp voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the recent scandal in the automotive sector, and considering that the automotive industry is one of the main drivers of growth and innovation, job creator for most Member States, the lack of a clear approach and the introduction of firm measures could undermine the reputation and the consequent competitiveness of this important sector. The fraud perpetrated must be condemned, the responsibilities ascertained, but the European Union must not fail to draw conclusions, based on the implementation of a firm strategy that does not compromise the importance of the sector.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This cross-party resolution calls on the Commission to take the recent news regarding automotive manufacturers into account when formulating new policies in the field of sustainable transport. It also stresses the need to ensure that vehicle emissions tests are accurate and that the European automotive industry remains at the forefront of innovation. I therefore supported this resolution.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the Volkswagen emissions-rigging scandal continues to grow leaving everyone perplexed and asking themselves what went wrong, drawing comparisons between the US and EU test systems and their differences and failings, we need to fully understand that what is at stake here is citizens’ health and what is important is to win back consumer trust and confidence in the standards and type-approval mechanism used in Europe.  Cars in Europe must be as clean and efficient on the road as they are in the laboratory. The Volkswagen scandal has opened our eyes to the massive loopholes and existing abuses in the current system, therefore I voted in favour of Parliament’s resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector, calling on car makers and on the European Commission and Member States to provide answers and take quick action to restore trust and repair consumer detriment and to ensure that consumers do not suffer from misleading commercial statements.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully supported a resolution that denounces an outright breach of EU environmental regulations and the manipulation of millions of consumers. The Volkswagen scandal signals the need for a tighter approach to implementing car emissions regulations in Europe. Such fraudulent behaviour puts at risk global confidence in the product of an industry that provides Europe with countless jobs in times of still-sluggish economic growth. The answer for more competitiveness must lie in more innovation, not in deceiving consumers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Six political groups on the subject: Verts/ALE, PPE, ECR, S&D, GUE/NGL and ALDE submitted motions for resolutions. Among them, Verts/ALE, PPE, S&D and ALDE reached an agreement, and I supported the compromise proposal they tabled.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution tabled by the EPP, S and D, ALDE and The Greens groups follows the scandal of the German company Volkswagen, accused of rigging its engines to distort pollution tests. At a time when international competition and economic war are raging, particularly against the United States, which has skilfully used this scandal to weigh on European car production, this resolution finds nothing better than to constrain the car industry by strengthening EU legislation and the Commission's grip under the cover of good environmentalist sentiments which the United States does not embarrass. It is obvious that such a text will resurface on the situation of Volkswagen workers and SMEs subcontractors.  How, on the other hand, can the Commission be given more power when it is now known that it was aware of the deception?  I have therefore decided to vote against this text which would harm the European car industry and which is the game of American industry.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on measures of polluting gas emissions in the automotive sector. This text, drafted in response to the scandal created by the revelation of a pollution test fraud by the Volkswagen company, is balanced and aims to restore the confidence of motorists in the use of diesel engines. In order to achieve this objective, the resolution calls for the introduction of tests in real driving conditions, already provided for by a regulation adopted in 2007 and extended in 2013 to all pollutants, not just nitrogen oxide. It is also called for consideration of the creation of an EU-level supervisory authority.  As stated in an EPP amendment for which I voted, I consider that diesel technology remains an important means of enabling manufacturers to meet the average CO2 emission targets for the fleet in circulation in the EU in 2021. It is essential to support this engine system that is less polluting than the one running on petrol and which allows many Europeans to gain purchasing power by paying less for their fuel.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following recent events concerning the violation of pollution rules by the Volkswagen Group, in which thousands of vehicles have been discovered to artificially reduce the amount of polluting emissions into the atmosphere, a series of measures have been proposed in the European Parliament to prevent fraudulent situations and to call into question public health and the environment. Emissions of polluting gases above the permitted criteria cause a number of problems. Hence the need to create conditions that provide effective pollutant emission control systems, strengthening surveillance systems, as the transport sector is a major contributor to the levels of pollution in the atmosphere, as well as to the impact that such a contribution has on health. For effective control, European and national authorities should strengthen the monitoring of the automotive sector, investigating possible situations of fraud that may arise.  I am in favour of this motion for a resolution, because this is an extremely important issue, which requires an effective response from the European Union, since social and environmental issues are at stake which need answers and prevention solutions.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the motion for a resolution. Parliament, with its direct democratic mandate, has the imperative to make its voice heard in the face of the violations of environmental and consumer protection standards perpetrated by the Volkswagen Group.  In addition to harming the interests and protection of consumers, the possible failure to do so could have deteriorated the health of citizens. I therefore support the call for the European Commission and the competent national authorities to launch an investigation into the handling of co2 emission measuring devices.  Once the liability and extent of any fraud have been clarified, it will be necessary to restore consumer confidence by giving them fair compensation. The cost of the same must not, however, fall in any way on the workers directly and indirectly involved in Volkswagen's production chain.  The condemnation spelled out in the resolution must, through an innovation of the current legislation, ensure that this does not happen again in the future. I therefore agree with the introduction of compulsory road testing during the type-approval and certification processes of motor vehicles. To this end, I support the establishment of a truly independent and single authority at European level, responsible for verifying and implementing the existing regulations, which will ensure greater homogeneity and unity in this area.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this resolution that will establish a committee of inquiry to investigate the respective responsibility of the Commission and of Member State authorities for the failure to ensure the proper implementation and enforcement of the relevant EU law on emission measurements in the automotive sector.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The automotive industry is one of the main players in the field of growth and innovation and contributes to employment in a significant number of Member States. Unless decisive action is taken, this scandal risks undermining the reputation and competitiveness of the entire EU car sector. We call on the Commission and the Member States to open an immediate investigation into the use of defeat devices (in relation to both the emission limit values and the level of CO2 in g/km released) for a wide range of vehicle brands and models.  The survey should be carried out on the basis of data collected and transmitted by member member approval authorities for vehicles on the market, using real-world driving tests. Member States and the Commission must quickly restore consumer confidence through concrete measures. That is why we call on the Commission to present a legislative proposal for an EU-wide collective action mechanism so that consumers can resort to collective action. We urge companies to take full responsibility for their actions, stressing that employees do not have to pay the price of manipulations at the level of emission measuring devices. As the S&D coordinator for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I voted for the resolution on emission measurement in the automotive sector.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on emissions measurement in the automotive industry, because I count on those who demand that appropriate conclusions be drawn from the ongoing emissions scandal known as dieselgate and clear ways to improve the situation. It is therefore right that we have called on the Commission to adopt and introduce a new test cycle based on real-world emission measurements without delay. In this respect, however, I was not pleasantly surprised by the agreement just announced between the Member States and the Commission on setting relatively soft conditions for newly introduced emission tests for cars (this is a link between the corresponding traffic tests and laboratory tests). I am not sure that this is the right way to restore consumer confidence in diesel engines and the automotive industry in general, and to ensure air quality, which can be achieved in today's state of modern technology.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of this report because I am in favour of a directive setting the national ceilings for air pollutants. Due to the large number of illnesses and even deaths per year caused by air pollution, the environment must be spared. The report also mentions that the total cost of air pollution should be reduced by EUR 40 billion by 2030.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The deception and misleading of millions of consumers by Volkswagen about vehicle emissions is deeply regrettable. It is also regrettable that the EU did not recognise the existence of irregularities and the lack of enforcement of eu internal market legislation. In the current situation, it is extremely important that both the European Commission and the Member States do everything to restore consumer confidence by adopting the necessary measures.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the resolution tabled.  In particular, the Commission should investigate volkswagen's emissions cheating in the field of emissions measurements as soon as possible and extend this investigation to all car manufacturers.  In view of the principle of full transparency, a thorough investigation is needed on the role and responsibilities of the Commission and the member state authorities. It is necessary to identify those who are responsible for the damage caused. Workers must not and may not be those who will bear the cost of manipulation.   Producers who have breached the requirements of the legislation should reimburse any subsidies, tax advantages or other financial incentives obtained on the basis of environmental performance claims.  In order to restore consumer confidence, the Commission should provide the public with access to detailed data from the Joint Research Centre's investigation, including sensitive data. I support the proposal for the establishment of an independent EU type-approval authority.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on Emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanking the rapporteur for the work he has done, which I have seen, I confirm my vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the resolution because I strongly condemn any cheating by car manufacturers, because excess emissions affect poorer human health and cause environmental damage. It is essential that the Commission and the Member States, and especially car manufacturers, swiftly restore consumer confidence through concrete measures. Therefore, the Commission should adopt as soon as possible a new test cycle based on HM emissions, while at the same time apply such a test to other pollutants, allowing the consumer to make decisions based on comprehensive and impartial technical characteristics. It is necessary to strengthen the existing arrangements for the type-approval of vehicles in the EEZ, including by increasing the supervision of authorities in the Member States, and the Commission should also take further steps to strengthen the EEHR strategy for sustainable transport, leading to a real reduction in actual traffic emissions and an improvement in urban mobility.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution tabled by the EPP, S and D, ALDE and The Greens groups follows the scandal of the German company Volkswagen accused of rigging its engines to distort pollution tests. At a time when international competition and economic war are raging, particularly against the United States, which has skilfully used this scandal to weigh on European car production, this resolution finds nothing better than to constrain the car industry by strengthening EU legislation and the Commission's grip under the cover of good environmentalist sentiments which the United States does not embarrass. It is obvious that such a text will resurface on the situation of Volkswagen workers and SMEs subcontractors. How, on the other hand, can the Commission be given more power when it is now known that it was aware of the deception? I have therefore decided to vote against this text which would harm the European car industry and which is the game of American industry.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Without prejudging the final outcome of the research, I think it is our duty to request a transparent investigation of the entire product emission measurement system as well as their energy efficiency regardless of the specific case. In particular, indications should be examined that some representatives of the institutions were aware of the shortcomings of the measurement system, but a timely and timely reaction was absent.  It is regrettable that serious disregard for EU internal market rules has been exposed thanks to the actions of the US authorities. Those responsible for manipulating emission measurements must be held accountable, but it is the workers working for car manufacturers and their suppliers, a large part of whom are SMEs, who will ultimately pay the price for this manipulation, and is particularly concerned about the potential negative impact on the supply chain in the automotive sector.  In addition to transparet informing consumers about the products they buy, we need to make sure that the manipulation scandal does not result in job losses.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Several EU Member States, as well as other countries, have opened investigations into vehicle emissions and manipulation of test results. National oversight of the authorities should continue to carry out large-level checks on various vehicle brands and models, and the Commission should oversee the investigation and insist that the investigation be conducted in full transparency and with public access to data.  Although diesel cars have lower CO2 emissions per kilometre than equivalent petrol vehicles, manufacturers must use the available clean technology to reduce various pollutants. It should be stressed that European automotive suppliers are world-leading in the development of diesel technology, combining fuel efficiency with low CO2 emissions and it is very important that this technology is supported in the future.  Greater EU scrutiny is essential, in particular as regards market surveillance, coordination and monitoring of vehicle regimes sold in the Union. I support this report in view of the fact that the automotive sector contributes significantly to the European economic recovery, and therefore the current incident must be investigated and clarified, found responsible and acted appropriately.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's European Parliament resolution on the dieselgate case, which clearly condemns the false information and fraud on customers committed by Volkswagen. The manipulation of information on the emissions of their cars has a major impact on the environment and citizens' health, and it should be remembered that the limits are not there to put a weight on manufacturers, but to protect the environment for all of us. Of course, the whole case can not do without noticeable economic consequences not only on the mentioned car maker, but perhaps also on the whole sector, suppliers and employees. In particular, I consider the impact on the redundancies to be inadmissible. Therefore, the investigation of the whole case must be properly carried out and punished by the real critics. I would like to stress once again here that this case is not, a priori, about intimidation or punishment, but about the realization that we are cheating ourselves in particular with any cheating. Ahead of the forthcoming climate summit in Paris, where it is preparing to persuade other countries to make further environmental commitments, the EU must send a clear signal that it is able to meet its own commitments not only on paper, but also in reality.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I certainly could not help but approve this joint motion for a resolution tabled following the scandal of nitrogen oxide emissions from certain diesel vehicles. I believe that the European Commission has been considerably behind schedule in reacting to the publication of tests on serious exceedments of the emission limit values. That is why we must strongly demand that more emission controls be carried out and that, by 2017, a test be introduced on emissions generated by driving under real conditions for all vehicles approved or registered from 2015. It is important to adopt and implement, as soon as possible, the new test cycles to measure emissions generated by driving under real conditions by providing for greater control by the Commission, in particular as regards market surveillance, coordination and follow-up system for vehicles sold in the Union.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I, of course, have watched the resolution in relation to the automotive industry very closely as a Czech, because my country is very heavily economically oriented precisely on the production of cars. Personally, I believe that it is necessary to separate the specific current case and the long-term setting of the rules in this field. In Europe, we must also avoid excessive emotions that could turn against European industry and, as a result, damage European jobs. In the end, I supported the resolution because it succeeded in removing from it, when voting on the amendments, those provisions which would be openly directed against the rational interests of European industry.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Following the discovery of the Volkswagen scandal and the German company's fraud, the European Parliament adopted a text condemning any attempt to defraud car manufacturers and infringe the rights of European consumers. In addition, the text calls on the Commission to set up real-world emissions tests to better control the environmental impact of new cars on the market. I have spoken in favour of this text and I believe that the Union must take the appropriate and swift action in the face of this vast organised piracy operation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that it is important that additional measures be taken to strengthen the EU strategy for sustainable and efficient transport systems. I voted in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the EU resolution on emission measurements in the automotive sector. We believe that targets should be set at the national level by democratically accountable governments.  We do not want new EU regulation in this field and we fear that the unelected EU Commission will want to reform EU emissions testing with a new regulatory framework whilst strengthening the implementation and enforcement of existing EU law.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. On 27 October 2015, MEPs adopted a resolution calling on the Commission to take all necessary measures to respond to the Volkswagen scandal and the rigging of pollution tests. I voted in favour of this resolution, which is a step in the right direction, to pave the way for thorough investigations and to revise the procedures for testing so that they can be carried out in real-world conditions.  MEPs are calling for the new tests, which will ensure compliance, to come into force in 2017. However, I regret that Members did not take this opportunity, in the run-up to COP21, to support the transition to alternative fuels, by questioning the preponderance of fossil fuels. Therefore, a specific paragraph should have been included in favour of diesel exit policies, which are at the root of the problem of air pollution causing serious public health problems throughout Europe.  Finally, I regret that the European Parliament has not adopted, by four votes, an amendment to support workers and subcontractors, who must not suffer the consequences of this fraud, which must be borne by the leaders.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. After calling on Elzbieta Bienkowska, European Commissioner for Internal Market, Industry, Entrepreneurship and SMEs, during a debate on measuring emissions in the automotive sector, I spoke in favour of a motion for a resolution to improve the efficiency and reliability of emissions controls.  The proposal calls for an end to laboratory testing, the results of which may be skewed by the use of optimization practices such as tire over-inflating or the use of specific lubricant, and the implementation of tests in real-world traffic conditions. The resolution also calls for the creation of a European-wide supervisory authority to strengthen the control of EU legislation in this area. Finally, in order not to excessively penalise employees, the text proposes to impose on fraudulent manufacturers the priority use of their own funds to pay the damages related to legal proceedings rather than the establishment of mass dismissals.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, which follows the shocking revelations about Volkswagen's fraud. Cheating is unacceptable, especially since it is about the health of citizens, the environmental model we want to build and consumer confidence in a major European industrial sector. That is why we strongly condemn any fraud committed by car manufacturers, encourage investigations by certain Member States and call on national authorities to carry out further checks. A thorough investigation must be conducted. It is regrettable that the proposal for a parliamentary committee of inquiry was rejected. The European vehicle reception system needs to be redesigned. For example, the new emissions test cycle should be introduced as soon as possible to allow tests to assess actual driving conditions. Finally, the creation of a European supervisory authority must be considered. Laws must be respected and consumer confidence restored. The competitiveness of the European automotive sector and the jobs associated with it depend on it.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it strongly condemns the fraud committed by Volkswagen, which installed deactivation devices on at least eleven million diesel vehicles to circumvent EU environmental legislation.   As a socialist, I regret that millions of consumers have been deceived by false information relating to the emissions of their vehicles, emissions causing harm to human health and environmental damage, and I have demanded in this Resolution that workers do not have to pay the price of manipulations, while taking into account that the automotive industry is one of the sectors that contributes the most to growth , innovation and employment.  We call for legislative changes to improve emissions measurement in the automotive sector through the introduction of tests under real driving conditions and to consider the establishment of an EU-wide control authority to detect emissions limits violations, to prevent this situation from recurring.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the opening of a commission of inquiry, supporting Amendment 17 to the joint motion for a resolution on emissions measures in the automotive sector, and regret that this proposal has not been accepted. I believe that it is necessary to shed light on the cheating of the Volkswagen company, which tampered with its diesel-powered vehicles to deceive US emissions inspections, and on any involvement of Any European authorities.  This case not only damages the image of the automotive industry, but it is also a sad symbol of the non-Europe in terms of industry. I call for strict rules to govern practices and for exemplary sanctions to restore trust. Finally, the employment of workers in the sector, who deplore these malicious acts as much as I do, must be protected.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, because I consider that any fraud by car manufacturers should be strongly condemned (this joint motion for a resolution has joined different resolutions from 4 different Parliamentary Groups – PPE, S&D, Greens and ALDE – the ECR and GUE/NGL Parliamentary Groups, which have maintained their initial proposals, are left out of this common understanding in order to mislead consumers in relation to the emissions of their vehicles, especially when we know that excess emissions are a cause of premature death and have harmful effects on human health and the environment (and obviously also in governments and businesses, although for these there are other reasons that add to the above , relating to tax evasion for environmental reasons or even possible fraud). For this reason, I consider it essential that the Commission and the Member States make every effort to restore consumer confidence, and that work on research, control and monitoring of emission limit values, dialogue and collaboration with the automotive industry and strict compliance with European legislation in this area is necessary.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on emissions measurements in the automotive sector because I believe that Parliament has an obligation to give its opinion on such a sensitive issue. At the same time, however, I think it is right to stress the importance of the difference ( little highlighted in the text) between the emission limits that can create pollutants and compliance with the rules that already exist in Europe. The case that led to the decision to write a resolution stems from the failure to comply with European standards that are already attentive to respect for the health of citizens and the environment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution because, according to the research centre under the European Commission, in 2013 the car emission detection tests presented problems because they could enable the use of tricked-out devices that activate or modify emission control systems with the aim of improving their effectiveness during the implementation of the checks. The Volkswagen scandal is the tip of the iceberg of a fraudulent system but it is NOT an isolated case; they have hit the engines of millions of diesel cars around the world, polluting up to 40 times more than allowed, and we consider it vital to change emission control mechanisms to be carried out in real driving circumstances and that this situation is not repeated. Moreover, this Resolution stresses the importance of not employees ultimately paying the consequences of the breaches in which the company has fallen.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The deliberate cheating of tests and sale of vast numbers of vehicles making false claims about their performance has left consumers’ confidence in the car industry badly damaged.  The Commission should look seriously at a robust, centralised test procedure which creates a level playing field for car manufacturers, ensures proper implementation of pollution laws, and restores consumers’ confidence in this industry.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. The EU is committed to ambitious CO2 and emission reductions. However, the 2020 targets can only be achieved with modern diesel technology and further electrification of the vehicles. Without diesel, we will not achieve these targets, because a diesel engine emits on average up to 20% less CO2 than a comparable petrol engine. We must not demonise this technology in general. Diesel technology is mature, low-consumption, and emissions are manageable!  What happened at Volkswagen was fraud by individuals. This must, of course, be properly clarified and punished. But neither the technology in detail nor the automotive industry in general and its workforce in its entirety should be subject to general suspicion.  To close the gap between real consumption and emissions, the EU is working on a new test cycle and an emissions test that better reflects real driving situations.

name: Jordi Sebastià (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. We voted against this Resolution because an amendment has been introduced amending that 'diesel vehicles contribute to reducing air pollution', which is absolutely absurd that scientists — who are the ones who should talk about this, and not politicians — tell us clearly that it is a lie.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the European Parliament's joint motion for a resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector, because it responds adequately to the unacceptable behaviour committed by some car manufacturers. The statement calls primarily on companies to take full responsibility for their actions and cooperate fully with the authorities in all investigations, and condemns the fact that many consumers have been mystified by false information about the emissions produced by their vehicles. I have personally called for clear provisions to be inserted, which will raise considerable concerns about the possible impact of the emissions case on the entire supply chain and ordinary employees, because the resulting text also expresses itself unequivocally on these issues. On the contrary, I did not support several provisions which, from my point of view, are not based on substantiated facts.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it condemns the multinational company Volkswagen for the emissions scandal, demanding guarantees in the measures to be taken to correct the situation caused by it. The Resolution calls for the protecting of jobs in the automotive sector, which under no circumstances can be at risk by the practices of a counterfeit directive.
