It also draws attention to the role played by the European Commission, which had information on the problem since 2011. Despite not being the best possible resolution, I have decided to vote in favour because it is a touch of attention to the multinational and the authorities involved in the scandal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as I do not want new EU regulatory frameworks relating to emission testing. However I believe that if VW is guilty as charged they should face appropriate penalties. I believe that the root cause of this is because of poorly written and over—complicated EU Commission legislation.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The effect on society of poor air quality is tremendous. Almost half a million premature deaths can be attributed to poor air quality, as well as costing the economy up to nearly €1 trillion every year. Measures to address these dangerous pollutants – covering all sectors – are needed urgently and this legislative report seeks to address this need.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Epa and CARB research has established that the VW Group violated pollution rules by faking emissions findings. As many as 11 million diesel vehicles with faulty devices have been sold since 2009, of which as many as 9 million belong to the European market. It is therefore necessary to gather information to assess whether European testing systems have been manipulated in the same way.  By voting, I did not support a resolution on emissions measurement in the automotive sector. Detailed steps should be taken to strengthen the EU strategy for sustainable systems, which make effective use of resources for use in road transport and all other modes of transport. Volkswagen Group vehicles are the best-selling in Croatia, and only the Government of the Republic of Croatia acquired 1500 vehicles during the last year, of which 1423 were Volkswagen groups.  Croatia commissioned the vehicles in question through public procurement and was inevitably damaged by false information when selecting vehicles and the amount of emissions dropped. The state budget suffers immeasurable damage on a daily basis, the scale of which cannot currently be estimated, as the excise duties paid into the budget represent a much lower amount than the actual state of vehicle emissions.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: in writing ‒ the volkswagen diesel emissions violations revealed by the United States Environmental Protection Agency cast a shadow over the control mechanisms of EU countries. The reputation of the automotive industry is threatened by unfair practices that could have been avoided if emission limits were consistently applied to cars. Each customer has the right to choose their product with comprehensive and undistorted technical parameters. However, companies such as Volkswagen are not only threatening the end customer, but also the many small and medium-sized enterprises that depend on vehicle sales.  I therefore believe that, in today's situation, there should be agreement that the current test procedures used in the EU are not sufficient. Any defeat devices or tests which do not replicate normal driving conditions mislead the consumer and make the whole industry less competitive. Practices improving the results of emission tests, such as excessive inflating of tyres, removal of side mirrors or the use of special lubricants, should not be tolerated by the authorities responsible for control. It would therefore be worth considering a proposal calling for the establishment of an independent approval authority, as the testing activities of national authorities are not overseeed by anyone. The testing procedures will have to be changed to reflect actual driving conditions and to be used to measure all types of pollutants.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The recent emissions scandal not only highlights the need for robust rules on competition among car manufacturers but, more importantly, it makes the case for the EU to update its testing procedures. Tests carried out by the EU's Joint Research Centre (JRC) and other independent NGOs clearly point to weaknesses in the current procedures. According to the JRC, real-world nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions of diesel passenger cars exceed two to five times the regulatory standards. Considerable discrepancies exist between type-approval and on-road CO2 emissions as well. This gap is due to the current EU test procedures, which do not use normal driving conditions and allow for undue ‘testing optimisation’ – a form of cheating all manufacturers resort to.   If we do not urgently adopt a real-life emissions test cycle for all major pollutants, not only will we keep denying our citizens their right to be adequately informed, but we will also work against our goals on the protection of public health and the environment.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The importance of fair competition is essential among car manufacturers, since the consumer can therefore make decisions on the basis of those comprehensive and impartial technical characteristics. Manufacturers are required to ensure that vehicles meet emission requirements during normal use under the Euro 5 and Euro 6 Standards Regulation. The regulation also explicitly prohibits the use of defeat devices and calls on the Commission to introduce tests and reception measures for the use of defeat mechanisms.  I agree with the requirement that the Commission introduce tests for all approved or registered vehicles after 2015 in order to ensure the effectiveness of emission control systems. I also consider it important in the report to emphasise the strengthening of the existing EU type-approval system, including through more EU controls (in particular market surveillance, coordination and monitoring of vehicles sold in the Union).  An amendment was tabled to the resolution by the EPP Political Group, which supports the use of diesel engines in cars, while also stating that diesel engines have less exhaust gas than other equivalent vehicles using petrol.  Since the aforementioned amendment was adopted at the meeting and is unacceptable to the Green Group, I voted against that resolution.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on emissions measurements in the automotive sector, in which Parliament takes a clear stand in favour of transparency and the protection of human health. With this resolution, we support the European Commission's call on national authorities to carry out in-depth checks on various types of vehicles in order to detect possible fraud in emissions tests and to penalise those responsible appropriately. In addition, we call on the Commission to adopt and implement as soon as possible a new system of testing emissions generated by driving under real conditions, extending the verification from nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions only to other pollutants. To this end, the resolution proposes the establishment of a Supervisory Authority at European level to conduct the tests in complete independence and transparency. These measures are necessary to remedy a situation that risks endangering not only the entire European automotive sector, but also the EU's air quality protection policy aimed at protecting the health of European citizens.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. Despite several attempts by the ALFA delegation to produce a balanced text, the resolution resulting from the VW scandal contains unfounded accusations of complicity between the Member States and the Commission in the emissions scandal. The request prejudges the results of the ongoing investigations by calling for more EU oversight and new control rights for the Commission with regard to authorisation procedures. Some groups have used the VW scandal to include their own ideological hobby horses, such as .B suspension of the TTIP negotiations, in this motion for a resolution. We need an agreement between the Member States and the European Commission on uniform standards for future audit procedures. However, we are opposed to further centralisation. Member States and their competent authorities must retain the right to reconsider authorisation procedures and, if necessary, to require product recalls if they can demonstrate evidence of non-compliance with EU emission levels. It is also important to prevent scandals of this dimension effectively and in an factual way. The manipulation by VW has nothing to do with the lack of representation of the current tests. Rather, the discrepancy between test results and real driving conditions should be minimized. That is why I supported these points in the resolution, but nevertheless rejected the text as a whole.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The emissions scandal undermines confidence in the entire European automotive industry. In order to avoid similar problems in the future, the tests must be credible and run under conditions of real operation.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution. This report suggested that diesel cars have lower carbon dioxide emissions per kilometre than equivalent petrol powered vehicles. I am technology neutral when it comes to emissions reductions and I believe that this sends the wrong signal in light of current uncertainties surrounding vehicle emission tests.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Days 18 September 2015 Since 2010, the U.S. Federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Protection Board (CARB) have issued a notice of violation of current pollution regulations for Volkswagen AG, Audi AG and the American Volkswagen Group (known collectively as "VW") resulting in an investigation that followed research into nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions from diesel vehicles conducted by an NGO in collaboration with researchers from the university.  The European Parliament strongly condemns all forms of fraud by car manufacturers and calls on companies to take full responsibility for their actions and to cooperate fully with the competent authorities through investigations, and regrets the fact that millions of consumers have been deceived and misled by false information about their vehicle emissions. It therefore calls on the Commission to adopt and implement a new cycle of real-world emissions tests without delay and to ensure its entry into force for regulatory purposes. I support this report because I believe that better emissions regulation is needed, which will better protect both consumer rights and the environment itself.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on measuring emissions in the automotive sector. The European Commission must verify and, if necessary, improve the quality and reliability of processes related to the testing and certification of discharges in the European Union. The Volkswagen scandal is more than the complexity of European standards compared to american exposes the (non)reliability of systems and procedures used to verify that emissions comply with regulations. The car industry in the European Union is very important both in terms of its contribution to reducing gases and combating climate change and in terms of employment. In Slovenia, too, we have companies that, as suppliers of large car groups, employ many people. It is therefore important to restore the trust of customers who are at risk by this scandal.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on emissions in the automotive sector. I believe that in the future, practices such as software manipulation in order to circumvent emission limits should be prevented. I believe that it is necessary to introduce new test procedures. However, the process of introducing new procedures must be based on a realistic timetable for the transition from existing measurement methods to new ones, not only from a legislative point of view, but also with regard to the appropriate equipment of approval and approval institutions. A new test cycle based on real-world emission measurements should be introduced. In particular, these measures are intended to ensure a level playing field for all operators operating on the internal market.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that it is crucial that testing programmes get under way as quickly as possible in order to ascertain what the situation is for VW and the implications for other car types.  I support EU wide action to ensure potential manipulations are investigated throughout the automobile sector and to assess to what extent independence and accountability of the national type approval and testing authorities can be improved. I also believe that coordinating approaches across Member States will improve consistency and enable testing of the widest range of vehicles. It is important that the resolution addresses the introduction of the Real Driving Emission (RDE) testing procedure, which would reflect real-world emissions and allow authorities to detect the use of defeat devices. The RDE procedure must be introduced as soon as possible to allow for new tests which eliminate conformity factors (the multiple by which engines can exceed current emission limits) and ensure that Euro 6 limits are finally met.  However, I voted against this report as it made unsubstantiated allegations against both the Commission and Member States regarding their complicity in the actions of VW and prejudges the outcome of ongoing investigations by calling for increased EU oversight and new Commission controls over the type approval regime.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The new measures in the automotive sector are in the right direction. We agree with the imposition of sanctions and fines on VW. The fraud of this company, with its managers responsible, highlighted the weakness of the control procedures applied by the European authorities. Immediate corrective action must be taken without affecting consumers in any way, and the committee must carry out an urgent investigation into this case. The new proposal on emissions of Euro6 vehicles under real driving conditions should also be finalised immediately. Finally, we agree that the legislative measures to be taken should not place undue burdens on European industry.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I believe that we need to draw conclusions on exhaust emissions tests in the automotive industry. The current system does not measure car emissions in real driving conditions, so I agree with the proposal to strengthen this test protocol. Poor practice can contribute to increasing air pollution levels, and high levels of emissions are estimated to be responsible for around 400 000 premature deaths in the EU each year. The current emissions test works by the manufacturer measuring vehicle emissions data under artificial conditions, a practice that allows for abuse. For the record, the scandal did not show how many companies knowingly distorted the results. In order to resolve the situation, the proposal calls, including representatives of the Socialists and Democrats, for a Real Driving Emissions (RDE) to be put in place from 2017. I believe that loopholes can be avoided. However, in addition to the environmental and health aspects, I think it is important to ensure that workers do not have to be laid off because of a flawed management decision. I believe that the scandal may provide a basis for companies to invest more resources, for example, in the development of electric cars.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution but I believe that it is largely lacking in transparency and accountability of the Commission, which has done nothing while knowing the 'discrepancies' between emissions from certain vehicles during laboratory tests and actual emissions. The polluter pays, but the fraudster must also pay. This is a scam against states that have for years provided incentives, at taxpayers' expense, to buy 'greener' cars. We will fight for exemplary punishments: and not just monetary punishments.  We must denounce those who are covering up the activities of an industrial sector full of loopholes and, in particular, the fraud activities that have been carried out in recent years by VW. The resolution we voted on was born as a strong criticism of what has happened and to underline the need to identify responsibilities. In the course of the negotiation that led to the joint motion for a resolution, however, volkswagen's name disappeared from the text and only the concepts that look to the future survived, without any commitment to identifying responsibility for what happened.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dieselgate, which started in early October, forces us to discuss an issue that has long been on the public agenda but ignored. I voted for the European Parliament's resolution following the debate on the subject of counterfeiting of car tests on emissions by a car manufacturer. Although the problem occurs only in one player in this market, consumer confidence has been severely affected and is spreading to the entire industry.  Technologies, such as diesel, are now under public scrutiny, although the issue is unethical business practices. Parliament is urgently calling for the implementation of a new testing protocol, the so-called WLTP, in 2017. WLTP is a necessary step to ensure that the consumption and emission figures produced are representative of a particular category of motor vehicles. In the same way, compliance checks must be carried out by independent bodies. Where they differ from those of the certification authorities of the Member States, car manufacturers should be determined to amend their declared figures.  But most importantly, we must have a European Certification Authority. In this way we ensure that certification procedures and standards are applied in the same way in all Member States.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for this text. I have also formally asked the European authorities to take sanctions and to push the Member States and the regions to file a complaint against the German company. To bring an action for damages would be justice; indeed, the tax incentives granted by the government to individuals in connection with purchases of environmentally friendly vehicles are based on a volkswagen lie. On the other hand, asking companies to self-control is like asking drivers to fine themselves!

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution which strongly condemns the fraud by Volkswagen, in which the company admitted to having installed defeat devices in at least 11 million of the diesel vehicles it has sold worldwide. The resolution urges the company to take responsibility and fully cooperate with the authorities in the investigations. It expresses disappointment that it was the USA who first found out and that the EU lacks enforcement of its internal market regulation. The resolution calls on the Commission to launch immediately an investigation into the use of defeat devices as regards both the pollutant limit values and advertised CO2 g/km. Furthermore, it urges the Commission to adopt and implement the new Real Driving Emissions test cycle for all pollutants without any further delay and to bring it into force for regulatory purposes within six months. Seeking to restore the confidence of consumers, it calls for the establishment of EU-level surveillance.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the joint motion for a resolution on measuring emissions in the automotive sector, as I believe that air pollution in the EU causes too many negative effects on the health and life of EU citizens per year, and the cost of the effects of pollution on the health of the population reaches more than EUR 900 billion per year.  In addition to many diseases and high costs, pollutants also affect environmental degradation. A third of the EU's urban population is still exposed to pollution, and as many as 20 Member States still do not meet THE EU air quality limit values.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution because, according to the research centre under the European Commission, in 2013 the car emission detection tests presented problems because they could enable the use of tricked-out devices that activate or modify emission control systems with the aim of improving their effectiveness during the implementation of the checks. The Volkswagen scandal is the tip of the iceberg of a fraudulent system but it is NOT an isolated case; they have hit the engines of millions of diesel cars around the world, polluting up to 40 times more than allowed, and we consider it vital to change emission control mechanisms to be carried out in real driving circumstances and that this situation is not repeated. Moreover, this Resolution stresses the importance of not employees ultimately paying the consequences of the breaches incurred by the company.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution follows the Volkswagen scandal. It considers a strategic industrial issue in a context of global trade war from a narrow and highly exaggerated view of the environment. Moreover, this "scandal" serves as a lever to strengthen EU legislation and the Commission's grip on an essential part of European industry.  I therefore object to this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The serious lack of enforcement of EU internal market legislation, which has come to light thanks to action by the US authorities, is regrettable. The S&D Group's motion for a resolution urges the Commission and the Member States to take preventive measures and to immediately launch an investigation into the manipulation devices used for vehicles marketed in the Union, as well as pollution limits and co2 values (g/km) specific to the normal performance of vehicles. I voted in favour of the S&D group's motion.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution because, according to the research centre under the European Commission, in 2013 the car emission detection tests presented problems because they could enable the use of tricked-out devices that activate or modify emission control systems with the aim of improving their effectiveness during the implementation of the checks. The Volkswagen scandal is the tip of the iceberg of a fraudulent system but it is NOT an isolated case; they have hit the engines of millions of diesel cars around the world, polluting up to 40 times more than allowed, and we consider it vital to change emission control mechanisms to be carried out in real driving circumstances and that this situation is not repeated. Moreover, this Resolution stresses the importance of not employees ultimately paying the consequences of the breaches incurred by the company.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that the emissions testing fraud should be investigated thoroughly and those responsible should face appropriate sanctions. I agree that EU emissions testing system should be strengthened to ensure that EU emission limits are respected and that vehicles exceeding these limits are discovered quickly. I strongly condemn any fraud by automobile manufacturers and deplore the fact that millions of consumers have been deceived, and regret the damage to human health and the environment from excessive emissions.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. The future actions and considerations set out in the text of the resolution are certainly to be welcomed. It is necessary, in fact, that any fraud committed by car manufacturers is strongly condemned, especially for the premature deaths that excessive emissions entail. I would also like to express my concern about the consequences for the supply chain, particularly for SMEs, which are facing enormous difficulties as a result of the fraud that has taken place.  However, despite my vote in favour of the resolution, I would like to express my regret at the rejection of our proposals calling for equally important actions, such as the extension to all Member States and to all car manufacturers of the obligation to carry out accurate checks on emissions from the vehicles produced, the return in the event of irregularities of any tax incentives, if any, the need for detailed information , accessible and transparent about the checks carried out and the establishment of a committee of inquiry by the European Parliament as a result of what has happened.  Therefore, despite the goodness of the proposed text, I believe that it was possible to implement a number of points of fundamental importance.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it condemns the multinational company Volkswagen for the emissions scandal, demanding guarantees in the measures to be taken to correct the situation caused by it. The Resolution calls for the protecting of jobs in the automotive sector, which under no circumstances can be at risk by the practices of a counterfeit directive. It also draws attention to the role played by the European Commission, which had information on the problem since 2011. Despite not being the best possible resolution, I have decided to vote in favour because it is a touch of attention to the multinational and the authorities involved in the scandal.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recent scandals over potential false readings of carbon emissions in certain vehicles have highlighted the importance of continued vigilance in this sphere. The threat that carbon emissions oppose to our way of society by inducing large scale climate change is a problem we must face up to very quickly.  Yet this is not the only chemical being poured into our atmosphere that could irreversible change our planet. I was therefore perturbed to see that Member States have recently agreed to allow the further pumping of nitrous oxide from diesel cars at double the Euro 6 levels agreed in 2007. Therefore I backed this motion and hope that the Commission and the Member States can work with us in the Parliament to get real on automotive emissions of all kinds instead of making a Faustian pact that could compromise all of our futures.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On September 18, 2015, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Atmospheric Resources Council (CARB) issued a notice of violation of pollution standards applicable to Volkswagen AG, Audi AG and Volkswagen Group of America.  Unfortunately, the Commission was alerted in 2013, through a report by the Joint Research Centre, to the potential existence of illegal software in diesel vehicles of the Volkswagen Group. Nevertheless, it did not warn the competent national authorities of the Member States of the impact of defeat devices on the reliability of measuring emissions from diesel cars. In other words, we are once again faced with the usual dominance of economic power over political power. We are once again faced with a European Commission manipulated by the interests of large multinational companies, which are effectively in the European Union.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, a balanced resolution with some good proposals to make the audit procedure more independent and transparent. Unfortunately, however, this is again being used to give the EU Commission more rights, which is why it is not possible to give its consent.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the measurement of emissions in the automotive sector because it is unacceptable for the European consumer to be misled about the true value of polluting vehicle emissions. Emissions which, among other things, have harmful effects on health and the environment.  The Commission must intervene with due investigation and must commit itself to a European authority to monitor the implementation of existing legislation. Finally, we must be sure that the effects of the wrong decisions of top managers do not fall on the workers.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. – Fraud is fraud and must be punished. It started with Volkswagen. Silence and politically correct disinterest still envelop the other car manufacturers. However, it is only a matter of time and a courageous whistleblower until irregularities are detected in other manufacturers as well. What then? Why is Europe's largest car manufacturer (a German company) now being dismantled in this way due to random testing in the US? Is it about fraud or about the massive damage to German industry? Motorists of any brand know that the manufacturer's fuel consumption and the reality of life on the road hardly match. The European Parliament, of course, does not miss the opportunity and hastens to comment on the event. It immediately calls for the introduction of a new supervisory authority at EU level, the state (not its owners) accountable "glass companies", new responsibilities for the EU and a tightening of the EU emission limits, which are obviously unsustainable. The EU Commissioner for Industry, Elzbieta Bienkowska, who has never been of colour and ideas, joins the chorus today, weathering her chances and calling for the EU Commission to monitor all national vehicle registration authorities. I reject that. The "European internal market" is not an argument for the national decision-making structures to be held accountable, especially the state government of Lower Saxony and the Federal Ministry of Transport. These bodies should first clean up their responsibilities before the EU Parliament expresses its opinion.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Following reports published on 18 September by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Air Resources Council (CARB) about the emission-interfering devices that Volkswagen had installed in its cars, the European Parliament decided to take a position on the matter by issuing a resolution. It calls on the European Commission to ensure a full assessment of the manipulations that may have occurred in the automotive sector and to assess the possibility of strengthening the participation of national authorities in the approval procedure. It is also proposed to introduce urgent real driving emissions (RDE) procedures in 2017. I believe that the disclosure of data on the falsification of measurements is evidence of disgrace not only of the VW group, but also of the European Union as a whole. However, I do not agree with the resolution's argument that a dedicated supervisory authority would have to be set up at EU level to ensure that existing rules are enforceable. This contradicts calls for unnecessary administrative burdens to be avoided and, above all, the principle of subsidiarity. For this reason, I could not vote in favour of the submitted act.

name: Flavio Zanonato (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have personally committed myself to parliament adopting a resolution on emissions measurements in the automotive sector. The credibility of our institutions and industries at international level is at stake today; It is more appropriate than ever to call for fraud in emissions testing to be thoroughly verified and to reiterate that those responsible must be penalised appropriately. I think the resolution is timely and measured, particularly where it calls for the EU's emissions testing system to be strengthened. In conclusion, I would like to point out that although those responsible for fraudulent behaviour must undoubtedly be penalised, this must in no way harm the workers in the industries involved, who absolutely must not have to pay for mistakes made at managerial level.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. On September 18, 2015, the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the California Atmospheric Resources Council (CARB) issued a notice of violation of pollution standards applicable to Volkswagen AG, Audi AG and Volkswagen Group of America.  Regrettably, the European Commission was alerted in 2013, through a report by the Joint Research Centre, to the potential existence of illegal software in diesel vehicles. We are once again faced with a European Commission manipulated by the interests of large multinational companies, which are effectively in the European Union. We abstained from this report, right away because this criticism is not implicit.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because it represents a small step in the direction of transparency in order to establish who is responsible for non-compliance with environmental and consumer protection standards, and to punish offenders.  The text, albeit with limitations, calls for an impartial European authority to be set up in the field of motor vehicle testing, for an investigation into the case and for the faults of those who have been silent, for the return of the European funds used to be reclaimed and for the appropriate sanctions to be applied. In my opinion, more can be done to improve the European governance of the automotive sector and to open infringement proceedings against manufacturers who have falsified their tests. Fraud must not be minimised and reduced to a mere question of falsified testing, but the power of the car industry must be limited in terms of self-regulation and self-certification, which is not subject to independent controls. We must also call the European Commission to account for its inaction in the light of internal reports prepared by research centres showing that improprieties have been known for at least four years.

name: elnök asszony. –
text: This concludes the explanations of reasons for the vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission Work Programme for 2016 (2015/2853(RSP)). I would point out that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that the blue card procedure does not apply either.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the motto of our Work Programme this year is ‘no time for business as usual’ and anybody in this room or around Europe who has followed this morning’s debate will agree with me that this is no time for business as usual. That is why the Commission today commits to making bold, focused and pragmatic proposals to allow us to overcome our common challenges and emerge stronger in the spirit of European solidarity and responsibility. President Juncker’s ten priorities, which are both our mission statement and the basis on which we were appointed to office by you, remain the right ones. Last year we said we would do different things and do things differently. We are concentrating on the big things. We have set out our vision and the concrete measures necessary in various areas: investment plan, digital single market, energy union, European Agenda on Security, European Agenda on Migration, capital markets union, action plan for fair and efficient corporate taxation, new trade strategy, deepened and strengthened economic and monetary union. Tomorrow we will present the single market strategy.  Still this year, we will complete the picture with our plans for a sustainable circular economy, labour mobility and better management of our external borders.  The Work Programme the Commission adopted today and its 23 key initiatives is focused on implementing these strategies. It represents a substantive legislative agenda. There will be a lot of work on the table for this Parliament. Members have all received a copy of the Work Programme hot-off-the-press so I assume not all of them will have read it. That is why I would like to point to five important issues which I would like to stress in particular. First, we will continue to prioritise the refugee and migration challenge. The European Agenda on Migration provides a comprehensive response. Immediate actions have been taken and I am very grateful to this House and its President for the speed with which you have acted and for the leadership you have consistently shown. We now propose new measures to improve migration management both to overhaul the Dublin system for asylum and to set out a new approach to legal migration. This will complement the strengthened border management proposals we will table by the end of the year, including a European border and coastguard. Secondly, we have to keep our sights firmly on creating jobs, growth and investment. The Investment Fund is now operational, thanks again to the commitments of this House and the speed with which it has worked, and is delivering high quality investments to further boost the European economy, including in research. We now will focus on improving the investment environment and deepening the single market so that it delivers better outcomes, fewer barriers and the right environment for innovation, especially among SMEs and start—ups. We will present a range of concrete proposals to implement the digital single market strategy. We will also present sectoral strategies on space and defence. Thirdly, the EU being a lead player in the Paris climate talks, we will follow up with three important packages under the energy union. We will deliver a circular economy package to maximise resource efficiency throughout the whole value chain. We will set out a new approach to ensure Europe’s economic, social and environmental sustainability, taking into account the Europe 2020 review and the United Nation’s sustainable development goals. Fourthly, we want to make 2016 a year of real social progress. We will present a new skills agenda aimed at helping people get quality jobs, in particular in the digital era. We will set out legislative and non-legislative action to give a new start to work/life balance for parents, including to support women in the workplace. The labour mobility proposals we will present still this year will help people use the opportunities of free movement whilst addressing abuses in the benefits system and social dumping. Free movement should not be a threat to social protection.  The 2016 European Semester will put a stronger focus on the economic and fiscal situation in the euro area as a whole and on Member States’ employment and social performance. This will be complemented by the development of a European pillar of social rights which will modernise and address the gaps in existing social protection legislation and identify social benchmarks built on national best practices with a view to upwards convergence, in particular of course in the euro area. Fifthly, the Commission will also press for further progress towards fair, efficient and growth–friendly corporate taxation, based on the principle that companies should pay taxes in the country where profits are generated. We will present a set of measures to enhance transparency of the corporate tax system and fight tax avoidance. We will also present an action plan for a more efficient and fraud–proof VAT regime. I wanted to stress these five points to you today as I cannot list everything here. The Commission will, of course, also continue to implement the European security agenda to tackle terrorism and organised crime and follow up on the trade and investment strategy as well as the Five Presidents’ report for a more resilient and prosperous economic and monetary union.  Given all these challenges, it is essential to make the best use of all our resources. The EU budget must be geared to results and the mid–term review of the multiannual financial framework will look at how to make sure that we target our funding better on priorities such as the refugee crisis while also putting a stronger focus on achieving results. The challenges such as migration, access to energy and other resources, and climate change also show the need for an effective external dimension to deliver on major internal policy objectives. Today more than ever before you can no longer distinguish between internal and external – I just want to point to the sustainable development goals, they can no longer distinguish between the two elements. The Commission will make a substantive contribution to the new global strategy on foreign and security policy – also, here, internal and external go hand in hand. Two final points. One: this Commission also said we would do things differently. All the actions we propose are underpinned by our new better regulation agenda. We remain committed to making sure that when the EU intervenes it does so in a way that will deliver results and make a positive difference on the ground. Our Work Programme includes our plans to review key areas of existing legislation such as health and safety at the workplace, to ensure that they are fit for purpose and continue to deliver on our ambitious policy objectives.  We also propose a number of withdrawals of initiatives which have become obsolete or watered down and have no chance to be adopted. The list is considerably shorter than last year which was a moment of political discontinuity. In line with our commitment under the Framework Agreement we will only enact the withdrawals once we have heard your views. My second concluding point is that the Work Programme cannot deliver results without sufficient ownership of the co–legislators. Again, here, it takes, strangely enough, three to tango. The Commission’s Work Programme reflects the Commission’s right of initiative and we take full responsibility for the choices we make. But for the EU to be strong it needs to be able to demonstrate that all our institutions are ready to set Europe’s agenda together and can work together swiftly and in agreement to reach our goals. In preparing our Work Programme we have taken account of the views you have expressed, including in your resolution and I think there is a very broad degree of convergence. I think everyone will agree that our joint working methods for this years’ dialogue were much improved, for instance with the new cluster format in the College–Conference of Committee Chairs (CCC) discussions, and I am grateful for all the input we have received from the committees and their Chairs, as well as the Groups and the Group leaders. I want to thank all the Group leaders for their leadership in this. I want to thank President Schulz for having taken this so seriously and helped us to organise the work better. I also want to thank President Buzek for taking the responsibility for doing the same with the CCC. I hope this will help us reach a common understanding of the pending and future proposals on which we hope the co–legislators will commit to proceed quickly. I am looking forward to working closely with you in 2016 as well and I am glad that we were able to improve our working methods to the satisfaction, I hope, of both our institutions.

name: József Szájer
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, after a very long two months’ negotiations in September we have agreed among several parties in this Chamber, and it was a very wide foundation for the Commission Work Programme, which we have been communicating to the Commission. Maybe it is because of the agreement that there is not much excitement in the House or in the press outside about this; if it were voted down or there were no agreement, there would be much more excitement. But it is very important that Parliament and the Commission work together on this because this Parliament, or most of this Parliament, was elected so that the message of how the European Institutions work should be changed considerably; they should be more effective.  I can shortlist why the EPP or in what areas the European People’s Party can support the Commission’s line, especially in methodology. We welcome the concentration on the 10 priorities of the Juncker plan. Also in the methodology, the key issues should be in line with subsidiarity and proportionality. We have seen very long Commission work programmes in the past not fulfilled, so implementation and checking red tape impact assessment and all the legislation throughout the process is an important issue which we should do all the time. Still on a methodology line, we asked the Commission to align the legislation to the delegated and implementing act provisions, which is my personal issue, although it is much more important than my single person. This is something which we are still in debt after long years after the Lisbon Treaty. The Commission should focus on the implementation of the existing legislation and a simplification in the area when we are speaking about the common agricultural or cohesion policy.  There are two priorities in this area which the EPP found very important: firstly, the mobility and the flexibility of the labour market has to be improved and youth employment skills have to be developed to keep our savoir faire and to develop innovation. Also, the completion of the internal market is a key priority on the energy field and on the digital area. The competitiveness of the EU industry, especially in the area of small and medium-sized enterprises, remains a top priority to creating and saving jobs in Europe.  However, everyone is overwhelmed with the urgency of the refugee crisis. The EPP believes in a European approach to secure the European external borders and to help those who are in danger, but we must ensure the security of our citizens as our first priority. In this area there is much legislation and Parliament has already demonstrated its readiness to cooperate and act swiftly in this area. I welcome the Commission’s proposal for the Work Programme 2016.

name: Maria João Rodrigues
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we agree with the First Vice-President that this is not the time for business as usual. In our opinion, the ten priorities remain valid but they need to be articulated in a completely different way. We can see that our most important challenge now is to address the refugee crisis and to prevent a humanitarian crisis on this front in such a way that we are also able to protect the Schengen Area. We know that this requires a real asylum system in Europe, a real European border and a real immigration policy.  So we will support the Commission in building up these new instruments. But at the same time we need to turn Europe into a real space for prosperity. We believe that this year should be the time for this Commission to deliver a real update of the Europe 2020 Strategy. This is not only about energy transition, but about a circular economy to better manage our resources. This is not only about research and development, but about providing new digital solutions and innovation, again to create quality jobs. We need to make the best of our investment plan, and of the revision of the budgetary instrument, to deliver much better on this strategy. But at the same time we are concerned with something which is happening now in Europe, namely a race to the bottom. There is a risk of a race to the bottom and of Member States competing with each other by downgrading their social standards. That is why we believe that this is the time for a strong pillar of social rights, this is the time for a mobility package to come, but this is also the time to tackle tax evasion in such a way that taxes are paid where profits are made. We really consider these a top priority and we think that the ambition to complete economic and monetary union should be driven by a central goal. The central goal is upward convergence. We consider that, if we want to deliver this upward convergence, we also need to complete the banking union and to build up a real fiscal capacity in the euro area. But then we say that none of these ambitions are effective if we are not supported by a more ambitious external action. Yes, Mr First Vice-President, we agree with you. We need to have an updated global strategy and the first test for this would be for Europe to lead the next Paris conference, for Europe to lead in the implementation of the sustainable development goals, and let me also address the importance of bringing about a real partnership with Africa as our neighbour continent.  So these are our expectations for the year to come. This Parliament was very active in delivering a resolution and you can count on us to be very active in pushing in the right direction.

name: Vicky Ford
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, we need to focus on the economy, boosting competitiveness, innovation and trade, both across the single market and beyond, in traditional sectors and in the digital age. There is much in the work programme that I can agree with. I have said that every EU initiative should face that simple test: will it make it easier or harder for businesses to thrive? The Commission has cut back on new legislation; you are making sure that existing laws work, and you have promised to remove more bureaucracy. You have taken 70 proposals off the table. Commissioner, thank you for listening to the ECR.  However, Parliament’s resolution on the Work Programme called for a deeper political union, including European standards on welfare, health care and education. I disagree – these are matters that are better left to our national governments, and I know that many colleagues across this Parliament felt the same. The Single Market is meant to help economic opportunity that delivers growth and jobs. You have said that this is no time for ‘business as usual’. Let us not be hoodwinked by the Left into proposals that could leave Europe no place for business as usual.

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, It is not ‘business as usual’, because the Vice-President of the Commission has achieved one thing that is pretty revolutionary, and that is keeping the Work Programme confidential until today. That is a real achievement for which I congratulate him. So I have not really had time to read it in great detail, but going through it I note a lot of very positive things for which the Vice-President will get the support of my group. These are the border and coastguard proposal and the proposal to revitalise the ‘blue card’ in the chapter on migration and asylum. I also note the proposal on the work-life balance. I suppose that is new eurospeak for maternity leave, which will at least be in there. I also note a proposal for the external representation of the euro, the common currency. We all welcome that, and I am sure there is a lot more in there that the Vice-President will get our support for. There are also a couple of things missing, and a couple of question marks. Regarding the security and counter—terrorism chapter, one of the things that we have urgently needed for many years – and which has been requested by this House – is a thorough, detailed evaluation of security and counter—terrorism measures already in place and their effectiveness. That is part of better law-making. Another thing we need – I do not know if it is in there – is a reference to somehow unblocking the horizontal anti-discrimination directive and the transparency regulation. I will come back to that. Then there is something that this House has been calling for – and I will have the honour and pleasure to elaborate on this – a mechanism for the enforcement of fundamental rights, the rule of law and democratic governance. Finally, on the digital agenda, I very much welcome the Vice-President’s words but wonder how I should then interpret the words of Mr Oettinger, who said that instead of creating an open worldwide web we are going to put a fence around the European cloud and the European internet. I hope the Vice-President does not share his views. One final remark, because we are talking a lot about political topics here: better law—making is not about the outcome of political debates, it is about the process itself. There the Commission could and should do a lot more. I have already mentioned transparency. We need to make some leaps forward because we are still in the era of diplomats and civil servants meeting behind closed doors. We also need to look at enforcement. I only need to mention ‘safe harbour’ and ‘dieselgate’. We also need to look at the quality of legislation and look at ourselves in a more critical manner, because I am sick and tired of passing legislation that we know is legally unsound and will end up before the European Court of Justice sooner or later. There is a whole lot more that can be said about the process, but I would like to see more emphasis on the process, because the final outcome is a matter of political choice, political preference. There are no objective criteria, but how we manage the process is something that we all share in.

name: Martina Michels
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the This morning, President Juncker has spoken touchingly and clearly in Parliament about the misguided refugee policy. "Well roared," we mean. But what are the courageous consequences? The adherence to a small-minded competitive ideology, a questionable privatisation of investments as with Mr Juncker's investment programme? No, social inequalities are often a breeding ground for the rejection of European solutions, in the worst case for racism. Good projects for employment and regional policy, for social and cultural integration or for consumer and data protection remain in your programme in the end only repair programmes. Because without the removal of the fundamental web errors of the European Union, the best ideas are of no use, the European values of freedom, equality and solidarity remain only fine words in preambles and in Sunday speeches. You would have had the opportunity, Commissioners, but unfortunately you did not take advantage of it.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I have observed the Commission, and in particular on the challenge of the influx of refugees in Europe, in 2014 and above all 2015, to act swiftly, with a sense of urgency and with ambition. So of course, some will say that it's never enough, but it doesn't stop you being quick to react and, in any case, did not hesitate to break down doors that were closed. I would really like to see you do the same on the issues that Europeans are concerned about. Because I have heard your catalogue of future proposals, the density of which, it seems to me, is matched only by the density of the presence of Members in this room. I would like to start with the issue of social dumping. You did the 2014 campaign. You have felt, like everyone here, how crucial this subject is to Europeans. The Commission was set up at the end of 2014 - well, let's say in the autumn of 2014 - so it is a year later. So far, nothing. In fact, it is not true that there is nothing. Because in the meantime, country-by-country recommendations, under the European Semester, continue to move towards more flexibilisation of the labour market and more weakening of collective bargaining, in other words, to exacerbate social dumping between Member States. So not only do you not stop it, but we are still waiting for the first proposal to turn back. Tax competition: A year ago, we had LuxLeaks. Since then, a small measure: the automatic exchange of information on tax decisions, a measure weakened by the Council, which is conspicuous by its absence here, and therefore everything else is to come. So we have to take your word for it, yes, maana! Tomorrow will come the solution. But in the meantime, I don't feel a sense of urgency or ambition. I would add that on social, fiscal and environmental dumping, what you want to do with TTIP and what you want to do with the better regulation program is more in the opposite direction of what should be done.  On the eurozone: as you know, there is a deadlock in the Council. But what are you waiting for to put on the table the proposals that disturb and put states and this Parliament before their responsibilities? Whether it is the deposit guarantee fund, the automatic stabilisers, the euro area budget and the other, you have the right of initiative. But grab it!  Finally, I would like to finish on the Volkswagen case. I was really looking forward to that. This is a scandal in public health, in terms of the environment, in terms of compliance with the law, in terms of market distortion, in short, nothing but matters for which the Commission is competent, and what Commissioner Bie-kowska tells us? "Oh, listen, let the Member States do their job, we are watching, but don't count on us to take an initiative." Do you actually know what's going on? The automotive industry is a taboo, and we know that it is in Germany that it is the most powerfully established, and therefore it is not touched. Please, sense of urgency and ambition! Prove to us in a year's time that you have really taken the measure of the challenges.

name: David Borrelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today the European Commission meeting here in Strasbourg wanted to give a strong signal on the adoption of the 2016 work programme, saying that it is no longer time for conventional management. I would therefore like to highlight some cross-cutting and strategic issues that will certainly require 'unconventional measures'. Whatever the practical configuration of the 2016 Work Programme, it is nevertheless important to build on some of the lessons that the European Union had in 2015. First of all, the Greek lesson: we must prevent the dynamics that have led a nation of the European Union to experience widespread and penetrating poverty today; We expect strong legislative implementations in this area. The Libyan-Syrian lesson: the inability to act strategically has put us in front of dangerous and urgent situations; we need an effective capacity for initiative in generating crisis moderation actions. The Volkswagen lesson: the large groups need to be better monitored and the controllers, who have failed in this case, must also be monitored. What would have happened if the scam had involved food or pharmaceutical products? We expect a proper legislative initiative. A special reflection deserves three economic issues that will accompany us throughout 2016: TTIP, the MES in favor of China and the use of EFSI. We call for an 'unconventional' impact assessment on macro-economic policies and larger trade agreements. All too often Brussels has shown short-sightedness for wanting to centralise impact analyses in its hands. The same mistake is being made in the case of the ES MES China. We call on the Member States, each for its own competences, to produce assessments of the expected impact on their economies. The Commission will have the task of sum-up and providing the other European institutions with a map of the countries on which the sun will shine and of those on which the clouds will be thickened. And we want the principle to pass that if even one country – only one – were to end up in the storm, this would not be good for europe as a whole. Finally, I would like to mention a fact that expresses the current state of Europe. The latest Eurostat figures show that one in four European citizens is in poverty. We believe that measures such as citizenship income and microcredit are not only the pro-economic development drive, but are now a fundamental instrument for signaling a Europe that regains its identity and its most authentic values of solidarity. And on this we ask that the Commission focus its efforts in 2016. Finally, the better regulation model must take on the challenge of being able to involve the local level, and not just the professionals. It faces the challenge of interpreting geographical differences in terms of the economic impact of legislative policies, and this can only be achieved by decentralise the public consultation process and by aggregating data by macro-regions.

name: Matteo Salvini
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the desert of this House tells us how the Commission of the European Soviet Union lives on another planet.  Immigration is a disaster. This morning, Mr Juncker told us that, after months of chatter and triumphs, the good result is that only nine countries have given their willingness to take in 700 immigrants – a few hundred thousand are missing. And some people think they're letting Turkey into Europe. No: Turkey has never been, is not, nor will it ever be Europe, and no one allows itself to use immigration as a commodity of exchange and blackmail to sell off the rights of European citizens. You can't hear anything about the winds of war that are there. What do this Commission and this Parliament intend to do to exterminate ISIS, which is driving hundreds of thousands of people away? Are we going to go ahead with the crazy economic sanctions against Russia, which this year alone have caused EUR 2 billion in damage to Italy? Are human rights in Ukraine worth more than the Syrian human rights trampled underfoot by ISIS, funded by those who facilitate this clandestine invasion? In my opinion, it is shameful that this Europe, which has asked Italy and all the other countries to make sacrifices for pensions and work, should only regain flexibility when immigrants are involved. Nothing about China market economy, which someone in this building would like to bring to export its machinery and which would produce hundreds of thousands more unemployed. Nothing about the protection of 'made in' and the compulsory labelling of products, which would protect consumers and producers and which, for Italy alone, would avoid EUR 60 billion in damage.  Let's take more protections off our people. This year 80 000 tonnes of rice arrive from Vietnam without controls, 35 000 tonnes of olive oil from Tunisia without controls, there are more unemployed people in Europe and more people landing in Europe: there is something wrong.  Fortunately, when people vote, they choose: they chose in Vienna, they chose in Poland, next year they will choose in the referendum in Britain. I hope he can also choose in Italy, and then it will be clear that this Europe is a cage from which the sooner we get out, the better it will be for everyone.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I would like to ask Frans Timmermans, Vice-President of the European Commission, who is here. Do you agree with me that what is going on here is a discussion of the Commission's work programme for 2016 between 20 of Parliament's 750-something members present and the Commission, which is about the same at European Union level as the debate on the government programme in nation states. I suppose that's an acceptable claim. I ask what explanation you can give that our beloved leader, Mr Juncker, and the Commission, led by you, have delivered his programme, his quasi-programme of government, which, of course, defines many aspects of the lives of 500 million European Union citizens to a large extent, well, this programme was delivered to elected Representatives a quarter of an hour before the debate began. At 14.45 we received your government programme by e-mail, the debate started at 3:00. I ask you to explain to the 500 million European citizens what they think. Don't you think that's humiliating? I also ask Mr Martin Schulz to make a statement on the same issue as President of the European Parliament. In principle, I wanted to talk about migration policy, which is one chapter of this scrappy programme. I think that they have now had some time to describe what the Member States will be obliged to do in the context of the migration that has started and is a brand new phenomenon. Most of us Hungarians believe that this is the right of the Hungarian people to decide what we will and will not do in the context of migration – given that we have not reseded from our sovereignty in this area. This is a brand new phenomenon, the European Union can only regulate in areas that have been explicitly renounced by nation states in the Treaties or in the EU. Migration is not included, this is the level of migration, i.e. migration. Thank you very much, I look forward to your reply.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, the best news today is that Ms Morvai called President Juncker her beloved leader. This is something I will cherish and take back to the Commission. Secondly, perhaps I should explain very briefly, this is just a presentation of the Commission Work Programme; nothing more nothing less. We will have ample opportunity in time to discuss all the elements of the Commission Work Programme. I count on Parliament not to make statements about something else or to make big grandstanding gestures on certain political issues, but to take us to the task of looking precisely at the precise proposals the Commission makes, and come to common conclusions on that.  This is extremely important, and sometimes this Commission takes this Parliament more seriously than some of the Members of this Parliament on the extremes of these benches do. This Commission will engage fully with Parliament to make sure that what we do is in line with both your priorities and ours and that we take common decisions that are highly needed. I was just reading a report from the Bertelsmann Foundation, let me quote it directly: ʻtoday in Europe 26 million children and young people are threatened by poverty and social exclusionʼ. This is what should be driving our work. This is what we should be doing, in concrete measures. Do you know how much unemployment there is among young people in so many of our Member States? That is why we want structural reform, that is why we have the EFSI, that is why we want to create opportunities in the digital single market and in the internal market. That is why we need to make sure that people no longer see freedom of movement as a threat to their social position but as an opportunity to perform better and to create careers. That is why we need to put proposals on the table that will lead to better social protection for European citizens, as long as the European Union is competent in these areas. Yes, there are always elements where we could do better, that is why we are here to listen to you, so that we can do better. But in the process, let me end on this. We are now talking intensively with your institution, the European Parliament, represented by Guy Verhofstadt, and the Council to make sure that we do better in the way we legislate together. I hope we can come to a conclusion between the three institutions that shows clearly that we have understood the message from our constituents and our citizens. The message is that we need to do better in the way we prepare legislation so as to avoid making mistakes, and to avoid what Ms in 't Veld was pointing to: that we sometimes adopt decisions knowing full well that they are good because they represent a compromise, but are not good because once you apply them in the Member States businesses suffer and citizens suffer and the Court will have to correct them. Let us try and prevent this from happening by having full and detailed impact assessments before we take a decision, so that we can avoid creating more and more red tape for our businesses and that we can start cutting red tape, instead of the other way around.  This is where this Commission stands, and action is highly needed. I think this is one of the few moments in our common history that the project itself is being challenged in an existential way. Everything has come together like a perfect storm: the economic crisis, the financial crisis, the refugee crisis, international threats, the climate crisis, the environmental crisis and the sustainability crisis. Everything has come together and threatens the very livelihood of Europeans. The European project should be an answer to that. This modest Commission Work Programme is part of a bigger answer we need to give to this challenge. But without this Commission Work Programme, the way we do business between the three institutions would not be as efficient. Let me reiterate that this Commission stands ready to work closely with the European Parliament to make sure that we deliver results for European citizens.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome the adoption of the Commission's work programme and await concrete proposals for the implementation of the Digital Single Market strategy so that it becomes fully operational. On the energy sector, I stress that the Energy Union must have as its central element an efficient and functioning internal energy market, ensuring growth, jobs, affordable and competitive prices for individual consumers and industrial consumers, as well as protecting vulnerable consumers. The European Commission and the Council will establish the governance framework after 2020 and must ensure that all legislative proposals forming part of the Energy Union follow the ordinary legislative procedure, thus fully involving the European Parliament. The Commission should submit an annual report on the implementation of the Energy Union, including details on the implementation of energy legislation. I regret that, so far, the Commission has not come up with any proposal for a harmonised compensation scheme for indirect carbon emissions, which is now left to the Member States. It would also be important to have a European action plan on energy poverty.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. "The Commission's new work programme supports innovations that improve well-being. I particularly welcome the Commission's guidelines for the development of the digital single market and the circular economy. The development of digital services creates new business opportunities and, as a way, new jobs. According to the Commission's calculation, the digital single market can bring an additional growth of up to EUR 250 billion. Faster and more comprehensive information networks, together with new innovations, will also significantly improve our well-being and quality of life. For example, e-health-related applications allow you to monitor your health at home without having to travel all the way to the health centre. In this way, the systems will enable better health monitoring. The main new initiatives presented in the Commission's work programme also include a circular economy package aimed at more efficient use of natural resources and reducing the amount of waste thus generated.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission presented its work programme for 2016 at its October plenary session, in which it tells citizens that it is time for a different approach. The 10 priorities to which the Commission has already committed itself in its political orientations and their implementation are at the forefront. In 2016, the Commission will focus in particular on measures to manage the refugee crisis, create jobs, strengthen growth and the single market, ensure tax fairness and promote economic, social and environmental sustainability. I, too, believe that the Commission must decisively end the current STAGRATION of the EU. Unfortunately, the policies that have been in place to date are based on the priorities of pre-crisis Europe and maintain the rigid economic policies that actually led to this crisis. In its future action, the Commission should, in particular, make a stronger ero to the relevant interinstitutional consultation and, within the framework of the regulatory fitness and performance programme, to draw up a list of legislation which should be revised. However, I would like to draw attention to the need not to use the programme as an excuse to lower ambition, to deregulate or to lower social and environmental standards. It's about quality, not quantity.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. –  The Commission’s Work Programme for 2016 impressed me, yet I must make a tiny comment related to certain aspects of this year’s preliminary activities. We often hear complaints that the rules and procedures to make EU funds available for SMEs are too complicated, slow and even controversial. The Commission has rightly begun to look for ways to ease them and cut out red tape.  However, it is more than unpleasantly surprising that the responsibility for the high level working group on this topic has been given to the person who is actually responsible for all the complexity, obscurity, non-transparency and other problems within the existing system. Indeed, that person spent 10 years in the Barroso Commissions complicating everything! Yet Mr Juncker and the College of Commissioners have allowed him to preside over the U-turn in policy.  The appointment of former Commissioner Mr Siim Kallas to such a position is like getting a wolf to guard the sheep. Or even an attempt to put a square peg in a round hole! It is indisputably a misuse of European tax-payers’ money.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Juncker plan represents a key pillar of the strategy of the current European Commission. Instead of putting the Central Bank financing the investment or changing the rules for accounting for deficits in order to relaunch public investment and attract private investment, the European Commission presents us with a financial engineering exercise that is not even new, as it has been experienced in the past, and to no avail. This fund won't solve anything. First, because it will not have the expected impact, given the totally unrealistic premises. Even if some capital is realized, it will finance projects based on criteria of financial profitability. In the Regulation, and despite our suggestions, there is no criterion of geographical distribution or regional cohesion. The fund is fully managed by technocrats, and the strategic guidelines will be defined by an administration where votes are proportional to the volume of invested capital. This is the antithesis of what we stand for for Europe. This is another plan to feed public-private partnerships, and it will once again be rich countries getting the lion's share.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2016 – all sections [11706/2015 – C8-0274/2015 – 2015/2132(BUD)] (A8-0298/2015).

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to greet the Commission, the Commissioner and the Presidency of the Council, as well as all colleagues.  This is a budget that I consider realistic, responsible and credible - I am talking about the proposal we are presenting here. The European Union must be up to the challenges it faces; the European Union must say yes to the agreements it has signed: as I have said several times, pacta sunt servanda, the commitments are to be fulfilled. I am referring to the multiannual financial framework; I am referring, for example, to the payment plan; I am referring to the expectations that have been created in citizens and beneficiaries on these issues.  Of course, we must respect the Europe 2020 strategy and implement the multiannual financial framework. To this end, for the amounts we propose, we do so in view of the absorption capacity of the lines, the interest of the programmes and the policies that are defined, and we want to make the most of the flexibility that we have available in the multiannual financial framework. Employment is the highest priority, the competitiveness of the European Union cannot be forgotten and all the programmes we have to strengthen it must be set in motion.  We want to strengthen horizon 2020 and COSME. Youth unemployment is still high and, therefore, the Employment for Youth Employment initiative must continue. We propose that in 2016, contrary to what the European Commission has done, there should be authorisation appropriations for this initiative to continue. We advocate the three "E" - employment, businesses (in particular small and medium-sized enterprises) and entrepreneurship - to strengthen the competitiveness of the European Union.  We have not forgotten the problem of refugees, the refugee crisis, and we have already said so in the various resolutions we have put forward here. In this context, we are advocating a package for this problem which takes into account the internal dimension and the external dimension, and therefore we do not understand, as I have already mentioned here in the last plenary, the Council's cuts to instruments contributing to cooperation and development, such as the instrument for cooperation and the instrument of pre-join , or cuts in combating poverty in the Mediterranean. In this package for the refugee crisis, in order to combat it, we want to strengthen the means that should give dignity and welcome to refugees, as well as internal solidarity, but also this external solidarity, using all the means and financial instruments that we have at our disposal, as well as the agencies. A common policy is required for this purpose; coordination and articulation is also required. Refugees are not to blame — refugees are victims — and for this extraordinary situation we must also have additional means, extraordinary means. It would be unacceptable for the Council not to want to make any further efforts in this area and to want to make re-allocations. If this were not to happen, we would be faced with beautiful words from the Council, but words that never materialise in practice. Solidarity, as I have said many times, is practiced, it is not proclaimed.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I have the responsibility, madam, to present our budgetary proposals with regard to the so-called other institutions.  Among these other institutions, I would start with those which, in our view, have presented the least problems between us, in the Committee on Budgets, and which, according to my information, will pose less with the other branch of the budgetary authority. I am talking about the Court of Auditors, the Economic and Social Committee, the Ombudsman, the European Data Protection Supervisor and the European External Action Service, for which we have taken up, on our own account, the proposals that were originally formulated by the Commission, because we found them, after examination, perfectly justified.
