However, there are slight exceptions: one - very limited - in favour of the Committee of the Regions of a few tens of thousands of euros and the other, of a larger scale, for the benefit of the European Court of Justice, whose ability to judge in a reasonable time would, in our view, be undermined by the indiscriminate application of cuts in support and translation staff.  I now turn to the European Parliament's actual budget. And while I know that a number of colleagues will find it difficult to believe me on this point, I consider it a budget of rigour and reform that we have the honour of proposing to Parliament. Since the beginning of its work, the Committee on Budgets has agreed, on my proposal, to set up an exceptional envelope of EUR 15,000. The exclusive purpose of this envelope is to finance urgent and necessary security measures: building security first, as it is true that access to buildings, in Brussels in particular, has demonstrated their deficiency; computer security, then, to adapt our computer systems to technological advances and protect them from possible attacks, increasingly varied and sophisticated.  Apart from this exceptional envelope, the European Parliament's budget will increase overall by only 1.6% in 2016 compared to 2015, a level close to predictable inflation. This limited increase is all the more significant because we have had to take into account very recently the creation of a new political group, which has led to requests for additional temporary jobs and a significant increase in spending, which has also been offset.  To those who would be tempted to believe - and I know there are some - that this increase is still too high in the current context of budgetary restrictions, I want to point out two realities: the first is that before presenting the European Parliament's budget to the plenary, the Committee on Budgets must reach an agreement with the European Parliament's Office. , a forum in which budgetary concern is not necessarily a priority. The second reality is that despite this constraint, the Committee on Budgets has managed to reduce by more than EUR 18 million the applications initially approved by the Office. I would add, and it is not unimportant, that at the instigation of the Committee on Budgets, and this is a point on which your rapporteur has been heavily involved, the Office last night agreed on a major reform of Members' personal assistants, which was budgetarily known as the secretariat allowance, which is inadequate and which we are proposing to amend.  Under the old system, an MP could spend all of this compensation on the payment of local assistants. Some, moreover, had hired an impressive number and did not hire any accredited assistants. I had felt - I was not the only one - and I still believe that in order to carry out his or her job fully as a legislator and to monitor the action of the executive, a Member must have at least one and, preferably, several accredited assistants, that is, carrying out their activities where Parliament does work.  I thought I had six minutes. Or is it only four minutes? (...) The Office, in its decision yesterday, largely takes this concern into account by allocating at least 25% of the amount made available to each Member of Parliament for the remuneration of accredited assistants. This means that this 25% sum will be frozen and not available if no accredited assistants are hired. Other provisions, which I do not have time to detail here, have been approved; they all are in the direction of greater transparency and a more effective fight against abuse. As a result, changes Article 34 propose the application of reference thresholds for the salaries and fees of local assistants in order to limit the risk of remuneration that deviates excessively from the average remuneration in the Member State concerned. In addition, and in order to better manage operating costs, proposed amendments are being discussed on parliamentary matters. This may seem somewhat marginal, but it is not so if we know that since the beginning of the Parliament, our colleagues have already asked more than 16,000 written questions and that each written question costs Parliament and the Commission a total of EUR 780.  Colleagues, I am aware that there are serious controversies in some of the provisions of this budget. I am also aware that the negotiations that will soon begin with the Council will be close, particularly on the staffing table. But it is with conviction and determination that I will defend with the whole delegation of the European Parliament the choices you will make tomorrow by voting on the budget of the other institutions.

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, it is an honour for me to be here today for this debate which is part of a relatively favourable starting point, since we have made good progress so far. We have been able to pass seven amending budgets very quickly and one-eighth is about to be. We have a payment plan to clear the arrears, so we have a serene starting point, which distinguishes this year's situation from last year's.  With regard to the political approach to the amendments that the European Parliament intends to adopt, I must nevertheless stress that the Council notes that there is a significant increase in the draft budget presented by the European Parliament and that its proposals would increase commitment appropriations by more than EUR 4.15 billion and payment appropriations by more than EUR 4.34 billion. Certainly, since the Council's proposal of 4 September, there has been the Commission's amending letter No. 2, which arrived on 14 October and is very welcome, as it aims to strengthen headings 3 and 4 of the multi-year financial framework to respond to the refugee crisis. But even in relation to this revision brought about by the Commission's amending letter, which is also very ambitious, Parliament's amendments still deviate from EUR 2 billion in payments and EUR 2.5 billion in commitments.  Moreover, the substantial credit increases proposed by the European Parliament would result in the ceilings of the multi-year framework being exceeded by a negative margin of -1.5 billion in commitments and -1.3 billion euros in payments. If we followed the european Parliament's amendments, the margins of headings 1a, 1b and 3 would be negative and those in heading 4 would be completely exhausted. It seems to me in this regard that the approach chosen by the European Parliament is maximalist or ambitious in the extreme, and the special instruments that the European Parliament would want to use would not even be sufficient to cover the proposed credit overruns for 2016.  We can certainly agree, as a Council, that it is important to address the political and historical challenges we face, particularly in the area of refugees, but it is still fundamental to realis that there are other priorities as well. The Commission has attempted to respond to this challenge with amending letter 2, which proposes to significantly strengthen headings 3 and 4. During the conciliation procedure, we will have the opportunity to discuss together the extent of the structure proposed by the Commission. The European Parliament has not sufficiently applied the necessary rules to set priorities: not all projects, all programmes can be priorities at the same time. The Council, for its part, has complied, in all headings and in all sub-headings, with the ceilings, and this is how it has been able to give itself the necessary and sufficient leeway. This is good not only for fiscal discipline but also for responding to the challenges and emergencies that lie ahead in 2016. Very quickly on heading 1a, the European Parliament decided to backtrack on the agreement that had been sealed in the middle of the year to make the European Fund for Strategic Investments possible, and that is regrettable. On point 1b, Parliament proposes to increase the endowments while the Commission has found a way to increase the necessary appropriations for Greece on existing endowments in 2015 and 2016: this does not make much sense. On the youth employment initiative, there was an agreement to be limited to 2014 and 2015, and if we wanted to plan for 2016, we would have to do it after an evaluation. For agricultural expenditure, Parliament is proposing an increase of 500 million, while here too the Commission, in its agricultural amending letter, has found different means and in fact even expected a reduction of 477 million in commitments and payments. In conclusion, I would like to stress the importance that the Council attaches to respecting the reduction of staff in all institutions, bodies and agencies, as reflected in the agreement that was concluded and according to the workforce tables of 1 January 2013. This reduction should be made without exception and without any particular or unilateral derogation, it is indeed a matter of the credibility of our institutions. Madam President, dear Members of the European Parliament, you can count on the will of the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council to reach a balanced and satisfactory agreement on the 2016 budget, with intend to do so within the time frames set out in the treaties.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, we are here today to discuss how to make best use of the EU budget to respond to the significant challenges the EU is facing. For the draft budget 2016 we have prioritised three objectives: to boost our economies, fill the investment gap and enhance economic recovery. For this we will leverage our budget instruments. I am very happy to report what we have done together. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is now operational, and we expect that it will trigger EUR 50 billion in additional investments – public and private – by the end of this year, 2015. For 2016 we expect an acceleration of delivery for our economies. Our second objective is to address the exceptional migratory pressures faced by the EU, and our draft budget proposal makes maximum use of the flexibility allowed. We will therefore more than double funding over this and next year to address the refugee crisis. Our third objective remains very important. It is to phase out the abnormal backlog of unpaid bills from the 2007-2013 programming period by the end of 2016. So in our draft proposal we believe we have put forward a sound basis on which to achieve these three objectives.  Let me first address commitment appropriations, including Amending Letter 2. We welcome the amendments proposed by the Committee on Budgets to restore the cuts made by Council. Life has shown that we need to move forward in 2016, especially given the dramatic impact of the refugee crisis. We need to provide room for collective EU-level action, in Heading 4 especially. We also take note of a number of amendments that increase commitment appropriations above the draft budget proposal made by the Parliament. We will fully employ the maximum flexibility test that is allowed by the current financial framework to respond to the challenges, and we want to do this in a prudent manner.  We all agree that migration should now be given highest priority. This should guide us through the choices that have to be made and the choices we will have to make. We have to be sure that budget 2016 is done in a way that allows us to face what is unfortunately a more uncertain future. I want to stress that for many in this House there has been concern about the Youth Employment Initiative. As a result of the major frontloading that we have done in 2014 and 2015 – and which will continue and even accelerate in 2016 – we expect to see progress on the ground in terms of jobs for our young people. We will make a first assessment of this experience at the end of this year, and that will allow us to have more informed actions in 2016. Let me now turn to payment appropriations. Here there is a large gap of EUR 4.3 billion between the Council’s and the Parliament’s reading. The level of payment appropriations proposed in draft budget 2016, as revised by Amending Letter number 2 (with more than EUR 914 million in payments) allows the proper implementation of programmes and enables us to meet our third objective, the phasing out of the abnormal backlog in line with the agreed payment plan. This will only happen if Parliament and Council agree on the payments requested by the Commission for 2016.  Again I want to turn to the Parliament’s Committee on Budgets and thank it for the restoration of most of the appropriations that we have put forward. It is now time for us in the Commission to take a very good look at the Council and Parliament proposals and carefully review each and every one of the amendments in detail. We will then send our reaction in writing, prior to the opening of the conciliation, so that the three institutions can negotiate with full knowledge of the choices we are making and the implications of these choices. I will conclude by saying that I am confident that we will have successful negotiations. We all recognise how important it is for Europe that we send a clear signal of commitment to serve our people and to meet the challenges that we face.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Firstly, as a reporter for the IMCO commission, I would like to thank Mr Fernandes, who has done and has done a great job so far. We all know that it has been a very long journey to be able to talk today about a well-structured, efficient and expected well-functioning budget. We have heard many times that because of FC there are certain cuts to be made and there have been areas where there have been cuts. However, there are areas where these cuts cannot be made. This is also the area of EU consumer protection. Every day, the citizens of the European Union face new challenges and a full body of information. It is therefore very important that adequate consumer protection can be applied at EU level – this requires adequate resources. That is why we have submitted a project which was supported by the Commission by a large majority. It is about being able to do this support at this level. I would like to ask my fellow Members to give particular support to this project when the budget is voted on.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, I support the budget for growth and jobs, and the budget to handle the refugee crisis, but we also need a budget for democracy. Europe needs the trust and confidence of its citizens, and this can come with a more generous participation by citizens in European decision-making; this can come with more democracy.  Democracy is an indispensable element to achieving economic success and that is why one of the priorities for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) is the ‘Europe for citizens’ programme. Its financial sufficiency is crucial to building more efficient communication with European Union citizens and regaining their trust. Equally important is improving the efficiency of the European Citizens’ Initiative as a tool for participatory European democracy and that is why we ask for an adequate budget for these issues and I truly hope that they will find their place in the final outcome of the 2016 budgetary procedure.

name: Peter Simon
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her First of all, thank you to the Committee on Budgets for taking on board our key demands. Our key demands relate in particular to the three supervisory authorities that we created during the financial crisis: the euro, to make the European Union safer, to put the securities, banks and insurance sectors on clearer, clearer, better footing here. However, when we now hear from the three supervisory authorities that the resources they have at their disposal are sometimes insufficient to carry out even basic tasks, that has been shocking to us. We have called for increases in individual areas. We are grateful that these have been taken up by the Committee on Budgets.  However, we also warn for the future that this will be taken into account even more closely in future budget preparation, because the best control on paper will not be of any use in practice if it is not adequately fed, and we have considerable catching up to do here, particularly in the area of personnel.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský
text: Draftsman of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, I am pleased that the draft budget respects the need to increase funding for adequate responses to the immigration crisis, which has a huge impact on states inside and outside the European Union. Some European agencies already play a key role in this area, they will have more such resources to carry out their work. However, even in the current situation, it is necessary to ensure the correct budgetary implementation and use the funds according to the principle of efficiency and effectiveness. The European Commission must regularly monitor and monitor the use of funds in this area and ensure that all funds are used in a transparent and transparent way in order to avoid an increased level of error. The Commission must also regularly provide impact assessments on migration and asylum. Member States must supply relevant data and the Commission must severely penalised the erroneous or false information of the Member States concerned.

name: Alain Cadec
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. Madam President, the Committee on Budgets has adopted a pilot project, proposed by the Committee on Fisheries. This pilot project provides supervision of the coastguard at European level. I thank my colleagues José Manuel Fernandes and Jean Arthuis for their support.  Indeed, the European Union is disarmed in the face of the tragedy of migrant shipwrecks. We are faced with a terrible contradiction: the problem is truly European, but the means of surveillance and intervention at sea are the responsibility of the States and the coordination between them is minimalist.  This pilot project therefore proposes to create a European supervisory mechanism to coordinate the action of the national coastguard as well as that of European agencies: Frontex, the Fisheries Control Agency and the Maritime Safety Agency. This proposal is accompanied by a budget of 750,000 euros to pool capacity and resources, share information and carry out coordinated planning of operations at sea. This is therefore a significant step forward in strengthening the Schengen area and better coordinating the action of Member States at the borders.

name: Péter Niedermüller
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Madam President, we in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) fully support the broad political message being sent by the Commission with its significant proposal for increasing the 2016 budget in the area of migration, asylum and even border control, as the LIBE Committee proposed earlier. But of course we have some questions on details. These are matters of tremendous political importance that we need to debate. I will just mention very shortly two points. First I welcome the increase suggested for the European Asylum Support Office (EASO). I think that we need to support EASO in order that people arriving can have their asylum application properly proceed. I also wonder why Europol should receive the same increase in funding and staff as EASO. The second point is that we have to change the nomenclature of the AMIF budget lines because putting integration and return together in one budget line is just avoiding being clear on where the money is being spent. These two small examples show that we need some more debate on the most important political issues of the budget.

name: Massimiliano Salini
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Committee on Transport has been very apprehensive about the construction of this budget, because, as we know, we face great challenges, the new challenges that the Juncker plan is the first and foremost.  On the other hand, we run the risk that support for this new great possibility for Europe would also become an instrument for draining resources from other instruments that are already working, such as the CEF and Horizon 2020. We have achieved , and I thank the rapporteurs for watching closely in this regard, a fair balance between the two needs: new financing instruments for investments that Europe needs and support for instruments that are already working.  Because Europe cares and European businesses care – especially the smallest, small and medium-sized enterprises – if we have a large network of connections for people, goods and data. We have today voted on a report on the circulation of data. We also need infrastructure in this regard for Europe to support all those who can generate value.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Madam President, Europe is facing multiple crises which would indeed require more and more Community means to manage them today.  The Council and the Member States must hear what Parliament is saying: there is an urgent need to embark resolutely on a new budgetary path where the Union would have its own resources, for example from financial transactions. There is an urgent need to give ourselves the financial leeway in relation to the issues of the moment: climate change, the energy transition, the advent of the digital society, industrial recovery, youth employment, the refugee crisis, geopolitical instability in the Middle East and, of course, agriculture, an issue for which I was rapporteur of the budget. Europe can do a lot; this political project has a proven track worth; today, it is broken, because it is subject, indeed, to headwinds. How can one imagine, on the one hand, a budgetary rigour and propose, on the other, a lot of investments? I believe that there is a contradiction here, Europe must remove this contradiction, we must give air to the European budget.

name: Reimer Böge
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her For the Committee on International Trade, it is a question of having adequate establishment plans in the Commission services so that the large number of agreements currently being negotiated can be negotiated appropriately and seriously and can subsequently be subject to a reasonable assessment. We need better public relations. We would also like to continue with the Aid for Trade project, and we also call for a study on the role of NGOs. But let me say one thing about the debate now with the Presidency of the Council: I have been doing budgetary procedures in this House for a relatively long time. We do not need the Council to tell us anything about the logic and seriousness of the budgetary procedure. They make it too easy for themselves. What has been agreed with previous presidencies, be it on arrears, on the issue of flexibility, on the issue of front loading and backloading, or on the constraints on the EFSI agreements, you are always quickly brushing that aside. I will tell you one thing: your seriousness, including in the 2016 budget procedure, will be largely answered by whether, at the time of the hearing, you are proving that the Member States are not continuing to refuse to make adequate payments for the Madad Fund and the Fund for Africa as they have done up to now. Just 20 million have been pledged so far for each of these funds. The Commission expects 501.8 billion further commitments. If you do not do so, then you are partly responsible, including the inadequacy of the work of the United Nations, for more refugees to make their way to Europe. This is the decisive decision of your seriousness!

name: n/a
text: Madam President, Vice-President Georgieva, in this 2016 budget we face three important challenges on the part of the REGI Committee: the first is the de-escalation of outstanding payments; In total, there are requests for EUR 15 billion. Euro. So there remains a gap. The second challenge we face is to monitor the absorption but also the efficiency in jobs and to develop the money invested by European taxpayers. I think it is a good thing that we have appointed a special MEP for Greece, but I believe that Greece should not be the exception, but monitoring the progress of the implementation of the Community framework should become the norm for the European Parliament. The third concerns tackling the refugee crisis. There it is particularly positive that countries such as Greece can use funds from the Structural Funds and cohesion to deal with the crisis as well as the open window left by President Junker to exclude these costs from the Stability Pact.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs, Mr Fernandes and Mr Deprez, for taking into account the opinion expressed by the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the 2016 budget in formulating the response to the Council's position on the budget.  I would then like to draw attention to the fact that, of all the sections of the budget, the Council has chosen to cut the most drastically in that which concerns the external activities of the European Union. From the point of view of the Union's ability to carry out a coherent foreign policy, and implicitly to influence the international scene, I believe that these budget cuts are extremely worrying. These reductions concern the European Neighbourhood Instrument, the pre-accession instrument, but also the development cooperation instrument, which is used, among other things, to finance European action on immigration.  Faced with the many crises facing the countries of our neighbourhood, faced with the challenge posed by the large number of refugees seeking to flee from countries in conflict, disinvesting is, I think, the worst strategy we could follow. It is for this reason that it is imperative to restore and strengthen payment credits and commitment credits.

name: Arne Lietz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. Madam President, I would like to thank the President-in-House for the work she has done This draft budget is important in the field of development cooperation because it responds to the new international challenges. We must address the current conflicts in Africa, Syria and Iraq and the associated refugee flows at the humanitarian, development and foreign policy levels at European level. The EU must respond more strongly to the catastrophic humanitarian situations.  I have advocated for the S&D Group to ensure that at least EUR 26 million should be spent on the education of boys – and girls, including girls – in the refugee camps. In doing so, we want to prevent a so-called lost generation.  The many additional funds currently being set up by the EU or co-financed by the EU show that this is not enough. It is important that the Member States finally clearly name their shares and also deposit them without delay. These include the Commission's new Africa Fund to combat the causes of flight, worth €1.8 billion, and the Madad Fund for Dealing with the Syrian Refugee Crisis, which is to be increased to EUR 1 billion.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Budgets should, of course, be for citizens, not finance ministers. That's what we know, we're aware of it. But is this the budget? In a way, it is, and in a sense not, because clarity is undoubtedly lacking. But it can be said without any doubt that this is a responsibility budget – extremely difficult, in extremely difficult times.  I would like to stress, above all, the need for solidarity both in the raising of funds in this budget and in the joint spending of the funds that are finally included in this budget. When representing the Committee on Culture, Education and Sport, I would like to emphasise the four most important things: firstly, as expected by the Commission as a whole, the Erasmus plus, Creative Europe and Europe programmes for citizens have been enlarged. This is very important and I would like to thank you very much for that. The second thing is very important: we are coming down from the old commitments, which is also very important, which is to reduce the commitments that citizens are waiting for. Lastly, a little critical: there is still a lack of funding for pilot programmes, and that is the only thing I would like to mention.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to express my sincere thanks for the Commission's proposal. It is quite simply important that we have this debate on an equal footing. In future, the Council will have to agree better on the political level, so that, when the negotiations begin, there is a mandate that can also be negotiated seriously with Parliament. The European Parliament also attaches great importance, of course, to the fact that the issue of the economy and employment must be an absolute priority, particularly in the areas of programmes for small and medium-sized enterprises, in the COSME programme. We need the 16.5 million new commitments here, including for the employment initiative, especially for the unemployed, but also for the refugees, so that new initiatives can take hold here and so that dual training with apprentices is put at the centre. Europe must set an example here, we must take action here. It is very clear that we need to set new standards in this area, including, of course, refugee policy. We must go through all the budget lines and see how we can support this, how we can achieve stability here, and how we can protect the legally stable area in Europe here. With regard to Parliament's budget, I would just like to say that, of course, the entry of the new group with more than 40 posts and EUR 3.5 million would place more burdenons on the European taxpayer. The fact is that we have at the moment taken enormous savings measures to avoid an increase in the budget here, that we are even below the 20% that we normally have, and that, despite the additional wishes of the new group, which are burdening the taxpayer, we have managed to provide a reasonable and long-term budget here. In the context of the employee pay that we have and the abuse limits that exist here, colleagues who do not want to take advantage of their opportunities should publicly disclose to the public which employees they do not need. Because if they are not present much and do not work a lot, then of course they do not need any employees. This would lead to enormous savings potential.

name: Jens Geier
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Minister Gramegna, Vice-President Georgieva, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the Rapporteur on the work she has said. First of all, I would like to thank our general rapporteur for excellent cooperation in the pre-litigation process of this debate and our decision-making tomorrow. I do not need to repeat his account, which is fully shared by the Socialist and Democratic Members of my group. The Council must now show its colours. This morning, many group chairmen of this House quite rightly criticised the fact that the Council, in one form, agrees on something politically, with the greatest possible violations, and that the same Council, in its financial formation, subsequently does not finance this agreement. The finance ministers now have a chance to heal this. But the trialogue last Monday afternoon said that tackling the refugee crisis is important, but it is also budgetary discipline. And that, ladies and gentlemen, Minister, cannot be your last word, and not for humanitarian reasons, nor for domestic reasons. I really believe that human lives are more important than budgetary discipline. Secondly, when it comes to the budgetary reasons, the Council's and Parliament's approach is now just EUR 4.3 billion apart. The Commission's amendment no 8 lists revenue in the EU budget from own resources and penalties, which would already cover a large part of this money. The same amending budget lists additional savings for the Member States from gross national income, so that we have a net effect of EUR 8 billion. So: money is there. All that stands in the way of an important EU contribution to alleviating the refugee crisis is the dogmatism of the Member States in budgetary matters. My problem when I hear the Council talking about savings and budgetary discipline is that when it comes to its own interests, it does not take it quite so seriously. I have a major problem with this when we are talking about savings in this House, but at the same time the Council is unable to agree on the reappointment of judges in the European Court of Justice, so that instead of twelve additional judges, we get twenty-eight, because the Member States are unable to agree differently from the fact that each Member State has a second judge's post at the European Court of Justice. Ladies and gentlemen, they do not come on foot, they have drivers, they have secretarial staff, they have staff. So the seriousness – as Mr Böge has already mentioned – on the council's point when it comes to savings, is a bit damaged. Verehrter Herr Minister Gramegna! Please encourage the Council to be positive about the Commission's amendment No 2 and come to conciliation with a different, changed, better Council position!

name: Richard Ashworth
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I welcome Commissioner Georgieva’s proposals. She is, as usual, disciplined, controlled and sensible and for that she has my thanks and my full support. She spoke of building a budget on principles. May I suggest too, first, European added value. That means a budget which focuses its resources on those areas where it can help the Member States most. For example: of course we must respond positively and urgently to the refugee crisis and of course we can and must help the farming sector through a very difficult period, but at the same time it is important that we neither get deflected from nor lose sight of the single most important thing the EU budget could be doing for Europe’s citizens, and that is creating jobs and growth. The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) is our flagship policy here and it is vital that it delivers this year.  The second policy principle is value for money. We do not have limited resources for the budget, but that does not justify Parliament’s call for an ever bigger budget. The size of the budget was agreed under the terms of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and this is not the time to be going back to the Member States asking for more money. Rather, this is the time for us to see more focus and greater prioritisation in our spending. That means taking the tough decisions. It does mean discipline and it means that we have to do more to ensure effective, efficient delivery.

name: Jean Arthuis
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Minister, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, the draft budget for 2016 as adjusted by the Committee on Budgets - and I would like, in this regard, to commend the remarkable work done by the rapporteur-general, José Manuel Fernandes, and by the rapporteur for the other sections, Gérard Deprez - is a budget corseted by the 2014-2020 multi-year financial framework. , supposed to address the problem of the time when it was conceived and adopted; in other words, despite our efforts, this budget is largely a mirror of the past.  Faced with the crises, that of the euro and the over-indebtedness of Greece, and then that of migration, the European Union, deprived of budgetary resources and flexibility, condemns itself to show its weaknesses, even its impotence. Beyond our votes, the prevailing impression is that the European Union can only curb migration flows if the causes of migration are effectively tackled, both by ending violence in the Middle East and the Horn of Africa and by committing a genuine development policy in sub-Saharan Africa. However, it is clear that the 2016 budget does not have the necessary funds to act at the root of population movements that converge on our continent.  And yet, Jean-Claude Juncker reminded us here this morning, in an exceptional situation, an exceptional budget. Beautiful words waiting for action. The first illustration of our indigence is the creation of coastguards and border guards at the external borders of the European Union and is proposed by the heads of state or government. Assuming that the terms of command of these coast guards and border guards are settled, where are the necessary funds? With regard to the refugee camps on the borders of Syria, Turkey, Lebanon, Jordan, Mrs Merkel and Jean-Claude Juncker, again this morning, agree that an envelope of three billion is required. Where are the corresponding credits?  At this stage, given the financial situation of most Member States, we must be aware of the difficulties that will mark the opening up of conciliation, Minister. Parliament's vote will give strength to the negotiators who will do everything to convince the Council of the merits of our budgetary options. Having said that, I guarantee that conciliation will be a tough test, whatever the conclusion. It will give us decisive arguments for the immediate review of the multi-year financial framework. It will be the test of truth for the Last Chance Commission and the Council's historic responsibility to respond to it.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, cuirim fáilte roimh chuid de na feabhsúcháin ón gCoiste um Buiséid maidir le seasamh na Comhairle agus an Choimisiúin ar Bhuiséad 2016, ach fós tá sé i bhfad ó cad atá ag teastáil uainn chun aghaidh a thabhairt ar na deacrachtaí. Cuireann sé béim ar an bpráinn atá le hathbhreithniú a dhéanamh ar an gCreat Airgeadais Ilbhliantúil. Is rud maith é ar ndóigh an méadú EUR 500 milliún mar fhreagairt don ghéarchéim déirí agus cuirim fáilte roimh an méadú do COSME mar atá molta ag an bParlaimint, go háirithe tar éis laghdú uafásach ón gComhairle. Ní mór dúinn a bheith meabhrach agus sinn ag obair le EUR 6 bhilliún níos lú ná mar a bhí againn i 2007 – 2013. Tá fadhbanna ollmhóra airgeadais os ár gcomhair amach agus tá sé seo ann de bharr an easnaimh a bhí againn arís i 2007 – 2014. Níl sé ceart agus tá sé meargánta nach bhfuil na Ballstáit ag déanamh aon rud faoi na billí nach bhfuil íoctha. Táimid ag cur an bhuiséid ar ghaineamh súraic agus sinn ag ciceáil an fhadhb síos an bóthar. Caithfidh an tAontas Eorpach a bheith réadúil faoi seo, mar cinnte, in 2017 beidh torthaí na bhfadhbanna airgeadais seo ró-shoiléir ar fad.

name: Indrek Tarand
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. –  Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her draft proposal, which is a good basis for us to work on, and I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their determination and tenacity.  I have four quick remarks. As for EFSI, we stand firmly behind the rapporteur to achieve full actual restoring, i.e. heeding, of the promises to undo EFSI-related cuts, in particular with regard to Horizon 2020 and CEF. Regarding migration, while we support the approach, we still believe, as stated in the resolution on DAB 7 a couple of weeks ago, that in particular the European Asylum Support Office needs to be boosted further. We welcome the wisdom of the Budget Committee to fight for the end of bullfighting subsidies and very much hope that Plenary does not fall back behind that. It was only one vote which decided the whole thing. Allow me a short comment on ITER. We regret that the excellent amendments made by Mr Berger were withdrawn. They reflected well the current concerns with the bad management and rising costs of ITER, as confirmed recently by the German Government. We hence hope that the plenary rejects the ITER position and supports our own amendments which, while not coordinated with Mr Berger, could have been his. We found a good compromise on the EU-EP budget, but we believe it is crucial to identify further saving areas for years to come, and I would promise to come up with some radical ideas in the committee.  Let me finish by encouraging the rapporteurs to continue being tenacious until the very end of our upcoming conciliation process.

name: Marco Zanni
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to start by thanking the two rapporteurs and the Commissioner for the difficult work they have done in recent months.  The European Parliament has expressed in its position a number of priorities which are also ours, starting with a greater commitment by Europe to address the issue of immigration. Since I began my experience in this House, I have insisted that this issue should be at the heart of our efforts and commitments. Some of my colleagues who are here today were with me in Sicily in July and saw how difficult it is to manage this emergency which Italy and the other border countries are unable to support on their own.  The European budget is not only made up of priorities to be supported, however, but also waste and privileges that cannot be tolerated. What is the need to increase public funds every year for European political parties and foundations? What is also the need to increase expenditure again for parliamentary assistants or political groups in this Parliament? I would also like to ask you what is the added value of institutions such as the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions, which have no legislative function but burn hundreds of millions of euros of public money every year.  We must be the first to set an example to the citizens to whom we are constantly asking for sacrifices. It is certainly not by increasing the costs of European politics and bureaucracy that we can be credible. I believe that there is still a long way to go.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – We are talking today about the budget, about the money that Brussels is taking from its citizens. While it rains after-taxes, more and more money has to be added. With all these billions, no solution to the financial crisis has been bought or a solution to the migration crisis has been found. But critics of it are threatened with an end to subsidies. This is undemocratic and irresponsible and shows the immaturity of this fake parliament. So where did all the money go? Among other things, to an airport in Spain where no one has ever landed, or to a sound screen in Poland, somewhere where no one lives. Moreover, the money is also not spent according to the rules. This is fixed by the Court of Auditors every year. In short, budgets are being spent ineffectively and incorrectly, and the asylum crisis will not be solved with money either. My party will therefore vote against these proposals and is calling for a huge reduction in the budget. Let the EU stop this useless and costly centrality.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI). Mr President, looking at the European Union budget for 2016, I have the impression that we are blinding ly. Behind the beautifully written headings lies a completely different world.  How is it possible that EUR 15.5 million will be used to fund the development of the European Union? young people aged 15-24 benefit from the budget but unemployment under the age of 25 reaches 21%? It is not possible to predict a reduction in expenditure on rural development, when, as a result of Russia's embargo on agricultural products since August 2014, there have been losses in agricultural incomes of EUR 3.6 billion. Euro. Or is it the demonstrations and incidents of farmers in the Member States to thank us for the measures we are taking? It is not possible to budget EUR 1.9 billion for the period 2007-2013. Some 710,000 migrants have entered the Union so far. In other words, for 2016 you are budgeting around EUR 2700 per migrant, while in my country more than 44% of the population had an income below the fixed poverty line in 2013. Such budgets are to stay in theory and give the citizens of the European Union the impression that we are helping them. That's a big lie.

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in recent years we have fought for all European policies to be implemented, and every year the budget has been a constant confrontation so that all political projects and policies can be implemented.  On behalf of the Committee on Budgets, I would simply like to highlight a number of needs that we highlight along the lines of our competence. On the one hand, those relating to climate research, climate change and health. Above all, however, there is an issue which is close to our hearts and which we would like to see satisfied in the budget. It is clear that some of the agencies – and I am referring to the European Medicines Agency and ECHA – are no longer able to carry out their duties, even if the resources for carrying out their functions come from outside, simply because they no longer have the necessary staff resources at their disposal. The work is increasing, the tasks we entrust are increasingly being done, but we must adapt the agencies' action plan, otherwise they will not give the services required.

name: Jan Olbrycht (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The year 2016, both in terms of the size of the budget and its implementation, will have a huge impact on the debate on the review of the Multiannual Financial Perspectives as well as on the next years of this perspective. It is important to realise that the first years of the outlook ahead of 2016 are already a period of largely flexibility, that is, the use of largely available margins. It is therefore very clear that 2016 is already the result of certain actions that were carried out in 2014 and 2015. Therefore, the size of the budget, its structure clearly indicates that the ceilings agreed for the period 2014-2020 are too low. They are too low and therefore certain things cannot be realised, and the new expenditure that arises makes this situation even worse. I would like to draw your attention to this, because it will have an impact on our debate on the review. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Thank you, President Tajani. I would have a question about the European Innovation Fund.  There, Parliament is proposing an increase of EUR 5 million to cover the total cost of implementing the new SME window, so the funds for small and medium-sized projects should therefore be available quickly and efficiently in the EFSE Fund, in the Juncker Fund.  Do you think that this can really be the Council's priority, that we create new jobs, especially in small and medium-sized enterprises?

name: n/a
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. I absolutely agree with you, and I believe that 2016 will be a test of some political will, expressed in the Juncker Fund. If so much has been said about what money should be spent on small and medium-sized enterprises, not only in Horizon 2020, not only in cohesion policy, but also in the so-called Juncker Fund, I believe that indeed the suggestion for action in this area is absolutely right.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: – despite the new unforeseen costs, we have found a way and solutions so that we do not have to increase the European Parliament's budget compared to the figures we agreed in the spring. We now need to focus on common solutions for higher growth and jobs, better people's lives. But also to address a vision in which life gradually brings about a financial and economic crisis, a migration crisis, a conflict in Ukraine, a Greek debt crisis. We should not put obstacles in the way ourselves. Today, in the Commission and in the European Parliament, 104 people are fully exploited only by answers to the questions that Members submit to the Commission. It costs millions of euros a year. If every Member behaved in the same way as those at the forefront of statistics, we would need more than EUR 200 million a year just for the Commission's answers to Members' questions. We have managed to limit a number of issues, but final solutions in the fight against bureaucracy still await us. If we want to kick-start Europe, we need a Juncker Investment Plan. European finance must go to projects with the highest added value. Implementation of EU funds cannot be delayed. The European Union must pay its commitments on time. We need to start a digital market, an energy union, a reform of the financial sector. Half of the world's financial operations cannot flow through tax havens. We can't afford mistakes. 1700 migrants do not have to perish in the sea before the Council will increase the funding for Frontex, which we had called for years earlier in the budget. The Juncker Investment Plan also has risks. The risk was the way in which the Director-General of the European Fund for Strategic Investments was selected. Whoever is responsible for the results should first have the managerial and psychological tests to verify the abilities of the candidates. Experience to date has shown that the financing of the European budget cannot depend on the political or economic situation in individual states. In a year's time, discussions on own resources will culminate. This is a chance to solve the problems associated with the financing of the European budget.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the budget for 2016 has been discussed several times regarding its priorities and the need to increase financing in key areas, and all in the context of the existing economic situation of an unprecedented migration and refugee crisis.  Unfortunately, the Council decision to make some cuts both in commitment and payment appropriations does not correspond to the political priorities nor to the unfavourable environment. That is why we are reversing the cuts made by the Council. Furthermore we propose that commitment and payment appropriations be raised in several key areas, supporting the full use of all flexibility tools available in the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.  In order to provide an initial response to the immigration crisis we need to increase by almost EUR 1.2 billion the commitments under the headings Security and citizenship and Global Europe, in comparison with the Commission’s original proposal.  In order to overcome the weakness of the EU’s economy almost EUR 1.9 billion in commitment appropriations are envisaged for the Smart and inclusive growth heading. This financing supports continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative, restores the original pre-EFSI profile of Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility in line with the commitment the Committee on Budgets made during the EFSI negotiations, as well as additional allocations to small and medium-enterprises.  In relation to the ongoing crisis affecting European farmers and in order to support the dairy sector, we have proposed increasing funding by EUR 500 million under the heading Sustainable growth: natural resources, in line with the measures announced by the Council and the Commission in September, thus supporting the main goals of the budget – to boost innovation, create jobs, deal more effectively with migration and strengthening the global role of the European Union.  We should not forget the commitments in the implementation of the payment plan agreed by Parliament, the Council and the Commission back in May 2015.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we are discussing a budget limited by the restrictive frameworks of the MFF, with very narrow room for manoeuvre. You know our appreciation of this framework, which sanctifies austerity and budgetary discipline as an unsurpassable horizon and, above all, deprives the Union of sufficient resources to meet the multiple challenges of a chaotic world, a world in crisis, a changing world and a Europe facing many difficulties.  I hope that we will have this debate when the MFF is re-established, and the question of own resources will inevitably arise, to give the Union the means to face these challenges.  We can see this with the migration crisis: the European Parliament's proposal is going in the right direction, but it will remain insufficient to meet the scale of the challenge before us.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, we tried to find ways of cutting the European Union budget, of understanding that, at a time such as this, taxpayers actually cannot support more and more money going from the people to the European Union. And so we, the EFDD, put in 142 amendments to the EU budget and we watched as every single one of those 142 attempts to save money for the taxpayer of the UK and the taxpayers in all of the Member States of the European Union was voted down. Not that we should be particularly surprised – just like the last 55 times the UK tried to oppose a measure in the Council of Ministers, when we were voted down 55 out of 55 times.  We put forward measures on issues like the coordination, surveillance of and communication on the EMU, including the euro. Do we really need to be spending more money on a propaganda campaign on the euro? A tenfold increase in the cost of the European Chemicals Agency – again, something we do not believe is needed. We believe that money could be cut from the European Union special representatives. The European Council, with this whole gentleman’s agreement that supposedly exists and yet, as we have seen even today as we have talked about the 2013 discharge, the Council just is not even answering Parliament’s questions. Well if they are not recognising a gentleman’s agreement then we should certainly not. The Committee of the Regions: again, a body which is getting far too much taxpayers’ money. And then we look at our own House. We should put our own house in order, see what we are spending that we do not need to be: cost of meetings and activities of former members, EUR 210 000 that, frankly, does not actually make a difference to anything whatsoever.  In the vast majority of these areas, we have talked about cutting rather than abolishing budget lines altogether. We have said we want to cut them – and some of them, personally, I would abolish altogether – but we see every single one voted down. That is what we get in this place. Sadly, that is how things work in this place, in the European Union.

name: Barbara Matera
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Fernandes for the work he is doing with dedication and knowledge.  The text of the opinion for which I am rapporteur for the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality reiterates precisely the need to make consistent use of part of EU expenditure for initiatives aimed at ensuring gender equality in all areas. Specifically, I and my colleagues ask that we insist on the importance of allocating funding to programmes to support women's entrepreneurship, mainly through COSME, the European Social Fund and the Youth Employment Initiative.  I also call, in the light of the many feminicides and acts of violence suffered by women on a daily basis, to increase expenditure to support awareness-raising and awareness-raising campaigns against gender stereotypes and the need to maintain the independence of the Daphne programme, precisely the programme that is part of the rights, equality and citizenship programme. Finally, I insisted that a reference be made in the document to the need to set up a European Monitoring Centre on Gender-Based Violence. I'm done with my minutes.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 2016 is the third year of the 2014-2020 MFF. Experience in past years shows that the budget is negotiated with a lot of effort and then not implemented. I wonder how much of the 2014 and 2015 budgets was spent as an allocation from the 2014-2020 MFF? I think very little. The Council uses this situation to propose a reduction in the 2016 budget. It is an attitude of national government, not of the European Council! It's unfair what's going on. Ministers who should, within their governments, take the necessary measures to implement European policies, but do not, decide to shrink the European budget because it is not spent. The Council must ask the Member States to implement European policies. The Commission must intervene and speed up the procedures necessary for the implementation of the budget. The Commission must take a proactive position; should not wait for the actions of the Member States. Negotiations will follow. I believe that the Position of the European Parliament must be in favour of making full use of budgetary resources for investment policies in all European programmes. At the same time, we must support the allocation of resources outside the crisis budget. I think we need to be extremely firm, even consider the non-approval of the budget if the Council maintains its current position.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Mr Minister, since the Commission presented us with your proposal for budgets, we have been working in this Parliament to see if the European Union's priorities fit with the Union's resources, and I think no one will be surprised to say that we do not think they are sufficient resources. That is why what our proposal implies is an increase of EUR 3.6 billion by 2016, which, a priori, may seem like a significant figure, but which, if we look at it with the budget, is only a 2.34% increase. A small increase, a small gesture, but that would allow to have a big impact. Because with this extra EUR 3.6 billion, we could make up for, for example, the cuts we were forced to make for the Juncker plan, and thus be able to meet the research and infrastructure objectives we set ourselves. Or we could also renew the commitment to youth unemployment by funding the Youth Guarantee for another year. Or we could compensate our farmers and ranchers, who are being affected by the Russian veto or the milk crisis. And also, yes, with these 3.6 billion we could finance measures to care in minimum conditions of dignity for those thousands of people who have had to leave their homes. But, Commissioner and Minister, today, beyond this conjunctural debate about whether more money is needed here or there, we must go one step further. Because it is not serious that every time an initiative, a new need, a crisis or an emergency arises, the budget is not agile. It is not serious that a political project such as that of the European Union has ridiculous budgetary capacity and, of course, it is not serious that the Union's resources depend on the goodwill of the Member States. Europe cannot live on the charity of states, but on their commitment. And that is why it is my responsibility, my group and this Parliament, to demand it. Jean Monnet said that Europe would be forced into crises and that it would be the sum of the solutions to these crises. Lately, more than add-ons we are seeing subtractions, so let's see if in the coming days we can change that equation and, of course, we can build a Europe that we are proud of.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: - With next year's budget, the European Union will have the opportunity to correct some important omissions concerning the massive refugee crisis. Thus, it is essential to finally increase the financial allocation for Syrian refugee camps in Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon, as well as for refugee camps in other conflict zones. Improving living conditions in these centres would allow refugees to avoid the perilous journey to Europe, as some of the reasons for moving refugees to Europe have been catastrophic underfunding of refugee camps. Yes, it is expensive to provide basic living conditions for the people in these centres, but it is even more difficult to see these people taking a dangerous route to Europe.  Secondly, the contribution to the establishment and adequate maintenance of refugee reception centres in Greece and Italy needs to be significantly increased. This would allow the tragic and unmanageable movement of refugees to be put across Europe. There is also a serious need to increase the contribution to support thoughtful development in both the European Union's southern and eastern neighbourhoods, including Ukraine.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, these budgets continue to represent a commitment to the Europe of austerity, that insolidarian Europe with its commitments in humanitarian aid, development cooperation and combating major climate risks, such as climate change; a Europe that treats countries such as Greece, Turkey or Morocco as cap states to prevent the mobility of hundreds of thousands of displaced persons, in many cases, because of the European Union's own policies. Budgets that promote a model of productive development that is deciduous and adverse to labour rights, based on dirty, insecure energy and transport megaprojects that increasingly drive citizens away from decision-making on issues affecting them on a daily basis, on access to essential public goods such as water, energy, food , health care or education. In short, these budgets do not meet the needs of European citizens, but to that of large transnationals and lobbies. Decide, when you vote, who you legislate for and what your loyalties are and who you are with. Ours are clear: they are with the citizens and workers of Europe.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, President Juncker acknowledged this morning that the European budget is no longer at the level of the responsibilities that Member States entrust to the Union.  He drew a first conclusion: exceptional circumstances, exceptional recipes. Certainly! But I will add an amendment: the twenty-first century itself will be exceptional. Before the refugees, there was terrorism, there was the investment plan - known as the Juncker Plan - and there was the exceptional programme on youth employment; in a few weeks there will be climate and energy, next year, the digital strategy, etc.  The real conclusion is that we need to prepare for the mid-term review of the multi-year financial framework now. To this end, I suggest that the European Commission undertake preparatory work that is politically necessary. The aim is to assess, sector by sector, the overall budgetary savings that are or will be made possible by the transfer of competence to The European level. A European border guard corps will obviously be more efficient and less expensive than twenty-eight national border police. The single skies - a single air traffic control - will cost less than twenty-eight national checks and improve aviation safety. Every year, the outstanding competition commissioners get billions of euros in fines from multinationals beyond the reach of our national authorities. At the end of the day, one more euro spent in Brussels can save 28 euros in the Member States, it is the simple budgetary translation of the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Mr President, Madam Vice-President, Minister, I know that you share the principle that all political decisions involving budget measures must be honoured with payments. This may seem obvious, but it is not, since the forecast of unpaid bills at the end of 2015 amounts to 17.5 billion euros. It is under this principle that Parliament, in charge, proposes to increase the volume of 2016 payments by 2.9 billion euros.  While we welcome the Commission's responsibility in its second amending letter, we cannot be satisfied with it or accept the Council's unrelenting budget cuts, such as the EUR 450 million in external aid, which is at the heart of the migration issue.  Ladies and gentlemen, the words are flying and the budgets are staying. So if we want to deal with the big issues - the reception of migrants, youth unemployment, recovery through investment - the budget must follow, first of all using all the existing flexibility margins. But, Minister, it is above all time to find a solution other than these systematic redeployments which run from one priority to another according to the emergencies, undressing Pierre to dress Paul, because today the research budget is in jeopardy. Mr Juncker said this morning that budgetary resources were limited and that the exceptional situation had to be taken into account. So, chick! Parliament's TAXE Committee has shown that multinationals, unlike European citizens, unlike European SMEs, evade tax by playing with tax competition between states. So, chick! Let us dare own resources, starting with this potential of a tax on multinationals at European level. Thus, we would not add a budgetary crisis to the other European crises.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this budget is a reflection of the current state of this European Union: a project that is stranded in a sea of uncertainty and lack of mutual trust, which retracts countries from contributing to their budget. This budget, short for such ambition, will only fuel the disillusionment of those who still believe in this European project.  We welcome the efforts to build the best possible budget within the narrow limits determined by the refusal of the main countries to contribute to strengthen it. We do not, however, feed into a project that focuses everything on supply-side measures and believes that investment will fall from the sky through a credible strategic investment fund, which will only strengthen public-private partnerships and the concentration of investment in the wealthiest regions.  It should also be recalled that many of the hottest issues discussed in this budget, such as support for farmers and refugees, stem from the wrong policies, which characterise this European Union in a crisis of values.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, I believe that today, rightly and objectively, everyone is paying tribute to the two fellow rapporteurs, José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez, for actually doing a great and important job with an excellent job, trying to serve the objectives of the European Union; the objectives of the Member States of the European Union of citizens, society, the economy and business. They fought with vigour and tried with great perseverance to overcome all obstacles, even facing some who we expected would be allies in this effort, who used us to be rich and generous in big words. It is the European Council, which has ultimately proved to be very poor in operations, has proved too poor in sensitivity to serve the objectives of the European Union.  I find it truly incredible that we are trying through the budget to serve the refugee crisis, to create new jobs, to create competitiveness, to support small and medium-sized enterprises, to create growth, progress and perspective, and for the Council to stand up to us. I think it is really incredible to try to get the European Union out of the crisis and in this effort not to be all united and not to fight all of us.  And one very important thing: If we have anything else to deal with in the European Union today, it is bureaucracy. I take advantage of the presence of the Vice-President to tell her that bureaucracy, which costs tens of millions, must be stepped down, and we must know that what we are voting for today does not go to business and to the citizens, because a lot of it goes to bureaucracy, and I will be the happiest of MEPs if next year we come here and have achieved more jobs. , more small and medium-sized enterprises to open up and less red tape. These are our objectives and these objectives have served and served both dear rapporteurs.

name: Siegfried Mureşan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last year when we were adopting the budget of the Union for 2015 we believed that we had a budget which addressed the priorities of the Union for this year and the challenges we believed we would face. Arguably we could not anticipate the dimension of the refugee crisis, but this year has proved to us that the budget as we had configured it for 2015 was not suitable to tackle these challenges, as proved by the two draft amending budgets in this field alone. Therefore, the Council has to understand that insufficient funding of the Union in certain areas poses risks to the Union and leaves it exposed, as was shown in the summer of this year. This is why we cannot understand and should not accept that on the one hand the Council calls for more action in order to tackle the refugee crisis and its causes, while on the other proposing cuts of EUR 50 million for action to reduce poverty in the Mediterranean countries. The Council will tell us that the appropriations in this heading are higher than last year’s budget, but the demand for action and funding is also much higher because conditions have worsened in the Union’s neighbourhood over the past year. These are the double standards which the Council has been imposing in recent years and which have led to a huge payment backlog which has even affected highly successful EU programmes like Erasmus. We at Parliament are committed to playing our role with responsibility in tomorrow’s vote and ensuring that the Union receives a budget which enables it to tackle the current challenges and those of next year.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, here we are again. This is only my second year of dealing with the annual budget, but already it feels alarmingly familiar. However, while the dance moves are the same, the music has changed considerably. In the last year we have seen the establishment of the investment plan, a welcome recognition of the fact that to build growth in our economies we need to invest. Unfortunately, the Commission chose to finance this plan for growth from the part of the budget that is dedicated to building growth. It demonstrated clearly that the straightjacket of the MFF as it stands is not fit for the challenges that we now face. Nowhere is this more obvious than with the refugee crisis. Both of these dramatic developments in the last year are areas where we are clearly stronger when we work together. But they also show the MFF severely limits effective action. I therefore ask for work to be done on areas not just for the 2016 budget but also for an imaginative and ambitious agenda for the MFF mid-term review.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – A week ago, the Council called on the European Parliament to make realism in adopting the European Union budget for 2016.  The proposed amendments are a very realistic response to the problems we face in the European Union, such as refugees, unemployment and growing disparities between members. In order for Member States along the Balkan route to be able to cooperate and protect one of the fundamental acquisitions of the European Union, Schengen and the free movement of people, they therefore need resources. It is true, however, that there is a great deal of room for manoeuvre in the use of funds for their more efficient and efficient use.  Tomorrow, there will be a debate in this Chamber on access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises. The European Commission's report on the business of SMEs finds that access to finance remains a major obstacle for SMEs, despite a number of activities and initiatives to improve.  At such and similar points, the public money we desperately need is being lost, and that is why budget debates are repeatedly a battle. Things that don't work need to be changed, so much needed resources will be released. I am therefore pleased that the Commission will pay greater attention to impact assessments and legislation evaluations. Well, at least that's what she announced in her May agenda for better regulation.

name: Inese Vaidere (PPE).
text: – Dear colleagues, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. First of all, thank you to Mr Fernandes and Mr Deré for their hard work on drafting the budget. It is generally focused on development and employment promotion, so almost half of the funding is for investment and job creation. I am also pleased that 500 million are allocated to dairy producers. Migration problems require a great deal of additional funding. However, it is unacceptable that they should be financed at the expense of existing programmes. Russia's hostilities in Ukraine, the intrusion into the airspace of the Baltic States and Finland, the massive influx of refugees and migrants through the Mediterranean make it clear how important well-protected external borders are. It is therefore necessary for all Member States to strengthen them jointly by providing appropriate resources in the budget. It is to be welcomed to increase the resources for foreign policy to be used to address the causes of migration: conflicts in third countries. Under cohesion policy, it is essential to continue to finance projects for science, research, reducing youth unemployment and developing entrepreneurship at least to the existing extent. At the same time, we need to think about saving money in the future. Firstly, by reducing the cost of red tape in the European institutions, and secondly by finally reaching an agreement on one seat of the European Parliament. Thank you!

name: Petri Sarvamaa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, with the EU budget we cannot change the way the world turns. We cannot change that. We can, however, give a signal and do some political steering, and we are giving those signals. Our priorities are there: job creation, SMEs, reinforcing competitiveness, innovation, more money for Horizon 2020 and COSME and we want to keep the youth employment initiative. For me it is also very important that we do not forget those who put the bread in our mouths. And I mean literally put the bread in our mouths. The EUR 500 million to alleviate suffering in the farm sector as a result of the Russian counter-sanctions is not performance-based budgeting, it is necessity-based budgeting. But the world actually did turn around. In respect of the wave of migration, we cannot accept Member States fiddling with the way they are supposed to deal with the matter. We need internal solidarity and we need external solidarity.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Our role as institutions must be this: to turn this 150 billion budget not just into reported balance sheets, but into visible and concrete investments. Comparing this draft budget with some previous ones, I must say that it is significantly better for several reasons. One of them is that we have fewer priorities, but bigger ones. The second is that we base the budget not on some imaginary achievement, but on concrete results, so that we have something to show people from the outside.  Last but not least, we need very strong communication with the people outside so that they understand that we have gathered here not just to show one number or another, but to report as many projects as possible with as many visible results as possible.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate my colleagues in the Committee on Budgets on this project, which responds to the priorities of European citizens. We are talking about funds for job creation for young people, we are talking about funds for SMEs, funds for farmers, funds for cohesion policy or even funds for coherent foreign policy action. Unfortunately, the Council seems to be fighting these projects for citizens. Critically, therefore, the public position expressed by the Council, which has spoken and still does not understand that only together can we fight against the challenges we face. MEPs' initiatives are citizens' initiatives, and I stress again here, for example, the important role of pilot projects and preparatory actions initiated by the European Parliament. I am proud, for example, of the five pilot projects proposed this year, worth EUR 5.3 million, which help Europe's industry and digital sector, and which will generate taxes that will help European citizens and, at its height, even the Council.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Many important projects have been mentioned here today. But when we talk today about the 2016 budget, it is also about the European Parliament's budget. One point: the cost of our travelling circus and the expensive second place of work in Brussels. Yes, you are right to hear that Brussels is costing us dearly, not Strasbourg. I therefore call for a single seat in Strasbourg. I call for an immediate halt to the wave plan for the multi-million dollar refurbishment of the dilapidated PHS building. We are talking about a construction period of three years. We are talking about investments of up to EUR 400 million. We are talking about renting 700 offices in Brussels for the period. We are talking about the madness of a provisional Chamber. I do not know who in the House is thinking about such erroneous plans.  But quite honestly: investments of up to EUR 1 billion to renovate two buildings that have already been completely dilapidated after twenty years over the next four years. You cannot explain this to any citizen, not to a taxpayer. We have a good functioning building in Strasbourg. We have a house with a European spirit and soul. Let us now opt for the single seat of Strasbourg.  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, when, a year ago, when we spoke of trust in the Commission and what the Commission needs to do, I was absolutely convinced that the only recovery of the European economy, large investments in SMEs, the Juncker Fund and all that constitutes tackling unemployment are what will determine the future of the Commission and determine the future and success of our parliament. However, the migrant crisis has broken out and that is why I want to be absolutely clear. Today, the migrant crisis is questioning Europe. This was also said by the Slovenian Prime Minister, who is deeply European, but is aware of the fact that european citizens react very differently to the migrant crisis.  That is why I ask the European Commission to take into account most seriously the need to finance everything that is happening around migrants, both in member states and non-member countries, i.e. in the Countries of the Western Balkans.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE).
