text: – The composition of the budget is always a very demanding project that can never satisfy everyone. And even when I read this draft budget and, of course, again have a tendency to cut funding, especially in some areas, including horizon 2020, and when I see that we are still on the various banks between the Council and Parliament in terms of the amount of individual funds, I naturally ask myself who really sets the priorities for financial cutting. Of course, I would have touched on something else that my colleague Jakovcic also warned. Of course, the main priority now is how to resolve the issue of the refugee crisis, and I think that is the European Commission's top priority, and therefore also how to act, how to help the Member States most affected, how to channel resources there, to actually dam, to get to Europe in the first place.  And one more thing: if we do not do so today, the price will be much, much higher in the future.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, in the same play viewers once again. Because last year we also saw a budget which was an austerity budget and this year there are crumbs available for the European Union and its budget, EUR 153 billion. The amount of the aid was EUR 1 million only I'm sorry. At a time when EUR 1.1 trillion is being allocated to Mr. Draghi for the famous quantitative easing. But with these crumbs is it possible for the European Union to face the great challenges? It is possible to provide for only EUR 500 million for the period 2000-2006. In order to compensate all farmers in the European Union for the damage caused by the Russian embargo? Only the losses of Greek farmers are not enough to cover this amount.  With these small amounts is it possible to tackle the challenge of employment? We need investment by creating jobs for our own young people, at a time when there is huge unemployment, at a time when we also need funds for refugees.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I support the greater transparency in the general expenditure allowance and the roadmap towards a single seat for Parliament. I also support the fact that the Commission’s draft budget has mostly been restored, thus rejecting the cuts by the Council with some adjustments to take into account the specific needs of the institutions. We must also take into consideration that the migration crisis has proved that the European Union does not have the necessary crisis management tools. The inadequate response of the European Union showed us that we also have to build its hard power of the European Union. The budget must contain sufficient funds to set up security structures to improve the capacity of the European Union to respond to such crises.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Fernández and Mr Deprez for the work they have done and will continue to do. In closing, I would like to make four short remarks.  One: the debate today has shown that there is indeed a lot of demand for the European budget and there is pressure on the European budget to deliver on multiple objectives. Many of you have said that what this means is that we have to work together, the three institutions, to prioritise and make sure that funding goes where it is most needed. From the perspective of the Commission, we have been working over the last year to execute our budget best to manage the money we have in the best possible way and then, when we hit a wall – when we run out of money – to look for any possible flexibility we have to meet a demand.  We have always been guided by what you, the Parliament, the Council, and our citizens, are saying – what they expect from us. They expect us to help our economy. They expect from us to deal with crisis when it hits, and let us remember that we now have the refugee crisis, before that it was the Greek crisis, and before that we had nature hitting us very hard, as some of you have mentioned. To deal with long—term development for the Union, and at the same time be agile, be able to respond, is what we have tried to get better at. That takes me to my second point, because we will need it. I do not know what the next crisis is going to be, but I know it will hit us because the world we live in is a fast moving world, and it is shock—prone. Shocks that come for economic reasons and shocks that come because of climate change and conflict. External problems then turn into internal ones and we have to have space in our budget to be able to respond. My third point is on the significance, as we work on this annual budget, of also looking ahead. Looking ahead brings the very important subject of own resources. We will have a report coming: it will be in 2016, when there will be a debate on this topic, and will fit into our next multiannual financial perspective and will be part of our discussion on the mid-term review.  This is my fourth and last point: many of you brought up the mid-term review. Yes, it will be a moment in time when we can seriously address the new challenges in front of us, what we collectively can do, but we will be faced with questions of the kind ‘what is to give’, because when we are faced with new challenges we have to recognise that the resources we have are never going to be unlimited. At the point in time of the mid-term review, we have to be guided by how we can get the best value for the money our citizens are trusting us with, in a changing world where new priorities also have to be integrated. We have our work cut out for us, and I am very much looking forward to the days and nights that are coming ahead for Parliament, the Council and the Commission to come up with the best possible judgement, the best possible budget for 2016.

name: Pierre Gramegna
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, first of all, I would like to say that I have listened very carefully to all the speeches and that I will, of course, bring back the essence of your debates here in the European Parliament to my colleagues in the Council. I think we actually have three anchors around which we can work. The first is the Council's position, the second is the position of the European Parliament, and the third, of course, is the Commission's amending letter No. 2, which takes into account the necessary reinforcements of appropriations for the refugee issue.  It is around these three axes that we will have to find a compromise. I am hopeful that we can achieve this through three principles - and I agree with Commissioner Georgieva here. The first is that we have to set priorities. Not everything can be given priority at the same time and to the same degree. With prioritization, we will find a solution.  The second, the Commission has shown us in its amending letter, is that we need to redeploy and make the best use of the flexibilities we have. This will indeed allow us to find compromises.  Third and final point, we need to have some leeway for the unforeseen events of next year. We cannot use all the resources available in the compromise that we will hopefully find together. For my part, I would like to thank the two rapporteurs, José Manuel Fernandes and Gérard Deprez, as well as President Jean Arthuis, with whom I have been able to build a relationship of trust over the past few weeks and months. I congratulate them on their enthusiasm and look forward to working with them in a spirit of loyal cooperation that we have begun and which will certainly be useful to us.  I welcome and congratulate Mrs Georgieva on what she has already done, and we will indeed spend days and nights together, and I can assure you that the Luxembourg Presidency will do so with enthusiasm and rigour.

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, allow me to thank all the rapporteurs who have worked with me on this budget, a special hug for Gérard Deprez, all the coordinators, also all the councillors, to the secretariat.  Give some information to the Presidency of the Council. First, when we adopted this budget, the Commission's amending letter was not yet adopted and was not known. Secondly, even after we have adopted the budget and learned of the amending letter no 2, we have learned that it is in line with our claims in the area of the refugee crisis, but also in the area of support for farmers and against the EUR 500 million with which we want to strengthen this support for farmers, contrary to what the Council Presidency said.  Another information which is a memory revival: when we approve efsi, when we approve the Juncker Plan, we always said that funding for the guarantee was temporary with regard to withdrawing money from Horizon 2020 and the European Connecting Europe mechanism. Don't confuse, we didn't reverse, we defended the Juncker Plan (I myself was rapporteur for the Juncker Plan). What we also advocate is that the commitments that have been made to the beneficiaries under the Multiannual Financial Framework for Horizon 2020 are respected.  Summarise our priorities which are very clear, less for the Presidency of the Council. Employment, but this means the competitiveness of the European Union, but for this we need to support small and medium-sized enterprises, reduce bureaucracy and, by the way, I have come to a conclusion. Neither the Commission nor the Council are available to put a euro in the next 2016 budget so that the Youth Employment Initiative can continue. It is a bad sign that they give young people in the European Union that they need this initiative, even if recast, to continue and in 2016 we will continue to hit us for commitment appropriations for this goal. For our part, there will be every willingness to continue to have the job and the refugee crisis as priorities. I welcome what has been said today by the President of our European Commission, which we have written in several resolutions: for extraordinary situations, we need extraordinary money. What they call redeployment, which they call redeployments, means cutting priorities and we cannot accept that refugees are used to cut policies that are important, nor can we place that responsibility on them. And, as I have always said, refugees are victims, are not guilty and therefore for them are necessary sufficient means and exceptional and additional amounts for that purpose.

name: Gérard Deprez
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Mr President of the Council, Commissioner, let me first of all, because I did not have time to do so in my first speech, to thank all those who helped us, who helped me to make this report and to present the budget for the other institutions: my colleague José Fernandes, my colleagues, my colleagues and the secretariat of the Committee on Budgets , which has done a remarkable job. For the rest, on the basis of the debate we have had, I draw the conclusion, perhaps premature, perhaps optimistic, that the proposals I have made with regard to Parliament's budget and other institutions will not be opposed. So I am optimistic about tomorrow's vote.  However, if there is no opposition on this side, we will be able to devote all our energy to what is essential, that is to say to what our colleague José Fernandes has just reminded us: the refugee crisis, of course, which we must treat both with lucidity and humanism, but also with their economic redeployment and the revival of growth. The less growth we have, the less creative our businesses will be, the more our small and medium-sized enterprises will be hindered, the less we will have the means to allocate them to some of our priorities, including the refugee crisis. Less growth means the loads will be heavier tomorrow.  Mr President of the Council, do not believe that some of the priorities we have set in this budget are priorities for form: we will defend them with total energy.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday 28 October at 12.00 p.m. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. We will vote on the EU budget for 2016 which gives the European Union the means to act. To this end, we have enhanced the objectives originally proposed by the Commission in various areas. An additional EUR 1.16 billion has been added to meet the needs of member states managing the largest refugee influx and half a billion for contracts under new programmes to help unemployed young people. Other sectors have received particular attention: agriculture is particularly helped in the wake of the impact of the Russian embargo on milk prices, as is the European research programme Horizon 2020.  Member States must now not block the will to work together. However, I voted against paragraph 77 of this text, which was only intended to remove the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Israel and Palestine.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. – Mr President, I apologise for being a little late but I was sharing our common work with the Chairs of the delegations; here is one, I was faster than him. The last time we met here in this chamber to discuss our common work on the Middle East Peace Process and Israel and Palestine was only six weeks ago. Back then we all agreed on something: that the stalemate in the peace process – indeed the lack of a peace process – could only lead to more violence, and this is what we are seeing today. It has happened time and again and it has been happening in dramatic ways in recent weeks. The new wave of violence and terror is affecting innocent Israelis and Palestinians. There is not, and there cannot be, any excuse for terror. Incitement and violence must end. The response of security forces needs to be proportionate and consistent, regardless of who is the perpetrator. It is now mostly up to the political leaders on the two sides to get out of the current impasse and to show leadership, most of all to show leadership. Showing leadership is much more difficult when the situation gets more difficult, but this is also when it is most needed. Both leaderships have a responsibility to contain the violence and to promote calm. They have an interest in doing this for their own people and they have a general responsibility towards the region and the rest of the word to make sure that the situation does not inflame on the religious level and spread across the globe. Last week I met with Prime Minister Netanyahu. I met President Abbas in Brussels just yesterday evening to pass on exactly the same message. You need to take leadership, strong positions and first and foremost to try to calm the situation on the ground. And the international community is and will be with you in this respect. They acknowledged that they need to work together in partnership to end the current unrest. And this is something relevant, but also something that needs to be tested for real. Obviously our thoughts today and in these days are with all the victims, with all the families, with all the people that are suffering on the ground. But as we try to de-escalate the crisis we must not lose sight of the underlying causes of tensions, the frustrations, the sense of insecurity, the lack of hope and the lack of a political horizon. Without that political horizon any de-escalation that we might even achieve – as difficult as that may be – will only last for a limited time, and we will go back again and again to the cycle of violence. We said this last year at the end of the conflict in Gaza. We are here one year later saying the same thing. Our first priority must be to build the conditions for final status talks based on mutual steps. For this to happen we need significant policy shifts on the ground. We need this policy shift to happen in line with previous agreements that need to start being implemented. We have to find an entry point to the process for it to start again. By this we mean not only restarting the political process, restarting the talks, restarting negotiations. We, the Israelis and the Palestinian people all know very well that talks for the sake of talks, negotiations for the sake of negotiations, would not bring anything real on the ground unless we create real conditions for the people, firstly, to live and, secondly, to live better, their respective lives. When we talk about this we mean concrete steps in the context of a political process: de-escalating the security aspect, ending violence, implementing concrete steps on the ground in line with prior agreements and creating the conditions for the political horizon. These are three elements we need to work on in parallel with the support of the international community. We mean measures that help the Palestinians take control over their lives and uphold Israel’s security, not just negotiating, not just for the sake of doing something, but to reach concrete results. These goals must be pursued in parallel: de-escalation on the ground, concrete steps to implement agreements that have already been signed and keeping the perspective of the political horizon of the final settlement. These three elements must go together, this is more urgent than ever. In New York last month and in Vienna last Friday the Quartet’s principles articulated this message loud and clear. It was the European Union’s choice to use the Quartet as a format for the international backing of these efforts. From this recent round of meetings, including with Secretary of State Kerry in Berlin, I retain the commitment of Prime Minister Netanyahu to guarantee the status quo in the holy sites and the desire of all parties to de-escalate the situation on the ground. I also welcome and support Secretary of State Kerry’s initiative to address the situation in the holy sites highlighting the role of Jordan in this, which is key. In the next few weeks the Quartet envoys will engage directly with the parties. It is now up to the Israeli and the Palestinian leadership to demonstrate, with acts, that their commitment to the two-state solution is real and not fake, not just a slogan. If Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas now fail to work together, if they do not cooperate to stop the violence, if they do not rebuild a credible political process, the situation will only get worse for their own people. The regional context is as tense as it could be, even if this is a sentence we should never say because it could always turn worse. We do not want to see an old conflict such as this one mix with a newer crisis in the neighbouring countries. The conditions around Israel and Palestine are today much, much more dangerous than they were decades ago. This is a risky time, for the people in Israel and in Palestine alike. And if the leaderships do not understand that now is not ‘business as usual’ in terms of managing this long-established conflict in the way we are all used to – although we never have never got used to a conflict that brings so much death and suffering – and realise that now it more urgent than ever to solve it, then there would be little that the international community could do to support a process. And the mix of old and new, of history and religious elements, at this moment in the region would be explosive, not only for the people involved but for all of us. Peace between the Israelis and the Palestinians is in the interest of all of us, in the region and beyond. It is for this reason that we invited – again on a European initiative – key Arab countries to join our Quartet meetings. Think of how relevant Egypt can be for Gaza and Jordan for the holy places – something we are seeing every day – and Saudi Arabia for relaunching the Arab peace initiative and adapting it to today’s world. Only in a renewed regional framework is peace possible. The Arab partners have stressed to me their readiness to work with the Quartet in the coming months. We have already started to work together with them but, like us, they need to see determined leadership by the parties. We can build all the international and regional support imaginable, but they first have to take responsibility for showing leadership in their own societies and communities.  Recent events should serve as a warning. If anyone still believes that we can just manage the current crisis, contain it a little bit and wait for the next one, they are wrong. This is not going to continue like this. Every cycle of violence is going to be worse than the previous one, and this will destroy the Middle East. So now is decision time. Israeli and Palestinian leaders will have to take a courageous, difficult choice, but this is the only path they have towards peace. They can either move forward or watch cowards prevail in their own societies. This is the message we have been passing on – I have been passing on personally – to the two leaders together with my Quartet colleagues and with my Arab friends. This is the line on which we are all committed to work. I have asked both Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas to receive the Quartet envoys in the coming days – not weeks – to start working together on concrete steps that can immediately be taken on the ground to de-escalate on one side and to improve the living conditions of the people. We have to find this entry point because in respect of talks, the big horizon today, I do not see the conditions internally in the two societies to allow the leaderships to invest credibly in this at a time when the security situation as it is and while confidence still needs to be built. First and foremost we need to find this entry point, making sure that at the end of the process the two-state solution is preserved and not pre-judged. We have to help them start implementing issues on the ground that can deliver for the ordinary people on both sides who today are seeing their children dying, albeit in different numbers, so that they can start having a future in their lands.

name: n/a
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Madam High Representative, I would like to begin by congratulating you on your personal commitment to this issue. Your messages today are very clear, although we would like to have more good news.  That said, the strength of your messages is pragmatism and realism. As you pointed out, the recent acts of violence and tensions, they should be seen in a different light, and perhaps not only to say that this prevents the resumption of negotiations, but rather as an opportunity to engage both sides more in favour of the people. Similarly, internal divisions and extremist views on both sides cannot be cited as obstacles to concrete progress.  But I think that today it is equally important to stress that the leaders of each side must show their will for peace, not only in the face of the international community, but also in their internal discourses by committing citizens to a peaceful two-state solution.  On the other hand, you cautioned us that if the Israeli or internal Palestinian national context does not seem favourable, we must look very carefully at what is happening in the regional context. But again, there may be opportunities here. On the one hand, we have the commitment of Arab countries in the fight against terrorism, on the other hand, we recently had the nuclear agreement with Iran.  Perhaps the question is whether there are possible levers for reviving peace negotiations. Moreover, the Quartet recently highlighted Jordan's role, as you said. But let us also think of the Arab peace initiative, launched in 2002, and what could result from it.  I would therefore like, once again, to thank you and, in conclusion, to say that you can be assured of the full support of this House for all your action on this issue.

name: Gianni Pittella
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, unfortunately, the conflict between Israel and Palestine is burning, burning again and again. And until a solution is found, the Middle East will be like a crooked tree, undermined by the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The violence of recent weeks speaks to us of a lost Palestinian generation, born after Oslo, which has never known the hope of peace. The Role of the Union is to revive this hope. And so we do not need rhetoric: we need action.  We agree with your strategy, Mrs Mogherini. You're doing a wise and valuable job. It is right, as you are doing, to focus on two objectives. Firstly, de-escalation on the ground. Secondly, the resumption of political initiative. Of course, the agreement of these hours on the preservation of the status quo on the esplanade of mosques in Jerusalem is a positive step. We cannot lose Jerusalem. I would also like to point out two cornerstones for the resumption of political initiative. Firstly, Europe, Israel and Palestine now have a common enemy, extremist violence. Which, be ware, coincides not only with Isis, but also with the hate practices of the most extreme wings, Palestinian and Israeli. Secondly, we need two states, an Israeli state and a sovereign Palestine, to meet along the 1967 borders with land exchanges and with Jerusalem, the capital of both states.  But if we want to save Israel and Palestine from war, we must first of all save them from themselves, or rather from their worst forces, from those who work as they worked in the mythical Odyssey Penelope, Ulysses' wife, who, in order to avoid a new marriage, waiting for her husband, unraed the canvas she built during the day. There are forces, in Israel and Palestine, that destroy what is being painstakingly built, and when it almost seems to touch the result, the goal of peace, those forces re-emerge and prevent the goal from being achieved. Israel and the European Union concluded an association agreement in 2000, which covers not only material aspects, but in which both sides have committed themselves to respect for human rights and democracy. The European Union must guarantee this commitment and remind all parties of their historic task: to turn the enemy into a sodal, the fanatic into a moderate, the avenger into a friend.  (The rapporteur agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – It may have been an error of translation but it appeared to come through my earphones that just then you made a comparison between Israel and ISIS. It appeared that you compared a beacon of democracy in the Middle East, which is under constant attack, to a barbaric terrorist organisation. If you did not do that could you please clarify, because I am sure you would not want to compare two things which are totally different?

name: Gianni Pittella (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I have no difficulty, my dear colleague, I read the part I have written, so there can be no misunderstanding. Europe, Israel and Palestine now have a common enemy: ISIS, and not only ISIS, but also the most extreme fringes, both Palestinian and Israeli. So Israel is one thing and ISIS is the enemy of Israel, the enemy of Palestine and the enemy of all of us.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. "The rise of radicalism in the Islamic world is a threat to us, but even more so to the inhabitants of cities such as Hebron and Jerusalem. The Iran agreement – the nuclear agreement – was for Israel what i used to reset relations with Russia for my region. Nevertheless, while recognising the need to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, both the international community (quartet) and Prime Minister Netanyahu are making numerous gestures. This agreement must also be welcomed by Palestine, President Abbas. It is necessary to bring both sides to a common table and to understand that, in such a difficult situation of increasing threat, an agreement may be possible for the benefit of the international community and both countries.

name: n/a
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam High Representative, let me start by thanking you wholeheartedly for your excellent efforts and your motivation in this matter. Since we met in September, the situation has only gotten more desperate. We disapprove of the violence from all sides but understand very well where the latest eruptions come from. The religious agreements on the Temple Mount must be respected again. Where does the European Union actually stand? We know that you are actively talking to the leaders, that points of stability have been found. You sat with the members of the Quartet and I am pleased to see that there is agreement between the European Union and the other countries. But ALDE believes it's time to take more initiative on both usual bilateral contacts. That is why we have written to you, together with a number of colleagues and also our group leader, calling on you to develop a genuine peace initiative. What we liberals would like to see is that you encourage the members of the Quartet to join in the push for this European peace initiative. We want you to bring the parties together and to go beyond the usual shuttle diplomacy where no one feels like making real concessions. When President Abbas states that the Oslo Accords are dead, breathe new life into them and take them to the next level. Palestinian and Israeli citizens want nothing more than a prospect of peace, with opportunities for their children. The European Parliament, Madam High Representative, is standing by you. We have demonstrated this with the resolution. Use your influence, use the credit you have built up in the short term, to decorate a "Mogherini deal" after the Oslo Accords. You have our support.

name: Martina Anderson
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, whilst I welcome any initiative to try to bring peace and stability to the region, the recent joint Israeli and Jordanian proposal will not solve the underlying issues. Nor will it result in a lowering of the tension on the ground. Placing recording devices around the Al-Aqsa Mosque will not assist in creating a shared peaceful Jerusalem, neither will they address the incredible rise in settlers’ violence or the ongoing occupation of the West Bank in the seas of Gaza.  We must not allow Israel to divert attention away from its ongoing breaches of international humanitarian law by turning this into a religious conflict. That is what restricting access to the Al-Aqsa Mosque is designed to do. Placing Palestine under international protection is a necessary first step towards lowering tension and ultimately peace.  Ms Mogherini, the international community must also demonstrate our commitment with action, because talk with talk is simply a lot of waffle, and it will help neither the Palestinian people nor the Israelis.

name: Margrete Auken
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to address the High Representative. I am sure that this conflict is in your core address and you have issued a lot of statements again but, again as I heard it now, you are treating the two partners as they are equal. You do not mention the word occupation with one single word. If we do not address the occupation, nothing will happen and the credibility of this House and the EU Institutions will vanish. Since you have been appointed the situation on the ground has gone from very bad to worse, and it can get even worse. I do not hold you responsible for the decade—long violence on the ground, but I do hold you accountable for not taking the tangible and meaningful steps within your reach. Why have you further delayed the publication of the EU guidelines on the labelling of products for the settlers? Why have you not taken any visible actions in response to the destruction of EU and Member State-funded projects in Area C? Which steps have you taken to create a blacklist of violent settlers and ban their entry – a measure that has been raised by many Member States many times in recent years? Why have we not heard any public statement from your side regarding Israel’s blacklisting of an entire institution, this Parliament, for granting access to the poor people in Gaza? There is a whole range of actions that could be taken by Brussels and yourself immediately and independently from ongoing negotiations. I urge you to now address this occupation.  Let me, last but not least, mention a strong and efficient step to take within EU existing legislation: a consequent differentiation between Israel and the illegal settlements where we cut all collaboration with settlers and settlements. This differentiation is not a boycott; it is a legal means which could boost real credible negotiations.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the third intifada or very severe escalation: little changes in a reality of death and blood on the streets. A reality in which dialogue and the negotiation process disappear from the table, overwhelmed by the extremist rhetoric of Hamas, on the one hand, and Netanyahu's Zionism, on the other, ready for extraordinary measures, also condemned by Ban Ki-Moon, against the people of East Jerusalem.  Perhaps it is the point of no return to a situation that is already difficult to recover. Those who preach a return to the status quo, such as Kerry, may not realise that they are confusing an unlikely solution with the certain cause of the problem, because between January and September already 26 Palestinians have died. You said so before, High Representative, 'no more business as usual'. I am convinced that you are sparing no effort in the laborious work of silent diplomacy, but I am equally convinced that it is time to take a strong and clear public position, even less equidistant, when necessary.  We are israel's first trading partner, an occupying power with great responsibilities. We are also the main donor to Palestine: we can, indeed must, make a difference. Let us take the initiative as the European Union with a mission to peace and protect civilians in the occupied territories, authorised by the UN and under European command. All those who believe in peace will give us credit for it. The 5 Star Movement proposes it to you; it will not be an easy road, but it will perhaps be the beginning of the right path.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too believe that much more incisive and also spectacular action is needed on the part of this European Union, which – the High Representative does not want it – takes home results that are, I would say, not very visible, not very concrete. An example of all: behind this intifada of stab wounds, there is incredible religious hatred on both sides: and what has been done to involve religious leaders?  History teaches us that coexistence in Palestine between Jews and Muslims in holy places has been possible for centuries, and then it is precisely from there that we must start. I have the impression that we are not following the right paths, that we are not making those who can impose different choices on these desperate people. You keep talking about the two-state solution, but are you really convinced, or is it your hypocrisy that makes you believe that the two leaders really believe in the two-state solution? I believe that we must find much more incisive and much more decisive ways. We are demonstrating once again that Europe does not see reality, and reality is very dangerous and opens the way to extreme and dangerous solutions for everyone and therefore also for us.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, it has been my long-held belief that we must respect Israel’s sovereign right to defend its borders and people from terrorism. It is also essential that we are mindful of the pain and suffering felt by those in Gaza. As a consequence, we must do all that we can to help bring stability and a lasting peace to the region. Yet what we have seen in recent weeks has been an upsurge in the number of senseless knife attacks carried out indiscriminately by Palestinians. That some as young as 16 years of age are involved in such attacks is deeply worrying for the future of the region. While we must remain an independent arbiter in this conflict, it is essential that the quest for balance does not equate with appeasement or inaction. We must stand with those committed to democratic principles and tackle the inherent incitement to violence so engrained in the region. Next week marks 20 years since the assassination of former Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, who notably once said ‘Yes to peace, no to violence’. Two decades on, his words ring more true than ever. Let us stand with those who want peace, and let us ensure that our actions give neither credence nor comfort to those engaged in violence.

name: n/a
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, less than two months ago we debated here and adopted an in-depth text on the union's role in the Middle East peace process and today we return to this debate and come back to it for a very simple reason: because there is this wave of violence.  It must be said that in the current context of the Middle East, which has been plagued by growing tensions and conflicts in the vicinity of Israel, this recent violence only increases the instability of the region. It is for this reason that I call on the Palestinian leadership to stop this incitement to violence and to publicly oppose extremism and the various acts perpetrated against the Israeli side; otherwise, we will not break out of the vicious circle of hatred and division.  I would also add that the resumption of direct dialogue is essential, because we need a political solution and we cannot accept what Mahmoud Abbas has been saying for months and months: that he is too tired to enter into this dialogue. It must be made very clear that the solution is political.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, last time when discussing the perspective of the peace process and the role of the EU we were showing full, unconditional support for your action. Now, when discussing the crisis, the two sides in Israel are only numbering the deaths and wounded people in their camps. We are, of course, highly concerned about the new wave of escalation somehow precipitated between the Israelis and Palestinians over the past weeks. The criminal actions and the retaliations not only bring additional affliction to the population, but they are endangering the peace process. The only conclusion to the stabbings, car rammings and shooting attacks is that the reality on the ground is not viable today. Violence always leads to more violence. Only positive steps, cooperation and concrete engagement on the ground could bring security improvements and reassurance for the population on both sides. Therefore I welcome your recent efforts, including cooperation with the US Secretary of State, John Kerry, and the role of some EU foreign ministers and a very united and effective Quartet Principles’ meeting in Vienna, which shows the need to speak united, to speak in a single voice, in order to be relevant for the two sides. And equally we reiterate, together with you, that the two leaders have to show responsibility, to show restraint in leadership, to contain the rhetoric that could easily inflame the situation not only on the ground, but also in the whole region. The security situation on the ground is different today, and it is much more dangerous than ever before if the conflict will still remain unaddressed, unresolved. We continue to support a two-state solution that must guarantee full respect for the dignity of the individuals on both sides and the rights of ethnic and religious minorities as equal citizens in their countries in both states. Without negotiations there is no solution; without solution there will be no peace and the violations will only continue.  One final call on the Palestinian friends: please stop your divisions and please start building your legitimate leadership to be our interlocutor. For peace and talks and negotiations we need interlocutors on both sides.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR).
text: – Madam President, let us be clear here that the lone-wolf attacks being committed by Palestinians against Israeli soldiers and civilians are terrorist attacks. We must uphold the right of Israel to defend itself against such attacks and the rights of Israel in respect of the fact that the perpetrators are responsible for them, and not in any way able to claim this is a legitimate attack on innocent civilians. They are jihadi extremists espousing an ideology that is inspiring the actions of more, unfortunately.  As US Secretary Kerry speaks of the possibility of a third Intifada now and with the increasing exchange of rocket attacks within Israel and the West Bank, the situation is looking ever more fragile. De-escalating tensions is vital and the international community must reassert the need for a return to peace talks, particularly the Arab peace initiative put forward in 2002, as the best item on the table as we speak. So I commend the High Representative’s idea of inviting all sides to talks under the Middle East Quartet mandate. Furthermore, concluding the Middle East peace process with a viable two-state solution would be a huge step in defeating the poisonous ideology espoused by ISIS that is also ravaging the region.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE).
text: – Madam President; Mrs. Mogherini, overwhelm you into thinking that the problem is violence. Violence is just the symptom, the problem is occupation. Fifty years of occupation is not a normal situation. It is humiliation, it is exploitation, it is an impossible life for people who have grown up, born and continue to grow and be born in the occupation. After that, the oslo road is created, which is the way nowhere. Oslo's plan is now almost twenty-four years old and leads to no conclusion, because it means the impossible equation that the jailer is negotiating with his prisoner. If you look at the map of Palestine from '47, '67, the current one and after Oslo, you'll see that Palestine is progressively becoming nothing. And in the face of this, to think that the solution is to negotiate between the parties is not to realize that, after Oslo, colonization has doubled in the territories. This is reality, not politics or words. Therefore, in the face of an impossible bilateral negotiation, which the years have shown to be impossible, what the international community has to do is to take its responsibility and establish a definitive plan on two States that means the end of the occupation, with recognized and secure borders, on the parameters of 67, bearing in mind that the international community will have to accept the violation of the Fourth Geneva Convention , that is, colonization, and establishing a seemingly equivalent change of territories, that is, legalizing what already means a violation of international legality. But this is realism. As long as we do not establish strong action by the international community and the European Union, which is the main partner of the two, we will continue to talk every day about violence, which is to talk about nothing. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - You mentioned the reasons from 50 years ago. Obviously, there are people in this room who can list reasons going back 100, 200, 500, even 1,000 years. But why do you think, or what makes you think, that the High Representative would be responsible for these historical reasons? I think – and I hope you agree with me, and this is also my question, whether you agree with me – that we need to start now and come to the negotiating table now, not for either side to take a unilateral step in any direction.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE)
text: "blue card" response. – I am passionate about history, but I am much more passionate about the life of the present. And the life of the present means that anyone who imagines that living under occupation is a normal situation is that they think normal life means life under oppression. After fifty years of occupation and twenty-something years of Oslo' journey, which is the way nowhere, anyone with some experience will realize that the solution lies not in impossible negotiations between the parties, but that the international community determines the end of the occupation, which is the end of the humiliation. And this word, "humiliation-occupation," Barack Obama said at his Cairo conference four or five years ago.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, there is no serious outcome for the Palestinian and Israeli peoples without respect for international law. And this international law will only be respected if the European Union acts in concert with the United States and a number of Arab countries. We must stop making false symmetries. What violence are we talking about here? There's a colonizer and a colonizer there. There is a people there who have their state: the Israeli people. At the other, one refuses a state, steals land and water, humiliates it, demolishes its houses, imprisons it, builds a wall, bombs it as in Gaza. There will therefore be no peace if the occupation of Israeli settlements is not tackled.  The European Union must say this and act accordingly, i.e. suspend the association agreement and programmes involving Israeli companies, often military for that matter. Furthermore, You can, Madam High Representative, in the interests of both peoples, act to create an international protection force for the Palestinian people, under the aegis of the United Nations, which at the same time will provide security for the Israeli people. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation.))

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You raised a point calling for international action to be taken by the United States, by the European Union and by Arab states. Bearing in mind that many of those Arab states do not actually recognise the State of Israel, and you speak of security and confidence for the Israeli people as well, how can such action genuinely offer security and safety for the Israeli people? It is a huge contradiction.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, in any case, when you do not want to resolve an issue, you are using the arguments that you are using at the moment.  It is enough to bring together the United Nations Security Council and follow the vast majority of countries that have now decided to recognize the Palestinian state. On the other hand, what we are asking, and the European Union and the United States have the key to this problem by involving a number of Arab countries, which have done so in the past, in particular in Egypt, is to put ourselves around a table, to protect the Palestinian people, to recognize the State of Palestine and to begin decolonization. This is the condition of peace. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation.))

name: Javier Nart (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Le Hyaric, I wanted to ask you if you know the Saudi initiative of a few years ago, and an older one, which is the initiative of the Arab League, in which israel was proposed full and absolute recognition, the absolute normalization of all cultural, commercial, open borders, like any other country, simply if they fulfilled something so basic, that we are all asking , such as the withdrawal from the occupied territories.

name: Patrick Le Hyaric (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I have heard of these various initiatives, and I support them. Anything that will contribute to the recognition of the State of Palestine and contribute to the security of both peoples, to the creation of the State of Palestine within the 1967 borders, with the recognition of East Jerusalem as its capital, and not what is being done today, which is to create the conditions to remove Jerusalem from the future Palestinian state, all these initiatives, of course we support them.

name: Pascal Durand (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, you have condemned violence against civilians, wherever it comes from, and you were right to do so and we fully support you. Simply, this violence has a cause, and a root cause, and you have called for the responsibility of both parties and you have also been absolutely right to do so. But let's not get rid of our own responsibility.  As it stands, the root cause is the occupation of a territory and the denial of the fundamental rights of a people. This is the root cause of the violence. And the European Union has a privileged association agreement with the State of Israel. For no country on the planet, the European Union would not accept its funding to be used to colonize occupied territories or to research on weapons or drones.  So I solemnly ask you, High Representative: when will the European Union finally agree to revise this cooperation agreement with the State of Israel so that this occupation and development of settlements in the occupied territories can be put to an end?

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: – The hatred and murder of Palestinians against the Jewish people has re-emerged in recent weeks. Prime Minister Netanyahu rightly pointed to the historical continuity of this. This wave of murderousness has nothing to do with the disputed territories, nothing to do with settlement policy and nothing to do with the glorious role of the Temple Mount for the Jewish people. The Prime Minister rightly pointed to the evil ideology of the terrorist Muslim Brotherhood and of the muffti of Jerusalem, al-Husseini. The latter actively participated in the Armenian genocide, organized pogroms in Jerusalem and in 1941 pleaded with Adolf Hitler to exterminate all Jews in Europe. Anti-Semitism is one of the core values of Islam. Israel's modest response shows that it is a beacon of humanity in the beastly world of Islam. That is why the EU must stop any financial support for Palestinians. Israel deserves our unconditional support.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this month we are seeing a worrying increase in violence and tension in Jerusalem, which, in addition to a tragic death toll, increases the loss of trust between the parties. The peace process is in grave danger, totally paralyzed. The international community, again, has mobilized. Meetings, including those of the Security Council, that of the Quartet in Vienna, starring Secretary of State Kerry, have proliferated these days; and you, Mrs Mogherini, have recently, or very recently, met with Netanyahu and Mahmud Abbas. I welcome your efforts to try to restore calm, as you have told us, and security on the ground, as well as to gradually launch a new political process. Of course, there is no alternative to dialogue aimed at a negotiated political solution between the parties. Paralysis or blockage is not an option. It is not a question of managing, but, if possible, of resolving the conflict, and the parties must avoid any action that makes it impossible. But on the other hand, the experience of these years shows us that the parties alone are unable to achieve that goal. They need momentum from the international community and we will need this bilateral negotiation to be accompanied by an international architecture involving not only the consensus of the international community, but also the main players in the region. And, in this sense, the format of the extended Quartet will be the most appropriate formula to accompany that negotiation that makes possible a definitive agreement and the end of the conflict. But, of course, first of all—and you have said it—political will is needed; firstly, the parties, who have to realize that the current situation of blocking no one benefits and that, in short, more frustration, more violence must be avoided, in a region where what is left over are conflict and terror.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the High Representative has the Socialist and Democratic Group’s support when she calls for talks in days not months, and says that this is decision time and that there must be no fake commitment to a two–state solution.  On the religious layer to the conflict, it seems that the preservation of the status quo may have been saved. But is this not a further example of us diffusing yet another additional aspect to the conflict – new provocations, temporary solutions – making us part of the cycle of violence rather than our contributing to solving its underlying causes?  On the violence itself, Ms Mogherini is right to recognise that the different sides experience different numbers of deaths, but as I listen in my own despair to the despair which fuels the violence, when I hear the rapidity with which commentators talk about a third Intifada, I want to note today that this is not yet organised violence and if the international community puts the same rapidity into seeking solutions as to predictions of a third Intifada, perhaps that would do best to avert it.  Ms Mogherini, you were right to talk to us about Palestinians and Israelis respecting and implementing past agreements, but that has to go for Europeans too and I join with colleagues in welcoming the commitment you gave to the Committee on Foreign Affairs to finally publish the guidelines on labelling of produce from illegal settlements. Tonight I ask you to set a deadline for this to be completed. My group believes that refraining from doing so does not advance the prospects of talks, but doing so shows that the failure to advance the peace process has consequences from us too. Last week I talked with Muslim community representatives in my own region in the towns of Cambridge, Harlow and Luton and they told me once again what we should understand: the grievances are not only felt in Israel and Palestine. Deradicalisation within Europe is connected to deradicalisation for Palestinians and makes European action for de–escalation more urgent. Finally, I join with those who remember with sorrow the assassination of Yitzhak Rabin on the twentieth anniversary this week of that bloody act. His daughter said in a speech at Mr Rabin’s graveside yesterday: ‘there is no peace process’. There is no peace process. Let us hear and agree with her words and let us create one.

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR).
text: – Madam President, with so much conflict in the Middle East, at least we could take some comfort from the fact that, for some time, Israel was not being blamed for the conflicts that were going on. Now we see this new ingredient of Israel and Palestine being dropped into the inferno yet again. I have to say that this is not by accident: I see the hand of Hamas and others at work here, throwing petrol on the fire.   Ms Mogherini, you will know from your conversations that Mr Netanyahu has repeatedly said that he is willing to engage in negotiations and the peace process without conditions. I wonder, when you saw Mahmoud Abbas on Monday, did you actually put this to him? Did you condemn the Palestinian violence, which has brought about the murder of a number of Israelis? Did you remind him, by the way, of the extent to which his Palestinian Authority is reliant on EU funding? Did you urge him to immediately take up the Israeli offer of an unconditional resumption of negotiations? (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Two questions. I was a little bit surprised – do you think it is Hamas who has caused us to talk about and mention the occupation? And calling for the occupation to be part of the solution, because if we do not do that, I think that it is the whole of international society, including the US, recognising that this is an occupation. Secondly, when you talk about ‘unconditional’, do you say when we, the international society, ask Israel to stop the illegal settlement building, is that unfair when we call for a true negotiation?

name: Geoffrey Van Orden (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Look, we can go on and go round and round in circles all the time on these issues. The fact is, there is an offer on the table to re—open negotiations. Let us resume those negotiations. And you say: is the hand of Hamas there? Of course it is, because these people, they only live off the violence that exists amongst the Palestinians. The Palestinian people want to live in peace and prosperity. They have been let down by their leaders over many, many decades now and it is time to get over this particular problem. Israel and Palestine together, they could create a really vibrant successful two-state solution in that part of the world. Think of all the benefits that would flow from that. But you have got to stop the terrorism, stop the extremism and get back to the negotiating table.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I wonder how much this debate differs from the last one that we had, or from the one before that. I am afraid that the next debate will be a repetition. One time it will be about rockets, then terrorist attacks and then new settlements. Each of us will have his or her own perception of what is going on. I say to Ms Mogherini that I very much appreciate what she said in terms of the responsibility of Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas. We need to see delivery from both of them. I wonder also, in this respect, when finally President Abbas will be able to administrate Gaza. Having said this, in terms of evaluation of what is going on, I very much agree with you. I also very much appreciate what you said in terms of the three elements and the entry point. My only question is: if one, the other or both fails on delivery, do we have the courage, the ability and, the unity to provide the right reaction? I believe we have the means and that we should have the other elements as well. I very much trust in your leadership in that, together with the Quartet, we will manage to get these two sides to enter direct negotiations. One has already declared readiness, the second one should do so soon as possible. Unless they deliver, we should have another proper answer.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, we must look the political deadlock in the eye. Twenty-one years later, the feeling is that Oslo is dead. The occupation continues and is established on the ground. How can you make statements of equal distance when the armed Israeli army, settlers and far-right Israelis are even covered by the Netanyahu government? When they kill a child in Jerusalem for throwing a stone or a girl in Hebron, on the way to the English lesson, or a doctor protecting his countrymen in Hebron? When 100,000 Palestinian residents of Jerusalem are at risk of losing their rights by staying outside the wall of shame? Really, how would people react in the Member States of the Union if they excluded them from their historical monuments, places of worship, stole their crops, threatened them every day? The European Union and the international community must assume its responsibilities before it is too late. Without the lifting of the occupation there is no peace. There will be a third and fourth Intifada as long as there is possession.  Mrs Mogherini, do you want peace? You must press Israel, freeze the association agreement, stop funding Israeli companies from Horizon 2020, immediately ban arms trade with Israel. That's enough impunity! Enough of your silence and complicity! (applause)

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the High Representative has been addressing the issue of the stabbings in Israel by saying it is vital that Prime Minister Netanyahu and President Abbas show leadership and promote calm. With all due respect, when innocent Israeli civilians are being killed in repeated terror attacks, the High Representative of the European Union needs to do better. Recent statements by the Palestinian President emphasise the importance of speaking out. President Abbas has claimed, and I quote, ‘The Al-Aqsa mosque is ours [...] we bless every drop of blood that has been spilled for Jerusalem.’ Two questions must be raised. When will the High Representative loudly and clearly condemn the Palestinian stabbings of Israeli civilians? When will the Commission deal with the hateful propaganda and anti-Semitism of the Palestinian leadership?

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in the context of the current Sunni-Shia conflict, the old Arab-Israeli conflict, which until recently dominated the scene, has become only one component – and not even the main one – in a much more complex situation. Absolutely, if unattended, this conflict has the potential to make things even worse in that troubled area, but to continue to focus exclusively on it, ignoring the larger picture, is a recipe for failure. I agree that without any prospects, the new generation of Palestinians living in camps, with parents who moved in decades ago, get angrier and angrier. But equally we should reject categorically the current wave of stabbings and violence against the Jewish population. Unfortunately, sometimes some of us, convinced that the Palestinians are always right, no matter what, forget to equally condemn sincerely such violence, creating an increasingly strong impression that the EU is biased against Israel, whom we might need tomorrow more than we think today – as we did with Turkey. Credible even-handedness is key to the success of our commendable efforts to push the parties into a final deal.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, in debates on this issue I often hear a lot of criticism toward Israel, but only a little towards Palestine. This surprises me. How come that a democratically—elected government gets nothing but criticism and an authority with a president who was officially chosen until 2009 and still is in function gets all kind of support? Unfortunately, I notice as well that what Mr Abbas says abroad is quite contrary to his domestic statements.  Publicly, Mr Abbas is urging a renewal of the peace process. Domestically, he awarded this week a cartoonist who promotes hate and violence. Publicly, Mr Abbas said this week that the current situation is extremely serious and grave and that the young people have no hope. Domestically, he promotes hate in the press and makes no effort to stop this violence or to give anyone hope. We need to unmask these lies from the Palestinian Authority.  Ms Mogherini, Will you force the authorities to stop the hatred against Jews in the Palestinian media, and the militant preachers who really stir up hate amongst the youth and the people of Palestine? We need to stop this.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has had on her part. The conflict between Israel and Palestine seems to be spiraling out of political control. As always, the civilian population on both sides is the main victim of outbreaks of violence. Both Abbasˊ announcement that we no longer feel bound by the Oslo Accords and Netanyahu's recent statements in complete historical transfiguration complicate our commitment to a fair two-state solution and our consistent fight against all forms of anti-Semitism. Mrs Mogherini, you are right to call for Netanyahu and Abbas to show leadership and to lead the de-escalation of the spiral of violence. As you said, you want to find a point of entry for the resumption of negotiations. Then, for example, follow the latest initiative by Israeli writers and Arab intellectuals under the motto "Israel needs cultural bridges instead of boycotts". And please, please apply this thinking equally to all Israel's neighbors. For if hatred and fantasies of extermination are uncontestedly rewarded with rapprochement or economic cooperation, a solution to the conflict is by no means approaching. But this, Mrs Mogherini, needs concrete steps instead of appeals and appeals. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Thank you for taking the blue card. Would you not accept that Israel is taking such steps to build cultural bridges, as demonstrated with regard to the agreement that has been agreed through Jordan with regard to the Temple Mount and the Western Wall?

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, if you had listened, you would have been able to say that this is precisely my petitum, including cultural values in the debate.  The recent appeal by writers and intellectuals, for example, is a very concrete way that can lead to bridges being built rather than conflicts being stirred up.

name: n/a
text: Madam President, Madam High Representative, as you have pointed out with great humanity in your opening remarks, rarely has there been such a low level of hope in this Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and yet we must stay the course towards peace, and you do so. We must also give peace a chance, find a two-state solution, and I believe that your determination is total, Madam High Representative.  To win our fight, your fight for peace, it is necessary not only for both sides to show leadership, as you have pointed out, but also for ourselves of course to help the mutual understanding of the parties, for us to be able to accompany Palestinian reconciliation and to collectively define the compensation that each side will need to sign a peace agreement. Both the Quartet and american leadership have reached their limits, so it was time to find other solutions, and involving our Arab partners is undoubtedly an undeniable asset. In conclusion, within the Quartet and with our Arab partners, I think that you are, Madam High Representative, the point of balance, the centre of the Union to win peace, and we support you.

name: Zdzisław Krasnodębski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I think it is possible to agree with all those in this House who say that a great deal, and perhaps even the most, depends on Israel's policies and opening up future prospects for the Palestinians. But as we know, there is a need for peace on both sides, and knife attacks on civilians should be strongly condemned by us, and here some colleagues behave very restrainedly on this issue, and instead we hear whether we are dealing with the idealisation of the Palestinian side. It also seems to me that the Union should stop aid to those Palestinian organisations that reject the normalisation of relations with Israel. I would remind you that the Palestinian NGOs Code of Conduct obliges Palestinian NGOs not to support standardisation activities either at the level of security policy or at the level of cultural and development policy. Nevertheless, they receive funds from the Union. I think it's time to change this policy and end the politics of false symmetry.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the latest developments in the escalation of Israeli-Palestinian violence will not bring about peace. Israeli and Palestinian leaders need to use their authority to curb, rather than incite, the current wave of violence. There is no sense of future with Israel systematically eating away at Palestinian land. There is a feeling among Palestinians that no one cares. The two-state solution is at risk of being lost; it must not remain a dream. Violence only brings about more violence. The great danger is that it will turn into a religious conflict. There is a lack of attention from the international community. We, the EU, cannot turn our backs on this. People are crying out for a solution: we must give them hope. It is the right of every human being to live with dignity, peace and security: two States living side by side in peace and security.  Ms Mogherini, as my colleague, Mr Carver, asked: when do you plan to adopt and publish the EU guidelines on the labelling of settlement products?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the European Union must take serious initiatives to promote peace in the Middle East. The civil war in Syria and the conflicts in Iraq have created huge refugee inflows to Europe. But there will be no viable solution in the Middle East without the resolution of the Palestinian one in accordance with UN resolutions. Because that is the only way the Israelis and Palestinians will be able to live together peacefully. But the European Union has not responded to these modern challenges. First of all, the amounts of funding included in the European Union budget for 2015 are not sufficient for the needs of the local population and in particular to address the humanitarian crisis in Gaza. There are also no European funds to stimulate growth in the region, increase investment, create jobs, hit poverty, which is a fertilizer for supporting jihadists. Therefore, Mrs Mogherini, you must step up your efforts in order to bring the parties concerned around the table in order to find a solution in the region. Because tension and violence only strengthen the jihadists and the DAES.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, thank you for the words you have uttered, and also for your commitment to this issue.  So the sense of despair that prevails today cannot be inevitable, as you said. In the last few days, you have stepped up your efforts in the various meetings you have made, but you have also said today that, in practice, we need to do more. We must do more to support the relaunch of the Palestinian political process, but we must also do more to immediately stop illegal israeli settlements.  So these are two minimum conditions and necessary for the resumption of dialogue. These are also two conditions on which the European Union has the power to do more. We talked earlier about the guidelines for colony products. I think that is something that we should activate as soon as possible in order to move forward on this issue.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Madam President, High Commissioners, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The situation in Israel and Palestine is extremely worrying.  I strongly support the call by our EU external envoy, Mrs Mogherini, for de-escalation on both sides – Israelis and Palestinians. I thank you very much for the steps outlined earlier, which you have outlined, how these negotiations must now move forward. It is good that you, Mrs Mogherini, together with US Secretary of State Kerry and Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier, held intensive talks with all the parties involved over the past week. I am glad that the agreement on camera surveillance on Jerusalem's Temple Mount was a first step towards calming the situation. However, sustained de-escalation can only succeed if both sides disarm in their rhetoric. I therefore very much regretted the fact that, before his visit to Germany last week, the Israeli Prime Minister named the Grand Mufti of Jerusalem as the main culprit for the murder of the Jews in Europe. As a historian, it is particularly important to me that the responsibility of the Germans in the Holocaust is not put into perspective. I would also ask you, in the negotiations, to ensure that the MEMBERS of the European Parliament have access to the Gaza Strip.  It is the EU that strongly supports UNRWA, and it is very important that we ourselves get an idea of how our humanitarian aid is actually being developed on the ground, what successes it has achieved and how we can improve it.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – The stalemate in the peace process between Israel and Palestine has opened the door to a new wave of violence triggered by radical Palestinian groups. This is happening in the shadow of the Syrian war, but it should not be underestimated by any means, because it can reach great proportions. Violence is born of violence, both sides bear responsibility, but it is not the same. The recent terrorist attacks on Israel, the recent terrorist attacks on Western banks, that it refuses to recognise Israel, all of this does not promote peace and stability. Israel has a right to self-defense.  It is essential that both sides return to peace talks based on the concept of two countries. Israel has repeatedly expressed its willingness to negotiate directly, without setting pre-emptive terms, but President Abbas has 400. There is a growing need for the EU to redefine its return to resolving this issue and to make its assistance to the Palestinian side conditional on its return to the negotiating table.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent weeks we have been witnessing with concern the outbreak of a new round of violence in Israel and Palestine, and some have already called it the new Intifada. We hope not. We hope that we will not be faced with a new, bloody conflict in that already battered land. Meanwhile, since the beginning of October there have already been dozens of victims, and the most worrying thing is the almost unprecedented nature of this new escalation of violence, a symptom of a deeper rift that makes the path to peace even more difficult between the two ethnic groups vying for the Holy Land. Resolving the Arab-Israeli conflict must be a priority for the Eu ropean Union. High Representative Mogherini's important and ongoing efforts to identify points of mediation are beginning to unfold. But we have not yet succeeded in developing an effective and autonomous policy in the peace process. Indeed, the European Union can only play a central role in achieving a global peace, based on a vision of a region in which two democratic states, Israel and Palestine, live side by side in a climate of reconciliation and with secure and recognised borders.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since September, we have seen a new wave of attacks by Palestinian terrorists against the Israeli civilian population. At the same time, we are once again witnessing a real campaign in which lies are built up and real myths are simply told that are not based on the truth. I think we should pay close attention to what really happens. I don't think Israel has changed its policy toward the Temple Mount. In 2014, millions went to the Temple Mount and visited it. 3.5 million were Muslims, 200,000 were Christians, 12,000 were Jews. And only Muslims are allowed to pray there. I think Israel is doing a lot here to defend the sanctuaries of all faiths. There is hardly a country that has three holidays: Friday Saturday, Sunday. I would like to leave it at that.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Madam High Representative, we are experiencing another terrible chapter of the occupation, which already lasts too long. On the one hand, we have individualities that commit terrible acts, but as a product of deep despair, after sixty-eight years of occupation. On the other side, we have an answer that stokes fire. We've seen extrajudicial executions, allowing lynchings. We've seen the wounded, and even killed, get older, and we've seen knives even put on people he'd shot himself at. Is this a weighted, discriminated reaction, proportionate? I grant you, Mrs Mogherini, that you have an interest in solving this problem. But the EU has the capacity to put pressure on its partner. Concrete measures are needed, because there is an occupant and there is a busy one. And there are UN resolutions, such as 242, that simply say that the territories should be stopped and a country in Palestine allowed.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, you said, and I agree, 'it's not business as usual'. True, we recognize your tenacity and your correct appeal to the recovery of dialogue. But you will agree that we run the risk of staying in the expression of good intentions. The issue is not what the European Union asks or requests from Israel and Palestine. The question is how the European Union acts, how it intervenes, with or without Quartet, what decisions it makes to influence and condition the process. That is why here we continue to speak in terms of co-responsibility practice on both sides, as if Palestine were not a drowned society, limited in its movements and reduced to pure subsistence. That's why I ask you some questions to add to those that have already been asked about labels, area C territories or European project demolitions. First, how do you plan to manage the relationship with the Arab community in Israel? When do you plan to meet with entities such as the Mossawa Center? Secondly, do you think it would be appropriate to include Iehava and other violent settler groups on the European visa ban list? How will you prevent the allocation of Horizon 2020 funds to weapons and military equipment factories in Israel?

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI). Madam President, the atrocity of the Israeli state, a local gendarme of imperialism, with dozens of murdered Palestinians in recent events is supported by the United States and the European Union. Hypocritically they chant wishes, but in practice keeping equal distances from abuser and victim, like the resolutions of the European Parliament, they undermine any prospect of a viable sovereign Palestinian state. Representing business interests in the oil region, where competition rages, sows wars, impoverishment, refugees, implicates all the peoples of the region in dangerous situations in cooperation with governments, such as the Greek one, which, instead of recognising the Palestinian state, is upgrading military and economic cooperation with Israel. The prospect of an end to the Israeli occupation – because that is the problem – for a sovereign viable Palestinian state on the 67th border, with East Jerusalem as its capital, the dissolution of settlements, the return of refugees, the release of political prisoners, will be vindicated by the struggle of the Palestinian people at home, but also by the international solidarity of the peoples. In this solidarity he calls and pioneers the Communist Party of Greece.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am deeply concerned about developments in Israel and Palestine, which are threatening to make a two-state solution impossible. Stabbings, car rammings and shooting attacks are making it clear that the situation is becoming more and more unstable and difficult. Both sides need to explore together ways to stop violence: to calm the situation down, to show leadership and to make sure that there is no further loss of life.  Our objective must remain a two-state solution with a democratic and viable Palestinian state living side-by-side with Israel in peace and security. For this it must receive all necessary guarantees from its other neighbours concerning its security and stability.
