If an agreement to finally end the conflict is reached, the door would be open for development and cooperation in the area. At the same time, everybody is speaking about two sides: I think, Ms Mogherini, that we must encourage the Palestinians to form a common side, and by this I refer to the Fatah and Hamas movements. They have to find a bridge and come to the negotiations as a united side.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). – Mrs Mogherini, what is different or what has been presented to us in today's debate? Did Israel stop human purges, settlements, illegal imprisonment, apartheid, occupation of Gaza? No, of course not. Every day the situation in the Middle East confirms in the most tragic way the catastrophic failure and impasse of your policy of peace in the region. At a time when Mr Netanyahu shamefully declares that Hitler has been seduced by a Palestinian mufti for the crimes he has committed, you are generally talking about reconstruction and milder rhetoric. At last, it is an insult to the thousands of dead to continue to discuss this content without doing anything. At least apply the clauses of the agreements and the decisions you have already made. Immediately suspend the association agreement and stop funding the Israeli war industry from Community programmes. Perhaps then any discussion will make sense, otherwise the terrorist state of the region will continue its murderous policy and despise you.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, what the Palestinians want is very simple: the end of the occupation, a free, independent and viable state, with the borders of 1967 and with East Jerusalem as its capital.  The Government of Israel has maintained for decades the promotion of state terrorism, maintains a gigantic action to sequestration of all Palestinian resources, through settlements, expropriation of land, water control, thus compromising any possibility of creating a Palestinian state. At the same time, it maintains pressure through an uninterrupted succession of provocative actions, with checkpoints, arbitrary arrests, selective killings. The situation in Gaza is intolerable.  The role of this House can only be to strive for international legality and respect for human rights. The European Parliament must unequivocally condemn the construction of settlements in the West Bank. The European Parliament should suspend all cooperation agreements with Israel until the atrocities stop. The European Parliament must use all its influence and all its prerogatives to contribute to a political and peaceful solution to the problem.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as one speaker said during this debate, we always have the same debate. And let me say very frankly, as I always tend to be, when we say this is not time for business as usual, that is also for us. Because here we see again and again, even within political families and within the groups, the same split. Some of you ask me to speak with a stronger voice when we condemn acts of terror, which we do, and some of you ask me to have a stronger voice when we call for the end of occupation, which we do. We do both. Please have a look – a serious one – not only at my statements, but also at the most recent statement of the Quartet of just a few days ago, which means that these are common positions, not only of the whole European Union united, but also of the international community through the Quartet. This is a common position that we have built. Let me say that the common position of the European Union and of the international community through the Quartet is much more united than Members are able to manage within their own political groups. This is not the time for us only to call for something or to condemn something. Do we realise that we are in a serious, dramatic situation which could be the end of the Oslo framework? So, if I hear readiness from both sides to work together, to restart talks and to work together in implementing some measures on the ground, I ask you in this room what you think our role as the European Union is:  to condemn and to call for something or to try to bring them to do it? I believe our role is the second one, partly because I do not see many actors pushing to play this role at this moment. There are plenty of other crises competing with this one, and we Europeans are one of the few still focusing very much on this. But we have to do it with the right approach: trying to help them to get out of this bubble. I am also a historian through my studies and I love history, but the problem we have here is that there is too much history. If someone does not help the parties and the people – the Israelis and the Palestinians – and not only them, but the whole region, to get out of the bubble of history and try to look at how to manage the common future they have committed to, nobody else will do it.  So I believe our role is a diplomatic one, which is not a nice exercise in good intentions. It is very hard. It is very tough. It is not naïve. It is a reality check that we have to make here. We risk losing the Oslo framework. Someone said at the beginning of the debate – I think it was Gianni Pittella – that we are losing generations. There are generations in Israel and in Palestine who do not believe in those two states anymore. On both sides, there are young people who believe either in no state at all or in one state only. I believe that the Oslo framework is still a valid perspective for both, with all that goes with it.  But we are at the edge. It is not going to continue like this. So this is what I am trying to do: passing the message to the leadership – and hopefully also to the people, but that is not only my job – that if you say you want two states, either you do something now or it is gone. We do not have the safety net of a plan B. We will have to reinvent it if we leave the Oslo framework. It is no longer about what we call for or what we condemn. If it is done, it is a totally different story. The world does not need another complication in the region. That is why, of all the conflicts we have, to me this is one of the most urgent because its global ramifications go everywhere in the world and the presence of the holy sites makes it even more serious. It is, paradoxically, also a conflict that, if there is enough political will, can be resolved, because they have been discussing for decades how it should look in the end, and there is – as someone rightly pointed out – an Arab peace initiative that can provide a regional framework for security and for peace.  I would invite you to go back to the spirit with which you discussed this issue in September, which was a constructive and useful one that gave us strength last month to gather the international community behind our proposals and our positions and to bring the parties to start looking at whether we can do something together. There are moments where violence is higher, like this one, that could also be the turning point in a crisis because the parties realise that they are risking too much internally. Violence in Israel also comes from the inside. The situation inside the West Bank means that, in my view, both leaderships realise that it is in their interests to tackle this seriously. I might be wrong: it could be that this does not lead anywhere, and then we will need to see, together with our friends in the rest of the international community, what we do about that.  But my role at the moment – and I will ask you, as Europeans, to be united on this – is to try to see if there is one chance for the two sides to start doing  something useful on the ground instead of having their people killing each other, and to facilitate this to happen because we are not going to have many chances in the future. I feel a sense of urgency and that a dramatic moment has come. I do not think that this is just another chapter of a long story.  The situation is different today.  We can come back in another month or another month and a half and discuss our statements, our options, our condemning, whatever. In the meantime, we need to try to bring them together again, together with Arab friends and together with the international community. But this is our work and I am sure that this Parliament will support this effort. This is a crisis where the European Union has a lot to spend in terms of political capacity. I said this exactly one year ago in the hearing in the Committee on Foreign Affairs. This is the crisis where we are the biggest player if we want to transform the money we have spent and the economic, political and cultural relations we have with both sites into political capital. This is what we are strongly building. Obviously this is not completely in our hands because peace cannot be imposed from the outside, but what can be done from the outside is the facilitation and the push for a serious shift of policy to happen. I think that in these dramatic conditions the parties all have interests in doing this for real.  (Applause)

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The escalation of the Arab-Israeli conflict in recent days, already known as the "third intifada" and indeed taking on the dimensions of religious war, is also observed with great concern and concern in Poland, a country that has never been indifferent to the fate of the Holy Land. Understanding that the guilty can always be found on both sides of the conflict, however, we want to appreciate the fact that it is the Israeli side that is now declaring its readiness for talks without preconditions. We are still waiting for a similar readiness of the Palestinian authorities, if only in the form of consent for permanent monitoring of the Temple Hill. While appreciating international engagement within the Middle East Quartet, I would like to call for these actions to be limited to creating a positive environment for the resumption of peace talks, without imposing ready-made solutions on the parties. Let us trust Prime Minister Netanyahu, who is also able to act effectively without the advice of Minister Lavrov. Finally, on behalf of the Polish people, I would like to express my condolences to the families of the soldiers and civilian casualties killed in the recent knife attacks, and I expect the Palestinian Authority to strongly condemn this form of violence.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in South Sudan.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: VPC/HR. – Madam President, let me apologize if sometimes I am a little bit too passionate in my statements. Normally it happens at the end of the debates, not at the beginning, so I will try to go back to my normal tone of voice. I would like to start by thanking Parliament for keeping a focus on South Sudan and for organising this debate. I think it is very important that we keep focused on that.  This is a country where huge hopes faded in the space of just a few years. It is a country that could be rich if it fully used its natural resources but, on the contrary, we have a humanitarian situation that is dire. We have some 30 000 people currently risking death by starvation and thousands more that are on the brink of famine, according to UN data. A million people are internally displaced. Over 700 000 have fled the country. It is one of the biggest refugee crises today, and I would like us to focus on the refugee crises that are happening in the world even when they are happening outside our own borders or regions. Innocent civilians continue to suffer human rights abuses. At least 80 civilians were reportedly killed over the last three weeks and a further 150 civilians have reportedly been killed since Friday 23 October in Unity State alone. Meanwhile, humanitarian organisations still have no access to this area. Sexual violence against women and children has reached shocking levels and these crimes go against the commitments made by all parties in South Sudan: commitments to protect its citizens and put an end to the human rights violations.  The people of South Sudan cannot wait. Justice and reconciliation must be central to our efforts to lay the foundation for sustainable peace. For this reason we welcomed the African Union’s decision to publish the Commission of Inquiry’s report and to move ahead with the establishment of the court. The recent peace agreement offers a really unique opportunity, one that cannot be missed. It is an opportunity for South Sudan to move towards a transparent, accountable government: a government that places the interests of the citizen above all else. And, if properly implemented, the agreement will end the fighting. It will install transitional institutions to rebuild the country. The government’s decision to increase the number of federal states in the country goes against the spirit and the letter of the agreement. The same goes for the reluctance of the opposition to commit to the implementation of the security arrangements. The recent clashes in Unity State and the worrying signs of growing crackdown on civil societies are all very worrying events. Just yesterday in Addis, the parties took a first step to move beyond the current deadlock. This gives us hope that the discussion can get to the next stage. But let me say that a positive conclusion of the dialogue is still not in sight. Only timely implementation of the agreement will lead to real peace, end the suffering of the people of South Sudan and stop the humanitarian tragedy. Spoilers on all sides must understand that there are consequences for their actions, and there will be. There are a number of steps that must be taken now: first, a ceasefire must come into place as a matter of urgency, and second, all obstacles to full and unconditional humanitarian access must be removed immediately. With statehood comes responsibility. Hard work begins now with the implementation of the agreement. South Sudan cannot afford this agreement to follow the same path of all past broken ceasefire agreements. For that, we need to sustain international pressure and cohesion. We all have welcomed the continued efforts of the International Authority on Development (IGAD) and the African Union in reaching this deal and the constructive engagement of Sudan, Uganda, Ethiopia and Kenya. I met exactly one week ago in Addis with the African Union’s Chairperson, Dr Zuma, and with the Ethiopian Prime Minister. We agreed to keep working together to help South Sudan. In the implementation phase regional unity is essential and plays a key role. With regard to the regional challenges, I recall the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Council of the EU/Horn of Africa Regional Action Plan 2015—2020 which outlines the European Union’s comprehensive approach to address the key issues in the region. It will also need a strong monitoring body representing the South Sudanese civil society together with regional and international players. In this context, the appointment of President Mogae as chair of the joint monitoring body is good news. His leadership will be essential to guide the implementation phase. The EU will continue to stand by the South Sudanese people during the transitional process. We have done so since the outbreak of fighting in December 2013. We worked to bring an end to the fighting and initiate a political transition and we provided massive humanitarian assistance. In 2014, the Commission’s humanitarian support exceeded EUR 116 million. This year our aid has already reached EUR 107 million. The United Nations calculated that the European Union as a whole, including Member States, funded almost 41% of all humanitarian donations to people in need in South Sudan this year, and in total over 3.1 million vulnerable people benefitted from life-saving assistance in South Sudan this year. But we know very well that humanitarian assistance alone cannot substitute for sound development programmes.  Not only is the EU contributing to humanitarian assistance, it also supports the implementation of the peace agreement across its five pillars. The support will originate mainly from the EDF national programme, but for pillars one and two, namely governance and security, the support will originate from the instrument contributing to stability and peace and the African Peace facility, respectively. We are now ready to work with a transitional government of national unity. We can help establish the transitional institutions and develop sound policies for rebuilding the country. This will include responsible, transparent and equitable management of South Sudan’s vast resources. It is time that these resources are used for the benefit of the population as a whole. Ratifying the Cotonou Agreement would be a sign of South Sudan’s will to announce its relation with the European Union, but right now it is urgent that all South Sudanese parties commit to implementing the agreement. This is the key step we need now, and this is what we have discussed with the regional players last week as our common horizon to work on this together. I thank Members very much for their attention and I look forward to hearing their views in this debate, which I consider extremely helpful and useful in our common work.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – The conflict in South Sudan and the peace process in south Sudan are issues that play an important role in my political group's policy towards African countries. The August peace agreement ending more than 20 months of civil war has not become a remedy to any problems for the country, which is still in deep humanitarian and political and economic crisis. This agreement is only the first, albeit significant, step towards stabilisation and a return to development. The statement by the leaders of South Sudan to set up a hybrid tribunal and to judge those responsible for violence and abuse is to be welcomed. This is important in the context of recent information on cases of abductions and enslavement of women and children as a form of remuneration for militant soldiers. This phenomenon is a violation of fundamental human rights, such as the right to life, and a ban on slavery or serenity. The Government of South Sudan should take all steps to counter this. We also want to draw attention to the poor humanitarian situation that is currently prevailing in this country. It is estimated that during the conflict more than 2 million residents left their homes, lack access to drinking water, medical care, spread diseases. Only swift and decisive action by the international community will help prevent famine and the next wave of refugees.  It is our duty to support the peace process in South Sudan and to provide all possible assistance to the people of south Sudan on their path to peace.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, because of the refugee crisis we are experiencing in Europe, this is the time for Syria and the time of Iraq, but as the High Representative has pointed out, we cannot forget that there are two equivalent and long-term crises in Africa: Central African Republic and South Sudan; a country with thirty years of war, which has only four years of existence and currently has two million refugees. All these cases are humanitarian crises caused by man, by wars. And for this reason, the main action we have to face is to just put the war in South Sudan behind us, to contribute as a European Union, in connection with the African Union, with regional authorities, with the international community, to stabilize the peace agreement reached last August. Secondly, the means must be put in place to deal with the consequences of this crisis. Only half of what the United Nations asked to deal with the situation in South Sudan has been contributed by the different donors. Thirdly, the food crisis must be seriously addressed. According to the United Nations ranking, we are in the Level 3 crisis, that is, catastrophe. Therefore, working for peace, putting more money, addressing the food crisis and having access to humanitarian actors.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, since achieving independence in 2011, South Sudan has been in the headlines for all the wrong reasons. As an early proponent myself of the benefits of Sudan’s splitting into two separate states, I am greatly saddened by the internal conflict that has since ensued.  Thousands have died and millions are now internally displaced, with the situation only worsening since December 2013. Following a series of failed ceasefires, it was announced yesterday that the parties from all sides had finally reached agreement as to the details regarding the implementation of measures agreed in August of this year. Reports suggest that these talks are a significant step forward as to resolving some tensions, but we must remain cautious with our optimism. The EU and Member State governments must now support the work of IGAD, the regional body that is mediating the talks along with the African Union. The UN also has announced the deployment of a mission to South Sudan that will investigate human rights abuses against civilians since December 2013, which my group, the ECR, welcomes. But to be absolutely frank, we all miss the late John Garang’s strong leadership. Sadly, he is no longer in the region. He is no longer with us.

name: Petr Ježek
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there are not many places in the world where the situation is worse than in South Sudan, where people suffer so much. Therefore, I also welcome the agreement on the resolution of the conflict signed in mid—August. It is an ambitious agreement which seeks to secure a permanent ceasefire and to put an end to impunity but also to manage better the country’s oil revenues. However, although the content is good, we all know that the worrying part is that commitment to this deal it is extremely weak and the fighting continues. Political leaders in South Sudan clearly do not care much about their own population but rather, I am afraid, about their villas and bank accounts outside the country.  I believe that a sustainable deal on ceasefire and other elements will only be achieved if we use the threat of targeted sanctions against the political leaders who do not stick to the agreement. The EU should reconsider imposing the arms embargo as well. On the positive side, I am glad that the African Union has released today the report of its Commission of inquiry on South Sudan. My questions to you, Vice President/High Representative, are what is the EU strategy to make sure South Sudan’s warring parties stick to the agreement, and not only to the ceasefire agreement but also to the other provisions regarding impunity and oil management? Also, you mentioned civil society, but does the EU plan to work closely with local grass—roots organisations to monitor the effective implementation of the agreement? And again, what is the strategy here?

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, we are talking about terrible data again: more than 50,000 dead, more than two million refugees, and no, it is not a natural catastrophe. Background is important and I cannot forget that secession was encouraged by the United States and Israel. It's funny how you play creative chaos as you see fit. Behind, as always, were not human rights, but control of major oil fields, to prevent China from accessing them. Or also the balkanization of the area, which reminds me of the Yinon plan. The atrocities committed have forced or driven a UN embargo, which even the United States is watching. On the contrary, Israel continues to repeatedly violate it. Mrs Mogherini, I believe that the European Union must be used thoroughly to enforce this arms embargo or the passage of mercenaries; support, of course, the UN mission that has just begun in the area; support that regional dialogue that you were talking about and, above all, try to ensure that there is no expoliating energy resources, which is what is behind this terrible situation.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President; thank you very much, Madam High Representative, for being here in this European Parliament. I see her quite often and that means she takes us into account, and we thank her very much. There has been a peace agreement in South Sudan, signed in August of the same year, but we all know it is not working. The fighting continues. Fifty-seven dead in early October alone, most of them children. As a member of this Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, I am absolutely terrified of the atrocities we are discovering, how women are used as a weapon of war, systematically violated. Women and girls. Europe's silence is not tolerable on this issue, because that would make us complicit. We're asking for involvement. We ask for deep involvement, we ask for a very strong will for the arms embargo, denouncing to those countries, such as Israel, which, as my colleague has said, are not respecting it. Not sanctions with humanitarian aid, since it is dependent on the citizens of that country, but a safe and strong involvement, to demand that the peace agreements be implemented, that this Hybrid Court of Justice be established which must judge crimes under universal law, and also for the establishment of that Truth, Reconciliation and Reparation Commission. If you get involved with all that strength, if Europe is present there, know, Madam High Representative, that you have us by your side.

name: James Carver
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, bearing in mind the rampant desire within this place to move towards a common foreign policy, I would be interested to hear whether the High Representative places any real confidence in the South Sudan leadership – both governmental and opposition – to deliver the agreement in good faith. After all, these are the same leaders who were responsible for downing UN helicopters in 2012 and 2014 and the 2013 attacks on both a UN convoy and the UNMISS camp at Akobo. Then there are the continuing arrests and detentions of IGAD monitoring staff whilst UN staff and contractors continue to be abducted. Is there any evidence, Commissioner, of the Lord’s Resistance Army working inside South Sudan in tandem, or whether former Vice-President, Riek Machar, enjoys military support from them, as rumours indicate? Finally, given the excellent work undertaken by IGAD, could she comment on the EU’s engagement with IGAD on Southern Sudan, and more widely in the Horn of Africa? Does she feel that such EU engagement further complicates their operation on the ground and raises possible duplication of work?

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam High Representative, Sudan is one of the youngest nations in the world and as such is one of the last Christian countries in Africa.  After two million deaths and more than four million refugees, Sudan may be living its final moments today. Of course, this agreement is quite welcome, but I am counting on you to make this country a viable state.  However, we must remain vigilant, because this agreement calls for two reflections. First, we must not forget the historical barbarity of Khartoum, a barbarism that still plagues us today, especially through its military interference. Second, South Sudan cannot be left to economic globalism because of the wealth of its subsoil.  Through these two observations, we must ensure that external interference, whether political or economic, is not the last living spaces for Sudan today.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE).
text: Mr President, Madam High Representative, yes, the last few months show that vigilance and constant mobilization of the international community are necessary for real progress towards peace in South Sudan. I would like to emphasize four things.  First, the real commitment of the parties to the conflict is necessary, both within the framework of the 26 August peace agreement and in the document signed on Monday under the aegis of the African Union. For the security side, both sides must refrain from taking contradictory steps in the spirit of the peace process. Second, the role of South Sudan's regional partners and the international community remains key. On the one hand, for IGAD and the African Union, in order to closely monitor the implementation of the agreement, and on the other hand, to deal with the humanitarian horror. The international community must continue to assist people displaced and threatened by famine. The protection of children must also remain a priority of international aid for this country today and in the future.  Third, the fight against impunity. It is a key element in the construction of South Sudan, including the demobilization of the armed forces and the creation of a single army. Perpetrators of serious human rights violations must not be able to reintegrate into the military or be part of a transitional government, especially given the extent of sexual violence in the conflict.  Finally, the Union must continue to keep open the possibility for South Sudan to ratify the Cotonou agreement, which will be yet another tool for the democratic construction of that state.

name: Linda McAvan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to say to the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative that she ended the last debate by apologising for being passionate. I do not think you should apologise, Madam, because passion shows you care, and when you care you will get things done. I hope very much that by raising the issue of South Sudan tonight we are showing that we care and are asking you to help us do something about what has become one of the world’s forgotten crises.  You mentioned some of the difficulties. NGOs on the ground have written to MEPs talking about thousands of civilians killed, thousands of women raped and children abducted. This weekend the UN agencies – the World Food Programme, the Food and Agriculture Organization and UNICEF – warned of imminent famine. So we have got to do something. You are trying to up the diplomacy, putting pressure on the warring factions to come back to the table and to respect the ceasefire.  But what do we do if they will not agree? What can we do about it? How can we get tough? Colleagues spoke about arms embargoes, sanctions, and sanctions against the right people; not at the low level, but the most senior representatives. Can we have sanctions and will they bite? Have they been discussed with our partners, like the United States, and also can we have projects to give women a voice in this country? If they had a voice, I think some of the policies could change. Finally, just to say, as I said at beginning, we need a sense of urgency about this because it is a forgotten crisis but if we do not act soon that forgotten crisis will soon be on our television screens in the form of starving children, in the form of more women being raped. It is a very familiar scene from Africa, but it is one we could avoid if we act now.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – After months of bloody fighting, President Salva Kiir signed a peace agreement, accompanied by numerous ceasefire violations. I appreciate the initiative of the international community, the pressure it has exerted, the negotiations, the IGAD+ initiative, the regional players. I appreciate the work in the Security Council to align the United Nations mandate for the peacekeeping mission and also the willingness to involve the UK's national contingent. However, I believe that the Security Council's agreement to targeted sanctions is needed, because the actions – the administrative division of the country – taken by the South Sudanese authorities show that there is still a lack of goodwill to implement the agreement.

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Commissioner, for Ebola, we have mobilized. 11,000 people, and now we're talking about 100, 200 times more deaths. The situation in South Sudan is unfortunately only a case of chaos that European policy - in fact Western politics under the leadership of the Americans - leaves in its path.  In a complex tribal complex between Dinka and Arabs, amplified by internal religious divisions, internal religious divisions also in South Sudan, it was necessary to maintain at all costs the unity of Sudan. However, when it comes to supporting US policy, the questioning of borders and the partition of countries are possible and supported by the Union. So we always have a double language. In this case, I do not change, I am still for national unity. South Sudan is now rotting, we could even move towards a partition in the partition.  It is under the aegis of the United Nations and the African Union that a solution to the conflict will be found. Let us support the transitional government of national unity, but the division of Sudan was a mistake.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, respected High Representative Mogherini, I first and foremost welcome the signing of the August peace agreement in Juba between South Sudanese government forces and rebel groups, which was to end the 20-month armed conflict in this youngest African country. But security tensions following the signing of agreements across the country, including in the capital, remain worrisome and call into question the distribution of humanitarian aid. President Kiir's decision on a new territorial division did not contribute to this ither, as it is contrary to the text and meaning of the agreement. Decisions on the organisation of a state can only be taken through political dialogue between opposing parties.  In the months ahead for South Sudan, the key tasks are reconstruction, transition, improvement of democratic institutions, and the current priority is peacekeeping, solving a very difficult humanitarian situation and adequately addressing other challenges of this post-conflict society. An effective system should be put in place to prosecute the most serious war crimes, combat organised crime and assist victims of sexual violence and military exploitation of children.  In this context, the Union must support the full implementation of the peace agreement and contribute strategically to the building of this weak state according to all international criteria. €300 million in humanitarian aid is essential through 2015, and since there are another 4 million malnourished people, 2 million who have had to leave their homes and two-thirds of the population depends on humanitarian aid, I think together with the African Union and other organizations we need to make an additional contribution to the international humanitarian catastrophe in South Sudan.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the humanitarian disaster in South Sudan is the result of an unaforeseeable conflict, partly instigated from abroad, in the region itself, represented in IGAD. There's no point in pretending it's not like that.  The international community cannot continue to silence the degree of destruction, atrocities and loss of human life, as the African Union has done, namely by depending on the report on the atrocities to which Federica Mogherini referred.  The European countries that supported sudan's split in 2011 cannot now whistle into the air, they cannot not make all their efforts to ensure peace, security, so that the African Union and the United Nations can achieve a ceasefire, mechanisms of national reconciliation, transitional justice. And that implies targeted sanctions and a strict arms embargo.  There is an urgent need to ensure immediate humanitarian access to all areas to rescue and save the wounded, maimed, people at risk of being killed in indiscriminate violence or decimated by hunger. We cannot turn a blind eye to the atrocities that happen as we speak: women being used as a weapon of war, children being forced to fight and then raped, neutered, burned inside burning buildings. Enough of the infamous silence.  The European Union must be at the front line demanding that the Security Council act to put an end to the barbarism that shames all humanity. I would like to believe, like Federica Mogherini, that IGAD can solve this problem, just as the Khartoum process can work to help us solve the other refugee crisis we have on our doorstep, but unfortunately I do not believe it.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – South Sudan is just about the youngest state in the world, but in 2011 it did not actually become a state. It became a violent kleptocracy, trapped in a tangle of regional interests and alliances of and between neighboring states and all kinds of rebel groups. The people have seen nothing but horror and impunity. There is now a peace agreement. The warring parties have made commitments to participate in a transition process. Forgive my skepticism, but without strong international commitment, it will remain a paper peace this time. Are we and our partners in the region ready for such a commitment to ensure that arms trade and looting of natural resources cease, that the stolen goods are frozen and returned, and that those who have gone beyond crimes are also accountable and punished? The Union has no choice but to take an active role. It has to be more than business as usual. There is a need for strong mediation, targeted development cooperation and, if necessary, financial and other sanctions against the key players. The EU should not always be nice. Sweet is a word I have not yet come across in relation to South Sudan.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European Parliament. Once again, there is a debate in Parliament on the situation in South Sudan. How many actually? The positive thing is certainly that we do not turn our eyes away from the fate of the people of this country. At the end of August, a peace agreement was reached again between the leaders of the opposing groups, President Salva Kiir and former Vice-President Riek Machar. But how many peace agreements has it been since the outbreak of the civil war? Nevertheless, as the high representative has pointed out, the killing continues. Apparently, murder has already become an end in itself for many. And when you have seen that children already know nothing else, that an entire generation has only grown up in war and violence, you can see that it is also a humanitarian disaster there. The starvation of tens of thousands, also caused by the drought that is now prevailing there, has already been pointed out. The recent peace agreement between the parties to the conflict was only created by strong foreign policy pressure. But President Kiir spoke of a forced peace agreement on the day the agreement was signed – not a good sign. That is why the pressure on the leaders of South Sudan must not be allowed to subside, and the EU and its Member States should stand alongside the United States and no longer rule out sanctions against the leaders of South Sudan if they do not implement this peace agreement and finally give peace to their citizens.

name: Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we recognise the efforts made by the African Union and IGAD to promote the peace agreement in South Sudan. However, an agreement threatened by government and rebel mistrust and the continuing violence in that state. Millions of South Sudanese have been suffering for far too long, while the war is in danger of being compounded by a very serious famine. We must ensure safe access to humanitarian organisations operating in the area, thus providing the necessary aid to the population.  Peace, Mr President: this is the hope that accompanied the birth of South Sudan, a country born from the rubble of an endless civil war. Peace not only for the South Sudanese people, who have been suffering for decades, but for the entire East African region. There can be no peace without justice, however. That is why it is essential in this context to establish a hybrid Court that sheds light on the crimes committed and dissolves the spectre of impunity, which risks accompanying this conflict. Finally, I would like to thank the High Representative Federica Mogherini for her work on the issue of peace.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Ms Mogherini sincerely for her passionately positive message in reminding us of our constructive role and of the need for a reality check to help heal conflicts abroad. The same applies, of course, for South Sudan because the refugee crisis we are facing in Europe should not prevent us paying attention to the similar tragedy that South Sudan is facing. True, it is still unclear if there is enough political goodwill to implement a ceasefire but I welcome the EU’s willingness to step up our engagement. Our absolute priority is to secure a credible peace and implementation of the Cotonou Agreements: without that, even humanitarian aid will not reach those in need, and South Sudan will face hunger.  We hope to do our utmost to enable this war—torn country to move towards stability, security and national reconciliation.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE).
text: – Mr President, four years after the independence referendum, the army still conducts military operations in the disputed areas and the tragic consequences of these operations affect the civilian population. The EU must continue with the increased development assistance to meet South Sudan’s needs, ensuring that the safety of the people is the first and foremost consideration. It is vital to make sure that the support gets to where it is needed most. It is unfortunately true that the current conflict was easy to predict – so why is it that we could not avoid it? Why do we have to repeat the same patterns in different parts of the world? Why is it that, first, comes the desire for freedom, and later it is defeated by bloody greed. This lesson has still not been learned, and we have to remember that.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have spoken on several occasions in this House about the difficult situation in Sudan, a country that has widespread and systematic violations of human rights, whose government continues to suppress fundamental freedoms, including through the practice of arbitrary arrests of journalists and leaders of political parties. In the last few days, 80 civilians have been killed in a single county in Unity State, including 57 children. In South Sudan, more than 30 000 people are at risk of starvation and tens of thousands more are at risk of famine, according to the UN bodies (FAO, UNICEF and World Food Programme).  Since the start of the conflict in South Sudan almost two years ago, this is the first time that the so-called integrated model for classifying the risk of the UN food emergency has been level 5, that of catastrophe, the highest on the scale of one to five, for all sections of the population. If the situation is not to escalate further, Europe and the international community must also mobilise in cooperation with the African Union to promote national reconciliation and to support a process of political and institutional reconstruction of the country.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, South Sudan, although it has many sources of wealth, nevertheless its population lives below the poverty line. At the same time, since 2013 it has been in a civil war between the Noyer and Dinka tribes. Moreover, according to the UN, in South Sudan most of the population is at risk of famine; it is currently malnourished. In addition, 2.2 million people have been displaced inside and outside the country and a large number of them have fallen victim to South Sudanese soldiers. At a time when the UN is calling for humanitarian aid in the region, the European Union should contribute to the construction of the new South Sudan. At the same time, it should support the action of humanitarian organisations by providing funding to provide food and healthcare to the population. Finally, the peace agreement signed in Addis Ababa in May 2014 for a permanent ceasefire must be implemented.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam High Commissioner, you have our full support for what you are doing, but I sincerely invite you to focus on two key moments. One is punishing all criminals.  From an area of Europe where there was recently a war just over 20 years ago, where I come from, I know what it means to punish criminals, to exorcise justice, because those who abused women, those who abused children and those who committed war crimes, they really need to be brought to justice.  And the second is what we do anyway, but obviously we have to make additional efforts. The question is, whether 300m euros is enough, it clearly is not. Humanitarian aid is really what we expect you to do at the moment so that it can really reach every person who has this humanitarian aid in South Sudan and as it awaits.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the situation in South Sudan is still a remnant of the colonial period where the tactic, which is still to be divided to rule.  The creation in South Sudan in 2011 is inseparable from the presence of important oil reserves. Only in this way can we see how fratrited conflicts are born, dressed as religious wars. Weapons do not fall from the sky, they are provided to war-free groups by powerful interests, the origin of which is not even difficult to uncover. It is probably no accident that glencore international, the raw materials giant known for its contempt for human rights, dominates oil production in that country today. This Swiss-based company is implicated in a succession of scandals related to tax fraud and evasion, arms trafficking, etc.  The solution to this conflict can only lie with respect for the sovereignty of the people of South Sudan, in their right to dispose of their resources. It therefore implies immediate cessation of the supply of arms, which is an absolutely necessary condition for any minimally consistent reconciliation process.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a very small annual harvest, 30 000 people at risk of starvation, a third of the population on the brink of a humanitarian catastrophe, thousands of child soldiers, ethnic massacres, systematic use of torture and sexual violence, the most ignoble weapon to destabilise the enemy, as Denis Mukwege teaches us. In the very violent war between the Dinka of Kiir and the Nuer of Machar there are no good and bad, only an undefined power struggle and hundreds of thousands of innocent victims, in a country that has already had 2.5 million dead and hundreds of thousands of orphans and refugees in the previous civil war with Sudan.  The news of the new signing to continue the implementation of the peace agreements in Juba is a glimmer of hope, but the spectre of ethnic hatred and an even greater fragmentation of the interests linked to the extraction of rich oil fields and the exploitation of water, the object of the desire – among many – of Chinese appetititi, are enough and they are advancing to warn us.  The youngest nation in the world needs not weapons and large multinationals, but the experience and support, including economic support, of the old Europe to support the peace agreement, to force the parties to cooperate and to learn to walk the path of democracy, and this also goes from combating impunity. Let us not allow the Chinese, Arabs, let alone ourselves, to make it a colony to exploit. That bad example, we've already given it for centuries. If we cannot make up for the mistakes of the past, we can at least prevent those of the future.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I promise I will be less passionate, but not because I care less – on the contrary, because one has to be reasonable enough not to overstate the case, and also because I really appreciate the debate we have had here this evening. I have found it helpful in relation to the work we have to do.  On the one hand – conscious of the fact that we have a role to play in this crisis, but that our role is very much in support of and in coordination with the regional players, starting with the African Union – I completely agree with all of you who mentioned the work with regional and international players as the strong point of our action in this crisis. There are two sides to the task. Firstly, the humanitarian side needs to remain the focus of our work: we have a responsibility, as by far the leading humanitarian contributor in the crisis, and again I would underline the need to keep our attention focused on humanitarian refugee crises that are apparently far away from our borders. Moreover, this is not only a matter of moral responsibility and human responsibility, it is also a matter of investment in stability and in the future for a large part of the world’s population. Secondly, on the political track, with regard to the implementation of the agreement, I would point out that this is an agreement signed under difficult circumstances, in a very fragile situation. As I said in my opening statement, the international community must continue, and we must continue, to support the people of South Sudan as the implementation of the peace process begins.  More than anything, the leaders of the country have to exercise full responsibility. On both sides – as many of you mentioned – there are spoilers. There are interests opposing the agreement, and they must be told loud and clear that if they do not implement the agreement they will be held responsible for the consequences of their actions. That message has to come clearly and in unison from all of us. Only a concerted effort by political leaders will bring an end to the suffering of the people in South Sudan and enable them to live in peace.  I believe the signing of the agreement offers space and an opportunity for that, but implementation is, as we can see, extremely difficult. Our work with our African partners is pushing in this direction.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the joint debate on: – the report by Ivan Jakovčić, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the EU strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian region (2014/2214(INI)) (A8-0279/2015) and – the report by Fernando Ruas, on behalf of the Committee on Development in on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy (2014/2246(INI)) (A8-0277/2015) and – the report by José Blanco López, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, on the European Structural and Investment Funds and sound economic governance: guidelines for the application of Article 104 of the Treaty establishing the European Community; Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation (2015/2052(INI)) (A8-0268/2015) and, the oral question addressed to the Commission by Iscra Mihaylova in on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development on simplifying cohesion policy for the period 2014-2020 and focusing it on results (O-000127/2015 - B8-1103/2015).

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: Rapporteur. – Mr. President, on 30 June 2006 in Pula, Pola, Istria, Croatia we founded the Adriatic Euroregion. 27 regions that jointly decided to cooperate in the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea because they saw a common future precisely in cooperation in the Adriatic and the Ionian Sea. In 2010, these same regions offered in the Committee of the Regions the Strategy of the European Union, which we wanted to have on the Adriatic, along the lines of the Baltic Strategy and later on the Danube Strategy. In 2015, meaning ten years after that, the Italian Presidency launched a strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Seas and today we have this strategy that we are discussing.  We have four member states that are part of that strategy, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia and Greece, and we have four countries that are candidate countries. They are Serbia, Montenegro and Albania and potential candidate country Bosnia and Herzegovina. This only shows how important this strategy is and how partially and complicated it is on the other hand, as of course it is also a kind of laboratory for non-EU countries and for their entry into the European Union.  However, this strategy knows the four pillars. He knows the pillar of infrastructure, as one of the key pillars coordinated by Italy and Serbia, and I would like to emphasize in particular the exceptional importance I attach to connecting the region. Namely, we undoubtedly need corridors such as the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, both the one on the western part, therefore practically in Italy and the one that is in the eastern part, the one that goes in some way from Trieste to Igumenica, and on to Athens. We also need a connection that goes from west to east and east to west, from the Iberian Peninsula, which connects to the Apennine peninsula and then to the Balkan Peninsula.  Another important pillar is tourism and here I want to highlight the problem of short seasonality of our tourism where it is culture, agriculture and many other new products that can solve this seasonality, which is what we are talking about in our strategy.  Blue growth, shipbuilding is almost forgotten. Let's get back to shipbuilding. Shipbuilding is a good European industry and I think that's what we need to talk about. Of course, aquaculture as something we know well in the Adriatic and Ionian Seas. Pillar 4 is environmental protection. We're all very sensitive to the environment. We all care that our Adriatic and our Ionian Sea are clear sea and that we protect it as much as possible than especially exploits that we can some way predict at the moment. In the future we must do everything to protect our Adriatic.  What I want to highlight in particular at the moment is the fact that the area this European Union strategy is talking about is the area where we are dealing with the migrant and refugee problem. And I want to kind of thank all those individuals, ordinary citizens who are helping us overcome this great crisis, this difficult situation. Of course, in this context, all countries participating in this are extremely important and extremely important and it is good that Juncker called this meeting in Brussels because it was important to talk about the refugee problem at this level as well. I repeat, the Western Balkans and on this occasion shows how important it is for the European Union, and that is why I want us all together and how seriously we think about how we will embrace the Western Balkans and all countries that are not yet members into our society called the European Union.  Finally, I would like to thank all my colleagues and colleagues with whom I have collaborated on this strategy, for this report and I hope to continue our cooperation soon .

name: Fernando Ruas
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have taken this own-initiative report with enthusiasm. I was mayor for 24 years and also president of the National Association of Portuguese Municipalities for 12 years. In these roles, and also, fundamentally, as a citizen of a Member State of cohesion, I have learned to respect and therefore implement the Structural and Investment Funds in my country.  Cohesion policy, aligned in this multiannual financial framework with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, has been the European Union's main development tool. Indeed, its objectives of reducing disparities between European regions and promoting convergence have contributed to a more harmonious development of our Union, and should also stress that, in the previous Community framework, cohesion policy was, in many of our Member States, practically the only source of investment in the territory. That is why, in good time, and in an effort to anticipate the dialogue and interinstitutional reflection that we have started today with the Commission on the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy, the REGI Commission has decided to make its position on the matter known. Commissioner, I hope that this position will also be the European Parliament's position on cohesion policy and the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy from tomorrow.  So, in a nutshell, we would like to have a balanced and intelligent review of the strategy, focusing on a greater interconnection between its five objectives and its flagship initiatives, as well as the possibility of voluntary differentiated regional targets for the strategy, discussed at regional level, greater accuracy in the progress indicators provided by Eurostat at NUTS 2 and NUTS 3 level and a strong focus on multilevel governance and the importance of ownership and ownership implementation, on the ground, of the strategy by all its actors. In this context, moreover, it is important to us to have a pact between regional authorities and the European institutions to ensure the ownership and participation of these important administrative actors in the strategy, as well as the adoption of a code of conduct, in line with the one already adopted in the context of cohesion policy, and the timely involvement of the European Parliament in all relevant discussions , aiming at the design of the policies covered by the strategy, its implementation and also its evaluation. The review of the strategy should also promote greater coordination and strengthening of synergies between cohesion policy and horizon 2020 funds, with a view to achieving the goals and objectives of the strategy itself, as well as the recognition of the important role of small, medium or large cities and urban areas and, in particular, urban people for the future of the Europe 2020 strategy.  It is important to underline the relevance of the european union's new investment instrument, the European Strategic Investment Fund, known as the Juncker Plan, which will already mobilise a maximum of EUR 315 billion in investments, with the aim of reducing the investment gap in the European Union and also maximising the impact of public expenditure, but stressing that it should always be complementary and additional to the European Structural and Investment Funds. In conclusion, I hope and hope that there will be no regrettable delays in the start-up of cohesion policy implementation at the beginning of the current financial framework. Thus, both cohesion policy and the european Union's next long-term strategy should be drawn up before the end of the european Commission's current mandate. On this issue, I would also like to remind you that there will also be elections to the European Parliament in 2019, which will place significant temporary restrictions not only on the co-legislators – for example, on the timing of the negotiations – but also for the next Commission and even the Member States, with regard to the preparation and approval of the new agreements and the partnerships of operational programmes, which is of course expected to happen before the start of the next Community framework.

name: José Blanco López
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, during the last parliamentary term one of the most controversial aspects of the negotiation process of the Regulation on common provisions of the Structural and Investment Funds was the so-called 'macroeconomic conditionality' of Article 23. I would like to begin by thanking all the shadow rapporteurs and their political groups for their availability and collaboration throughout the extensive negotiation process, which has enabled the agreement contained in this report. We are all concerned about the practical implications of rescheduling and suspension of funds that macro-conditionality can lead to.  Considering a moment of crisis such as the current one, which has led to a sharp decline in investment, cohesion policy is key in maintaining the level of investment of Member States and their regions, in particular for improving employment. We therefore understand that macroeconomic conditionality should be considered as a last resort that responds to the sole objective of contributing to more effective implementation of funds. That is, any decision under Article 23 can be taken only in exceptional contexts, and must be well weighted and thoroughly justified, in order to ensure its transparency, verification and review. And so it is reflected in this report. As enshrined therein, the achievement of the objectives of the Structural and Investment Funds should not be hampered by economic governance mechanisms, which prevents them from being recognized in contributing to a stable macroeconomic environment and an efficient and results-oriented cohesion policy. In addition, in this report I wanted to highlight something that was not the subject of the Commission Communication: the role that Parliament had to play in democratising this decision much more. And, therefore, good institutional coordination is essential to ensure complementarity in the interaction between cohesion and good economic governance. In this regard, I have given particular attention to the participation of the European Parliament in the event of the activation of macro-conditionality, lamenting the Commission's guidelines, which do not contain any reference to it. Commission, Council and Parliament must engage in a structured dialogue, at interinstitutional level, ensuring constant and clear collaboration and an adequate flow of information throughout the process. Parliament must be informed immediately of any request for rescheduling and suspension of payments, so that it can express its position in a timely manner and that it be taken into account by the Commission, of whom we will demand accountability. We also call for an early warning approach to the Member States affected by rescheduling, while calling on the Commission to carry out, in close cooperation with the Member State concerned, a comprehensive analysis of all options other than the application of Article 23, which only has to be applied as an exceptional case and at the last minute. These are some of the principles and aspects and demands that I would like to highlight in this first intervention. It is therefore a report which I think is balanced and, moreover, that is aimed — and I set out in particular on this — for the fairest and most democratic application possible of what is contained in Article 23. I was against Article 23. Now is not the time for that discussion. Now the discussion is how Article 23 can be applied to make its application as fair and democratic as possible.

name: Younous Omarjee
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, it is on behalf of the REGI Committee that I speak to present the question of the simplification and effectiveness of cohesion policy for 2014-2020. I will leave it to my colleagues to give the impression on behalf of our group. With the new multi-year financial framework launched on 1 January 2014, a new period has begun for cohesion policy. Much has been done, as we all know, but just because certain progress - it is true - has not been achieved that we must therefore consider that our work is finished. Our legislative work, on the other hand, is only getting stronger with the implementation of the new period of cohesion policy planning and, with it, a number of concerns have arisen.  For almost two years now, the beneficiaries have told us about the difficulties they face on a daily basis. We, therefore, as legislators, are confronted with our role in observing and monitoring the implementation of this policy in all European regions. We intend to play this role fully, Commissioner, and that is why we have increased the number of hearings, exchanges of views and field missions. We need to do this not only to support the beneficiaries, but also to know what mistakes to avoid in the future and what we could correct either in the mid-term review or for the new programming period that needs to be well prepared.  About two weeks ago, the Committee on Regional Development held a hearing on simplification, and the observation is still the same: it is always very difficult to navigate the maze of administrative meanders. We must recognise, Commissioner, that the Commission is showing good will to solve this problem, and the creation of the group of independent experts is proof of this. The first meeting of this group took place - as you know - seven days ago and identified three main challenges for the coming year. This is a sign that some obstacles have been known to us for a very long time and also that work is progressing very quickly. I also tend to believe that we, the European parliamentarians, have indeed been aware of these problems for a very long time, and these obstacles on the way to an effective implementation of cohesion policy on the ground are still, admittedly, very numerous. This is true for fund management at European level, but it is also true at Member State level, at regional and local level. I would just like, if I may, to quote a sentence heard at our recent hearing. It has been said that each new group, every new group, more explanations and more expertise to navigate each new text, is needed. In reality, very often, no one finds themselves there because there is a tendency to complexity rather than simplification. The Juncker Commission's credo is to legislate less and legislate better, which amounts to simpler and more effective regulation. In this respect, the European Parliament, in its role as co-legislator, will also have to assess where we ourselves have complicated rules that are already complex and added sometimes superfluous layers.  We also know that there is a contradiction between the objective we all proclaim and the growing tendency to strengthen controls, to favour discipline, to monitor and punish. The less trust between the European institutions and the beneficiaries, the more red tape increases. We must also try to ensure that the principle of proportionality is respected. The larger the sums incurred or spent, the more complex the procedures can be, if only to ensure the appropriate use of the funds and avoid any risk of irregularities. And I will end, Commissioner, by telling you how committed we are to establishing a structured dialogue with our committee, of course, but also with all the actors, and in particular the Committee of the Regions.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you, it is a pleasure for me to be here this evening. I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Ruas, Mr Blanco López and Mr Jakovčić for the three important reports we are discussing today. I would also like to thank Mr Omarjee for his comments on simplification.  As you know, this Commission has been appointed with a clear mandate to work for a new beginning for Europe, based on ten major political priorities and, of course, the European Structural and Investment Funds actively contribute to many of these priorities, as is reflected in the three reports we are discussing today: the review of the Europe 2020 strategy , good economic governance and the current state of play of the EU strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Regions. Let me start by talking briefly about these reports, after which I will also refer to the current simplification process. Firstly, Mr Ruas's report, the EU 2020 strategy; the strategy targets five specific objectives in the following areas: employment, innovation, climate change and energy sustainability, education, as well as combating poverty and social exclusion. Unfortunately, the consequences of the economic crisis, such as rising unemployment and the very slow economic recovery, have been a real obstacle to achieving these objectives. In this context, the Commission has started a process of reflection on the future of this strategy. Last year we launched a public consultation which showed that the Europe 2020 strategy and its objectives are still very relevant, but also that we still have a long way to go to achieve our proposed objectives. I would like to welcome the suggestions by Mr Ruas, the rapporteur, on improving knowledge and the need for local and regional authorities, Member States and all stakeholders to take responsibility, and I urge you, surely, together, to continue to mobilise national parliaments in this regard. of these funds. These provisions have been established with the aim of increasing the efficiency of European funds and, in this context, partnership agreements and operational programmes have already been gended in line with country-specific recommendations. The European Commission will therefore only use its reprogramming powers when it can have a real impact on the implementation of country-specific recommendations. In the same vein, I would like to remind you that last week the Commission communication on the steps to be taken to complete Europe's economic and monetary union was adopted. As I have said before in this Chamber, if one of the conditions for a possible suspension of the Structural and Investment Funds is met, the European Commission will immediately inform Parliament, and I totally agree with Mr Blanco López in this respect. With regard to the Adriatic-Ionian macro-regional strategy, I am pleased to say that this is the third macro-regional strategy of the European Union. Exactly a year ago I was present in Milan to launch this strategy. It was adopted last year. It aims to promote sustainable economic and social prosperity in the region and contribute to the integration into the European Union of the western Balkan countries, and I welcome your report, Mr Jakovčić, which includes several valuable recommendations detailed. I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that we, the European Commission, are ready to help implement the strategy, but, in order to ensure its success, a few conditions are needed. Firstly, participating countries take responsibility and firm commitment in support of this strategy, allocating sufficient resources and administrative resources. Secondly, national and regional policies, investment plans and allocated funds must be in line with the objectives of the strategy and, thirdly, civil society must be effectively involved in the implementation of the strategy, as well as national and regional parliaments. You have also raised the possibility that these macro-regions will contribute more to solving and mitigating the consequences of the refugee crisis. I want to tell you that, indeed, I believe that we can exploit more to the extent that these macro-regions can contribute to this issue. I would just like to inform you on this subject that, together with the auditors, we have made a list of possibilities from the regional development, what kind of projects can be made from regional development funds for refugee accommodation, for mobile hospitals, sanitary facilities, water supply, in the medium and long term, and I want to reiterate that we are taking into account any proposal from the Member States, but it is indeed the obligation of the Member States to tell us to what extent I think it is necessary to change the financial allocations for this purpose. So far, we have only received a request from Italy and already EUR 220 million has been redirected from the Regional Development Fund to finance migrant accommodation centres and coastal patrols. In any case, I sent a letter to all the ministers of the European funds last week, informing them of these possibilities. With regard to simplification, I would like to assure you all and, in particular, Mr Omarjee, who raised this issue, that it is a common concern of us, the European Parliament and the European Commission, we want, like you, to ensure effective and efficient management of European funds. Simplification of funds is one of the Commission's objectives for better regulation and a European Union budget focused on results.  The High-Level Group on Simplification has been created, as you said, precisely for this purpose, has started to work and make recommendations for concrete actions that can maximise the potential for simplification in the current programming period. As you mentioned in your oral question, I can confirm that the high-level group will look at e-cohesion, access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises, which I think is a very important subject, cost simplification and excessive regulation, what we call the goldplating phenomenon at national level. You know very well that there are projects where 20-30 signatures are needed, but this is not a request from the European Commission. But I believe that a simplification of success also depends on the commitment of the Member States to simplify their own rules imposed at national level. I would like to continue working with the European Parliament. As you know, the REGI Committee was represented at the first meeting of the High Level Group by a Vice-President and of course we will inform Parliament of the work of the High Level Group on a regular basis.  I would also like to take this opportunity to launch your invitation, together, from the coming period, to think about the reform of this cohesion policy, post-2020 reform. I believe that this debate must start as early as next year. Thank you for your attention and I look forward to your debate and comments.

name: Dubravka Šuica
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the AFET Committee. – Mr. President, at the beginning I want to thank Mr. Jakovcic for such a good report, with which I have had the opportunity to cooperate since 2006 when we founded the Adriatic Euroregion. Back then, we were in completely different functions, in local, regional self-government. This strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian Macro-Region aims to enable the region's 70 million inhabitants to take advantage of closer cooperation in areas such as promoting the maritime economy, preserving the marine environment, completing transport and energy networks and fostering sustainable tourism. It is worth pointing out today that this is the first macroeconomic strategy of the European Union with such a share of non-EU countries such as Serbia, Montenegro, Albania, which are candidates, and Bosnia and Herzegovina as a potential candidate, and which cooperate with Member States such as Croatia, Greece, Italy and Slovenia. The former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Kosovo issue remains undefined.  I put special emphasis in the opinion for which I was in charge on behalf of the foreign affairs committee on the transport connections of states involved in road and railway infrastructure projects, including the Adriatic-Ionian corridor, and thus the Peljesac Bridge in the south of Croatia with the aim of reducing differences and shortcomings in the infrastructure of these countries.  And finally, I expect the strategy to come to life as soon as possible, I believe, given that Ms. Cretu has expressed her will on behalf of the Commission that this strategy can be implemented as soon as possible.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President; Commissioner Creu, macro-conditionality, that is, the possibility of imposing sanctions for non-compliance with deficit or debt targets, has been introduced into the Stability and Growth Pact since its signing, but moving it to cohesion policy is the biggest speculator and the biggest mistake the European Commission has made in its crisis policies in recent years. Firstly, because social and cohesion policy is the only policy of strong solidarity of distribution, of redistribution of income that the European Union has. Establishing, as I say, macro-conditionality in cohesion policy is not only a spectacle, but is an inapplicable error. You yourself have demonstrated this with the latest decisions that have been taken in the case of Greece. Secondly, because withdrawing funds means going against social cohesion means further damaging territorial convergence and also entails charging a countercyclical element of boosting economic growth by the European Union to the Member States that are having the worst time. We, from the Committee on Employment, therefore fully share Mr Blanco's report, thank him for his work and are absolutely sure that this objective of mitigating the effects of Article 23 is the right path for a better European Union, a better social union. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Am I to understand from your speech that you see this report as the key to socialist redistribution of wealth on a grand scale across the EU? Would you say that this is the key reason for this report: a socialist design for redistribution?

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto
text: "blue card" response. – It is true that redistribution is one of the hallmarks of the socialist project, but it is also one of the hallmarks of the social model. I understand that you do not understand this, precisely because of the Group to which you belong, because you do not understand the redistribution or signs, the DNA of the European project. What I do say is yes: that a well-designed cohesion policy favours redistribution and reduction of territorial divergences throughout the European Union, which I am very proud to defend from the Socialist Group.

name: Marco Affronte
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am speaking on the report on the Adriatic-Ionian strategy, for which I was the draftsman of the opinion of the ENVI Committee. We recognise the importance of the strategy and its four pillars, particularly as they insist on environments rich in biodiversity and ecosystems that are as important as they are sensitive and already subject to many anthropogenic impacts.  In the final report, which also has many interesting and positive ideas, we do not find some of the important recommendations that we have decided to make in the Committee on the Environment, such as that of the minimum target of 10% of the area of the Adriatic and Ionian Seas covered by marine protected areas by 2020, as indicated by international commitments and the framework directive on the strategy for the marine environment.  We reiterate that the promotion of the region's economic and social prosperity must not be pursued at the expense of ecological balance, biodiversity and natural resources. Some of the points in the report seem to run counter to this approach and concern us. We are talking about relifiers, major works, motorways of the sea and TEN-T. On the other hand, we welcome the acceptance of the amendment on concern about possible future drilling in the Adriatic.

name: Franc Bogovič
