text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the Commission for your – As shadow rapporteur for the Adriatic and Ionian Strategy, I would first of all like to thank my colleague Jakovčić for his excellent cooperation and quality document. We are talking about a third macro-region, which comprises a very diverse area: four countries that are members of the European Union, four countries that want to be. 70 million people live in this area, an area with very large differences within a region, within a country, and that is why we have set ourselves these key objectives to establish good cooperation within the macro-region, good development opportunities and to prepare good opportunities for the lives of all, especially young people in the region. The four pillars of this macro-region are basic: blue growth, that is to say, promoting sea-related economic growth, linked to the rest of the economy. Integration in the region, both in terms of transport corridors, rail, road, sea corridors, opportunities of north Adriatic port in the area.  We talked about energy connections, we also talked about the environment as a key parameter for a good living environment and, of course, sustainable tourism. The characteristics of this area are that it has been affected by all the ailment of today, both the extraordinary economic crisis and the refugee-migrant crisis. What is very problematic, however, is that today it is in the area, it has shown poor cooperation between these countries, even the Commission has had to call the leaders from these areas to start talking seriously. I therefore hope and want that this strategy, the implementation of this strategy with the help of the Commission, will provide the right basis so that the people of the area will really start to cooperate with each other and make economic development. In Slovenia we have a saying that you meet a friend in need, and in the area, first of all, countries should become friends with each other, and in Europe find that friend who will help better develop this area.

name: Constanze Krehl
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Thank you, Mr President, Thank you, Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Fernando Ruas.  He has presented an excellent report on cohesion policy and the review of the Europe 2020 strategy. On the one hand, this is an important inventory of what has already happened in recent years within the framework of structural policy and this strategy. On the other hand, it is already the beginning of a debate on a future cohesion policy, and we must indeed begin to do so now. With the new funding period, we see very clearly that investments in infrastructure projects, including telecommunications projects, investment in research and technology, support for SMEs, sustainable development, the important components of this cohesion policy in investing in the labour market and also the fight against unemployment are important components of this very cohesion policy, to single out just a few issues. We will continue to need such investments in the future in order to support the regions, towns and cities. This cannot be done only through an investment plan, as presented by Mr Juncker. This really requires the involvement of local people in the regions and the direct appeal of citizens in the regions. Only cohesion policy can do that.  The fact that all regions can participate in it according to their capacity is also an important part of such a cohesion policy based on solidarity, which we need in the future. However, our efforts in the old parliamentary term to simplify procedures in the new funding period seem to have been only partially successful, with complaints coming from both the administrative bodies and the applicants. This cannot be ignored, especially when you consider that we say that we have flattened administrative costs in the European Regional Fund.  If we are then shown in the hearing that we now need a thick book to explain what the administrative costs are, then that is over. I therefore welcome the establishment of these high-level working groups in the Commission on simplification. I would very, very quickly very quickly like to see very concrete proposals for real simplification.

name: Andrew Lewer
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, ‘Off Target: the case for bringing EU regional policy back home’ by Open Europe, is, I believe, the best policy document on this subject that there is. It could form the blueprint for radical change without decreasing the funding going to newer Member States. I have called on the UK Government to include these Open Europe proposals in its reform and renegotiation discussions. After all, we are talking about a third of the EU’s total budget. If the possibility of Brexit does not mean that it is time to push for big changes, then when is? At the moment, the policy brings to mind Punch magazine of 1895 and George du Maurier’s curate’s egg: ‘I am afraid you have got a bad egg, Mr Jones’ – ‘Oh no, my Lord, I assure you that some parts of it are excellent!’ Thus, the ECR Group welcomes Mr Ruas’s report, but it should be just the start. Ultimately, I want regional development that is time—limited, not permanent, so that the cohesion money is used rightly, as an investment and not as a way of life. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. Listening to your lyrical speech, I would like to ask you what reforms do you mean in particular? And I also understand, of course, your generous offer as far as the British Government's push is concerned, but really, we always say reform, reform, but what reforms do you expect in particular? For example, in my country, Hungary, despite cohesion efforts, 40% of the population currently lives below the minimum wage and 5% of the population is starving.

name: Andrew Lewer (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – That is quite difficult to explain briefly, but it is about not shuffling money around from one country to another, and not particularly that large-scale recipient countries give money to the Commission that the Commission then gives them back and tells them what to do. Rather, it is focusing on countries like yours, in situations like yours, so that cohesion achieves sustainable economic growth and lifts people out of that situation for the benefit of everybody within the EU – on a limited basis, not forever.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης –
text: Mr President, I would like to say that the three reports enable us to have a meaningful debate on cohesion policy. My group and I have personally worked very hard, with constructive proposals. Some of the reports we will vote for, others we will not vote against, but it is an opportunity to look at the substance, and the bottom line is that in the years that have passed, inequality has increased, unemployment has increased, poverty has increased, investment has decreased, regional disparities have increased, social exclusion has increased. Cohesion policy has therefore also proved to be inadequate in the report prepared by the Commission services. It needs strengthening, not weakening, and the question is: Does the Commission and its proposals strengthen cohesion policy? The objectives you have set are not being met, either in the field of research, development, or in the case of the non-leaving of the children of poor families from schools, and this absurd Article 23 of macroeconomic conditionality, which Parliament rejected when it was discussed in the previous term, imposes disparities at the expense of the countries most in need of cohesion policies.  So I expect you, in your reply, to tell us what you will do to strengthen cohesion policy in favour of weak regions and social strata.

name: Davor Škrlec
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Club. – Madam President, I greet and congratulate my colleague Jakovcic on the exhaustive report and quality results in the negotiations. The European approach based on macro-regional cooperation is more cost-effective and effective than the 28 national approaches and it is this report that is of great importance, as it recognises and underlines the importance of macro-regional strategies, which are a tool for European integration and an example of cross-border cooperation with a view to territorial cohesion of areas that share common challenges. In order to achieve a sustainable and stable Adriatic-Ionian macroregion, it is essential to enhance sustainable cross-border cooperation and quality macroregion management. To maximise potential, cooperation between macro-regions needs to be achieved.  This is the only way we will optimally achieve the fulfilment of the core objectives of each macro-regional strategy. Optimal exploitation of the potential of renewable energy sources and transport connectivity within the macro-climate itself contribute to the stated objectives. It is necessary to provide intermodal infrastructure in order to connect states and develop energy, but we should take into account the protection of the environment and the sustainability of individual projects. I am extremely pleased with the compromise reached where my amendment regarding oil and gas exploration and exploitation in the Adriatic has been respected, especially in areas of high risk to the environment. In conclusion, the Adriatic-Ionian Macro-Region has high potential for the development of the economy of the entire macro-region, the potential to create new green jobs that are crucial in the fight against unemployment.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will vote on two important reports: firstly, the report by my colleague Blanco López, which re-proposes a controversial issue of cohesion policy, the mechanism of stopping the disbursement of regional funds if the governments do not comply with the economic recommendations of Brussels. I would have expected a bolder report that would address the very rationale of macro-conditionality.  We have the opportunity to improve the text with an amendment proposed by the 5-Star Movement and the GUE, calling for the investment clause to be revised in order to allow them, both regional and national, co-financed through the ESI funds, to be excluded from the calculation of the deficit. The 5-star Movement, the GUE and even the Spanish People's Party and the French Socialists also proposed this amendment in the REGI Committee, but it has been hit by compromises. Everything is on the record, everything is demonstrable.  The revision of the clause is not a battle of the right or the left, but of common sense, called for by the regions and also highlighted by the PPE in a resolution of October 2013. For reasons unknown to us, some colleagues, including Italians, have withdrawn their signatures. The amendment is therefore in danger. I appeal to my fellow Members, especially the Italians, because it is possible to resume signatures until tomorrow. This is the time to move from the words of the speeches made in plenary, in committee, to action.  Tomorrow we will also vote on the Jakovčić reaction, which has many positive ideas, but contains critical issues. Critical issues related to references and projects of the Juncker plan and therefore projects ranging from the revamping of the Ilva to the relifiers and the Tav. There are references to pipelines, easily identifiable in TAP. These pipelines have a significant environmental impact in the face of a visible economic and strategic advantage. Only if these references are withered will we vote in favour of the report tomorrow.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI). Madam President, cohesion policy is the European Union's main investment policy in order to develop and achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. It also provides for inclusive growth and a reduction in inequalities between Europe's regions; A typical example of this aerology is Greece. We are destroying a country's economy, we are granting it a loan on usury terms, we are giving this loan in instalments and we are under the illusion that there will be growth.  We argue that cohesion policy will create jobs and reduce unemployment. But how can this be done when thousands of unemployed people, especially in long-suffering Greece, are being added to the thousands of unemployed illegal immigrants arriving in Europe? We claim that we will create specialised jobs, and Mr Juncker is even worried about how talented young people who come from third countries will find work and he does not care about...  (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would first of all like to thank the rapporteur, Mr López, for the very excellent work done, because he has tried to take into account the common starting points of all factions across Parliament. A much-needed thank you, and I would like to say on the subject that, as regards Mr López's report, the purpose of this report was to set out guidelines for the application of Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation, the current text of which leaves the European Commission quite a considerable scope for interpretation. This is in itself very unfortunate, given the potential consequences for cohesion policy actors. I would just like to remind you that the European Parliament was well aware of this when it adopted the general regulation in the previous period, and the form of Article 23 was then adopted critically from the European Parliament and the Commission promised to issue the following guidelines.  Our joint effort in drafting the report on these guidelines was to set out the space in which the European Commission can move in the application of Article 23, in particular by naming and responding to the risks that occur. What is crucial is the requirement that the Commission be as judicious as possible in applying this provision and that reprogramming should only take place in the most necessary cases. There should always be scope for expression from local and regional authorities. In the draft report, we also talk about the fact that the Council should be in a special composition for cohesion policy to decide under Article 23. Last but not least, the European Parliament should also be drawn into the application of Article 23 in the form of supervisory exercise, which is certainly an incentive for the future period.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for the work he has done on the strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region. I believe that the launch of this strategy represents a very important turning point for cohesion policy, anchored in the principles and rules established for previous macro-regional strategies, but inevitably forward-looking and, above all, in the contexts of the regions involved.  The macro-region itself, already in the territories it includes, has many characteristics of innovation: Member States of the European Union and countries that border on the Union, and which look to Europe sitting around a table planning, designing and coordinating growth and development with full respect for the resources they possess, most of which come from the Adriatic-Ionian basin that this strategy places at the heart of production activities. The challenge now is to integrate the strategy with the Structural Funds of the 2014-2020 agenda. Member States and regions must align policies and their funds and incorporate the EUSAIR strategy into EU programmes. In short, we need that fruitful multi-level interaction that has already been highlighted in the drafting of this strategy and that has been really fruitful. I would like to thank Commissioner Crețu and, of course, I welcome the recent approval of the ADRION programme, which contributes EUR 118 million to the implementation of projects in the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region and, more importantly, it is a testimony that shows precisely that strategy does not mean, in this case, just theory.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, after thanking the rapporteur, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Jakovčić would like to point out that the Adriatic-Ionian Sea macroregion is a conquest of the peoples of the region and local authorities. It brings together regions of eight countries, where unemployment and over-indebtedness are high, regions undergoing a violent fiscal adjustment, and this applies mainly to the Greek Ionian Sea. What might be the answer? But of course growth, growth with job creation, and in particular, blue growth that focuses on marine fisheries, aquaculture, blue technologies, maritime governance. Macro-regional cooperative formations must be strengthened, tourism and fisheries links must be made and infrastructure and, above all, ports should be built. In July I visited Zakynthos and had the opportunity to speak to the Regional Council of the Ionian Islands about the new opportunities for blue development and the Adriatic-Ionian macroregion. That's the direction I'm going to stand by.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Article 23 of the Common Provisions Regulation is a destructive mechanism that further entrenches austerity policies and threatens to undermine the goals of cohesion policy. Both Sinn Féin and GUE/NGL Group are fundamentally opposed to this mechanism on a number of fronts. The provision is fundamentally undemocratic and was imposed despite strong opposition from this Parliament. Despite a few token concessions in negotiation, the Commission and Council have further diluted the powers of the European Parliament in imposing this mechanism. We do not accept that the purpose of Article 23 is to achieve a more sustainable and efficient cohesion policy: it is about imposing antisocial diktats to strengthen and deepen a failing monetary union. By linking investment co-financing through European structural and investment funds to national deficits, it imposes austerity policies on local and regional authorities for budgetary issues beyond their control. Forced re-programming and suspension of funds under the provision will cause significant harm, particularly to vulnerable regions and Member States still suffering from the economic and social crisis. My resolution demands that the Commission should not use Article 23 and that it should immediately move for its review. It should be replaced by a democratic mechanism involving Parliament and the effective communities and partners.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I see the report on the macroeconomic conditionality mechanism as an important and well-designed and well-designed and a rapporteur as a constructive policy listening to all opinions. I note that the mechanism of macroeconomic conditionality is a highly controversial tool for economic governance in the EU. The principle that member states' economic governance errors will be punished by reducing the possibilities for implementing their cohesion policy seems strangely. What is even more bizarre is that, in reality, the mistakes of the national government will be suffered primarily by local and regional authorities directly implementing cohesion policy and closest to every citizen.  Our aim was to narrow the scope of the conditionality mechanism. If we can no longer reject this mechanism, then at least we must ensure that its application would, as little as possible, undermine the important objective of the Union, cohesion policy.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, regional development and cohesion policies are exactly about preparing the ground for the United States of Europe. We spend meeting after meeting redistributing taxpayers’ money to facilitate this state-building. The EU wants to use the Europe 2020 programme to create jobs, innovation, combat climate change, encourage sustainable energy and fight poverty. These are all functions of the nation—state. The EU is not a nation—state.  These measures are simply the EU superstate rearing its ugly head. It wants socialist wealth redistribution on a grand scale across the Union. It wants to set the priorities of all of Europe in a United States of Europe. We say: no, no, no.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI). Madam President, the establishment of the so-called macro-regions of the European Union, such as that of the Adriatic-Ionian, aims to create an arena of privileged profitability for monopolies amid sharp competition between the urban classes of the countries of the region. More favourable conditions are being created for greater group penetration into new gold-bearing sectors such as the blue economy, energy networks and connected transport. A prerequisite for these projects is the complete surrender to the large capital of Greek ports, railways and other vital infrastructure promoted by the Greek government. All this with funds from the so-called cohesion policy of the European Union, for which he has been appointed a supervisor of the European Parliament in order to monitor whether these in Greece are, as he says, rightly directed to business groups, at the same time as all labour rights that have been left standing up to egg the profits of business groups. But the people can spoil their plans by deciding to clash with the European Union, their monopolies and their power to become the owner of the wealth they produce.

name: Lambert van Nistelrooij (PPE).
text: I have a slightly different story from the last two speakers, because the reports of rapporteurs Ruas, Blanco López and Yakovčić show that the agreed EU 2020 targets and the European structural and investment funds go hand in hand. With the €360 billion we are investing in the heart of the EU 2020 targets and within the agreements of the Stability and Growth Pact. This includes, as Mrs Creţu also indicated, knowledge, innovation, digital economy, small and medium-sized enterprises, low-carbon and blue economy, energy and social inclusion, including for refugees. This is actually the end of this debate for 2016 and the adjustments of the multianne financial framework and the EU 2020 agreements. At the beginning of 2016, more figures are on the table. But at the same time, we also see that there are problems with implementation. Procedures for applications have become too heavy. Control density is also increasing. The controls are piling up. That is why I ask Commissioner Creţu: would you like to make proposals for simplification soon, where necessary? The High Level Working Group, led by Vice-President and Commissioner Siim Kallas, can be helpful here. The EP has already voted in favour of interim technical adjustments to the regulations. We have already prepared a resolution, courtesy of My Colleague Andrey Novakov, which can be voted on after further depth this year.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, First of all, I welcome commissioner Crețu's announcement here in this House this evening about the use of EU resources and cohesion policy in the service of the refugee crisis. This was also a request from Parliament. I hope that more can be done, especially for those countries that are struggling to close the EU cohesion policy programme and to use some of those resources for immigrants and the solution that will be adopted in the individual countries.  The second issue concerns macro-country. I believe that Mr President, i.e. the commission of the European Committee on The Blanco López has done everything possible to bring a good report. But let us face it, among ourselves, at least among those who have knowledge of this matter: it is an old debate, already overtaken by the facts, by the decisions we have only recently taken on Greece and by the way in which the Commission itself is adopting the flexibility clause on investments. We must work and push for cohesion policy to help Europe to relaunch a policy of public and private investment in employment and employment.  Finally, very important things have been said about simplification in this debate and I believe that we must insist, because cohesion policy remains the most guarded policy in Europe. There is no supervised European public policy like cohesion policy. We must make it simpler, more able to build relationships with interlocutors, but also more monitored.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Given that the Europe 2020 strategy is the European Union's overarching long-term strategy for growth and jobs based on the five objectives we know, and after examining the relevant documents, the following questions arise: when will the European Parliament be informed by the Commission on the results orientation and the concrete contribution of cohesion policy to the Europe 2020 objectives for the 2007-2013 programming period? The conclusions reached could be useful in the ongoing implementation of the strategy and its potential evaluation. Is there a substantive responsibility and a work plan in the short and medium term for better implementation of European Union funds? How was the selection process conducted in terms of substance? Has a work plan been set out for both the short-term and long-term structural reform support services, which officially started work on 1 July 2015 and will provide technical assistance to Member States with a view to implementing structural reforms and country-specific recommendations more effectively? What activities has the service undertaken in the July-October period, i.e. to date?

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the Ruas and Blanco López reports seek to strengthen cohesion policy, and that is positive. And I like them to look at the most disadvantaged and crisis-hit regions, but I do not like the Ruas report toliate the effectiveness of the Structural and Investment Funds with economic governance, according to the European Semester. That means more austerity and fewer utilities. I recognise Mr Blanco's quest for balance in trying to limit the application of macroeconomic conditionality, but whether or not the time to discuss it ends up institutionalizing Article 23, and I do not like that because, among other things, it may end up penalizing local and regional institutions, those closest to citizenship. We must safeguard the investments of regional policy from decisions and, perhaps, from the mistakes of States, and also from the austerity recommendations of the European Semester.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have always believed that one must speak when he has something to say. That's why I initiated this oral question back in June, and I'm glad we're debating it today.  Ask any engineer outside and he will tell you that the simpler one thing is, the better it works. That is why I want simpler rules for European funds, simpler rules for the management and control of European projects.  I'm sure that's what business and people outside want. I want to believe that the reports, resolutions and questions we take in this chamber have a real effect on people in Europe, on business in Europe.  I would like to congratulate Commissioner Creţu on his efforts to reduce the administrative burden, to reduce red tape. Unfortunately, however, we need results as quickly as possible and not at the end of the programming period. Let's adopt standardised public procurement across the European Union! Let's apply electronic cohesion to reduce queue waiting times to reduce red tape so we can ask for fewer documents! We can do it. Let us adopt simpler procedures for cross-border cooperation so that Schengen does not interfere with the Member States. Europe needs this. We need this. More Europe does not mean more bureaucracy.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – Madam President, on many occasions this House has stressed that, considering the fundamental relevance of the objectives of the cohesion policy, beneficiaries should not suffer the consequences of bad economic governance at national level. Cohesion policy is, by definition, a policy aimed at reducing development gaps between regions and is based on a programme, which should be a long-term programme when it comes to the most important projects.  It is evident that the application of macroeconomic conditionality goes exactly in the opposite direction. It risks widening development gaps and also undermining the predictability which the beneficiaries strongly need. The provisions of Article 23 of Common Provision Regulation must therefore be used only as a last resort, when it can be demonstrated that such measures are not detrimental for the objectives of the policy, but are in fact beneficial.

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am a clear supporter of cohesion and structural policy, on one condition: that cohesion policy also remains regional policy. This means that Europe's regions, cities and municipalities, as well as civil society groups, must participate in the opportunities offered by this policy area. Participation here means not only having access to the financial sources, but also being able to participate in the programming and implementation of the programme. And that is where we have our problems at the moment. I hear many complaints that there was little flexibility in programming, that tight guidelines were made, that national concerns often took precedence over what the regions wanted, but that there are also different rules for programme management for the various fund areas, which make it almost impossible to link – as we actually wanted – from different funds, and that the bureaucratic burden of implementing the project has increased, not reduced. We are now at the end of the second year of the new programming period, but many programmes have not yet taken effect. If we do not manage to resolve the problems raised relatively quickly – and that is what our question serves today – then I see difficult times ahead for the continuation of cohesion, structural and regional policy beyond 2020.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to make a few comments, the first on the Adriatic-Ionian macro-regional strategy. I believe that this will be an opportunity to demonstrate and implement on the ground the principle of territorial cohesion which, in my opinion, after being introduced in Lisbon, is being put into practice in this field.  My second point concerns the issue of simplification. In the meantime, Commissioner, simplification must be directed towards giving priority to content and results over the exasperated form. Another point is that the principle of proportionality cannot, however, make us forget the attention paid to quality expenditure that applies to everyone, including small projects.  The third point is that simplification must first and foremost be an instrument of support for managing authorities. I would like to say a moment about the Structural Funds, about macroeconomic conditionality: I would like to point out that it is the main instrument. (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Cohesion policy is undoubtedly one of the eu's most pro-development and pro-investment policies. However, I am convinced that by simplifying this policy, we could increase its effectiveness and achieve even better results. Last year, more than 1,500 irregularities were reported in cohesion policy projects. However, it should be borne in mind that the huge number of these irregularities is not the result of the bad will of the beneficiaries, but of a misunderstanding of the guidelines and rules. Simplification of language as well as clearer formulation of expectations towards beneficiaries would certainly be reflected in subsequent audits. The Commission should also avoid making changes to the rules during the duration of the projects. Such a practice not only imposes additional costs on beneficiaries, but also involves a lot of work, which in turn does not allow them to concentrate on the project. There is also frustration at the lack of an adequate analysis of the financial impact of the legislation introduced and the lengthy procedures. It cannot be that the procedural costs are disproportionate to the activities of the project and that the duration of the procedures makes it less reasonable. I am also in favour of increasing the flexibility of cohesion policy based on mutual trust between the European Commission and the Member States. Today, unfortunately, this trust is not enough.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Madam High Commissioner, acknowledging the importance of all the reports discussed, I nevertheless point out in particular the creation of a third European macro-regulation. The Adriatic-Ionian strategy covers four member states and four aspirant countries for full membership in the European Union. For them, such a project can and should be assisted on the Euro-immigration path. Macro-financial differences in economic development between members and non-members of the European Union are large. The transport infrastructure of these others is poorly developed. So far, only Croatia realizes the Adriatic-Ionian motorway project. I hope that soon the European Union will stimulate the project, because along with political connections, transport routes as well as energy corridors need to be developed. That is why joint energy projects, such as the Adriatic-Ionian pipeline, should be among the priorities. The implementation of the strategy should involve all interested parties in a transparent and comprehensive manner in order to foster social cohesion, economic development and environmental sustainability. If successful, the Adriatic-Ionian Strategy will contribute to the further integration of the internal market and the stability of this area, which represents the interest of all members of the European Union.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would just like to ask you, Commissioner, about the simplification of the European Funds. It is a subject of concern to many countries, many territories, it is an eminently political subject. Too many small project owners are now discouraged by the number of coins, by the procedures they are asked to pay, by the cost of management or the time to pay, and I think it is important to think about this simplification of the European Funds if we want Europe to be better understood tomorrow.  Some who should legitimately benefit from European funds now prefer to use banks. Of course, we need controls , that is the role of our institution - but it is not only control, we also need the will to distribute European money. I would like you to have an answer simply on the working group that has been set up by the Commission on this subject. It seems that there is a high-level working group. Can you elaborate on that?

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Article 23 of the Regulation on Common Provisions is penalising, which clearly contradicts the spirit of cohesion policy. Economic macro-conditionality has been incorporated into that regulation, making European funds hostage to circumstances, often created by the European Union itself and other institutions. This is the case of the well-known troika.  It is worth remembering that since 2008, asymmetries between European regions have increased. We all agree on good governance and we all advocate transparency and accountability, which we do not all want is a double penalty of countries and regions that need the Structural Funds to ensure their economic growth, job creation and social inclusion. In some cases we have the triple penalty, as is the case with the outermost regions.  In fact, Article 23 itself is a policy of austerity.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: – Dear Madam President, dear Colleagues, One of our guiding principles when creating the framework for cohesion policy 2014-2020 was to make EU cohesion policy more effective and effective. Progress has been made towards simplification, but the administrative burden on the extremes of cohesion policy is still unacceptably high. This is particularly true of public procurement. Not coincidentally, this is the area where the error rate is extremely high, and this often results from the complexity and ambiguous interpretation of the specifications.  Among the proposals made in the current oral question, I would now like to draw attention to the need to find an optimal balance between simplification and accountability. It is important that potential beneficiaries of cohesion policy submit all the data and information during the application process that demonstrates their right to UNION support and, where appropriate, in public procurement, meet the requirements of conflicts of interest, while not expecting information that only complicates the process and complicates its implementation, and is ultimately a barrier to effectiveness.

name: Massimo Paolucci (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, macro-regions represent an important institutional innovation, a concrete instrument for reducing the distance between Europe and its citizens. The Ionian-Adriatic macro-region is a real opportunity for development: it includes an area of great cultural and environmental value, an extraordinary tourist district, an East-West/North-South bridge, a bridge of peace and cooperation with great commercial potential.  There is no sustainable development of the macro-region without an adequate transport infrastructure network, a two-way south-north/east-west network. That is why, together with 90 colleagues, I have tabled an amendment, which I would ask you to support, for the completion of the Adriatic-Ionian motorway to the south, going beyond Ravenna. I will end by recalling my question on drilling. In my opinion, they are in breach of specific European provisions and are irreconcilable with the development of the macro-region.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (
text: PPE). Madam President, I propose five simple thoughts that will help to increase absorption, especially now that we are dealing with bureaucracy. First of all, the convergence of procedures throughout cohesion policy should proceed quickly, so that we have a single management framework and thus not confuse either the beneficiaries or the managing authorities. Then avoid multiple controls, which also have dubious results in tackling fraud, while at the same time having an immediate and exemplary response to methodical fraud. To have zero tolerance for corruption, to use all means to fight corruption at all levels of the European Union. To proceed immediately with the implementation of the 'e-Cohesion', which will also help to reduce the management burden but will also allow the electronic exchange of data between beneficiaries and managing authorities. Finally, consider setting up a register of beneficiaries and, in the long term, even a register of contractors, in order to reduce the red tape of submitting programmes to the European Union and monitoring funded projects. In this way we will be able to facilitate absorption but above all we will be able to facilitate the achievement of the objective, which is none other than growth and jobs.

name: Werner Kuhn (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Ladies and gentlemen, the Adriatic-Ionian region is currently in the spotlight, including the refugee crisis. And I think that this own-initiative report is really designed to make us think in principle about how we can economically support the countries that are most affected – whether that is Slovenia, Italy in the southern region, or even Greece. And the Structural Funds, which are set up by the European Union, are, of course, excellent in this respect. We have a budget of EUR 147 billion. Of this, more than 50 billion goes to the countries that are less than 75% of gross national product in their economic output. It is very important that we focus on these investment initiatives in this way. Whether these are erDF funds, transport infrastructure , a prerequisite for economic development – can be located there, small or medium-sized enterprises can be located there and additional investment aid can be provided. The retraining of workers, which can be financially supported there in the ESF Fund. People must also have a future there, in the tourist sector – I am a member of the Committee on Fisheries. We need to invest in fishing ports. We must invest in the small craft enterprises that have a chance there. Only tourism and fisheries together are, so to speak, the only gainers to be supported here. I think it is incredibly important that we regain confidence for Europe. regain confidence, with more growth, more jobs and the fight against youth unemployment.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Madam Chairman, I welcome the Commissioner and thank all my colleagues for their excellent reports and messages on the importance of cohesion policy for the daily lives of our citizens. In addition to investment and development, cohesion policy has many additional values that help strengthen the European Union. Cohesion policy brings together European and national policies, directs us to implement reforms, strengthen the single market, partnership, cooperation, modernisation, transparent state administration and good economic governance. That is why we have an obligation to do our best together to make cohesion policy work in practice and meet its objectives. We must do everything to make sure that there is no decommitment and that we successfully and quickly realize projects. Hundreds of pages of instructions, too many different rules for each of the programmes are moving cohesion policy away from our citizens, young people, entrepreneurs, non-profit organisations, scientists. They ask me, they ask all of us, is your goal that we use these funds and realize ideas, why are the terms of the EU tender the most complicated and least adapted to our needs? Therefore, I call on the Commission and all of us to accelerate simplification, to help all countries to provide national funding more, to think about how to achieve a greater level of coordination and link between cohesion policy and all EU policies and also to help the realisation of macro-regional strategies.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, as a result of the economic and financial crisis that some States are experiencing, the funds that give part to cohesion policy and which are intended to finance projects aimed at promoting it have taken on a decisive importance. They have guaranteed investment capacity to relaunch the economy of countries with macroeconomic imbalances. Economic governance recommendations should take this into account and ensure that regions are safeguarded as receivers of these funds.  In this mid-term review of Europe 2020, the unequal impact of the crisis should be taken into account. The different territorial and social characteristics determined the capacity for differentiated resilience, taking into care about youth unemployment in the outermost regions. Multi-level governance mechanisms should recognise regional and local authorities' capacity to intervene. I'll end up with an alert. Although operational programmes are agreed, their implementation is still incipient and has generated difficulties.

name: Σοφία Σακοράφα (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say from the outset that I categorically reject any link between cohesion policy and economic governance and oppose macroeconomic conditionality. I emit a distress signal about its negative effects, especially in the face of a severe economic crisis. Its implementation violates the fundamental principles of the European Union for the development and well-being of citizens, undermines the core of cohesion policy which advocates the redistribution of wealth and solidarity, is an obstacle to the equal treatment of States, undermines the equal implementation of cohesion policy, is a hindrance to hereticality and multi-level governance, brings about a double and unfair sanction in the context of fiscal consolidation and finally strengthens the toolbox of tough memorandum measures.  Ladies and gentlemen, macroeconomic conditionality is not just a wrong choice but a dangerous choice. It weakens the development effort and turns cohesion policy into a guinea pig with full allegiance to an almighty neoliberal compulsion. I call on you, even now, to immediately reverse its implementation.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Pepe Blanco has refused to ask him a question about his social cohesion report. It seems to me of very little democratic quality that you refuse to debate in this House a crucial report for the future of Spain. I was going to tell you, Mr Blanco, that cohesion policy is not just big projects. It should be a solidarity investment tool in the most needy regions. That is why we table an amendment to ensure that social cohesion takes over the needs of these regions and does not pose an austitarian threat to local and regional authorities. For the final report to oppose sanctions and the general logic of economic governance. Will you vote, Mr Blanco, in favour of an amendment to ensure that investment clauses are reviewed to allow regional investments, through the Structural and Investment Funds, not to compute on the calculation of regional deficits?

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we agree with the strategic objectives of cohesion policy. What we cannot understand is why the poorest countries and regions continue to diverge from the European average. This is the case for Portugal, which has not stopped diverging from the EU average in terms of GDP per capita since it came into operation.  Something is therefore wrong. There is no cohesion. Policies do not work because the macroeconomic framework is not consistent with regional development policies, i.e. austerity policies, public spending restraint, whether good or bad, do not allow the establishment of virtuous dynamics of local or regional development.  I can give you examples of projects that do not leave the paper because there is no funding, because the bank prefers to speculate. We can see funds that were not used in Portugal because of the impositions of the troika and the necessary adjustment, aiming at the so-called consolidation of public finances.  And the result is in sight. After almost 30 years of integration, Portugal is poorer, more dependent and indebted.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – I have listened very carefully to your comments and questions and I would like to refer briefly to the reports. Mr Ruas' report, the EU 2020 strategy and discussions on the Europe 2020 strategy and a long-term vision of it are ongoing. Last month, the European Commission held a policy debate within the College and is currently in the process of collecting contributions from stakeholders and, of course, the report is an important contribution in this regard. You will receive them as soon as possible. With regard to Mr Blanco López's report, as I mentioned earlier in my presentation, I would like to reconfirm that we will apply the powers of the reprogramming committee only under the current regulation; You are well aware that this has been voted on by the European Parliament and the Council, as co-legislators, and of course we will be in constant contact, as the European Commission, with the European Parliament.  With regard to Mr Jakovčić's report on the strategy for the Adriatic-Ionian region, I would like to highlight, in particular, one issue that was addressed by Mr Jakovčić: if we want to have results within the objectives proposed by the strategy, then the firm commitment and responsibility of all stakeholders is absolutely necessary. I would like to make a few more comments, because there has been a lot of discussion and I really appreciate all the contributions. I would like to say to Mr Bogovič that, with regard to Slovenia, we are aware of the enormous challenge on the Member States. I believe that Slovenia is remarkably coping with the current situation, and Sunday's summit was indeed an exercise in solidarity between the countries facing this unique situation, and I would like to congratulate the national, local, people authorities, on this effort. The European Commission is at the disposal of all Member States to help and to see to what extent we can contribute to having synergies between the Regional Development Fund, we are working closely with Mrs Thyssen, the Social Fund and also with Mr Avramopoulos, who is responsible for the Asylum and Migration Fund. I particularly wanted to make this point because Slovenia is a small country which, fortunately, is doing remarkably well with this problem.  Many of the speakers, among colleagues, raised the issue of bureaucracy. It is, indeed, a big problem. I would like everyone who can make their contribution to come up with proposals. As I said at the beginning, I think we will have to talk about what cohesion policy will look like after 2020, because now we have this Regulation, which is sometimes very complicated, but we have to do everything we can and, for this programming period, maximise the impact of European funds. I do not agree with those who talk about the fact that cohesion policy would be a transfer or an act of charity, it is an exercise in solidarity, which translates into a lot of visible things and hundreds of jobs, and I would link myself here to the example of Greece that several speakers have raised, Mr Papadimoulis. Greece is the country where we can practically see this contribution of cohesion policy. He asked me how cohesion policy could create jobs. I want to tell you that cohesion policy has created hundreds of thousands of jobs in Greece since 1981, when Greece was a member of the European Union, and you can see in any of Greece's regions motorways made for European money. We have done more than a thousand kilometres in five regions of Greece, not even a single kilometre was made without European funds: motorways, roads, schools, bridges, such as the one linking the Peloponnese with mainland Greece. So the results of cohesion policy are visible in Greece and, as you know, I personally came to the REGI Committee to adopt the exceptional measures. I believe that now, with this 100% co-financing for Greece, there is no longer any excuse to unlock major projects such as the Thessaloniki metro or waste management projects, because, as you know, after you approved these exceptional measures in the European Parliament and were also approved by the Council, Greece received this liquidity injection , so I congratulate you once again for all the reports. I would just like to add that I am very grateful for the European Parliament's support and contribution to the simplification agenda and I would like to sure Members that the Commission will continue its dialogue with Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and other stakeholders because in fact it is a common and our common goal is to have effective implementation. This is the most important thing. We have done all the regulation but implementation in many houses – in most of the houses – is 100% the responsibility of Member States.

name: Ivan Jakovčić
text: Rapporteur. – Dear Madam Commissioner, I want to tell you right from the beginning that there are high expectations for you. You are a woman who knows this macroregion well and I know that our cooperation so far has been going exactly in the direction that is favorable for this macroregion, and I want to thank you for the first funds that are already foreseen through the ADRION program, 118 million euros, for the development of macro-regional cooperation and for the realization of the Adriatic-Ionian strategy.  I believe it's a good start. However, our expectations are far higher. Our expectations when we talk about structural or cohesion policy are extremely large, you have mentioned Greece yourself at the moment, but other countries also have a need for what you can do for these countries and for the whole macroregion. Also, I want to point out that perhaps the key basic problem that I see in the future is who will own (owner), how we will solve the ownership of this macro-regional strategy and otherwise macro-regional strategies.  This is a key problem, because after we adopt this report, after everything we have all done together, how we will further manage the processes. In this context, I think we have to make a very precise decision, because we leave everything to the states. leave in some way only to the Commission or only to Parliament, to Parliament most likely not, but leaving it only to the states will not solve the problem. We've seen it now that we're talking about the refugee crisis.  So, I direct you to think carefully all together about how we will lead this process in the future so that this macro-regional strategy, and of course everyone else, has its success at the end of this whole political process.

name: Fernando Ruas
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, just to take the opportunity, to thank all the colleagues who have come forward to support the report that I am the rapporteur, i believe that, despite it being coherent and affirmative, it naturally includes various ideas and guidelines that came from other political groups, which I considered relevant and which have enriched the original document. So i thank the shadow rapporteurs and all the colleagues who have decided to make amendments and there have been 191 amendments.  Thank you also to the Commissioner for her words and I would like to thank her for her clarity of analysis and for her success also in recognising that the five objectives of the strategy are far from being achieved. I would also like to thank you for the words and for having taken on many of my concerns that are in the report, especially those which are related to the strengthening of the feeling of co-ownership of the strategy by the agents on the ground, especially local and regional authorities, but also of national and regional parliaments. We also want, as the Commissioner rightly said, that strengthening multi-level governance, in addition to increasing the sense of co-ownership of the strategy, greatly improves its effectiveness and, consequently, also its results.  Finally, I would like to conclude with the certainty that this debate has contributed, in our opinion, in a comprehensive political-partisan and territorial way, on the one hand, but also in a positive and consistent way, on the other, to the joint interinstitutional dialogue and reflection which we have started in this Plenary today on the revision of the Europe 2020 strategy, after the public consultation process carried out during 2014.

name: José Blanco López
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, thank you all very much for your reflections. This is, I repeat, a balanced report aimed at a fair and balanced implementation of the possible mechanism of Article 23. Throughout my political life, if there is one thing I have worked for, it has been for social and territorial cohesion, for the cohesion of people and territories, and this report is moving in precisely that direction. And it is precisely moving forward with broad consensus, since even those groups which, such as the GUE/NGL, have tabled an amendment to the report itself, have abstained in committee, which shows that this report is a fairly balanced, fairly fair and quite advanced report. In addition, I would like to tell you, from my perspective, and this is reflected in the document, that Article 23 cannot serve to exclude from the funds — Mr Juaristi referred to this — in the deterioration of his situation, those who cannot invest or attract investment. That is, those who face socio-economic difficulties and have the funds as a significant part of their investment should not suffer additional damage. I therefore reject, and I want to say this quite clearly, that local regions or authorities — as well as the citizens themselves beneficiaries of the funds — may be paralyzed as a result of macroeconomic non-compliance at a central level of the Administration. That is why, ladies and gentlemen, there is no doubt that frequent rescheduling would be counterproductive. It should therefore be avoided in order not to disrupt the management of funds, nor to undermine the stability and predictability of the multiannual investment strategy, while to avoid any negative effect on the absorption of funds. Emphasis should also be placed on the criminal nature of any suspension of payments and request the Commission to use its discretion with the utmost caution, having considered all the elements derived from the structured dialogue and the views expressed therein. I'm done; I welcome the commission's intention to restrict to the maximum unnecessary rescheduling and suspensions in the medium term, since the programmes and collaboration agreements adopted in the current period take into account the country-specific recommendation and relevant Council recommendations.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, October 28, at 12 p.m. The resolution of the Committee on Regional Development will be put to a vote at the next session. Written Declarations (Article 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – EUSAIR is the third EU macro-regional strategy that can build on the experience of strategies for the Baltic Sea and danube regions. The Adriatic and Yin Sea region is home to more than 70 million people and covers eight countries, four of which are EU Member States (Croatia, Greece, Italy, Slovenia), three candidate countries (Albania, Montenegro, Serbia) and Bosnia and Herzegovina as potential candidate countries.  In my opinion, the draft report is well founded, as EUSAIR provides a good opportunity for countries in the region to stimulate sustainable development. The pillars of the Strategy ("blue growth", the development of infrastructure links in the region, environmental protection, sustainable, competitive tourism) and other priorities (EU integration of the Western Balkan countries, ensuring coherence between the three EU macro-regional strategies and national strategic projects) promote economic development and job creation. However, I think it is important to stress that a comprehensive evaluation of the results is needed for all macro-regional strategies. It is necessary to ensure that the strategies have genuine European added value and that they have real, tangible positive effects in the region concerned.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. – The EU Strategy for the Adriatic and Ionian Region regulates a new European macro-region that includes 8 countries, eu member states (Italy, Slovenia, Croatia and Greece) and candidate countries (Serbia, Montenegro, Albania and Bosnia and Herzegovina). This is a very significant step, as it provides the region with the opportunity for faster development, economic recovery, the development of connectivity and, above all, closer cooperation in order to preserve good relations. With my amendments to the report, I felt it was important to stress that, in the event of natural disasters, we must provide these countries with rapid and appropriate assistance in order to restore the consequences of the damage suffered as soon as possible. From a transport point of view and for better connectivity, it is essential that these countries are successfully connected to the TEN-T transport network and that the strategy creates even closer cooperation between the countries of the region.

name: Момчил Неков (
text: S&D), in writing. – The revision of the Europe 2020 strategy is happening at a key moment for Europe. The last few years have been marked by policies of strict economic discipline because of the financial and economic crisis from which the EU is still trying to recover. Unfortunately, in times of crisis, national governments make savings by cutting the education and culture budget. The truth is that investment in education is often seen as an additional burden rather than a long-term investment in human capital. Young people are most affected by this, with unemployment rates the highest. We are still a long way from achieving the objectives set out in the Strategy. Achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth runs through a clear commitment to investing in quality and accessible education for all, as well as providing opportunities for young people in Europe. It's the only way to prevent the brain drain process.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – EU cohesion policy and the Europe 2020 strategy have until recently been the main tools for achieving smart, sustainable and inclusive growth of countries in the Union. Today, however, we have another strong helper in this endeavor – the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I am pleased that the role of efsi is reflected in my colleague Ruas's report. I would like to rebut the concerns of some of my colleagues that the differences between the ESI Funds and efsi may hamper cohesion policy.  On the contrary, efsi complements these funds by creating a higher level of synergies and added value. It is also, according to a proposal from the European Parliament, that the efsi's success indicators include the achievement of the objectives of economic and social cohesion.  I would like to encourage all competent European and national authorities to put synergies between the ESI Funds and efsi at the heart of the future cohesion policy.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. When we talk about the Adriatic and Ionian Regions, we are talking about an area that affects eight countries and involves over 70 million inhabitants. Perhaps these two figures are enough to make us understand the need and importance of a common front in order to respond to the current challenges which have a considerable impact on the economic and social development of this macro-region. The sustainable exploitation of fishery resources, the preservation of the maritime ecosystem, the improvement of connectivity in the transport and energy sector cannot be translated into drivers for growth without ambitious planning. The European strategy can only represent a significant opportunity for development if the political will to forge cooperation links is followed by operational commitment on the part of both governments and regional and local authorities. I hope that the new ADRION transnational cooperation programme will provide an important first impetus in this regard. It is time for concrete action and action. Working together between all the countries in the area is also the best strategy to relaunch the economy of the fisheries sector and support those who work in fisheries. I would like to point out that aquaculture and mariculture represent a business potential that is just waiting to be exploited in an effective and sustainable way.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. – Cohesion policy is one of the most important investment tools contributing to the achievement of the Europe 2020 objectives.  In the new perspective 2014-2020, cohesion policy, with so-called thematic conditionality and partnership agreements setting investment objectives, focuses in particular on achieving the Europe 2020 objectives.  I agree with my colleague Ruas, who has produced a strong report, that strengthening multi-level governance is particularly important in order to achieve these objectives. In the future, it will also be important to use genuine territorial approaches to the Europe 2020 strategy in order to adapt public actions and investments to different territorial characteristics and specific needs.  And finally, the so-called "i.d. The Juncker Investment Plan (EFSI) should be clearly linked to the Europe 2020 strategy, taking on a complementary role for the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESI), as it could make a significant contribution to the implementation of the strategy by selecting viable and sustainable projects.  However, we will probably also consider this synergy when designing a future cohesion policy.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the report by Maria Hunner and Jo Leinen, on behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the report on the reform of the European Union electoral law (2015/2035 (INL)) (A8-0286/2015)

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we are here because we decided to amend the European Union electoral law. This law dates back to 1976 and, in the meantime, as we all know, Europe has been through major and unimaginable changes, in terms of both the scope and the substance of EU integration. The European Parliament has also changed dramatically, in size and in relation to its competences, especially as a co—legislator, with its decisions having huge impact on people’s lives. It should not come as a surprise that we want to adjust the Electoral Act of 1976 to the new reality. This report highlights the right of the European Parliament to decide on its own electoral procedure. We all have similar experience, as European parliamentarians, of elections to the European Parliament, which continue to be extremely national. No European issues are discussed during the electoral campaign and the European dimension of this democratic process is not sufficiently visible. That is why we have proposed a change to the European Electoral Act of 1976. In the proposal, we give the European Parliament the right to decide on the date of the election. We ask Member States to ensure that all citizens working or living outside the European Union are granted the right to vote and enabled to do. We also propose machinery to avoid double voting. We are asking Member States to create the conditions for voting by electronic means, via the internet or by post. People with reduced mobility will certainly benefit. I know that some colleagues worry about internet voting, but it can be made safe. We have the example of Estonia which started internet voting in 2005, when 2% of Estonians decided to use this tool. This year, 30% of Estonians voted via the internet. We also want to see more gender equality in the lists, so we are proposing the alignment of deadlines for some elements of the electoral process, such as the establishment of lists. Let me also mention the possibility for national parties of informing voters, via the ballot paper, of their affiliation with European political parties. Citizens should have this information. Through these and other measures we hope to contribute to making elections to the European Parliament truly European, and to increasing citizens’ interest in participating in this important element of European decision making. Let me conclude by saying that people’s impact on Europe starts with their informed participation in the European elections.

name: Jo Leinen
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The European Parliament is unique in the world. Nowhere else do people have the opportunity to elect a common civic chamber in 28 countries. Yes, there is nowhere else to do so, but only in the European Union. We know, however, that these elections are causing a number of problems across 28 countries. Although we have had European elections eight times, not much has been done to remedy the shortcomings of this European election. That is why we are now making a new attempt to make proposals for the next European elections in 2019, in order to make them more transparent and democratic and, it must be said, to make them more European. Mrs Hübner has already pointed out that we want to make recommendations to the Member States and also to change the 1976 electoral act. The recommendations are about broadening access to the European elections. We believe that the young generation should be invited to take part in these elections. Many young people could go to the European elections for the first time at the age of 16. Such a turnout may mark their lives for a long time to come. We therefore believe that the Member States should look at how Austria has already done to reduce the voting age to 16. I also believe that the younger generation is the Internet generation that would rather do an election act with one click than go to the town hall or a school building. This, too, can be examined, into the future. Postal voting is also not allowed in many countries. Not everyone is at home on Sunday or Election Day. Postal voting has helped in many countries. The serious preparation of the European elections is another matter. We have noticed that in some countries the electoral lists are not completed until 17 days before the election. I don't know how to campaign , 17 days before the election. We now say: at least twelve weeks. You can then campaign for three months in the rather large constituencies that we all represent. Above all, we want to highlight the European nature of the European elections. We often have national debates, national disputes, and the European dimension is totally lost. This must be made visible, in TV commercials, on campaign materials, on the ballot papers, and if it is the case nationally that the names of the parties appear there, the European party families should also appear. Above all, the European parties should also determine their top candidates for the office of President of the Commission in good time – at least twelve weeks – before the election. A huge step forward would be gender equality; we think that fifty-fifty can be achieved. Many parties, many countries are already doing this, why not others? Maybe 2019 is a bit early. We think it can be achieved in 2024. We also want to achieve equality of electoral opportunities everywhere. Twenty-six countries have minimum thresholds of 3 percent – why not the other two countries? We propose at least 3 percent, but not more than 5 percent. Some wanted to go much further: transnational lists. I am very much in favour of that. But we have decided to do this in a next step. This is to be enshrined in the report that the AFCO Committee will draw up, because this Parliament has already failed on several occasions. This needs a deeper debate. So, ladies and gentlemen, I hope that you will be able to agree to these pragmatic proposals. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Leinen, do you know these two analyses– both on European electoral law?  You are old enough. They would have to be far-sighted enough to recognize them: one from February, one from September. One of those with the recognized election law expert and ex-colleague Andrew Duff, one without him. One with a clear 'no' to the EU-wide blocking clause, one with a 'yes'.  Don't find it strange that we can afford two expensive studies within six months with two completely different results, and I think that (the President is taking the floor out of the speaker.)

name: Jo Leinen (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, I would like to thank my colleague for his work We have discussed this on several occasions in the AFCO Committee. We believe that there is equality of electoral chances in all 28 countries.  Today we have a situation where you can win a mandate in one or two countries with 0.6 percent of the vote, whereas in other countries you need at least 3 percent. That is not a balance, 3 per cent for everyone was our proposal, and that is the latest policy line decided by the majority in the AFCO Committee.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, democracy as a founding value of the Union means that the EU institutions must exercise their powers according to the highest standards of representativeness and accountability. The Commission and the European Parliament share the same objectives of strengthening the democratic legitimacy of the European Union.  I congratulate Parliament on the proposal under discussion today for amending the rules for electing its Members. The report adopted in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, on the basis of the proposal by Ms Hübner and Mr Leinen, has the potential to become a milestone in the democratic evolution of the European project, which – as we all have to recognise – has been a remarkable, though also a long and painful, process. Ahead of the most recent European elections, the Commission – mindful of the strengths of the European Parliament and of its role in the appointment of the President of the Commission under the Lisbon Treaty, and echoing long—standing calls from Parliament – had prompted European political parties to nominate lead candidates for the function of President of the Commission. The European political families did so for the first time, and Jean-Claude Juncker, a candidate able to command a majority in the newly formed European Parliament, was nominated by the European Council and elected by Parliament as President of the Commission. This key novelty of the 2014 elections connected the election of the Commission President more directly to the voters’ choice. Consolidating these new elements for future elections will reinforce the democratic legitimacy of the European decision—making process and will be a significant step forward, fostering the emergence of a genuinely European political sphere.  The Commission supports the proposed reform which will further strengthen our political accountability, as European parties will have to nominate their lead candidates at the latest 12 weeks ahead of the elections. The reforms can also help bridge the divide between political processes at national and at EU level. Showcasing the affiliation between national and European political parties, on ballot papers and in political broadcasts during the electoral campaign, will make the links between the main players more visible to voters and will improve their trust in the process. Here, I think, we have all been victims of the lack of discussion and debate about European issues, which is so very important. National political parties and authorities have also a decisive role to play in helping to increase transparency and to make citizens more aware of the European repercussions of votes cast for national parties. Having further common principles in the organisation of the European Parliament elections, such as a minimum threshold in all Member States for the allocation of seats, will also contribute to strengthening the European dimension of these elections. In substance, the establishment of such a minimum threshold will make the functioning of the European Parliament more efficient by decreasing the risk of fragmentation and by facilitating stable majorities. We have been talking about a crisis of representative democracy, and of disillusionment with politics. Promoting participation is essential for the progress of the European project. That is why I warmly welcome the proposals for extending the right to vote to EU citizens living in third countries; for putting in place more flexible and inclusive ways of casting votes; and for fostering women’s political participation in Union decision making and in European elections. Using electoral lists that ensure gender balance, as proposed in the report, is another important step in the right direction. By the way, I was here, though in another capacity, when we proposed such gender quotas many times in the past. On the basis of experience in the country I know best, I would also advocate action at national level because, as I have said, this aspect is catastrophic in many countries, both at local level and in national parliaments. At least here we have this principle, and that is very important.  Fair and objective media coverage during European election campaigns is, of course, another key element and I wish to stress it, since it is an essential condition for free and fair elections.  I take note of the proposal to establish a European electoral authority where information about elections to the European Parliament would be centralised. Before any further commitment, this would need to be carefully examined and, in particular, we need to examine the timeliness and feasibility of such a proposal, including in relation to the responsibilities of such an authority, possible arrangements for establishing it, and the institutional, legal, budgetary and staffing requirements for its functioning. The Commission, as I said, fully supports Parliament’s efforts to adopt these timely and ambitious proposals. Congratulations.

name: György Schöpflin
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, there is nothing untoward in the European Parliament looking to establish a common system of elections for itself. Every parliament in the world does so, and it adds to transparency and predictability if the systems by which citizens choose their representatives in the EU are broadly similar – similar if not identical, given that there are 28 different political traditions involved. The sensitive issue here is that of a threshold. Should there be a minimum percentage of votes that a party list has to attract before it acquires representation? In some Member States there is no support for this, but in the great majority it is accepted practice. The threshold helps to weed out frivolous contestants whose sole interest is in attracting attention. There is a counter-argument that the institution of the threshold restricts the political marketplace by creating too high a barrier to entry. The answer is a balance between the two: to have a threshold but not to set it too high. That is what this report tries to attain – setting a threshold but not making that threshold insurmountable. From every standpoint, this is the sensible, rational solution.

name: Mercedes Bresso
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank the rapporteurs for their complex work, as well as the Commissioner for the support she has given to our initiative.  This is a sensitive issue, because it is one of the two cases in which Parliament has legislative initiative. We are proposing changes, albeit limited, to legislation. I would like to remind you that since 1976 the Council has refused to amend the text of the electoral law and thus to make the elections more European, as Mr Schöpflin has already mentioned.  The proposals are therefore contained proposals, but they aim to move in the direction of having more homogeneous electoral legislation.
