I will mention a few of them: in the meantime, the one that aims to give visibility to European political parties, and therefore to make european sense in the elections, to stabilise the nomination of the candidate for the European Commission and to allow the voters to know him through an adequate number of weeks during which the names will be known; gender balance, which is, I believe, indispensable; the issue of transnational lists, which could come under at least one recital, and therefore a small note.  I hope that we will be able to build, for the first time, an electoral law in this Parliament.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Group of the European Conservatives and Reformists has a good assessment of the current law in the European Parliament and we do not see the need to amend it, and we certainly do not see the need to change the direction of centralisation, the unification of electoral law. There are two important things to look out for: firstly, the belief that if we encourage a reduction in the voting age to 16, or encourage light voting online, turnout in the European Parliament will increase very much. We are not convinced of these measures. The electoral act has its rank, its seriousness. Do not resort to online forms as common forms.  But it is more important to centralise electoral law, including ideas such as the obligation to use the European party logo on the national party logo. We do not see such a necessity, it should not be an obligation. There are new political parties in the life of our countries that can make this choice later, sitting only in the European Parliament. Why force them to do so during the election campaign?  Above all, the legitimacy of the European Parliament should be based on respect for national traditions, for constitutional traditions, for the sovereignty of peoples. The closer to the national context, the closer the citizens are. The more centralised, unified the law, the more the European Parliament will move away from the real problems of citizens. That is why we will vote against this project.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, just a few hours after this debate it has been decided — I think it is right to delay the vote so that it gives time to be able to analyse some of the aspects that define the report and which can complete it. The reform, in our view, has been uns ambitious to this day. It is surely the example of insufficient or overly prudent use of great opportunity and need, because we are living in a moment of crisis and discrediting our European institutions. Only one in four persons with the right to vote, on average, participates in European elections. And elections are indeed understood in national terms, because public opinions are defined in this way. Because governments play it, too. The big parties are also split between what they say in this Parliament and what they do in the rest of the institutions, especially when they govern. We have not made recommendations in the report to really promote the awareness that is invoked from a European point of view. Elections can be — European elections — more than just a national policy assessment, of course, and they can bring Parliament's institution closer to the citizens. And parliamentarians, their representatives, must submit to accountability on a permanent basis. We must ask ourselves whether this report actually achieves these objectives in its recommendations. We, rather think that there are changes that are positive, some that are cosmetic and some that favor those who have more territorial and social implementation. The reform has improvements such as gender equality or voting in third countries, but it cannot be seriously defended that it is a major step forward to put the symbols of European political parties on ballots, although it is not bad. But the report falls short. The changes are minor and substantial change, which is the establishment of a mandatory threshold, does not seem to us to reinforce a greater possibility of integrity or equal opportunities for political pluralism.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Thank you, Madam President, Commissioner, for the work she has done. After the election, there is a choice and the further development of European electoral law is therefore, in my view, rightly on our agenda. It can do a great deal politically, but it has to be judged by who it ends up serving. Does it help to strengthen the public space in Europe, to overcome the speechlessness between citizens and european politics that has persisted for years? And does it provide more active and passive political participation to this day, including gender parity? The great shortcoming of the report, dear co-rapporteurs, for all its good intentions – again underlined today – is that it simply does not boldly approach the reform, but is tangled up in anticipating political constellations in the Council and is therefore more self-sufficient in the end.  The report does not follow the proposal to create political spaces and expanded opportunities for participation, but rather tries to manage technically what cannot be controlled: the dynamics of political life and corresponding discourses in the societies of the member states.  For me, democratic changes cannot be reconciled with the identity imply in the report between the interests of the citizens of Europe and those of the German grand coalition in Berlin. A large German bourgeois newspaper has clearly characterized the process of introducing a blocking clause: a provocation against the German Federal Constitutional Court. Why should we go down this road?

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the reform of the electoral law of the European Union is a very important issue. The fact that it had two rapporteurs was a first signal of alliance in the leadership, and was not necessarily bad in itself. However, it was also soon complemented with a certain amount of lack of flexibility when the debate came to the point of accepting, or not, some of the many suggestions and proposals brought up by other groups.  In this sense, I very much regret to have to say that this is a weak reform which has not been capable of encompassing the sense of history. Among many other things, the report should have insisted on proposals reinforcing the confidence of European citizens in their institutions, but it has not done so, at least in the following four areas. Firstly, the report establishes something new, namely an obligatory threshold declared unacceptable by the German Constitutional Court and now introduced as obligatory for all countries in Europe. This measure clearly goes against the spirit of diversity and protection of minorities. Secondly, transnational lists were just mentioned in passing, almost by chance, transformed into a mere recital. Thirdly, surprisingly enough, even the introduction of gender equality has been postponed until the European elections in 2024. Finally, we have not established the minimum age of voters at 16.

name: Diane James
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I listened to the opening statements outlining the goals proposed and attempting to justify them. Quite frankly, I was aghast to hear some of what I heard. There is a famous author called George Orwell who would have been proud of what was outlined this evening. The feelings of those who are frightened by the contents of his book would have been substantiated. More control of the electoral outcome seems to be the goal: even less democracy, despite the calls for it. Just look at what happened recently in Portugal in terms of the election outcome there! Is the goal in what I have heard this evening, and what is being outlined, to ignore the will of the people and ignore a democratic electoral outcome? I have heard no account thus far of the scale of global cyber-attacks or personal ID theft, and yet we have this whole focus on electronic voting and suchlike. I am going to finish by saying that electoral law is a matter for sovereign nations, not for this Chamber – to which it is alien.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The old electoral act of 1976 is sufficient to this day to hold democratic elections in an orderly manner and to manage them in the Member States. The European Parliament now wants to enact a new electoral law to lead the European electorate to the polls more massively, but above all, the voters are also being pushed into this EU unity sausage and the Member States are increasingly sidelined. The forthcoming European electoral law stipulates that the elected representatives will no longer be representatives of their respective Member States, but so-called representatives of all citizens of the Union. The EU will even interfere in the way in which the political parties will draw up their electoral lists. A mandatory electoral threshold will also be introduced everywhere, ostensibly to prevent further fragmentation, but just to keep new, small and often EU critical parties out. For us, Member States must be and remain autonomous in order to be able to determine the electoral conditions and procedures themselves for their citizens. (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question)

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. I will be thunderous: I would remind you that already under the current Treaties – I do not know if you have read them – we represent the whole Union and not our states. I wanted to know if he's aware of it.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam, I was not elected here for what is in those treaties. You see all these flags of my colleagues and I hope that more and more of these flags will come. We represent the voters who choose us here and we have the right to do so. There is also the right to pretend that we represent the whole of Europe, but they do not. We represent our voters here, our people and only then Europe.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union gives the European Parliament the opportunity to initiate a reform of the rules under which elections to the European Parliament are held throughout the Union, and I am glad that, thanks to the efforts of our colleagues in the AFCO committee in particular, we are now making use of this possibility. I believe that the intention behind the various parts of the report submitted must be supported. Strengthening the democratic principles of European elections is a prerequisite for a positive perception of European elections, which will hopefully lead to greater turnout and a positive perception of the Union as a whole. As a gathering of directly elected representatives of citizens, the European Parliament has great opportunities to develop Europeanism and a positive perception of the Union, and it is certainly in the interest of all of us not to disappoint the expectations of our constituents. I therefore support the harmonisation of electoral rules, which will highlight this European dimension.

name: Pedro Silva Pereira (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we usually spend more time lamenting the old problem of the democratic deficit than discussing measures to improve our democracy. That is not the case today, and i would therefore like to welcome our colleagues Jo Leinen and Danuta Hübner for their excellent report, which proposes a very important but realistic reform of the electoral law for the European elections.  This is one of the few matters on which Parliament has the right to legislative initiative, but we have a duty, not just the right, to do more to strengthen the European dimension of democracy. We have already taken an important step in linking the candidacies for President of the Commission to the European elections, and we must now go further. With this reform, ballot papers and campaign materials will also give visibility to European parties. We will have the same principle of gender equality across Europe, the same deadlines for submitting lists and candidates, the same closing time, the same possibility of electronic and postal voting, and we will also have a barrier clause requiring a minimum of 3 to 5 % of the votes to elect Members in the states that elect more than 26 parliamentarians. More harmonised rules and more transparency so that citizens know who they vote for and for what. European democracy will be better off with this electoral reform.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Federal Constitutional Court has declared the five percent hurdle to the EU election in Germany unconstitutional. So even small parties came into the house and, of course, at the expense of the pledging of the others, they acquired their mandates. That is why the SPD and the Union and the Greens want to reintroduce the blocking clause. They had previously suggested that the work here in the House would be disrupted by the small parties. This argument is dead. The Federal Constitutional Court made it clear in its 2014 judgment, and rightly so. Count Lambsdorff of the FDP or even Mr. Sonneborn of the Fun Party probably do not disturb anyone here in the house. Ladies and gentlemen of the SPD and the Union: please be honest! You have now simply exchanged your dead argument and, with a trick, you now want to continue to prevent competition and secure assets by incorporating a mandatory hurdle in European law in order to eliminate the Constitutional Court. That is not democratic, Mr Leinen, that is transparent, and that is shabby!

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her This is where the reform of European electoral law is to be tackled by a large majority in Parliament, even though compliance with subsidiarity has always been the focus. For me, there is no reason to introduce a 3% lockout clause, as it affects only 2 out of 28 countries in particular, namely Spain and Germany. The arguments that the small parties do not get involved in the political groups and would jeopardise Parliament's functioning can also be easily refuted. In Germany, we have two judgments of the Federal Constitutional Court against blocking clauses, which are intended to circumvent them. As a result, 8 million votes would not be taken into account in the future. This is harmful to democracy and encourages political disaffection. I can say for myself that I am the Member who received the most votes – 428 800. That is only 1.6% in my country, but more than Malta has inhabitants. And that is why I have the legitimacy for it!

name: Klaus Buchner (Verts/ALE).
text: Thank you very much, Madam President. As has already been said, the introduction of a 3 or 5 % threshold concerns only Germany and Spain, because these are the only countries that, on the one hand, have more than 26 Members, and on the other hand, they do not currently have a blocking clause.  What would that mean if we introduced a blocking clause? There can be no question of justice for smaller countries, of which you are talking, Mr Leinen. Let us look at the figures: 3 per cent in Luxembourg means about 12,000 votes. In Germany, 3 percent means ten times that. If you take it on the part of the Members, because Germany is disadvantaged in this proportionality, then there are 30 times as many. Is this democracy? I would also like to point out that the votes are allocated by the smaller parties to the large ones, that is, the big ones have a genuine interest in getting votes now that the voters (the President takes the floor from the speaker.)

name: Vicky Maeijer (ENF).
text: – Today we are witnessing yet another attempt by Brussels to erode the sovereignty of the nation states. Elections to the European Parliament must become more European and less national, ostensively because you are concerned about the democratic deficit in Brussels, about the ever-falling turnout, about the fact that no one knows who the President of the European Commission is. This democratic deficit is not fixed by a fight by combating democracy in the Member States with a ban on exit polls, with the obligation to put men and women on the electoral roll, with electoral thresholds. It's better to worry about why no one cares, why only 42 percent of eligible voters feel called to vote. Perhaps it has something to do with the alien attitude of the majority of the so-called representatives of the people who are housed here in Parliament. Elections to the European Parliament are elections for national representatives who, in my case, should represent the Dutch people. These elections are held in the Netherlands and regulated by dutch electoral law. Please don't get involved.

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: – First of all, I congratulate Danuta Hübner and Jo Leinen on their report. Since I have been in the European Parliament, this is the second attempt to reform the Union's electoral legislation. The previous exercise showed us that it is not easy to find a balance between boldness and political realism, or I think the proposals now achieve this objective.  If we want the European elections to be not just the sum of 28 national legislations or a result of 28 parallel elections, we must support the proposals contained in the Hübner-Leinen report, keeping as far as possible the powerlines of reform adopted in the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, because the essence of the reform is precisely the Europeanisation of the elections to the European Parliament.  By setting minimum standards, the democratic legitimacy of the decision-making process will be strengthened, and I mention here three points which I find essential and which I have consistently supported: the arrangement of the possibility of voting from the age of 16, the observance of democratic procedures in the nomination of candidates for elections and the introduction of electronic voting. I believe that these simple mechanisms are likely to increase turnout and thus the democratic nature of elections to the European Parliament. Finally, I hope that the high number of amendments tabled will not alter the report adopted in the AFCO, which is a good basis for negotiation with the Council.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first question I would like to ask you: don't you think that forty years later the electoral law needs to be changed? The law is from 1976, it's been forty years. Has Europe changed in these forty years? I'm sure you are! Second question: do you not think that those of us here must have the same rules, the same rights, that we have to have a harmonised system of electoral law in order for us to be chosen? Third question: do you not think that it is essential that there be a representation of the European parties, not of the aggregated national parties, but that those here representing European sovereignty - European sovereignty, I repeat - must at the same time have the same rules to be here, even forming transnational lists that would allow the list head of each political group to top the list of the party that intends to govern Europe? Isn't that the logical rule of democracy? And finally, a request to my colleagues in the Green Group and the GUE/NGL Group: please do not join those who are against Europe with 'no' to a law that is not perfect, which is a law that we would like to see better, but which is not a law that deserves a 'no'. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, thank you very much for giving me this blue card. I was struck by listening to you to see that you no longer conceive that we represent peoples here. You now want us to represent European parties as part of this electoral reform. And I personally think it's a mistake. I think that the last chance you have to save the European Union is to reconcile it with the people.  Personally, I am in favour of taking down this European Union. But if you want to save her, I think you have to reconcile her with the people. What do you think? Isn't this the last chance you have left?

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D)
text: "blue card" response. – But the peoples are Europe. Peoples, being peoples, are also Europe. I do want more European political parties. I don't want an aggregation of national parties; I want European parties representing European sovereignty, yes. That is why I believe that this law lacks more transnational lists and more European parties, certainly. But we take a step in that direction.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I condemn the fact that the SPD, CDU and CSU are leading their report to push through the reintroduction of a three-percent hurdle, under complete ignorance of the decision of the Federal Constitutional Court. I maintain that you are afraid of the courage of the little ones. A CSU colleague recently said: "We are watching you now." That shows me that you underestimated us. The electorate, on the other hand, appreciates us more and more. I call it the Asterix principle: small, but oho. Should I be a threat to democracy? Why? Because I have already looked after more reports than many of my colleagues in ten years? Because I am one of the five most active German MEPs? Because I take the concerns of the citizens in the large constituency of Germany seriously? Because I raise the voice for the families out loud?  Honestly, if you take your job here as seriously as I do, then dare to compete fairly with us Asterixen! But stop ignoring the Federal Constitutional Court! Stop flouting our smaller parties and get up to 8 million votes in Germany (the President is taking the floor out of the speaker.)

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have listened carefully to the whole debate here, I agree with the proposal put forward by the rapporteurs, the proposal has a number of positive things, such as electronic voting. In general, however, I want to warn against the trend of strengthening the European dimension of elections as such. These elections should also be held nationally, if you will, at the state level, for one simple reason. If we cancel individual elections in individual national states, then we will break the link between a politician, an MP and his constituents. This is very important from a legitimacy point of view. The voter should know his OR her Member, he should see what he is doing in the European Parliament, he should understand his speech and he should know who he is. The moment we tear down this principle and create Pan-European constituencies, Then I believe that legitimacy will be significantly reduced, voters will not know their Member and turnout in European elections will fall.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the report on the revision of the electoral process attempts from the window to build the famous European municipality 'European Demos'.  Amendment 1 thus specifies that Members of the European Parliament are elected as representatives of the citizens of the Union, and not as representatives of the peoples of the Member States of the Union. But european peoples cannot be abolished by law, and everyone must understand that. In addition, the new electoral law imposes a 3% threshold for the allocation of seats, with the aim of excluding from the next composition of the European Parliament various movements and annoying voices against German Europe. The new electoral law also strengthens European partisanship at the expense of movements and citizens. At the same time, peoples are being undermined as a source of democratic legitimacy, while the european melting pot puzzle is complemented by paragraph 21 of the report, which challenges the official languages of the Member States of the Union and calls for minority representation in European elections.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this reform will not strengthen the democratic dimension of European elections, nor will the democratic legitimacy of the Union's decision-making process; much less bringing citizenship closer or seducing. The reform refers to the principle of subsidiarity and gives advice to regional political parties — in our case, parties or coalitions of a nation still stateless, Euskal Herria — but then forces the introduction of a mandatory threshold that goes against minorities and seeks to drive millions of citizens away from the European political game. This does not confer more democratic legitimacy, nor more efficiency — in my opinion — as has been said here. If you want more legitimacy in my country, more European legitimacy, please sedation us, for example, with the possibility of having a single constituency.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: Thank you, Madam President, for the work she has done. I think this proposal is definitely a wasted opportunity. If you look at the fact that, in the current situation, he would probably be prepared to approve every proposal for a European electoral law in order to get back their beloved blocking clause, I have to say to the rapporteurs: yes, then take the opportunity, make an ambitious proposal and actually introduce transnational lists! The European dimension of the European elections is not enhanced by imprinting the logo of a European party on the ballot papers or by excluding small parties from Parliament. The European dimension is enhanced by actually encouraging Members from different countries to work together and to find common political positions.  This would be achieved by transnational lists. But this proposal is simply unambitious and a very obvious way of trying to remove German small parties from Parliament.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I was quite surprised by the debate, because the question of the electoral threshold in particular is often mentioned here. The example of Germany, where the German Constitutional Court has recognised that the 5% threshold is unacceptable, I completely respect it. I would like to say, however, that in the Czech Republic, the Constitutional Court also decided on the 5% threshold and decided to keep it, that it considered it appropriate to the Constitution. There is an example at the moment of two completely different decisions by two constitutional courts from two Member States. And I think that's exactly what illustrates the problem we're in. The idea that absolutely detailed rules for choice will be implemented into the constitutional rights of individual nation states is, in my opinion, odd, and I think it increases tensions that are not appropriate. I am not in support of creating absolute common rules, so I would be kind of cautious about this report.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, let us look at the most recent years: passing treaties on citizens' backs, fleeing democratic scrutiny, fleeing referendums or confronting and disrespecting their outcome when it is inconvenient. When they cannot even approve treaties, the rules in force are subverted and treaties are approved outside the current legal system, as was the case with the budgetary treaty, which Mrs Merkel justified by saying "we need something to ensure that even if governments change, they do not change policies". It interferes directly and openly, in an illegitimate way, in the sovereign decisions of the peoples. Governments are determined, policies are required and democratically elected bodies, such as national parliaments, are submitted.  There is no possible cover for the undemocratic nature of this European Union. The building is structurally undemocratic, there is no paint that seeks to apply to it on the walls that change that nature. This report contains aspects of the greatest severity, so they mean an undemocratic escalation and ...  (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker)

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank Members for all their comments and for this very interesting debate. I wish to conclude by reiterating that the Commission fully supports Parliament’s efforts to adopt this timely and very ambitious proposal. In our opinion, to deliver a Union of democratic change we need to build on the concept of lead candidates. The success of Europe as a political project requires an efficient democratic system in which its citizens are fully engaged. Strengthening the link between the elections for representatives of the citizens and the selection and election process of the head of the European executive is a tangible demonstration of the impact of citizens’ democratic participation on the EU decision-making process. As I said at the beginning, it is very important to highlight the importance of a quota or gender balance, to which I gave my full support as a Member of the European Parliament. This proposal is a concrete way to create a new sense of engagement in the construction of Europe and stimulate citizens to play a more active role in European democracy. As I said at the beginning, at the present time it is really crucial to build and contribute to trust between citizens and European institutions.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank both those who were saying that we lack ambition and those who were saying that we are too ambitious, because basically those were the two groups we heard here in the Chamber. To those who consider that we lack ambition with this report, I would say that sometimes in our work, and you all experience this, we want to bring more people on board for the ideas we consider important for European citizens – then, of course, our level of ambition falls to that of the common ambition. To a certain extent, that is why we could not do certain things. Another reason, however, has to do with the procedure involving the Council: we have to go with this proposal to the Council, and the Council, under the Treaty, can completely ignore our proposal. That is why we are trying to build something that will get through the whole system and take us a step forward in the evolution of the European Parliament’s right to decide on the procedure for its own electoral process. These points may constitute an explanation in response to the first group of comments. To all those who consider we are going too far, I have to say that I totally disagree with you. In response to those who say we are moving too far in the sense of taking responsibility for issues that should be addressed at national level, as matters for national sovereignty, I would say that this proposal brings Members of the European Parliament closer to the voters, and also brings European citizens closer to Europe. So through this proposal I believe we are addressing what is today the biggest weakness of the European Union, namely the huge distance between the citizens and the Union. I hope that, as a result of all our discussions, at committee level, here and subsequently in the Council, we will achieve something which, though it may not be milestone, as the Commissioner nicely put it, will certainly take us forward in terms of the European Parliament’s right to decide on its own electoral procedures. As György Schöpflin was saying, we are probably the only parliament in the world that is not currently able to decide for itself about its electoral procedures. Lastly, with regard to the threshold and the recent ruling by the German Federal Constitutional Court, I hope Jo Leinen will explain it but, if I remember correctly, one of the points the Court made was that if there were a European law on the threshold it would be a different story. That is why we are proposing a European law: so that we can avoid all the problems we are having at national level, with differing interpretations by different constitutional courts. In any case, thank you, colleagues, very much. I hope that you will still have time to rethink how you are going to vote. (Applause)

name: Jo Leinen
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank all those who have taken part in the debate. Mr Schöpflin has indeed said that a minimum threshold is okay, but it should not be too high. Well, what did we do? We have looked at what exists in 26 Member States. There is a minimum threshold of three per cent everywhere by law or de facto, and we have now proposed this for two other countries where this does not exist. This is not too high, but that is the norm in most of our countries, and it is somehow practiced and exists there and is also accepted. Indeed, ladies and gentlemen, our German Constitutional Court has delivered this verdict. But it has also opened the door to a minimum threshold. It said that as long as there is no European law, we will judge our country as we have done. It has also said that we must monitor the development of the European Parliament. With the new powers, in the new tasks of electing a European executive – as we did with the election of the President of the Commission – they would also change their judgment on the zero- percent clause. So, I think there is too one-sided argument. I understand that from the very small parties, but it is also not right to present it so one-sidedly here. I am also encouraged by colleagues who have said that we should have gone much further. However, from the experience of the last period, we have meant that we represent a two-stage approach. The first stage that is possible now, and then again, we come up with further proposals, which will most likely also have to be decided in a Convention in a larger consultation with national parliaments and national governments. Let us not deceive ourselves: European lists also require the amendment of existing decisions. That is not to be found here, as the last period has shown us. I would just like to say that this is a milestone, as Commissioner Creu said, in relation to the decades in which nothing has happened. It has been mentioned here what we are proposing. This is a big step forward and we should not miss this opportunity. Because if we miss them, there will be no reform of the electoral law in this period, and we will then fall back into the old paths in 2019, which have proved to be very deficit-in-the-day. Finally, I would like to say that those who do not accept here that we are elected at home in our Member States, but at the moment when we are here in Parliament, represent the whole of the EU and not just our Member States, they simply cannot be helped. We know that there are Eurosceptics and anti-Europeans. We can make proposals as we wish, and they will always be against it. They are also a minority, and they should remain so.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Wednesday, October 28, at 12 p.m. Written Declarations (Article 162)

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. – The report of the European Parliament's Committee on Constitutional Affairs on the revision of legislation on the election of MEPs proposes a series of amendments to the Electoral Act 1976. The most important of these amendments is the introduction of a mandatory limit of between 3% and 5% for the allocation of seats in at least some of the Member States. This proposal is problematic from the point of view of the democratic principle enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. Especially when this threshold exceeds 3% and reaches 5%, there is an excessive restriction of pluralism, which is not necessary to ensure the functioning of the European Parliament. The introduction of electronic voting without adequate clarification and guarantees also raises questions as to the security of voting. I recall the extraordinary negative experience of the 2000 US presidential election, when the result was judged because of the inability of a few hundred voters in the state of Florida to meet the complex requirements of the relevant process for them. The report must therefore be reformed, otherwise it cannot be accepted.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. – The report on the reform of electoral legislation in the European Union calls for an amendment to the framework applied since 1979, when the first direct EP elections were held. The EU Treaties give Parliament the right to initiate a reform of its own electoral procedure with a view to developing a procedure that is uniformly applicable in all Member States or based on common principles. The reform also aims to strengthen the democratic legitimacy of the EU decision-making process.  Since the adoption of electoral legislation, we have witnessed a number of political and social changes. The report focuses on the changed forms of participation of EU citizens in politics and the visibility of the parties, which also aims to legitimise the work of the European Parliament. I consider it important to create different opportunities for participation in elections in the Member States. For the time being, the legislative provisions of my own Member State, Slovakia, allow only traditional participation, excluding many citizens from the EP elections. This has contributed to the lowest turnout in the Member State in the last EP elections.  It is to be welcomed that the report encourages Member States to take measures to promote the proper representation of ethnic, linguistic and other minorities in European elections. The planned reform could bring parliament's work and MPs themselves closer to their constituents.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. –  Many of the ideas floated in this report are unacceptable. Many of the tabled amendments are even more unpalatable. The rapporteurs, a ‘grand coalition’ of EPP and Socialist groups, refer to their perceived need to avoid ‘further fragmentation’ of the European Parliament. That statement exemplifies the traditional approach of the two larger groups in this Parliament – they would use any opportunity to place obstacles, such as mandatory thresholds, in the way of parties and groups other than their own.  The diversity of views represented in this Parliament is, in my view, a considerable asset and a direct result of a democratic election process rather than an obstacle to it. I have not seen any beneficial effect arising from the notion of lead candidates, supposedly gathering votes from across the entire EU. The amendments which propose a 25-strong Transnational List of candidates at European Elections are not likely to lead to any greater level of voter interest in future European Parliament elections. In my view, transnational lists simply are another mechanism which would mainly benefit the two largest groups in this parliament. I will be voting against all of the amendments which are supportive of the principle of transnational lists.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls for debate on the recommendation for the second reading of the Committee on Legal Affairs on the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the European Parliament and Council regulation amending Protocol 3 on the status of the European Court of Justice (09375/1/2015-C-0166/2015-2011/0901B (COD)) (Reporter: Antonio Marinho e Pinto) (A8-0296/2015)

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the Court of Justice of the European Union launched a legislative initiative in 2011 to amend its statutes in order to allow the appointment of 12 more judges to the General Court. In April 2014, this claim deserved parliament's agreement at first reading. However, the Council has never appointed any of these 12 judges because the Member States did not achieve an understanding in the choice of judges, since each State wanted to appoint its judge and the number of judges to be appointed, 12, did not coincide with the number of appointing States, 28.  Thus, in October 2014, the Court asked for 28 more judges, twice as many as the existing ones, as well as the abolition of the Civil Service Tribunal. That is, in April 2014, 12 more judges were needed to resolve the court's alleged problems, but in October of that year, after all, 28 more judges were already needed, as well as the extinction of a court. It is clear that it is not a question of solving any of the Court's problems, but of solving a council problem which is not capable of appointing members who do not coincide with its members. On the other hand, the proposal under discussion is not a mere amendment to the initial legislative proposal, but a new proposal, because it is no longer just about the appointment of 12 more judges, but 28 more and the extinction of a specialised court provided for in the Nice and Lisbon Treaties.  However, in the case of a new legislative proposal, the Commission must give a ruling on its content, which has not happened, since it has only ruled on the appointment of 12 more judges and not 28 more, and has never given any opinion on the extinction of the Court from the civil service. The Treaty provides for the establishment of specialised courts and not their deletion.  The extinction of the Civil Service Tribunal would mean the abandonment of the system of specialised courts provided for in the Nice and Lisbon Treaties, when it is generally known that specialised justice is a better quality justice and, therefore, should face—whether the possibility of creating new specialised courts, in particular for trade marks and patents, rather than trying to extinguish the only one exists , and whose success is recognized by all. Such a reform should be preceded by an impact study, which would enlighten the co-legislators – Council and Parliament – about their need, their breadth, their costs and other consequences. However, this study was never carried out. Due to the irrationality of the Council proposal, I proposed in my report the reconstitution of the position adopted by Parliament at its first reading in April 2014, because moving from 12 judges to 28 judges will not be well understood by European public opinion, as it translates into an increase in the Union's structural expenditure of more than EUR 20 million per year , just because the Council was unable to appoint the judges approved.  At a time when many countries are subject to strict austerity measures and the European Union is proposing to reduce staff and cut public spending, thus increasing the Union's structural public spending would be a bad example for the whole of Europe. But the Council was not permeable to this position, and it maintained its position, and it is now up to Parliament to accept that claim or refuse it on behalf of the European taxpayers we represent. In my report, I also proposed absolute respect for gender parity in the recruitment of judges, but that rule was also rejected by the Council, on the grounds that the treaties do not allow their adoption, replacing it with a mere declaration in the recitals, without any legal value.  If the Council's position is to be accepted by Parliament, we must then assume that, in the European Union, effective gender equality is nothing more than a rhetorical proclamation, without normative content or binding legal force. We must then assume that eu constitutional law does not allow the realisation of a fundamental right which is, moreover, one of the foundational values of the European Union itself. That is also why I would ask for the Council's position to be rejected and to return to the first reading of this Parliament.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission supports the compromise agreed in principle between the Parliament and the Council. This compromise is the result of long negotiations. It strikes a balanced solution which allows us to move forward on a file which has been blocked for too long. We should also keep in mind that this compromise is directly based on ideas submitted by the Court of Justice itself. A quick finalisation of this reform is considered very important by the Commission. The situation within the General Court remains a source of concern. This reform will allow the Court to reduce its backlog of pending cases and to speed up the treatment of cases. Effective judicial review is a fundamental right guaranteed by the Charter. However, judicial review is only effective if it is also timely. We therefore owe it to citizens and economic operators to reinforce the capacity of the Court to hear their cases quickly. Rapid settlement of disputes and clarification of legal issues is also in the interests of the Commission and of the Union as a whole. The Commission also welcomes the solution found to promote gender balance within the Court, which is an objective fully shared by the Commission. Accordingly, let me again stress the full support of the Commission for the compromise found and its confidence that, if the amendments negotiated with the Council are approved, the Commission will be in a position to deliver a positive opinion on these amendments.

name: Tadeusz Zwiefka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab A well-functioning justice system is one of the most important pillars of a democratic state. The European Union is a family of democratic states, and therefore a well-functioning European justice system should be deeply at our heart. Therefore, on behalf of the PPE Group, I would like to say with great satisfaction that this difficult, very tedious process of negotiating the final compromise is finally coming to an end. We have a compromise vote tomorrow, which was negotiated between the European Parliament and the Council last week. This compromise is based on recognising the need to increase the number of judges in the Court. No one doubts that the Court must have more judges in order to function efficiently, so that we do not incur financial penalties for protracted hearings. But I would also like to express my deep gratitude that the European Parliament has succeeded in introducing two important elements: firstly, a review clause that will allow us, shortly after the end of the reform in 2019, to look at how it has affected the functioning of the Court, and whether it is indeed as effective as we see it today.  Secondly, the adoption, together with the Council, of a European Parliament resolution on the need for gender equality at the Court of Justice. But I want to say that this is just the beginning of the road and that this gender equality should manifest itself everywhere. It cannot therefore be established for one institution without looking at the other institutions. This is the beginning of the road that we will continue on. Tomorrow, the PPE Group will support with its votes the agreement that has been concluded with the Council.

name: Mady Delvaux
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Madam President, justice is a fundamental principle, a right and an obligation in a democracy, and the justice of the European Union, ours, is now in trouble. As representatives of citizens, we owe it to ourselves to defend and protect them by giving them the means they need to do their job.  The numbers don't lie. The need to increase the number of judges in court is undeniable. The number of pending cases is increasing year after year on the altar of inaction and five appeals for non-compliance with the reasonable time limit have already been introduced, with the total amount claimed amounting to almost 27 million, which is more than the cost of the reform. The compromise reached also allows us an unprecedented step towards gender equality, and this is to the credit of the European Parliament. Let us not pass up this opportunity to achieve a concrete goal that has been claimed many times in symbolic statements.  That is why I call on all Democrats to vote for the proposal, for compromise, for more justice and equality in the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – I would like to ask the Member if she thinks that the problem of the growing onslaught on this judicial institution would not be solved if the number of legal assistants increased. We may have a very good experience with this from the Czech Republic.

name: Mady Delvaux (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, we have come to the conclusion that having too many referendums per judge implies a disempowerment of judges and that it is important to give them the means, but rather by increasing the number of judges.

name: Sajjad Karim
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Madam President, in over 20 years of elected public office service this must be amongst the most gerrymandered of political processes I have witnessed to date.  I do not make these comments lightly. I have been involved in the Legal Affairs Committee in trying to work with colleagues, including the rapporteur, on trying to reach a proper solution to the problem that was presented to us. But yet again, though there is a genuine case for reform we have made a choice to actually surrender that genuine opportunity and sacrifice it on the altar of political expediency, to arrive at a solution which is actually a non-solution. When our citizens from right across the European Union are demanding genuine reforms that reflect actual service to them, we have chosen to come forward once again with a compromise solution that actually adds to the burdens of those citizens but does nothing about providing a solution to the problem that was presented to us.  We are about to spend EUR 20 million a year extra where there was absolutely no need for us to add even one single euro cent to the burden for European taxpayers. We are failing each of our citizens by pushing this through and that is why I have taken the step, without any small measure of burden being attached, of moving an amendment to the resolution that rejects the Council position. I call upon colleagues – and I know many of them have stated to me in private how they know and they recognise that in years to come we will come to regret this decision – to support my move.

name: Jean-Marie Cavada
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the reform project which we are now considering and which has been negotiated in a four-media programme will enable us to exercise greater budgetary control over the real needs of the Court, but also to consolidate an absolutely indispensable and high democracy function called justice, which is demanded by the citizens.  Since the publication of the 2012 reform proposal, the number of cases dealt with by the Court has increased by 43% in 2014. Five appeals have already been filed for excessive duration, without justice being served, as Ms. Delvaux pointed out, costing $27 million in damages. And we can see here that it's a huge mess by slowness.  The reform of the Court, which is scalable and structural, as I support it, allows us to have three stages. And at the end of each step, an evaluation is carried out to see whether or not to go further. Therefore, I have no fear as to the financial mess argument; in my opinion, it is demagogic.  And finally, I'd like to say one thing. Let us not underestimate the absolutely indispensable democratic function, because if Europe looks like something from the point of view of the peoples, it is an executive, it is a legislative that must go to the people, and it is a judiciary that must have the means to function.

name: Heidi Hautala
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we are in the second reading of this issue, and since 2011 the Council could not – and, according to my estimation, never will – modify its request for 28 new judges.  But for those who question this, I want to underline that this reform is not just about the number of judges and the dispute that that has arisen about that. This is about ensuring the operating conditions of the EU court system, and the task and role of the General Court is crucial for the judicial protection of the citizens. The Court of Justice of the European Union is the court that constantly fosters the rule of law, transparency and fundamental rights. The quality and efficiency of the EU court system should be our highest priority. In the trilogues, Parliament has also achieved something historical: this is the very first time that the EU co—legislators are including a clause on gender parity into a regulation that governs an EU institution. The gender parity provision in the regulation is pushed as far as the Treaties enable. This is a step; it is a legal innovation that is bound to be only the beginning of a development towards more gender parity in the EU institutions. The Court and the Member States are committing themselves to gender parity, and it is our task to hold them accountable.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, let us be frank about this: this reform of the Court of First Instance is truly a scandal. At best, we are faced with the obvious inability of the Council, endorsed by the People's Party, Socialists and Greens, to overcome the nationalist and anti-Community logic that still has the reform to the principle of 'one State, one judge', with the peace of any impact study on the real need to double the number of judges. At worst, we are faced with unconfessable interests that are behind a mere division of seats.  From tomorrow, Parliament will have to explain to its citizens why Europe can impose significant economic sacrifices on them, which in Italy, for example, have also halved the number of courts, while Then Europe itself decides to double the number of judges in its court.  We believe in justice and that is why we are opposed to this reform which the Council and Parliament are carrying out with an unusual haste. I am sorry for my Green colleagues and the Socialists, but not even the fig leaf of gender equality can justify this scandalous reform.

name: Gilles Lebreton
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, this reform is a scandal, first of all because it is useless. The judges we have heard in the Committee on Legal Affairs have told us, including Mr. Jaeger, who is still the chair of the Tribunal. We are therefore going to vote on a reform that will cost us around 20 million euros a year for nothing.  Secondly, this reform has resulted in multiple violations of parliamentary procedure: violation of our regulation on the rule of double reading, violation of the most basic rules of parliamentary law in the hasty vote which took place against the will of the rapporteur, Mr Pinto, on 8 October - that day was a sham of democracy, it was hardly that time to debate. Finally, a hearing of the judges which took place in incredible conditions, since I almost had to force my way into my own committee, which claimed to forbid me entry.  Thirdly, a violation of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, since this reform involves the abolition of the Public Service Tribunal - by the way, hello for the respect of civil servants and employees of the European Union - in defiance of this treaty which allows the creation of courts but which does not allow to abolish them in any way (Article 257, for those who would like to check).  In the end, all this shows the weight of lobbying and private interests in the European Union, which should not surprise us. We have already had many examples, here is one more. The bottom line of this case is that there are 28 places of well-paid judges to distribute. That is why I tabled an amendment in the Committee on Legal Affairs which prohibited European parliamentarians from becoming judges. This would have at least had the merit of recalling a great rule that is the separation of powers and erasing any risk of conflict of interest. That amendment was rejected. We have to come to my conclusion... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, what is the cost of not having a functioning, impeccable jurisdiction? The European Court of Justice keeps rulings against very large, very powerful companies. One example is the Max Schrems ruling on data protection of late.  We therefore need a jurisdiction at European level that reacts quickly and makes good, excellent, high-quality judgments. The European Parliament is trying to save a murky Council decision here. Yes, we need more judges, as we in the European Parliament know. But whether there should be 28 more? This is to be reviewed as soon as possible in the revision clause, which we are clearly calling for.  And I would like to remind you of the example of gender parity. The European Court of Justice can play a pioneering role here. There are so many excellent, excellent judges, and this could really be a positive example to all the European institutions.

name: Diane James (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, when even the rapporteur is highly critical of his proposal, then – to use a parody – ‘Houston, we have a problem’. Well, fellow MEPs, we have a serious problem. Even the rapporteur cannot sell this proposal to us. Just consider a selection of his comments: ‘it shows a deep contempt for taxpayers’ money’; ‘no sense for the European Union to increase spending so frivolously’; ‘this legislative initiative clearly lacks transparency, both internally and externally’; ‘there has not even been a cost-benefit analysis or any impact assessment’. He ends by calling for rejection of the proposal. The rapporteur’s comments are robust, justified, and should be followed. Rejection is the only course of action and this Chamber should follow his recommendations, otherwise why in the hell do we have rapporteurs?

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, William Gladstone said that late justice is a null justice. That is why I welcome the Council's proposal to increase the number of judges at the Court of Justice of the European Union. The State must be the guarantor of the independence, impartiality and authority of the court, but at the same time it is obliged to create mechanisms that allow real access to justice.  The European Union must always be concerned about the image of justice in the long term. A fair assessment of developments is needed to enable the organisation of the means and modalities of the courts to be adapted. They must face the challenges given not only by increasing the number of Member States, but also by a considerable increase in the volume of cases in recent years, which has led to an unacceptable increase in their resolution time. I therefore consider that the act of justice must be carried out within a reasonable time, since an ineffective justice can cause negative long-term economic effects.

name: Jytte Guteland (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for There is no doubt that more judges are needed on the Court of Justice. The number of cases which the General Court was able to decide is far fewer than those brought, which leads to both delays and legal uncertainty and, by extension, to price. Let me be clear, however, that the way in which the Council chooses to do so is, of course, childish. Probably it is to offend children to call it childish, because they would certainly find a better model.  However, we are now in a position to move forward on this matter if we want to take responsibility for legal certainty. Parliament therefore sees no choice but to move forward, but in exchange we must make sure that we demand ours, demand an equal court. Today we see that the proportion of women in the General Court is only 21%, and in the European Court of Justice only 18%. It is bad for all the competent women who would do a good job in court.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I have subscribed to this point because I have been Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic for five years and have dealt with the professional burden on the courts, and I must say that I find this proposal completely absurd. Commissioner, doubling the number of judges without a serious analysis of the onslaught and the increase in the onslaught on the General Court seems to me to be very irresponsible, and I take this only as a political decision, not a factual decision. I have calculated the onslaught on the General Court we are talking about, the increase is there, but it would be objectively manageable if we increased the number of judges by a maximum of ten. Increasing the number of judges to double is really a political decision, not a substantive one, and we should say it fairly and not mislead our constituents. If we are not able to achieve a serious increase in the number of judges, then it is better, in my opinion, to increase the number of administrative staff and legal assistants.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – The European Union, Madam President, is a union of law. And the guarantee of law lies in the Court of Justice, especially the guarantee of citizens' rights, as the recent judgment on safe harbour has shown. And that is precisely why some questions can be asked: Is slow justice a denied justice? Yes. Does inefficient justice amount to denial of justice? Yes. Can this Parliament remain indefinitely indifferent to the problems of the Functioning of the Court of Justice? No. We've been arguing for four years. A compromise is needed to help the Court become more efficient. That there were other solutions? Yes. Surely, increase the number of attorneys general or even the number of judges, without having to double them; it was a considerable option, but the only possible compromise has been this that has been reached. The best, in this case, cannot be an enemy of good and practically possible. If, moreover, we have a guarantee of gender equality, for the first time in an institutional agreement and, secondly, a review clause, it is an agreement that is worth a vote on.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Madam President, the basic principle of European cooperation is respect for the law. So the European Community was built in the first place as a community of law. A community in which the interpretation and observance of its law was entrusted to its Court of Justice, which by decisions kept the European project alive and opened new avenues for the European course. Both I and other professors of institutions of the European Union, by teaching our students in universities, have had the opportunity to play the role of the Court of Justice in protecting citizens' rights. I support the proposal to strengthen the General Court by increasing the number of judges to 28, i.e. one judge per Member State, in order to strengthen the legitimacy of the Court before the peoples of the Union, to represent all the legal systems of the Member States there on an equal footing and to make the administration of justice effective and rapid.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I was surprised by the contributions of some colleagues, because judging the judiciary on the basis of specific judgments, whether it is therefore good or bad, I do not know whether it is a good way to respect the principle of an impartial and independent judiciary. I think that the proposed reform, or the compromise reached by Parliament in its negotiations with the Council, will not be the answer to the definition of the subject provided to us by the judges of the European Court of Justice. And I will admit that I am very sceptical about my vote tomorrow, because I cannot imagine supporting this reform as it is advocated here, because even the judges of the Court of Justice will certainly not be happy about it.

name: Corina Crețu
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I wish to thank Members very much for their comments. The European Commission will support the compromise between the European Parliament and the Council on the number of judges in the General Court, and I think that the capacity of the Court to hear the cases of citizens quickly and ensure a rapid settlement of disputes and clarification of legal issues is crucial. It is also linked to the previous debate we had here on the reform of electoral systems: it is about trust between the citizens, the population and European institutions. Anyhow, needless to say, the Commission welcomes the solution found to promote gender balance within the Court, as we recognise gender balance as an important value within the European Union.

name: António Marinho e Pinto
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, in the name of truth, no more than 28 judges are needed to resolve any problem in the General Court. These 28 judges are only the result of the Council's inability to appoint the 12 judges needed, according to the court itself, to solve its problems. From April 2014 to October 2014, 12 more judges went from 28 more judges. This is an offence to members' intelligence and is an offence to the intelligence and interests of the citizens of the European Union.  In the name of truth, I say to this Parliament, here and now, that the existing delays are not due to the lack of judges, but to the lack of officials. Commissioner, only one process has been waiting for more than a year to be translated, more than a year waiting to be translated. In 2014, 9 more referenda were appointed and this allowed the resolution of more than 100 cases in a year.  What this Parliament is doing is unconditionally capitulating to a Council diktat, because the Council is not able to appoint judges, a number of judges different from the number of Member States, and so instead of appointing 12, it wants 28 more so that each State has 12 more judges.  In the name of truth, this is an offence to the interests of the citizens of the European Union, it is an offence to taxpayers and it is an offence to this Parliament's role in looking after the genuine interests of European taxpayers - not to spend what is not necessary and this money is not necessary. The alleged existence of claims for damages of more than EUR 27 million needs to be demonstrated as valid. The Court of Human Rights has been demanding more than five years and no case has lasted for more than three years.  Moreover, Commissioner, to approve this reform, every year Parliament, the European Union, will spend more than 20 million euros, that is, every year it will pay for what, even if the number of cases were true, it would only pay once.  In the name of truth, this cannot happen in a democratic European Union that respects the genuine interests of citizens.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, October 28, at 12 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The reform of the Court of Justice of the European Union is dictated by the ever-increasing number of cases to be dealt with. There were less than 600 in 2010, 912 in 2014 and a record 1393 by March 2015. The waiting time for a ruling is currently 4-5 years. It should be borne in mind that the right to receive a judgment within a reasonable time is ensured by Article 47 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and access to justice is the basis of democracy. In this context, it is necessary to strengthen the General Court with more judges so that it can adjudicating effectively. At the end of the envisaged reform, it will consist of 56 judges, two from each Member State. Furthermore, given that the pursuit of equality between women and men is one of the objectives of the Union, I am pleased that we have also succeeded in introducing an amendment that member governments should, as far as possible, ensure equal participation of both sexes in the selection of future judges. The good functioning of the judiciary requires investment. An increase of 28 judges will cost around EUR 13.5 million per year, but compared to, for example, eur 26.8 million, as compensation for delays in several ongoing cases, this is not an excessive price. I consider the compromise reached with the Council to be satisfactory.
